Text

CHAPTER I [Emma Woodhouse]79-emma , handsome , clever , and rich , with [a comfortable home]391-a comfortable home and happy disposition , seemed to unite some of the best blessings of existence ; and had lived nearly twenty - one years in [the world]392-the world with very little to distress or vex [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma was [the youngest of [the two daughters of [a most affectionate , indulgent father]395-a most affectionate , indulgent father]394-the two daughters of a most affectionate , indulgent father]393-the youngest of the two daughters of a most affectionate , indulgent father ; and had , in consequence of [[her]79-emma sister]396-her sister ’s marriage , been [mistress of [[his]395-a most affectionate , indulgent father house]398-his house]397-mistress of his house from a very early period . [[Her]79-emma mother]399-her mother had died too long ago for [her]79-emma to have more than an indistinct remembrance of [her]399-her mother caresses ; and [her]79-emma place had been supplied by [an excellent woman]400-an excellent woman as [governess]401-governess , who had fallen little short of [a mother]402-a mother in affection . Sixteen years had [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor been in [[Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s family]403-mr. woodhouse ’s family , less as [a governess]404-a governess than [a friend]405-a friend , very fond of [both daughters]406-both daughters , but particularly of [Emma]79-emma . Between [them]407-them it was more the intimacy of [sisters]408-sisters . Even before [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor had ceased to hold the nominal office of [governess]401-governess , the mildness of [her]80-miss taylor temper had hardly allowed [her]80-miss taylor to impose any restraint ; and the shadow of authority being now long passed away , [they]407-them had been living together as [friend]410-friend and [friend]410-friend very mutually attached , and [Emma]79-emma doing just what [she]79-emma liked ; highly esteeming [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ’s judgment , but directed chiefly by [her]79-emma own . The real evils , indeed , of [Emma]79-emma ’s situation were the power of having rather too much [her]79-emma own way , and a disposition to think a little too well of [herself]79-emma ; these were the disadvantages which threatened alloy to [her]79-emma many enjoyments . The danger , however , was at present so unperceived , that [they]412-they did not by any means rank as misfortunes with [her]79-emma . Sorrow came — a gentle sorrow — but not at all in the shape of any disagreeable consciousness.—Miss [Taylor]80-miss taylor married . It was [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ’s loss which first brought grief . It was on the wedding - day of [this beloved friend]413-this beloved friend that [Emma]79-emma first sat in mournful thought of any continuance . The wedding over , and [the bride - people]414-the bride - people gone , [[her]79-emma father]415-her father and [herself]79-emma were left to dine together , with no prospect of a third to cheer a long evening . [[Her]79-emma father]415-her father composed [himself]415-her father to sleep after dinner , as usual , and [she]79-emma had then only to sit and think of what [she]79-emma had lost . The event had every promise of happiness for [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was [a man of unexceptionable character , easy fortune , suitable age , and pleasant manners]418-a man of unexceptionable character , easy fortune , suitable age , and pleasant manners ; and there was some satisfaction in considering with what self - denying , generous friendship [she]79-emma had always wished and promoted the match ; but it was a black morning ’s work for [her]79-emma . The want of [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor would be felt every hour of every day . [She]79-emma recalled [her]79-emma past kindness — the kindness , the affection of sixteen years — how [she]79-emma had taught and how [she]79-emma had played with [her]79-emma from five years old — how [she]79-emma had devoted all [her]79-emma powers to attach and amuse [her]79-emma in health — and how nursed [her]79-emma through the various illnesses of childhood . A large debt of gratitude was owing here ; but the intercourse of the last seven years , the equal footing and perfect unreserve which had soon followed [Isabella]83-isabella ’s marriage , on [their]419-their being left to [each other]420-each other , was yet a dearer , tenderer recollection . [She]79-emma had been [a friend]405-a friend and companion such as [few possessed]422-few possessed : intelligent , well - informed , useful , gentle , knowing all the ways of [the family]423-the family , interested in all its concerns , and peculiarly interested in [herself]79-emma , in every pleasure , every scheme of [hers]79-emma — one to whom [she]79-emma could speak every thought as it arose , and who had such an affection for [her]79-emma as could never find fault . How was [she]79-emma to bear the change?—It was true that [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend was going only half a mile from [them]419-their ; but [Emma]79-emma was aware that great must be the difference between [a Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , only half a mile from [them]419-their , and [a Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor in [the house]425-the house ; and with all [her]79-emma advantages , natural and domestic , [she]79-emma was now in great danger of suffering from intellectual solitude . [She]79-emma dearly loved [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , but [he]415-her father was [no companion for [her]79-emma]427-no companion for her . [He]415-her father could not meet [her]79-emma in conversation , rational or playful . The evil of the actual disparity in [their]419-their ages ( and [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse had not married early ) was much increased by [his]415-her father constitution and habits ; for having been [a valetudinarian]428-a valetudinarian all [his]415-her father life , without activity of mind or body , [he]415-her father was [a much older man in ways than in years]429-a much older man in ways than in years ; and though everywhere beloved for the friendliness of [his]415-her father heart and [his]415-her father amiable temper , [his]415-her father talents could not have recommended [him]415-her father at any time . [[Her]79-emma sister]396-her sister , though comparatively but little removed by matrimony , being settled in [London]1-london , only sixteen miles off , was much beyond [her]79-emma daily reach ; and many a long October and November evening must be struggled through at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , before Christmas brought the next visit from [Isabella]83-isabella and [[her]83-isabella husband]431-her husband , and [[their]419-their little children]432-their little children , to fill [the house]425-the house , and give [her]79-emma pleasant society again . [Highbury]3-highbury , [the large and populous village]434-the large and populous village , almost amounting to [a town]435-a town , to which [Hartfield]90-hartfield , in spite of [its]90-hartfield separate lawn , and shrubberies , and name , did really belong , afforded [her]79-emma no equals . [The Woodhouses]436-the woodhouses were first in consequence [there]437-there . [All]438-all looked up to [them]436-the woodhouses . [She]79-emma had many acquaintance in [the place]439-the place , for [[her]79-emma father]415-her father was universally civil , but not one among [them]436-the woodhouses who could be accepted in lieu of [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor for even half a day . It was a melancholy change ; and [Emma]79-emma could not but sigh over it , and wish for impossible things , till [[her]79-emma father]415-her father awoke , and made it necessary to be cheerful . [His]415-her father spirits required support . [He]415-her father was [a nervous man]442-a nervous man , easily depressed ; fond of every body that [he]415-her father was used to , and hating to part with [them]443-them ; hating change of every kind . [Matrimony]85-matrimony , as the origin of change , was always disagreeable ; and [he]415-her father was by no means yet reconciled to [[his]415-her father own daughter]444-his own daughter ’s marrying , nor could ever speak of [her]444-his own daughter but with compassion , though it had been entirely a match of affection , when [he]415-her father was now obliged to part with [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor too ; and from [his]415-her father habits of gentle selfishness , and of being never able to suppose that [other people]445-other people could feel differently from [himself]415-her father , [he]415-her father was very much disposed to think [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor had done as sad a thing for [herself]80-miss taylor as for [them]446-them , and would have been a great deal happier if [she]80-miss taylor had spent all the rest of [her]80-miss taylor life at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . [Emma]79-emma smiled and chatted as cheerfully as [she]79-emma could , to keep [him]415-her father from such thoughts ; but when tea came , it was impossible for [him]415-her father not to say exactly as [he]415-her father had said at dinner , “ [Poor Miss Taylor!—I]3112-poor miss taylor!—i wish [she]80-miss taylor were [here]3113-here again . What a pity it is that [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ever thought of [her]80-miss taylor ! ”[415-her father] “ [I]415-her father can not agree with [you]415-her father , [papa]3114-papa ; [you]415-her father know [I]415-her father can not . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston is such [a good - humoured , pleasant , excellent man]3115-a good - humoured , pleasant , excellent man , that [he]82-mr. weston thoroughly deserves a good wife;—and [you]415-her father would not have had [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor live with [us]3116-we for ever , and bear all [my]415-her father odd humours , when [she]80-miss taylor might have [a house of [her]80-miss taylor own]3117-a house of her own ? ”[415-her father] “ [A house of [her]80-miss taylor own!—But]3118-a house of her own!—but where is the advantage of [a house of [her]80-miss taylor own]3117-a house of her own ? This is three times as large.—And [you]415-her father have never any odd humours , [[my]415-her father dear]3120-my dear . ”[415-her father] “ How often [we]3116-we shall be going to see [them]3121-they , and [they]3121-they coming to see [us!—We]3116-we shall be always meeting ! [We]3116-we must begin ; [we]3116-we must go and pay wedding visit very soon . ”[415-her father] “ [[My]415-her father dear]3120-my dear , how am [I]415-her father to get so far ? [Randalls]97-randalls is such a distance . [I]415-her father could not walk half so far . ”[415-her father] “ No , [papa]3114-papa , [nobody]3124-nobody thought of [your]3114-papa walking . [We]3116-we must go in [the carriage]3125-the carriage , to be sure . ”[415-her father] “ [The carriage]3125-the carriage ! But [James]86-james will not like to put the horses to for such a little way;—and where are the poor horses to be while [we]3116-we are paying [our]3116-we visit ? ”[415-her father] “ [They]3121-they are to be put into [[Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s stable]3127-mr. weston ’s stable , [papa]3114-papa . [You]3114-papa know [we]3116-we have settled all that already . [We]3116-we talked it all over with [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston last night . And as for [James]86-james , [you]3114-papa may be very sure [he]82-mr. weston will always like going to [Randalls]97-randalls , because of [[his]82-mr. weston daughter]3129-his daughter ’s being housemaid [there]437-there . [I]415-her father only doubt whether [he]82-mr. weston will ever take [us]3116-we anywhere else . That was [your]3114-papa doing , [papa]3114-papa . [You]3114-papa got [Hannah]87-hannah [that good place]3132-that good place . [Nobody]3124-nobody thought of [Hannah]87-hannah till [you]3114-papa mentioned [her]87-hannah — [James]86-james is so obliged to [you]3114-papa ! ”[415-her father] “ [I]415-her father am very glad [I]415-her father did think of [her]87-hannah . It was very lucky , for [I]415-her father would not have had [poor James]86-james think [himself]86-james slighted upon any account ; and [I]415-her father am sure [she]87-hannah will make [a very good servant]3134-a very good servant : [she]87-hannah is [a civil , pretty - spoken girl]3135-a civil , pretty - spoken girl ; [I]415-her father have a great opinion of [her]87-hannah . Whenever [I]415-her father see [her]87-hannah , [she]87-hannah always curtseys and asks [me]415-her father how [I]415-her father do , in a very pretty manner ; and when [you]3114-papa have had [her]87-hannah here to do needlework , [I]415-her father observe [she]87-hannah always turns the lock of the door the right way and never bangs it . [I]415-her father am sure [she]87-hannah will be [an excellent servant]3136-an excellent servant ; and it will be a great comfort to poor [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor to have somebody about [her]87-hannah that [she]87-hannah is used to see . Whenever [James]86-james goes over to see [[his]415-her father daughter]3129-his daughter , [you]3114-papa know , [she]87-hannah will be hearing of [us]3138-us . [He]415-her father will be able to tell [her]87-hannah how [we]3138-us all are . ”[415-her father] [Emma]79-emma spared no exertions to maintain this happier flow of ideas , and hoped , by the help of backgammon , to get [[her]79-emma father]415-her father tolerably through the evening , and be attacked by no regrets but [her]79-emma own . The backgammon - table was placed ; but [a visitor immediately afterwards]448-a visitor immediately afterwards walked in and made it unnecessary . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , [a sensible man about seven or eight - and - thirty]449-a sensible man about seven or eight - and - thirty , was not only [a very old and intimate friend of [the family]423-the family]450-a very old and intimate friend of the family , but particularly connected with [it]423-the family , as [the elder brother of [[Isabella]83-isabella ’s husband]453-isabella ’s husband]452-the elder brother of isabella ’s husband . [He]88-mr. knightley lived about a mile from [Highbury]3-highbury , was [a frequent visitor]454-a frequent visitor , and always welcome , and at this time more welcome than usual , as coming directly from [their]455-we mutual connexions in [London]1-london . [He]88-mr. knightley had returned to a late dinner , after some days ’ absence , and now walked up to [Hartfield]90-hartfield to say that all were well in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square . It was a happy circumstance , and animated [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse for some time . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley had a cheerful manner , which always did [him]88-mr. knightley good ; and [his]88-mr. knightley many inquiries after “ poor [Isabella]83-isabella ”[83-isabella] and [[her]83-isabella children]456-her children were answered most satisfactorily . When this was over , [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse gratefully observed , “ It is very kind of [you]88-mr. knightley , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , to come out at this late hour to call upon [us]455-we . [I]81-mr. woodhouse am afraid [you]88-mr. knightley must have had a shocking walk . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ Not at all , [sir]3139-sir . It is a beautiful moonlight night ; and so mild that [I]81-mr. woodhouse must draw back from [your]88-mr. knightley great fire . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ But [you]88-mr. knightley must have found it very damp and dirty . [I]81-mr. woodhouse wish [you]88-mr. knightley may not catch cold . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ Dirty , [sir]3139-sir ! Look at [my]81-mr. woodhouse shoes . Not a speck on them . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ Well ! that is quite surprising , for [we]455-we have had a vast deal of rain here . It rained dreadfully hard for half an hour while [we]455-we were at breakfast . [I]81-mr. woodhouse wanted [them]3141-them to put off the wedding . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ By the bye — [I]81-mr. woodhouse have not wished [you]88-mr. knightley joy . Being pretty well aware of what sort of joy [you]88-mr. knightley must both be feeling , [I]81-mr. woodhouse have been in no hurry with [my]81-mr. woodhouse congratulations ; but [I]81-mr. woodhouse hope it all went off tolerably well . How did [you]88-mr. knightley all behave ? [Who cried most]3142-who cried most ? ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ Ah ! poor [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ! ’ Tis a sad business . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ [Poor Mr.]3143-poor mr. and [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , if [you]88-mr. knightley please ; but [I]81-mr. woodhouse can not possibly say ‘ poor [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor . ’ [I]81-mr. woodhouse have a great regard for [you]88-mr. knightley and [Emma]79-emma ; but when it comes to the question of dependence or independence!—At any rate , it must be better to have only [one to please than two]3144-one to please than two . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ Especially when one of those two is such [a fanciful , troublesome creature]3145-a fanciful , troublesome creature ! ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma playfully . “ That is what [you]88-mr. knightley have in [your]88-mr. knightley head , [I]79-emma know — and what [you]88-mr. knightley would certainly say if [[my]79-emma father]3146-my father were not by . ”[79-emma] “ [I]81-mr. woodhouse believe it is very true , [[my]81-mr. woodhouse dear]3120-my dear , indeed , ”[81-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , with a sigh . “ [I]81-mr. woodhouse am afraid [I]81-mr. woodhouse am sometimes very fanciful and troublesome . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ [[My]88-mr. knightley dearest papa]3148-my dearest papa ! [You]3148-my dearest papa do not think [I]88-mr. knightley could mean [you]3148-my dearest papa , or suppose [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley to mean [you]3148-my dearest papa . What a horrible idea ! [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor has been used to have [two persons to please]3151-two persons to please ; [she]80-miss taylor will now have but one . The chances are that [she]79-emma must be [a gainer]3152-a gainer . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Well , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , willing to let it pass—“you want to hear about the wedding ; and [I]88-mr. knightley shall be happy to tell [you]415-her father , for [we]3153-we all behaved charmingly . Every body was punctual , every body in [their]3151-two persons to please best looks : not a tear , and hardly a long face to be seen . Oh no ; [we]3153-we all felt that [we]3153-we were going to be only half a mile apart , and were sure of meeting every day . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [Dear Emma]79-emma bears every thing so well , ”[415-her father] said [[her]79-emma father]415-her father . “ But , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , [she]80-miss taylor is really very sorry to lose poor [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor , and [I]415-her father am sure [she]80-miss taylor will miss [her]80-miss taylor more than [she]80-miss taylor thinks for . ”[415-her father] [Emma]79-emma turned away [her]79-emma head , divided between tears and smiles . “ It is impossible that [Emma]79-emma should not miss [such a companion]3154-such a companion , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . “ [We]3153-we should not like [her]80-miss taylor so well as [we]3153-we do , [sir]3139-sir , if [we]3153-we could suppose it ; but [she]80-miss taylor knows how much the marriage is to [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ’s advantage ; [she]80-miss taylor knows how very acceptable it must be , at [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ’s time of life , to be settled in [a home of [her]80-miss taylor own]3156-a home of her own , and how important to [her]80-miss taylor to be secure of a comfortable provision , and therefore can not allow [herself]80-miss taylor to feel so much pain as pleasure . [Every friend of [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor]3157-every friend of miss taylor must be glad to have [her]80-miss taylor so happily married . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ And [you]88-mr. knightley have forgotten one matter of joy to [me]79-emma , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , “ and a very considerable one — that [I]79-emma made the match [myself]79-emma . [I]79-emma made the match , [you]88-mr. knightley know , four years ago ; and to have it take place , and be proved in the right , when [so many people]3158-so many people said [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston would never marry again , may comfort [me]79-emma for any thing . ”[79-emma] [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley shook [his]88-mr. knightley head at [her]79-emma . [[Her]79-emma father]415-her father fondly replied , “ Ah ! It is the greatest amusement in [the world]392-the world ! And after such success , [you]79-emma know!—Every body said that [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston would never marry again . Oh dear , no ! [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , who had been [a widower]3163-a widower so long , and who seemed so perfectly comfortable without [a wife]3164-a wife , so constantly occupied either in [his]82-mr. weston business in [town]3165-town or among [[his]82-mr. weston friends]3166-his friends here , always acceptable wherever [he]82-mr. weston went , always cheerful — [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston need not spend a single evening in the year alone if [he]82-mr. weston did not like it . Oh no ! [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston certainly would never marry again . [Some people]3167-some people even talked of a promise to [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife on [her]3168-his wife deathbed , and others of [the son]3169-the son and [the uncle]3170-the uncle not letting [him]82-mr. weston . All manner of solemn nonsense was talked on the subject , but [I]415-her father believed none of it . “[415-her father] Ever since the day — about four years ago — that [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor and [I]0-i met with [him]463-him in [Broadway Lane]6-broadway lane , when , because it began to drizzle , [he]463-him darted away with so much gallantry , and borrowed two umbrellas for [us]464-us from [[Farmer Mitchell]89-farmer mitchell ’s]465-farmer mitchell ’s , [I]0-i made up [my]0-i mind on the subject . [I]0-i planned the match from that hour ; and when such success has blessed [me]0-i in this instance , [dear papa]466-dear papa , [you]466-dear papa can not think that [I]0-i shall leave off match - making . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do not understand what [you]466-dear papa mean by ‘ success , ’ ” said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . “[466-dear papa] Success supposes endeavour . [Your]466-dear papa time has been properly and delicately spent , if [you]466-dear papa have been endeavouring for the last four years to bring about this marriage . A worthy employment for [a young lady]467-a young lady ’s mind ! But if , which [I]0-i rather imagine , [your]466-dear papa making the match , as [you]466-dear papa call it , means only [your]466-dear papa planning it , [your]466-dear papa saying to [yourself]466-dear papa one idle day , ‘ [I]0-i think it would be a very good thing for [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor if [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston were to marry [her]80-miss taylor , ’ and saying it again to [yourself]466-dear papa every now and then afterwards , why do [you]466-dear papa talk of success ? Where is [your]466-dear papa merit ? What are [you]466-dear papa proud of ? [You]466-dear papa made a lucky guess ; and that is all that can be said . ” “[466-dear papa] And have [you]466-dear papa never known the pleasure and triumph of a lucky guess?—I pity you.—I thought [you]466-dear papa cleverer — for , depend upon it a lucky guess is never merely luck . There is always some talent in it . And as to [my]0-i poor word ‘ success , ’ which [you]466-dear papa quarrel with , [I]0-i do not know that [I]0-i am so entirely without any claim to it . [You]466-dear papa have drawn two pretty pictures ; but [I]0-i think there may be a third — a something between the do - nothing and [the do - all]468-the do - all . If [I]0-i had not promoted [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s visits [here]3113-here , and given many little encouragements , and smoothed many little matters , it might not have come to any thing after all . [Poor Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ! [You]466-dear papa like [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [papa,—I]466-dear papa must look about for [a wife]3164-a wife for [him]91-mr. elton . There is nobody in [Highbury]3-highbury who deserves [him]91-mr. elton — and [he]91-mr. elton has been [here]3113-here a whole year , and has fitted up [[his]91-mr. elton house]398-his house so comfortably , that it would be a shame to have [him]91-mr. elton single any longer — and [I]0-i thought when [he]91-mr. elton was joining [their]480-their hands to - day , [he]91-mr. elton looked so very much as if [he]91-mr. elton would like to have the same kind office done for [him]91-mr. elton ! Depend upon it , [a man of six or seven - and - twenty]488-a man of six or seven - and - twenty can take care of [himself]91-mr. elton . ” CHAPTER II [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was [a native of [Highbury]3-highbury]3171-a native of highbury , and born of [a respectable family , which for the last two or three generations had been rising into gentility and property]3172-a respectable family , which for the last two or three generations had been rising into gentility and property . [He]82-mr. weston had received a good education , but , on succeeding early in life to a small independence , had become indisposed for any of the more homely pursuits in which [[his]82-mr. weston brothers]3173-his brothers were engaged , and had satisfied an active , cheerful mind and social temper by entering into [the militia of [[his]82-mr. weston county]3175-his county]3174-the militia of his county , then embodied . [Captain Weston]92-captain weston was [a general favourite]3176-a general favourite ; and when the chances of [his]92-captain weston military life had introduced [him]92-captain weston to [Miss Churchill]93-miss churchill , of [a great Yorkshire family]3177-a great yorkshire family , and [Miss Churchill]93-miss churchill fell in love with [him]92-captain weston , [nobody]3124-nobody was surprized , except [[her]93-miss churchill brother]3179-her brother and [[his]3179-her brother wife]3168-his wife , who had never seen [him]3179-her brother , and who were full of pride and importance , which the connexion would offend . [Miss Churchill]93-miss churchill , however , being of age , and with the full command of [her]93-miss churchill fortune — though [her]93-miss churchill fortune bore no proportion to [the family]423-the family - estate — was not to be dissuaded from the marriage , and it took place , to the infinite mortification of [Mr.]3182-mr. and [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill , who threw [her]93-miss churchill off with due decorum . It was an unsuitable connexion , and did not produce much happiness . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ought to have found more in it , for [she]84-mrs. weston had [a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper]3183-a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper made [him]3183-a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper think every thing due to [her]84-mrs. weston in return for the great goodness of being in love with [him]3183-a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper ; but though [she]84-mrs. weston had one sort of spirit , [she]84-mrs. weston had not the best . [She]84-mrs. weston had resolution enough to pursue [her]84-mrs. weston own will in spite of [[her]84-mrs. weston brother]3179-her brother , but not enough to refrain from unreasonable regrets at [that brother]3185-that brother ’s unreasonable anger , nor from missing the luxuries of [[her]84-mrs. weston former home]3186-her former home . [They]3187-they lived beyond [their]3187-they income , but still it was nothing in comparison of [Enscombe]7-enscombe : [she]84-mrs. weston did not cease to love [[her]84-mrs. weston husband]431-her husband , but [she]84-mrs. weston wanted at once to be [the wife of [Captain Weston]92-captain weston , and [Miss Churchill]93-miss churchill of [Enscombe]7-enscombe]3189-the wife of captain weston , and miss churchill of enscombe . [Captain Weston]92-captain weston , who had been considered , especially by [the Churchills]96-the churchills , as making such an amazing match , was proved to have much the worst of the bargain ; for when [[his]92-captain weston wife]3168-his wife died , after a three years ’ marriage , [he]92-captain weston was rather [a poorer man than at first]3191-a poorer man than at first , and with [a child to maintain]3192-a child to maintain . From the expense of [the child]3193-the child , however , [he]92-captain weston was soon relieved . [The boy]3194-the boy had , with the additional softening claim of a lingering illness of [[his]3194-the boy mother]3195-his mother ’s , been the means of a sort of reconciliation ; and [Mr.]3196-mr. and [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill , having [no children of [their]3198-their own]3197-no children of their own , nor [any other young creature of equal kindred to care for]3199-any other young creature of equal kindred to care for , offered to take the whole charge of [the little Frank]3200-the little frank soon after [her]3168-his wife decease . Some scruples and some reluctance [the widower - father]3201-the widower - father may be supposed to have felt ; but as [they]3198-their were overcome by other considerations , [the child]3193-the child was given up to the care and the wealth of [the Churchills]96-the churchills , and [he]3193-the child had only [his]3193-the child own comfort to seek , and [his]3193-the child own situation to improve as [he]3193-the child could . A complete change of life became desirable . [He]3193-the child quitted [the militia]3203-the militia and engaged in trade , having [brothers]3204-brothers already established in a good way in [London]1-london , which afforded [him]3193-the child a favourable opening . It was a concern which brought just employment enough . [He]3193-the child had still [a small house in [Highbury]3-highbury]3205-a small house in highbury , where most of [his]3193-the child leisure days were spent ; and between useful occupation and the pleasures of society , the next eighteen or twenty years of [his]3193-the child life passed cheerfully away . [He]3193-the child had , by that time , realised an easy competence — enough to secure the purchase of [a little estate adjoining [Highbury]3-highbury , which [he]3193-the child had always longed for]3206-a little estate adjoining highbury , which he had always longed for — enough to marry [a woman]3207-a woman as portionless even as [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor , and to live according to the wishes of [his]3193-the child own friendly and social disposition . It was now some time since [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor had begun to influence [his]3193-the child schemes ; but as it was not the tyrannic influence of youth on youth , it had not shaken [his]3193-the child determination of never settling till [he]3193-the child could purchase [Randalls]97-randalls , and the sale of [Randalls]97-randalls was long looked forward to ; but [he]3193-the child had gone steadily on , with these objects in view , till they were accomplished . [He]3193-the child had made [his]3193-the child fortune , bought [[his]3193-the child house]398-his house , and obtained [[his]3193-the child wife]3168-his wife ; and was beginning a new period of existence , with every probability of greater happiness than in any yet passed through . [He]3193-the child had never been [an unhappy man]3210-an unhappy man ; [his]3193-the child own temper had secured [him]3193-the child from that , even in [his]3193-the child first marriage ; but [his]3193-the child second must shew [him]3193-the child how delightful [a well - judging and truly amiable woman]3211-a well - judging and truly amiable woman could be , and must give [him]3193-the child the pleasantest proof of its being a great deal better to choose than to be chosen , to excite gratitude than to feel it . [He]3193-the child had only [himself]3193-the child to please in [his]3193-the child choice : [his]3193-the child fortune was [his]3193-the child own ; for as to [Frank]98-frank churchill , it was more than being tacitly brought up as [[his]3193-the child uncle]3212-his uncle ’s heir , it had become so avowed an adoption as to have [him]3193-the child assume the name of [Churchill]98-frank churchill on coming of age . It was most unlikely , therefore , that [he]3193-the child should ever want [[his]3193-the child father]3213-his father ’s assistance . [[His]3193-the child father]3213-his father had no apprehension of it . [The aunt]3215-the aunt was [a capricious woman]3216-a capricious woman , and governed [[her]3215-the aunt husband]431-her husband entirely ; but it was not in [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s nature to imagine that any caprice could be strong enough to affect one so dear , and , as [he]3213-his father believed , so deservedly dear . [He]3213-his father saw [[his]3213-his father son]3218-his son every year in [London]1-london , and was proud of [him]3218-his son ; and [his]3213-his father fond report of [him]3218-his son as [a very fine young man]3219-a very fine young man had made [Highbury]3-highbury feel a sort of pride in [him]3218-his son too . [He]3218-his son was looked on as sufficiently belonging to [the place]439-the place to make [his]3218-his son merits and prospects a kind of common concern . [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill was one of [the boasts of [Highbury]3-highbury]3221-the boasts of highbury , and a lively curiosity to see [him]98-frank churchill prevailed , though the compliment was so little returned that [he]3218-his son had never been there in [his]3218-his son life . [His]98-frank churchill coming to visit [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father had been often talked of but never achieved . Now , upon [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father ’s marriage , it was very generally proposed , as a most proper attention , that the visit should take place . There was not a dissentient voice on the subject , either when [Mrs. Perry]100-mrs. perry drank tea with [Mrs.]3224-mrs. and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , or when [Mrs.]3225-mrs. and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates returned the visit . Now was the time for [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill to come among [them]3226-them ; and the hope strengthened when it was understood that [he]98-frank churchill had written to [[his]98-frank churchill new mother]3227-his new mother on the occasion . For a few days , every morning visit in [Highbury]3-highbury included some mention of the handsome letter [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston had received . “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [you]489-you have heard of the handsome letter [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill has written to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ? [I]0-i understand it was a very handsome letter , indeed . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse told [me]0-i of it . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse saw the letter , and [he]81-mr. woodhouse says [he]81-mr. woodhouse never saw such a handsome letter in [his]81-mr. woodhouse life . ” It was , indeed , a highly prized letter . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston had , of course , formed a very favourable idea of [the young man]3228-the young man ; and such a pleasing attention was an irresistible proof of [his]3228-the young man great good sense , and a most welcome addition to every source and every expression of congratulation which [her]84-mrs. weston marriage had already secured . [She]84-mrs. weston felt [herself]84-mrs. weston [a most fortunate woman]3229-a most fortunate woman ; and [she]84-mrs. weston had lived long enough to know how fortunate [she]84-mrs. weston might well be thought , where the only regret was for a partial separation from [friends]3230-friends whose friendship for [her]84-mrs. weston had never cooled , and who could ill bear to part with [her]84-mrs. weston . [She]84-mrs. weston knew that at times [she]84-mrs. weston must be missed ; and could not think , without pain , of [Emma]79-emma ’s losing a single pleasure , or suffering an hour ’s ennui , from the want of [her]79-emma companionableness : but [dear Emma]79-emma was of no feeble character ; [she]79-emma was more equal to [her]79-emma situation than [most girls]3231-most girls would have been , and had sense , and energy , and spirits that might be hoped would bear [her]79-emma well and happily through its little difficulties and privations . And then there was such comfort in the very easy distance of [Randalls]97-randalls from [Hartfield]90-hartfield , so convenient for even solitary female walking , and in [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s disposition and circumstances , which would make the approaching season no hindrance to [their]97-randalls spending half the evenings in the week together . [Her]79-emma situation was altogether the subject of hours of gratitude to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , and of moments only of regret ; and [her]79-emma satisfaction — [her]79-emma more than satisfaction — [her]79-emma cheerful enjoyment , was so just and so apparent , that [Emma]79-emma , well as [she]79-emma knew [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , was sometimes taken by surprize at [his]415-her father being still able to pity ‘ poor [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor , ’ when [they]97-randalls left [her]79-emma at [Randalls]97-randalls in the centre of every domestic comfort , or saw [her]79-emma go away in the evening attended by [[her]79-emma pleasant husband]3233-her pleasant husband to [a carriage of [her]79-emma own]3234-a carriage of her own . But never did [she]79-emma go without [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s giving a gentle sigh , and saying , “[81-mr. woodhouse] Ah , poor [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ! [She]80-miss taylor would be very glad to stay . ” There was no recovering [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor — nor much likelihood of ceasing to pity [her]80-miss taylor ; but a few weeks brought some alleviation to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse . The compliments of [[his]81-mr. woodhouse neighbours]3235-his neighbours were over ; [he]81-mr. woodhouse was no longer teased by being wished joy of so sorrowful an event ; and the wedding - cake , which had been a great distress to [him]81-mr. woodhouse , was all eat up . [His]81-mr. woodhouse own stomach could bear nothing rich , and [he]81-mr. woodhouse could never believe [other people]445-other people to be different from [himself]81-mr. woodhouse . What was unwholesome to [him]81-mr. woodhouse [he]81-mr. woodhouse regarded as unfit for any body ; and [he]81-mr. woodhouse had , therefore , earnestly tried to dissuade [them]3235-his neighbours from having any wedding - cake at all , and when that proved vain , as earnestly tried to prevent any body ’s eating it . [He]81-mr. woodhouse had been at the pains of consulting [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry , [the apothecary]3237-the apothecary , on the subject . [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry was [an intelligent , gentlemanlike man]3238-an intelligent , gentlemanlike man , whose frequent visits were one of the comforts of [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s life ; and upon being applied to , [he]81-mr. woodhouse could not but acknowledge ( though it seemed rather against the bias of inclination ) that wedding - cake might certainly disagree with [many]3239-many — perhaps with [most people]3240-most people , unless taken moderately . With such an opinion , in confirmation of [his]81-mr. woodhouse own , [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse hoped to influence [every visitor of [the newly married pair]3242-the newly married pair]3241-every visitor of the newly married pair ; but still the cake was eaten ; and there was no rest for [his]81-mr. woodhouse benevolent nerves till it was all gone . There was a strange rumour in [Highbury]3-highbury of all [the little Perrys]103-the little perrys being seen with a slice of [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s wedding - cake in [their]3235-his neighbours hands : but [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse would never believe it . [CHAPTER III Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was fond of society in [his]81-mr. woodhouse own way . [He]81-mr. woodhouse liked very much to have [[his]81-mr. woodhouse friends]3166-his friends come and see [him]81-mr. woodhouse ; and from various united causes , from [[his]81-mr. woodhouse long residence at [Hartfield]90-hartfield]3244-his long residence at hartfield , and [his]81-mr. woodhouse good nature , from [his]81-mr. woodhouse fortune , [[his]81-mr. woodhouse house]398-his house , and [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter , [he]81-mr. woodhouse could command the visits of [[his]81-mr. woodhouse own little circle]3247-his own little circle , in a great measure , as [he]81-mr. woodhouse liked . [He]81-mr. woodhouse had not much intercourse with [any families beyond that circle]3248-any families beyond that circle ; [his]81-mr. woodhouse horror of late hours , and large dinner - parties , made [him]81-mr. woodhouse unfit for any acquaintance but such as would visit [him]81-mr. woodhouse on [his]81-mr. woodhouse own terms . Fortunately for [him]81-mr. woodhouse , [Highbury]3-highbury , including [Randalls]97-randalls in [the same parish]3249-the same parish , and [Donwell Abbey]202-donwell in [the parish]3250-the parish adjoining , [the seat of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley]3251-the seat of mr. knightley , comprehended many such . Not unfrequently , through [Emma]79-emma ’s persuasion , [he]81-mr. woodhouse had some of the chosen and the best to dine with [him]81-mr. woodhouse : but evening parties were what [he]81-mr. woodhouse preferred ; and , unless [he]81-mr. woodhouse fancied [himself]81-mr. woodhouse at any time unequal to company , there was scarcely an evening in the week in which [Emma]79-emma could not make up a card - table for [him]81-mr. woodhouse . Real , long - standing regard brought [the Westons]104-the westons and [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ; and by [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [a young man living alone]3252-a young man living alone without liking it , the privilege of exchanging any vacant evening of [his]91-mr. elton own blank solitude for the elegancies and society of [[Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s drawing - room]3253-mr. woodhouse ’s drawing - room , and the smiles of [[his]81-mr. woodhouse lovely daughter]3254-his lovely daughter , was in no danger of being thrown away . After these came a second set ; among the most come - at - able of whom were [Mrs.]3255-mrs. and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , and [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard , [three ladies almost always at the service of an invitation from [Hartfield]90-hartfield]3256-three ladies almost always at the service of an invitation from hartfield , and [who were fetched and carried]3257-who were fetched and carried [home]3258-home so often , that [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse thought it no hardship for either [James]86-james or the horses . Had it taken place only once a year , it would have been a grievance . [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates , [the widow of [a former vicar of [Highbury]3-highbury]3260-a former vicar of highbury]3259-the widow of a former vicar of highbury , was [a very old lady , almost past every thing but tea and quadrille]3261-a very old lady , almost past every thing but tea and quadrille . [She]106-mrs. bates lived with [[her]106-mrs. bates single daughter]3262-her single daughter in a very small way , and was considered with all the regard and respect which [a harmless old lady]3263-a harmless old lady , under such untoward circumstances , can excite . [[Her]106-mrs. bates daughter]3264-her daughter enjoyed a most uncommon degree of popularity for [a woman neither young , handsome , rich , nor married]3265-a woman neither young , handsome , rich , nor married . [Miss Bates]101-miss bates stood in the very worst predicament in [the world]392-the world for having much of the public favour ; and [she]101-miss bates had no intellectual superiority to make atonement to [herself]101-miss bates , or frighten those who might hate [her]101-miss bates into outward respect . [She]101-miss bates had never boasted either beauty or cleverness . [Her]101-miss bates youth had passed without distinction , and [her]101-miss bates middle of life was devoted to the care of [a failing mother]3267-a failing mother , and the endeavour to make a small income go as far as possible . And yet [she]101-miss bates was [a happy woman]3268-a happy woman , and [a woman whom no one named without good - will]3269-a woman whom no one named without good - will . It was [her]101-miss bates own universal good - will and contented temper which worked such wonders . [She]101-miss bates loved every body , was interested in every body ’s happiness , quicksighted to [every body]3270-every body ’s merits ; thought [herself]101-miss bates [a most fortunate creature]3271-a most fortunate creature , and surrounded with blessings in such [an excellent mother]3272-an excellent mother , and so many [good neighbours]3273-good neighbours and [friends]3230-friends , and [a home that wanted for nothing]3275-a home that wanted for nothing . The simplicity and cheerfulness of [her]101-miss bates nature , [her]101-miss bates contented and grateful spirit , were a recommendation to every body , and a mine of felicity to [herself]101-miss bates . [She]101-miss bates was [a great talker]3276-a great talker upon little matters , which exactly suited [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , full of trivial communications and harmless gossip . [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard was [the mistress of [a School]3278-a school]3277-the mistress of a school — not of [a seminary]3279-a seminary , or an establishment , or any thing which professed , in long sentences of refined nonsense , to combine liberal acquirements with elegant morality , upon new principles and new systems — and where [young ladies]3280-young ladies for enormous pay might be screwed out of health and into vanity — but [a real , honest , old - fashioned Boarding - school]3281-a real , honest , old - fashioned boarding - school , where a reasonable quantity of accomplishments were sold at a reasonable price , and where [girls]3282-girls might be sent to be out of the way , and scramble [themselves]3282-girls into a little education , without any danger of coming back prodigies . [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s school]3283-mrs. goddard ’s school was in high repute — and very deservedly ; for [Highbury]3-highbury was reckoned [a particularly healthy spot]3284-a particularly healthy spot : [she]101-miss bates had [an ample house and garden]3285-an ample house and garden , gave [the children]3286-the children plenty of wholesome food , let [them]3286-the children run about a great deal in the summer , and in winter dressed [their]3286-the children chilblains with [her]101-miss bates own hands . It was no wonder that [a train of twenty young couple]3287-a train of twenty young couple now walked after [her]101-miss bates to [church]3288-church . [She]101-miss bates was [a plain , motherly kind of woman , who had worked hard in [her]101-miss bates youth]3289-a plain , motherly kind of woman , who had worked hard in her youth , and now thought [herself]101-miss bates [entitled to the occasional holiday of a tea - visit]3290-entitled to the occasional holiday of a tea - visit ; and having formerly owed much to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s kindness , felt [his]81-mr. woodhouse particular claim on [her]101-miss bates to leave [[her]101-miss bates neat parlour]3291-her neat parlour , hung round with fancy - work , whenever [she]101-miss bates could , and win or lose a few sixpences by [his]81-mr. woodhouse fireside . These were the ladies whom [Emma]79-emma found [herself]79-emma very frequently able to collect ; and happy was [she]79-emma , for [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s sake , in the power ; though , as far as [she]79-emma was [herself]79-emma concerned , it was no remedy for the absence of [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . [She]79-emma was delighted to see [[her]79-emma father]415-her father look comfortable , and very much pleased with [herself]79-emma for contriving things so well ; but the quiet prosings of [three such women]3294-three such women made [her]79-emma feel that every evening so spent was indeed one of the long evenings [she]79-emma had fearfully anticipated . As [she]79-emma sat one morning , looking forward to exactly such a close of the present day , a note was brought from [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard , requesting , in most respectful terms , to be allowed to bring [Miss Smith]107-harriet with [her]79-emma ; a most welcome request : for [Miss Smith]107-harriet was [a girl of seventeen]3295-a girl of seventeen , whom [Emma]79-emma knew very well by sight , and had long felt an interest in , on account of [her]107-harriet beauty . A very gracious invitation was returned , and the evening no longer dreaded by [the fair mistress of [the mansion]3297-the mansion]3296-the fair mistress of the mansion . [Harriet Smith]107-harriet was [the natural daughter of [somebody]3299-somebody]3298-the natural daughter of somebody . [Somebody]3299-somebody had placed [her]107-harriet , several years back , at [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s school]3283-mrs. goddard ’s school , and [somebody]3299-somebody had lately raised [her]107-harriet from the condition of [scholar]3303-scholar to that of [parlour - boarder]3304-parlour - boarder . This was all that was generally known of [her]107-harriet history . [She]107-harriet had [no visible friends]3305-no visible friends but what had been acquired at [Highbury]3-highbury , and was now just returned from a long visit in [the country]3306-the country to [some young ladies who had been at [school]3308-school [there]437-there with [her]107-harriet]3307-some young ladies who had been at school there with her . [She]107-harriet was [a very pretty girl]3310-a very pretty girl , and [her]107-harriet beauty happened to be of a sort which [Emma]79-emma particularly admired . [She]107-harriet was short , plump , and fair , with a fine bloom , blue eyes , light hair , regular features , and a look of great sweetness , and , before the end of the evening , [Emma]79-emma was as much pleased with [her]79-emma manners as [[her]79-emma person]3311-her person , and quite determined to continue the acquaintance . [She]79-emma was not struck by any thing remarkably clever in [Miss Smith]107-harriet ’s conversation , but [she]79-emma found [her]107-harriet altogether very engaging — not inconveniently shy , not unwilling to talk — and yet so far from pushing , [shewing]3312-shewing so proper and becoming a deference , seeming so pleasantly grateful for being admitted to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , and so artlessly impressed by the appearance of every thing in so superior a style to what [she]79-emma had been used to , that [she]79-emma must have good sense , and deserve encouragement . Encouragement should be given . Those soft blue eyes , and all those natural graces , should not be wasted on the inferior society of [Highbury]3-highbury and [its]3-highbury connexions . The acquaintance [she]79-emma had already formed were unworthy of [her]79-emma . [The friends from whom [she]79-emma had just parted , though [very good sort of people]3314-very good sort of people]3313-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people , must be doing [her]79-emma harm . [They]3313-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people were [a family of the name of [Martin]108-elizabeth , whom [Emma]79-emma well knew by character , as renting [a large farm of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley]3316-a large farm of mr. knightley , and residing in [the parish of [Donwell]202-donwell]3317-the parish of donwell]3315-a family of the name of martin , whom emma well knew by character , as renting a large farm of mr. knightley , and residing in the parish of donwell — very creditably , [she]79-emma believed — [she]79-emma knew [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley thought highly of [them]3313-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people — but [they]3313-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people must be coarse and unpolished , and very unfit to be the intimates of [a girl who wanted only a little more knowledge and elegance to be quite perfect]3318-a girl who wanted only a little more knowledge and elegance to be quite perfect . [She]79-emma would notice [her]79-emma ; [she]79-emma would improve [her]79-emma ; [she]79-emma would detach [her]79-emma from [her]79-emma bad acquaintance , and introduce [her]79-emma into good society ; [she]79-emma would form [her]79-emma opinions and [her]79-emma manners . It would be an interesting , and certainly a very kind undertaking ; highly becoming [her]79-emma own situation in life , [her]79-emma leisure , and powers . [She]79-emma was so busy in admiring those soft blue eyes , in talking and listening , and forming all these schemes in the in - betweens , that the evening flew away at a very unusual rate ; and the supper - table , which always closed such parties , and for which [she]79-emma had been used to sit and watch the due time , was all set out and ready , and moved forwards to the fire , before [she]79-emma was aware . With an alacrity beyond the common impulse of [a spirit which yet was never indifferent to the credit of doing every thing well and attentively , with the real good - will of a mind delighted with its own ideas]3319-a spirit which yet was never indifferent to the credit of doing every thing well and attentively , with the real good - will of a mind delighted with its own ideas , did [she]79-emma then do all the honours of the meal , and help and recommend the minced chicken and scalloped oysters , with an urgency which [she]79-emma knew would be acceptable to the early hours and civil scruples of [[their]3320-their guests]3321-their guests . Upon such occasions poor [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s feelings were in sad warfare . [He]81-mr. woodhouse loved to have the cloth laid , because it had been the fashion of [his]81-mr. woodhouse youth , but [his]81-mr. woodhouse conviction of suppers being very unwholesome made [him]81-mr. woodhouse rather sorry to see any thing put on it ; and while [his]81-mr. woodhouse hospitality would have welcomed [[his]81-mr. woodhouse visitors]3322-his visitors to every thing , [his]81-mr. woodhouse care for [their]3322-his visitors health made [him]81-mr. woodhouse grieve that [they]3322-his visitors would eat . Such another small basin of thin gruel as [his]81-mr. woodhouse own was all that [he]81-mr. woodhouse could , with thorough self - approbation , recommend ; though [he]81-mr. woodhouse might constrain [himself]81-mr. woodhouse , while [the ladies]3323-the ladies were comfortably clearing the nicer things , to say : “[80-miss taylor] [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates , let [me]0-i propose [your]106-mrs. bates venturing on one of these eggs . An egg boiled very soft is not unwholesome . [Serle]109-serle understands boiling an egg better than any body . [I]0-i would not recommend an egg boiled by any body else ; but [you]106-mrs. bates need not be afraid , they are very small , [you]106-mrs. bates see — one of [our]490-our small eggs will not hurt [you]106-mrs. bates . [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , let [Emma]79-emma help [you]106-mrs. bates to a little bit of tart — a very little bit . [Ours]490-our are all apple - tarts . [You]106-mrs. bates need not be afraid of unwholesome preserves here . [I]0-i do not advise the custard . [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard , what say [you]106-mrs. bates to half a glass of wine ? A small half - glass , put into a tumbler of water ? [I]0-i do not think it could disagree with [you]106-mrs. bates . ” [Emma]79-emma allowed [[her]79-emma father]415-her father to talk — but supplied [[her]79-emma visitors]3325-her visitors in a much more satisfactory style , and on the present evening had particular pleasure in sending [them]3325-her visitors away happy . The happiness of [Miss Smith]107-harriet was quite equal to [her]79-emma intentions . [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor was so great [a personage in [Highbury]3-highbury]3326-a personage in highbury , that the prospect of the introduction had given as much panic as pleasure ; but [the humble , grateful little girl]3327-the humble , grateful little girl went off with highly gratified feelings , delighted with the affability with which [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor had treated [her]3327-the humble , grateful little girl all the evening , and actually shaken hands with [her]3327-the humble , grateful little girl at last ! CHAPTER IV [Harriet Smith]107-harriet ’s intimacy at [Hartfield]90-hartfield was soon a settled thing . Quick and decided in [her]79-emma ways , [Emma]79-emma lost no time in inviting , encouraging , and telling [her]79-emma to come very often ; and as [their]3328-their acquaintance increased , so did [their]3328-their satisfaction in [each other]420-each other . As [a walking companion]3330-a walking companion , [Emma]79-emma had very early foreseen how useful [she]79-emma might find [her]79-emma . In that respect [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s loss had been important . [[Her]79-emma father]415-her father never went beyond the shrubbery , where two divisions of the ground sufficed [him]415-her father for [his]415-her father long walk , or [his]415-her father short , as the year varied ; and since [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s marriage [her]79-emma exercise had been too much confined . [She]79-emma had ventured once alone to [Randalls]97-randalls , but it was not pleasant ; and [a Harriet Smith]107-harriet , therefore , one whom [she]79-emma could summon at any time to a walk , would be a valuable addition to [her]79-emma privileges . But in every respect , as [she]79-emma saw more of [her]107-harriet , [she]79-emma approved [her]107-harriet , and was confirmed in all [her]107-harriet kind designs . [Harriet]107-harriet certainly was not clever , but [she]107-harriet had a sweet , docile , grateful disposition , was totally free from conceit , and only desiring to be guided by any one [she]107-harriet looked up to . [Her]107-harriet early attachment to [herself]107-harriet was very amiable ; and [her]107-harriet inclination for good company , and power of appreciating what was elegant and clever , [shewed]107-harriet that there was no want of taste , though strength of understanding must not be expected . Altogether [she]107-harriet was quite convinced of [Harriet Smith]107-harriet ’s being exactly [the young friend [she]107-harriet wanted]3332-the young friend she wanted — exactly the something which [[her]107-harriet home]3333-her home required . [Such a friend as [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston]3334-such a friend as mrs. weston was out of the question . Two such could never be granted . Two such [she]107-harriet did not want . It was quite a different sort of thing , a sentiment distinct and independent . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was the object of a regard which had its basis in gratitude and esteem . [Harriet]107-harriet would be loved as one to whom [she]107-harriet could be useful . For [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston there was nothing to be done ; for [Harriet]107-harriet every thing . [Her]107-harriet first attempts at usefulness were in an endeavour to find out who were [the parents]3335-the parents , but [Harriet]107-harriet could not tell . [She]107-harriet was ready to tell every thing in [her]107-harriet power , but on this subject questions were vain . [Emma]79-emma was obliged to fancy what [she]79-emma liked — but [she]79-emma could never believe that in the same situation [she]79-emma should not have discovered the truth . [Harriet]107-harriet had no penetration . [She]107-harriet had been satisfied to hear and believe just what [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard chose to tell [her]107-harriet ; and looked no farther . [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard , and [the teachers]3336-the teachers , and [the girls]3337-the girls and the affairs of [the school]3338-the school in general , formed naturally a great part of the conversation — and but for [her]107-harriet acquaintance with [the Martins of [Abbey - Mill Farm]11-abbey - mill farm]3339-the martins of abbey - mill farm , it must have been the whole . But [the Martins]110-the martins occupied [her]107-harriet thoughts a good deal ; [she]107-harriet had spent two very happy months with [them]110-the martins , and now loved to talk of the pleasures of [her]107-harriet visit , and describe the many comforts and wonders of [the place]439-the place . [Emma]79-emma encouraged [her]107-harriet talkativeness — amused by such a picture of [another set of beings]3341-another set of beings , and enjoying the youthful simplicity which could speak with so much exultation of [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin ’s having “[0-i] [two parlours]491-two parlours , [two very good parlours]492-two very good parlours , indeed ; one of [them]491-two parlours quite as large as [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s drawing - room]493-mrs. goddard ’s drawing - room ; and of [her]105-mrs. goddard having [an upper maid]494-an upper maid who had lived five - and - twenty years with [her]105-mrs. goddard ; and of [their]495-their having eight cows , two of [them]491-two parlours [Alderneys]12-alderneys , and one a little Welch cow , a very pretty little Welch cow indeed ; and of [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin ’s saying as [she]111-mrs. martin was so fond of it , it should be called [her]111-mrs. martin cow ; and of [their]495-their having [a very handsome summer - house in [[their]495-their garden]497-their garden]496-a very handsome summer - house in their garden , where some day next year [they]495-their were all to drink [tea:—a very handsome summer - house , large enough to hold [a dozen people]499-a dozen people]498-tea:—a very handsome summer - house , large enough to hold a dozen people . ” For some time [she]111-mrs. martin was amused , without thinking beyond the immediate cause ; but as [she]111-mrs. martin came to understand [the family]423-the family better , other feelings arose . [She]111-mrs. martin had taken up a wrong idea , fancying it was [a mother]402-a mother and [daughter]3344-daughter , [a son]3345-a son and [[son]3346-son ’s wife]3347-son ’s wife , who all lived together ; but when it appeared that [the Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin , who bore a part in the narrative , and was always mentioned with approbation for [his]112-mr. martin great good - nature in doing something or other , was [a single man]3348-a single man ; that there was no young [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin , [no wife in the case]3349-no wife in the case ; [she]111-mrs. martin did suspect danger to [[her]111-mrs. martin poor little friend]3350-her poor little friend from all this hospitality and kindness , and that , if [she]111-mrs. martin were not taken care of , [she]111-mrs. martin might be required to sink [herself]111-mrs. martin forever . With this inspiriting notion , [her]111-mrs. martin questions increased in number and meaning ; and [she]111-mrs. martin particularly led [Harriet]107-harriet to talk more of [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin , and there was evidently no dislike to it . [Harriet]107-harriet was very ready to speak of the share [he]112-mr. martin had had in [their]3351-their moonlight walks and merry evening games ; and dwelt a good deal upon [his]112-mr. martin being so very good - humoured and obliging . [He]112-mr. martin had gone three miles round one day in order to bring [her]107-harriet some walnuts , because [she]107-harriet had said how fond [she]107-harriet was of them , and in every thing else [he]112-mr. martin was so very obliging . [He]112-mr. martin had [[his]112-mr. martin shepherd ’s son]3352-his shepherd ’s son into [the parlour]3353-the parlour one night on purpose to sing to [her]107-harriet . [She]107-harriet was very fond of singing . [He]112-mr. martin could sing a little [himself]112-mr. martin . [She]107-harriet believed [he]112-mr. martin was very clever , and understood every thing . [He]112-mr. martin had [a very fine flock]3354-a very fine flock , and , while [she]107-harriet was with [them]3354-a very fine flock , [he]112-mr. martin had been bid more for [his]112-mr. martin wool than any body in [the country]3306-the country . [She]107-harriet believed [every body]3270-every body spoke well of [him]112-mr. martin . [[His]112-mr. martin mother]3195-his mother and [sisters]408-sisters were very fond of [him]112-mr. martin . [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin had told [her]107-harriet one day ( and there was a blush as [she]111-mrs. martin said it , ) that it was impossible for any body to be [a better son]3359-a better son , and therefore [she]107-harriet was sure , whenever [he]112-mr. martin married , [he]112-mr. martin would make [a good husband]3360-a good husband . Not that [she]107-harriet wanted [him]112-mr. martin to marry . [She]107-harriet was in no hurry at all . “[111-mrs. martin] Well done , [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin ! ” thought [Emma]79-emma . “[111-mrs. martin] [You]111-mrs. martin know what [you]111-mrs. martin are about . ” “[111-mrs. martin] And when [she]111-mrs. martin had come away , [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin was so very kind as to send [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard a beautiful goose — the finest goose [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard had ever seen . [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard had dressed it on a Sunday , and asked [all the three teachers]500-all the three teachers , [Miss Nash]113-miss nash , and [Miss Prince]114-miss prince , and [Miss Richardson]115-miss richardson , to sup with [her]111-mrs. martin . ” “[115-miss richardson] [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin , [I]0-i suppose , is not [a man of information beyond the line of]501-a man of information beyond the line of [his]112-mr. martin own business ? [He]112-mr. martin does not read ? ” “[112-mr. martin] Oh yes!—that is , no — [I]0-i do not know — but [I]0-i believe [he]112-mr. martin has read a good deal — but not what [you]111-mrs. martin would think any thing of . [He]112-mr. martin reads the Agricultural Reports , and some other books that lay in one of the window seats — but [he]112-mr. martin reads all them to [himself]112-mr. martin . But sometimes of an evening , before [we]502-we went to cards , [he]112-mr. martin would read something aloud out of the Elegant Extracts , very entertaining . And [I]0-i know [he]112-mr. martin has read [the Vicar of [Wakefield]13-wakefield]503-the vicar of wakefield . [He]112-mr. martin never read the Romance of [the Forest]14-the forest , nor [The Children of [the Abbey]505-the abbey]504-the children of the abbey . [He]112-mr. martin had never heard of such books before [I]0-i mentioned them , but [he]112-mr. martin is determined to get them now as soon as ever [he]112-mr. martin can . ” The next question was — “[506-sort of looking man] What [sort of looking man]506-sort of looking man is [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin ? ” “[112-mr. martin] Oh ! not handsome — not at all handsome . [I]0-i thought [him]112-mr. martin very plain at first , but [I]0-i do not think [him]112-mr. martin so plain now . [One]475-one does not , [you]0-i know , after a time . But did [you]0-i never see [him]112-mr. martin ? [He]112-mr. martin is in [Highbury]3-highbury every now and then , and [he]112-mr. martin is sure to ride through every week in [his]112-mr. martin way to [Kingston]15-kingston . [He]112-mr. martin has passed [you]0-i very often . ” “[112-mr. martin] That may be , and [I]0-i may have seen [him]112-mr. martin fifty times , but without having any idea of [his]112-mr. martin name . [A young farmer , whether on horseback or on foot]508-a young farmer , whether on horseback or on foot , is the very last sort of person to raise [my]0-i curiosity . The yeomanry are precisely the order of people with whom [I]0-i feel [I]0-i can have nothing to do . A degree or two lower , and a creditable appearance might interest [me]0-i ; [I]0-i might hope to be useful to [[their]509-their families]510-their families in some way or other . But [a farmer]511-a farmer can need none of [my]0-i help , and is , therefore , in one sense , as much above [my]0-i notice as in every other [he]112-mr. martin is below it . ” “[112-mr. martin] To be sure . Oh yes ! It is not likely [you]0-i should ever have observed [him]112-mr. martin ; but [he]112-mr. martin knows [you]0-i very well indeed — [I]0-i mean by sight . ” “[112-mr. martin] [I]0-i have no doubt of [his]112-mr. martin being [a very respectable young man]512-a very respectable young man . [I]0-i know , indeed , that [he]112-mr. martin is so , and , as such , wish [him]112-mr. martin well . What do [you]0-i imagine [his]112-mr. martin age to be ? ” “[0-i] [He]112-mr. martin was four - and - twenty the 8th of last June , and [my]0-i birthday is the 23rd just a fortnight and a day ’s difference — which is very odd . ” “[0-i] Only four - and - twenty . That is too young to settle . [[His]112-mr. martin mother]3195-his mother is perfectly right not to be in a hurry . [They]514-they seem very comfortable as [they]514-they are , and if [she]3195-his mother were to take any pains to marry [him]112-mr. martin , [she]3195-his mother would probably repent it . Six years hence , if [he]112-mr. martin could meet with [a good sort of young woman in the same rank as [his]112-mr. martin own]515-a good sort of young woman in the same rank as his own , with a little money , it might be very desirable . ” “[80-miss taylor] Six years hence ! [Dear Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , [he]112-mr. martin would be thirty years old ! ” “[112-mr. martin] Well , and that is as early as [most men]516-most men can afford to marry , who are not born to an independence . [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin , [I]0-i imagine , has [his]112-mr. martin fortune entirely to make — cannot be at all beforehand with [the world]392-the world . Whatever money [he]112-mr. martin might come into when [[his]112-mr. martin father]3213-his father died , whatever [his]112-mr. martin share of [the family property]519-the family property , it is , [I]0-i dare say , all afloat , all employed in [his]112-mr. martin stock , and so forth ; and though , with diligence and good luck , [he]112-mr. martin may be rich in time , it is next to impossible that [he]112-mr. martin should have realised any thing yet . ” “[521-no indoors man] To be sure , so it is . But [they]520-they live very comfortably . [They]520-they have [no indoors man]521-no indoors man , else [they]520-they do not want for any thing ; and [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin talks of taking [a boy]522-a boy another year . ” “[111-mrs. martin] [I]0-i wish [you]523-you may not get into a scrape , [Harriet]107-harriet , whenever [he]112-mr. martin does marry;—I mean , as to being acquainted with [[his]112-mr. martin wife]3168-his wife — for though [[his]112-mr. martin sisters]525-his sisters , from a superior education , are not to be altogether objected to , it does not follow that [he]112-mr. martin might marry any body at all fit for [you]523-you to notice . The misfortune of [your]523-you birth ought to make [you]523-you particularly careful as to [[your]523-you associates]526-your associates . There can be no doubt of [your]523-you being [[a gentleman]527-a gentleman ’s daughter]528-a gentleman ’s daughter , and [you]523-you must support [your]523-you claim to [that station]529-that station by every thing within [your]523-you own power , or there will be plenty of people who would take pleasure in degrading [you]523-you . ” “[0-i] Yes , to be sure , [I]0-i suppose there are . But while [I]0-i visit at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , and [you]523-you are so kind to [me]0-i , [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , [I]0-i am not afraid of what [any body]530-any body can do . ” “[523-you] [You]523-you understand the force of influence pretty well , [Harriet]107-harriet ; but [I]0-i would have [you]523-you so firmly established in good society , as to be independent even of [Hartfield]90-hartfield and [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield . [I]0-i want to see [you]523-you permanently well connected , and to that end it will be advisable to have as few odd acquaintance as may be ; and , therefore , [I]0-i say that if [you]523-you should still be in [this country]531-this country when [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin marries , [I]0-i wish [you]523-you may not be drawn in by [your]523-you intimacy with [the sisters]532-the sisters , to be acquainted with [the wife]533-the wife , who will probably be [[some mere farmer]534-some mere farmer ’s daughter]535-some mere farmer ’s daughter , without education . ” “[0-i] To be sure . Yes . Not that [I]0-i think [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin would ever marry [any body but what had had some education — and been very well brought up]536-any body but what had had some education — and been very well brought up . However , [I]0-i do not mean to set up [my]0-i opinion against [yours]523-you — and [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i shall not wish for the acquaintance of [[his]112-mr. martin wife]3168-his wife . [I]0-i shall always have a great regard for [the Miss Martins]110-the martins , especially [Elizabeth]108-elizabeth , and should be very sorry to give [them]110-the martins up , for [they]110-the martins are quite as well educated as [me]0-i . [The young man]3228-the young man had been [the first admirer]3362-the first admirer , but [she]79-emma trusted there was no other hold , and that there would be no serious difficulty , on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s side , to oppose any friendly arrangement of [her]79-emma own . [They]3363-they met [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin the very next day , as [they]3363-they were walking on [the Donwell road]3364-the donwell road . [He]112-mr. martin was on foot , and after looking very respectfully at [her]79-emma , looked with most unfeigned satisfaction at [[her]79-emma companion]3365-her companion . [Emma]79-emma was not sorry to have such an opportunity of survey ; and walking a few yards forward , while [they]3363-they talked together , soon made [her]79-emma quick eye sufficiently acquainted with [Mr. Robert Martin]112-mr. martin . [His]112-mr. martin appearance was very neat , and [he]112-mr. martin looked like [a sensible young man]3366-a sensible young man , but [his]112-mr. martin person had no other advantage ; and when [he]112-mr. martin came to be contrasted with [gentlemen]3367-gentlemen , [she]79-emma thought [he]112-mr. martin must lose all the ground [he]112-mr. martin had gained in [Harriet]107-harriet ’s inclination . [Harriet]107-harriet was not insensible of manner ; [she]107-harriet had voluntarily noticed [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father ’s gentleness with admiration as well as wonder . [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin looked as if [he]112-mr. martin did not know what manner was . [They]539-we remained but a few minutes together , as [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield must not be kept waiting ; and [Harriet]107-harriet then came running to [her]90-hartfield with a smiling face , and in a flutter of spirits , which [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield hoped very soon to compose . “[540-he] Only think of [our]539-we happening to meet him!—How very odd ! It was quite a chance , [he]540-he said , that [he]540-he had not gone round by [Randalls]97-randalls . [He]540-he did not think [we]539-we ever walked [this road]541-this road . [He]540-he thought [we]539-we walked towards [Randalls]97-randalls most days . [He]540-he has not been able to get the Romance of [the Forest]14-the forest yet . [He]540-he was so busy the last time [he]540-he was at [Kingston]15-kingston that [he]540-he quite forgot it , but [he]540-he goes again to - morrow . So very odd [we]539-we should happen to meet ! Well , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , is [he]540-he like what [you]90-hartfield expected ? What do [you]90-hartfield think of [him]540-he ? Do [you]90-hartfield think [him]540-he so very plain ? ” “[90-hartfield] [He]540-he is very plain , undoubtedly — remarkably plain:—but that is nothing compared with [his]540-he entire want of gentility . [I]0-i had no right to expect much , and [I]0-i did not expect much ; but [I]0-i had no idea that [he]540-he could be so very clownish , so totally without air . [I]0-i had imagined [him]540-he , [I]0-i confess , a degree or two nearer gentility . ” “[540-he] To be sure , ” said [Harriet]107-harriet , in a mortified voice , “[540-he] [he]540-he is not so genteel as [real gentlemen]542-real gentlemen . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i think , [Harriet]107-harriet , since [your]107-harriet acquaintance with [us]543-us , [you]107-harriet have been repeatedly in the company of [some such very real gentlemen]544-some such very real gentlemen , that [you]107-harriet must [yourself]107-harriet be struck with the difference in [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin . [I]0-i should be surprized if , after seeing [them]546-them , [you]107-harriet could be in company with [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin again without perceiving [him]112-mr. martin to be [a very inferior creature]547-a very inferior creature — and rather wondering at [yourself]107-harriet for having ever thought [him]112-mr. martin at all agreeable before . Do not [you]107-harriet begin to feel that now ? Were not [you]107-harriet struck ? [I]0-i am sure [you]107-harriet must have been struck by [his]112-mr. martin awkward look and abrupt manner , and the uncouthness of a voice which [I]0-i heard to be wholly unmodulated as [I]0-i stood here . ” “[112-mr. martin] Certainly , [he]112-mr. martin is not like [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [He]112-mr. martin has not such a fine air and way of walking as [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [I]0-i see the difference plain enough . But [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley is so very fine [a man]548-a man ! ” “[88-mr. knightley] [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s air is so remarkably good that it is not fair to compare [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin with [him]88-mr. knightley . [You]107-harriet might not see one in a hundred with [gentleman]549-gentleman so plainly written as in [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . Compare [their]551-them manner of carrying [themselves]551-them ; of walking ; of speaking ; of being silent . [You]107-harriet must see the difference . ” “[107-harriet] Oh yes!—there is a great difference . But [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston is almost [an old man]552-an old man . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston must be between forty and fifty . ” “[82-mr. weston] Which makes [his]82-mr. weston good manners the more valuable . The older [a person]553-a person grows , [Harriet]107-harriet , the more important it is that [their]553-a person manners should not be bad ; the more glaring and disgusting any loudness , or coarseness , or awkwardness becomes . What is passable in youth is detestable in later age . [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin is now awkward and abrupt ; what will [he]112-mr. martin be at [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s time of life ? ” “[112-mr. martin] There is no saying , indeed , ” replied [Harriet]107-harriet rather solemnly . “[112-mr. martin] But there may be pretty good guessing .
