That will be very bad . ” “[112-mr. martin] How much [his]112-mr. martin business engrosses [him]112-mr. martin already is very plain from the circumstance of [his]112-mr. martin forgetting to inquire for the book [you]107-harriet recommended . [He]112-mr. martin was a great deal too full of the market to think of any thing else — which is just as it should be , for [a thriving man]555-a thriving man . What has [he]112-mr. martin to do with books ? And [I]0-i have no doubt that [he]112-mr. martin will thrive , and be [a very rich man]556-a very rich man in time — and [his]112-mr. martin being illiterate and coarse need not disturb [us]557-us . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i wonder [he]112-mr. martin did not remember the book”—was all [Harriet]107-harriet ’s answer , and spoken with a degree of grave displeasure which [Emma]79-emma thought might be safely left to itself . [She]107-harriet , therefore , said no more for some time . [Her]107-harriet next beginning was , “[0-i] In one respect , perhaps , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s manners are superior to [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s or [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s . [They]558-they have more gentleness . They might be more safely held up as a pattern . There is an openness , a quickness , almost a bluntness in [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , which every body likes in [him]82-mr. weston , because there is so much good - humour with it — but that would not do to be copied . Neither would [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s downright , decided , commanding sort of manner , though it suits [him]88-mr. knightley very well ; [his]88-mr. knightley figure , and look , and situation in life seem to allow it ; but if [any young man]559-any young man were to set about copying [him]82-mr. weston , [he]82-mr. weston would not be sufferable . On the contrary , [I]0-i think [a young man]560-a young man might be very safely recommended to take [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton as [a model]561-a model . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton is good - humoured , cheerful , obliging , and gentle . [He]91-mr. elton seems to [me]0-i to be grown particularly gentle of late . [I]0-i do not know whether [he]91-mr. elton has any design of ingratiating [himself]91-mr. elton with either of [us]562-us , [Harriet]107-harriet , by additional softness , but it strikes [me]0-i that [his]91-mr. elton manners are softer than they used to be . If [he]91-mr. elton means any thing , it must be to please [you]107-harriet . Did not [I]0-i tell [you]107-harriet what [he]91-mr. elton said of [you]107-harriet the other day ? ” [She]107-harriet then repeated some warm personal praise which [she]107-harriet had drawn from [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , and now did full justice to ; and [Harriet]107-harriet blushed and smiled , and said [she]107-harriet had always thought [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton very agreeable . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was the very person fixed on by [Emma]79-emma for driving [the young farmer]3369-the young farmer out of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s head . [She]107-harriet thought it would be an excellent match ; and only too palpably desirable , natural , and probable , for [her]107-harriet to have much merit in planning it . [She]107-harriet feared it was what [every body else]3370-every body else must think of and predict . It was not likely , however , that any body should have equalled [her]107-harriet in the date of the plan , as it had entered [her]107-harriet brain during the very first evening of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s coming to [Hartfield]90-hartfield . The longer [she]107-harriet considered it , the greater was [her]107-harriet sense of its expediency . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s situation was most suitable , quite [the gentleman]3371-the gentleman [himself]91-mr. elton , and without low connexions ; at the same time , not of [any family that could fairly object to the doubtful birth of [Harriet]107-harriet]3372-any family that could fairly object to the doubtful birth of harriet . [He]91-mr. elton had [a comfortable home for [her]107-harriet]3373-a comfortable home for her , and [Emma]79-emma imagined a very sufficient income ; for though [the vicarage of Highbury]3374-the vicarage of highbury was not large , [he]91-mr. elton was known to have some independent property ; and [she]107-harriet thought very highly of [him]91-mr. elton as [a good - humoured , well - meaning , respectable young man]3375-a good - humoured , well - meaning , respectable young man , without any deficiency of useful understanding or knowledge of [the world]392-the world . [She]107-harriet had already satisfied [herself]107-harriet that [he]91-mr. elton thought [Harriet]107-harriet [a beautiful girl]3377-a beautiful girl , which [she]107-harriet trusted , with such frequent meetings at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , was foundation enough on [his]91-mr. elton side ; and on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s there could be little doubt that the idea of being preferred by [him]91-mr. elton would have all the usual weight and efficacy . And [he]91-mr. elton was really [a very pleasing young man]3378-a very pleasing young man , [a young man whom [any woman not fastidious]3380-any woman not fastidious might like]3379-a young man whom any woman not fastidious might like . [He]91-mr. elton was reckoned very handsome ; [[his]91-mr. elton person]3381-his person much admired in general , though not by [her]107-harriet , there being a want of elegance of feature which [she]107-harriet could not dispense with:—but [the girl who could be gratified by a [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin ’s riding about [the country]3306-the country to get walnuts for [her]107-harriet]3382-the girl who could be gratified by a robert martin ’s riding about the country to get walnuts for her might very well be conquered by [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s admiration . CHAPTER V “[91-mr. elton] [I]0-i do not know what [your]563-you opinion may be , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , ” said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , “[84-mrs. weston] of this great intimacy between [Emma]79-emma and [Harriet Smith]107-harriet , but [I]0-i think it a bad thing . ” “[0-i] A bad thing ! Do [you]563-you really think it a bad thing?—why so ? ” “[563-you] [I]0-i think [they]564-they will neither of [them]564-they do the other any good . ” “[563-you] [You]563-you surprize [me]0-i ! [Emma]79-emma must do [Harriet]107-harriet good : and by supplying [her]107-harriet with a new object of interest , [Harriet]107-harriet may be said to do [Emma]79-emma good . [I]0-i have been seeing [their]564-they intimacy with the greatest pleasure . How very differently [we]565-we feel!—Not think [they]564-they will do [each other]420-each other any good ! This will certainly be the beginning of one of [our]565-we quarrels about [Emma]79-emma , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . ” “[88-mr. knightley] Perhaps [you]563-you think [I]0-i am come on purpose to quarrel with [you]563-you , knowing [Weston]82-mr. weston to be out , and that [you]563-you must still fight [your]563-you own battle . ” “[82-mr. weston] [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston would undoubtedly support [me]0-i , if [he]82-mr. weston were here , for [he]82-mr. weston thinks exactly as [I]0-i do on the subject . [We]565-we were speaking of it only yesterday , and agreeing how fortunate it was for [Emma]79-emma , that there should be [such a girl in [Highbury]3-highbury]567-such a girl in highbury for [her]79-emma to associate with . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , [I]0-i shall not allow [you]563-you to be [a fair judge in this case]568-a fair judge in this case . [You]563-you are so much used to live alone , that [you]563-you do not know the value of [a companion]569-a companion ; and , perhaps [no man]570-no man can be a good judge of the comfort [a woman]3207-a woman feels in the society of one of [her]3207-a woman own sex , after being used to it all [her]3207-a woman life . [I]0-i can imagine [your]563-you objection to [Harriet Smith]107-harriet . [She]107-harriet is not [the superior young woman which [[Emma]79-emma ’s friend]573-emma ’s friend ought to be]572-the superior young woman which emma ’s friend ought to be . But on the other hand , as [Emma]79-emma wants to see [her]79-emma better informed , it will be an inducement to [her]79-emma to read more [herself]79-emma . [They]574-they will read together . [She]79-emma means it , [I]0-i know . ” “[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma has been meaning to read more ever since [she]79-emma was twelve years old . [I]0-i have seen a great many lists of [her]79-emma drawing - up at various times of books that [she]79-emma meant to read regularly through — and very good lists they were — very well chosen , and very neatly arranged — sometimes alphabetically , and sometimes by some other rule . The list [she]79-emma drew up when only fourteen — [I]0-i remember thinking it did [her]79-emma judgment so much credit , that [I]0-i preserved it some time ; and [I]0-i dare say [she]79-emma may have made out a very good list now . But [I]0-i have done with expecting any course of steady reading from [Emma]79-emma . [She]79-emma will never submit to any thing requiring industry and patience , and a subjection of the fancy to the understanding . Where [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor failed to stimulate , [I]0-i may safely affirm that [Harriet Smith]107-harriet will do nothing.—You never could persuade [her]107-harriet to read half so much as [you]575-you wished.—You know [you]575-you could not . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i dare say , ” replied [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , smiling , “[0-i] that [I]0-i thought so then;—but since [we]576-we have parted , [I]0-i can never remember [Emma]79-emma ’s omitting to do any thing [I]0-i wished . ” “[79-emma] There is hardly any desiring to refresh such a memory as that,”—said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , feelingly ; and for a moment or two [he]0-i had done . “[79-emma] But [I]0-i , ” [he]0-i soon added , “[0-i] who have had no such charm thrown over [my]0-i senses , must still see , hear , and remember . [Emma]79-emma is spoiled by being [the cleverest of [[her]79-emma family]578-her family]577-the cleverest of her family . At ten years old , [she]79-emma had the misfortune of being able to answer questions which puzzled [[her]79-emma sister]396-her sister at seventeen . [She]79-emma was always quick and assured : [Isabella]83-isabella slow and diffident . And ever since [she]79-emma was twelve , [Emma]79-emma has been [mistress of [the house]425-the house]580-mistress of the house and of [you]582-you all . In [[her]79-emma mother]399-her mother [she]79-emma lost [the only person able to cope with [her]79-emma]584-the only person able to cope with her . [She]79-emma inherits [[her]79-emma mother]399-her mother ’s talents , and must have been under subjection to [her]399-her mother . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i should have been sorry , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , to be dependent on [your]88-mr. knightley recommendation , had [I]0-i quitted [[Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s family]403-mr. woodhouse ’s family and wanted another situation ; [I]0-i do not think [you]88-mr. knightley would have spoken a good word for [me]0-i to [any body]530-any body . [I]0-i am sure [you]88-mr. knightley always thought [me]0-i unfit for the office [I]0-i held . ” “[88-mr. knightley] Yes , ” said [he]88-mr. knightley , smiling . “[88-mr. knightley] [You]88-mr. knightley are better placed here ; very fit for [a wife]3164-a wife , but not at all for [a governess]404-a governess . But [you]88-mr. knightley were preparing [yourself]88-mr. knightley to be [an excellent wife]590-an excellent wife all the time [you]88-mr. knightley were at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . [You]88-mr. knightley might not give [Emma]79-emma such a complete education as [your]88-mr. knightley powers would seem to promise ; but [you]88-mr. knightley were receiving a very good education from [her]79-emma , on the very material matrimonial point of submitting [your]88-mr. knightley own will , and doing as [you]88-mr. knightley were bid ; and if [Weston]82-mr. weston had asked [me]0-i to recommend [him]82-mr. weston [a wife]3164-a wife , [I]0-i should certainly have named [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor . ” “[88-mr. knightley] Thank [you]88-mr. knightley . There will be very little merit in making [a good wife]592-a good wife to [such a man]593-such a man as [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston . ” “[592-a good wife] Why , to own the truth , [I]0-i am afraid [you]88-mr. knightley are rather thrown away , and that with every disposition to bear , there will be nothing to be borne . [We]594-we will not despair , however . [Weston]82-mr. weston may grow cross from the wantonness of comfort , or [[his]82-mr. weston son]3218-his son may plague [him]82-mr. weston . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i hope not that.—It is not likely . No , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , do not foretell vexation from that quarter . ” “[0-i] Not [I]0-i , indeed . [I]0-i only name possibilities . [I]0-i do not pretend to [Emma]79-emma ’s genius for foretelling and guessing . [I]0-i hope , with all [my]0-i heart , [the young man]3228-the young man may be a [Weston]82-mr. weston in merit , and a [Churchill]98-frank churchill in fortune.—But [Harriet Smith]107-harriet — [I]0-i have not half done about [Harriet Smith]107-harriet . [I]0-i think [her]107-harriet the very worst sort of companion that [Emma]79-emma could possibly have . [She]79-emma knows nothing [herself]79-emma , and looks upon [Emma]79-emma as knowing every thing . [She]79-emma is a flatterer in all [her]79-emma ways ; and so much the worse , because undesigned . [Her]79-emma ignorance is hourly flattery . How can [Emma]79-emma imagine [she]79-emma has any thing to learn [herself]79-emma , while [Harriet]107-harriet is presenting such a delightful inferiority ? And as for [Harriet]107-harriet , [I]0-i will venture to say that [she]107-harriet can not gain by the acquaintance . [Hartfield]90-hartfield will only put [her]107-harriet out of conceit with [all the other places [she]107-harriet belongs to]597-all the other places she belongs to . [She]107-harriet will grow just refined enough to be uncomfortable with [those among whom birth and circumstances]598-those among whom birth and circumstances have placed [her]107-harriet [home]3258-home . [I]0-i am much mistaken if [Emma]79-emma ’s doctrines give any strength of mind , or tend at all to make [a girl]600-a girl adapt [herself]600-a girl rationally to the varieties of [her]600-a girl situation in life.—They only give a little polish . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i either depend more upon [Emma]79-emma ’s good sense than [you]0-i do , or am more anxious for [her]79-emma present comfort ; for [I]0-i can not lament the acquaintance . How well [she]79-emma looked last night ! ” “[79-emma] Oh ! [you]0-i would rather talk of [her]79-emma person than [her]79-emma mind , would [you]0-i ? Very well ; [I]0-i shall not attempt to deny [Emma]79-emma ’s being pretty . ” “[79-emma] Pretty ! say beautiful rather . Can [you]0-i imagine any thing nearer perfect beauty than [Emma]79-emma altogether — face and figure ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do not know what [I]0-i could imagine , but [I]0-i confess that [I]0-i have seldom seen a face or figure more pleasing to [me]0-i than [hers]79-emma . But [I]0-i am [a partial old friend]601-a partial old friend . ” “[601-a partial old friend] Such an eye!—the true hazle eye — and so brilliant ! regular features , open countenance , with a complexion ! oh ! what a bloom of full health , and such a pretty height and size ; such a firm and upright figure ! There is health , not merely in [her]79-emma bloom , but in [her]79-emma air , [her]79-emma head , [her]79-emma glance . [One]475-one hears sometimes of [a child]603-a child being ‘ the picture of health ; ’ now , [Emma]79-emma always gives [me]0-i the idea of being the complete picture of grown - up health . [She]79-emma is loveliness itself . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , is not [she]79-emma ? ” “[88-mr. knightley] [I]0-i have not a fault to find with [[her]79-emma person]3311-her person , ” [he]0-i replied . “[0-i] [I]0-i think [her]79-emma all [you]0-i describe . [I]0-i love to look at [her]79-emma ; and [I]0-i will add this praise , that [I]0-i do not think [her]79-emma personally vain . Considering how very handsome [she]79-emma is , [she]79-emma appears to be little occupied with it ; [her]79-emma vanity lies another way . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , [I]0-i am not to be talked out of [my]0-i dislike of [Harriet Smith]107-harriet , or [my]0-i dread of its doing [them]605-them both harm . ” “[0-i] And [I]0-i , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , am equally stout in [my]0-i confidence of its not doing [them]605-them any harm . With all dear [Emma]79-emma ’s little faults , [she]79-emma is [an excellent creature]606-an excellent creature . Where shall [we]607-we see [a better daughter]608-a better daughter , or [a kinder sister]609-a kinder sister , or [a truer friend]610-a truer friend ? No , no ; [she]79-emma has qualities which may be trusted ; [she]79-emma will never lead [any one]611-any one really wrong ; [she]79-emma will make no lasting blunder ; where [Emma]79-emma errs once , [she]79-emma is in the right a hundred times . ” “[79-emma] Very well ; [I]0-i will not plague [you]88-mr. knightley any more . [Emma]79-emma shall be [an angel]612-an angel , and [I]0-i will keep [my]0-i spleen to [myself]0-i till [Christmas]116-christmas brings [John]88-mr. knightley and [Isabella]83-isabella . [I]0-i am sure of having [their]3286-the children opinions with [me]0-i . ” “[3286-the children] [I]0-i know that [you]88-mr. knightley all love [her]79-emma really too well to be unjust or unkind ; but excuse [me]0-i , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , if [I]0-i take the liberty ( [I]0-i consider [myself]0-i , [you]88-mr. knightley know , as having somewhat of the privilege of speech that [[Emma]79-emma ’s mother]614-emma ’s mother might have had ) the liberty of hinting that [I]0-i do not think any possible good can arise from [Harriet Smith]107-harriet ’s intimacy being made a matter of much discussion among [you]88-mr. knightley . Pray excuse [me]0-i ; but supposing any little inconvenience may be apprehended from the intimacy , it can not be expected that [Emma]79-emma , accountable to [nobody]3124-nobody but [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , who perfectly approves the acquaintance , should put an end to it , so long as it is a source of pleasure to [herself]79-emma . It has been so many years [my]0-i province to give advice , that [you]88-mr. knightley can not be surprized , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , at this little remains of office . ” “[88-mr. knightley] Not at all , ” cried [he]0-i ; “[88-mr. knightley] [I]0-i am much obliged to [you]88-mr. knightley for it . It is very good advice , and it shall have a better fate than [your]88-mr. knightley advice has often found ; for it shall be attended to . ” “[117-mrs. john knightley] [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley is easily alarmed , and might be made unhappy about [[her]117-mrs. john knightley sister]396-her sister . ” “[117-mrs. john knightley] Be satisfied , ” said [he]0-i , “[117-mrs. john knightley] [I]0-i will not raise any outcry . [I]0-i will keep [my]0-i ill - humour to [myself]0-i . [I]0-i have a very sincere interest in [Emma]79-emma . [Isabella]83-isabella does not seem more [[my]0-i sister]618-my sister ; has never excited a greater interest ; perhaps hardly so great . There is an anxiety , a curiosity in what [one]475-one feels for [Emma]79-emma . [I]0-i wonder what will become of [her]79-emma ! ” “[0-i] So do [I]0-i , ” said [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston gently , “[0-i] very much . ” “[79-emma] [She]79-emma always declares [she]79-emma will never marry , which , of course , means just nothing at all . But [I]0-i have no idea that [she]79-emma has yet ever seen [a man [she]79-emma cared for]620-a man she cared for . It would not be a bad thing for [her]79-emma to be very much in love with a proper object . [I]0-i should like to see [Emma]79-emma in love , and in some doubt of a return ; it would do [her]79-emma good . But there is [nobody]3124-nobody hereabouts to attach [her]79-emma ; and [she]79-emma goes so seldom from [home]3258-home . ” “[3124-nobody] There does , indeed , seem as little to tempt [her]79-emma to break [her]79-emma resolution at present , ” said [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , “[3124-nobody] as can well be ; and while [she]79-emma is so happy at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [I]0-i can not wish [her]79-emma to be forming any attachment which would be creating such difficulties on poor [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s account . [I]0-i do not recommend matrimony at present to [Emma]79-emma , though [I]0-i mean no slight to the state , [I]0-i assure [you]623-you . ” Part of [her]84-mrs. weston meaning was to conceal some favourite thoughts of [her]84-mrs. weston own and [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s on the subject , as much as possible . There were wishes at [Randalls]97-randalls respecting [Emma]79-emma ’s destiny , but it was not desirable to have [them]97-randalls suspected ; and the quiet transition which [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley soon afterwards made to “[0-i] What does [Weston]82-mr. weston think of the weather ; shall [we]624-we have rain ? ” convinced [her]84-mrs. weston that [he]82-mr. weston had nothing more to say or surmise about [Hartfield]90-hartfield . CHAPTER VI [Emma]79-emma could not feel a doubt of having given [Harriet]107-harriet ’s fancy a proper direction and raised the gratitude of [her]79-emma young vanity to a very good purpose , for [she]79-emma found [her]79-emma decidedly more sensible than before of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s being [a remarkably handsome man , with most agreeable manners]3384-a remarkably handsome man , with most agreeable manners ; and as [she]79-emma had no hesitation in following up the assurance of [his]91-mr. elton admiration by agreeable hints , [she]79-emma was soon pretty confident of creating as much liking on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s side , as there could be any occasion for . [She]79-emma was quite convinced of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s being in the fairest way of falling in love , if not in love already . [She]79-emma had no scruple with regard to [him]91-mr. elton . [He]91-mr. elton talked of [Harriet]107-harriet , and praised [her]107-harriet so warmly , that [she]79-emma could not suppose any thing wanting which a little time would not add . [His]91-mr. elton perception of the striking improvement of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s manner , since [her]107-harriet introduction at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , was not one of the least agreeable proofs of [his]91-mr. elton growing attachment . “[82-mr. weston] [You]625-you have given [Miss Smith]107-harriet all that [she]107-harriet required , ” said [he]91-mr. elton ; “[625-you] [you]625-you have made [her]107-harriet graceful and easy . [She]107-harriet was a beautiful creature when [she]107-harriet came to [you]625-you , but , in [my]0-i opinion , the attractions [you]625-you have added are infinitely superior to what [she]107-harriet received from nature . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am glad [you]625-you think [I]0-i have been useful to [her]107-harriet ; but [Harriet]107-harriet only wanted drawing out , and receiving a few , very few hints . [She]107-harriet had all the natural grace of sweetness of temper and artlessness in [herself]107-harriet . [I]0-i have done very little . ” “[0-i] If it were admissible to contradict [a lady]626-a lady , ” said [the gallant Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton — “[0-i] [I]0-i have perhaps given [her]626-a lady a little more decision of character , have taught [her]626-a lady to think on points which had not fallen in [her]626-a lady way before . ” “[0-i] Exactly so ; that is what principally strikes [me]0-i . So much superadded decision of character ! Skilful has been the hand ! ” “[0-i] Great has been the pleasure , [I]0-i am sure . [I]0-i never met with a disposition more truly amiable . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have no doubt of it . ” And it was spoken with a sort of sighing animation , which had a vast deal of [the lover]3385-the lover . [She]107-harriet was not less pleased another day with the manner in which [he]0-i seconded a sudden wish of [hers]107-harriet , to have [Harriet]107-harriet ’s picture . “[0-i] Did [you]0-i ever have [your]0-i likeness taken , [Harriet]107-harriet ? ” said [she]107-harriet : “[0-i] did [you]0-i ever sit for [your]0-i picture ? ” [Harriet]107-harriet was on the point of leaving [the room]3386-the room , and only stopt to say , with a very interesting naïveté , “[0-i] Oh ! dear , no , never . ” No sooner was [she]107-harriet out of sight , than [Emma]79-emma exclaimed , “[0-i] What an exquisite possession a good picture of [her]626-a lady would be ! [I]0-i would give any money for it . [I]0-i almost long to attempt [her]626-a lady likeness [myself]0-i . [You]627-you do not know it [I]0-i dare say , but two or three years ago [I]0-i had a great passion for taking likenesses , and attempted [several of [[my]0-i friends]629-my friends]628-several of my friends , and was thought to have a tolerable eye in general . But from one cause or another , [I]0-i gave it up in disgust . But really , [I]0-i could almost venture , if [Harriet]107-harriet would sit to [me]0-i . It would be such a delight to have [her]626-a lady picture ! ” “[0-i] Let [me]0-i entreat [you]627-you , ” cried [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ; “[0-i] it would indeed be a delight ! Let [me]0-i entreat [you]627-you , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , to exercise so charming a talent in favour of [[your]627-you friend]630-your friend . [I]0-i know what [your]627-you drawings are . How could [you]627-you suppose [me]0-i ignorant ? Is not [this room]631-this room rich in specimens of [your]627-you landscapes and flowers ; and has not [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston some inimitable figure - pieces in [[her]84-mrs. weston drawing - room]632-her drawing - room , at [Randalls]97-randalls ? ” Yes , good man!—thought [Emma]79-emma — but what has all that to do with taking likenesses ? [You]627-you know nothing of drawing . Do n’t pretend to be in raptures about [mine]0-i . Keep [your]627-you raptures for [Harriet]107-harriet ’s face . “[84-mrs. weston] Well , if [you]627-you give [me]0-i such kind encouragement , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [I]0-i believe [I]0-i shall try what [I]0-i can do . [Harriet]107-harriet ’s features are very delicate , which makes a likeness difficult ; and yet there is a peculiarity in the shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth which [one]475-one ought to catch . ” “[475-one] Exactly so — The shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth — [I]0-i have not a doubt of [your]627-you success . Pray , pray attempt it . As [you]627-you will do it , it will indeed , to use [your]627-you own words , be an exquisite possession . ” “[91-mr. elton] But [I]0-i am afraid , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [Harriet]107-harriet will not like to sit . [She]107-harriet thinks so little of [her]107-harriet own beauty . Did not [you]627-you observe [her]107-harriet manner of answering [me]0-i ? How completely it meant , ‘ why should [my]0-i picture be drawn ? ’ ” “[627-you] Oh ! yes , [I]0-i observed it , [I]0-i assure [you]627-you . It was not lost on [me]0-i . But still [I]0-i can not imagine [she]107-harriet would not be persuaded . ” [Harriet]107-harriet was soon back again , and the proposal almost immediately made ; and [she]107-harriet had no scruples which could stand many minutes against the earnest pressing of [both the others]3387-both the others . [Emma]79-emma wished to go to work directly , and therefore produced the portfolio containing [her]79-emma various attempts at portraits , for not one of them had ever been finished , that [they]3387-both the others might decide together on the best size for [Harriet]107-harriet . [Her]107-harriet many beginnings were displayed . Miniatures , half - lengths , whole - lengths , pencil , crayon , and water - colours had been all tried in turn . [She]107-harriet had always wanted to do every thing , and had made more progress both in drawing and music than many might have done with so little labour as [she]107-harriet would ever submit to . [She]107-harriet played and sang;—and drew in almost every style ; but steadiness had always been wanting ; and in nothing had [she]107-harriet approached the degree of excellence which [she]107-harriet would have been glad to command , and ought not to have failed of . [She]107-harriet was not much deceived as to [her]107-harriet own skill either as [an artist]3388-an artist or [a musician]3389-a musician , but [she]107-harriet was not unwilling to have [others]473-others deceived , or sorry to know [her]107-harriet reputation for accomplishment often higher than it deserved . There was merit in every drawing — in the least finished , perhaps the most ; [her]107-harriet style was spirited ; but had there been much less , or had there been ten times more , the delight and admiration of [[her]107-harriet two companions]3391-her two companions would have been the same . [They]3391-her two companions were both in ecstasies . A likeness pleases every body ; and [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield ’s performances must be capital . “[107-harriet] No great variety of faces for [you]634-you , ” said [Emma]79-emma . “[107-harriet] [I]0-i had only [[my]0-i own family]635-my own family to study from . There is [[my]0-i father]3146-my father — [another of [[my]0-i father]3146-my father]637-another of my father — but the idea of sitting for [his]3146-my father picture made [him]3146-my father so nervous , that [I]0-i could only take [him]3146-my father by stealth ; neither of [them]639-them very like therefore . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston again , and again , and again , [you]634-you see . [Dear Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ! always [[my]0-i kindest friend]640-my kindest friend on every occasion . [She]640-my kindest friend would sit whenever [I]0-i asked [her]640-my kindest friend . There is [[my]0-i sister]618-my sister ; and really quite [her]618-my sister own little elegant figure!—and the face not unlike . [I]0-i should have made a good likeness of [her]618-my sister , if [she]618-my sister would have sat longer , but [she]618-my sister was in such a hurry to have [me]0-i draw [[her]618-my sister four children]642-her four children that [she]618-my sister would not be quiet . Then , here come all [my]0-i attempts at three of those four children;—there [they]642-her four children are , [Henry]118-henry and [John]88-mr. knightley and [Bella]83-isabella , from one end of the sheet to the other , and any one of [them]642-her four children might do for any one of the rest . [She]618-my sister was so eager to have [them]642-her four children drawn that [I]0-i could not refuse ; but there is no making [children of three or four years old]643-children of three or four years old stand still [you]644-you know ; nor can it be very easy to take any likeness of [them]643-children of three or four years old , beyond the air and complexion , unless they are coarser featured than any of [[mama]645-mama ’s children]646-mama ’s children ever were . Here is [my]0-i sketch of the fourth , who was [a baby]647-a baby . [I]0-i took [him]647-a baby as [he]647-a baby was sleeping on the sofa , and it is as strong a likeness of [his]647-a baby cockade as [you]644-you would wish to see . [He]647-a baby had nestled down [his]647-a baby head most conveniently . That ’s very like . [I]0-i am rather proud of [little George]119-george . The corner of the sofa is very good . Then here is [my]0-i last,”—unclosing a pretty sketch of [a gentleman in small size , whole - length—“my]3392-a gentleman in small size , whole - length—“my[0-i] last and [my]0-i best — [[my]0-i brother]648-my brother , [Mr. John Knightley.—This]120-mr. john knightley.—this did not want much of being finished , when [I]0-i put it away in a pet , and vowed [I]0-i would never take another likeness . [I]0-i could not help being provoked ; for after all [my]0-i pains , and when [I]0-i had really made a very good likeness of [it—(Mrs]649-it—(mrs . [Weston]84-mrs. weston and [I]0-i were quite agreed in thinking it very like)—only too handsome — too flattering — but that was a fault on the right side”—after all this , came poor dear [Isabella]83-isabella ’s cold approbation of—“Yes[84-mrs. weston] , it was a little like — but to be sure it did not do [him]647-a baby justice . [We]650-we had had a great deal of trouble in persuading [him]647-a baby to sit at all . It was made a great favour of ; and altogether it was more than [I]0-i could bear ; and so [I]0-i never would finish it , to have it apologised over as an unfavourable likeness , to [every morning visitor in [Brunswick Square;—and]16-brunswick square;—and]651-every morning visitor in brunswick square;—and , as [I]0-i said , [I]0-i did then forswear ever drawing any body again . But for [Harriet]107-harriet ’s sake , or rather for [my]0-i own , and as there are no [husbands]652-husbands and [wives]653-wives in the case at present , [I]0-i will break [my]0-i resolution now . ” [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton seemed very properly struck and delighted by the idea , and was repeating , “[0-i] No [husbands]652-husbands and [wives]653-wives in the case at present indeed , as [you]656-you observe . Exactly so . No [husbands]652-husbands and [wives]653-wives , ” with so interesting a consciousness , that [Emma]79-emma began to consider whether [she]79-emma had not better leave [them]3393-them together at once . But as [she]79-emma wanted to be drawing , the declaration must wait a little longer . [She]79-emma had soon fixed on the size and sort of portrait . It was to be a whole - length in water - colours , like [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s , and was destined , if [she]79-emma could please [herself]79-emma , to hold a very honourable station over the mantelpiece . The sitting began ; and [Harriet]107-harriet , smiling and blushing , and afraid of not keeping [her]107-harriet attitude and countenance , presented a very sweet mixture of youthful expression to the steady eyes of [the artist]3394-the artist . But there was no doing any thing , with [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton fidgeting behind [her]107-harriet and watching every touch . [She]107-harriet gave [him]659-him credit for stationing [himself]659-him where [he]659-him might gaze and gaze again without offence ; but was really obliged to put an end to it , and request [him]659-him to place [himself]659-him elsewhere . It then occurred to [her]107-harriet to employ [him]659-him in reading . “[653-wives] If [he]659-him would be so good as to read to [them]660-them , it would be a kindness indeed ! It would amuse away the difficulties of [her]661-her part , and lessen the irksomeness of [Miss Smith]107-harriet ’s . ” [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was only too happy . [Harriet]107-harriet listened , and [Emma]79-emma drew in peace . [She]107-harriet must allow [him]659-him to be still frequently coming to look ; any thing less would certainly have been too little in [a lover]3395-a lover ; and [he]659-him was ready at the smallest intermission of the pencil , to jump up and see the progress , and be charmed.—There was no being displeased with [such an encourager]3396-such an encourager , for [his]659-him admiration made [him]659-him discern a likeness almost before it was possible . [She]107-harriet could not respect [his]659-him eye , but [his]659-him love and [his]659-him complaisance were unexceptionable . The sitting was altogether very satisfactory ; [she]107-harriet was quite enough pleased with the first day ’s sketch to wish to go on . There was no want of likeness , [she]107-harriet had been fortunate in the attitude , and as [she]107-harriet meant to throw in a little improvement to the figure , to give a little more height , and considerably more elegance , [she]107-harriet had great confidence of its being in every way a pretty drawing at last , and of its filling its destined place with credit to [them]3397-them both — a standing memorial of the beauty of one , the skill of the other , and the friendship of both ; with as many other agreeable associations as [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s very promising attachment was likely to add . [Harriet]107-harriet was to sit again the next day ; and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , just as [he]91-mr. elton ought , entreated for the permission of attending and reading to [them]3397-them again . “[107-harriet] By all means . [We]662-we shall be most happy to consider [you]663-you as [one of the party]664-one of the party . ” The same civilities and courtesies , the same success and satisfaction , took place on the morrow , and accompanied the whole progress of the picture , which was rapid and happy . [Every body who saw it]3398-every body who saw it was pleased , but [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was in continual raptures , and defended it through every criticism . “[662-we] [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield has given [[her]90-hartfield friend]417-her friend the only beauty [she]90-hartfield wanted,”—observed [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston to [him]417-her friend — not in the least suspecting that [she]90-hartfield was addressing a lover.—“The[662-we] expression of the eye is most correct , but [Miss Smith]107-harriet has not those eyebrows and eyelashes . It is the fault of [her]90-hartfield face that [she]90-hartfield has them not . ” “[90-hartfield] Do [you]663-you think so ? ” replied [he]0-i . “[663-you] [I]0-i can not agree with [you]663-you . It appears to [me]0-i a most perfect resemblance in every feature . [I]0-i never saw such a likeness in [my]0-i life . [We]666-we must allow for the effect of shade , [you]663-you know . ” “[663-you] [You]663-you have made [her]107-harriet too tall , [Emma]79-emma , ” said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [Emma]79-emma knew that [she]79-emma had , but would not own it ; and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton warmly added , “[79-emma] Oh no ! certainly not too tall ; not in the least too tall . Consider , [she]107-harriet is sitting down — which naturally presents a different — which in short gives exactly the idea — and the proportions must be preserved , [you]663-you know . Proportions , fore - shortening.—Oh no ! it gives one exactly the idea of such a height as [Miss Smith]107-harriet ’s . Exactly so indeed ! ” “[107-harriet] It is very pretty , ” said [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse . “[107-harriet] So prettily done ! Just as [your]663-you drawings always are , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear . [I]0-i do not know any body who draws so well as [you]663-you do . The only thing [I]0-i do not thoroughly like is , that [she]107-harriet seems to be sitting out of doors , with only a little shawl over [her]107-harriet shoulders — and it makes [one]475-one think [she]107-harriet must catch cold . ” “[107-harriet] But , [[my]0-i dear papa]669-my dear papa , it is supposed to be summer ; a warm day in summer . Look at the tree . ” “[107-harriet] But it is never safe to sit out of doors , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i , [sir]3139-sir , may say any thing , ” cried [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , “[3139-sir] but [I]0-i must confess that [I]0-i regard it as a most happy thought , the placing of [Miss Smith]107-harriet out of doors ; and the tree is touched with such inimitable spirit ! Any other situation would have been much less in character . The naïveté of [Miss Smith]107-harriet ’s manners — and altogether — Oh , it is most admirable ! [I]0-i can not keep [my]0-i eyes from it . [I]0-i never saw such a likeness . ” The next thing wanted was to get the picture framed ; and here were a few difficulties . It must be done directly ; it must be done in [London]1-london ; the order must go through the hands of [some intelligent person whose taste could be depended on]3399-some intelligent person whose taste could be depended on ; and [Isabella]83-isabella , [the usual doer of all commissions]3400-the usual doer of all commissions , must not be applied to , because it was December , and [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse could not bear the idea of [her]83-isabella stirring out of [[her]83-isabella house]3401-her house in the fogs of December . But no sooner was the distress known to [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , than it was removed . [His]91-mr. elton gallantry was always on the alert . “[0-i] Might [he]0-i be trusted with the commission , what infinite pleasure should [he]0-i have in executing it ! [he]0-i could ride to [London]1-london at any time . It was impossible to say how much [he]0-i should be gratified by being employed on such an errand . ” “[0-i] [He]0-i was too good!—she could not endure the thought!—she would not give [him]0-i such a troublesome office for the world,”—brought on the desired repetition of entreaties and assurances,—and a very few minutes settled the business . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was to take the drawing to [London]1-london , chuse the frame , and give the directions ; and [Emma]79-emma thought [she]79-emma could so pack it as to ensure its safety without much incommoding [him]672-this man , while [he]672-this man seemed mostly fearful of not being incommoded enough . “[0-i] What a precious deposit ! ” said [he]672-this man with a tender sigh , as [he]672-this man received it . “[672-this man] [This man]672-this man is almost too gallant to be in love , ” thought [Emma]79-emma . “[0-i] [I]0-i should say so , but that [I]0-i suppose there may be a hundred different ways of being in love . [He]672-this man is [an excellent young man]673-an excellent young man , and will suit [Harriet]107-harriet exactly ; it will be an ‘ Exactly so , ’ as [he]672-this man says [himself]672-this man ; but [he]672-this man does sigh and languish , and study for compliments rather more than [I]0-i could endure as [a principal]674-a principal . [I]0-i come in for a pretty good share as a second . But it is [his]672-this man gratitude on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s account . ” CHAPTER VII The very day of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s going to [London]1-london produced a fresh occasion for [Emma]79-emma ’s services towards [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend . [Harriet]107-harriet had been at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , as usual , soon after breakfast ; and , after a time , had gone [home]3258-home to return again to dinner : [she]107-harriet returned , and sooner than had been talked of , and with an agitated , hurried look , announcing something extraordinary to have happened which [she]107-harriet was longing to tell . Half a minute brought it all out . [She]107-harriet had heard , as soon as [she]107-harriet got back to [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s]3404-mrs. goddard ’s , that [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin had been [there]437-there an hour before , and finding [she]107-harriet was not at [home]3258-home , nor particularly expected , had left a little parcel for [her]107-harriet from [one of [[his]112-mr. martin sisters]525-his sisters]3407-one of his sisters , and gone away ; and on opening this parcel , [she]107-harriet had actually found , besides the two songs which [she]107-harriet had lent [Elizabeth]108-elizabeth to copy , a letter to [herself]675-she ; and this letter was from [him]676-he , from [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin , and contained a direct proposal of marriage . “[672-this man] Who could have thought it ? [She]675-she was so surprized [she]675-she did not know what to do . Yes , quite a proposal of marriage ; and a very good letter , at least [she]675-she thought so . And [he]676-he wrote as if [he]676-he really loved [her]675-she very much — but [she]675-she did not know — and so , [she]675-she was come as fast as [she]675-she could to ask [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield what [she]675-she should do . — ” [Emma]79-emma was half - ashamed of [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend for seeming so pleased and so doubtful . “[675-she] Upon [my]0-i word , ” [she]79-emma cried , “[675-she] [the young man]3228-the young man is determined not to lose any thing for want of asking . [He]3228-the young man will connect [himself]3228-the young man well if [he]3228-the young man can . ” “[3228-the young man] Will [you]678-you read the letter ? ” cried [Harriet]107-harriet . “[678-you] Pray do . II’d rather [you]678-you would . ” [Emma]79-emma was not sorry to be pressed . [She]79-emma read , and was surprized . The style of the letter was much above [her]79-emma expectation . There were not merely no grammatical errors , but as a composition it would not have disgraced [a gentleman]527-a gentleman ; the language , though plain , was strong and unaffected , and the sentiments it conveyed very much to the credit of [the writer]3411-the writer . It was short , but expressed good sense , warm attachment , liberality , propriety , even delicacy of feeling . [She]79-emma paused over it , while [Harriet]107-harriet stood anxiously watching for [her]79-emma opinion , with a “[678-you] Well , well , ” and was at last forced to add , “[678-you] Is it a good letter ? or is it too short ? ” “[678-you] Yes , indeed , a very good letter , ” replied [Emma]79-emma rather slowly—“so[107-harriet] good a letter , [Harriet]107-harriet , that every thing considered , [I]0-i think [one of [[his]3228-the young man sisters]525-his sisters]3407-one of his sisters must have helped [him]3228-the young man . [I]0-i can hardly imagine [the young man whom [I]0-i saw talking with [you]107-harriet the other day]681-the young man whom i saw talking with you the other day could express [himself]681-the young man whom i saw talking with you the other day so well , if left quite to [his]681-the young man whom i saw talking with you the other day own powers , and yet it is not the style of [a woman]3207-a woman ; no , certainly , it is too strong and concise ; not diffuse enough for [a woman]3207-a woman . No doubt [he]681-the young man whom i saw talking with you the other day is [a sensible man]684-a sensible man , and [I]0-i suppose may have a natural talent for — thinks strongly and clearly — and when [he]681-the young man whom i saw talking with you the other day takes a pen in hand , [his]681-the young man whom i saw talking with you the other day thoughts naturally find proper words . It is so with [some men]685-some men . Yes , [I]0-i understand the sort of mind . Vigorous , decided , with sentiments to a certain point , not coarse . A better written letter , [Harriet]107-harriet ( returning it , ) than [I]0-i had expected . ” “[107-harriet] Well , ” said the still waiting [Harriet;—“well]121-harriet;—“well[107-harriet] — and — and what shall [I]0-i do ? ” “[0-i] What shall [you]0-i do ! In what respect ? Do [you]0-i mean with regard to this letter ? ” “[0-i] Yes . ” “[0-i] But what are [you]0-i in doubt of ? [You]0-i must answer it of course — and speedily . ” “[0-i] Yes . But what shall [I]0-i say ? [Dear Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , do advise [me]0-i . ” “[90-hartfield] Oh no , no ! the letter had much better be all [your]0-i own . [You]0-i will express [yourself]0-i very properly , [I]0-i am sure . There is no danger of [your]0-i not being intelligible , which is the first thing . [Your]0-i meaning must be unequivocal ; no doubts or demurs : and such expressions of gratitude and concern for the pain [you]0-i are inflicting as propriety requires , will present themselves unbidden to [your]0-i mind , [I]0-i am persuaded . [You]0-i need not be prompted to write with the appearance of sorrow for [his]686-him disappointment . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i think [I]0-i ought to refuse [him]686-him then , ” said [Harriet]107-harriet , looking down . “[0-i] Ought to refuse [him]686-him ! [[My]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Harriet]107-harriet , what do [you]107-harriet mean ? Are [you]107-harriet in any doubt as to that ? [I]0-i thought — but [I]0-i beg [your]107-harriet pardon , perhaps [I]0-i have been under a mistake . [I]0-i certainly have been misunderstanding [you]107-harriet , if [you]107-harriet feel in doubt as to the purport of [your]107-harriet answer . [I]0-i had imagined [you]107-harriet were consulting [me]0-i only as to the wording of it . ” [Harriet]107-harriet was silent . With a little reserve of manner , [Emma]79-emma continued : “[107-harriet] [You]107-harriet mean to return a favourable answer , [I]0-i collect . ” “[0-i] No , [I]0-i do not ; that is , [I]0-i do not mean — What shall [I]0-i do ? What would [you]107-harriet advise [me]0-i to do ? Pray , dear [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , tell [me]0-i what [I]0-i ought to do . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i shall not give [you]107-harriet any advice , [Harriet]107-harriet . [I]0-i will have nothing to do with it . This is a point which [you]107-harriet must settle with [your]107-harriet feelings . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i had no notion that [he]688-he liked [me]0-i so very much , ” said [Harriet]107-harriet , contemplating the letter . For a little while [Emma]79-emma persevered in [her]79-emma silence ; but beginning to apprehend the bewitching flattery of that letter might be too powerful , [she]79-emma thought it best to say , “[0-i] [I]0-i lay it down as a general rule , [Harriet]107-harriet , that if [a woman]3207-a woman doubts as to whether [she]3207-a woman should accept [a man]548-a man or not , [she]3207-a woman certainly ought to refuse [him]548-a man . If [she]3207-a woman can hesitate as to ‘ Yes , ’ [she]3207-a woman ought to say ‘ No ’ directly . It is not a state to be safely entered into with doubtful feelings , with half a heart . [I]0-i thought it [my]0-i duty as [a friend]405-a friend , and older than [yourself]107-harriet , to say thus much to [you]107-harriet . But do not imagine that [I]0-i want to influence [you]107-harriet . ” “[0-i] Oh ! no , [I]0-i am sure [you]107-harriet are a great deal too kind to — but if [you]107-harriet would just advise [me]0-i what [I]0-i had best do — No , no , [I]0-i do not mean that — As [you]107-harriet say , [one]475-one ’s mind ought to be quite made up — [One]122-one should not be hesitating — It is a very serious thing.—It will be safer to say ‘ No , ’ perhaps.—Do [you]107-harriet think [I]0-i had better say ‘ No ? ’ ” “[107-harriet] Not for [the world]392-the world , ” said [Emma]79-emma , smiling graciously , “[0-i] would [I]0-i advise [you]107-harriet either way . [You]107-harriet must be the best judge of [your]107-harriet own happiness . If [you]107-harriet prefer [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin to [every other person]694-every other person ; if [you]107-harriet think [him]112-mr. martin [the most agreeable man [you]107-harriet have ever been in company with]695-the most agreeable man you have ever been in company with , why should [you]107-harriet hesitate ? [You]107-harriet blush , Harriet.—Does any body else occur to [you]107-harriet at this moment under such a definition ? [Harriet]107-harriet , [Harriet]107-harriet , do not deceive [yourself]107-harriet ; do not be run away with by gratitude and compassion . At this moment whom are [you]107-harriet thinking of ? ” The symptoms were favourable.—Instead of answering , [Harriet]107-harriet turned away confused , and stood thoughtfully by the fire ; and though the letter was still in [her]107-harriet hand , it was now mechanically twisted about without regard . [Emma]79-emma waited the result with impatience , but not without strong hopes . At last , with some hesitation , [Harriet]107-harriet said — “[107-harriet] [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , as [you]90-hartfield will not give [me]0-i [your]90-hartfield opinion , [I]0-i must do as well as [I]0-i can by [myself]0-i ; and [I]0-i have now quite determined , and really almost made up [my]0-i mind — to refuse [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin . Do [you]90-hartfield think [I]0-i am right ? ” “[90-hartfield] Perfectly , perfectly right , [[my]0-i dearest]696-my dearest [Harriet]107-harriet ; [you]107-harriet are doing just what [you]107-harriet ought . While [you]107-harriet were at all in suspense [I]0-i kept [my]0-i feelings to [myself]0-i , but now that [you]107-harriet are so completely decided [I]0-i have no hesitation in approving . [Dear Harriet]123-harriet , [I]0-i give [myself]0-i joy of this . It would have grieved [me]0-i to lose [your]107-harriet acquaintance , which must have been the consequence of [your]107-harriet marrying [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin . While [you]107-harriet were in the smallest degree wavering , [I]0-i said nothing about it , because [I]0-i would not influence ; but it would have been the loss of [a friend]405-a friend to [me]0-i . [I]0-i could not have visited [Mrs. Robert Martin]111-mrs. martin , of [Abbey - Mill Farm]698-abbey - mill farm . Now [I]0-i am secure of [you]107-harriet for ever . ” [Harriet]123-harriet had not surmised [her]123-harriet own danger , but the idea of it struck [her]123-harriet forcibly . “[107-harriet] [You]107-harriet could not have visited [me]0-i ! ” [she]123-harriet cried , looking aghast . “[107-harriet] No , to be sure [you]107-harriet could not ; but [I]0-i never thought of that before . That would have been too dreadful!—What an escape!—Dear [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [I]0-i would not give up the pleasure and honour of being intimate with [you]107-harriet for any thing in [the world]392-the world . ” “[0-i] Indeed , [Harriet]123-harriet , it would have been a severe pang to lose [you]107-harriet ; but it must have been . [You]107-harriet would have thrown [yourself]107-harriet out of all good society . [I]0-i must have given [you]107-harriet up . ” “[0-i] Dear me!—How should [I]0-i ever have borne it ! It would have killed [me]0-i never to come to [Hartfield]90-hartfield any more ! ” “[0-i] [Dear affectionate creature!—You banished to [Abbey - Mill Farm!—You]17-abbey - mill farm!—you confined to the society of [the illiterate and vulgar]701-the illiterate and vulgar all [your]107-harriet life]700-dear affectionate creature!—you banished to abbey - mill farm!—you confined to the society of the illiterate and vulgar all your life ! [I]0-i wonder how [the young man]3228-the young man could have the assurance to ask it . [He]3228-the young man must have a pretty good opinion of [himself]3228-the young man . ” “[3228-the young man] [I]0-i do not think [he]3228-the young man is conceited either , in general , ” said [Harriet]123-harriet , [her]123-harriet conscience opposing such censure ; “[0-i] at least , [he]3228-the young man is very good natured , and [I]0-i shall always feel much obliged to [him]3228-the young man , and have a great regard for — but that is quite a different thing from — and [you]107-harriet know , though [he]3228-the young man may like [me]0-i , it does not follow that [I]0-i should — and certainly [I]0-i must confess that since [my]0-i visiting [here]3113-here [I]0-i have seen [people]704-people — and if [one]475-one comes to compare [them]704-people , person and manners , there is no comparison at all , [one]475-one is so very handsome and agreeable . However , [I]0-i do really think [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin [a very amiable young man]707-a very amiable young man , and have a great opinion of [him]112-mr. martin ; and [his]112-mr. martin being so much attached to [me]0-i — and [his]112-mr. martin writing such a letter — but as to leaving [you]107-harriet , it is what [I]0-i would not do upon any consideration . ” “[107-harriet] Thank [you]107-harriet , thank [you]107-harriet , [[my]0-i own sweet little friend]708-my own sweet little friend . [We]709-we will not be parted . [A woman]3207-a woman is not to marry [a man]548-a man merely because [she]3207-a woman is asked , or because [he]548-a man is attached to [her]3207-a woman , and can write a tolerable letter . ” “[107-harriet] Oh no;—and it is but a short letter too . ” [Emma]79-emma felt the bad taste of [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend , but let it pass with a “[107-harriet] very true ; and it would be a small consolation to [her]3207-a woman , for the clownish manner which might be offending [her]3207-a woman every hour of the day , to know that [[her]3207-a woman husband]431-her husband could write a good letter . ” “[107-harriet] Oh ! yes , very . [Nobody]3124-nobody cares for a letter ; the thing is , to be always happy with [pleasant companions]714-pleasant companions . [I]0-i am quite determined to refuse [him]548-a man . But how shall [I]0-i do ? What shall [I]0-i say ? ” [Emma]79-emma assured [her]417-her friend there would be no difficulty in the answer , and advised its being written directly , which was agreed to , in the hope of [her]79-emma assistance ; and though [Emma]79-emma continued to protest against any assistance being wanted , it was in fact given in the formation of every sentence . The looking over [his]548-a man letter again , in replying to it , had such a softening tendency , that it was particularly necessary to brace [her]79-emma up with a few decisive expressions ; and [she]79-emma was so very much concerned at the idea of making [him]548-a man unhappy , and thought so much of what [[his]548-a man mother]3195-his mother and [sisters]408-sisters would think and say , and was so anxious that [they]3415-they should not fancy [her]79-emma ungrateful , that [Emma]79-emma believed if [the young man]3228-the young man had come in [her]79-emma way at that moment , [he]3228-the young man would have been accepted after all . This letter , however , was written , and sealed , and sent . The business was finished , and [Harriet]123-harriet safe . [She]123-harriet was rather low all the evening , but [Emma]79-emma could allow for [her]123-harriet amiable regrets , and sometimes relieved [them]3417-them by speaking of [her]123-harriet own affection , sometimes by bringing forward the idea of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . “[0-i] [I]0-i shall never be invited to [Abbey - Mill]18-abbey - mill again , ” was said in rather a sorrowful tone . “[0-i] Nor , if [you]715-you were , could [I]0-i ever bear to part with [you]715-you , [[my]0-i Harriet]716-my harriet . [You]715-you are a great deal too necessary at [Hartfield]90-hartfield to be spared to [Abbey - Mill]717-abbey - mill . ” “[715-you] And [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i should never want to go [there]437-there ; for [I]0-i am never happy but at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . ” Some time afterwards it was , “[0-i] [I]0-i think [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard would be very much surprized if [she]105-mrs. goddard knew what had happened . [I]0-i am sure [Miss Nash]113-miss nash would — for [Miss Nash]113-miss nash thinks [[her]113-miss nash own sister]719-her own sister very well married , and it is only [a linen - draper]720-a linen - draper . ” “[720-a linen - draper] [One]475-one should be sorry to see greater pride or refinement in [the teacher of [a school]3278-a school]722-the teacher of a school , [Harriet]123-harriet . [I]0-i dare say [Miss Nash]113-miss nash would envy [you]123-harriet such an opportunity as this of being married . Even this conquest would appear valuable in [her]113-miss nash eyes . As to any thing superior for [you]123-harriet , [I]0-i suppose [she]113-miss nash is quite in the dark . The attentions of [a certain person]724-a certain person can hardly be among the tittle - tattle of [Highbury]3-highbury yet . Hitherto [I]0-i fancy [you]123-harriet and [I]0-i are [the only people to whom [his]724-a certain person looks and manners have explained [themselves]726-themselves]725-the only people to whom his looks and manners have explained themselves . ” [Harriet]123-harriet blushed and smiled , and said something about wondering that [people]704-people should like [her]123-harriet so much . The idea of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was certainly cheering ; but still , after a time , [she]123-harriet was tender - hearted again towards [the rejected Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin . “[0-i] Now [he]724-a certain person has got [my]0-i letter , ” said [she]123-harriet softly . “[724-a certain person] [I]0-i wonder what [they]727-they are all doing — whether [[his]724-a certain person sisters]525-his sisters know — if [he]724-a certain person is unhappy , [they]525-his sisters will be unhappy too . [I]0-i hope [he]724-a certain person will not mind it so very much . ” “[0-i] Let [us]729-us think of those among [[our]729-us absent friends]730-our absent friends who are more cheerfully employed , ” cried [Emma]79-emma . “[0-i] At this moment , perhaps , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton is shewing [your]0-i picture to [[his]724-a certain person mother]3195-his mother and [sisters]408-sisters , telling how much more beautiful is the original , and after being asked for it five or six times , allowing [them]727-they to hear [your]0-i name , [your]0-i own dear name . ” “[0-i] [My]0-i picture!—But [he]91-mr. elton has left [my]0-i picture in [Bond - street]19-bond - street . ” “[91-mr. elton] Has [he]91-mr. elton so!—Then [I]0-i know nothing of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . No , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear little modest [Harriet]123-harriet , depend upon it the picture will not be in [Bond - street]734-bond - street till just before [he]91-mr. elton mounts [his]91-mr. elton horse to - morrow . It is [[his]91-mr. elton companion]735-his companion all this evening , [his]91-mr. elton solace , [his]91-mr. elton delight . It opens [his]91-mr. elton designs to [[his]91-mr. elton family]736-his family , it introduces [you]123-harriet among [them]736-his family , it diffuses through the party those pleasantest feelings of [our]737-our nature , eager curiosity and warm prepossession . How cheerful , how animated , how suspicious , how busy [their]736-his family imaginations all are ! ” [Harriet]123-harriet smiled again , and [her]123-harriet smiles grew stronger . [CHAPTER VIII Harriet]124-harriet slept at [Hartfield]90-hartfield that night . For some weeks past [she]123-harriet had been spending more than half [her]123-harriet time [there]437-there , and gradually getting to have [a bed - room appropriated to [herself]123-harriet]3420-a bed - room appropriated to herself ; and [Emma]79-emma judged it best in every respect , safest and kindest , to keep [her]123-harriet with [them]736-his family as much as possible just at present . [She]123-harriet was obliged to go the next morning for an hour or two to [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s]3404-mrs. goddard ’s , but it was then to be settled that [she]123-harriet should return to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , to make a regular visit of some days . While [she]123-harriet was gone , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley called , and sat some time with [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse and [Emma]79-emma , till [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , who had previously made up [his]81-mr. woodhouse mind to walk out , was persuaded by [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter not to defer it , and was induced by the entreaties of both , though against the scruples of [his]81-mr. woodhouse own civility , to leave [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley for that purpose . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , who had nothing of ceremony about [him]88-mr. knightley , was offering by [his]88-mr. knightley short , decided answers , an amusing contrast to the protracted apologies and civil hesitations of [the other]3423-the other . “[0-i] Well , [I]0-i believe , if [you]0-i will excuse [me]0-i , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , if [you]0-i will not consider [me]0-i as doing a very rude thing , [I]0-i shall take [Emma]79-emma ’s advice and go out for a quarter of an hour . As the sun is out , [I]0-i believe [I]0-i had better take [my]0-i three turns while [I]0-i can . [I]0-i treat [you]0-i without ceremony , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [[We]738-we invalids]739-we invalids think [we]738-we are [privileged people]740-privileged people . ” “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear [sir]3139-sir]741-my dear sir , do not make [a stranger of [me]0-i]743-a stranger of me . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i leave an excellent substitute in [[my]0-i daughter]744-my daughter . [Emma]79-emma will be happy to entertain [you]0-i . And therefore [I]0-i think [I]0-i will beg [your]0-i excuse and take [my]0-i three turns — [my]0-i winter walk . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i can not do better , [sir]3139-sir . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i would ask for the pleasure of [your]0-i company , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , but [I]0-i am [a very slow walker]746-a very slow walker , and [my]0-i pace would be tedious to [you]0-i ; and , besides , [you]0-i have another long walk before [you]0-i , to [Donwell Abbey]202-donwell . ” “[0-i] Thank [you]0-i , [sir]3139-sir , thank [you]0-i ; [I]0-i am going this moment [myself]0-i ; and [I]0-i think the sooner [you]0-i go the better . [I]0-i will fetch [your]0-i greatcoat and open the garden door for [you]0-i . ” [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse at last was off ; but [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , instead of being immediately off likewise , sat down again , seemingly inclined for more chat . [He]0-i began speaking of [Harriet]124-harriet , and speaking of [her]748-her with more voluntary praise than [Emma]79-emma had ever heard before . “[0-i] [I]0-i can not rate [her]748-her beauty as [you]749-you do , ” said [he]0-i ; “[0-i] but [she]748-her is [a pretty little creature]750-a pretty little creature , and [I]0-i am inclined to think very well of [her]748-her disposition . [Her]748-her character depends upon those [she]748-her is with ; but in good hands [she]748-her will turn out [a valuable woman]751-a valuable woman . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am glad [you]0-i think so ; and the good hands , [I]0-i hope , may not be wanting . ” “[0-i] Come , ” said [he]0-i , “[749-you] [you]749-you are anxious for a compliment , so [I]0-i will tell [you]749-you that [you]749-you have improved [her]748-her . [You]749-you have cured [her]748-her of [[her]748-her school - girl]752-her school - girl ’s giggle ; [she]748-her really does [you]749-you credit . ” “[748-her] Thank [you]749-you . [I]0-i should be mortified indeed if [I]0-i did not believe [I]0-i had been of some use ; but it is not every body who will bestow praise where [they]753-they may . [You]749-you do not often overpower [me]0-i with it . ” “[749-you] [You]749-you are expecting [her]748-her again , [you]749-you say , this morning ? ” “[749-you] Almost every moment . [She]748-her has been gone longer already than [she]748-her intended . ” “[748-her] Something has happened to delay [her]748-her ; [some visitors]754-some visitors perhaps . ” “[754-some visitors] [Highbury]3-highbury gossips!—Tiresome wretches ! ” “[124-harriet] [Harriet]124-harriet may not consider every body tiresome that [you]749-you would . ” [Emma]79-emma knew this was too true for contradiction , and therefore said nothing . [He]0-i presently added , with a smile , “[749-you] [I]0-i do not pretend to fix on times or places , but [I]0-i must tell [you]749-you that [I]0-i have good reason to believe [[your]749-you little friend]755-your little friend will soon hear of something to [her]748-her advantage . ” “[755-your little friend] Indeed ! how so ? of what sort ? ” “[755-your little friend] A very serious sort , [I]0-i assure [you]749-you ; ” still smiling . “[755-your little friend] Very serious ! [I]0-i can think of but one thing — Who is in love with [her]124-harriet ? Who makes [you]749-you [[their]756-their confidant]757-their confidant ? ” [Emma]79-emma was more than half in hopes of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s having dropt a hint . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley was [a sort of general friend and adviser]3424-a sort of general friend and adviser , and [she]79-emma knew [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton looked up to [him]0-i . “[0-i] [I]0-i have reason to think , ” [he]0-i replied , “[0-i] that [Harriet Smith]107-harriet will soon have an offer of marriage , and from a most unexceptionable quarter:—Robert [Martin]112-mr. martin is [the man]758-the man . [Her]124-harriet visit to [Abbey - Mill]18-abbey - mill , this summer , seems to have done [his]0-i business . [He]0-i is desperately in love and means to marry [her]124-harriet . ” “[0-i] [He]0-i is very obliging , ” said [Emma]79-emma ; “[0-i] but is [he]0-i sure that [Harriet]107-harriet means to marry [him]0-i ? ” “[107-harriet] Well , well , means to make [her]124-harriet an offer then . Will that do ? [He]0-i came to [the Abbey]505-the abbey two evenings ago , on purpose to consult [me]0-i about it . [He]0-i knows [I]0-i have a thorough regard for [him]0-i and all [[his]0-i family]736-his family , and , [I]0-i believe , considers [me]0-i as [one of [[his]0-i best friends]762-his best friends]761-one of his best friends . [He]0-i came to ask [me]0-i whether [I]0-i thought it would be imprudent in [him]0-i to settle so early ; whether [I]0-i thought [her]124-harriet too young : in short , whether [I]0-i approved [his]0-i choice altogether ; having some apprehension perhaps of [her]124-harriet being considered ( especially since [your]763-your making so much of [her]124-harriet ) as in [a line of society above [him]0-i]764-a line of society above him . [I]0-i was very much pleased with all that [he]0-i said . [I]0-i never hear better sense from any one than [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin . [He]0-i always speaks to the purpose ; open , straightforward , and very well judging . [He]0-i told [me]0-i every thing ; [his]0-i circumstances and plans , and what [they]765-they all proposed doing in the event of [his]0-i marriage . [He]0-i is [an excellent young man]673-an excellent young man , both as [son]3346-son and [brother]768-brother . [I]0-i had no hesitation in advising [him]0-i to marry . [He]0-i proved to [me]0-i that [he]0-i could afford it ; and that being the case , [I]0-i was convinced [he]0-i could not do better . [I]0-i praised [the fair lady]769-the fair lady too , and altogether sent [him]0-i away very happy . If [he]0-i had never esteemed [my]0-i opinion before , [he]0-i would have thought highly of [me]0-i then ; and , [I]0-i dare say , left [the house]425-the house thinking [me]0-i [the best friend and [counsellor man]772-counsellor man ever had]771-the best friend and counsellor man ever had . This happened the night before last . Now , as [we]773-we may fairly suppose , [he]0-i would not allow much time to pass before [he]0-i spoke to [the lady]774-the lady , and as [he]0-i does not appear to have spoken yesterday , it is not unlikely that [he]0-i should be at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s to - day ; and [she]774-the lady may be detained by [a visitor]775-a visitor , without thinking [him]0-i at all [a tiresome wretch]776-a tiresome wretch . ” “[774-the lady] Pray , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , ” said [Emma]79-emma , who had been smiling to [herself]79-emma through a great part of this speech , “[88-mr. knightley] how do [you]88-mr. knightley know that [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin did not speak yesterday ? ” “[112-mr. martin] Certainly , ” replied [he]0-i , surprized , “[112-mr. martin] [I]0-i do not absolutely know it ; but it may be inferred . Was not [she]774-the lady the whole day with [you]88-mr. knightley ? ” “[774-the lady] Come , ” said [she]79-emma , “[0-i] [I]0-i will tell [you]88-mr. knightley something , in return for what [you]88-mr. knightley have told [me]0-i . [He]112-mr. martin did speak yesterday — that is , [he]112-mr. martin wrote , and was refused . ” This was obliged to be repeated before it could be believed ; and [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley actually looked red with surprize and displeasure , as [he]88-mr. knightley stood up , in tall indignation , and said , “[112-mr. martin] Then [she]774-the lady is a greater simpleton than [I]0-i ever believed [her]774-the lady . What is [the foolish girl]777-the foolish girl about ? ” “[777-the foolish girl] Oh ! to be sure , ” cried [Emma]79-emma , “[777-the foolish girl] it is always incomprehensible to [a man]548-a man that [a woman]3207-a woman should ever refuse an offer of marriage .
