But what is the meaning of this ? [Harriet Smith]107-harriet refuse [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin ? madness , if it is so ; but [I]0-i hope [you]88-mr. knightley are mistaken . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i saw [her]107-harriet answer!—nothing could be clearer . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i saw [her]107-harriet answer!—you wrote [her]107-harriet answer too . [Emma]79-emma , this is [your]88-mr. knightley doing . [You]88-mr. knightley persuaded [her]107-harriet to refuse [him]112-mr. martin . ” “[88-mr. knightley] And if [I]0-i did , ( which , however , [I]0-i am far from allowing ) [I]0-i should not feel that [I]0-i had done wrong . [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin is [a very respectable young man]512-a very respectable young man , but [I]0-i can not admit [him]112-mr. martin to be [[Harriet]107-harriet ’s equal]784-harriet ’s equal ; and am rather surprized indeed that [he]112-mr. martin should have ventured to address [her]107-harriet . By [your]88-mr. knightley account , [he]112-mr. martin does seem to have had some scruples . It is a pity that they were ever got over . ” “[112-mr. martin] Not [Harriet]107-harriet ’s equal ! ” exclaimed [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley loudly and warmly ; and with calmer asperity , added , a few moments afterwards , “[112-mr. martin] No , [he]112-mr. martin is not [her]107-harriet equal indeed , for [he]112-mr. martin is as much [her]107-harriet superior in sense as in situation . [Emma]79-emma , [your]88-mr. knightley infatuation about [that girl]785-that girl blinds [you]88-mr. knightley . What are [Harriet Smith]107-harriet ’s claims , either of birth , nature or education , to any connexion higher than [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin ? [She]785-that girl is [the natural daughter of [nobody knows whom , with probably no settled provision at all , and certainly no respectable relations]787-nobody knows whom , with probably no settled provision at all , and certainly no respectable relations]786-the natural daughter of nobody knows whom , with probably no settled provision at all , and certainly no respectable relations . [She]785-that girl is known only as [parlour - boarder at [a common school]789-a common school]788-parlour - boarder at a common school . [She]785-that girl is not [a sensible girl]790-a sensible girl , nor [a girl of any information]791-a girl of any information . [She]785-that girl has been taught nothing useful , and is too young and too simple to have acquired any thing [herself]785-that girl . At [her]785-that girl age [she]785-that girl can have no experience , and with [her]785-that girl little wit , is not very likely ever to have any that can avail [her]785-that girl . [She]785-that girl is pretty , and [she]785-that girl is good tempered , and that is all . [My]0-i only scruple in advising the match was on [his]792-his account , as being beneath [his]792-his deserts , and a bad connexion for [him]792-his . [I]0-i felt that , as to fortune , in all probability [he]792-his might do much better ; and that as to [a rational companion]793-a rational companion or [useful helpmate]794-useful helpmate , [he]792-his could not do worse . But [I]0-i could not reason so to [a man in love]795-a man in love , and was willing to trust to there being no harm in [her]785-that girl , to [her]785-that girl having that sort of disposition , which , in good hands , like [his]792-his , might be easily led aright and turn out very well . The advantage of the match [I]0-i felt to be all on [her]785-that girl side ; and had not the smallest doubt ( nor have [I]0-i now ) that there would be a general cry - out upon [her]785-that girl extreme good luck . Even [your]796-your satisfaction [I]0-i made sure of . It crossed [my]0-i mind immediately that [you]796-your would not regret [[your]796-your friend]630-your friend ’s leaving [Highbury]3-highbury , for the sake of [her]785-that girl being settled so well . [I]0-i remember saying to [myself]0-i , ‘ Even [Emma]79-emma , with all [her]79-emma partiality for [Harriet]107-harriet , will think this a good match . ’ ” “[0-i] [I]0-i can not help wondering at [your]796-your knowing so little of [Emma]79-emma as to say any such thing . What ! think [a farmer]511-a farmer , ( and with all [his]511-a farmer sense and all [his]511-a farmer merit [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin is nothing more , ) a good match for [[my]0-i intimate friend]799-my intimate friend ! Not regret [her]785-that girl leaving [Highbury]3-highbury for the sake of marrying [a man whom [I]0-i could never admit as an acquaintance of [my]0-i own]800-a man whom i could never admit as an acquaintance of my own ! [I]0-i wonder [you]796-your should think it possible for [me]0-i to have such feelings . [I]0-i assure [you]796-your [mine]0-i are very different . [I]0-i must think [your]796-your statement by no means fair . [You]796-your are not just to [Harriet]107-harriet ’s claims . [They]801-they would be estimated very differently by [others]473-others as well as [myself]0-i ; [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin may be the richest of the two , but [he]112-mr. martin is undoubtedly [her]785-that girl inferior as to rank in society.—The sphere in which [she]785-that girl moves is much above his.—It would be a degradation . ” “[112-mr. martin] A degradation to illegitimacy and ignorance , to be married to [a respectable , intelligent gentleman - farmer]803-a respectable , intelligent gentleman - farmer ! ” “[803-a respectable , intelligent gentleman - farmer] As to the circumstances of [her]785-that girl birth , though in a legal sense [she]785-that girl may be called [Nobody]3124-nobody , it will not hold in common sense . [She]785-that girl is not to pay for the offence of [others]473-others , by being held below the level of those with whom [she]785-that girl is brought up.—There can scarcely be a doubt that [[her]785-that girl father]415-her father is [a gentleman]527-a gentleman — and [a gentleman of fortune.—Her allowance]808-a gentleman of fortune.—her allowance is very liberal ; nothing has ever been grudged for [her]785-that girl improvement or comfort.—That [she]785-that girl is [[a gentleman]527-a gentleman ’s daughter]528-a gentleman ’s daughter , is indubitable to [me]0-i ; that [she]785-that girl associates with [[gentlemen]3367-gentlemen ’s daughters]812-gentlemen ’s daughters , [no one]813-no one , [I]0-i apprehend , will deny.—She is superior to [Mr. Robert Martin]112-mr. martin . ” “[112-mr. martin] Whoever might be [[her]785-that girl parents]814-her parents , ” said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , “[112-mr. martin] whoever may have had the charge of [her]785-that girl , it does not appear to have been any part of [their]814-her parents plan to introduce [her]785-that girl into what [you]815-you would call good society . After receiving a very indifferent education [she]785-that girl is left in [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s hands to shift as [she]785-that girl can;—to move , in short , in [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s line , to have [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s acquaintance]816-mrs. goddard ’s acquaintance . [[Her]785-that girl friends]817-her friends evidently thought this good enough for [her]785-that girl ; and it was good enough . [She]785-that girl desired nothing better [herself]785-that girl . Till [you]815-you chose to turn [her]785-that girl into [a friend]405-a friend , [her]785-that girl mind had no distaste for [her]785-that girl own set , nor any ambition beyond it . [She]785-that girl was as happy as possible with [the Martins]110-the martins in the summer . [She]785-that girl had no sense of superiority then . If [she]785-that girl has it now , [you]815-you have given it . [You]815-you have been [no friend to [Harriet Smith]107-harriet]819-no friend to harriet smith , [Emma]79-emma . [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin would never have proceeded so far , if [he]112-mr. martin had not felt persuaded of [her]785-that girl not being disinclined to [him]112-mr. martin . [I]0-i know [him]112-mr. martin well . [He]112-mr. martin has too much real feeling to address [any woman]820-any woman on the haphazard of selfish passion . And as to conceit , [he]112-mr. martin is the farthest from it of [any man [I]0-i know]821-any man i know . Depend upon it [he]112-mr. martin had encouragement . ” It was most convenient to [Emma]79-emma not to make a direct reply to this assertion ; [she]79-emma chose rather to take up [her]79-emma own line of the subject again . “[112-mr. martin] [You]815-you are [a very warm friend to [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin]822-a very warm friend to mr. martin ; but , as [I]0-i said before , are unjust to [Harriet]107-harriet . [Harriet]107-harriet ’s claims to marry well are not so contemptible as [you]815-you represent [them]823-them . [She]107-harriet is not [a clever girl]824-a clever girl , but [she]107-harriet has better sense than [you]815-you are aware of , and does not deserve to have [her]107-harriet understanding spoken of so slightingly . Waiving that point , however , and supposing [her]107-harriet to be , as [you]815-you describe [her]107-harriet , only pretty and good - natured , let [me]0-i tell [you]815-you , that in the degree [she]107-harriet possesses them , they are not trivial recommendations to [the world]392-the world in general , for [she]107-harriet is , in fact , [a beautiful girl]3377-a beautiful girl , and must be thought so by [ninety - nine people]827-ninety - nine people out of an hundred ; and till it appears that [men]828-men are much more philosophic on the subject of beauty than [they]828-men are generally supposed ; till [they]828-men do fall in love with well - informed minds instead of handsome faces , [a girl]600-a girl , with such loveliness as [Harriet]107-harriet , has a certainty of being admired and sought after , of having the power of chusing from among [many]3239-many , consequently a claim to be nice . [Her]107-harriet good - nature , too , is not so very slight a claim , comprehending , as it does , real , thorough sweetness of temper and manner , a very humble opinion of [herself]107-harriet , and a great readiness to be pleased with [other people]445-other people . [I]0-i am very much mistaken if [your]815-you sex in general would not think such beauty , and such temper , the highest claims [a woman]3207-a woman could possess . ” “[0-i] Upon [my]0-i word , [Emma]79-emma , to hear [you]79-emma abusing the reason [you]79-emma have , is almost enough to make [me]0-i think so too . Better be without sense , than misapply it as [you]79-emma do . ” “[79-emma] To be sure ! ” cried [she]107-harriet playfully . “[79-emma] [I]0-i know that is the feeling of [you]815-you all . [I]0-i know that [such a girl as [Harriet]107-harriet]833-such a girl as harriet is exactly what [every man]834-every man delights in — what at once bewitches [his]834-every man senses and satisfies [his]834-every man judgment . Oh ! [Harriet]107-harriet may pick and chuse . Were [you]815-you , [yourself]815-you , ever to marry , [she]107-harriet is [the very woman for [you]815-you]835-the very woman for you . And is [she]107-harriet , at seventeen , just entering into life , just beginning to be known , to be wondered at because [she]107-harriet does not accept the first offer [she]107-harriet receives ? No — pray let [her]107-harriet have time to look about [her]107-harriet . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have always thought it a very foolish intimacy , ” said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley presently , “[0-i] though [I]0-i have kept [my]0-i thoughts to [myself]0-i ; but [I]0-i now perceive that it will be a very unfortunate one for [Harriet]107-harriet . [You]815-you will puff [her]107-harriet up with such ideas of [her]107-harriet own beauty , and of what [she]107-harriet has a claim to , that , in a little while , nobody within [her]107-harriet reach will be good enough for [her]107-harriet . [Vanity]125-vanity working on a weak head , produces every sort of mischief . Nothing so easy as for [a young lady]467-a young lady to raise [her]467-a young lady expectations too high . [Miss Harriet Smith]107-harriet may not find offers of marriage flow in so fast , though [she]107-harriet is [a very pretty girl]3310-a very pretty girl . [Men of sense]838-men of sense , whatever [you]815-you may chuse to say , do not want [silly wives]839-silly wives . [Men of family]840-men of family would not be very fond of connecting [themselves]840-men of family with [a girl of such obscurity]841-a girl of such obscurity — and [most prudent men]842-most prudent men would be afraid of the inconvenience and disgrace [they]842-most prudent men might be involved in , when the mystery of [her]107-harriet parentage came to be revealed . Let [her]107-harriet marry [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin , and [she]107-harriet is safe , respectable , and happy for ever ; but if [you]815-you encourage [her]107-harriet to expect to marry greatly , and teach [her]107-harriet to be satisfied with nothing less than [a man of consequence and large fortune]843-a man of consequence and large fortune , [she]107-harriet may be a parlour - boarder at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s all the rest of [her]107-harriet life — or , at least , ( for [Harriet Smith]107-harriet is [a girl who will marry [somebody or other]845-somebody or other , ) till [she]107-harriet grow desperate , and is glad to catch at [[the old writing - master]846-the old writing - master ’s son]847-the old writing - master ’s son]844-a girl who will marry somebody or other , ) till she grow desperate , and is glad to catch at the old writing - master ’s son . ” “[107-harriet] [We]848-we think so very differently on this point , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , that there can be no use in canvassing it . [We]848-we shall only be making [each other]420-each other more angry . But as to [my]0-i letting [her]107-harriet marry [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin , it is impossible ; [she]107-harriet has refused [him]112-mr. martin , and so decidedly , [I]0-i think , as must prevent any second application . [She]107-harriet must abide by the evil of having refused [him]112-mr. martin , whatever it may be ; and as to the refusal itself , [I]0-i will not pretend to say that [I]0-i might not influence [her]107-harriet a little ; but [I]0-i assure [you]850-you there was very little for [me]0-i or for any body to do . [His]112-mr. martin appearance is so much against [him]112-mr. martin , and [his]112-mr. martin manner so bad , that if [she]107-harriet ever were disposed to favour [him]112-mr. martin , [she]107-harriet is not now . [I]0-i can imagine , that before [she]107-harriet had seen [any body superior]851-any body superior , [she]107-harriet might tolerate [him]112-mr. martin . [He]112-mr. martin was [the brother of [[her]107-harriet friends]817-her friends , and [he]112-mr. martin took pains to please [her]107-harriet]852-the brother of her friends , and he took pains to please her ; and altogether , having seen [nobody]3124-nobody better ( that must have been [[his]112-mr. martin great assistant]855-his great assistant ) [she]107-harriet might not , while [she]107-harriet was at [Abbey - Mill]18-abbey - mill , find [him]112-mr. martin disagreeable . But the case is altered now . [She]107-harriet knows now what [gentlemen]3367-gentlemen are ; and [nothing but a gentleman in education and manner]857-nothing but a gentleman in education and manner has any chance with [Harriet]107-harriet . ” “[857-nothing but a gentleman in education and manner] Nonsense , errant nonsense , as ever was talked ! ” cried [Mr. Knightley.—“Robert[857-nothing but a gentleman in education and manner] Martin]126-mr. knightley.—“robert martin ’s manners have sense , sincerity , and good - humour to recommend them ; and [his]112-mr. martin mind has more true gentility than [Harriet Smith]107-harriet could understand . ” [Emma]79-emma made no answer , and tried to look cheerfully unconcerned , but was really feeling uncomfortable and wanting [him]112-mr. martin very much to be gone . [She]107-harriet did not repent what [she]107-harriet had done ; [she]107-harriet still thought [herself]107-harriet a better judge of such a point of female right and refinement than [he]112-mr. martin could be ; but yet [she]107-harriet had a sort of habitual respect for [his]112-mr. martin judgment in general , which made [her]107-harriet dislike having it so loudly against [her]107-harriet ; and to have [him]112-mr. martin sitting just opposite to [her]107-harriet in angry state , was very disagreeable . Some minutes passed in this unpleasant silence , with only one attempt on [Emma]79-emma ’s side to talk of the weather , but [he]112-mr. martin made no answer . [He]112-mr. martin was thinking . The result of [his]112-mr. martin thoughts appeared at last in these words . “[112-mr. martin] [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin has no great loss — if [he]112-mr. martin can but think so ; and [I]0-i hope it will not be long before [he]112-mr. martin does . [Your]112-mr. martin views for [Harriet]107-harriet are best known to [yourself]112-mr. martin ; but as [you]112-mr. martin make no secret of [your]112-mr. martin love of match - making , it is fair to suppose that views , and plans , and projects [you]112-mr. martin have;—and as [a friend]405-a friend [I]0-i shall just hint to [you]112-mr. martin that if [Elton]91-mr. elton is [the man]758-the man , [I]0-i think it will be all labour in vain . ” [Emma]79-emma laughed and disclaimed . [He]0-i continued , “[91-mr. elton] Depend upon it , [Elton]91-mr. elton will not do . [Elton]91-mr. elton is [a very good sort of man]860-a very good sort of man , and [a very respectable vicar of [Highbury]3-highbury]861-a very respectable vicar of highbury , but not at all likely to make an imprudent match . [He]91-mr. elton knows the value of a good income as well as any body . [Elton]91-mr. elton may talk sentimentally , but [he]91-mr. elton will act rationally . [He]91-mr. elton is as well acquainted with [his]91-mr. elton own claims , as [you]862-you can be with [Harriet]107-harriet ’s . [He]91-mr. elton knows that [he]91-mr. elton is [a very handsome young man]863-a very handsome young man , and a great favourite wherever [he]91-mr. elton goes ; and from [his]91-mr. elton general way of talking in unreserved moments , when there are only [men present]864-men present , [I]0-i am convinced that [he]91-mr. elton does not mean to throw [himself]91-mr. elton away . [I]0-i have heard [him]91-mr. elton speak with great animation of [a large family of young ladies that [[his]91-mr. elton sisters]525-his sisters are intimate with , who have all twenty thousand pounds apiece]865-a large family of young ladies that his sisters are intimate with , who have all twenty thousand pounds apiece . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am very much obliged to [you]91-mr. elton , ” said [Emma]79-emma , laughing again . “[91-mr. elton] If [I]0-i had set [my]0-i heart on [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s marrying [Harriet]107-harriet , it would have been very kind to open [my]0-i eyes ; but at present [I]0-i only want to keep [Harriet]107-harriet to [myself]0-i . [I]0-i have done with match - making indeed . [I]0-i could never hope to equal [my]0-i own doings at [Randalls]97-randalls . [I]0-i shall leave off while [I]0-i am well . ” “[107-harriet] Good morning to you,”—said [he]91-mr. elton , rising and walking off abruptly . [He]91-mr. elton was very much vexed . [He]91-mr. elton felt the disappointment of [the young man]3228-the young man , and was mortified to have been the means of promoting it , by the sanction [he]91-mr. elton had given ; and the part which [he]91-mr. elton was persuaded [Emma]79-emma had taken in the affair , was provoking [him]91-mr. elton exceedingly . [Emma]79-emma remained in a state of vexation too ; but there was more indistinctness in the causes of [her]79-emma ’s , than in [his]91-mr. elton . [She]79-emma did not always feel so absolutely satisfied with [herself]79-emma , so entirely convinced that [her]79-emma opinions were right and [[her]79-emma adversary]3426-her adversary ’s wrong , as [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [He]91-mr. elton walked off in more complete self - approbation than [he]91-mr. elton left for [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma was not so materially cast down , however , but that a little time and the return of [Harriet]107-harriet were very adequate restoratives . [Harriet]107-harriet ’s staying away so long was beginning to make [her]79-emma uneasy . The possibility of [the young man]3228-the young man ’s coming to [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s that morning , and meeting with [Harriet]107-harriet and pleading [his]3228-the young man own cause , gave alarming ideas . The dread of such a failure after all became the prominent uneasiness ; and when [Harriet]107-harriet appeared , and in very good spirits , and without having any such reason to give for [her]107-harriet long absence , [she]107-harriet felt a satisfaction which settled [her]107-harriet with [her]107-harriet own mind , and convinced [her]107-harriet , that let [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley think or say what [he]91-mr. elton would , [she]107-harriet had done nothing which [woman]3428-woman ’s friendship and [woman]3428-woman ’s feelings would not justify . [He]88-mr. knightley had frightened [her]107-harriet a little about [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ; but when [she]107-harriet considered that [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley could not have observed [him]88-mr. knightley as [she]107-harriet had done , neither with the interest , nor ( [she]107-harriet must be allowed to tell [herself]107-harriet , in spite of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s pretensions ) with the skill of such an observer on such a question as [herself]107-harriet , that [he]88-mr. knightley had spoken it hastily and in anger , [she]107-harriet was able to believe , that [he]88-mr. knightley had rather said what [he]88-mr. knightley wished resentfully to be true , than what [he]88-mr. knightley knew any thing about . [He]88-mr. knightley certainly might have heard [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton speak with more unreserve than [she]107-harriet had ever done , and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton might not be of an imprudent , inconsiderate disposition as to money matters ; [he]91-mr. elton might naturally be rather attentive than otherwise to [them]3430-them ; but then , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley did not make due allowance for the influence of a strong passion at war with all interested motives . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley saw no such passion , and of course thought nothing of its effects ; but [she]107-harriet saw too much of it to feel a doubt of its overcoming any hesitations that a reasonable prudence might originally suggest ; and more than a reasonable , becoming degree of prudence , [she]107-harriet was very sure did not belong to [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . [Harriet]107-harriet ’s cheerful look and manner established [hers]107-harriet : [she]107-harriet came back , not to think of [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin , but to talk of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . [Miss Nash]113-miss nash had been telling [her]107-harriet something , which [she]107-harriet repeated immediately with great delight . [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry had been to [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s]3404-mrs. goddard ’s to attend [a sick child]3432-a sick child , and [Miss Nash]113-miss nash had seen [him]102-mr. perry , and [he]102-mr. perry had told [Miss Nash]113-miss nash , that as [he]102-mr. perry was coming back yesterday from [Clayton Park]21-clayton park , [he]102-mr. perry had met [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , and found to [his]102-mr. perry great surprize , that [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was actually on [his]91-mr. elton road to [London]1-london , and not meaning to return till the morrow , though it was the whist - club night , which [he]91-mr. elton had been never known to miss before ; and [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry had remonstrated with [him]91-mr. elton about it , and told [him]91-mr. elton how shabby it was in [him]91-mr. elton , [[their]3433-their best player]3434-their best player , to absent [himself]91-mr. elton , and tried very much to persuade [him]91-mr. elton to put off [his]91-mr. elton journey only one day ; but it would not do ; [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton had been determined to go on , and had said in a very particular way indeed , that [he]91-mr. elton was going on business which [he]91-mr. elton would not put off for any inducement in [the world]392-the world ; and something about a very enviable commission , and being the bearer of something exceedingly precious . [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry could not quite understand [him]91-mr. elton , but [he]102-mr. perry was very sure there must be [a lady in the case]3436-a lady in the case , and [he]102-mr. perry told [him]102-mr. perry so ; and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton only looked very conscious and smiling , and rode off in great spirits . [Miss Nash]113-miss nash had told [her]113-miss nash all this , and had talked a great deal more about [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ; and said , looking so very significantly at [her]113-miss nash , “[867-she] that [she]867-she did not pretend to understand what [his]868-his business might be , but [she]867-she only knew that [any woman whom [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton]869-any woman whom mr. elton could prefer , [she]867-she should think [the luckiest woman in [the world]392-the world]870-the luckiest woman in the world ; for , beyond a doubt , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton had not [his]91-mr. elton equal for beauty or agreeableness . ” [CHAPTER IX Mr. Knightley]127-mr. knightley might quarrel with [her]113-miss nash , but [Emma]79-emma could not quarrel with [herself]113-miss nash . [He]91-mr. elton was so much displeased , that it was longer than usual before [he]91-mr. elton came to [Hartfield]90-hartfield again ; and when [they]3437-they did meet , [his]91-mr. elton grave looks [shewed]3438-shewed that [she]113-miss nash was not forgiven . [She]113-miss nash was sorry , but could not repent . On the contrary , [her]113-miss nash plans and proceedings were more and more justified and endeared to [her]113-miss nash by the general appearances of the next few days . The Picture , elegantly framed , came safely to hand soon after [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s return , and being hung over the mantelpiece of [the common sitting - room]3439-the common sitting - room , [he]91-mr. elton got up to look at it , and sighed out [his]91-mr. elton half sentences of admiration just as [he]91-mr. elton ought ; and as for [Harriet]107-harriet ’s feelings , they were visibly forming themselves into as strong and steady an attachment as [her]107-harriet youth and sort of mind admitted . [Emma]79-emma was soon perfectly satisfied of [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin ’s being no otherwise remembered , than as [he]91-mr. elton furnished a contrast with [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , of the utmost advantage to the latter . [Her]113-miss nash views of improving [[her]113-miss nash little friend]3440-her little friend ’s mind , by a great deal of useful reading and conversation , had never yet led to more than a few first chapters , and the intention of going on to - morrow . It was much easier to chat than to study ; much pleasanter to let [her]113-miss nash imagination range and work at [Harriet]107-harriet ’s fortune , than to be labouring to enlarge [her]107-harriet comprehension or exercise it on sober facts ; and the only literary pursuit which engaged [Harriet]107-harriet at present , the only mental provision [she]107-harriet was making for the evening of life , was the collecting and transcribing all the riddles of every sort that [she]107-harriet could meet with , into a thin quarto of hot - pressed paper , made up by [[her]107-harriet friend]417-her friend , and ornamented with ciphers and trophies . In this age of literature , such collections on a very grand scale are not uncommon . [Miss Nash]113-miss nash , [head - teacher at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s]3442-head - teacher at mrs. goddard ’s , had written out at least three hundred ; and [Harriet]107-harriet , who had taken the first hint of it from [her]113-miss nash , hoped , with [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield ’s help , to get a great many more . [Emma]79-emma assisted with [her]79-emma invention , memory and taste ; and as [Harriet]107-harriet wrote a very pretty hand , it was likely to be an arrangement of the first order , in form as well as quantity . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was almost as much interested in the business as [the girls]3337-the girls , and tried very often to recollect something worth [their]3337-the girls putting in . “[91-mr. elton] So many clever riddles as there used to be when [he]872-he was young — [he]872-he wondered [he]872-he could not remember them ! but [he]872-he hoped [he]872-he should in time . ” And it always ended in “[128-kitty] [Kitty]128-kitty , [a fair but frozen maid]873-a fair but frozen maid . ” [[His]872-he good friend]3444-his good friend [Perry]102-mr. perry , too , whom [he]872-he had spoken to on the subject , did not at present recollect any thing of the riddle kind ; but [he]872-he had desired [Perry]102-mr. perry to be upon the watch , and as [he]872-he went about so much , something , [he]872-he thought , might come from that quarter . It was by no means [[his]872-he daughter]3129-his daughter ’s wish that the intellects of [Highbury]3-highbury in general should be put under requisition . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was the only one whose assistance [she]3129-his daughter asked . [He]91-mr. elton was invited to contribute any really good enigmas , charades , or conundrums that [he]91-mr. elton might recollect ; and [she]3129-his daughter had the pleasure of seeing [him]91-mr. elton most intently at work with [his]91-mr. elton recollections ; and at the same time , as [she]3129-his daughter could perceive , most earnestly careful that nothing ungallant , nothing that did not breathe a compliment to the sex should pass [his]91-mr. elton lips . [They]3446-they owed to [him]91-mr. elton [their]3446-they two or three politest puzzles ; and the joy and exultation with which at last [he]91-mr. elton recalled , and rather sentimentally recited , that well - known charade , [My]128-kitty first doth affliction denote , Which [my]128-kitty second is destin’d to feel And [my]128-kitty whole is the best antidote That affliction to soften and heal . — made [her]3129-his daughter quite sorry to acknowledge that [they]3446-they had transcribed it some pages ago already . “[128-kitty] Why will not [you]874-you write one [yourself]874-you for [us]875-us , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ? ” said [she]3129-his daughter ; “[874-you] that is the only security for its freshness ; and nothing could be easier to [you]874-you . ” “[876-the stupidest fellow] Oh no ! [he]91-mr. elton had never written , hardly ever , any thing of the kind in [his]91-mr. elton life . [The stupidest fellow]876-the stupidest fellow ! [He]91-mr. elton was afraid not even [Miss Woodhouse”—he]129-miss woodhouse”—he stopt a moment—“or[107-harriet] [Miss Smith]107-harriet could inspire [him]91-mr. elton . ” The very next day however produced some proof of inspiration . [He]0-i called for a few moments , just to leave a piece of paper on the table containing , as [he]0-i said , a charade , which [a friend of [his]0-i]3447-a friend of his had addressed to [a young lady]467-a young lady , the object of [his]0-i admiration , but which , from [his]0-i manner , [Emma]79-emma was immediately convinced must be [his]0-i own . “[107-harriet] [I]0-i do not offer it for [Miss Smith]107-harriet ’s collection , ” said [he]0-i . “[0-i] Being [[my]0-i friend]877-my friend ’s , [I]0-i have no right to expose it in any degree to the public eye , but perhaps [you]878-you may not dislike looking at it . ” The speech was more to [Emma]79-emma than to [Harriet]107-harriet , which [Emma]79-emma could understand . There was deep consciousness about [him]0-i , and [he]0-i found it easier to meet [her]79-emma eye than [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend ’s . [He]0-i was gone the next moment:—after another moment ’s pause , “[878-you] Take it , ” said [Emma]79-emma , smiling , and pushing the paper towards [Harriet—“it]130-harriet—“it[878-you] is for [you]878-you . Take [your]878-you own . ” But [Harriet]107-harriet was in a tremor , and could not touch it ; and [Emma]79-emma , never loth to be first , was obliged to examine it [herself]79-emma . To [Miss]3450-miss — — CHARADE . [My]878-you first displays the wealth and pomp of [kings]3451-kings , [Lords of [the earth]3453-the earth]3452-lords of the earth ! [their]3452-lords of the earth luxury and ease . Another view of [man]3454-man , [my]878-you second brings , Behold [him]3454-man there , [the monarch of [the seas]3456-the seas]3455-the monarch of the seas ! But ah ! united , what reverse [we]3457-we have ! [Man]3454-man ’s boasted power and freedom , [all are flown]3459-all are flown ; Lord of [the earth]3453-the earth and [sea]3461-sea , [he]3454-man bends [a slave]3462-a slave , And [woman]3428-woman , [lovely woman]3464-lovely woman , reigns alone . [Thy]3465-thy ready wit the word will soon supply , May its approval beam in that soft eye ! [She]107-harriet cast [her]107-harriet eye over it , pondered , caught the meaning , read it through again to be quite certain , and quite mistress of the lines , and then passing it to [Harriet]107-harriet , sat happily smiling , and saying to [herself]107-harriet , while [Harriet]107-harriet was puzzling over the paper in all the confusion of hope and dulness , “[878-you] Very well , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , very well indeed . [I]0-i have read worse charades . Courtship — a very good hint . [I]0-i give [you]0-i credit for it . This is feeling [your]0-i way . This is saying very plainly—‘Pray , [Miss Smith]107-harriet , give [me]0-i leave to pay [my]0-i addresses to [you]0-i . Approve [my]0-i charade and [my]0-i intentions in the same glance . ’ May its approval beam in that soft eye ! [Harriet]107-harriet exactly . Soft is the very word for [her]107-harriet eye — of all epithets , the justest that could be given . [Thy]107-harriet ready wit the word will soon supply . Humph — [Harriet]107-harriet ’s ready wit ! All the better . [A man]548-a man must be very much in love , indeed , to describe [her]107-harriet so . Ah ! [Mr. Knightley]127-mr. knightley , [I]0-i wish [you]127-mr. knightley had the benefit of this ; [I]0-i think this would convince [you]127-mr. knightley . For once in [your]127-mr. knightley life [you]127-mr. knightley would be obliged to own [yourself]127-mr. knightley mistaken . An excellent charade indeed ! and very much to the purpose . Things must come to a crisis soon now . ” [She]107-harriet was obliged to break off from these very pleasant observations , which were otherwise of a sort to run into great length , by the eagerness of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s wondering questions . “[880-miss woodhouse?—what] What can it be , [Miss Woodhouse?—what]880-miss woodhouse?—what can it be ? [I]0-i have not an idea — [I]0-i can not guess it in the least . What can it possibly be ? Do try to find it out , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield . Do help [me]0-i . [I]0-i never saw any thing so hard . Is it kingdom ? [I]0-i wonder who [the friend]881-the friend was — and who could be [the young lady]882-the young lady . Do [you]127-mr. knightley think it is a good one ? Can it be [woman]3428-woman ? And [woman]3428-woman , [lovely woman]3464-lovely woman , reigns alone . Can it be [Neptune]131-neptune ? Behold [him]131-neptune there , [the monarch of]886-the monarch of [the seas]3456-the seas ! Or a trident ? or [a mermaid]888-a mermaid ? or a shark ? Oh , no ! shark is only one syllable . It must be very clever , or [he]131-neptune would not have brought it . Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , do [you]90-hartfield think [we]889-we shall ever find it out ? ” “[90-hartfield] [Mermaids]890-mermaids and sharks ! Nonsense ! [[My]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Harriet]107-harriet , what are [you]107-harriet thinking of ? Where would be the use of [his]131-neptune bringing [us]889-we a charade made by [a friend]405-a friend upon a mermaid or a shark ? Give [me]0-i the paper and listen . For [Miss]893-miss — — — , read [Miss Smith]107-harriet . [My]0-i first displays the wealth and pomp of [kings]3451-kings , [Lords of the earth]3452-lords of the earth ! That is ship;—plain as it can be.—Now for the cream . But ah ! united , ( courtship , [you]107-harriet know , ) what reverse [we]889-we have ! [Man]3454-man ’s boasted power and freedom , all are flown . A very proper compliment!—and then follows the application , which [I]0-i think , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Harriet]107-harriet , [you]107-harriet can not find much difficulty in comprehending . Read it in comfort to [yourself]107-harriet . There can be no doubt of its being written for [you]107-harriet and to [you]107-harriet . ” [Harriet]107-harriet could not long resist so delightful a persuasion . [She]107-harriet read the concluding lines , and was all flutter and happiness . [She]107-harriet could not speak . But [she]107-harriet was not wanted to speak . It was enough for [her]107-harriet to feel . [Emma]79-emma spoke for [her]107-harriet . “[107-harriet] There is so pointed , and so particular a meaning in this compliment , ” said [she]107-harriet , “[91-mr. elton] that [I]0-i can not have a doubt as to [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s intentions . [You]107-harriet are [his]91-mr. elton object — and [you]107-harriet will soon receive the completest proof of it . [I]0-i thought it must be so . [I]0-i thought [I]0-i could not be so deceived ; but now , it is clear ; the state of [his]91-mr. elton mind is as clear and decided , as [my]0-i wishes on the subject have been ever since [I]0-i knew [you]107-harriet . Yes , [Harriet]107-harriet , just so long have [I]0-i been wanting the very circumstance to happen that has happened . [I]0-i could never tell whether an attachment between [you]107-harriet and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton were most desirable or most natural . [Its]906-its probability and its eligibility have really so equalled each other ! [I]0-i am very happy . [I]0-i congratulate [you]107-harriet , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Harriet]107-harriet , with all [my]0-i heart . This is an attachment which [a woman]3207-a woman may well feel pride in creating . This is a connexion which offers nothing but good . It will give [you]107-harriet every thing that [you]107-harriet want — consideration , independence , a proper home — it will fix [you]107-harriet in the centre of all [[your]107-harriet real friends]909-your real friends , close to [Hartfield]90-hartfield and to [me]0-i , and confirm [our]910-our intimacy for ever . This , [Harriet]107-harriet , is an alliance which can never raise a blush in either of [us]910-our . ” “[132-miss woodhouse] [Dear Miss Woodhouse!”—and]132-miss woodhouse “[132-miss woodhouse] [Dear Miss Woodhouse]132-miss woodhouse , ” was all that [Harriet]107-harriet , with many tender embraces could articulate at first ; but when [they]910-our did arrive at something more like conversation , it was sufficiently clear to [[her]107-harriet friend]417-her friend that [she]107-harriet saw , felt , anticipated , and remembered just as [she]107-harriet ought . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s superiority had very ample acknowledgment . “[132-miss woodhouse] Whatever [you]132-miss woodhouse say is always right , ” cried [Harriet]107-harriet , “[132-miss woodhouse] and therefore [I]0-i suppose , and believe , and hope it must be so ; but otherwise [I]0-i could not have imagined it . It is so much beyond any thing [I]0-i deserve . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , who might marry any body ! There can not be two opinions about [him]91-mr. elton . [He]91-mr. elton is so very superior . Only think of those sweet verses—‘To Miss — — — . ’ Dear [me]0-i , how clever!—Could it really be meant for [me]0-i ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i can not make a question , or listen to a question about that . [I]0-i am sure , a month ago , [I]0-i had no more idea myself!—The strangest things do take place ! ” “[912-they] When [Miss Smiths]133-miss smiths and [Mr. Eltons]134-the eltons get acquainted — [they]912-they do indeed — and really it is strange ; it is out of the common course that what is so evidently , so palpably desirable — what courts the pre - arrangement of [other people]445-other people , should so immediately shape itself into the proper form . [You]914-you and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton are by situation called together ; [you]914-you belong to [one another]3150-one another by every circumstance of [[your]914-you respective homes]916-your respective homes . [Your]914-you marrying will be equal to the match at [Randalls]97-randalls . There does seem to be a something in the air of [Hartfield]90-hartfield which gives love exactly the right direction , and sends it into the very channel where it ought to flow . The course of true love never did run smooth — A Hartfield edition of Shakespeare would have a long note on that passage . ” “[91-mr. elton] That [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton should really be in love with [me,—me]917-me,—me , of all people , who did not know [him]91-mr. elton , to speak to [him]91-mr. elton , at Michaelmas ! [He]91-mr. elton was arm - in - arm with [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole . ” “[135-mr. cole] This is an alliance which , whoever — whatever [[your]925-you friends]926-your friends may be , must be agreeable to [them]926-your friends , provided at least [they]926-your friends have common sense ; and [we]924-we are not to be addressing [our]924-we conduct to [fools]927-fools . This charade!—If [I]0-i had studied a twelvemonth , [I]0-i could never have made any thing like it . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i thought [he]91-mr. elton meant to try [his]91-mr. elton skill , by [his]91-mr. elton manner of declining it yesterday . ” “[91-mr. elton] [I]0-i do think it is , without exception , the best charade [I]0-i ever read . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i never read one more to the purpose , certainly . ” “[0-i] It is as long again as almost all [we]931-we have had before . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do not consider its length as particularly in its favour . Such things in general can not be too short . ” [Harriet]107-harriet was too intent on the lines to hear . The most satisfactory comparisons were rising in [her]107-harriet mind . “[0-i] It is one thing , ” said [she]107-harriet , presently — [her]107-harriet cheeks in a glow—“to[0-i] have very good sense in a common way , like every body else , and if there is any thing to say , to sit down and write a letter , and say just what [you]925-you must , in a short way ; and another , to write verses and charades like this . ” [Emma]79-emma could not have desired a more spirited rejection of [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin ’s prose . “[132-miss woodhouse] Such sweet lines ! ” continued [Harriet—“these]136-harriet—“these[132-miss woodhouse] two last!—But how shall [I]0-i ever be able to return the paper , or say [I]0-i have found it out?—Oh ! The couplet does not cease to be , nor does its meaning change . But take it away , and all appropriation ceases , and a very pretty gallant charade remains , fit for any collection . [He]118-henry wishes [[his]118-henry boys]997-his boys to be active and hardy ; and if [they]997-his boys misbehave , can give [them]997-his boys a sharp word now and then ; but [he]118-henry is [an affectionate father]998-an affectionate father — certainly [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley is [an affectionate father]998-an affectionate father . [The children]3286-the children are all fond of [him]118-henry . ” “[3286-the children] And then [[their]3286-the children uncle]1001-their uncle comes in , and tosses [them]3286-the children up to the ceiling in a very frightful way ! ” “[1001-their uncle] But [they]3286-the children like it , [papa]3114-papa ; there is nothing [they]3286-the children like so much . It is such enjoyment to [them]3286-the children , that if [[their]3286-the children uncle]1001-their uncle did not lay down the rule of [their]3286-the children taking turns , whichever began would never give way to the other . ” “[3114-papa] Well , [I]0-i can not understand it . ” “[3114-papa] That is the case with [us]1004-us all , [papa]3114-papa . [One half of [the world]392-the world]1006-one half of the world can not understand the pleasures of the other . ” Later in the morning , and just as [the girls]3337-the girls were going to separate in preparation for the regular four o’clock dinner , [the hero of this inimitable charade]3472-the hero of this inimitable charade walked in again . [Harriet]107-harriet turned away ; but [Emma]79-emma could receive [him]118-henry with the usual smile , and [her]79-emma quick eye soon discerned in [his]118-henry the consciousness of having made a push — of having thrown a die ; and [she]79-emma imagined [he]118-henry was come to see how it might turn up . [His]118-henry ostensible reason , however , was to ask whether [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s party could be made up in the evening without [him]118-henry , or whether [he]118-henry should be in the smallest degree necessary at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . If [he]118-henry were , every thing else must give way ; but otherwise [[his]118-henry friend]3473-his friend [Cole]135-mr. cole had been saying so much about [his]118-henry dining with [him]118-henry — had made such a point of it , that [he]118-henry had promised [him]118-henry conditionally to come . [Emma]79-emma thanked [him]118-henry , but could not allow of [his]118-henry disappointing [[his]118-henry friend]3473-his friend on [their]1009-their account ; [[her]79-emma father]415-her father was sure of [his]415-her father rubber . [He]118-henry re - urged — [she]79-emma re - declined ; and [he]118-henry seemed then about to make [his]118-henry bow , when taking the paper from the table , [she]79-emma returned it — “[1006-one half of the world] Oh ! here is the charade [you]1008-you were so obliging as to leave with [us]1009-their ; thank [you]1008-you for the sight of it . [We]1009-their admired it so much , that [I]0-i have ventured to write it into [Miss Smith]107-harriet ’s collection . [[Your]1008-you friend]630-your friend will not take it amiss [I]0-i hope . Of course [I]0-i have not transcribed beyond the first eight lines . ” [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton certainly did not very well know what to say . [He]91-mr. elton looked rather doubtingly — rather confused ; said something about “[0-i] honour,”—glanced at [Emma]79-emma and at [Harriet]107-harriet , and then seeing the book open on the table , took it up , and examined it very attentively . With the view of passing off an awkward moment , [Emma]79-emma smilingly said , “[1008-you] [You]1008-you must make [my]0-i apologies to [[your]1008-you friend]630-your friend ; but so good a charade must not be confined to one or two . [He]630-your friend may be sure of [every woman]1012-every woman ’s approbation while [he]630-your friend writes with such gallantry . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have no hesitation in saying , ” replied [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , though hesitating a good deal while [he]0-i spoke ; “[0-i] [I]0-i have no hesitation in saying — at least if [[my]0-i friend]877-my friend feels at all as [I]0-i do — [I]0-i have not the smallest doubt that , could [he]877-my friend see [his]877-my friend little effusion honoured as [I]0-i see it , ( looking at the book again , and replacing it on the table ) , [he]877-my friend would consider it as the proudest moment of [his]877-my friend life . ” After this speech [he]0-i was gone as soon as possible . [Emma]79-emma could not think it too soon ; for with all [his]0-i good and agreeable qualities , there was a sort of parade in [his]0-i speeches which was very apt to incline [her]79-emma to laugh . [She]79-emma ran away to indulge the inclination , leaving the tender and the sublime of pleasure to [Harriet]107-harriet ’s share . CHAPTER X Though now the middle of December , there had yet been no weather to prevent [the young ladies]3476-the young ladies from tolerably regular exercise ; and on the morrow , [Emma]79-emma had a charitable visit to pay to [a poor sick family]3477-a poor sick family , who lived a little way out of [Highbury]3-highbury . [[Their]3477-a poor sick family road to [this detached cottage]3479-this detached cottage]3478-their road to this detached cottage was down [Vicarage Lane]23-vicarage lane , a lane leading at right angles from [the broad , though irregular , main street of [the place]439-the place]3480-the broad , though irregular , main street of the place ; and , as may be inferred , containing [the blessed abode of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton]3482-the blessed abode of mr. elton . [A few inferior dwellings]3483-a few inferior dwellings were first to be passed , and then , about a quarter of a mile down [the lane]3484-the lane rose [the Vicarage]3485-the vicarage , [an old and not very good house]3486-an old and not very good house , almost as close to [the road]3487-the road as [it]3486-an old and not very good house could be . [It]3486-an old and not very good house had no advantage of situation ; but had been very much smartened up by [the present proprietor]3488-the present proprietor ; and , such as it was , there could be no possibility of [the two friends]3489-the two friends passing [it]3486-an old and not very good house without a slackened pace and observing eyes.—Emma ’s remark was — “[877-my friend] There it is . There go [you]1014-you and [your]1014-you riddle - book one of these days . ”—Harriet ’s was — “[877-my friend] Oh , what a sweet house!—How very beautiful!—There are the yellow curtains that [Miss Nash]113-miss nash admires so much . ” “[113-miss nash] [I]0-i do not often walk this way now , ” said [Emma]79-emma , as [they]3489-the two friends proceeded , “[0-i] but then there will be an inducement , and [I]0-i shall gradually get intimately acquainted with all the hedges , gates , pools and pollards of [this part of [Highbury]3-highbury]1015-this part of highbury . ” [Harriet]107-harriet , [she]107-harriet found , had never in [her]107-harriet life been inside [the Vicarage]3485-the vicarage , and [her]107-harriet curiosity to see it was so extreme , that , considering exteriors and probabilities , [Emma]79-emma could only class it , as a proof of love , with [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s seeing ready wit in [her]107-harriet . “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [we]1016-we could contrive it , ” said [she]107-harriet ; “[0-i] but [I]0-i can not think of any tolerable pretence for going in;—no servant that [I]0-i want to inquire about of [[his]1017-his housekeeper]1018-his housekeeper — no message from [[my]0-i father]3146-my father . ” [She]107-harriet pondered , but could think of nothing . After a mutual silence of some minutes , [Harriet]107-harriet thus began again — “[3146-my father] [I]0-i do so wonder , [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , that [you]80-miss taylor should not be married , or going to be married ! so charming as [you]80-miss taylor are ! ” — [Emma]79-emma laughed , and replied , “[80-miss taylor] [My]0-i being charming , [Harriet]107-harriet , is not quite enough to induce [me]0-i to marry ; [I]0-i must find [other people]445-other people charming — [one other person]1021-one other person at least . And [I]0-i am not only , not going to be married , at present , but have very little intention of ever marrying at all . ” “[80-miss taylor] Ah!—so [you]80-miss taylor say ; but [I]0-i can not believe it . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i must see somebody very superior to any one [I]0-i have seen yet , to be tempted ; [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [you]80-miss taylor know , ( recollecting [herself]0-i , ) is out of the question : and [I]0-i do not wish to see [any such person]1022-any such person . [I]0-i would rather not be tempted . [I]0-i can not really change for the better . If [I]0-i were to marry , [I]0-i must expect to repent it . ” “[1023-dear] [Dear]1023-dear [me!—it]1024-me!—it is so odd to hear [a woman]3207-a woman talk so ! ” — “[3207-a woman] [I]0-i have none of the usual inducements of [women to marry]1026-women to marry . Were [I]0-i to fall in love , indeed , it would be a different thing ! but [I]0-i never have been in love ; it is not [my]0-i way , or [my]0-i nature ; and [I]0-i do not think [I]0-i ever shall . And , without love , [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i should be [a fool]1027-a fool to change such a situation as [mine]0-i . Fortune [I]0-i do not want ; employment [I]0-i do not want ; consequence [I]0-i do not want : [I]0-i believe [few married women]1028-few married women are half as much mistress of [[[their]1028-few married women husband]1029-their husband ’s house]1030-their husband ’s house as [I]0-i am of [Hartfield]90-hartfield ; and never , never could [I]0-i expect to be so truly beloved and important ; so always first and always right in [any man]1031-any man ’s eyes as [I]0-i am in [[my]0-i father]3146-my father ’s . ” “[0-i] But then , to be [an old maid]1033-an old maid at last , like [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ! ” “[1033-an old maid] That is as formidable an image as [you]1034-you could present , [Harriet]107-harriet ; and if [I]0-i thought [I]0-i should ever be like [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ! so silly — so satisfied — so smiling — so prosing — so undistinguishing and unfastidious — and so apt to tell every thing relative to every body about [me]0-i , [I]0-i would marry to - morrow . But between [us]1035-us , [I]0-i am convinced there never can be any likeness , except in being unmarried . ” “[0-i] But still , [you]0-i will be [an old maid]1033-an old maid ! and that ’s so dreadful ! ” “[1033-an old maid] Never mind , [Harriet]107-harriet , [I]0-i shall not be [a poor old maid]1037-a poor old maid ; and it is poverty only which makes celibacy contemptible to [a generous public]1038-a generous public ! [A single woman]1039-a single woman , with a very narrow income , must be [a ridiculous , disagreeable old maid]1040-a ridiculous , disagreeable old maid ! the proper sport of [boys]1041-boys and [girls]3282-girls , but [a single woman , of good fortune]1043-a single woman , of good fortune , is always respectable , and may be as sensible and pleasant as any body else . And the distinction is not quite so much against the candour and common sense of [the world]392-the world as appears at first ; for a very narrow income has a tendency to contract the mind , and sour the temper . [Those who can barely live]1045-those who can barely live , and who live perforce in a very small , and generally very inferior , society , may well be illiberal and cross . This does not apply , however , to [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ; [she]101-miss bates is only too good natured and too silly to suit [me]0-i ; but , in general , [she]101-miss bates is very much to the taste of every body , though single and though poor . [Poverty]140-poverty certainly has not contracted [her]101-miss bates mind : [I]0-i really believe , if [she]101-miss bates had only a shilling in [the world]392-the world , [she]101-miss bates would be very likely to give away sixpence of it ; and [nobody]3124-nobody is afraid of [her]101-miss bates : that is a great charm . ” “[3124-nobody] Dear [me]0-i ! but what shall [you]0-i do ? how shall [you]0-i employ [yourself]0-i when [you]0-i grow old ? ” “[0-i] If [I]0-i know [myself]0-i , [Harriet]107-harriet , [mine]0-i is an active , busy mind , with a great many independent resources ; and [I]0-i do not perceive why [I]0-i should be more in want of employment at forty or fifty than one - and - twenty . [Woman]3428-woman ’s usual occupations of hand and mind will be as open to [me]0-i then as they are now ; or with no important variation . If [I]0-i draw less , [I]0-i shall read more ; if [I]0-i give up music , [I]0-i shall take to carpet - work . And as for objects of interest , objects for the affections , which is in truth the great point of inferiority , the want of which is really the great evil to be avoided in not marrying , [I]0-i shall be very well off , with [all the children of [a sister]1050-a sister [I]0-i love so much , to care about]1049-all the children of a sister i love so much , to care about . There will be enough of [them]1049-all the children of a sister i love so much , to care about , in all probability , to supply every sort of sensation that declining life can need . There will be enough for every hope and every fear ; and though [my]0-i attachment to none can equal that of [a parent]1051-a parent , it suits [my]0-i ideas of comfort better than what is warmer and blinder . [[My]0-i nephews]1052-my nephews and [nieces!—I]1053-nieces!—i shall often have [a niece]1054-a niece with [me]0-i . ” “[1054-a niece] Do [you]0-i know [[Miss Bates]101-miss bates ’s niece]1055-miss bates ’s niece ? That is , [I]0-i know [you]0-i must have seen [her]1055-miss bates ’s niece a hundred times — but are [you]0-i acquainted ? ” “[0-i] Oh ! yes ; [we]1056-we are always forced to be acquainted whenever [she]1055-miss bates ’s niece comes to [Highbury]3-highbury . By the bye , that is almost enough to put one out of conceit with [a niece]1054-a niece . Heaven forbid ! at least , that [I]0-i should ever bore [people]704-people half so much about all [the Knightleys]141-the mr. knightleys together , as [she]1055-miss bates ’s niece does about [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . [One]475-one is sick of the very name of [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . Every letter from [her]1055-miss bates ’s niece is read forty times over ; [her]1055-miss bates ’s niece compliments to [all friends]1060-all friends go round and round again ; and if [she]1055-miss bates ’s niece does but send [[her]1055-miss bates ’s niece aunt]1061-her aunt the pattern of a stomacher , or knit a pair of garters for [[her]1055-miss bates ’s niece grandmother]1062-her grandmother , [one]475-one hears of nothing else for a month . [I]0-i wish [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax very well ; but [she]1055-miss bates ’s niece tires [me]0-i to death . ” [They]3491-they were now approaching [the cottage]3492-the cottage , and all idle topics were superseded . [Emma]79-emma was very compassionate ; and the distresses of [the poor]3493-the poor were as sure of relief from [her]79-emma personal attention and kindness , [her]79-emma counsel and [her]79-emma patience , as from [her]79-emma purse . [She]79-emma understood [their]3493-the poor ways , could allow for [their]3493-the poor ignorance and [their]3493-the poor temptations , had no romantic expectations of extraordinary virtue from [those for whom education had done so little]3494-those for whom education had done so little ; entered into [their]3493-the poor troubles with ready sympathy , and always gave [her]79-emma assistance with as much intelligence as good - will . In the present instance , it was sickness and poverty together which [she]79-emma came to visit ; and after remaining there as long as [she]79-emma could give comfort or advice , [she]79-emma quitted [the cottage]3492-the cottage with such an impression of the scene as made [her]79-emma say to [Harriet]107-harriet , as [they]3493-the poor walked away , “[1055-miss bates ’s niece] These are the sights , [Harriet]107-harriet , to do one good . How trifling [they]1064-they make every thing else appear!—I feel now as if [I]0-i could think of nothing but [these poor creatures]1065-these poor creatures all the rest of the day ; and yet , who can say how soon it may all vanish from [my]0-i mind ? ” “[107-harriet] Very true , ” said [Harriet]107-harriet . “[1066-poor creatures] [Poor creatures]1066-poor creatures ! [one]475-one can think of nothing else . ” “[475-one] And really , [I]0-i do not think the impression will soon be over , ” said [Emma]79-emma , as [she]79-emma crossed the low hedge , and tottering footstep which ended the narrow , slippery path through [the cottage garden]3496-the cottage garden , and brought [them]3493-the poor into [the lane]3484-the lane again . “[0-i] [I]0-i do not think it will , ” stopping to look once more at all the outward wretchedness of [the place]439-the place , and recall the still greater within . “[0-i] Oh ! dear , no , ” said [[her]79-emma companion]3365-her companion . [They]3493-the poor walked on . [The lane]3484-the lane made a slight bend ; and when that bend was passed , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was immediately in sight ; and so near as to give [Emma]79-emma time only to say farther , “[0-i] Ah ! [Harriet]107-harriet , here comes a very sudden trial of [our]1068-we stability in good thoughts . Well , ( smiling , ) [I]0-i hope it may be allowed that if compassion has produced exertion and relief to [the sufferers]1069-the sufferers , it has done all that is truly important . If [we]1068-we feel for the wretched , enough to do all [we]1068-we can for [them]1069-the sufferers , the rest is empty sympathy , only distressing to [ourselves]1068-we . ” [Harriet]107-harriet could just answer , “[0-i] Oh ! dear , yes , ” before [the gentleman]3371-the gentleman joined [them]3493-the poor . The wants and sufferings of [the poor family]3502-the poor family , however , were [the first subject on meeting]3503-the first subject on meeting . [He]3371-the gentleman had been going to call on [them]3493-the poor . [His]3371-the gentleman visit [he]3371-the gentleman would now defer ; but [they]3493-the poor had a very interesting parley about what could be done and should be done . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton then turned back to accompany [them]3493-the poor . “[0-i] To fall in with [each other]420-each other on such an errand as this , ” thought [Emma]79-emma ; “[0-i] to meet in a charitable scheme ; this will bring a great increase of love on each side . [I]0-i should not wonder if it were to bring on the declaration . It must , if [I]0-i were not [here]3113-here . [I]0-i wish [I]0-i were anywhere else . ” Anxious to separate [herself]79-emma from [them]3493-the poor as far as [she]79-emma could , [she]79-emma soon afterwards took possession of a narrow footpath , a little raised on [one side of [the lane]3484-the lane]3504-one side of the lane , leaving [them]3493-the poor together in [the main road]3506-the main road . But [she]79-emma had not been there two minutes when [she]79-emma found that [Harriet]107-harriet ’s habits of dependence and imitation were bringing [her]79-emma up too , and that , in short , [they]3493-the poor would both be soon after [her]79-emma . This would not do ; [she]79-emma immediately stopped , under pretence of having some alteration to make in the lacing of [her]79-emma half - boot , and stooping down in complete occupation of [the footpath]3507-the footpath , begged [them]3493-the poor to have the goodness to walk on , and [she]79-emma would follow in half a minute . [They]3493-the poor did as [they]3493-the poor were desired ; and by the time [she]79-emma judged it reasonable to have done with [her]79-emma boot , [she]79-emma had the comfort of farther delay in [her]79-emma power , being overtaken by [a child from [the cottage]3492-the cottage]3508-a child from the cottage , setting out , according to orders , with [her]79-emma pitcher , to fetch broth from [Hartfield]90-hartfield . To walk by the side of [this child]3510-this child , and talk to and question [her]3510-this child , was the most natural thing in [the world]392-the world , or would have been the most natural , had [she]3510-this child been acting just then without design ; and by this means [the others]3512-the others were still able to keep ahead , without any obligation of waiting for [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma gained on [them]3493-the poor , however , involuntarily : [the child]3193-the child ’s pace was quick , and theirs rather slow ; and [she]79-emma was the more concerned at it , from [their]3493-the poor being evidently in a conversation which interested [them]3493-the poor . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was speaking with animation , [Harriet]107-harriet listening with a very pleased attention ; and [Emma]79-emma , having sent [the child]3193-the child on , was beginning to think how [she]79-emma might draw back a little more , when [they]3493-the poor both looked around , and [she]79-emma was obliged to join [them]3493-the poor . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was still talking , still engaged in some interesting detail ; and [Emma]79-emma experienced some disappointment when [she]79-emma found that [he]91-mr. elton was only giving [[his]91-mr. elton fair companion]3515-his fair companion an account of the yesterday ’s party at [[his]91-mr. elton friend]3473-his friend [Cole]135-mr. cole ’s , and that [she]3515-his fair companion was come in [herself]3515-his fair companion for the Stilton cheese , [the north Wiltshire]3517-the north wiltshire , the butter , the celery , the beet - root , and all the dessert . “[0-i] This would soon have led to something better , of course , ” was [her]79-emma consoling reflection ; “[0-i] any thing interests between [those who love]1072-those who love ; and any thing will serve as introduction to what is near the heart . If [I]0-i could but have kept longer away ! ” [They]3493-the poor now walked on together quietly , till within view of [the vicarage pales]3518-the vicarage pales , when a sudden resolution , of at least getting [Harriet]107-harriet into [the house]425-the house , made [her]107-harriet again find something very much amiss about [her]107-harriet boot , and fall behind to arrange it once more . [She]107-harriet then broke the lace off short , and dexterously throwing it into a ditch , was presently obliged to entreat [them]3493-the poor to stop , and acknowledged [her]107-harriet inability to put [herself]107-harriet to rights so as to be able to walk [home]3258-home in tolerable comfort . “[0-i] Part of [my]0-i lace is gone , ” said [she]107-harriet , “[0-i] and [I]0-i do not know how [I]0-i am to contrive . [I]0-i really am [a most troublesome companion to [you]1074-them both]1073-a most troublesome companion to you both , but [I]0-i hope [I]0-i am not often so ill - equipped . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [I]0-i must beg leave to stop at [[your]91-mr. elton house]1075-your house , and ask [[your]91-mr. elton housekeeper]1076-your housekeeper for a bit of ribband or string , or any thing just to keep [my]0-i boot on . ” [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton looked all happiness at this proposition ; and nothing could exceed [his]91-mr. elton alertness and attention in conducting [them]1074-them into [[his]91-mr. elton house]398-his house and endeavouring to make every thing appear to advantage . [The room [they]1074-them were taken into]3522-the room they were taken into was [the one [he]91-mr. elton chiefly occupied]3523-the one he chiefly occupied , and looking forwards ; behind [it]3522-the room they were taken into was another with which [it]3522-the room they were taken into immediately communicated ; the door between [them]1074-them was open , and [Emma]79-emma passed into [it]3522-the room they were taken into with [the housekeeper]3524-the housekeeper to receive [her]79-emma assistance in the most comfortable manner . [She]79-emma was obliged to leave the door ajar as [she]79-emma found it ; but [she]79-emma fully intended that [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton should close [it]3522-the room they were taken into . It was not closed , however , [it]3522-the room they were taken into still remained ajar ; but by engaging [the housekeeper]3524-the housekeeper in incessant conversation , [she]79-emma hoped to make it practicable for [him]91-mr. elton to chuse [his]91-mr. elton own subject in [the adjoining room]3526-the adjoining room . For ten minutes [she]79-emma could hear nothing but [herself]79-emma . It could be protracted no longer . [She]79-emma was then obliged to be finished , and make [her]79-emma appearance . [The lovers]3527-the lovers were standing together at one of the windows . [It]3528-it had a most favourable aspect ; and , for half a minute , [Emma]79-emma felt the glory of having schemed successfully . But it would not do ; [he]1077-he had not come to the point . [He]1077-he had been most agreeable , most delightful ; [he]1077-he had told [Harriet]107-harriet that [he]1077-he had seen [them]3527-the lovers go by , and had purposely followed [them]3527-the lovers ; other little gallantries and allusions had been dropt , but nothing serious . “[1076-your housekeeper] Cautious , very cautious , ” thought [Emma]79-emma ; “[1077-he] [he]1077-he advances inch by inch , and will hazard nothing till [he]1077-he believes [himself]1077-he secure . ” Still , however , though every thing had not been accomplished by [her]79-emma ingenious device , [she]79-emma could not but flatter [herself]79-emma that it had been the occasion of much present enjoyment to both , and must be leading [them]3527-the lovers forward to the great event . [CHAPTER XI Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton must now be left to [himself]1077-he . It was no longer in [Emma]79-emma ’s power to superintend [his]1077-he happiness or quicken [his]1077-he measures . The coming of [[[her]79-emma sister]396-her sister ’s family]3530-her sister ’s family was so very near at hand , that first in anticipation , and then in reality , it became henceforth [her]79-emma prime object of interest ; and during the ten days of [their]3527-the lovers stay at [Hartfield]90-hartfield it was not to be expected — [she]79-emma did not [herself]79-emma expect — that any thing beyond occasional , fortuitous assistance could be afforded by [her]79-emma to [the lovers]3527-the lovers . [They]3527-the lovers might advance rapidly if [they]3527-the lovers would , however ; [they]3527-the lovers must advance somehow or other whether [they]3527-the lovers would or no . [She]79-emma hardly wished to have more leisure for [them]3527-the lovers . There are [people]704-people , who the more [you]3533-you do for [them]704-people , the less [they]704-people will do for [themselves]704-people . [Mr.]3534-mr. and [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley , from having been longer than usual absent from [Surry]24-surry , were exciting of course rather more than the usual interest . Till this year , every long vacation since [their]3527-the lovers marriage had been divided between [Hartfield]90-hartfield and [Donwell Abbey]202-donwell ; but all the holidays of this autumn had been given to sea - bathing for [the children]3286-the children , and it was therefore many months since [they]3286-the children had been seen in a regular way by [their]3286-the children Surry connexions , or seen at all by [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , who could not be induced to get so far as [London]1-london , even for poor [Isabella]83-isabella ’s sake ; and who consequently was now most nervously and apprehensively happy in forestalling this too short visit . [He]3534-mr. thought much of the evils of the journey for [her]83-isabella , and not a little of the fatigues of [his]3534-mr. own horses and coachman who were to bring [some of the party]3536-some of the party the last half of the way ; but [his]3534-mr. alarms were needless ; the sixteen miles being happily accomplished , and [Mr.]3537-mr. and [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley , [[their]3527-the lovers five children]3538-their five children , and [a competent number of [nursery - maids]3540-nursery - maids]3539-a competent number of nursery - maids , all reaching [Hartfield]90-hartfield in safety . The bustle and joy of such an arrival , [the many to be talked]3541-the many to be talked to , welcomed , encouraged , and variously dispersed and disposed of , produced a noise and confusion which [his]3534-mr. nerves could not have borne under any other cause , nor have endured much longer even for this ; but the ways of [Hartfield]90-hartfield and the feelings of [[her]83-isabella father]415-her father were so respected by [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley , that in spite of maternal solicitude for the immediate enjoyment of [[her]117-mrs. john knightley little ones]3543-her little ones , and for [their]3543-her little ones having instantly all the liberty and attendance , all the eating and drinking , and sleeping and playing , which [they]3543-her little ones could possibly wish for , without the smallest delay , [the children]3286-the children were never allowed to be long a disturbance to [him]3534-mr. , either in [themselves]3286-the children or in any restless attendance on [them]3286-the children . [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley was [a pretty , elegant little woman , of gentle , quiet manners]3545-a pretty , elegant little woman , of gentle , quiet manners , and a disposition remarkably amiable and affectionate ; wrapt up in [[her]117-mrs. john knightley family]578-her family ; [a devoted wife]3547-a devoted wife , [a doating mother]3548-a doating mother , and so tenderly attached to [[her]117-mrs. john knightley father]415-her father and [sister]977-sister that , but for these higher ties , a warmer love might have seemed impossible . [She]117-mrs. john knightley could never see a fault in any of [them]3543-her little ones . [She]117-mrs. john knightley was not [a woman of strong understanding or any quickness]3551-a woman of strong understanding or any quickness ; and with this resemblance of [[her]117-mrs. john knightley father]415-her father , [she]117-mrs. john knightley inherited also much of [his]415-her father constitution ; was delicate in [her]117-mrs. john knightley own health , over - careful of that of [[her]117-mrs. john knightley children]456-her children , had many fears and many nerves , and was as fond of [[her]117-mrs. john knightley own Mr. Wingfield in [town]3165-town as [[her]117-mrs. john knightley father]415-her father could be of [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry]3554-her own mr. wingfield in town as her father could be of mr. perry . [They]3543-her little ones were alike too , in a general benevolence of temper , and a strong habit of regard for [every old acquaintance]3557-every old acquaintance . [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley was [a tall , gentleman - like , and very clever man]3558-a tall , gentleman - like , and very clever man ; rising in [his]88-mr. knightley profession , domestic , and respectable in [his]88-mr. knightley private character ; but with reserved manners which prevented [his]88-mr. knightley being generally pleasing ; and capable of being sometimes out of humour . [He]88-mr. knightley was not [an ill - tempered man]3559-an ill - tempered man , not so often unreasonably cross as to deserve such a reproach ; but [his]88-mr. knightley temper was not [his]88-mr. knightley great perfection ; and , indeed , with such [a worshipping wife]3560-a worshipping wife , it was hardly possible that any natural defects in it should not be increased . The extreme sweetness of [her]3560-a worshipping wife temper must hurt [his]88-mr. knightley . [He]88-mr. knightley had all the clearness and quickness of mind which [she]3560-a worshipping wife wanted , and [he]88-mr. knightley could sometimes act an ungracious , or say a severe thing . [He]88-mr. knightley was not [a great favourite with [[his]88-mr. knightley fair sister - in - law]3562-his fair sister - in - law]3561-a great favourite with his fair sister - in - law . Nothing wrong in [him]88-mr. knightley escaped [her]3560-a worshipping wife . [She]3560-a worshipping wife was quick in feeling the little injuries to [Isabella]83-isabella , which [Isabella]83-isabella never felt [herself]83-isabella . Perhaps [she]3560-a worshipping wife might have passed over more had [his]88-mr. knightley manners been flattering to [[Isabella]83-isabella ’s sister]3563-isabella ’s sister , but they were only those of [a calmly kind brother]3564-a calmly kind brother and [friend , without praise and without blindness]3565-friend , without praise and without blindness ; but hardly any degree of personal compliment could have made [her]3560-a worshipping wife regardless of that greatest fault of all in [her]3560-a worshipping wife eyes which [he]88-mr. knightley sometimes fell into , the want of respectful forbearance towards [[her]3560-a worshipping wife father]415-her father . There [he]88-mr. knightley had not always the patience that could have been wished . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s peculiarities and fidgetiness were sometimes provoking [him]88-mr. knightley to a rational remonstrance or sharp retort equally ill - bestowed . It did not often happen ; for [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley had really a great regard for [[his]88-mr. knightley father - in - law]3567-his father - in - law , and generally a strong sense of what was due to [him]88-mr. knightley ; but it was too often for [Emma]79-emma ’s charity , especially as there was all the pain of apprehension frequently to be endured , though the offence came not . The beginning , however , of every visit displayed none but the properest feelings , and this being of necessity so short might be hoped to pass away in unsullied cordiality . [They]3568-they had not been long seated and composed when [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , with a melancholy shake of the head and a sigh , called [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter ’s attention to the sad change at [Hartfield]90-hartfield since [she]80-miss taylor had been [there]437-there last . “[3120-my dear] Ah , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , ” said [he]81-mr. woodhouse , “[3120-my dear] poor [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor — It is a grievous business . ” “[80-miss taylor] Oh yes , [sir]3139-sir , ” cried [she]80-miss taylor with ready sympathy , “[80-miss taylor] how [you]3139-sir must miss [her]80-miss taylor ! And [dear Emma]79-emma , too!—What a dreadful loss to [you]79-emma both!—I have been so grieved for you.—I could not imagine how [you]79-emma could possibly do without her.—It is a sad change indeed.—But [I]0-i hope [she]80-miss taylor is pretty well , [sir]3139-sir . ” “[3139-sir] Pretty well , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear — [I]0-i hope — pretty well.—I do not know but that [the place]439-the place agrees with [her]80-miss taylor tolerably . ” [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley here asked [Emma]79-emma quietly whether there were any doubts of the air of [Randalls]97-randalls . “[0-i] Oh ! no — none in the least . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse hesitated.—“Not[3139-sir] near so often , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , as [I]0-i could wish . ” “[3114-papa] Oh ! [They]1087-they are very , very kind in [their]1087-they visits . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston is really as kind as [herself]84-mrs. weston .
