[Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston is rather [an easy , cheerful - tempered man]1128-an easy , cheerful - tempered man , than [a man of strong feelings]1129-a man of strong feelings ; [he]82-mr. weston takes things as [he]82-mr. weston finds them , and makes enjoyment of them somehow or other , depending , [I]0-i suspect , much more upon what is called society for [his]82-mr. weston comforts , that is , upon the power of eating and drinking , and playing whist with [[his]82-mr. weston neighbours]3235-his neighbours five times a week , than upon family affection , or any thing that [home]3258-home affords . ” [Emma]79-emma could not like what bordered on a reflection on [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , and had half a mind to take it up ; but [she]79-emma struggled , and let it pass . [She]79-emma would keep the peace if possible ; and there was something honourable and valuable in the strong domestic habits , the all - sufficiency of [home]3258-home to [himself]82-mr. weston , whence resulted [[her]79-emma brother]3179-her brother ’s disposition to look down on the common rate of social intercourse , and [those to whom it was important.—It]3576-those to whom it was important.—it had a high claim to forbearance . CHAPTER XII [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley was to dine with [them]3577-they — rather against the inclination of [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , who did not like that [any one]611-any one should share with [him]88-mr. knightley in [Isabella]83-isabella ’s first day . [Emma]79-emma ’s sense of right however had decided it ; and besides the consideration of what was due to [each brother]3579-each brother , [she]79-emma had particular pleasure , from the circumstance of the late disagreement between [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [herself]79-emma , in procuring [him]88-mr. knightley the proper invitation . [She]79-emma hoped [they]3577-they might now become [friends]3230-friends again . [She]79-emma thought it was time to make up . Making - up indeed would not do . [She]79-emma certainly had not been in the wrong , and [he]88-mr. knightley would never own that [he]88-mr. knightley had . [Concession]146-concession must be out of the question ; but it was time to appear to forget that [they]3577-they had ever quarrelled ; and [she]79-emma hoped it might rather assist the restoration of friendship , that when [he]88-mr. knightley came into [the room]3386-the room [she]79-emma had one of [the children]3286-the children with [her]79-emma — [the youngest]3583-the youngest , [a nice little girl about eight months old , who was now making [her]3584-a nice little girl about eight months old , who was now making her first visit to hartfield first visit to [Hartfield]90-hartfield]3584-a nice little girl about eight months old , who was now making her first visit to hartfield , and very happy to be danced about in [[her]3584-a nice little girl about eight months old , who was now making her first visit to hartfield aunt]1061-her aunt ’s arms . It did assist ; for though [he]88-mr. knightley began with grave looks and short questions , [he]88-mr. knightley was soon led on to talk of [them]3286-the children all in the usual way , and to take [the child]3193-the child out of [her]3584-a nice little girl about eight months old , who was now making her first visit to hartfield arms with all the unceremoniousness of perfect amity . [Emma]79-emma felt [they]1132-we were [friends]3230-friends again ; and the conviction giving [her]79-emma at first great satisfaction , and then a little sauciness , [she]79-emma could not help saying , as [he]88-mr. knightley was admiring [the baby]3588-the baby , “[1136-women] What a comfort it is , that [we]1132-we think alike about [[our]1132-we nephews]1133-our nephews and [nieces]1134-nieces . As to [men]828-men and [women]1136-women , [our]1132-we opinions are sometimes very different ; but with regard to [these children]1137-these children , [I]0-i observe [we]1132-we never disagree . ” “[0-i] If [you]0-i were as much guided by nature in [your]0-i estimate of [men]828-men and [women]1136-women , and as little under the power of fancy and whim in [your]0-i dealings with [them]1137-these children , as [you]0-i are where [these children]1137-these children are concerned , [we]1132-we might always think alike . ” “[1136-women] To be sure — [our]1132-we discordancies must always arise from [my]0-i being in the wrong . ” “[1136-women] Yes , ” said [he]0-i , smiling—“and[1136-women] reason good . [I]0-i was sixteen years old when [you]0-i were born . ” “[0-i] A material difference then , ” [she]3589-she replied—“and[0-i] no doubt [you]0-i were much [my]0-i superior in judgment at that period of [our]1132-we lives ; but does not the lapse of one - and - twenty years bring [our]1132-we understandings a good deal nearer ? ” “[0-i] Yes — a good deal nearer . ” “[0-i] But still , not near enough to give [me]0-i a chance of being right , if [we]1132-we think differently . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have still the advantage of [you]0-i by sixteen years ’ experience , and by not being [a pretty young woman]1141-a pretty young woman and [a spoiled child]1142-a spoiled child . Come , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , let [us]1132-we be [friends]3230-friends , and say no more about it . Tell [[your]79-emma aunt]1145-your aunt , [little Emma]79-emma , that [she]1145-your aunt ought to set [you]79-emma a better example than to be renewing old grievances , and that if [she]1145-your aunt were not wrong before , [she]1145-your aunt is now . ” “[1145-your aunt] That ’s true , ” [she]79-emma cried—“very[1145-your aunt] true . [Little Emma]79-emma , grow up [a better woman than [[your]79-emma aunt]1145-your aunt]1146-a better woman than your aunt . Be infinitely cleverer and not half so conceited . Now , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , a word or two more , and [I]0-i have done . As far as good intentions went , [we]1132-we were both right , and [I]0-i must say that no effects on [my]0-i side of the argument have yet proved wrong . [I]0-i only want to know that [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin is not very , very bitterly disappointed . ” “[112-mr. martin] [A man]548-a man can not be more so , ” was [his]0-i short , full answer . “[112-mr. martin] Ah!—Indeed [I]0-i am very sorry.—Come , shake hands with [me]0-i . ” This had just taken place and with great cordiality , when [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley made [his]88-mr. knightley appearance , and “[0-i] How [d’ye]1149-d’ye do , [George]119-george ? ” and “[119-george] [John]88-mr. knightley , how are [you]88-mr. knightley ? ” succeeded in the true English style , burying under a calmness that seemed all but indifference , the real attachment which would have led either of [them]1132-we , if requisite , to do every thing for the good of the other . The evening was quiet and conversable , as [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse declined cards entirely for the sake of comfortable talk with [[his]81-mr. woodhouse dear]3590-his dear [Isabella]83-isabella , and [the little party]3591-the little party made two natural divisions ; on one side [he]81-mr. woodhouse and [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter ; on the other the two [Mr. Knightleys]141-the mr. knightleys ; [[their]1132-we subjects]3593-their subjects totally distinct , or very rarely mixing — and [Emma]79-emma only occasionally joining in one or the other . [The brothers]3594-the brothers talked of [their]3594-the brothers own concerns and pursuits , but principally of those of [the elder]3595-the elder , whose temper was by much the most communicative , and who was always [the greater talker]3596-the greater talker . As [a magistrate]3597-a magistrate , [he]81-mr. woodhouse had generally some point of law to consult [John]88-mr. knightley about , or , at least , some curious anecdote to give ; and as [a farmer]511-a farmer , as keeping in hand [the home - farm at [Donwell]202-donwell]3599-the home - farm at donwell , [he]81-mr. woodhouse had to tell what every field was to bear next year , and to give all such local information as could not fail of being interesting to [a brother whose home it had equally been the longest part of [his]81-mr. woodhouse life , and whose attachments were strong]3600-a brother whose home it had equally been the longest part of his life , and whose attachments were strong . The plan of a drain , the change of a fence , the felling of a tree , and the destination of every acre for wheat , turnips , or spring corn , was entered into with as much equality of interest by [John]88-mr. knightley , as [his]88-mr. knightley cooler manners rendered possible ; and if [[his]88-mr. knightley willing brother]3601-his willing brother ever left [him]88-mr. knightley any thing to inquire about , [his]88-mr. knightley inquiries even approached a tone of eagerness . While [they]3602-they were thus comfortably occupied , [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was enjoying a full flow of happy regrets and fearful affection with [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter . “[88-mr. knightley] [[My]0-i poor dear]1150-my poor dear [Isabella]83-isabella , ” said [he]81-mr. woodhouse , fondly taking [her]83-isabella hand , and interrupting , for a few moments , [her]83-isabella busy labours for some one of [her]83-isabella five children—“How[88-mr. knightley] long it is , how terribly long since [you]1151-you were [here]3113-here ! And how tired [you]1151-you must be after [your]1151-you journey ! [You]1151-you must go to bed early , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear — and [I]0-i recommend a little gruel to [you]1151-you before [you]1151-you go.—You and [I]0-i will have a nice basin of gruel together . [[My]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , suppose [we]1155-we all have a little gruel . ” [Emma]79-emma could not suppose any such thing , knowing as [she]79-emma did , that both [the Mr. Knightleys]141-the mr. knightleys were as unpersuadable on that article as [herself;—and]3604-herself;—and two basins only were ordered . After a little more discourse in praise of gruel , with some wondering at its not being taken every evening by [every body]3270-every body , [he]0-i proceeded to say , with an air of grave reflection , “[79-emma] It was an awkward business , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , [your]3120-my dear spending the autumn at [South End]27-south end instead of coming [here]3113-here . [I]0-i never had much opinion of [the sea air]1158-the sea air . ” “[0-i] [Mr. Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield most strenuously recommended it , [sir]3139-sir — or [we]1155-we should not have gone . [He]147-mr. wingfield recommended it for [all the children]1160-all the children , but particularly for the weakness in [little Bella]83-isabella ’s throat,—both sea air and bathing . ” “[147-mr. wingfield] Ah ! [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , but [Perry]102-mr. perry had many doubts about [the sea]1162-the sea doing [her]83-isabella any good ; and as to [myself]0-i , [I]0-i have been long perfectly convinced , though perhaps [I]0-i never told [you]3120-my dear so before , that [the sea]1162-the sea is very rarely of use to [any body]530-any body . [I]0-i am sure it almost killed [me]0-i once . ” “[0-i] Come , come , ” cried [Emma]79-emma , feeling this to be an unsafe subject , “[0-i] [I]0-i must beg [you]3139-sir not to talk of [the sea]1162-the sea . It makes [me]0-i envious and [miserable;—I who have never seen it]1166-miserable;—i who have never seen it ! [South End]27-south end is prohibited , if [you]3139-sir please . [[My]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Isabella]83-isabella , [I]0-i have not heard [you]3120-my dear make one inquiry about [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry yet ; and [he]102-mr. perry never forgets [you]3120-my dear . ” “[102-mr. perry] Oh ! good [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry — how is [he]102-mr. perry , [sir]3139-sir ? ” “[102-mr. perry] Why , pretty well ; but not quite well . [Poor Perry]148-poor perry is bilious , and [he]102-mr. perry has not time to take care of [himself]102-mr. perry — [he]102-mr. perry tells [me]0-i [he]102-mr. perry has not time to take care of [himself]102-mr. perry — which is very sad — but [he]102-mr. perry is always wanted all round [the country]3306-the country . [I]0-i suppose there is [not a man in such practice anywhere]1170-not a man in such practice anywhere . But then there is not so clever [a man]548-a man any where . ” “[100-mrs. perry] And [Mrs. Perry]100-mrs. perry and [the children]3286-the children , how are [they]3286-the children ? do [the children]3286-the children grow ? [I]0-i have a great regard for [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry . [I]0-i hope [he]102-mr. perry will be calling soon . [He]102-mr. perry will be so pleased to see [my]0-i little ones . ” “[102-mr. perry] [I]0-i hope [he]102-mr. perry will be here to - morrow , for [I]0-i have a question or two to ask [him]102-mr. perry about [myself]0-i of some consequence . And , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , whenever [he]102-mr. perry comes , [you]3120-my dear had better let [him]102-mr. perry look at little [Bella]83-isabella ’s throat . ” “[102-mr. perry] Oh ! [[my]0-i dear sir]741-my dear sir , [her]83-isabella throat is so much better that [I]0-i have hardly any uneasiness about it . Either bathing has been of the greatest service to [her]83-isabella , or else it is to be attributed to an excellent embrocation of [Mr. Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield ’s , which [we]1176-we have been applying at times ever since August . ” “[147-mr. wingfield] It is not very likely , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , that bathing should have been of use to [her]83-isabella — and if [I]0-i had known [you]3120-my dear were wanting an embrocation , [I]0-i would have spoken to — “ [You]3120-my dear seem to [me]79-emma to have forgotten [Mrs.]3606-mrs. and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , “ [I]79-emma have not heard one inquiry after [them]3607-them . ”[79-emma] “ Oh ! [the good Bateses]149-the bateses — [I]79-emma am quite ashamed of [myself]79-emma — but [you]3120-my dear mention them in most of [your]3120-my dear letters . [I]79-emma hope they are quite well . [Good old Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates — [I]79-emma will call upon [her]106-mrs. bates to - morrow , and take [[my]79-emma children.—They]3608-my children.—they are always so pleased to see [my]79-emma children.—And that excellent [Miss Bates!—such]150-miss bates!—such thorough worthy people!—How are [they]3607-them , [sir]3139-sir ? ”[79-emma] “ Why , pretty well , [[my]79-emma dear]3120-my dear , upon the whole . But [poor Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates had a bad cold about a month ago . ”[79-emma] “ How sorry [I]79-emma am ! But colds were never so prevalent as they have been this autumn . [Mr. Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield told [me]79-emma that [he]147-mr. wingfield has never known them more general or heavy — except when it has been quite an influenza . ”[79-emma] “ That has been a good deal the case , [[my]79-emma dear]3120-my dear ; but not to the degree [you]3120-my dear mention . [Perry]102-mr. perry says that colds have been very general , but not so heavy as [he]147-mr. wingfield has very often known them in November . [Perry]102-mr. perry does not call it altogether a sickly season . ”[79-emma] “ No , [I]79-emma do not know that [Mr. Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield considers it very sickly except — “[79-emma] Ah ! [[my]0-i poor dear child]1178-my poor dear child , the truth is , that in [London]1-london it is always a sickly season . [Nobody]3124-nobody is healthy in [London]1-london , [nobody]3124-nobody can be . It is a dreadful thing to have [you]1178-my poor dear child forced to live [there]437-there ! so far off!—and the air so bad ! ” “[1182-we] No , indeed — [we]1182-we are not at all in a bad air . [[Our]1182-we part of [London]1-london]1183-our part of london is very superior to most others!—You must not confound [us]1182-we with [London]1-london in general , [[my]0-i dear sir]741-my dear sir . [The neighbourhood of [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square]1185-the neighbourhood of brunswick square is very different from almost [all the rest]1186-all the rest . [We]1182-we are so very airy ! [I]0-i should be unwilling , [I]0-i own , to live in [any other part of [the town;—there]1188-the town;—there]1187-any other part of the town;—there is hardly any other that [I]0-i could be satisfied to have [[my]0-i children]1189-my children in : but [we]1182-we are so remarkably airy!—Mr . [Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield thinks [the vicinity of [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square]1190-the vicinity of brunswick square decidedly the most favourable as to air . ” “[147-mr. wingfield] Ah ! [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , it is not like [Hartfield]90-hartfield . [You]3120-my dear make the best of it — but after [you]3120-my dear have been a week at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [you]3120-my dear are all of [you]3120-my dear different creatures ; [you]3120-my dear do not look like the same . Now [I]0-i can not say , that [I]0-i think [you]3120-my dear are any of [you]3120-my dear looking well at present . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am sorry to hear [you]0-i say so , [sir]3139-sir ; but [I]0-i assure [you]0-i , excepting those little nervous head - aches and palpitations which [I]0-i am never entirely free from anywhere , [I]0-i am quite well [myself]0-i ; and if [the children]3286-the children were rather pale before [they]3286-the children went to bed , it was only because [they]3286-the children were a little more tired than usual , from [their]3286-the children journey and the happiness of coming . [I]0-i hope [you]0-i will think better of [their]3286-the children looks to - morrow ; for [I]0-i assure [you]0-i [Mr. Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield told [me]0-i , that [he]147-mr. wingfield did not believe [he]147-mr. wingfield had ever sent [us]1194-us off altogether , in such good case . [I]0-i trust , at least , that [you]0-i do not think [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley looking ill , ” turning [her]3120-my dear eyes with affectionate anxiety towards [[her]3120-my dear husband]431-her husband . “[88-mr. knightley] Middling , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear ; [I]0-i can not compliment [you]0-i . [I]0-i think [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley very far from looking well . ” “[88-mr. knightley] What is the matter , sir?—Did [you]0-i speak to [me]0-i ? ” cried [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley , hearing [his]0-i own name . “[0-i] [I]0-i am sorry to find , [[my]0-i love]1093-my love , that [[my]0-i father]3146-my father does not think [you]0-i looking well — but [I]0-i hope it is only from being a little fatigued . [I]0-i could have wished , however , as [you]0-i know , that [you]0-i had seen [Mr. Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield before [you]0-i left [home]3258-home . ” “[147-mr. wingfield] [[My]0-i dear]3120-my dear Isabella,”—exclaimed [he]0-i hastily—“pray[0-i] do not concern [yourself]0-i about [my]0-i looks . Be satisfied with doctoring and coddling [yourself]0-i and [the children]3286-the children , and let [me]0-i look as [I]0-i chuse . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i did not thoroughly understand what [you]0-i were telling [[your]0-i brother]1106-your brother , ” cried [Emma]79-emma , “[0-i] about [[your]0-i friend [Mr. Graham]151-mr. graham ’s intending to have [a bailiff from [Scotland]28-scotland]1203-a bailiff from scotland , to look after [[his]151-mr. graham new estate]1204-his new estate]1202-your friend mr. graham ’s intending to have a bailiff from scotland , to look after his new estate . What will it answer ? Will not [the old prejudice]1205-the old prejudice be too strong ? ” And [she]79-emma talked in this way so long and successfully that , when forced to give [her]79-emma attention again to [[her]79-emma father]415-her father and [sister]977-sister , [she]79-emma had nothing worse to hear than [Isabella]83-isabella ’s kind inquiry after [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ; and [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , though no great favourite with [her]79-emma in general , [she]79-emma was at that moment very happy to assist in praising . “[1205-the old prejudice] [That sweet , amiable Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ! ” said [Mrs. John Knightley.—“It]152-mrs. john knightley.—“it[1205-the old prejudice] is so long since [I]0-i have seen [her]142-miss fairfax , except now and then for a moment accidentally in [town]3165-town ! What happiness it must be to [[her]142-miss fairfax good old grandmother]1207-her good old grandmother and [excellent aunt]1208-excellent aunt , when [she]142-miss fairfax comes to visit [them]1209-them ! [I]0-i always regret excessively on [dear Emma]79-emma ’s account that [she]142-miss fairfax can not be more at [Highbury]3-highbury ; but now [[their]1209-them daughter]1210-their daughter is married , [I]0-i suppose [Colonel]153-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell will not be able to part with [her]142-miss fairfax at all . [She]142-miss fairfax would be such a delightful companion for [Emma]79-emma . ” [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse agreed to it all , but added , “[142-miss fairfax] [[Our]1209-them little friend]1211-our little friend [Harriet Smith]107-harriet , however , is just such [another pretty kind of young person]1212-another pretty kind of young person . [You]79-emma will like [Harriet]107-harriet . [Emma]79-emma could not have a better companion than [Harriet]107-harriet . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am most happy to hear it — but only [Jane]142-miss fairfax Fairfax one knows to be so very accomplished and superior!—and exactly [Emma]79-emma ’s age . ” This topic was discussed very happily , and [others]473-others succeeded of similar moment , and passed away with similar harmony ; but the evening did not close without a little return of agitation . The gruel came and supplied a great deal to be said — much praise and many comments — undoubting decision of its wholesomeness for every constitution , and pretty severe Philippics upon [the many houses where it was never met with tolerably;—but]3616-the many houses where it was never met with tolerably;—but , unfortunately , among the failures which [the daughter]3617-the daughter had to instance , the most recent , and therefore most prominent , was in [[her]3617-the daughter own cook]3618-her own cook at [South End]27-south end , [a young woman hired for the time]3619-a young woman hired for the time , who never had been able to understand what [she]3617-the daughter meant by a basin of nice smooth gruel , thin , but not too thin . Often as [she]3617-the daughter had wished for and ordered it , [she]3617-the daughter had never been able to get any thing tolerable . Here was a dangerous opening . “[79-emma] Ah ! ” said [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , shaking [his]81-mr. woodhouse head and fixing [his]81-mr. woodhouse eyes on [her]79-emma with tender concern.—The ejaculation in [Emma]79-emma ’s ear expressed , “[79-emma] Ah ! there is no end of the sad consequences of [your]79-emma going to [South End]27-south end . It does not bear talking of . ” And for a little while [she]79-emma hoped [he]81-mr. woodhouse would not talk of it , and that a silent rumination might suffice to restore [him]81-mr. woodhouse to the relish of [his]81-mr. woodhouse own smooth gruel . After an interval of some minutes , however , [he]81-mr. woodhouse began with , “[0-i] [I]0-i shall always be very sorry that [you]79-emma went to [the sea]1162-the sea this autumn , instead of coming [here]3113-here . ” “[0-i] But why should [you]79-emma be sorry , sir?—I assure [you]79-emma , it did [the children]3286-the children a great deal of good . ” “[79-emma] And , moreover , if [you]79-emma must go to [the sea]1162-the sea , it had better not have been to [South End]27-south end . [South End]27-south end is [an unhealthy place]1217-an unhealthy place . [Perry]102-mr. perry was surprized to hear [you]79-emma had fixed upon [South End]27-south end . ” “[102-mr. perry] [I]0-i know there is such an idea with [many people]1218-many people , but indeed it is quite a mistake , sir.—We [all]438-all had [our]438-all health perfectly well there , never found the least inconvenience from the mud ; and [Mr. Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield says it is entirely a mistake to suppose [the place]439-the place unhealthy ; and [I]0-i am sure [he]147-mr. wingfield may be depended on , for [he]147-mr. wingfield thoroughly understands the nature of the air , and [[his]147-mr. wingfield own brother]1221-his own brother and [family]1222-family have been [there]437-there repeatedly . ” “[147-mr. wingfield] [You]79-emma should have gone to [Cromer]29-cromer , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , if [you]79-emma went anywhere.—Perry was a week at [Cromer]29-cromer once , and [he]147-mr. wingfield holds it to be the best of [all the sea - bathing places]1225-all the sea - bathing places . [A fine open sea]1226-a fine open sea , [he]147-mr. wingfield says , and very pure air . And , by what [I]0-i understand , [you]79-emma might have had [lodgings]1227-lodgings [there]437-there quite away from [the sea]1162-the sea — a quarter of a mile off — very comfortable . [You]79-emma should have consulted [Perry]102-mr. perry . ” “[102-mr. perry] But , [[my]0-i dear sir]741-my dear sir , the difference of the journey;—only consider how great it would have been.—An hundred miles , perhaps , instead of forty . ” “[102-mr. perry] Ah ! [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , as [Perry]102-mr. perry says , where health is at stake , nothing else should be considered ; and if one is to travel , there is not much to chuse between forty miles and an hundred.—Better not move at all , better stay in [London]1-london altogether than travel forty miles to get into a worse air . This is just what [Perry]102-mr. perry said . It seemed to [him]102-mr. perry a very ill - judged measure . ” [Emma]79-emma ’s attempts to stop [[her]79-emma father]415-her father had been vain ; and when [he]102-mr. perry had reached such a point as this , [she]79-emma could not wonder at [[her]79-emma brother - in - law]3621-her brother - in - law ’s breaking out . “[102-mr. perry] [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry , ” said [he]102-mr. perry , in a voice of very strong displeasure , “[102-mr. perry] would do as well to keep [his]102-mr. perry opinion till it is asked for . Why does [he]102-mr. perry make it any business of [his]102-mr. perry , to wonder at what [I]0-i do?—at [my]0-i taking [[my]0-i family]1232-my family to [one part of [the coast]1234-the coast]1233-one part of the coast or another?—I may be allowed , [I]0-i hope , the use of [my]0-i judgment as well as [Mr. Perry.—I]155-mr. perry.—i want [his]102-mr. perry directions no more than [his]102-mr. perry drugs . ” [He]0-i paused — and growing cooler in a moment , added , with only sarcastic dryness , “[102-mr. perry] If [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry can tell [me]0-i how to convey [a wife]3164-a wife and [five children]1236-five children a distance of an hundred and thirty miles with no greater expense or inconvenience than a distance of forty , [I]0-i should be as willing to prefer [Cromer]29-cromer to [South End]27-south end as [he]102-mr. perry could [himself]102-mr. perry . ” “[102-mr. perry] True , true , ” cried [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , with most ready interposition—“very[102-mr. perry] true . That ’s a consideration indeed.—But [John]88-mr. knightley , as to what [I]0-i was telling [you]88-mr. knightley of [my]0-i idea of moving the path to [Langham]30-langham , of turning it more to the right that it may not cut through [the home meadows]1237-the home meadows , [I]0-i can not conceive any difficulty . [I]0-i should not attempt it , if it were to be the means of inconvenience to [the Highbury people]1238-the highbury people , but if [you]88-mr. knightley call to mind exactly the present line of the path .... The only way of proving it , however , will be to turn to [our]1239-our maps . [I]0-i shall see [you]88-mr. knightley at [the Abbey]505-the abbey to - morrow morning [I]0-i hope , and then [we]1239-our will look them over , and [you]88-mr. knightley shall give [me]0-i [your]88-mr. knightley opinion . ” [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was rather agitated by such harsh reflections on [[his]81-mr. woodhouse friend]3473-his friend [Perry]102-mr. perry , to whom [he]81-mr. woodhouse had , in fact , though unconsciously , been attributing many of [his]81-mr. woodhouse own feelings and expressions;—but the soothing attentions of [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughters]3623-his daughters gradually removed the present evil , and the immediate alertness of [one brother]3624-one brother , and better recollections of the other , prevented any renewal of it . CHAPTER XIII There could hardly be a happier creature in [the world]392-the world than [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley , in this short visit to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , going about every morning among [her]117-mrs. john knightley old acquaintance with [[her]117-mrs. john knightley five children]3626-her five children , and talking over what [she]117-mrs. john knightley had done every evening with [[her]117-mrs. john knightley father]415-her father and sister . [She]117-mrs. john knightley had nothing to wish otherwise , but that the days did not pass so swiftly . It was a delightful visit;—perfect , in being much too short . In general [their]3628-their evenings were less engaged with [friends]3230-friends than [their]3628-their mornings ; but one complete dinner engagement , and out of [the house]425-the house too , there was no avoiding , though at Christmas . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston would take no denial ; [they]3628-their must all dine at [[Randalls one]97-randalls]3631-randalls one [day;—even Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was persuaded to think it a possible thing in preference to a division of [the party]3632-the party . How [they]3628-their were all to be conveyed , [he]415-her father would have made a difficulty if [he]415-her father could , but as [[his]415-her father son]3218-his son and [daughter]3344-daughter ’s carriage and horses were actually at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [he]415-her father was not able to make more than a simple question on that head ; it hardly amounted to a doubt ; nor did it occupy [Emma]79-emma long to convince [him]415-her father that [they]3628-their might in one of [the carriages]3635-the carriages find room for [Harriet]107-harriet also . [Harriet]107-harriet , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , and [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , [[their]3628-their own especial set]3636-their own especial set , were [the only persons invited to meet]3637-the only persons invited to meet [them;—the]3638-them;—the hours were to be early , as well as the numbers few ; [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s habits and inclination being consulted in every thing . The evening before this great event ( for it was a very great event that [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse should dine out , on the 24th of December ) had been spent by [Harriet]107-harriet at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , and [she]107-harriet had gone [home]3258-home so much indisposed with a cold , that , but for [her]107-harriet own earnest wish of being nursed by [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard , [Emma]79-emma could not have allowed [her]107-harriet to leave [the house]425-the house . [Emma]79-emma called on [her]107-harriet the next day , and found [her]107-harriet doom already signed with regard to [Randalls]97-randalls . [She]107-harriet was very feverish and had a bad sore throat : [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard was full of care and affection , [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry was talked of , and [Harriet]107-harriet [herself]107-harriet was too ill and low to resist the authority which excluded [her]107-harriet from this delightful engagement , though [she]107-harriet could not speak of [her]107-harriet loss without many tears . [Emma]79-emma sat with [her]107-harriet as long as [she]79-emma could , to attend [her]107-harriet in [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s unavoidable absences , and raise [her]107-harriet spirits by representing how much [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s would be depressed when [he]91-mr. elton knew [her]107-harriet state ; and left [her]107-harriet at last tolerably comfortable , in the sweet dependence of [his]91-mr. elton having a most comfortless visit , and of [their]3641-they all missing [her]107-harriet very much . [She]107-harriet had not advanced many yards from [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s door , when [she]107-harriet was met by [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton [himself]91-mr. elton , evidently coming towards [it]3642-it , and as [they]3641-they walked on slowly together in conversation about [the invalid]3643-the invalid — of whom [he]91-mr. elton , on the rumour of considerable illness , had been going to inquire , that [he]91-mr. elton might carry some report of [her]107-harriet to [Hartfield]90-hartfield — [they]3641-they were overtaken by [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley returning from the daily visit to [Donwell]202-donwell , with [[his]88-mr. knightley two eldest boys]3644-his two eldest boys , whose [healthy , glowing faces shewed all the benefit of a country run]3645-healthy , glowing faces shewed all the benefit of a country run , and seemed to ensure a quick despatch of the roast mutton and rice pudding [they]3641-they were hastening [home]3258-home for . [They]3641-they joined [company]3647-company and proceeded together . [Emma]79-emma was just describing the nature of [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend ’s complaint;—“a[1241-her] throat very much inflamed , with a great deal of heat about [her]1241-her , a quick , low pulse , & c. and [she]1241-her was sorry to find from [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard that [Harriet]107-harriet was liable to very bad sore - throats , and had often alarmed [her]1241-her with them . ” [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton looked all alarm on the occasion , as [he]0-i exclaimed , “[105-mrs. goddard] A sore - throat!—I hope not infectious . [I]0-i hope not of a putrid infectious sort . Has [Perry]102-mr. perry seen [her]1241-her ? Indeed [you]1242-you should take care of [yourself]1242-you as well as of [[your]1242-you friend]630-your friend . Let [me]0-i entreat [you]1242-you to run no risks . Why does not [Perry]102-mr. perry see [her]1241-her ? ” [Emma]79-emma , who was not really at all frightened [herself]79-emma , tranquillised this excess of apprehension by assurances of [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s experience and care ; but as there must still remain a degree of uneasiness which [she]79-emma could not wish to reason away , which [she]79-emma would rather feed and assist than not , [she]79-emma added soon afterwards — as if quite another subject , “[102-mr. perry] It is so cold , so very cold — and looks and feels so very much like snow , that if it were to any other place or with any other party , [I]0-i should really try not to go out to - day — and dissuade [[my]0-i father]3146-my father from venturing ; but as [he]3146-my father has made up [his]3146-my father mind , and does not seem to feel the cold [himself]3146-my father , [I]0-i do not like to interfere , as [I]0-i know it would be so great a disappointment to [Mr.]1245-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . But , upon [my]0-i word , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , in [your]91-mr. elton case , [I]0-i should certainly excuse [myself]0-i . [You]91-mr. elton appear to [me]0-i a little hoarse already , and when [you]91-mr. elton consider what demand of voice and what fatigues to - morrow will bring , [I]0-i think it would be no more than common prudence to stay at [home]3258-home and take care of [yourself]91-mr. elton to - night . ” [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton looked as if [he]91-mr. elton did not very well know what answer to make ; which was exactly the case ; for though very much gratified by the kind care of [such a fair lady]3649-such a fair lady , and not liking to resist any advice of [her]3649-such a fair lady ’s , [he]91-mr. elton had not really the least inclination to give up the visit;—but [Emma]79-emma , too eager and busy in [her]79-emma own previous conceptions and views to hear [him]91-mr. elton impartially , or see [him]91-mr. elton with clear vision , was very well satisfied with [his]91-mr. elton muttering acknowledgment of its being “[0-i] very cold , certainly very cold , ” and walked on , rejoicing in having extricated [him]91-mr. elton from [Randalls]97-randalls , and secured [him]91-mr. elton the power of sending to inquire after [Harriet]107-harriet every hour of the evening . “[91-mr. elton] [You]91-mr. elton do quite right , ” said [she;—“we]79-emma[91-mr. elton] will make [your]91-mr. elton apologies to [Mr.]1247-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . ” But hardly had [she]79-emma so spoken , when [she]79-emma found [[her]79-emma brother]3179-her brother was civilly offering a seat in [[his]91-mr. elton carriage]3651-his carriage , if the weather were [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s only objection , and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton actually accepting the offer with much prompt satisfaction . It was a done thing ; [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was to go , and never had [his]91-mr. elton broad handsome face expressed more pleasure than at this moment ; never had [his]91-mr. elton smile been stronger , nor [his]91-mr. elton eyes more exulting than when [he]91-mr. elton next looked at [her]79-emma . “[84-mrs. weston] Well , ” said [she]79-emma to [herself]79-emma , “[84-mrs. weston] this is most strange!—After [I]0-i had got [him]91-mr. elton off so well , to chuse to go into company , and leave [Harriet]107-harriet ill behind!—Most strange indeed!—But there is , [I]0-i believe , in [many men]1248-many men , especially [single men]1249-single men , such an inclination — such a passion for dining out — a dinner engagement is so high in the class of [their]1248-many men pleasures , [their]1248-many men employments , [their]1248-many men dignities , almost [their]1248-many men duties , that any thing gives way to it — and this must be the case with [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ; [a most valuable , amiable , pleasing young man]1250-a most valuable , amiable , pleasing young man undoubtedly , and very much in love with [Harriet]107-harriet ; but still , [he]91-mr. elton can not refuse an invitation , [he]91-mr. elton must dine out wherever [he]91-mr. elton is asked . What a strange thing love is ! [he]91-mr. elton can see ready wit in [Harriet]107-harriet , but will not dine alone for [her]107-harriet . ” Soon afterwards [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton quitted [them]3652-them , and [she]107-harriet could not but do [him]91-mr. elton the justice of feeling that there was a great deal of sentiment in [his]91-mr. elton manner of naming [Harriet]107-harriet at parting ; in the tone of [his]91-mr. elton voice while assuring [her]107-harriet that [he]91-mr. elton should call at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s for news of [[her]107-harriet fair friend]3653-her fair friend , the last thing before [he]91-mr. elton prepared for the happiness of meeting [her]107-harriet again , when [he]91-mr. elton hoped to be able to give a better report ; and [he]91-mr. elton sighed and smiled [himself]91-mr. elton off in a way that left the balance of approbation much in [his]91-mr. elton favour . After a few minutes of entire silence between [them]3654-them , [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley began with — “[0-i] [I]0-i never in [my]0-i life saw [a man]548-a man more intent on being agreeable than [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . It is downright labour to [him]91-mr. elton where [ladies]1252-ladies are concerned . With [men]828-men [he]91-mr. elton can be rational and unaffected , but when [he]91-mr. elton has [ladies]1252-ladies to please , every feature works . ” “[91-mr. elton] [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s manners are not perfect , ” replied [Emma]79-emma ; “[91-mr. elton] but where there is a wish to please , [one]475-one ought to overlook , and [one]475-one does overlook a great deal . Where [a man]548-a man does [his]548-a man best with only moderate powers , [he]548-a man will have the advantage over negligent superiority . There is such perfect good - temper and good - will in [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton as [one]475-one can not but value . ” “[91-mr. elton] Yes , ” said [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley presently , with some slyness , “[91-mr. elton] [he]91-mr. elton seems to have a great deal of good - will towards [you]1259-you . ” “[0-i] [Me]0-i ! ” [she]79-emma replied with a smile of astonishment , “[91-mr. elton] are [you]91-mr. elton imagining [me]0-i to be [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s object ? ” “[91-mr. elton] Such an imagination has crossed [me]0-i , [I]0-i own , [Emma]79-emma ; and if it never occurred to [you]79-emma before , [you]79-emma may as well take it into consideration now . ” “[79-emma] [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton in love with me!—What an idea ! ” “[91-mr. elton] [I]0-i do not say it is so ; but [you]79-emma will do well to consider whether it is so or not , and to regulate [your]79-emma behaviour accordingly . [I]0-i think [your]79-emma manners to [him]91-mr. elton encouraging . [I]0-i speak as [a friend]405-a friend , [Emma]79-emma . [You]79-emma had better look about [you]79-emma , and ascertain what [you]79-emma do , and what [you]79-emma mean to do . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i thank [you]79-emma ; but [I]0-i assure [you]79-emma [you]79-emma are quite mistaken . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton and [I]0-i are very [good friends]1261-good friends , and nothing more ; ” and [she]79-emma walked on , amusing [herself]79-emma in the consideration of the blunders which often arise from a partial knowledge of circumstances , of the mistakes which [people of high pretensions to judgment]3655-people of high pretensions to judgment are for ever falling into ; and not very well pleased with [[her]79-emma brother]3179-her brother for imagining [her]79-emma blind and ignorant , and in want of counsel . [He]3179-her brother said no more . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse had so completely made up [his]81-mr. woodhouse mind to the visit , that in spite of the increasing coldness , [he]81-mr. woodhouse seemed to have no idea of shrinking from it , and set forward at last most punctually with [[his]81-mr. woodhouse eldest daughter]3657-his eldest daughter in [[his]81-mr. woodhouse own carriage]3658-his own carriage , with less apparent consciousness of the weather than either of the others ; too full of the wonder of [his]81-mr. woodhouse own going , and the pleasure it was to afford at [Randalls]97-randalls to see that it was cold , and too well wrapt up to feel it . The cold , however , was severe ; and by the time [the second carriage]3659-the second carriage was in motion , a few flakes of snow were finding [their]97-randalls way down , and the sky had the appearance of being so overcharged as to want only a milder air to produce a very white world in a very short time . [Emma]79-emma soon saw that [[her]79-emma companion]3365-her companion was not in the happiest humour . The preparing and the going abroad in such weather , with the sacrifice of [[his]81-mr. woodhouse children]3661-his children after dinner , were evils , were disagreeables at least , which [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley did not by any means like ; [he]81-mr. woodhouse anticipated nothing in the visit that could be at all worth the purchase ; and the whole of [their]3662-their drive to [the vicarage]3485-the vicarage was spent by [him]81-mr. woodhouse in expressing [his]81-mr. woodhouse discontent . “[548-a man] [A man]548-a man , ” said [he]81-mr. woodhouse , “[548-a man] must have a very good opinion of [himself]548-a man when [he]548-a man asks [people]704-people to leave [[their]704-people own fireside]1264-their own fireside , and encounter such a day as this , for the sake of coming to see [him]548-a man . [He]548-a man must think [himself]548-a man [a most agreeable fellow]1265-a most agreeable fellow ; [I]0-i could not do such a thing . It is the greatest absurdity — Actually snowing at this moment!—The folly of not allowing [people]704-people to be comfortable at [home]3258-home — and the folly of [people]704-people ’s not staying comfortably at [home]3258-home when [they]704-people can ! If [we]1270-we were obliged to go out such an evening as this , by any call of duty or business , what a hardship [we]1270-we should deem it;—and here are [we]1270-we , probably with rather thinner clothing than usual , setting forward voluntarily , without excuse , in defiance of the voice of nature , which tells [man]3454-man , in every thing given to [his]3454-man view or [his]3454-man feelings , to stay at [home]3258-home [himself]3454-man , and keep all under shelter that [he]3454-man can;—here are [we]1270-we setting forward to spend five dull hours in [[another man]1273-another man ’s house]1274-another man ’s house , with nothing to say or to hear that was not said and heard yesterday , and may not be said and heard again to - morrow . Going in dismal weather , to return probably in worse;—four horses and [four servants]1275-four servants taken out for nothing but to convey five idle , shivering creatures into [colder rooms]1276-colder rooms and worse company than [they]1277-they might have had at [home]3258-home . ” [Emma]79-emma did not find [herself]79-emma equal to give the pleased assent , which no doubt [he]0-i was in the habit of receiving , to emulate the “[0-i] Very true , [my]0-i love , ” which must have been usually administered by [[his]0-i travelling companion]3664-his travelling companion ; but [she]79-emma had resolution enough to refrain from making any answer at all . [She]79-emma could not be complying , [she]79-emma dreaded being quarrelsome ; [her]79-emma heroism reached only to silence . [She]79-emma allowed [him]0-i to talk , and arranged the glasses , and wrapped [herself]79-emma up , without opening [her]79-emma lips . [They]3665-they arrived , [the carriage]3125-the carriage turned , the step was let down , and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , spruce , black , and smiling , was with [them]3665-they instantly . [Emma]79-emma thought with pleasure of some change of subject . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was all obligation and cheerfulness ; [he]91-mr. elton was so very cheerful in [his]91-mr. elton civilities indeed , that [she]79-emma began to think [he]91-mr. elton must have received a different account of [Harriet]107-harriet from what had reached [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma had sent while dressing , and the answer had been , “[0-i] Much the same — not better . ” “[0-i] [My]0-i report from [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s , ” said [she]79-emma presently , “[105-mrs. goddard] was not so pleasant as [I]0-i had hoped—‘Not better ’ was [my]0-i answer . ” [His]91-mr. elton face lengthened immediately ; and [his]91-mr. elton voice was the voice of sentiment as [he]91-mr. elton answered . “[0-i] Oh ! no — [I]0-i am grieved to find — [I]0-i was on the point of telling [you]1279-you that when [I]0-i called at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s door , which [I]0-i did the very last thing before [I]0-i returned to dress , [I]0-i was told that [Miss Smith]107-harriet was not better , by no means better , rather worse . Very much grieved and concerned — [I]0-i had flattered [myself]0-i that [she]107-harriet must be better after such a cordial as [I]0-i knew had been given [her]107-harriet in the morning . ” [Emma]79-emma smiled and answered—“My[0-i] visit was of use to the nervous part of [her]107-harriet complaint , [I]0-i hope ; but not even [I]0-i can charm away a sore throat ; it is a most severe cold indeed . [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry has been with [her]107-harriet , as [you]1279-you probably heard . ” “[102-mr. perry] Yes — [I]0-i imagined — that is — [I]0-i did not — ” “[102-mr. perry] [He]102-mr. perry has been used to [her]107-harriet in these complaints , and [I]0-i hope to - morrow morning will bring [us]1280-we both a more comfortable report . But it is impossible not to feel uneasiness . Such a sad loss to [our]1280-we party to - day ! ” “[102-mr. perry] Dreadful!—Exactly so , indeed.—She will be missed every moment . ” This was very proper ; the sigh which accompanied it was really estimable ; but it should have lasted longer . [Emma]79-emma was rather in dismay when only half a minute afterwards [he]102-mr. perry began to speak of other things , and in a voice of the greatest alacrity and enjoyment . “[102-mr. perry] What an excellent device , ” said [he]102-mr. perry , “[102-mr. perry] the use of a sheepskin for [carriages]1281-carriages . How very comfortable [they]1282-they make it;—impossible to feel cold with such precautions . The contrivances of modern days indeed have rendered [[a gentleman]527-a gentleman ’s carriage]1284-a gentleman ’s carriage perfectly complete . [One]475-one is so fenced and guarded from the weather , that not a breath of air can find its way unpermitted . Weather becomes absolutely of no consequence . It is a very cold afternoon — but in [this carriage]1286-this carriage [we]1280-we know nothing of the matter.—Ha ! snows a little [I]0-i see . ” “[0-i] Yes , ” said [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley , “[0-i] and [I]0-i think [we]1280-we shall have a good deal of it . ” “[0-i] Christmas weather , ” observed [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . “[0-i] Quite seasonable ; and extremely fortunate [we]1280-we may think [ourselves]1280-we that it did not begin yesterday , and prevent this day ’s party , which it might very possibly have done , for [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse would hardly have ventured had there been much snow on the ground ; but now it is of no consequence . This is quite the season indeed for friendly meetings . At Christmas [every body]3270-every body invites [[their]3270-every body friends]1288-their friends about [them]3270-every body , and [people]704-people think little of even the worst weather . [I]0-i was snowed up at [[a friend]405-a friend ’s house]1291-a friend ’s house once for a week . Nothing could be pleasanter . [I]0-i went for only one night , and could not get away till that very day se’nnight . ” [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley looked as if [he]0-i did not comprehend the pleasure , but said only , coolly , “[0-i] [I]0-i can not wish to be snowed up a week at [Randalls]97-randalls . ” At another time [Emma]79-emma might have been amused , but [she]79-emma was too much astonished now at [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s spirits for other feelings . [Harriet]107-harriet seemed quite forgotten in the expectation of a pleasant party . “[1280-we] [We]1280-we are sure of excellent fires , ” continued [he]0-i , “[1280-we] and every thing in the greatest comfort . [Charming people]1292-charming people , [Mr.]1293-mr. and [Mrs. Weston;—Mrs]156-mrs. weston;—mrs . [Weston]82-mr. weston indeed is much beyond praise , and [he]82-mr. weston is exactly what one values , so hospitable , and so fond of [society;—it]1294-society;—it will be [a small party]1295-a small party , but where [small parties]1296-small parties are select , [they]1296-small parties are perhaps the most agreeable of any . [[Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s dining - room]1297-mr. weston ’s dining - room does not accommodate more than ten comfortably ; and for [my]0-i part , [I]0-i would rather , under such circumstances , fall short by two than exceed by two . [I]0-i think [you]1298-you will agree with [me]0-i , ( turning with a soft air to [Emma]79-emma , ) [I]0-i think [I]0-i shall certainly have [your]1298-you approbation , though [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley perhaps , from being used to [the large parties of [London]1-london]1299-the large parties of london , may not quite enter into [our]1300-they feelings . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i know nothing of [the large parties of [London]1-london]1299-the large parties of london , [sir]3139-sir — [I]0-i never dine with any body . ” “[0-i] Indeed ! ( in a tone of wonder and pity , ) [I]0-i had no idea that the law had been so great a slavery . Well , [sir]3139-sir , the time must come when [you]3139-sir will be paid for all this , when [you]3139-sir will have little labour and great enjoyment . ” “[0-i] [My]0-i first enjoyment , ” replied [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley , as [they]1300-they passed through the sweep - gate , “[0-i] will be to find [myself]0-i safe at [Hartfield]90-hartfield again . ” CHAPTER XIV Some change of countenance was necessary for [each gentleman]3667-each gentleman as [they]1300-they walked into [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s drawing - room;—Mr . [Elton]91-mr. elton must compose [his]91-mr. elton joyous looks , and [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley disperse [his]91-mr. elton ill - humour . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton must smile less , and [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley more , to fit [them]1300-they for the place.—Emma only might be as nature prompted , and [shew]0-i [herself]0-i just as happy as [she]84-mrs. weston was . To [her]84-mrs. weston it was real enjoyment to be with [the Westons]104-the westons . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was a great favourite , and there was not a creature in [the world]392-the world to whom [she]84-mrs. weston spoke with such unreserve , as to [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife ; [not any one , to whom [she]84-mrs. weston related with such conviction of being listened to and understood , of being always interesting and always intelligible , the little affairs , arrangements , perplexities , and pleasures of [[her]84-mrs. weston father]415-her father and [herself]84-mrs. weston]3670-not any one , to whom she related with such conviction of being listened to and understood , of being always interesting and always intelligible , the little affairs , arrangements , perplexities , and pleasures of her father and herself . [She]84-mrs. weston could tell nothing of [Hartfield]90-hartfield , in which [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston had not a lively concern ; and half an hour ’s uninterrupted communication of all those little matters on which the daily happiness of private life depends , was one of the first gratifications of each . This was a pleasure which perhaps the whole day ’s visit might not afford , which certainly did not belong to the present half - hour ; but the very sight of [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , [her]84-mrs. weston smile , [her]84-mrs. weston touch , [her]84-mrs. weston voice was grateful to [Emma]79-emma , and [she]84-mrs. weston determined to think as little as possible of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s oddities , or of any thing else unpleasant , and enjoy all that was enjoyable to the utmost . The misfortune of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s cold had been pretty well gone through before [her]79-emma arrival . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse had been safely seated long enough to give the history of it , besides all the history of [his]81-mr. woodhouse own and [Isabella]83-isabella ’s coming , and of [Emma]79-emma ’s being to follow , and had indeed just got to the end of [his]81-mr. woodhouse satisfaction that [James]86-james should come and see [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter , when [the others]3512-the others appeared , and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , who had been almost wholly engrossed by [her]84-mrs. weston attentions to [him]91-mr. elton , was able to turn away and welcome [her]84-mrs. weston dear [Emma]79-emma . [Emma]79-emma ’s project of forgetting [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton for a while made [her]79-emma rather sorry to find , when [they]3674-they had all taken [their]3674-they places , that [he]91-mr. elton was close to [her]79-emma . The difficulty was great of driving [his]91-mr. elton strange insensibility towards [Harriet]107-harriet , from [her]79-emma mind , while [he]91-mr. elton not only sat at [her]79-emma elbow , but was continually obtruding [his]91-mr. elton happy countenance on [her]79-emma notice , and solicitously addressing [her]79-emma upon every occasion . Instead of forgetting [him]91-mr. elton , [his]91-mr. elton behaviour was such that [she]79-emma could not avoid the internal suggestion of “[0-i] Can it really be as [[my]0-i brother]648-my brother imagined ? can it be possible for [this man]672-this man to be beginning to transfer [his]672-this man affections from [Harriet]107-harriet to me?—Absurd and insufferable!”—Yet [he]91-mr. elton would be so anxious for [her]79-emma being perfectly warm , would be so interested about [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , and so delighted with [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ; and at last would begin admiring [her]79-emma drawings with so much zeal and so little knowledge as seemed terribly like [a would - be lover]3676-a would - be lover , and made it some effort with [her]79-emma to preserve [her]79-emma good manners . For [her]79-emma own sake [she]79-emma could not be rude ; and for [Harriet]107-harriet ’s , in the hope that all would yet turn out right , [she]79-emma was even positively civil ; but it was an effort ; especially as something was going on amongst [the others]3512-the others , in the most overpowering period of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s nonsense , which [she]79-emma particularly wished to listen to . [She]79-emma heard enough to know that [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was giving some information about [[his]0-i son]3218-his son ; [she]79-emma heard the words “[1306-my son] [[my]0-i son]1306-my son , ” and “[98-frank churchill] [Frank]98-frank churchill , ” and “[1306-my son] [[my]0-i son]1306-my son , ” repeated several times over ; and , from a few other half - syllables very much suspected that [he]0-i was announcing an early visit from [[his]0-i son]3218-his son ; but before [she]79-emma could quiet [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , the subject was so completely past that any reviving question from [her]79-emma would have been awkward . Now , it so happened that in spite of [Emma]79-emma ’s resolution of never marrying , there was something in the name , in the idea of [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , which always interested [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma had frequently thought — especially since [[his]3218-his son father]3213-his father ’s marriage with [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor — that if [she]79-emma were to marry , [he]3218-his son was the very person to suit [her]79-emma in age , character and condition . [He]3218-his son seemed by this connexion between [the families]3681-the families , quite to belong to [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma could not but suppose it to be a match that [every body who knew [them]3681-the families]3682-every body who knew them must think of . That [Mr.]3683-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston did think of it , [she]79-emma was very strongly persuaded ; and though not meaning to be induced by [him]3218-his son , or by any body else , to give up a situation which [she]79-emma believed more replete with good than any [she]79-emma could change it for , [she]79-emma had a great curiosity to see [him]3218-his son , a decided intention of finding [him]3218-his son pleasant , of being liked by [him]3218-his son to a certain degree , and a sort of pleasure in the idea of [their]3681-the families being coupled in [[their]3681-the families friends]1288-their friends ’ imaginations . With such sensations , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s civilities were dreadfully ill - timed ; but [she]79-emma had the comfort of appearing very polite , while feeling very cross — and of thinking that the rest of the visit could not possibly pass without bringing forward the same information again , or the substance of it , from the open - hearted [Mr. Weston.—So]157-mr. weston.—so it proved;—for when happily released from [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , and seated by [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , at dinner , [he]0-i made use of the very first interval in the cares of hospitality , the very first leisure from the saddle of mutton , to say to [her]79-emma , “[1306-my son] [We]1308-we want only two more to be just the right number . [I]0-i should like to see [two more]1309-two more [here,—your pretty little friend]1310-here,—your pretty little friend , [Miss Smith]107-harriet , and [[my]0-i son]1306-my son — and then [I]0-i should say [we]1308-we were quite complete . [I]0-i believe [you]1312-you did not hear [me]0-i telling the others in [the drawing - room]1313-the drawing - room that [we]1308-we are expecting [Frank]98-frank churchill . [I]0-i had a letter from [him]98-frank churchill this morning , and [he]98-frank churchill will be with [us]1308-we within a fortnight . ” [Emma]79-emma spoke with a very proper degree of pleasure ; and fully assented to [his]98-frank churchill proposition of [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill and [Miss Smith]107-harriet making [their]1308-we party quite complete . “[98-frank churchill] [He]98-frank churchill has been wanting to come to [us]1308-we , ” continued [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , “[98-frank churchill] ever since September : every letter has been full of it ; but [he]98-frank churchill can not command [his]98-frank churchill own time . [He]98-frank churchill has those to please who must be pleased , and who ( between [ourselves]1308-we ) are sometimes to be pleased only by a good many sacrifices . But now [I]0-i have no doubt of seeing [him]98-frank churchill here about the second week in January . ” “[0-i] What a very great pleasure it will be to [you]0-i ! and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston is so anxious to be acquainted with [him]98-frank churchill , that [she]84-mrs. weston must be almost as happy as [yourself]0-i . ” “[84-mrs. weston] Yes , [she]84-mrs. weston would be , but that [she]84-mrs. weston thinks there will be another put - off . [She]84-mrs. weston does not depend upon [his]98-frank churchill coming so much as [I]0-i do : but [she]84-mrs. weston does not know the parties so well as [I]0-i do . The case , [you]0-i see , is—(but this is quite between [ourselves]1308-we : [I]0-i did not mention a syllable of it in [the other room]1314-the other room . There are secrets in [all families]1315-all families , [you]0-i know)—The case is , that [a party of [friends]3230-friends]1316-a party of friends are invited to pay a visit at [Enscombe]7-enscombe in January ; and that [Frank]98-frank churchill ’s coming depends upon [their]1316-a party of friends being put off . If [they]1316-a party of friends are not put off , [he]98-frank churchill can not stir . But [I]0-i know [they]1316-a party of friends will , because it is [a family that [a certain lady , of some consequence]1319-a certain lady , of some consequence , at [Enscombe]7-enscombe]1318-a family that a certain lady , of some consequence , at enscombe , has a particular dislike to : and though it is thought necessary to invite [them]1316-a party of friends once in two or three years , [they]1316-a party of friends always are put off when it comes to the point . [I]0-i have not the smallest doubt of the issue . [I]0-i am as confident of seeing [Frank]98-frank churchill here before the middle of January , as [I]0-i am of being [here]3113-here [myself]0-i : but [[your]1321-you good friend]1322-your good friend there ( nodding towards the upper end of the table ) has so few vagaries [herself]1322-your good friend , and has been so little used to them at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , that [she]1322-your good friend can not calculate on [their]1316-a party of friends effects , as [I]0-i have been long in the practice of doing . ” “[1322-your good friend] [I]0-i am sorry there should be any thing like doubt in the case , ” replied [Emma]79-emma ; “[0-i] but am disposed to side with [you]1321-you , [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston . If [you]1321-you think [he]98-frank churchill will come , [I]0-i shall think so too ; for [you]1321-you know [Enscombe]7-enscombe . ” “[1321-you] Yes — [I]0-i have some right to that knowledge ; though [I]0-i have never been at the place in [[my]0-i life.—She]1323-my life.—she is an odd woman!—But [I]0-i never allow [myself]0-i to speak ill of [her]1322-your good friend , on [Frank]98-frank churchill ’s account ; for [I]0-i do believe [her]1322-your good friend to be very fond of [him]98-frank churchill . [I]0-i used to think [she]1322-your good friend was not capable of being fond of any body , except [herself]1322-your good friend : but [she]1322-your good friend has always been kind to [him]98-frank churchill ( in [her]1322-your good friend way — allowing for little whims and caprices , and expecting every thing to be as [she]1322-your good friend likes ) . And it is no small credit , in [my]0-i opinion , to [him]98-frank churchill , that [he]98-frank churchill should excite such an affection ; for , though [I]0-i would not say it to [any body else]1324-any body else , [she]1322-your good friend has no more heart than a stone to [people in general]1325-people in general ; and the devil of a temper . ” [Emma]79-emma liked the subject so well , that [she]79-emma began upon it , to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , very soon after [their]3685-their moving into [the drawing - room]1313-the drawing - room : wishing [her]79-emma joy — yet observing , that [she]79-emma knew the first meeting must be rather alarming . — [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston agreed to it ; but added , that [she]79-emma should be very glad to be secure of undergoing the anxiety of a first meeting at the time talked of : “[1322-your good friend] for [I]0-i can not depend upon [his]98-frank churchill coming . [I]0-i can not be so sanguine as [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston . [I]0-i am very much afraid that it will all end in nothing . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , [I]0-i dare say , has been telling [you]0-i exactly how the matter stands ? ” “[82-mr. weston] Yes — it seems to depend upon nothing but the ill - humour of [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill , which [I]0-i imagine to be the most certain thing in [the world]392-the world . ” “[94-mrs. churchill] [[My]0-i [Emma]79-emma]1327-my emma ! ” replied [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , smiling , “[94-mrs. churchill] what is the certainty of caprice ? ” Then turning to [Isabella]83-isabella , who had not been attending before—“You[94-mrs. churchill] must know , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Mrs. Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley , that [we]1329-we are by no means so sure of seeing [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , in [my]0-i opinion , as [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father thinks .
