To be constantly living with [an ill - tempered person]1335-an ill - tempered person , must be dreadful . It is what [we]1336-we happily have never known any thing of ; but it must be a life of misery . What a blessing , that [she]94-mrs. churchill never had [any children]1337-any children ! [Poor little creatures]1338-poor little creatures , how unhappy [she]94-mrs. churchill would have made [them]1338-poor little creatures ! ” [Emma]79-emma wished [she]79-emma had been alone with [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . [She]79-emma should then have heard more : [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston would speak to [her]79-emma , with a degree of unreserve which [she]84-mrs. weston would not hazard with [Isabella]83-isabella ; and , [she]79-emma really believed , would scarcely try to conceal any thing relative to [the Churchills]96-the churchills from [her]79-emma , excepting those views on [the young man]3228-the young man , of which [her]79-emma own imagination had already given [her]79-emma such instinctive knowledge . But at present there was nothing more to be said . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse very soon followed [them]3688-them into [the drawing - room]1313-the drawing - room . To be sitting long after dinner , was a confinement that [he]3228-the young man could not endure . Neither wine nor conversation was any thing to [him]3228-the young man ; and gladly did [he]3228-the young man move to those with whom [he]3228-the young man was always comfortable . While [he]3228-the young man talked to [Isabella]83-isabella , however , [Emma]79-emma found an opportunity of saying , “[94-mrs. churchill] And so [you]1339-you do not consider this visit from [[your]1339-you son]1340-your son as by any means certain . [I]0-i am sorry for it . The introduction must be unpleasant , whenever it takes place ; and the sooner it could be over , the better . ” “[94-mrs. churchill] Yes ; and every delay makes one more apprehensive of other delays . Even if [this family]1341-this family , [the Braithwaites]158-the braithwaites , are put off , [I]0-i am still afraid that some excuse may be found for disappointing [us]1342-us . [I]0-i can not bear to imagine any reluctance on [his]1340-your son side ; but [I]0-i am sure there is a great wish on [the Churchills]96-the churchills ’ to keep [him]1340-your son to [themselves]96-the churchills . There is jealousy . [They]1343-they are jealous even of [his]1340-your son regard for [[his]1340-your son father]3213-his father . In short , [I]0-i can feel no dependence on [his]1340-your son coming , and [I]0-i wish [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston were less sanguine . ” “[82-mr. weston] [He]1340-your son ought to come , ” said [Emma]79-emma . “[82-mr. weston] If [he]1340-your son could stay only a couple of days , [he]1340-your son ought to come ; and one can hardly conceive [a young man]560-a young man ’s not having it in [his]560-a young man power to do as much as that . [A young woman]1346-a young woman , if [she]1346-a young woman fall into bad hands , may be teased , and kept at a distance from those [she]1346-a young woman wants to be with ; but one can not comprehend [a young man]560-a young man ’s being under such restraint , as not to be able to spend a week with [[his]560-a young man father]3213-his father , if [he]560-a young man likes it . ” “[475-one] [One]475-one ought to be at [Enscombe]7-enscombe , and know the ways of [the family]423-the family , before [one]475-one decides upon what [he]475-one can do , ” replied [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . “[475-one] [One]475-one ought to use the same caution , perhaps , in judging of the conduct of [any one individual of [any one family]1354-any one family]1353-any one individual of any one family ; but [Enscombe]7-enscombe , [I]0-i believe , certainly must not be judged by general rules : [she]1346-a young woman is so very unreasonable ; and every thing gives way to [her]1346-a young woman . ” “[1346-a young woman] But [she]1346-a young woman is so fond of [the nephew]1355-the nephew : [he]1355-the nephew is so very great a favourite . Now , according to [my]0-i idea of [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill , it would be most natural , that while [she]1346-a young woman makes no sacrifice for the comfort of [the husband]1356-the husband , to whom [she]1346-a young woman owes every thing , while [she]1346-a young woman exercises incessant caprice towards [him]1356-the husband , [she]1346-a young woman should frequently be governed by [the nephew]1355-the nephew , to whom [she]1346-a young woman owes nothing at all . ” “[0-i] [[My]0-i dearest]696-my dearest [Emma]79-emma , do not pretend , with [your]79-emma sweet temper , to understand a bad one , or to lay down rules for it : [you]79-emma must let it go its own way . [I]0-i have no doubt of [his]1355-the nephew having , at times , considerable influence ; but it may be perfectly impossible for [him]1355-the nephew to know beforehand when it will be . ” [Emma]79-emma listened , and then coolly said , “[0-i] [I]0-i shall not be satisfied , unless [he]1355-the nephew comes . ” “[1355-the nephew] [He]1355-the nephew may have a great deal of influence on some points , ” continued [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , “[1355-the nephew] and on others , very little : and among those , on which [she]1346-a young woman is beyond [his]1355-the nephew reach , it is but too likely , may be this very circumstance of [his]1355-the nephew coming away from [them]1359-them to visit [us]1360-us . ” CHAPTER XV [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was soon ready for [his]81-mr. woodhouse tea ; and when [he]81-mr. woodhouse had drank [his]81-mr. woodhouse tea [he]81-mr. woodhouse was quite ready to go [home]3258-home ; and it was as much as [[his]81-mr. woodhouse three companions]3691-his three companions could do , to entertain away [his]81-mr. woodhouse notice of the lateness of the hour , before [the other gentlemen]3692-the other gentlemen appeared . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was chatty and convivial , and [no friend to early separations of any sort]3693-no friend to early separations of any sort ; but at last [the drawing - room party]3694-the drawing - room party did receive an augmentation . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , in very good spirits , was one of the first to walk in . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston and [Emma]79-emma were sitting together on a sofa . [He]1355-the nephew joined [them]1359-them immediately , and , with scarcely an invitation , seated [himself]1355-the nephew between [them]1359-them . [Emma]79-emma , in good spirits too , from the amusement afforded [her]79-emma mind by the expectation of [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , was willing to forget [his]1355-the nephew late improprieties , and be as well satisfied with [him]1355-the nephew as before , and on [his]1355-the nephew making [Harriet]107-harriet [his]1355-the nephew very first subject , was ready to listen with most friendly smiles . [He]1355-the nephew professed [himself]1355-the nephew extremely anxious about [[her]79-emma fair friend]3653-her fair friend — [[her]79-emma fair , lovely , amiable friend]3696-her fair , lovely , amiable friend . “[1361-she] Did [she]1361-she know?—had [she]1361-she heard any thing about [her]1361-she , since [their]1362-their being at [Randalls?—he]159-randalls?—he felt much anxiety — [he]1361-she must confess that the nature of [her]1361-she complaint alarmed [him]1361-she considerably . ” And in this style [he]1355-the nephew talked on for some time very properly , not much attending to any answer , but altogether sufficiently awake to the terror of a bad sore throat ; and [Emma]79-emma was quite in charity with [him]1355-the nephew . But at last there seemed a perverse turn ; it seemed all at once as if [he]1355-the nephew were more afraid of its being a bad sore throat on [her]79-emma account , than on [Harriet’s]160-harriet’s — more anxious that [she]79-emma should escape the infection , than that there should be no infection in the complaint . [He]1355-the nephew began with great earnestness to entreat [her]79-emma to refrain from visiting [the sick - chamber]3697-the sick - chamber again , for the present — to entreat [her]79-emma to promise [him]1355-the nephew not to venture into such hazard till [he]1355-the nephew had seen [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry and learnt [his]1355-the nephew opinion ; and though [she]79-emma tried to laugh it off and bring the subject back into its proper course , there was no putting an end to [his]1355-the nephew extreme solicitude about [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma was vexed . It did appear — there was no concealing it — exactly like the pretence of being in love with [her]79-emma , instead of [Harriet]107-harriet ; an inconstancy , if real , the most contemptible and abominable ! and [she]79-emma had difficulty in behaving with temper . [He]1355-the nephew turned to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston to implore [her]84-mrs. weston assistance , “[1363-she] Would not [she]1363-she give [him]1364-him [her]1363-she support?—would not [she]1363-she add [her]1363-she persuasions to [his]1364-him , to induce [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor not to go to [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s till it were certain that [Miss Smith]107-harriet ’s disorder had no infection ? [He]1364-him could not be satisfied without a promise — would not [she]1363-she give [him]1364-him [her]1363-she influence in procuring it ? ” “[1363-she] So scrupulous for [others]473-others , ” [he]0-i continued , “[1363-she] and yet so careless for [herself]1363-she ! [She]1363-she wanted [me]0-i to nurse [my]0-i cold by staying at [home]3258-home to - day , and yet will not promise to avoid the danger of catching an ulcerated sore throat [herself]1363-she . Is this fair , [Mrs. Weston?—Judge]161-mrs. weston?—judge between [us]1367-us . Have not [I]0-i some right to complain ? [I]0-i am sure of [your]1363-she kind support and aid . ” [Emma]79-emma saw [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s surprize , and felt that it must be great , at an address which , in words and manner , was assuming to [himself]0-i the right of first interest in [her]1363-she ; and as for [herself]79-emma , [she]79-emma was too much provoked and offended to have the power of directly saying any thing to the purpose . [She]79-emma could only give [him]0-i a look ; but it was such a look as [she]79-emma thought must restore [him]0-i to [his]0-i senses , and then left the sofa , removing to a seat by [[her]79-emma sister]396-her sister , and giving [her]79-emma all [her]79-emma attention . [She]79-emma had not time to know how [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton took the reproof , so rapidly did another subject succeed ; for [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley now came into [the room]3386-the room from examining the weather , and opened on [them]3700-them all with the information of the ground being covered with snow , and of its still snowing fast , with a strong drifting wind ; concluding with these words to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse : “[0-i] This will prove a spirited beginning of [your]1368-your winter engagements , [sir]3139-sir . Something new for [[your]1368-your coachman]1370-your coachman and horses to be making [their]1371-their way through a storm of snow . ” [Poor Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was silent from consternation ; but [every body else]3370-every body else had something to say ; [every body]3270-every body was either surprized or not surprized , and had some question to ask , or some comfort to offer . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston and [Emma]79-emma tried earnestly to cheer [him]0-i and turn [his]0-i attention from [[his]0-i son - in - law]3703-his son - in - law , who was pursuing [his]0-i triumph rather unfeelingly . “[0-i] [I]0-i admired [your]1368-your resolution very much , [sir]3139-sir , ” said [he]0-i , “[1368-your] in venturing out in such weather , for of course [you]1368-your saw there would be snow very soon . [Every body]3270-every body must have seen the snow coming on . [I]0-i admired [your]1368-your spirit ; and [I]0-i dare say [we]1374-we shall get [home]3258-home very well . Another hour or two ’s snow can hardly make [the road]3487-the road impassable ; and [we]1374-we are two carriages ; if one is blown over in [the bleak part of [the common field]1378-the common field]1377-the bleak part of the common field there will be the other at hand . [I]0-i dare say [we]1374-we shall be all safe at [Hartfield]90-hartfield before midnight . ” [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , with triumph of a different sort , was confessing that [he]82-mr. weston had known it to be snowing some time , but had not said a word , lest it should make [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse uncomfortable , and be an excuse for [his]81-mr. woodhouse hurrying away . As to there being any quantity of snow fallen or likely to fall to impede [their]1374-we return , that was a mere joke ; [he]81-mr. woodhouse was afraid [they]1374-we would find no difficulty . [He]81-mr. woodhouse wished [the road]3487-the road might be impassable , that [he]81-mr. woodhouse might be able to keep [them]1374-we all at [Randalls]97-randalls ; and with the utmost good - will was sure that accommodation might be found for every body , calling on [[his]81-mr. woodhouse wife]3168-his wife to agree with [him]81-mr. woodhouse , that with a little contrivance , every body might be lodged , which [she]3168-his wife hardly knew how to do , from the consciousness of there being but [two spare rooms in [the house]425-the house]3706-two spare rooms in the house . “[0-i] What is to be done , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Emma?—what]162-emma?—what is to be done ? ” was [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s first exclamation , and all that [he]81-mr. woodhouse could say for some time . To [her]3168-his wife [he]81-mr. woodhouse looked for comfort ; and [her]3168-his wife assurances of safety , [her]3168-his wife representation of the excellence of the horses , and of [James]86-james , and of [their]1374-we having so many friends about [them]1374-we , revived [him]81-mr. woodhouse a little . [[His]81-mr. woodhouse eldest daughter]3657-his eldest daughter ’s alarm was equal to [his]81-mr. woodhouse own . The horror of being blocked up at [Randalls]97-randalls , while [[her]3168-his wife children]456-her children were at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , was full in [her]3168-his wife imagination ; and fancying [the road]3487-the road to be now just passable for [adventurous people]3711-adventurous people , but in a state that admitted no delay , [she]3168-his wife was eager to have it settled , that [[her]3168-his wife father]415-her father and [Emma]79-emma should remain at [Randalls]97-randalls , while [she]3168-his wife and [[her]3168-his wife husband]431-her husband set forward instantly through all the possible accumulations of drifted snow that might impede [them]3711-adventurous people . “[1380-you] [You]1380-you had better order [the carriage]3125-the carriage directly , [[my]0-i love]1093-my love , ” said [she]3168-his wife ; “[1380-you] [I]0-i dare say [we]1383-we shall be able to get along , if [we]1383-we set off directly ; and if [we]1383-we do come to any thing very bad , [I]0-i can get out and walk . [I]0-i am not at all afraid . [I]0-i should not mind walking half the way . [I]0-i could change [my]0-i shoes , [you]1380-you know , the moment [I]0-i got [home]3258-home ; and it is not the sort of thing that gives [me]0-i cold . ” “[1380-you] Indeed ! ” replied [he]0-i . “[1380-you] Then , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Isabella]83-isabella , it is the most extraordinary sort of thing in [the world]392-the world , for in general every thing does give [you]83-isabella cold . Walk home!—you are prettily shod for walking [home]3258-home , [I]0-i dare say . It will be bad enough for the horses . ” [Isabella]83-isabella turned to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston for [her]84-mrs. weston approbation of the plan . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston could only approve . [Isabella]83-isabella then went to [Emma]79-emma ; but [Emma]79-emma could not so entirely give up the hope of [their]3714-their being all able to get away ; and [they]3714-their were still discussing the point , when [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , who had left [the room]3386-the room immediately after [[his]88-mr. knightley brother]3468-his brother ’s first report of the snow , came back again , and told [them]3714-their that [he]88-mr. knightley had been out of doors to examine , and could answer for there not being the smallest difficulty in [their]3714-their getting [home]3258-home , whenever [they]3714-their liked it , either now or an hour hence . [He]88-mr. knightley had gone beyond the sweep — some way along [the Highbury road]3718-the highbury road — the snow was nowhere above half an inch deep — in many places hardly enough to whiten the ground ; a very few flakes were falling at present , but the clouds were parting , and there was every appearance of its being soon over . [He]88-mr. knightley had seen [the coachmen]3719-the coachmen , and [they]3719-the coachmen both agreed with [him]88-mr. knightley in there being nothing to apprehend . To [Isabella]83-isabella , the relief of such tidings was very great , and they were scarcely less acceptable to [Emma]79-emma on [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s account , who was immediately set as much at ease on the subject as [his]88-mr. knightley nervous constitution allowed ; but the alarm that had been raised could not be appeased so as to admit of any comfort for [him]88-mr. knightley while [he]88-mr. knightley continued at [Randalls]97-randalls . [He]88-mr. knightley was satisfied of there being no present danger in returning [home]3258-home , but no assurances could convince [him]88-mr. knightley that it was safe to stay ; and while [the others]3512-the others were variously urging and recommending , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [Emma]79-emma settled it in a few brief sentences : thus — “[1388-your] [[Your]1388-your father]1389-your father will not be easy ; why do not [you]1388-your go ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am ready , if [the others]3512-the others are . ” “[0-i] Shall [I]0-i ring the bell ? ” “[0-i] Yes , do . ” And the bell was rung , and the carriages spoken for . A few minutes more , and [Emma]79-emma hoped to see [one troublesome companion]3723-one troublesome companion deposited in [[his]88-mr. knightley own house]3724-his own house , to get sober and cool , and the other recover [his]88-mr. knightley temper and happiness when this visit of hardship were over . [The carriage]3125-the carriage came : and [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , always [the first object on such occasions]3726-the first object on such occasions , was carefully attended to [his]81-mr. woodhouse own by [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ; but not all that [either]3727-either could say could prevent some renewal of alarm at the sight of the snow which had actually fallen , and the discovery of a much darker night than [he]81-mr. woodhouse had been prepared for . “[1389-your father] [He]1389-your father was afraid [they]1391-they should have a very bad drive . [He]1389-your father was afraid poor [Isabella]83-isabella would not like it . And there would be poor [Emma]79-emma in [the carriage]3125-the carriage behind . [He]1389-your father did not know what [they]1391-they had best do . [They]1391-they must keep as much together as [they]1391-they could ; ” and [James]86-james was talked to , and given a charge to go very slow and wait for [the other carriage]3728-the other carriage . [Isabella]83-isabella stept in after [[her]83-isabella father]415-her father ; [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley , forgetting that [he]88-mr. knightley did not belong to [[their]1391-they party]3730-their party , stept in after [[his]88-mr. knightley wife]3168-his wife very naturally ; so that [Emma]79-emma found , on being escorted and followed into [the second carriage]3659-the second carriage by [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , that the door was to be lawfully shut on [them]1391-they , and that [they]1391-they were to have a tête - à - tête drive . It would not have been the awkwardness of a moment , it would have been rather a pleasure , previous to the suspicions of this very day ; [she]79-emma could have talked to [him]91-mr. elton of [Harriet]107-harriet , and the three - quarters of a mile would have seemed but one . But now , [she]79-emma would rather it had not happened . [She]79-emma believed [he]91-mr. elton had been drinking too much of [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s good wine , and felt sure that [he]91-mr. elton would want to be talking nonsense . To restrain [him]91-mr. elton as much as might be , by [her]79-emma own manners , [she]79-emma was immediately preparing to speak with exquisite calmness and gravity of the weather and the night ; but scarcely had [she]79-emma begun , scarcely had [they]1391-they passed the sweep - gate and joined [the other carriage]3728-the other carriage , than [she]79-emma found [her]79-emma subject cut up — [her]79-emma hand seized — [her]79-emma attention demanded , and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton actually making violent love to [her]79-emma : availing [himself]91-mr. elton of the precious opportunity , declaring sentiments which must be already well known , hoping — fearing — adoring — ready to die if [she]79-emma refused [him]91-mr. elton ; but flattering [himself]91-mr. elton that [his]91-mr. elton ardent attachment and unequalled love and unexampled passion could not fail of having some effect , and in short , very much resolved on being seriously accepted as soon as possible . It really was so . Without scruple — without apology — without much apparent diffidence , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [the lover of [Harriet]107-harriet]3734-the lover of harriet , was professing [himself]91-mr. elton [[her]79-emma lover]3735-her lover . [She]79-emma tried to stop [him]91-mr. elton ; but vainly ; [he]91-mr. elton would go on , and say it all . Angry as [she]79-emma was , the thought of the moment made [her]79-emma resolve to restrain [herself]79-emma when [she]79-emma did speak . [She]79-emma felt that half this folly must be drunkenness , and therefore could hope that it might belong only to the passing hour . Accordingly , with a mixture of the serious and the playful , which [she]79-emma hoped would best suit [his]91-mr. elton half and half state , [she]79-emma replied , “[1391-they] [I]0-i am very much astonished , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . This to [me]0-i ! [you]91-mr. elton forget [yourself]91-mr. elton — [you]91-mr. elton take [me]0-i for [[my]0-i friend]877-my friend — any message to [Miss Smith]107-harriet [I]0-i shall be happy to deliver ; but no more of this to [me]0-i , if [you]91-mr. elton please . ” “[163-miss smith!—message] [Miss Smith!—message]163-miss smith!—message to [Miss Smith!—What]164-miss smith!—what could [she]107-harriet possibly mean!”—And [he]91-mr. elton repeated [her]107-harriet words with such assurance of accent , such boastful pretence of amazement , that [she]107-harriet could not help replying with quickness , “[107-harriet] [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , this is the most extraordinary conduct ! and [I]0-i can account for it only in one way ; [you]91-mr. elton are not [yourself]91-mr. elton , or [you]91-mr. elton could not speak either to [me]0-i , or of [Harriet]107-harriet , in such a manner . Command [yourself]91-mr. elton enough to say no more , and [I]0-i will endeavour to forget it . ” But [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton had only drunk wine enough to elevate [his]91-mr. elton spirits , not at all to confuse [his]91-mr. elton intellects . [He]91-mr. elton perfectly knew [his]91-mr. elton own meaning ; and having warmly protested against [her]107-harriet suspicion as most injurious , and slightly touched upon [his]91-mr. elton respect for [Miss Smith]107-harriet as [[her]107-harriet friend,—but]3736-her friend,—but acknowledging [his]91-mr. elton wonder that [Miss Smith]107-harriet should be mentioned at all,—he resumed the subject of [his]91-mr. elton own passion , and was very urgent for a favourable answer . As [she]107-harriet thought less of [his]91-mr. elton inebriety , [she]107-harriet thought more of [his]91-mr. elton inconstancy and presumption ; and with fewer struggles for politeness , replied , “[91-mr. elton] It is impossible for [me]0-i to doubt any longer . [You]91-mr. elton have made [yourself]91-mr. elton too clear . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [my]0-i astonishment is much beyond any thing [I]0-i can express . After such behaviour , as [I]0-i have witnessed during the last month , to [Miss Smith]107-harriet — such attentions as [I]0-i have been in the daily habit of observing — to be addressing [me]0-i in this manner — this is an unsteadiness of character , indeed , which [I]0-i had not supposed possible ! Believe [me]0-i , [sir]3139-sir , [I]0-i am far , very far , from gratified in being the object of such professions . ” “[165-good heaven] [Good Heaven]165-good heaven ! ” cried [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , “[165-good heaven] what can be the meaning of this?—Miss [Smith!—I]166-smith!—i never thought of [Miss Smith]107-harriet in the whole course of [my]0-i existence — never paid [her]107-harriet any attentions , but as [[your]91-mr. elton friend]630-your friend : never cared whether [she]107-harriet were dead or alive , but as [[your]91-mr. elton friend]630-your friend . If [she]107-harriet has fancied otherwise , [her]107-harriet own wishes have misled [her]107-harriet , and [I]0-i am very sorry — extremely sorry — But , [Miss Smith]107-harriet , indeed!—Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor ! who can think of [Miss Smith]107-harriet , when [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor is near ! No , upon [my]0-i honour , there is no unsteadiness of character . [I]0-i have thought only of [you]91-mr. elton . [I]0-i protest against having paid the smallest attention to [any one else]1397-any one else . Every thing that [I]0-i have said or done , for many weeks past , has been with the sole view of marking [my]0-i adoration of [yourself]91-mr. elton . [You]91-mr. elton can not really , seriously , doubt it . No!—(in an accent meant to be insinuating)—I am sure [you]91-mr. elton have seen and understood [me]0-i . ” It would be impossible to say what [Emma]79-emma felt , on hearing this — which of all [her]79-emma unpleasant sensations was uppermost . [She]79-emma was too completely overpowered to be immediately able to reply : and two moments of silence being ample encouragement for [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s sanguine state of mind , [he]3139-sir tried to take [her]79-emma hand again , as [he]3139-sir joyously exclaimed — “[91-mr. elton] [Charming Miss Woodhouse]167-charming miss woodhouse ! allow [me]0-i to interpret this interesting silence . It confesses that [you]167-charming miss woodhouse have long understood [me]0-i . ” “[167-charming miss woodhouse] No , [sir]3139-sir , ” cried [Emma]79-emma , “[167-charming miss woodhouse] it confesses no such thing . So far from having long understood [you]3139-sir , [I]0-i have been in a most complete error with respect to [your]3139-sir views , till this moment . As to [myself]0-i , [I]0-i am very sorry that [you]3139-sir should have been giving way to any feelings — Nothing could be farther from [my]0-i wishes — [your]3139-sir attachment to [[my]0-i friend]877-my friend [Harriet]107-harriet — [your]3139-sir pursuit of [her]107-harriet , ( pursuit , it appeared , ) gave [me]0-i great pleasure , and [I]0-i have been very earnestly wishing [you]3139-sir success : but had [I]0-i supposed that [she]107-harriet were not [your]3139-sir attraction to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [I]0-i should certainly have thought [you]3139-sir judged ill in making [your]3139-sir visits so frequent . Am [I]0-i to believe that [you]3139-sir have never sought to recommend [yourself]3139-sir particularly to [Miss Smith?—that]1400-miss smith?—that [you]3139-sir have never thought seriously of [her]107-harriet ? ” “[3139-sir] Never , [madam]1401-madam , ” cried [he]0-i , affronted in [his]0-i turn : “[1401-madam] never , [I]0-i assure [you]1401-madam . [I]0-i think seriously of [Miss Smith!—Miss Smith]168-miss smith!—miss smith is [a very good sort of girl]1402-a very good sort of girl ; and [I]0-i should be happy to see [her]107-harriet respectably settled . [I]0-i wish [her]107-harriet extremely well : and , no doubt , there are [men who might not object to — Every body]1403-men who might not object to — every body has [their]1403-men who might not object to — every body level : but as for [myself]0-i , [I]0-i am not , [I]0-i think , quite so much at a loss . [I]0-i need not so totally despair of an equal alliance , as to be addressing [myself]0-i to [Miss Smith!—No]169-miss smith!—no , [madam]1401-madam , [my]0-i visits to [Hartfield]90-hartfield have been for [yourself]1401-madam only ; and the encouragement [I]0-i received — ” “[0-i] Encouragement!—I give [you]1401-madam encouragement!—Sir , [you]1401-madam have been entirely mistaken in supposing it . [I]0-i am exceedingly sorry : but it is well that the mistake ends where it does . Had the same behaviour continued , [Miss Smith]168-miss smith!—miss smith might have been led into a misconception of [your]1401-madam views ; not being aware , probably , any more than [myself]0-i , of the very great inequality which [you]1401-madam are so sensible of . But , as it is , the disappointment is single , and , [I]0-i trust , will not be lasting . [I]0-i have no thoughts of matrimony at present . ” [He]0-i was too angry to say another word ; [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith manner too decided to invite supplication ; and in this state of swelling resentment , and mutually deep mortification , [they]3737-they had to continue together a few minutes longer , for the fears of [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse had confined [them]3737-they to a foot - pace . If there had not been so much anger , there would have been desperate awkwardness ; but [their]3737-they straightforward emotions left no room for the little zigzags of embarrassment . Without knowing when [the carriage]3125-the carriage turned into [Vicarage Lane]23-vicarage lane , or when it stopped , [they]3737-they found [themselves]3737-they , all at once , at the door of [[his]0-i house]398-his house ; and [he]0-i was out before another syllable passed.—Emma then felt it indispensable to wish [him]0-i a good night . The compliment was just returned , coldly and proudly ; and , under indescribable irritation of spirits , [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith was then conveyed to [Hartfield]90-hartfield . There [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith was welcomed , with the utmost delight , by [[her]168-miss smith!—miss smith father]415-her father , who had been trembling for the dangers of a solitary drive from [Vicarage Lane]23-vicarage lane — turning a corner which [he]415-her father could never bear to think of — and in strange hands — [a mere common coachman]3741-a mere common coachman — [no James]86-james ; and there it seemed as if [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith return only were wanted to make every thing go well : for [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley , ashamed of [his]88-mr. knightley ill - humour , was now all kindness and attention ; and so particularly solicitous for the comfort of [[her]168-miss smith!—miss smith father]415-her father , as to seem — if not quite ready to join [him]415-her father in a basin of gruel — perfectly sensible of its being exceedingly wholesome ; and the day was concluding in peace and comfort to all [[their]3737-they little party]3743-their little party , except herself.—But [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith mind had never been in such perturbation ; and it needed a very strong effort to appear attentive and cheerful till the usual hour of separating allowed [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith the relief of quiet reflection . [[CHAPTER XVI]170-chapter xvi]3744-chapter xvi The hair was curled , and [the maid]3745-the maid sent away , and [Emma]79-emma sat down to think and be miserable.—It was a wretched business indeed!—Such an overthrow of every thing [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith had been wishing for!—Such a development of every thing most unwelcome!—Such a blow for [Harriet!—that]171-harriet!—that was the worst of all . Every part of it brought pain and humiliation , of some sort or other ; but , compared with the evil to [Harriet]107-harriet , all was light ; and [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith would gladly have submitted to feel yet more mistaken — more in error — more disgraced by mis - judgment , than [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith actually was , could the effects of [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith blunders have been confined to [herself]168-miss smith!—miss smith . “[0-i] If [I]0-i had not persuaded [Harriet]107-harriet into liking [the man]758-the man , [I]0-i could have borne any thing . [He]758-the man might have doubled [his]758-the man presumption to [me]0-i — but poor [Harriet]107-harriet ! ” How [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith could have been so deceived!—He protested that [he]758-the man had never thought seriously of [Harriet]107-harriet — never ! [She]168-miss smith!—miss smith looked back as well as [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith could ; but it was all confusion . [She]168-miss smith!—miss smith had taken up the idea , [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith supposed , and made every thing bend to it . [His]758-the man manners , however , must have been unmarked , wavering , dubious , or [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith could not have been so misled . The picture!—How eager [he]758-the man had been about the picture!—and the charade!—and an hundred other circumstances;—how clearly [they]3746-they had seemed to point at [Harriet]107-harriet . To be sure , the charade , with its “[107-harriet] ready wit”—but then the “[758-the man] soft eyes”—in fact it suited neither ; it was a jumble without taste or truth . Who could have seen through such thick - headed nonsense ? Certainly [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith had often , especially of late , thought [his]758-the man manners to [herself]168-miss smith!—miss smith unnecessarily gallant ; but it had passed as [his]758-the man way , as a mere error of judgment , of knowledge , of taste , as one proof among others that [he]758-the man had not always lived in the best society , that with all the gentleness of [his]758-the man address , true elegance was sometimes wanting ; but , till this very day , [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith had never , for an instant , suspected it to mean any thing but grateful respect to [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith as [[Harriet]107-harriet ’s friend]3747-harriet ’s friend . To [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley was [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith indebted for [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith first idea on the subject , for the first start of its possibility . There was no denying that [those brothers]3748-those brothers had penetration . [She]168-miss smith!—miss smith remembered what [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley had once said to [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith about [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , the caution [he]88-mr. knightley had given , the conviction [he]88-mr. knightley had professed that [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton would never marry indiscreetly ; and blushed to think how much truer a knowledge of [his]758-the man character had been there shewn than any [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith had reached [herself]168-miss smith!—miss smith . It was dreadfully mortifying ; but [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was proving [himself]91-mr. elton , in many respects , the very reverse of what [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith had meant and believed [him]91-mr. elton ; proud , assuming , conceited ; very full of [his]91-mr. elton own claims , and little concerned about the feelings of [others]473-others . Contrary to the usual course of things , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s wanting to pay [his]91-mr. elton addresses to [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith had sunk [him]91-mr. elton in [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith opinion . [His]91-mr. elton professions and [his]91-mr. elton proposals did [him]91-mr. elton no service . [She]168-miss smith!—miss smith thought nothing of [his]91-mr. elton attachment , and was insulted by [his]91-mr. elton hopes . [He]91-mr. elton wanted to marry well , and having the arrogance to raise [his]91-mr. elton eyes to [her]168-miss smith!—miss smith , pretended to be in love ; but [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith was perfectly easy as to [his]91-mr. elton not suffering any disappointment that need be cared for . There had been no real affection either in [his]91-mr. elton language or manners . Sighs and fine words had been given in abundance ; but [she]168-miss smith!—miss smith could hardly devise any set of expressions , or fancy any tone of voice , less allied with real love . [She]168-miss smith!—miss smith need not trouble [herself]168-miss smith!—miss smith to pity [him]91-mr. elton . [He]91-mr. elton only wanted to aggrandise and enrich [himself]91-mr. elton ; and if [Miss Woodhouse of Hartfield]90-hartfield , [the heiress of thirty thousand pounds]3750-the heiress of thirty thousand pounds , were not quite so easily obtained as [he]91-mr. elton had fancied , [he]91-mr. elton would soon try for [Miss Somebody]172-miss somebody else with twenty , or with ten . But — that [he]91-mr. elton should talk of encouragement , should consider [her]90-hartfield as aware of [his]91-mr. elton views , accepting [his]91-mr. elton attentions , meaning ( in short ) , to marry [him!—should]91-mr. elton suppose [himself]91-mr. elton [her]90-hartfield equal in connexion or mind!—look down upon [[her]90-hartfield friend]417-her friend , so well understanding the gradations of rank below [him]91-mr. elton , and be so blind to what rose above , as to fancy [himself]91-mr. elton shewing no presumption in addressing her!—It was most provoking . Perhaps it was not fair to expect [him]91-mr. elton to feel how very much [he]91-mr. elton was [her]90-hartfield inferior in talent , and all the elegancies of mind . The very want of such equality might prevent [his]91-mr. elton perception of it ; but [he]91-mr. elton must know that in fortune and consequence [she]90-hartfield was greatly [[his]91-mr. elton superior]3752-his superior . [He]91-mr. elton must know that [the Woodhouses]436-the woodhouses had been settled for several generations at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [the younger branch of [a very ancient family]3755-a very ancient family]3754-the younger branch of a very ancient family — and that [the Eltons]134-the eltons were [nobody]3124-nobody . [The landed property of [Hartfield]90-hartfield]3757-the landed property of hartfield certainly was inconsiderable , being but a sort of notch in [the Donwell]3758-the donwell Abbey estate , to which [all the rest of [Highbury]3-highbury]3759-all the rest of highbury belonged ; but [their]436-the woodhouses fortune , from other sources , was such as to make them scarcely secondary to [Donwell Abbey]202-donwell [itself]202-donwell , in every other kind of consequence ; and [the Woodhouses]436-the woodhouses had long held a high place in the consideration of the neighbourhood which [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton had first entered not two years ago , to make [his]91-mr. elton way as [he]91-mr. elton could , without any alliances but in trade , or any thing to recommend [him]91-mr. elton to notice but [his]91-mr. elton situation and [his]91-mr. elton civility.—But [he]91-mr. elton had fancied [her]3761-her in love with [him]91-mr. elton ; that evidently must have been [his]91-mr. elton dependence ; and after raving a little about the seeming incongruity of gentle manners and a conceited head , [Emma]79-emma was obliged in common honesty to stop and admit that [her]79-emma own behaviour to [him]91-mr. elton had been so complaisant and obliging , so full of courtesy and attention , as ( supposing [her]79-emma real motive unperceived ) might warrant [a man of ordinary observation and delicacy]3762-a man of ordinary observation and delicacy , like [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , in fancying [himself]91-mr. elton a very decided favourite . If [she]79-emma had so misinterpreted [his]91-mr. elton feelings , [she]79-emma had little right to wonder that [he]91-mr. elton , with self - interest to blind [him]91-mr. elton , should have mistaken [hers]79-emma . The first error and the worst lay at [her]79-emma door . It was foolish , it was wrong , to take so active a part in bringing [any two people]3763-any two people together . It was adventuring too far , assuming too much , making light of what ought to be serious , a trick of what ought to be simple . [She]79-emma was quite concerned and ashamed , and resolved to do such things no more . “[107-harriet] Here have [I]0-i , ” said [she]79-emma , “[0-i] actually talked poor [Harriet]107-harriet into being very much attached to [this man]672-this man . [She]107-harriet might never have thought of [him]672-this man but for [me]0-i ; and certainly never would have thought of [him]672-this man with hope , if [I]0-i had not assured [her]107-harriet of [his]672-this man attachment , for [she]107-harriet is as modest and humble as [I]0-i used to think [him]672-this man . Oh ! that [I]0-i had been satisfied with persuading [her]107-harriet not to accept [young Martin]112-mr. martin . There [I]0-i was quite right . That was well done of [me]0-i ; but there [I]0-i should have stopped , and left the rest to time and chance . [I]0-i was introducing [her]107-harriet into good company , and giving [her]107-harriet the opportunity of pleasing [some one worth having]1410-some one worth having ; [I]0-i ought not to have attempted more . But now , [poor girl]1411-poor girl , [her]107-harriet peace is cut up for some time . [I]0-i have been but half a friend to [her]107-harriet ; and if [she]107-harriet were not to feel this disappointment so very much , [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i have not an idea of any body else who would be at all desirable for [her;—William Coxe]173-her;—william coxe — Oh ! no , [I]0-i could not endure [William Coxe]173-her;—william coxe — [a pert young lawyer]1412-a pert young lawyer . ” [She]107-harriet stopt to blush and laugh at [her]107-harriet own relapse , and then resumed a more serious , more dispiriting cogitation upon what had been , and might be , and must be . The distressing explanation [she]107-harriet had to make to [Harriet]107-harriet , and all that poor [Harriet]107-harriet would be suffering , with the awkwardness of future meetings , the difficulties of continuing or discontinuing the acquaintance , of subduing feelings , concealing resentment , and avoiding eclat , were enough to occupy [her]107-harriet in most unmirthful reflections some time longer , and [she]107-harriet went to bed at last with nothing settled but the conviction of [her]107-harriet having blundered most dreadfully . To youth and natural cheerfulness like [Emma]79-emma ’s , though under temporary gloom at night , the return of day will hardly fail to bring return of spirits . The youth and cheerfulness of morning are in happy analogy , and of powerful operation ; and if the distress be not poignant enough to keep the eyes unclosed , they will be sure to open to sensations of softened pain and brighter hope . [Emma]79-emma got up on the morrow more disposed for comfort than [she]79-emma had gone to bed , more ready to see alleviations of the evil before [her]79-emma , and to depend on getting tolerably out of it . It was a great consolation that [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton should not be really in love with [her]79-emma , or so particularly amiable as to make it shocking to disappoint [him]91-mr. elton — that [Harriet]107-harriet ’s nature should not be of that superior sort in which the feelings are most acute and retentive — and that there could be no necessity for [any body]530-any body ’s knowing what had passed except [the three principals]3765-the three principals , and especially for [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s being given a moment ’s uneasiness about it . These were very cheering thoughts ; and the sight of a great deal of snow on the ground did [her]107-harriet further service , for any thing was welcome that might justify [their]3767-their all three being quite asunder at present . The weather was most favourable for [her]107-harriet ; though Christmas Day , [she]107-harriet could not go to [church]3288-church . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse would have been miserable had [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter attempted it , and [she]107-harriet was therefore safe from either exciting or receiving unpleasant and most unsuitable ideas . The ground covered with snow , and the atmosphere in that unsettled state between frost and thaw , which is of all others the most unfriendly for exercise , every morning beginning in rain or snow , and every evening setting in to freeze , [she]107-harriet was for many days [a most honourable prisoner]3770-a most honourable prisoner . No intercourse with [Harriet]107-harriet possible but by note ; no [church]3288-church for [her]107-harriet on Sunday any more than on Christmas Day ; and no need to find excuses for [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s absenting [himself]91-mr. elton . It was weather which might fairly confine every body at [home]3258-home ; and though [she]107-harriet hoped and believed [him]91-mr. elton to be really taking comfort in some society or other , it was very pleasant to have [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father so well satisfied with [his]91-mr. elton being all alone in [[his]91-mr. elton own house]3724-his own house , too wise to stir out ; and to hear [him]91-mr. elton say to [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , whom no weather could keep entirely from [them]3775-them , — “[1412-a pert young lawyer] Ah ! [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , why do not [you]88-mr. knightley stay at [home]3258-home like [poor Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ? ” These days of confinement would have been , but for [her]107-harriet private perplexities , remarkably comfortable , as such seclusion exactly suited [[her]107-harriet brother]3179-her brother , whose feelings must always be of great importance to [[his]3179-her brother companions]3777-his companions ; and [he]3179-her brother had , besides , so thoroughly cleared off [his]3179-her brother ill - humour at [Randalls]97-randalls , that [his]3179-her brother amiableness never failed [him]3179-her brother during the rest of [his]3179-her brother stay at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . [He]3179-her brother was always agreeable and obliging , and speaking pleasantly of every body . But with all the hopes of cheerfulness , and all the present comfort of delay , there was still such an evil hanging over [her]107-harriet in the hour of explanation with [Harriet]107-harriet , as made it impossible for [Emma]79-emma to be ever perfectly at ease . CHAPTER XVII [Mr.]3778-mr. and [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley were not detained long at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . The weather soon improved enough for [those to move who must move]3779-those to move who must move ; and [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse having , as usual , tried to persuade [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter to stay behind with all [[her]3129-his daughter children]456-her children , was obliged to see [the whole party]3782-the whole party set off , and return to [his]81-mr. woodhouse lamentations over the destiny of [poor Isabella;—which poor [Isabella]83-isabella , passing [her]83-isabella life with those [she]83-isabella doated on , full of [their]456-her children merits , blind to [their]456-her children faults , and always innocently busy]83-isabella , might have been a model of right feminine happiness . The evening of the very day on which [they]456-her children went brought a note from [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , a long , civil , ceremonious note , to say , with [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s best compliments , “[1414-he] that [he]1414-he was proposing to leave [Highbury]3-highbury the following morning in [his]1414-he way to [Bath]32-bath ; where , in compliance with the pressing entreaties of [some friends]1415-some friends , [he]1414-he had engaged to spend a few weeks , and very much regretted the impossibility [he]1414-he was under , from various circumstances of weather and business , of taking a personal leave of [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , of whose friendly civilities [he]1414-he should ever retain a grateful sense — and had [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse any commands , should be happy to attend to [them]1416-them . ” [Emma]79-emma was most agreeably surprized.—Mr . [Elton]91-mr. elton ’s absence just at this time was the very thing to be desired . [She]79-emma admired [him]91-mr. elton for contriving it , though not able to give [him]91-mr. elton much credit for the manner in which it was announced . Resentment could not have been more plainly spoken than in a civility to [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , from which [she]79-emma was so pointedly excluded . [She]79-emma had not even a share in [his]91-mr. elton opening compliments.—Her name was not mentioned;—and there was so striking a change in all this , and such an ill - judged solemnity of leave - taking in [his]91-mr. elton graceful acknowledgments , as [she]79-emma thought , at first , could not escape [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s suspicion . It did , [however.—Her father]3785-however.—her father was quite taken up with the surprize of so sudden a journey , and [his]91-mr. elton fears that [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton might never get safely to the end of it , and saw nothing extraordinary in [his]91-mr. elton language . It was a very useful note , for it supplied [them]3786-them with fresh matter for thought and conversation during the rest of [their]3786-them lonely evening . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse talked over [his]91-mr. elton alarms , and [Emma]79-emma was in spirits to persuade [them]3786-them away with all [her]79-emma usual promptitude . [She]79-emma now resolved to keep [Harriet]107-harriet no longer in the dark . [She]79-emma had reason to believe [her]79-emma nearly recovered from [her]79-emma cold , and it was desirable that [she]79-emma should have as much time as possible for getting the better of [her]79-emma other complaint before [the gentleman]3371-the gentleman ’s return . [She]79-emma went to [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s accordingly]3788-mrs. goddard ’s accordingly the very next day , to undergo the necessary penance of communication ; and a severe one it was.—She had to destroy all the hopes which [she]79-emma had been so industriously feeding — to appear in the ungracious character of [the one preferred]3789-the one preferred — and acknowledge [herself]79-emma grossly mistaken and mis - judging in all [her]79-emma ideas on one subject , all [her]79-emma observations , all [her]79-emma convictions , all [her]79-emma prophecies for the last six weeks . The confession completely renewed [her]79-emma first shame — and the sight of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s tears made [her]79-emma think that [she]79-emma should never be in charity with [herself]79-emma again . [Harriet]107-harriet bore the intelligence very well — blaming [nobody]3124-nobody — and in every thing testifying such an ingenuousness of disposition and lowly opinion of [herself]107-harriet , as must appear with particular advantage at that moment to [[her]107-harriet friend]417-her friend . [Emma]79-emma was in the humour to value simplicity and modesty to the utmost ; and all that was amiable , all that ought to be attaching , seemed on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s side , not [her]107-harriet own . [Harriet]107-harriet did not consider [herself]107-harriet as having any thing to complain of . The affection of [such a man as [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton]3792-such a man as mr. elton would have been too great a distinction.—She never could have deserved [him]91-mr. elton — and [nobody but so partial and kind a friend]3793-nobody but so partial and kind a friend as [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield would have thought it possible . [Her]107-harriet tears fell abundantly — but [her]107-harriet grief was so truly artless , that no dignity could have made it more respectable in [Emma]79-emma ’s eyes — and [she]79-emma listened to [her]107-harriet and tried to console [her]107-harriet with all [her]79-emma heart and understanding — really for the time convinced that [Harriet]107-harriet was [the superior creature of the two]3794-the superior creature of the two — and that to resemble [her]107-harriet would be more for [her]107-harriet own welfare and happiness than all that genius or intelligence could do . It was rather too late in the day to set about being simple - minded and ignorant ; but [she]79-emma left [her]107-harriet with every previous resolution confirmed of being humble and discreet , and repressing imagination all the rest of [her]107-harriet life . [Her]107-harriet second duty now , inferior only to [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father ’s claims , was to promote [Harriet]107-harriet ’s comfort , and endeavour to prove [her]107-harriet own affection in some better method than by match - making . [She]107-harriet got [her]107-harriet to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , and shewed [her]107-harriet the most unvarying kindness , striving to occupy and amuse [her]107-harriet , and by books and conversation , to drive [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton from [her]107-harriet thoughts . Time , [she]107-harriet knew , must be allowed for this being thoroughly done ; and [she]107-harriet could suppose [herself]107-harriet but [an indifferent judge of such matters in general]3796-an indifferent judge of such matters in general , and very inadequate to sympathise in an attachment to [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton in particular ; but it seemed to [her]107-harriet reasonable that at [Harriet]107-harriet ’s age , and with the entire extinction of all hope , such a progress might be made towards a state of composure by the time of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s return , as to allow [them]3797-them all to meet again in the common routine of acquaintance , without any danger of betraying sentiments or increasing [them]3798-them . [Harriet]107-harriet did think [him]91-mr. elton all perfection , and maintained the non - existence of any body equal to [him]91-mr. elton in person or goodness — and did , in truth , prove [herself]107-harriet more resolutely in love than [Emma]79-emma had foreseen ; but yet it appeared to [her]107-harriet so natural , so inevitable to strive against an inclination of that sort unrequited , that [she]107-harriet could not comprehend its continuing very long in equal force . If [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , on [his]91-mr. elton return , made [his]91-mr. elton own indifference as evident and indubitable as [she]107-harriet could not doubt [he]91-mr. elton would anxiously do , [she]107-harriet could not imagine [Harriet]107-harriet ’s persisting to place [her]107-harriet happiness in the sight or the recollection of [him]91-mr. elton . [Their]3797-them being fixed , so absolutely fixed , in the same place , was bad for each , for all three . Not one of [them]3797-them had the power of removal , or of effecting any material change of society . [They]3797-them must encounter [each other]420-each other , and make the best of it . [Harriet]107-harriet was farther unfortunate in the tone of [[her]107-harriet companions]3800-her companions at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s ; [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton being the adoration of all [the teachers]3336-the teachers and [great girls in [the school]3338-the school]3802-great girls in the school ; and it must be at [Hartfield]90-hartfield only that [she]107-harriet could have any chance of hearing [him]91-mr. elton spoken of with cooling moderation or repellent truth . Where the wound had been given , there must the cure be found if anywhere ; and [Emma]79-emma felt that , till [she]79-emma saw [her]107-harriet in the way of cure , there could be no true peace for [herself]79-emma . CHAPTER XVIII [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill did not come . When the time proposed drew near , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s fears were justified in the arrival of a letter of excuse . For the present , [he]1417-he could not be spared , to [his]1417-he “[81-mr. woodhouse] very great mortification and regret ; but still [he]1417-he looked forward with the hope of coming to [Randalls]97-randalls at no distant period . ” [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was exceedingly disappointed — much more disappointed , in fact , than [[her]84-mrs. weston husband]431-her husband , though [her]84-mrs. weston dependence on seeing [the young man]3228-the young man had been so much more sober : but a sanguine temper , though for ever expecting more good than occurs , does not always pay for its hopes by any proportionate depression . [It]3806-it soon flies over the present failure , and begins to hope again . For half an hour [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was surprized and sorry ; but then [he]82-mr. weston began to perceive that [Frank]98-frank churchill ’s coming two or three months later would be a much better plan ; better time of year ; better weather ; and that [he]82-mr. weston would be able , without any doubt , to stay considerably longer with [them]3807-their than if [he]82-mr. weston had come sooner . These feelings rapidly restored [his]82-mr. weston comfort , while [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , of a more apprehensive disposition , foresaw nothing but a repetition of excuses and delays ; and after all [her]84-mrs. weston concern for what [[her]84-mrs. weston husband]431-her husband was to suffer , suffered a great deal more [herself]84-mrs. weston . [Emma]79-emma was not at this time in a state of spirits to care really about [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s not coming , except as a disappointment at [Randalls]97-randalls . [The acquaintance]3809-the acquaintance at present had no charm for [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma wanted , rather , to be quiet , and out of temptation ; but still , as it was desirable that [she]79-emma should appear , in general , like [her]79-emma usual self , [she]79-emma took care to express as much interest in the circumstance , and enter as warmly into [Mr.]3810-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s disappointment , as might naturally belong to [their]3807-their friendship . [She]79-emma was the first to announce it to [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ; and exclaimed quite as much as was necessary , ( or , being acting a part , perhaps rather more , ) at the conduct of [the Churchills]96-the churchills , in keeping [him]431-her husband away . [She]79-emma then proceeded to say a good deal more than [she]79-emma felt , of the advantage of such an addition to [their]3807-their confined society in [Surry]24-surry ; the pleasure of looking at [somebody new]3811-somebody new ; the gala - day to [Highbury]3-highbury entire , which the sight of [him]431-her husband would have made ; and ending with reflections on [the Churchills]96-the churchills again , found [herself]79-emma directly involved in a disagreement with [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ; and , to [her]79-emma great amusement , perceived that [she]79-emma was taking the other side of the question from [her]79-emma real opinion , and making use of [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s arguments against [herself]79-emma . “[1417-he] [The Churchills]96-the churchills are very likely in fault , ” said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , coolly ; “[96-the churchills] but [I]0-i dare say [he]96-the churchills might come if [he]96-the churchills would . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do not know why [you]0-i should say so . [He]96-the churchills wishes exceedingly to come ; but [[his]96-the churchills uncle]3212-his uncle and [aunt]1419-aunt will not spare [him]96-the churchills . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i can not believe that [he]96-the churchills has not the power of coming , if [he]96-the churchills made a point of it . It is too unlikely , for [me]0-i to believe it without proof . ” “[0-i] How odd [you]0-i are ! What has [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill done , to make [you]0-i suppose [him]96-the churchills such [an unnatural creature]1420-an unnatural creature ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am not supposing [him]96-the churchills at all [an unnatural creature]1420-an unnatural creature , in suspecting that [he]96-the churchills may have learnt to be above [his]96-the churchills connexions , and to care very little for any thing but [his]96-the churchills own pleasure , from living with those who have always set [him]96-the churchills the example of it . It is a great deal more natural than [one]475-one could wish , that [a young man]560-a young man , brought up by [those who are proud , luxurious , and selfish]1424-those who are proud , luxurious , and selfish , should be proud , luxurious , and selfish too . If [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill had wanted to see [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father , [he]98-frank churchill would have contrived it between September and January . [A man at [his]1426-a man at his age age]1426-a man at his age — what is [he?—three]1427-he?—three or four - and - twenty — cannot be without the means of doing as much as that . It is impossible . ” “[1429-the worst judge in the world] That ’s easily said , and easily felt by [you]0-i , who have always been [[your]0-i own master]1428-your own master . [You]0-i are [the worst judge in [the world]392-the world]1429-the worst judge in the world , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , of the difficulties of dependence . [You]0-i do not know what it is to have tempers to manage . ” “[0-i] It is not to be conceived that [a man of three or four - and - twenty]1431-a man of three or four - and - twenty should not have liberty of mind or limb to that amount . [He]96-the churchills can not want money — [he]96-the churchills can not want leisure . [We]1432-we know , on the contrary , that [he]96-the churchills has so much of both , that [he]96-the churchills is glad to get rid of [them]1433-them at [the idlest haunts in [the kingdom]1435-the kingdom]1434-the idlest haunts in the kingdom . [We]1432-we hear of [him]96-the churchills for ever at some watering - place or other . A little while ago , [he]96-the churchills was at [Weymouth]26-weymouth . This proves that [he]96-the churchills can leave [the Churchills]96-the churchills . ” “[96-the churchills] Yes , sometimes [he]96-the churchills can . ” “[96-the churchills] And those times are whenever [he]96-the churchills thinks it worth [his]96-the churchills while ; whenever there is any temptation of pleasure . ” “[96-the churchills] It is very unfair to judge of [any body]530-any body ’s conduct , without an intimate knowledge of [their]530-any body situation . [[Nobody]3124-nobody , who has not been in the interior of [a family]1439-a family]1438-nobody , who has not been in the interior of a family , can say what the difficulties of [any individual of that family]1440-any individual of that family may be . [We]1432-we ought to be acquainted with [Enscombe]7-enscombe , and with [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill ’s temper , before [we]1432-we pretend to decide upon what [[her]94-mrs. churchill nephew]1441-her nephew can do . [He]1441-her nephew may , at times , be able to do a great deal more than [he]1441-her nephew can at [others]473-others . ” “[1441-her nephew] There is one thing , [Emma]79-emma , which [a man]548-a man can always do , if [he]548-a man chuses , and that is , [his]548-a man duty ; not by manoeuvring and finessing , but by vigour and resolution . It is [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s duty to pay this attention to [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father . [He]98-frank churchill knows it to be so , by [his]98-frank churchill promises and messages ; but if [he]98-frank churchill wished to do it , it might be done . [A man who felt rightly]1445-a man who felt rightly would say at once , simply and resolutely , to [Mrs. Churchill—‘Every]174-mrs. churchill—‘every sacrifice of mere pleasure [you]1446-you will always find [me]0-i ready to make to [your]1446-you convenience ; but [I]0-i must go and see [[my]0-i father]3146-my father immediately . [I]0-i know [he]3146-my father would be hurt by [my]0-i failing in such a mark of respect to [him]3146-my father on the present occasion . [I]0-i shall , therefore , set off to - morrow . ’—If [he]3146-my father would say so to [her]174-mrs. churchill—‘every at once , in the tone of decision becoming [a man]548-a man , there would be no opposition made to [his]3146-my father going . ” “[3146-my father] No , ” said [Emma]79-emma , laughing ; “[3146-my father] but perhaps there might be some made to [his]3146-my father coming back again . Such language for [a young man]560-a young man entirely dependent , to use!—Nobody but [you]1446-you , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , would imagine it possible . But [you]1446-you have not an idea of what is requisite in situations directly opposite to [your]1446-you own . [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill to be making such a speech as that to [the uncle]3170-the uncle and aunt , who have brought [him]98-frank churchill up , and are to provide for him!—Standing up in the middle of [the room]3386-the room , [I]0-i suppose , and speaking as loud as [he]98-frank churchill could!—How can [you]1446-you imagine such conduct practicable ? ” “[1446-you] Depend upon it , [Emma]79-emma , [a sensible man]684-a sensible man would find no difficulty in it . [He]684-a sensible man would feel [himself]684-a sensible man in the right ; and the declaration — made , of course , as [a man of sense]1453-a man of sense would make it , in a proper manner — would do [him]684-a sensible man more good , raise [him]684-a sensible man higher , fix [his]684-a sensible man interest stronger with [the people [he]684-a sensible man depended on]1454-the people he depended on , than all that a line of shifts and expedients can ever do . Respect would be added to affection . [They]1455-their would feel that [they]1455-their could trust [him]684-a sensible man ; that [the nephew who had done rightly by [[his]1456-the nephew who had done rightly by his father , would do rightly by them father]3213-his father , would do rightly by [them]1455-their]1456-the nephew who had done rightly by his father , would do rightly by them ; for [they]1455-their know , as well as [he]1456-the nephew who had done rightly by his father , would do rightly by them does , as well as all [the world]392-the world must know , that [he]1456-the nephew who had done rightly by his father , would do rightly by them ought to pay this visit to [[his]1456-the nephew who had done rightly by his father , would do rightly by them father]3213-his father ; and while meanly exerting [their]1455-their power to delay it , are in [their]1455-their hearts not thinking the better of [him]684-a sensible man for submitting to [their]1455-their whims . Respect for right conduct is felt by every body . If [he]684-a sensible man would act in this sort of manner , on principle , consistently , regularly , [their]1455-their little minds would bend to [his]684-a sensible man . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i rather doubt that . [You]0-i are very fond of bending little minds ; but where little minds belong to [rich people in authority]1460-rich people in authority , [I]0-i think [they]1460-rich people in authority have a knack of swelling out , till [they]1460-rich people in authority are quite as unmanageable as [great ones]1461-great ones . [I]0-i can imagine , that if [you]0-i , as [you]0-i are , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , were to be transported and placed all at once in [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s situation , [you]0-i would be able to say and do just what [you]0-i have been recommending for [him]684-a sensible man ; and it might have a very good effect . [The Churchills]96-the churchills might not have a word to say in return ; but then , [you]0-i would have no habits of early obedience and long observance to break through . To [him]684-a sensible man who has , it might not be so easy to burst forth at once into perfect independence , and set all [their]1455-their claims on [his]684-a sensible man gratitude and regard at nought . [He]684-a sensible man may have as strong a sense of what would be right , as [you]0-i can have , without being so equal , under particular circumstances , to act up to it . ” “[684-a sensible man] Then it would not be so strong a sense . If it failed to produce equal exertion , it could not be an equal conviction . ” “[684-a sensible man] Oh , the difference of situation and habit ! [I]0-i wish [you]0-i would try to understand what [an amiable young man]1462-an amiable young man may be likely to feel in directly opposing those , whom as [child]1463-child and [boy]1464-boy [he]1462-an amiable young man has been looking up to all [his]1462-an amiable young man life . ” “[1465-our] [[Our]1465-our amiable young man]1466-our amiable young man is [a very weak young man]1467-a very weak young man , if this be the first occasion of [his]1466-our amiable young man carrying through a resolution to do right against the will of [others]473-others . It ought to have been a habit with [him]1466-our amiable young man by this time , of following [his]1466-our amiable young man duty , instead of consulting expediency . [I]0-i can allow for the fears of [the child]3193-the child , but not of [the man]758-the man . As [he]1466-our amiable young man became rational , [he]1466-our amiable young man ought to have roused [himself]1466-our amiable young man and shaken off all that was unworthy in [their]1471-their authority . [He]1466-our amiable young man ought to have opposed the first attempt on [their]1471-their side to make [him]1466-our amiable young man slight [[his]1466-our amiable young man father]3213-his father . Had [he]1466-our amiable young man begun as [he]1466-our amiable young man ought , there would have been no difficulty now . ” “[1473-we] [We]1473-we shall never agree about [him]1466-our amiable young man , ” cried [Emma]79-emma ; “[1473-we] but that is nothing extraordinary . [I]0-i have not the least idea of [his]1466-our amiable young man being [a weak young man]1474-a weak young man : [I]0-i feel sure that [he]1466-our amiable young man is not . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston would not be blind to folly , though in [[his]82-mr. weston own son]1475-his own son ; but [he]82-mr. weston is very likely to have a more yielding , complying , mild disposition than would suit [your]1476-your notions of [man]3454-man ’s perfection . [I]0-i dare say [he]1466-our amiable young man has ; and though it may cut [him]1466-our amiable young man off from some advantages , it will secure [him]1466-our amiable young man many others . ” “[0-i] Yes ; all the advantages of sitting still when [he]1466-our amiable young man ought to move , and of leading a life of mere idle pleasure , and fancying [himself]1466-our amiable young man extremely expert in finding excuses for it . [He]1466-our amiable young man can sit down and write a fine flourishing letter , full of professions and falsehoods , and persuade [himself]1466-our amiable young man that [he]1466-our amiable young man has hit upon the very best method in the world of preserving peace at [home]3258-home and preventing [[his]1466-our amiable young man father]3213-his father ’s having any right to complain . [His]1466-our amiable young man letters disgust [me]0-i . ” “[1466-our amiable young man] [Your]1476-your feelings are singular . They seem to satisfy every body else . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i suspect they do not satisfy [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . [They]1480-they hardly can satisfy [a woman]3207-a woman of [her]3207-a woman good sense and quick feelings : standing in [[a mother]402-a mother ’s place]1483-a mother ’s place , but without [a mother]402-a mother ’s affection to blind [her]3207-a woman . It is on [her]84-mrs. weston account that attention to [Randalls]97-randalls is doubly due , and [she]84-mrs. weston must doubly feel the omission . Had [she]84-mrs. weston been [a person of consequence]1485-a person of consequence [herself]84-mrs. weston , [he]1466-our amiable young man would have come [I]0-i dare say ; and it would not have signified whether [he]1466-our amiable young man did or no . Can [you]1476-your think [[your]1476-your friend]630-your friend behindhand in these sort of considerations ? Do [you]1476-your suppose [she]630-your friend does not often say all this to [herself]630-your friend ? No , [Emma]79-emma , [[your]1476-your amiable young man]1487-your amiable young man can be amiable only in French , not in English . [He]1487-your amiable young man may be very ‘ amiable , ’ have very good manners , and be very agreeable ; but [he]1487-your amiable young man can have no English delicacy towards the feelings of [other people]445-other people : nothing really amiable about [him]1487-your amiable young man . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i seem determined to think ill of [him]1487-your amiable young man . ” “[0-i] [Me!—not]1489-me!—not at all , ” replied [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , rather displeased ; “[0-i] [I]0-i do not want to think ill of [him]1487-your amiable young man . [I]0-i should be as ready to acknowledge [his]1487-your amiable young man merits as [any other man]1490-any other man ; but [I]0-i hear of none , except what are merely personal ; that [he]1487-your amiable young man is well - grown and good - looking , with smooth , plausible manners . ” “[1487-your amiable young man] Well , if [he]1487-your amiable young man have nothing else to recommend [him]1487-your amiable young man , [he]1487-your amiable young man will be [a treasure at [Highbury]3-highbury]1491-a treasure at highbury . [We]1492-we do not often look upon [fine young men]1493-fine young men , well - bred and agreeable . [We]1492-we must not be nice and ask for all the virtues into the bargain . Can not [you]0-i imagine , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , what a sensation [his]1487-your amiable young man coming will produce ? There will be but one subject throughout [the parishes of [Donwell]202-donwell and [Highbury]3-highbury]1494-the parishes of donwell and highbury ; but one interest — one object of curiosity ; it will be all [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ; [we]1492-we shall think and speak of [nobody else]1495-nobody else . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i will excuse [my]0-i being so much over - powered .
