To [you]0-i , [he]1487-your amiable young man will talk of farming ; to [me]0-i , of drawing or music ; and so on to every body , having that general information on all subjects which will enable [him]1487-your amiable young man to follow the lead , or take the lead , just as propriety may require , and to speak extremely well on each ; that is [my]0-i idea of [him]1487-your amiable young man . ” “[0-i] And [mine]0-i , ” said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley warmly , “[0-i] is , that if [he]1487-your amiable young man turn out any thing like it , [he]1487-your amiable young man will be [the most insufferable fellow breathing]1497-the most insufferable fellow breathing ! What ! at three - and - twenty to be [the king of [his]1487-your amiable young man company]1498-the king of his company — [the great man]1499-the great man — [the practised politician , who is to read every body ’s character , and make every body ’s talents conduce to the display of [his]1487-your amiable young man own superiority]1500-the practised politician , who is to read every body ’s character , and make every body ’s talents conduce to the display of his own superiority ; to be dispensing [his]1487-your amiable young man flatteries around , that [he]1487-your amiable young man may make [all appear like fools]1501-all appear like fools compared with [himself]1487-your amiable young man ! [My]0-i dear [Emma]79-emma , [your]79-emma own good sense could not endure such a puppy when it came to the point . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i will say no more about [him]1487-your amiable young man , ” cried [Emma]79-emma , “[79-emma] [you]79-emma turn every thing to evil . [We]1502-we are both prejudiced ; [you]79-emma against , [I]0-i for [him]1487-your amiable young man ; and [we]1502-we have no chance of agreeing till [he]1487-your amiable young man is really here . ” “[1487-your amiable young man] Prejudiced ! [I]0-i am not prejudiced . ” “[0-i] But [I]0-i am very much , and without being at all ashamed of it . [My]0-i love for [Mr.]1503-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston gives [me]0-i a decided prejudice in [his]1487-your amiable young man favour . ” “[84-mrs. weston] [He]1487-your amiable young man is a person [I]0-i never think of from one month ’s end to another , ” said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , with a degree of vexation , which made [Emma]79-emma immediately talk of something else , though [she]79-emma could not comprehend why [he]88-mr. knightley should be angry . To take a dislike to [a young man]560-a young man , only because [he]88-mr. knightley appeared to be of a different disposition from [himself]88-mr. knightley , was unworthy the real liberality of mind which [she]79-emma was always used to acknowledge in [him]88-mr. knightley ; for with all the high opinion of [himself]88-mr. knightley , which [she]79-emma had often laid to [his]88-mr. knightley charge , [she]79-emma had never before for a moment supposed it could make [him]88-mr. knightley unjust to the merit of another . VOLUME II CHAPTER I [Emma]79-emma and [Harriet]107-harriet had been walking together one morning , and , in [Emma]79-emma ’s opinion , had been talking enough of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton for that day . [She]79-emma could not think that [Harriet]107-harriet ’s solace or [her]107-harriet own sins required more ; and [she]79-emma was therefore industriously getting rid of the subject as [they]3813-them returned;—but it burst out again when [she]79-emma thought [she]79-emma had succeeded , and after speaking some time of what [the poor]3493-the poor must suffer in winter , and receiving no other answer than a very plaintive—“Mr[1487-your amiable young man] . [Elton]91-mr. elton is so good to [the poor]3493-the poor ! ” [she]79-emma found something else must be done . [They]3813-them were just approaching [the house where lived [Mrs.]3816-mrs. and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates]3815-the house where lived mrs. and miss bates . [She]79-emma determined to call upon [them]3813-them and seek safety in numbers . There was always sufficient reason for such an attention ; [Mrs.]3817-mrs. and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates loved to be called on , and [she]79-emma knew [she]79-emma was considered by [the very few who presumed ever to see imperfection in [her]79-emma , as rather negligent in that respect , and as not contributing what [she]79-emma ought to the stock of [their]3813-them scanty comforts]3818-the very few who presumed ever to see imperfection in her , as rather negligent in that respect , and as not contributing what she ought to the stock of their scanty comforts . [She]79-emma had had many a hint from [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and some from [her]79-emma own heart , as to [her]79-emma deficiency — but none were equal to counteract the persuasion of its being very disagreeable,—a waste of time — [tiresome women]3819-tiresome women — and all the horror of being in danger of falling in with [the second - rate and third - rate of [Highbury]3-highbury]3820-the second - rate and third - rate of highbury , who were calling on [them]3813-them for ever , and therefore [she]79-emma seldom went near [them]3813-them . But now [she]79-emma made the sudden resolution of not passing [their]3813-them door without going in — observing , as [she]79-emma proposed it to [Harriet]107-harriet , that , as well as [she]79-emma could calculate , [they]3813-them were just now quite safe from any letter from [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . [The house]425-the house belonged to [people in business]3822-people in business . [Mrs.]3823-mrs. and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates occupied [the drawing - room floor]3824-the drawing - room floor ; and there , in [the very moderate - sized apartment , which was every thing to [them]3813-them]3825-the very moderate - sized apartment , which was every thing to them , [the visitors]3826-the visitors were most cordially and even gratefully welcomed ; [the quiet neat old lady , who with [her]3827-the quiet neat old lady , who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up her place to miss woodhouse knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up [her]3827-the quiet neat old lady , who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up her place to miss woodhouse place to [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield]3827-the quiet neat old lady , who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up her place to miss woodhouse , and [[her]3827-the quiet neat old lady , who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up her place to miss woodhouse more active , talking daughter]3828-her more active , talking daughter , almost ready to overpower [them]1506-them with care and kindness , thanks for [their]1506-them visit , solicitude for [their]1506-them shoes , anxious inquiries after [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s health , cheerful communications about [[her]3828-her more active , talking daughter mother]399-her mother ’s , and sweet - cake from the beaufet—“Mrs[91-mr. elton] . [Cole]135-mr. cole had just been [there]437-there , just called in for ten minutes , and had been so good as to sit an hour with [them]1506-them , and [she]1507-she had taken a piece of cake and been so kind as to say [she]1507-she liked it very much ; and , therefore , [she]1507-she hoped [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield and [Miss Smith]107-harriet would do [them]1506-them the favour to eat a piece too . ” The mention of [the Coles]175-the coles was sure to be followed by that of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . There was intimacy between [them]1506-them , and [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole had heard from [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton since [his]91-mr. elton going away . [Emma]79-emma knew what was coming ; [they]1506-them must have the letter over again , and settle how long [he]91-mr. elton had been gone , and how much [he]91-mr. elton was engaged in company , and what a favourite [he]91-mr. elton was wherever [he]91-mr. elton went , and how full [the Master of the Ceremonies]3830-the master of the ceremonies ’ ball had been ; and [she]79-emma went through it very well , with all the interest and all the commendation that could be requisite , and always putting forward to prevent [Harriet]107-harriet ’s being obliged to say a word . This [she]79-emma had been prepared for when [she]79-emma entered [the house]425-the house ; but meant , having once talked [him]91-mr. elton handsomely over , to be no farther incommoded by any troublesome topic , and to wander at large amongst all [the Mistresses and Misses of [Highbury]3-highbury]3832-the mistresses and misses of highbury , and [their]3832-the mistresses and misses of highbury card - parties . [She]79-emma had not been prepared to have [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax succeed [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ; but [he]91-mr. elton was actually hurried off by [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , [she]79-emma jumped away from [him]91-mr. elton at last abruptly to [the Coles]175-the coles , to usher in a letter from [[her]79-emma niece]3833-her niece . “[1507-she] Oh ! yes — [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [I]0-i understand — certainly as to dancing — [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole was telling [me]0-i that dancing at [the rooms at [Bath]32-bath]1508-the rooms at bath was — [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole was so kind as to sit some time with [us]1509-us , talking of [Jane]101-miss bates ; for as soon as [she]176-mrs. cole came in , [she]176-mrs. cole began inquiring after [her]176-mrs. cole , [Jane]101-miss bates is so very great a favourite there . Whenever [she]101-miss bates is with [us]1509-us , [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole does not know how to shew [her]101-miss bates kindness enough ; and [I]0-i must say that [Jane]101-miss bates deserves it as much as [any body]530-any body can . And so [she]176-mrs. cole began inquiring after [her]176-mrs. cole directly , saying , ‘ [I]0-i know [you]176-mrs. cole can not have heard from [Jane]101-miss bates lately , because it is not [her]101-miss bates time for writing ; ’ and when [I]0-i immediately said , ‘ But indeed [we]1509-us have , [we]1509-us had a letter this very morning , ’ [I]0-i do not know that [I]0-i ever saw [any body more surprized]1511-any body more surprized . ‘ Have [you]176-mrs. cole , upon [your]176-mrs. cole honour ? ’ said [she]176-mrs. cole ; ‘ well , that is quite unexpected . Do let [me]0-i hear what [she]101-miss bates says . ’ ” [Emma]79-emma ’s politeness was at hand directly , to say , with smiling interest — “[101-miss bates] Have [you]176-mrs. cole heard from [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax so lately ? [I]0-i am extremely happy . [I]0-i hope [she]101-miss bates is well ? ” “[176-mrs. cole] Thank [you]176-mrs. cole . [You]176-mrs. cole are so kind ! ” replied [the happily deceived aunt]3834-the happily deceived aunt , while eagerly hunting for the letter.—“Oh[176-mrs. cole] ! here it is . [I]0-i was sure it could not be far off ; but [I]0-i had put [my]0-i huswife upon it , [you]1512-you see , without being aware , and so it was quite hid , but [I]0-i had it in [my]0-i hand so very lately that [I]0-i was almost sure it must be on the table . [I]0-i was reading it to [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole , and since [she]176-mrs. cole went away , [I]0-i was reading it again to [[my]0-i mother]1513-my mother , for it is such a pleasure to [her]1513-my mother — a letter from [Jane]142-miss fairfax — that [she]1513-my mother can never hear it often enough ; so [I]0-i knew it could not be far off , and here it is , only just under [my]0-i huswife — and since [you]1512-you are so kind as to wish to hear what [she]142-miss fairfax says;—but , first of all , [I]0-i really must , in justice to [Jane]142-miss fairfax , apologise for [her]142-miss fairfax writing so short a letter — only two pages [you]1512-you see — hardly two — and in general [she]142-miss fairfax fills the whole paper and crosses half . [[My]0-i mother]1513-my mother often wonders that [I]0-i can make it out so well . [She]1513-my mother often says , when the letter is first opened , ‘ Well , [Hetty]177-hetty , now [I]0-i think [you]177-hetty will be put to it to make out all that checker - work’—don’t [you]177-hetty , ma’am?—And then [I]0-i tell [her]1513-my mother , [I]0-i am sure [she]1513-my mother would contrive to make it out [herself]1513-my mother , if [she]1513-my mother had [nobody]3124-nobody to do it for [her]1513-my mother — every word of it — [I]0-i am sure [she]1513-my mother would pore over it till [she]1513-my mother had made out every word . And , indeed , though [[my]0-i mother]1513-my mother ’s eyes are not so good as they were , [she]1513-my mother can see amazingly well still , thank [God]178-god ! with the help of spectacles . It is such a blessing ! [[My]0-i mother]1513-my mother ’s are really very good indeed . [Jane]178-god often says , when [she]178-god is here , ‘ [I]0-i am sure , [grandmama]1518-grandmama , [you]1518-grandmama must have had very strong eyes to see as [you]1518-grandmama do — and so much fine work as [you]1518-grandmama have done too!—I only wish [my]0-i eyes may last [me]0-i as well . ’ ” All this spoken extremely fast obliged [Miss Bates]101-miss bates to stop for breath ; and [Emma]79-emma said something very civil about the excellence of [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s handwriting . “[1518-grandmama] [You]1518-grandmama are extremely kind , ” replied [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , highly gratified ; “[1518-grandmama] [you]1518-grandmama who are such [a judge , and write so beautifully]1519-a judge , and write so beautifully [yourself]1518-grandmama . [I]0-i am sure there is [nobody]3124-nobody ’s praise that could give [us]1521-us so much pleasure as [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield ’s . [[My]0-i mother]1513-my mother does not hear ; [she]1513-my mother is a little deaf [you]1518-grandmama know . [Ma’am]179-ma’am , ” addressing [her]179-ma’am , “[179-ma’am] do [you]179-ma’am hear what [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield is so obliging to say about [Jane]101-miss bates ’s handwriting ? ” And [Emma]79-emma had the advantage of hearing [her]79-emma own silly compliment repeated twice over before [the good old lady]3835-the good old lady could comprehend it . [She]79-emma was pondering , in the meanwhile , upon the possibility , without seeming very rude , of making [her]79-emma escape from [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s letter , and had almost resolved on hurrying away directly under some slight excuse , when [Miss Bates]101-miss bates turned to [her]179-ma’am again and seized [her]179-ma’am attention . “[90-hartfield] [[My]0-i mother]1513-my mother ’s deafness is very trifling [you]1518-grandmama see — just nothing at all . By only raising [my]0-i voice , and saying any thing two or three times over , [she]1513-my mother is sure to hear ; but then [she]1513-my mother is used to [my]0-i voice . But it is very remarkable that [she]1513-my mother should always hear [Jane]101-miss bates better than [she]1513-my mother does [me]0-i . [Jane]101-miss bates speaks so distinct ! However , [she]101-miss bates will not find [[her]101-miss bates grandmama]951-her grandmama at all deafer than [she]101-miss bates was two years ago ; which is saying a great deal at [[my]0-i mother]1513-my mother ’s time of life — and it really is full two years , [you]1518-grandmama know , since [she]101-miss bates was [here]3113-here . [We]1527-we never were so long without seeing [her]101-miss bates before , and as [I]0-i was telling [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole , [we]1527-we shall hardly know how to make enough of [her]101-miss bates now . ” “[0-i] Are [you]0-i expecting [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax [here]3113-here soon ? ” “[0-i] Oh yes ; next week . ” “[0-i] Indeed!—that must be a very great pleasure . ” “[0-i] Thank [you]0-i . [You]0-i are very kind . Yes , next week . [Every body]3270-every body is so surprized ; and [every body]3270-every body says the same obliging things . [I]0-i am sure [she]101-miss bates will be as happy to see [[her]101-miss bates friends]817-her friends at [Highbury]3-highbury , as [they]817-her friends can be to see [her]101-miss bates . Yes , Friday or Saturday ; [she]101-miss bates can not say which , because [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell will be wanting [the carriage]3125-the carriage [himself]153-colonel campbell one of those days . So very good of [them]817-her friends to send [her]101-miss bates the whole way ! But [they]817-her friends always do , [you]1533-you know . Oh yes , Friday or Saturday next . That is what [she]101-miss bates writes about . That is the reason of [her]101-miss bates writing out of rule , as [we]1534-we call it ; for , in the common course , [we]1534-we should not have heard from [her]101-miss bates before next Tuesday or Wednesday . ” “[0-i] Yes , so [I]0-i imagined . [I]0-i was afraid there could be little chance of [my]0-i hearing any thing of [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax to - day . ” “[142-miss fairfax] So obliging of [you]1533-you ! No , [we]1534-we should not have heard , if it had not been for this particular circumstance , of [her]101-miss bates being to come here so soon . [[My]0-i mother]1513-my mother is so delighted!—for [she]1513-my mother is to be three months with [us]1534-we at least . Three months , [she]1513-my mother says so , positively , as [I]0-i am going to have the pleasure of reading to [you]1533-you . The case is , [you]1533-you see , that [the Campbells]180-the campbells are going to [Ireland]34-ireland . [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon has persuaded [[her]181-mrs. dixon father]415-her father and [mother]1537-mother to come over and see [her]101-miss bates directly . [They]180-the campbells had not intended to go over till the summer , but [she]101-miss bates is so impatient to see [them]180-the campbells again — for till [she]101-miss bates married , last October , [she]101-miss bates was never away from [them]180-the campbells so much as a week , which must make it very strange to be in different kingdoms , [I]0-i was going to say , but [however different countries]1538-however different countries , and so [she]101-miss bates wrote a very urgent letter to [[her]181-mrs. dixon mother]399-her mother — or [[her]181-mrs. dixon father]415-her father , [I]0-i declare [I]0-i do not know which it was , but [we]1541-we shall see presently in [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s letter — wrote in [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon ’s name as well as [her]142-miss fairfax own , to press [their]180-the campbells coming over directly , and [they]180-the campbells would give [them]180-the campbells the meeting in [Dublin]35-dublin , and take [them]180-the campbells back to [[their]180-the campbells country seat]1542-their country seat , [Baly - craig]36-baly - craig , [a beautiful place , [I]0-i fancy]1543-a beautiful place , i fancy . [Jane]142-miss fairfax has heard a great deal of its beauty ; from [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , [I]0-i mean — [I]0-i do not know that [she]142-miss fairfax ever heard about it from any body else ; but it was very natural , [you]1544-you know , that [he]182-mr. dixon should like to speak of [[his]182-mr. dixon own place]1545-his own place while [he]182-mr. dixon was paying [his]182-mr. dixon addresses — and as [Jane]142-miss fairfax used to be very often walking out with [them]180-the campbells — for [Colonel]153-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell were very particular about [[their]180-the campbells daughter]1210-their daughter ’s not walking out often with only [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , for which [I]0-i do not at all blame [them]180-the campbells ; of course [she]142-miss fairfax heard every thing [he]182-mr. dixon might be telling [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell about [[his]182-mr. dixon own home in [Ireland]34-ireland]1547-his own home in ireland ; and [I]0-i think [she]142-miss fairfax wrote [us]1548-us word that [he]182-mr. dixon had shewn [them]180-the campbells some drawings of [the place]439-the place , views that [he]182-mr. dixon had taken [himself]182-mr. dixon . [He]182-mr. dixon is [a most amiable , charming young man]1550-a most amiable , charming young man , [I]0-i believe . [Jane]142-miss fairfax was quite longing to go to [Ireland]34-ireland , from [his]182-mr. dixon account of things . ” At this moment , an ingenious and animating suspicion entering [Emma]79-emma ’s brain with regard to [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , this charming [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , and the not going to [Ireland]34-ireland , [she]142-miss fairfax said , with the insidious design of farther discovery , “[142-miss fairfax] [You]1551-you must feel it very fortunate that [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax should be allowed to come to [you]1551-you at such a time . Considering the very particular friendship between [her]142-miss fairfax and [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon , [you]1551-you could hardly have expected [her]142-miss fairfax to be excused from accompanying [Colonel]153-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell . ” “[154-mrs. campbell] Very true , very true , indeed . The very thing that [we]1552-we have always been rather afraid of ; for [we]1552-we should not have liked to have [her]142-miss fairfax at such a distance from [us]1552-we , for months together — not able to come if any thing was to happen . But [you]1551-you see , every thing turns out for the best . [They]1553-they want [her]142-miss fairfax ( [Mr.]1554-mr. and [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon ) excessively to come over with [Colonel]153-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell ; quite depend upon it ; nothing can be more kind or pressing than [their]1553-they joint invitation , [Jane]142-miss fairfax says , as [you]1551-you will hear presently ; [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon does not seem in the least backward in any attention . [He]182-mr. dixon is [a most charming young man]1555-a most charming young man . Ever since the service [he]182-mr. dixon rendered [Jane]142-miss fairfax at [Weymouth]26-weymouth , when [they]1553-they were out in that party on [the water]1556-the water , and [she]142-miss fairfax , by the sudden whirling round of something or other among the sails , would have been dashed into [the sea]1162-the sea at once , and actually was all but gone , if [he]182-mr. dixon had not , with the greatest presence of mind , caught hold of [her]142-miss fairfax habit — ( [I]0-i can never think of it without trembling!)—But ever since [we]1553-they had the history of that day , [I]0-i have been so fond of [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon ! ” “[182-mr. dixon] But , in spite of all [[her]142-miss fairfax friends]817-her friends ’ urgency , and [her]142-miss fairfax own wish of seeing [Ireland]34-ireland , [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax prefers devoting the time to [you]182-mr. dixon and [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates ? ” “[142-miss fairfax] Yes — entirely [her]142-miss fairfax own doing , entirely [her]142-miss fairfax own choice ; and [Colonel]153-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell think [she]142-miss fairfax does quite right , just what [they]817-her friends should recommend ; and indeed [they]817-her friends particularly wish [her]142-miss fairfax to try [her]142-miss fairfax native air , as [she]142-miss fairfax has not been quite so well as usual lately . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am concerned to hear of it . [I]0-i think [they]817-her friends judge wisely . But [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon must be very much disappointed . [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon , [I]0-i understand , has no remarkable degree of personal beauty ; is not , by any means , to be compared with [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . ” “[142-miss fairfax] Oh ! no . [You]182-mr. dixon are very obliging to say such things — but certainly not . There is no comparison between [them]1559-them . [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell always was absolutely plain — but extremely elegant and amiable . ” “[183-miss campbell] Yes , that of course . ” “[183-miss campbell] [Jane]142-miss fairfax caught a bad cold , poor thing ! so long ago as the 7th of November , ( as [I]0-i am going to read to [you]182-mr. dixon , ) and has never been well since . A long time , is not it , for a cold to hang upon [her]142-miss fairfax ? [She]142-miss fairfax never mentioned it before , because [she]142-miss fairfax would not alarm [us]1560-us . Just like [her]142-miss fairfax ! so considerate!—But however , [she]142-miss fairfax is so far from well , that [[her]142-miss fairfax kind friends]1561-her kind friends [the Campbells]180-the campbells think [she]142-miss fairfax had better come [home]3258-home , and try an air that always agrees with [her]142-miss fairfax ; and [they]1561-her kind friends have no doubt that three or four months at [Highbury]3-highbury will entirely cure [her]142-miss fairfax — and it is certainly a great deal better that [she]142-miss fairfax should come here , than go to [Ireland]34-ireland , if [she]142-miss fairfax is unwell . [Nobody]3124-nobody could nurse [her]142-miss fairfax , as [we]1560-us should do . ” “[3124-nobody] It appears to [me]0-i the most desirable arrangement in [the world]392-the world . ” “[3124-nobody] And so [she]142-miss fairfax is to come to [us]1560-us next Friday or Saturday , and [the Campbells]180-the campbells leave [town]3165-town in [their]180-the campbells way to [Holyhead]37-holyhead the Monday following — as [you]1566-you will find from [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s letter . So [sudden!—You]1567-sudden!—you may guess , dear [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , what a flurry it has thrown [me]0-i in ! If it was not for the drawback of [her]142-miss fairfax illness — but [I]0-i am afraid [we]1560-us must expect to see [her]142-miss fairfax grown thin , and looking very poorly . [I]0-i must tell [you]1566-you what an unlucky thing happened to [me]0-i , as to that . [I]0-i always make a point of reading [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s letters through to [myself]0-i first , before [I]0-i read them aloud to [[my]0-i mother]1513-my mother , [you]1566-you know , for fear of there being any thing in them to distress [her]1513-my mother . [Jane]142-miss fairfax desired [me]0-i to do it , so [I]0-i always do : and so [I]0-i began to - day with [my]0-i usual caution ; but no sooner did [I]0-i come to the mention of [her]142-miss fairfax being unwell , than [I]0-i burst out , quite frightened , with ‘ Bless [me]0-i ! poor [Jane]142-miss fairfax is ill!’—which [[my]0-i mother]1513-my mother , being on the watch , heard distinctly , and was sadly alarmed at . However , when [I]0-i read on , [I]0-i found it was not near so bad as [I]0-i had fancied at first ; and [I]0-i make so light of it now to [her]1513-my mother , that [she]1513-my mother does not think much about it . But [I]0-i can not imagine how [I]0-i could be so off [my]0-i guard . If [Jane]142-miss fairfax does not get well soon , [we]1570-we will call in [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry . The expense shall not be thought of ; and though [he]102-mr. perry is so liberal , and so fond of [Jane]142-miss fairfax that [I]0-i dare say [he]102-mr. perry would not mean to charge any thing for attendance , [we]1570-we could not suffer it to be so , [you]1571-you know . [He]102-mr. perry has [a wife]3164-a wife and [family]1222-family to maintain , and is not to be giving away [his]102-mr. perry time . Well , now [I]0-i have just given [you]1571-you a hint of what [Jane]142-miss fairfax writes about , [we]1570-we will turn to [her]142-miss fairfax letter , and [I]0-i am sure [she]142-miss fairfax tells [her]142-miss fairfax own story a great deal better than [I]0-i can tell it for [her]142-miss fairfax . ” “[142-miss fairfax] [I]0-i am afraid [we]1570-we must be running away , ” said [Emma]79-emma , glancing at [Harriet]107-harriet , and beginning to rise—“My[1574-father] [father]1574-father will be expecting [us]1570-we . [I]0-i had no intention , [I]0-i thought [I]0-i had no power of staying more than five minutes , when [I]0-i first entered [the house]425-the house . [I]0-i merely called , because [I]0-i would not pass the door without inquiring after [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates ; but [I]0-i have been so pleasantly detained ! Now , however , [we]1570-we must wish [you]1576-you and [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates good morning . ” And not all that could be urged to detain [her]106-mrs. bates succeeded . [She]106-mrs. bates regained [the street]3836-the street — happy in this , that though much had been forced on [her]106-mrs. bates against [her]106-mrs. bates will , though [she]106-mrs. bates had in fact heard the whole substance of [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s letter , [she]106-mrs. bates had been able to escape the letter itself . CHAPTER II [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax was [an orphan]3837-an orphan , [the only child of [[Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates ’s youngest daughter]3839-mrs. bates ’s youngest daughter]3838-the only child of mrs. bates ’s youngest daughter . The marriage of [Lieut . Fairfax of [the — — regiment of infantry]3841-the — — regiment of infantry]3840-lieut . fairfax of the — — regiment of infantry , and [Miss Jane Bates]101-miss bates , had had its day of fame and pleasure , hope and interest ; but nothing now remained of it , save the melancholy remembrance of [him]3840-lieut . fairfax of the — — regiment of infantry dying in action abroad — of [[his]3840-lieut . fairfax of the — — regiment of infantry widow]3842-his widow sinking under consumption and grief soon afterwards — and [this girl]3843-this girl . By birth [she]142-miss fairfax belonged to [Highbury]3-highbury : and when at three years old , on losing [[her]142-miss fairfax mother]399-her mother , [she]142-miss fairfax became the property , the charge , the consolation , the foundling of [[her]142-miss fairfax grandmother]1062-her grandmother and [aunt]1419-aunt , there had seemed every probability of [her]142-miss fairfax being permanently fixed [there]437-there ; of [her]142-miss fairfax being taught only what very limited means could command , and growing up with no advantages of connexion or improvement , to be engrafted on what nature had given [her]142-miss fairfax in [a pleasing person]3848-a pleasing person , good understanding , and warm - hearted , well - meaning relations . But the compassionate feelings of [a friend of [[her]142-miss fairfax father]415-her father]3849-a friend of her father gave a change to [her]142-miss fairfax destiny . This was [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell , who had very highly regarded [Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , as [an excellent officer and most deserving young man]3851-an excellent officer and most deserving young man ; and farther , had been indebted to [him]153-colonel campbell for such attentions , during a severe camp - fever , as [he]153-colonel campbell believed had saved [his]153-colonel campbell life . These were claims which [he]153-colonel campbell did not learn to overlook , though some years passed away from the death of [poor Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , before [his]153-colonel campbell own return to [England]38-england put any thing in [his]153-colonel campbell power . When [he]153-colonel campbell did return , [he]153-colonel campbell sought out [the child]3193-the child and took notice of [her]3193-the child . [He]153-colonel campbell was [a married man]3853-a married man , with [only one living child]3854-only one living child , [a girl]600-a girl , about [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s age : and [Jane]142-miss fairfax became [[their]3856-their guest]3857-their guest , paying [them]3856-their long visits and growing a favourite with [all]438-all ; and before [she]142-miss fairfax was nine years old , [[his]153-colonel campbell daughter]3129-his daughter ’s great fondness for [her]142-miss fairfax , and [his]153-colonel campbell own wish of being [a real friend]3860-a real friend , united to produce an offer from [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell of undertaking the whole charge of [her]142-miss fairfax education . It was accepted ; and from that period [Jane]142-miss fairfax had belonged to [[Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell ’s family]3861-colonel campbell ’s family , and had lived with [them]3861-colonel campbell ’s family entirely , only visiting [[her]142-miss fairfax grandmother]1062-her grandmother from time to time . The plan was that [she]142-miss fairfax should be brought up for educating [others]473-others ; the very few hundred pounds which [she]142-miss fairfax inherited from [[her]142-miss fairfax father]415-her father making independence impossible . To provide for [her]142-miss fairfax otherwise was out of [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell ’s power ; for though [his]153-colonel campbell income , by pay and appointments , was handsome , [his]153-colonel campbell fortune was moderate and must be all [[his]153-colonel campbell daughter]3129-his daughter ’s ; but , by giving [her]142-miss fairfax an education , [he]153-colonel campbell hoped to be supplying the means of respectable subsistence hereafter . Such was [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s history . [She]142-miss fairfax had fallen into good hands , known nothing but kindness from [the Campbells]180-the campbells , and been given an excellent education . Living constantly with [right - minded and well - informed people]3866-right - minded and well - informed people , [her]142-miss fairfax heart and understanding had received every advantage of discipline and culture ; and [[Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell ’s residence]3867-colonel campbell ’s residence being in [London]1-london , every lighter talent had been done full justice to , by the attendance of [first - rate masters]3868-first - rate masters . [Her]142-miss fairfax disposition and abilities were equally worthy of all that friendship could do ; and at eighteen or nineteen [she]142-miss fairfax was , as far as such an early age can be qualified for the care of [children]3869-children , fully competent to the office of instruction [herself]142-miss fairfax ; but [she]142-miss fairfax was too much beloved to be parted with . Neither [father]1574-father nor [mother]1537-mother could promote , and [the daughter]3617-the daughter could not endure it . The evil day was put off . It was easy to decide that [she]142-miss fairfax was still too young ; and [Jane]142-miss fairfax remained with [them]180-the campbells , sharing , as [another daughter]3873-another daughter , in all the rational pleasures of an elegant society , and a judicious mixture of [home]3258-home and amusement , with only the drawback of the future , the sobering suggestions of [her]142-miss fairfax own good understanding to remind [her]142-miss fairfax that all this might soon be over . The affection of [the whole family]3875-the whole family , the warm attachment of [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell in particular , was the more honourable to [each party]3876-each party from the circumstance of [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s decided superiority both in beauty and acquirements . That nature had given it in feature could not be unseen by [the young woman]3877-the young woman , nor could [her]142-miss fairfax higher powers of mind be unfelt by [the parents]3335-the parents . [They]180-the campbells continued together with unabated regard however , till the marriage of [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell , who by [that chance , that luck which so often defies anticipation in matrimonial affairs , giving attraction to what is moderate rather than to what is superior]3879-that chance , that luck which so often defies anticipation in matrimonial affairs , giving attraction to what is moderate rather than to what is superior , engaged the affections of [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , [a young man]560-a young man , rich and agreeable , almost as soon as [they]180-the campbells were acquainted ; and was eligibly and happily settled , while [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax had yet [her]142-miss fairfax bread to earn . This event had very lately taken place ; too lately for any thing to be yet attempted by [[her]142-miss fairfax less fortunate friend]3881-her less fortunate friend towards entering on [her]142-miss fairfax path of duty ; though [she]142-miss fairfax had now reached the age which [her]142-miss fairfax own judgment had fixed on for beginning . [She]142-miss fairfax had long resolved that one - and - twenty should be the period . With the fortitude of [a devoted novitiate]3882-a devoted novitiate , [she]142-miss fairfax had resolved at one - and - twenty to complete the sacrifice , and retire from all the pleasures of life , of rational intercourse , equal society , peace and hope , to penance and mortification for ever . The good sense of [Colonel]153-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell could not oppose such a resolution , though [their]180-the campbells feelings did . As long as [they]180-the campbells lived , no exertions would be necessary , [[their]180-the campbells home]3883-their home might be hers for ever ; and for [their]180-the campbells own comfort [they]180-the campbells would have retained [her]142-miss fairfax wholly ; but this would be selfishness:—what must be at last , had better be soon . Perhaps [they]180-the campbells began to feel it might have been kinder and wiser to have resisted the temptation of any delay , and spared [her]142-miss fairfax from a taste of such enjoyments of ease and leisure as must now be relinquished . Still , however , affection was glad to catch at any reasonable excuse for not hurrying on the wretched moment . [She]142-miss fairfax had never been quite well since the time of [[their]180-the campbells daughter]1210-their daughter ’s marriage ; and till [she]142-miss fairfax should have completely recovered [her]142-miss fairfax usual strength , [they]180-the campbells must forbid [her]142-miss fairfax engaging in duties , which , so far from being compatible with a weakened frame and varying spirits , seemed , under the most favourable circumstances , to require something more than human perfection of body and mind to be discharged with tolerable comfort . With regard to [her]142-miss fairfax not accompanying [them]180-the campbells to [Ireland]34-ireland , [her]142-miss fairfax account to [[her]142-miss fairfax aunt]1061-her aunt contained nothing but truth , though there might be some truths not told . It was [her]142-miss fairfax own choice to give the time of [their]180-the campbells absence to [Highbury]3-highbury ; to spend , perhaps , [her]142-miss fairfax last months of perfect liberty with [those kind relations to whom [she]142-miss fairfax was so very dear]3886-those kind relations to whom she was so very dear : and [the Campbells]180-the campbells , whatever might be [their]180-the campbells motive or motives , whether single , or double , or treble , gave the arrangement [their]180-the campbells ready sanction , and said , that [they]180-the campbells depended more on a few months spent in [her]142-miss fairfax native air , for the recovery of [her]142-miss fairfax health , than on any thing else . Certain it was that [she]142-miss fairfax was to come ; and that [Highbury]3-highbury , instead of welcoming that perfect novelty which had been so long promised it — [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill — must put up for the present with [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , who could bring only the freshness of a two years ’ absence . [Emma]79-emma was sorry;—to have to pay civilities to [a person [she]142-miss fairfax did not like]3887-a person she did not like through three long months!—to be always doing more than [she]142-miss fairfax wished , and less than [she]142-miss fairfax ought ! Why [she]142-miss fairfax did not like [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax might be a difficult question to answer ; [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley had once told [her]142-miss fairfax it was because [she]142-miss fairfax saw in [her]142-miss fairfax [the really accomplished young woman]3888-the really accomplished young woman , which [she]142-miss fairfax wanted to be thought [herself]142-miss fairfax ; and though the accusation had been eagerly refuted at the time , there were moments of self - examination in which [her]142-miss fairfax conscience could not quite acquit [her]142-miss fairfax . But “[1577-she] [she]1577-she could never get acquainted with [her]1577-she : [she]1577-she did not know how it was , but there was such coldness and reserve — such apparent indifference whether [she]1577-she pleased or not — and then , [[her]1577-she aunt]1061-her aunt was such an eternal talker!—and [she]1061-her aunt was made such a fuss with by every body!—and it had been always imagined that [they]1579-they were to be so intimate — because [their]1579-they ages were the same , [every body]3270-every body had supposed [they]1579-they must be so fond of [each other]420-each other . ” These were [her]142-miss fairfax reasons — [she]142-miss fairfax had no better . It was a dislike so little just — every imputed fault was so magnified by fancy , that [she]142-miss fairfax never saw [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax the first time after any considerable absence , without feeling that [she]142-miss fairfax had injured [her]142-miss fairfax ; and now , when the due visit was paid , on [her]142-miss fairfax arrival , after a two years ’ interval , [she]142-miss fairfax was particularly struck with the very appearance and manners , which for those two whole years [she]142-miss fairfax had been depreciating . [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax was very elegant , remarkably elegant ; and [she]142-miss fairfax had [herself]142-miss fairfax the highest value for elegance . [Her]142-miss fairfax height was pretty , just such as almost every body would think tall , and [nobody]3124-nobody could think very tall ; [her]142-miss fairfax figure particularly graceful ; [her]142-miss fairfax size a most becoming medium , between fat and thin , though a slight appearance of ill - health seemed to point out the likeliest evil of the two . [Emma]79-emma could not but feel all this ; and then , [her]142-miss fairfax face — [her]142-miss fairfax features — there was more beauty in them altogether than [she]142-miss fairfax had remembered ; it was not regular , but it was very pleasing beauty . [Her]142-miss fairfax eyes , a deep grey , with dark eye - lashes and eyebrows , had never been denied their praise ; but the skin , which [she]142-miss fairfax had been used to cavil at , as wanting colour , had a clearness and delicacy which really needed no fuller bloom . It was a style of beauty , of which elegance was the reigning character , and as such , [she]142-miss fairfax must , in honour , by all [her]142-miss fairfax principles , admire it:—elegance , which , whether of person or of mind , [she]142-miss fairfax saw so little in [Highbury]3-highbury . There , not to be vulgar , was distinction , and merit . In short , [she]142-miss fairfax sat , during the first visit , looking at [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax with twofold complacency ; the sense of pleasure and the sense of rendering justice , and was determining that [she]142-miss fairfax would dislike [her]142-miss fairfax no longer . When [she]142-miss fairfax took in [her]142-miss fairfax history , indeed , [her]142-miss fairfax situation , as well as [her]142-miss fairfax beauty ; when [she]142-miss fairfax considered what all this elegance was destined to , what [she]142-miss fairfax was going to sink from , how [she]142-miss fairfax was going to live , it seemed impossible to feel any thing but compassion and respect ; especially , if to every well - known particular entitling [her]142-miss fairfax to interest , were added the highly probable circumstance of an attachment to [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , which [she]142-miss fairfax had so naturally started to [herself]142-miss fairfax . In that case , nothing could be more pitiable or more honourable than the sacrifices [she]142-miss fairfax had resolved on . [Emma]79-emma was very willing now to acquit [her]142-miss fairfax of having seduced [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon ’s affections from [[his]182-mr. dixon wife]3168-his wife , or of any thing mischievous which [her]142-miss fairfax imagination had suggested at first . If it were love , it might be simple , single , successless love on [her]142-miss fairfax side alone . [She]142-miss fairfax might have been unconsciously sucking in the sad poison , while a sharer of [his]182-mr. dixon conversation with [[her]142-miss fairfax friend]417-her friend ; and from the best , the purest of motives , might now be denying [herself]142-miss fairfax this visit to [Ireland]34-ireland , and resolving to divide [herself]142-miss fairfax effectually from [him]182-mr. dixon and [his]182-mr. dixon connexions by soon beginning [her]142-miss fairfax career of laborious duty . Upon the whole , [Emma]79-emma left [her]142-miss fairfax with such softened , charitable feelings , as made [her]142-miss fairfax look around in walking [home]3258-home , and lament that [Highbury]3-highbury afforded [no young man]3893-no young man worthy of giving [her]142-miss fairfax independence ; nobody that [she]142-miss fairfax could wish to scheme about for [her]142-miss fairfax . These were charming feelings — but not lasting . Before [she]142-miss fairfax had committed [herself]142-miss fairfax by any public profession of eternal friendship for [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , or done more towards a recantation of past prejudices and errors , than saying to [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , “[1582-she] [She]1582-she certainly is handsome ; [she]1582-she is better than handsome ! ” [Jane]142-miss fairfax had spent an evening at [Hartfield]90-hartfield with [[her]142-miss fairfax grandmother]1062-her grandmother and [aunt]1419-aunt , and every thing was relapsing much into its usual state . Former provocations reappeared . [The aunt]3215-the aunt was as tiresome as ever ; more tiresome , because anxiety for [her]3215-the aunt health was now added to admiration of [her]3215-the aunt powers ; and [they]3897-they had to listen to the description of exactly how little bread and butter [she]142-miss fairfax ate for breakfast , and how small a slice of mutton for dinner , as well as to see exhibitions of new caps and new workbags for [[her]142-miss fairfax mother]399-her mother and [herself]142-miss fairfax ; and [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s offences rose again . [They]3897-they had music ; [Emma]79-emma was obliged to play ; and the thanks and praise which necessarily followed appeared to [her]79-emma an affectation of candour , an air of greatness , meaning only to shew off in higher style [her]79-emma own very superior performance . [She]79-emma was , besides , which was the worst of all , so cold , so cautious ! There was no getting at [her]79-emma real opinion . Wrapt up in a cloak of politeness , [she]79-emma seemed determined to hazard nothing . [She]79-emma was disgustingly , was suspiciously reserved . If any thing could be more , where all was most , [she]79-emma was more reserved on the subject of [Weymouth]26-weymouth and [the Dixons]184-the dixons than any thing . [She]79-emma seemed bent on giving no real insight into [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon ’s character , or [her]79-emma own value for [his]182-mr. dixon company , or opinion of the suitableness of the match . It was all general approbation and smoothness ; nothing delineated or distinguished . It did [her]79-emma no service however . [Her]79-emma caution was thrown away . [Emma]79-emma saw its artifice , and returned to [her]79-emma first surmises . There probably was something more to conceal than [her]79-emma own preference ; [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , perhaps , had been very near changing [one friend]3899-one friend for the other , or been fixed only to [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell , for the sake of the future twelve thousand pounds . The like reserve prevailed on other topics . [She]79-emma and [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill had been at [Weymouth]26-weymouth at the same time . It was known that [they]3900-they were a little acquainted ; but not a syllable of real information could [Emma]79-emma procure as to what [he]1583-he truly was . “[1583-he] Was [he]1583-he handsome?”—“She believed [he]1583-he was reckoned [a very fine young man]3219-a very fine young man . ”[1586-her;—but] “ Was [he]1583-he agreeable?”—“He[1583-he] was generally thought so . ” “[1586-her;—but] Did [he]1583-he appear [a sensible young man]3366-a sensible young man ; [a young man of information?”—“At a watering - place]3902-a young man of information?”—“at a watering - place , or in a common [London]1-london acquaintance , it was difficult to decide on such points . Manners were all that could be safely judged of , under a much longer knowledge than [they]3900-they had yet had of [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill . [She]79-emma believed every body found [his]1583-he manners pleasing . ”[1583-he] [Emma]79-emma could not forgive [her]1585-her . CHAPTER III [Emma]79-emma could not forgive [her;—but]1586-her;—but as neither provocation nor resentment were discerned by [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , who had been of [the party]3632-the party , and had seen only proper attention and pleasing behaviour on each side , [he]88-mr. knightley was expressing the next morning , being at [Hartfield]90-hartfield again on business with [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , [his]88-mr. knightley approbation of the whole ; not so openly as [he]88-mr. knightley might have done had [[her]79-emma father]415-her father been out of [the room]3386-the room , but speaking plain enough to be very intelligible to [Emma]79-emma . [He]88-mr. knightley had been used to think [her]79-emma unjust to [Jane]142-miss fairfax , and had now great pleasure in marking an improvement . “ A very pleasant evening , ”[88-mr. knightley] [he]88-mr. knightley began , as soon as [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse had been talked into what was necessary , told that [he]88-mr. knightley understood , and the papers swept away;—“particularly pleasant . [You]79-emma and [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax gave [us]3903-us some very good music . [I]88-mr. knightley do not know a more luxurious state , [sir]3139-sir , than sitting at [one]475-one ’s ease to be entertained a whole evening by [two such young women]3906-two such young women ; sometimes with music and sometimes with conversation . [I]88-mr. knightley am sure [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax must have found the evening pleasant , [Emma]79-emma . [You]79-emma left nothing undone . [I]88-mr. knightley was glad [you]3139-sir made [her]142-miss fairfax play so much , for having no instrument at [[her]142-miss fairfax grandmother]1062-her grandmother ’s , it must have been a real indulgence . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [I]79-emma am happy [you]3139-sir approved , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , smiling ; “ but [I]79-emma hope [I]79-emma am not often deficient in what is due to [guests]3908-guests at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . ”[79-emma] “ No , [[my]415-her father dear]3120-my dear , ”[415-her father] said [[her]79-emma father]415-her father instantly ; “ that [I]415-her father am sure [you]79-emma are not . There is [nobody half so attentive and civil]3910-nobody half so attentive and civil as [you]79-emma are . If any thing , [you]79-emma are too attentive . The muffin last night — if it had been handed round once , [I]415-her father think it would have been enough . ”[415-her father] “ No , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , nearly at the same time ; “ [you]79-emma are not often deficient ; not often deficient either in manner or comprehension . [I]88-mr. knightley think [you]79-emma understand [me]88-mr. knightley , therefore . ”[88-mr. knightley] An arch look expressed—“I understand [you]415-her father well enough ; ”[79-emma] but [she]79-emma said only , “ [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax is reserved . ”[79-emma] “ [I]415-her father always told [you]415-her father [she]142-miss fairfax was — a little ; but [you]415-her father will soon overcome all that part of [her]142-miss fairfax reserve which ought to be overcome , all that has its foundation in diffidence . What arises from discretion must be honoured . ”[415-her father] “ [You]415-her father think [her]142-miss fairfax diffident . [I]79-emma do not see it . ”[79-emma] “ [[My]88-mr. knightley dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [he]88-mr. knightley , moving from [his]88-mr. knightley chair into one close by [her]79-emma , “ [you]79-emma are not going to tell [me]88-mr. knightley , [I]88-mr. knightley hope , that [you]79-emma had not a pleasant evening . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Oh ! no ; [I]79-emma was pleased with [my]79-emma own perseverance in asking questions ; and amused to think how little information [I]79-emma obtained . ”[79-emma] “ [I]88-mr. knightley am disappointed , ”[88-mr. knightley] was [his]88-mr. knightley only answer . “ [I]81-mr. woodhouse hope [every body]3270-every body had a pleasant evening , ”[81-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , in [his]81-mr. woodhouse quiet way . “ [I]81-mr. woodhouse had . Once , [I]81-mr. woodhouse felt the fire rather too much ; but then [I]81-mr. woodhouse moved back [my]81-mr. woodhouse chair a little , a very little , and it did not disturb [me]81-mr. woodhouse . [Miss Bates]101-miss bates was very chatty and good - humoured , as [she]101-miss bates always is , though [she]101-miss bates speaks rather too quick . However , [she]101-miss bates is very agreeable , and [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates too , in a different way . [I]81-mr. woodhouse like [old friends]3913-old friends ; and [Miss Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax is [a very pretty sort of young lady]3914-a very pretty sort of young lady , [a very pretty and a very well - behaved young lady]3915-a very pretty and a very well - behaved young lady indeed . [She]142-miss fairfax must have found the evening agreeable , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , because [she]142-miss fairfax had [Emma]79-emma . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ True , [sir]3139-sir ; and [Emma]79-emma , because [she]142-miss fairfax had [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . ”[1591-his] [Emma]79-emma saw [his]1591-his anxiety , and wishing to appease it , at least for the present , said , and with a sincerity which [no one]813-no one could question — “ [She]79-emma is a sort of elegant creature that one can not keep [one]475-one ’s eyes from . [I]88-mr. knightley am always watching [her]79-emma to admire ; and [I]88-mr. knightley do pity [her]79-emma from [my]88-mr. knightley heart . ”[88-mr. knightley] [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley looked as if [he]88-mr. knightley were more gratified than [he]88-mr. knightley cared to express ; and before [he]88-mr. knightley could make any reply , [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , whose thoughts were on [the Bates]106-mrs. bates ’s , said — “ It is a great pity that [their]3918-their circumstances should be so confined ! a great pity indeed ! and [I]81-mr. woodhouse have often wished — but it is so little one can venture to do — small , trifling presents , of any thing uncommon — Now [we]3919-we have killed [a porker]3920-a porker , and [Emma]79-emma thinks of sending [them]3918-their a loin or a leg ; it is very small and delicate — Hartfield pork is not like any other pork — but still it is pork — and , [[my]81-mr. woodhouse dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , unless one could be sure of [their]3918-their making it into steaks , nicely fried , as [ours]3919-we are fried , without the smallest grease , and not roast it , for no stomach can bear roast pork — [I]81-mr. woodhouse think [we]3919-we had better send the leg — do not [you]79-emma think so , [[my]81-mr. woodhouse dear]3120-my dear ? ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ [[My]81-mr. woodhouse dear papa]669-my dear papa , [I]81-mr. woodhouse sent the whole hind - quarter . [I]81-mr. woodhouse knew [you]79-emma would wish it . There will be the leg to be salted , [you]79-emma know , which is so very nice , and the loin to be dressed directly in any manner [they]3918-their like . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ That ’s right , [[my]81-mr. woodhouse dear]3120-my dear , very right . [I]81-mr. woodhouse had not thought of it before , but that is the best way . [They]3918-their must not over - salt the leg ; and then , if it is not over - salted , and if it is very thoroughly boiled , just as [Serle]109-serle boils [ours]3919-we , and eaten very moderately of , with a boiled turnip , and a little carrot or parsnip , [I]81-mr. woodhouse do not consider it unwholesome . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ [Emma]79-emma , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley presently , “ [I]88-mr. knightley have a piece of news for [you]79-emma . [He]3139-sir has been gone only four weeks . ”[79-emma] [Nobody]3124-nobody had any information to give ; and , after a few more wonderings , [Emma]79-emma said , “ [You]3139-sir are silent , [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax — but [I]79-emma hope [you]3139-sir mean to take an interest in this news . And as it is some months since [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell married , the impression may be a little worn off . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ Yes , [he]91-mr. elton has been gone just four weeks , as [you]3139-sir observe , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , ”[101-miss bates] said [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , “ four weeks yesterday.—A [Miss Hawkins!—Well]190-miss hawkins!—well , [I]101-miss bates had always rather fancied it would be [some young lady]3971-some young lady hereabouts ; not that [I]101-miss bates ever — [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole once whispered to [me]101-miss bates — but [I]101-miss bates immediately said , ‘ No , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton is [a most worthy young man]3972-a most worthy young man — but’—In short , [I]101-miss bates do not think [I]101-miss bates am particularly quick at those sort of discoveries . [I]101-miss bates do not pretend to it . What is before [me]101-miss bates , [I]101-miss bates see . At the same time , [nobody]3124-nobody could wonder if [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton should have aspired — [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield lets [me]101-miss bates chatter on , so good - humouredly . [She]90-hartfield knows [I]101-miss bates would not offend for [the world]392-the world . How does [Miss Smith]107-harriet do ? [She]107-harriet seems quite recovered now . Have [you]90-hartfield heard from [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley lately ? Oh ! [those dear little children]3975-those dear little children . [Jane]101-miss bates , do [you]101-miss bates know [I]101-miss bates always fancy [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon like [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [One]475-one takes up a notion , and runs away with it . [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , [you]90-hartfield say , is not , strictly speaking , handsome ? ”[101-miss bates] “ Handsome ! Oh ! no — far from it — certainly plain . [I]142-miss fairfax told [you]101-miss bates [he]182-mr. dixon was plain . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ [[My]142-miss fairfax dear]3120-my dear , [you]101-miss bates said that [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell would not allow [him]182-mr. dixon to be plain , and that [you]101-miss bates [yourself]101-miss bates — ”[142-miss fairfax] “ Oh ! as for [me]101-miss bates , [my]101-miss bates judgment is worth nothing . But [I]101-miss bates gave what [I]101-miss bates believed the general opinion , when [I]101-miss bates called [him]182-mr. dixon plain . ”[101-miss bates] “ Well , [[my]79-emma dear]3120-my dear [Jane]101-miss bates , [I]79-emma believe [we]3982-we must be running away . The weather does not look well , and [grandmama]1518-grandmama will be uneasy . [You]101-miss bates are too obliging , [[my]79-emma dear]3120-my dear [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield ; but [we]3982-we really must take leave . This has been a most agreeable piece of news indeed . [I]79-emma shall just go round by [[Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole ’s]3985-mrs. cole ’s ; but [I]79-emma shall not stop three minutes : and , [Jane]101-miss bates , [you]101-miss bates had better go [home]3258-home directly — [I]79-emma would not have [you]101-miss bates out in a shower!—We think [she]101-miss bates is the better for [Highbury]3-highbury already . Thank [you]101-miss bates , [we]3982-we do indeed . [I]79-emma shall not attempt calling on [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard , for [I]79-emma really do not think [she]105-mrs. goddard cares for any thing but boiled pork : when [we]3982-we dress the leg it will be another thing . [Elton]91-mr. elton , and [Miss Hawkins!—Good]191-miss hawkins!—good morning to [you]101-miss bates . ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma , alone with [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , had half [her]79-emma attention wanted by [him]415-her father while [he]415-her father lamented that [young people]1597-young people would be in such a hurry to marry — and to marry [strangers]1598-strangers too — and the other half [she]79-emma could give to [her]79-emma own view of the subject . It was to [herself]79-emma an amusing and a very welcome piece of news , as proving that [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton could not have suffered long ; but [she]79-emma was sorry for [Harriet]107-harriet : [Harriet]107-harriet must feel it — and all that [she]79-emma could hope was , by giving the first information [herself]79-emma , to save [her]79-emma from hearing it abruptly from [others]473-others . It was now about the time that [she]79-emma was likely to call . If [she]79-emma were to meet [Miss Bates]101-miss bates in [her]101-miss bates way!—and upon its beginning to rain , [Emma]79-emma was obliged to expect that the weather would be detaining [her]79-emma at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s , and that the intelligence would undoubtedly rush upon [her]79-emma without preparation . The shower was heavy , but short ; and it had not been over five minutes , when in came [Harriet]107-harriet , with just the heated , agitated look which hurrying thither with a full heart was likely to give ; and the “ Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , what do [you]90-hartfield think has happened ! ”[107-harriet] which instantly burst forth , had all the evidence of corresponding perturbation . As the blow was given , [Emma]79-emma felt that [she]79-emma could not now [shew]79-emma greater kindness than in listening ; and [Harriet]107-harriet , unchecked , ran eagerly through what [she]79-emma had to tell . “ [She]79-emma had set out from [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s]3404-mrs. goddard ’s half an hour ago — [she]79-emma had been afraid it would rain — [she]79-emma had been afraid it would pour down every moment — but [she]79-emma thought [she]79-emma might get to [Hartfield]90-hartfield first — [she]79-emma had hurried on as fast as possible ; but then , as [she]79-emma was passing by [the house]425-the house where [a young woman]1346-a young woman was making up a gown for [her]79-emma , [she]79-emma thought [she]79-emma would just step in and see how it went on ; and though [she]79-emma did not seem to stay half a moment there , soon after [she]79-emma came out it began to rain , and [she]79-emma did not know what to do ; so [she]79-emma ran on directly , as fast as [she]79-emma could , and took shelter at [Ford’s]39-ford’s . [”—Ford[1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper] ’s]3991-”—ford ’s was [the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper , and [[haberdasher]1601-haberdasher ’s shop united]1602-haberdasher ’s shop united ; [the shop first in size and fashion in the place.—“And]3992-the shop first in size and fashion in the place.—“and so , there [she]79-emma had set , without an idea of any thing in [the world]392-the world , full ten minutes , perhaps — when , all of a sudden , who should come in — to be sure it was so very odd!—but [they]3994-they always dealt at [Ford’s]39-ford’s — who should come in , but [Elizabeth Martin]108-elizabeth and [her]108-elizabeth brother!—Dear [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield ! only think . [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper thought [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper should have fainted . [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper did not know what to do .
