[She]108-elizabeth did not do any of it in the same way that [she]108-elizabeth used ; [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper could see [she]108-elizabeth was altered ; but , however , [she]108-elizabeth seemed to try to be very friendly , and [we]4000-we shook hands , and stood talking some time ; but [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper know no more what [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper said — [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was in such a tremble!—I remember [she]108-elizabeth said [she]108-elizabeth was sorry [we]4000-we never met now ; which [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper thought almost too kind ! Dear , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was absolutely miserable ! By that time , it was beginning to hold up , and [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was determined that nothing should stop [me]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper from getting away — and then — only think!—I found [he]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was coming up towards [me]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper too — slowly [you]90-hartfield know , and as if [he]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper did not quite know what to do ; and so [he]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper came and spoke , and [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper answered — and [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper stood for a minute , feeling dreadfully , [you]90-hartfield know , one ca n’t tell how ; and then [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper took courage , and said it did not rain , and [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper must go ; and so off [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper set ; and [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper had not got three yards from the door , when [he]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper came after [me]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper , only to say , if [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was going to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [he]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper thought [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper had much better go round by [[Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole ’s stables]4001-mr. cole ’s stables , for [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper should find the near way quite floated by this rain . Oh ! dear , [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper thought it would have been the death of [me]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper ! So [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper said , [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was very much obliged to [him]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper : [you]90-hartfield know [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper could not do less ; and then [he]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper went back to [Elizabeth]108-elizabeth , and [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper came round by [the stables]4002-the stables — [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper believe [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper did — but [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper hardly knew where [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was , or any thing about it . Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [I]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper would rather done any thing than have it happen : and yet , [you]90-hartfield know , there was a sort of satisfaction in seeing [him]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper behave so pleasantly and so kindly . And [Elizabeth]108-elizabeth , too . Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , do talk to [me]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper and make [me]1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper comfortable again . ”[1600-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper] Very sincerely did [Emma]79-emma wish to do so ; but it was not immediately in [her]79-emma power . [She]79-emma was obliged to stop and think . [She]79-emma was not thoroughly comfortable [herself]79-emma . [The young man]3228-the young man ’s conduct , and [[his]3228-the young man sister]1604-his sister ’s , seemed the result of real feeling , and [she]79-emma could not but pity [them]1605-them . As [Harriet]107-harriet described it , there had been an interesting mixture of wounded affection and genuine delicacy in [their]1605-them behaviour . But [she]107-harriet had believed [them]1605-them to be [well - meaning , worthy people]1606-well - meaning , worthy people before ; and what difference did this make in the evils of the connexion ? It was folly to be disturbed by it . Of course , [he]3228-the young man must be sorry to lose [her]107-harriet — [they]1605-them must be all sorry . Ambition , as well as love , had probably been mortified . [They]1605-them might all have hoped to rise by [Harriet]107-harriet ’s acquaintance : and besides , what was the value of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s description?—So easily pleased — so little discerning;—what signified [her]107-harriet praise ? [She]79-emma exerted [herself]79-emma , and did try to make [her]107-harriet comfortable , by considering all that had passed as a mere trifle , and quite unworthy of being dwelt on , “ It might be distressing , for the moment , ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma ; “ but [you]107-harriet seem to have behaved extremely well ; and it is over — and may never — can never , as a first meeting , occur again , and therefore [you]107-harriet need not think about it . ”[107-harriet] [Harriet]107-harriet said , “ very true , ”[107-harriet] and [she]107-harriet “ would not think about it ; ”[107-harriet] but still [she]107-harriet talked of it — still [she]107-harriet could talk of nothing else ; and [Emma]79-emma , at last , in order to put [the Martins]110-the martins out of [her]79-emma head , was obliged to hurry on the news , which [she]79-emma had meant to give with so much tender caution ; hardly knowing [herself]79-emma whether to rejoice or be angry , ashamed or only amused , at such a state of mind in poor [Harriet]107-harriet — such a conclusion of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s importance with [her]107-harriet ! [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s rights , however , gradually revived . Though [she]79-emma did not feel the first intelligence as [she]79-emma might have done the day before , or an hour before , its interest soon increased ; and before [their]1607-their first conversation was over , [she]79-emma had talked [herself]79-emma into all the sensations of curiosity , wonder and regret , pain and pleasure , as to this fortunate [Miss Hawkins]187-miss hawkins , which could conduce to place [the Martins]1608-the martins under proper subordination in [her]79-emma fancy . [Emma]79-emma learned to be rather glad that there had been such a meeting . It had been serviceable in deadening the first shock , without retaining any influence to alarm . As [Harriet]107-harriet now lived , [the Martins]1608-the martins could not get at [her]107-harriet , without seeking [her]107-harriet , where hitherto [they]1608-the martins had wanted either the courage or the condescension to seek [her]107-harriet ; for since [her]107-harriet refusal of [the brother]1610-the brother , [the sisters]532-the sisters never had been at [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s]3404-mrs. goddard ’s ; and [a twelvemonth]1613-a twelvemonth might pass without [their]532-the sisters being thrown together again , with any necessity , or even any power of speech . CHAPTER IV Human nature is so well disposed towards [those who are in interesting situations]1614-those who are in interesting situations , that [a young person , who either marries or dies]1615-a young person , who either marries or dies , is sure of being kindly spoken of . A week had not passed since [Miss Hawkins]187-miss hawkins ’s name was first mentioned in [Highbury]3-highbury , before [she]187-miss hawkins was , by some means or other , discovered to have every recommendation of [person]1616-person and mind ; to be handsome , elegant , highly accomplished , and perfectly amiable : and when [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton [himself]91-mr. elton arrived to triumph in [his]91-mr. elton happy prospects , and circulate the fame of [her]187-miss hawkins merits , there was very little more for [him]91-mr. elton to do , than to tell [her]187-miss hawkins Christian name , and say whose music [she]187-miss hawkins principally played . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton returned , [a very happy man]1617-a very happy man . [He]91-mr. elton had gone away rejected and mortified — disappointed in a very sanguine hope , after a series of what appeared to [him]91-mr. elton strong encouragement ; and not only losing [the right lady]1618-the right lady , but finding [himself]91-mr. elton debased to the level of [a very wrong one]1619-a very wrong one . [He]91-mr. elton had gone away deeply offended — [he]91-mr. elton came back engaged to another — and to another as superior , of course , to the first , as under such circumstances what is gained always is to what is lost . [He]91-mr. elton came back gay and self - satisfied , eager and busy , caring nothing for [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , and defying [Miss Smith]107-harriet . The charming [Augusta Hawkins]192-augusta , in addition to all the usual advantages of perfect beauty and merit , was in possession of an independent fortune , of so many thousands as would always be called ten ; a point of some dignity , as well as some convenience : the story told well ; [he]91-mr. elton had not thrown [himself]91-mr. elton away — [he]91-mr. elton had gained [a woman of 10,000 l.]1620-a woman of 10,000 l. or thereabouts ; and [he]91-mr. elton had gained [her]187-miss hawkins with such delightful rapidity — the first hour of introduction had been so very soon followed by distinguishing notice ; the history which [he]91-mr. elton had to give [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole of the rise and progress of the affair was so glorious — the steps so quick , from the accidental rencontre , to the dinner at [Mr. Green]193-mr. green ’s , and the party at [Mrs. Brown’s]194-mrs. brown’s — smiles and blushes rising in importance — with consciousness and agitation richly scattered — [the lady]774-the lady had been so easily impressed — so sweetly disposed — had in short , to use a most intelligible phrase , been so very ready to have [him]91-mr. elton , that vanity and prudence were equally contented . [He]91-mr. elton had caught both substance and shadow — both fortune and affection , and was just [the happy man [he]91-mr. elton ought to be]1622-the happy man he ought to be ; talking only of [himself]91-mr. elton and [his]91-mr. elton own concerns — expecting to be congratulated — ready to be laughed at — and , with cordial , fearless smiles , now addressing all [the young ladies of [the place]439-the place]1623-the young ladies of the place , to whom , a few weeks ago , [he]91-mr. elton would have been more cautiously gallant . The wedding was no distant event , as [the parties]1625-the parties had only [themselves]1625-the parties to please , and nothing but the necessary preparations to wait for ; and when [he]91-mr. elton set out for Bath again , there was a general expectation , which a certain glance of [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole ’s did not seem to contradict , that when [he]91-mr. elton next entered [Highbury]3-highbury [he]91-mr. elton would bring [[his]91-mr. elton bride]1626-his bride . During [his]91-mr. elton present short stay , [Emma]79-emma had barely seen [him]91-mr. elton ; but just enough to feel that the first meeting was over , and to give [her]79-emma the impression of [his]91-mr. elton not being improved by the mixture of pique and pretension , now spread over [his]91-mr. elton air . [She]79-emma was , in fact , beginning very much to wonder that [she]79-emma had ever thought [him]91-mr. elton pleasing at all ; and [his]91-mr. elton sight was so inseparably connected with some very disagreeable feelings , that , except in a moral light , as a penance , a lesson , a source of profitable humiliation to [her]79-emma own mind , [she]79-emma would have been thankful to be assured of never seeing [him]91-mr. elton again . [She]79-emma wished [him]91-mr. elton very well ; but [he]91-mr. elton gave [her]79-emma pain , and [his]91-mr. elton welfare twenty miles off would administer most satisfaction . The pain of [his]91-mr. elton continued residence in [Highbury]3-highbury , however , must certainly be lessened by [his]91-mr. elton marriage . Many vain solicitudes would be prevented — many awkwardnesses smoothed by it . [A Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton would be an excuse for any change of intercourse ; former intimacy might sink without remark . It would be almost beginning [their]1627-their life of civility again . Of [the lady]774-the lady , individually , [Emma]79-emma thought very little . [She]195-mrs. elton was good enough for [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , no doubt ; accomplished enough for [Highbury]3-highbury — handsome enough — to look plain , probably , by [Harriet]107-harriet ’s side . As to connexion , there [Emma]79-emma was perfectly easy ; persuaded , that after all [his]91-mr. elton own vaunted claims and disdain of [Harriet]107-harriet , [he]91-mr. elton had done nothing . On that article , truth seemed attainable . What [she]79-emma was , must be uncertain ; but who [she]79-emma was , might be found out ; and setting aside the 10,000 l. , it did not appear that [she]79-emma was at all [[Harriet]107-harriet ’s superior]1629-harriet ’s superior . [She]79-emma brought no name , no blood , no alliance . [Miss Hawkins]187-miss hawkins was [the youngest of the two daughters of a [Bristol]43-bristol — [merchant]1631-merchant , of course , [he]1631-merchant must be called]1630-the youngest of the two daughters of a bristol — merchant , of course , he must be called ; but , as the whole of the profits of [his]1631-merchant mercantile life appeared so very moderate , it was not unfair to guess the dignity of [his]1631-merchant line of trade had been very moderate also . Part of every winter [she]79-emma had been used to spend in [Bath]32-bath ; but [Bristol]43-bristol was [[her]79-emma home]3333-her home , [the very heart of [Bristol]43-bristol]1633-the very heart of bristol ; for though [the father]1634-the father and [mother]1537-mother had died some years ago , [an uncle]1636-an uncle remained — in the law line — nothing more distinctly honourable was hazarded of [him]1636-an uncle , than that [he]1636-an uncle was in the law line ; and with [him]1636-an uncle [the daughter]3617-the daughter had lived . [Emma]79-emma guessed [him]1636-an uncle to be the drudge of [some attorney]1638-some attorney , and too stupid to rise . And all the grandeur of the connexion seemed dependent on [the elder sister]1639-the elder sister , who was very well married , to [a gentleman in a great way , near [Bristol]43-bristol , who kept [two carriages]1641-two carriages]1640-a gentleman in a great way , near bristol , who kept two carriages ! That was the wind - up of the history ; that was the glory of [Miss Hawkins]187-miss hawkins . Could [she]187-miss hawkins but have given [Harriet]107-harriet [her]187-miss hawkins feelings about it all ! [She]187-miss hawkins had talked [her]107-harriet into love ; but , alas ! [she]107-harriet was not so easily to be talked out of it . The charm of an object to occupy the many vacancies of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s mind was not to be talked away . [He]1636-an uncle might be superseded by another ; [he]1636-an uncle certainly would indeed ; nothing could be clearer ; even [a Robert Martin]112-mr. martin would have been sufficient ; but nothing else , [she]107-harriet feared , would cure [her]107-harriet . [Harriet]107-harriet was one of [those , who , having once begun , would be always in love]1642-those , who , having once begun , would be always in love . And now , [poor girl]1411-poor girl ! [she]107-harriet was considerably worse from this reappearance of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . [She]107-harriet was always having a glimpse of [him]91-mr. elton somewhere or other . [Emma]79-emma saw [him]91-mr. elton only once ; but two or three times every day [Harriet]107-harriet was sure just to meet with [him]91-mr. elton , or just to miss [him]91-mr. elton , just to hear [his]91-mr. elton voice , or see [his]91-mr. elton shoulder , just to have something occur to preserve [him]91-mr. elton in [her]107-harriet fancy , in all the favouring warmth of surprize and conjecture . [She]107-harriet was , moreover , perpetually hearing about [him]91-mr. elton ; for , excepting when at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [she]107-harriet was always among those who saw no fault in [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , and found nothing so interesting as the discussion of [his]91-mr. elton concerns ; and every report , therefore , every guess — all that had already occurred , all that might occur in the arrangement of [his]91-mr. elton affairs , comprehending income , [servants]1644-servants , and furniture , was continually in agitation around [her]107-harriet . [Her]107-harriet regard was receiving strength by invariable praise of [him]91-mr. elton , and [her]107-harriet regrets kept alive , and feelings irritated by ceaseless repetitions of [Miss Hawkins]187-miss hawkins ’s happiness , and continual observation of , how much [he]91-mr. elton seemed attached!—his air as [he]91-mr. elton walked by [the house]425-the house — the very sitting of [his]91-mr. elton hat , being all in proof of how much [he]91-mr. elton was in love ! Had it been allowable entertainment , had there been no pain to [[her]107-harriet friend]417-her friend , or reproach to [herself]107-harriet , in the waverings of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s mind , [Emma]79-emma would have been amused by its variations . Sometimes [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton predominated , sometimes [the Martins]1608-the martins ; and each was occasionally useful as a check to [the other]3423-the other . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s engagement had been the cure of the agitation of meeting [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin . The unhappiness produced by the knowledge of that engagement had been a little put aside by [Elizabeth Martin]108-elizabeth ’s calling at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s a few days afterwards . [Harriet]107-harriet had not been at [home]3258-home ; but a note had been prepared and left for [her]107-harriet , written in the very style to touch ; a small mixture of reproach , with a great deal of kindness ; and till [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton [himself]91-mr. elton appeared , [she]107-harriet had been much occupied by it , continually pondering over what could be done in return , and wishing to do more than [she]107-harriet dared to confess . But [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , in person , had driven away all such cares . While [he]91-mr. elton staid , [the Martins]1608-the martins were forgotten ; and on the very morning of [his]91-mr. elton setting off for [Bath]32-bath again , [Emma]79-emma , to dissipate some of the distress it occasioned , judged it best for [her]107-harriet to return [Elizabeth Martin]108-elizabeth ’s visit . How that visit was to be acknowledged — what would be necessary — and what might be safest , had been a point of some doubtful consideration . Absolute neglect of [the mother and sisters]1651-the mother and sisters , when invited to come , would be ingratitude . It must not be : and yet the danger of a renewal of the acquaintance — ! After much thinking , [she]79-emma could determine on nothing better , than [Harriet]107-harriet ’s returning the visit ; but in a way that , if [they]1651-the mother and sisters had understanding , should convince [them]1651-the mother and sisters that it was to be only a formal acquaintance . [She]79-emma meant to take [her]107-harriet in [the carriage]3125-the carriage , leave [her]107-harriet at [the Abbey Mill]18-abbey - mill , while [she]79-emma drove a little farther , and call for [her]107-harriet again so soon , as to allow no time for insidious applications or dangerous recurrences to the past , and give the most decided proof of what degree of intimacy was chosen for the future . [She]79-emma could think of nothing better : and though there was something in it which [her]79-emma own heart could not approve — something of ingratitude , merely glossed over — it must be done , or what would become of [Harriet]107-harriet ? CHAPTER V Small heart had [Harriet]107-harriet for visiting . Only half an hour before [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend called for [her]107-harriet at [[Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s]3404-mrs. goddard ’s , [her]79-emma evil stars had led [her]107-harriet to the very spot where , at that moment , a trunk , directed to [The Rev. Philip Elton]196-the rev. philip elton , [White - Hart , Bath]1655-white - hart , bath , was to be seen under the operation of being lifted into [the butcher]1656-the butcher ’s cart , which was to convey it to where [the coaches past]1657-the coaches past ; and every thing in [this world]1658-this world , excepting that trunk and the direction , was consequently a blank . [She]107-harriet went , however ; and when [they]1659-they reached [the farm]1660-the farm , and [she]107-harriet was to be put down , at the end of [the broad , neat gravel walk]1661-the broad , neat gravel walk , which led between espalier apple - trees to the front door , the sight of every thing which had given [her]107-harriet so much pleasure the autumn before , was beginning to revive a little local agitation ; and when [they]1659-they parted , [Emma]79-emma observed [her]107-harriet to be looking around with a sort of fearful curiosity , which determined [her]107-harriet not to allow the visit to exceed the proposed quarter of an hour . [She]107-harriet went on [herself]107-harriet , to give that portion of time to [an old servant who was married , and settled in [Donwell]202-donwell]1662-an old servant who was married , and settled in donwell . The quarter of an hour brought [her]107-harriet punctually to the white gate again ; and [Miss Smith]107-harriet receiving [her]107-harriet summons , was with [her]107-harriet without delay , and unattended by [any alarming young man]1663-any alarming young man . [She]107-harriet came solitarily down [the gravel walk]1664-the gravel walk — [a Miss Martin]197-a miss martin just appearing at the door , and parting with [her]107-harriet seemingly with ceremonious civility . [Harriet]107-harriet could not very soon give an intelligible account . [She]107-harriet was feeling too much ; but at last [Emma]79-emma collected from [her]107-harriet enough to understand the sort of meeting , and the sort of pain it was creating . [She]107-harriet had seen only [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin and [the two girls]1665-the two girls . [They]1666-they had received [her]107-harriet doubtingly , if not coolly ; and nothing beyond the merest commonplace had been talked almost all the time — till just at last , when [Mrs. Martin]111-mrs. martin ’s saying , all of a sudden , that [she]111-mrs. martin thought [Miss Smith]107-harriet was grown , had brought on a more interesting subject , and a warmer manner . In [that very room]1667-that very room [she]107-harriet had been measured last September , with [[her]107-harriet two friends]1668-her two friends . There were the pencilled marks and memorandums on the wainscot by the window . [He]1669-he had done it . [They]1666-they all seemed to remember the day , the hour , the party , the occasion — to feel the same consciousness , the same regrets — to be ready to return to the same good understanding ; and [they]1666-they were just growing again like [themselves]1666-they , ( [Harriet]107-harriet , as [Emma]79-emma must suspect , as ready as the best of [them]1666-they to be cordial and happy , ) when [the carriage]3125-the carriage reappeared , and all was over . The style of the visit , and the shortness of it , were then felt to be decisive . Fourteen minutes to be given to those with whom [she]107-harriet had thankfully passed six weeks not six months [ago!—Emma]1671-ago!—emma could not but picture it all , and feel how justly [they]1666-they might resent , how naturally [Harriet]107-harriet must suffer . It was a bad business . [She]107-harriet would have given a great deal , or endured a great deal , to have had [the Martins]110-the martins in a higher rank of life . [They]110-the martins were so deserving , that a little higher should have been enough : but as it was , how could [she]107-harriet have done otherwise?—Impossible!—She could not repent . [They]110-the martins must be separated ; but there was a great deal of pain in the process — so much to [herself]107-harriet at this time , that [she]107-harriet soon felt the necessity of a little consolation , and resolved on going [home]3258-home by way of [Randalls]97-randalls to procure it . [Her]107-harriet mind was quite sick of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton and [the Martins]110-the martins . The refreshment of [Randalls]97-randalls was absolutely necessary . It was a good scheme ; but on driving to the door [they]110-the martins heard that [neither “ master]4003-neither “ master nor [mistress]4004-mistress was at [home]3258-home ; ”[4003-neither “ master] [they]110-the martins had both been out some time ; [the man]758-the man believed [they]110-the martins were gone to [Hartfield]90-hartfield . “ This is too bad , ”[79-emma] cried [Emma]79-emma , as [they]110-the martins turned away . “ And now [we]110-the martins shall just miss [them]110-the martins ; too provoking!—I do not know when [I]79-emma have been so disappointed . ”[79-emma] And [she]107-harriet leaned back in the corner , to indulge [her]107-harriet murmurs , or to reason them away ; probably a little of both — such being the commonest process of a not ill - disposed mind . Presently [the carriage]3125-the carriage stopt ; [she]107-harriet looked up ; it was stopt by [Mr.]1675-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , who were standing to speak to [her]107-harriet . There was instant pleasure in the sight of [them]110-the martins , and still greater pleasure was conveyed in sound — for [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston immediately accosted [her]107-harriet with , “ How d’ye do?—how d’ye do?—We have been sitting with [[your]107-harriet father]1389-your father — glad to see [him]1389-your father so well . [Frank]98-frank churchill comes to - morrow — [I]82-mr. weston had a letter this morning — [we]110-the martins see [him]1389-your father to - morrow by dinner - time to a certainty — [he]1389-your father is at [Oxford]45-oxford to - day , and [he]1389-your father comes for a whole fortnight ; [I]82-mr. weston knew it would be so . If [he]1389-your father had come at Christmas [he]1389-your father could not have staid three days ; [I]82-mr. weston was always glad [he]1389-your father did not come at Christmas ; now [we]110-the martins are going to have just the right weather for [him]1389-your father , fine , dry , settled weather . [We]110-the martins shall enjoy [him]1389-your father completely ; every thing has turned out exactly as [we]110-the martins could wish . ”[82-mr. weston] There was no resisting such news , no possibility of avoiding the influence of such a happy face as [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s , confirmed as it all was by the words and the countenance of [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife , fewer and quieter , but not less to the purpose . To know that [she]3168-his wife thought [his]82-mr. weston coming certain was enough to make [Emma]79-emma consider it so , and sincerely did [she]3168-his wife rejoice in [their]1677-their joy . It was a most delightful reanimation of exhausted spirits . The worn - out past was sunk in the freshness of what was coming ; and in the rapidity of half a moment ’s thought , [she]3168-his wife hoped [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton would now be talked of no more . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston gave [her]3168-his wife the history of the engagements at [Enscombe]7-enscombe , which allowed [[his]82-mr. weston son]3218-his son to answer for having an entire fortnight at [his]82-mr. weston command , as well as the route and the method of [his]82-mr. weston journey ; and [she]3168-his wife listened , and smiled , and congratulated . “ [I]82-mr. weston shall soon bring [him]82-mr. weston over to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , ”[82-mr. weston] said [he]82-mr. weston , at the conclusion . [Emma]79-emma could imagine [she]79-emma saw a touch of the arm at this speech , from [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife . “ [We]4007-we had better move on , [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , ”[3168-his wife] said [she]3168-his wife , “ [we]4007-we are detaining [the girls]3337-the girls . ”[3168-his wife] “ Well , well , [I]79-emma am ready;”—and[79-emma] turning again to [Emma]79-emma , “ but [you]79-emma must not be expecting [such a very fine young man]4009-such a very fine young man ; [you]79-emma have only had [my]79-emma account [you]79-emma know ; [I]79-emma dare say [he]4009-such a very fine young man is really nothing extraordinary:”—though[79-emma] [his]82-mr. weston own sparkling eyes at the moment were speaking a very different conviction . [Emma]79-emma could look perfectly unconscious and innocent , and answer in a manner that appropriated nothing . “ Think of [me]84-mrs. weston to - morrow , [[my]84-mrs. weston dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , about four o’clock , ”[84-mrs. weston] was [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s parting injunction ; spoken with some anxiety , and meant only for [her]79-emma . “ Four o’clock!—depend upon it [he]4009-such a very fine young man will be [here]3113-here by three , ”[82-mr. weston] was [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s quick amendment ; and so ended a most satisfactory meeting . [Emma]79-emma ’s spirits were mounted quite up to happiness ; every thing wore a different air ; [James]86-james and [his]82-mr. weston horses seemed not half so sluggish as before . When [she]79-emma looked at the hedges , [she]79-emma thought [the elder]3595-the elder at least must soon be coming out ; and when [she]79-emma turned round to [Harriet]107-harriet , [she]79-emma saw something like a look of spring , a tender smile even there . “ Will [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill pass through [Bath]32-bath as well as Oxford?”—was[79-emma] a question , however , which did not augur much . But neither geography nor tranquillity could come all at once , and [Emma]79-emma was now in a humour to resolve that [they]1681-they should both come in time . The morning of the interesting day arrived , and [[Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil did not forget either at ten , or eleven , or twelve o’clock , that [she]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil was to think of [her]79-emma at four . “ [[My]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil dear]3120-my dear , dear anxious friend,”—said[1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil] [she]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil , in mental soliloquy , while walking [downstairs]1683-downstairs from [[her]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil own room]955-her own room , “ always overcareful for every body ’s comfort but [your]3120-my dear own ; [I]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil see [you]3120-my dear now in all [your]3120-my dear little fidgets , going again and again into [[his]98-frank churchill room]4013-his room , to be sure that all is right . ”[1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil] The clock struck twelve as [she]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil passed through [the hall]1685-the hall . “ ’ Tis twelve ; [I]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil shall not forget to think of [you]3120-my dear four hours hence ; and by this time to - morrow , perhaps , or a little later , [I]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil may be thinking of the possibility of [their]1686-two gentlemen all calling here . [The Frank Churchill so long talked of]1690-the frank churchill so long talked of , so high in interest , was actually before [her]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil — [he]98-frank churchill was presented to [her]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil , and [she]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil did not think too much had been said in [his]98-frank churchill praise ; [he]98-frank churchill was [a very good looking young man]1691-a very good looking young man ; height , air , address , all were unexceptionable , and [his]98-frank churchill countenance had a great deal of the spirit and liveliness of [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father ’s ; [he]98-frank churchill looked quick and sensible . [She]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil felt immediately that [she]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil should like [him]98-frank churchill ; and there was a well - bred ease of manner , and a readiness to talk , which convinced [her]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil that [he]98-frank churchill came intending to be acquainted with [her]1682-mrs. weston ’s faithful pupil , and that acquainted [they]1693-they soon must be . [He]98-frank churchill had reached [Randalls]97-randalls the evening before . [I]82-mr. weston remembered what [I]82-mr. weston used to do [myself]82-mr. weston . [One]475-one can not creep upon a journey ; [one]475-one can not help getting on faster than [one]475-one has planned ; and the pleasure of coming in upon [[one]475-one ’s friends]4019-one ’s friends before the look - out begins , is worth a great deal more than any little exertion it needs . ”[82-mr. weston] “ It is a great pleasure where [one]475-one can indulge in it , ”[3228-the young man] said [the young man]3228-the young man , “ though there are [not many houses that [I]3228-the young man should presume on so far]4021-not many houses that i should presume on so far ; but in coming [home]3258-home [I]3228-the young man felt [I]3228-the young man might do any thing . ”[3228-the young man] The word [home]3258-home made [[his]3228-the young man father]3213-his father look on [him]3228-the young man with fresh complacency . [Emma]79-emma was directly sure that [he]3228-the young man knew how to make [himself]3228-the young man agreeable ; the conviction was strengthened by what followed . [He]3228-the young man was very much pleased with [Randalls]97-randalls , thought [it]97-randalls [a most admirably arranged house]1697-a most admirably arranged house , would hardly allow [it]97-randalls even to be very small , admired the situation , the walk to [Highbury]3-highbury , [Highbury]3-highbury itself , [Hartfield]90-hartfield still more , and professed [himself]3228-the young man to have always felt the sort of interest in [the country which [none but one ’s own country]1699-none but one ’s own country]1698-the country which none but one ’s own country gives , and the greatest curiosity to visit [it]1698-the country which none but one ’s own country . That [he]3228-the young man should never have been able to indulge so amiable a feeling before , passed suspiciously through [Emma]79-emma ’s brain ; but still , if it were a falsehood , it was a pleasant one , and pleasantly handled . [His]3228-the young man manner had no air of study or exaggeration . [He]3228-the young man did really look and speak as if in a state of no common enjoyment . [[Their]1700-their subjects]3593-their subjects in general were such as belong to an opening acquaintance . On [his]3228-the young man side were the inquiries,—“Was [she]1704-his mother - in - law a horsewoman?—Pleasant rides?—Pleasant walks?—Had [they]1700-their a large neighbourhood?—Highbury , perhaps , afforded society enough?—There were [several very pretty houses in and about it.—Balls]4023-several very pretty houses in and about it.—balls — had [they]1700-their balls?—Was it a musical society ? ”[3228-the young man] But when satisfied on all these points , and [their]1700-their acquaintance proportionably advanced , [he]3228-the young man contrived to find an opportunity , while [[their]1700-their two fathers]1702-their two fathers were engaged with [each other]420-each other , of introducing [[his]3228-the young man mother - in - law]1704-his mother - in - law , and speaking of [her]1704-his mother - in - law with so much handsome praise , so much warm admiration , so much gratitude for the happiness [she]1704-his mother - in - law secured to [[his]3228-the young man father]3213-his father , and [her]1704-his mother - in - law very kind reception of [himself]3228-the young man , as was an additional proof of [his]3228-the young man knowing how to please — and of [his]3228-the young man certainly thinking it worth while to try to please [her]1704-his mother - in - law . [He]3228-the young man did not advance a word of praise beyond what [she]1704-his mother - in - law knew to be thoroughly deserved by [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ; but , undoubtedly [he]3228-the young man could know very little of the matter . [He]3228-the young man understood what would be welcome ; [he]3228-the young man could be sure of little else . “ [[His]3228-the young man father]3213-his father ’s marriage , ”[3228-the young man] [he]3228-the young man said , “ had been the wisest measure , [every friend]4025-every friend must rejoice in it ; and [the family from whom [he]3228-the young man had received such a blessing]4026-the family from whom he had received such a blessing must be ever considered as having conferred the highest obligation on [him]3228-the young man . ”[3228-the young man] [He]3228-the young man got as near as [he]3228-the young man could to thanking [her]1704-his mother - in - law for [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ’s merits , without seeming quite to forget that in the common course of things it was to be rather supposed that [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor had formed [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor ’s character , than [Miss Woodhouse Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ’s . And at last , as if resolved to qualify [his]3228-the young man opinion completely for travelling round to its object , [he]3228-the young man wound it all up with astonishment at the youth and beauty of [her]1704-his mother - in - law person . “ Elegant , agreeable manners , [I]3228-the young man was prepared for , ”[3228-the young man] said [he]3228-the young man ; “ but [I]3228-the young man confess that , considering every thing , [I]3228-the young man had not expected more than [a very tolerably well - looking woman of a certain age]4027-a very tolerably well - looking woman of a certain age ; [I]3228-the young man did not know that [I]3228-the young man was to find [a pretty young woman]1141-a pretty young woman in [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . ”[3228-the young man] “ [You]3228-the young man can not see too much perfection in [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston for [my]79-emma feelings , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma ; “ were [you]3228-the young man to guess [her]84-mrs. weston to be eighteen , [I]79-emma should listen with pleasure ; but [she]84-mrs. weston would be ready to quarrel with [you]3228-the young man for using such words . Do n’t let [her]84-mrs. weston imagine that [you]3228-the young man have spoken of [her]84-mrs. weston as [a pretty young woman]1141-a pretty young woman . ”[79-emma] “ [I]1706-he hope [I]1706-he should know better , ”[1706-he] [he]1706-he replied ; “ no , depend upon it , ( with a gallant bow , ) that in addressing [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston [I]1706-he should understand whom [I]1706-he might praise without any danger of being thought extravagant in [my]1706-he terms . ”[1706-he] [Emma]79-emma wondered whether the same suspicion of what might be expected from [their]1707-them knowing each other , which had taken strong possession of [her]79-emma mind , had ever crossed [his]1706-he ; and whether [his]1706-he compliments were to be considered as marks of acquiescence , or proofs of defiance . [She]79-emma must see more of [him]1706-he to understand [his]1706-he ways ; at present [she]79-emma only felt they were agreeable . [She]79-emma had no doubt of what [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was often thinking about . [His]1706-he quick eye [she]79-emma detected again and again glancing towards [them]1707-them with a happy expression ; and even , when [he]1706-he might have determined not to look , [she]79-emma was confident that [he]1706-he was often listening . [[Her]79-emma own father]1708-her own father ’s perfect exemption from any thought of the kind , the entire deficiency in [him]1706-he of all such sort of penetration or suspicion , was a most comfortable circumstance . Happily [he]1706-he was not farther from approving matrimony than from foreseeing it.—Though always objecting to every marriage that was arranged , [he]1706-he never suffered beforehand from the apprehension of any ; it seemed as if [he]1706-he could not think so ill of [any two persons]1709-any two persons ’ understanding as to suppose [they]1707-them meant to marry till it were proved against [them]1707-them . [She]79-emma blessed the favouring blindness . [He]1706-he could now , without the drawback of a single unpleasant surmise , without a glance forward at any possible treachery in [[his]1706-he guest]1710-his guest , give way to all [his]1706-he natural kind - hearted civility in solicitous inquiries after [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s accommodation on [his]1706-he journey , through the sad evils of sleeping two nights on [the road]3487-the road , and express very genuine unmixed anxiety to know that [he]1706-he had certainly escaped catching cold — which , however , [he]1706-he could not allow [him]1706-he to feel quite assured of [himself]1706-he till after another night . A reasonable visit paid , [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston began to move.—“He must be going . [He]82-mr. weston had business at [the Crown]46-the crown about [his]82-mr. weston hay , and a great many errands for [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston at [Ford ’s]200-ford ’s , but [he]82-mr. weston need not hurry any body else . ”[82-mr. weston] [[His]1706-he son]3218-his son , too well bred to hear the hint , rose immediately also , saying , “ As [you]1706-he are going farther on business , [sir]3139-sir , [I]82-mr. weston will take the opportunity of paying a visit , which must be paid some day or other , and therefore may as well be paid now . [I]82-mr. weston have the honour of being acquainted with [a neighbour of [yours]1706-he]4031-a neighbour of yours , ( turning to [Emma]79-emma , ) [a lady residing in or near [Highbury]3-highbury]4032-a lady residing in or near highbury ; [a family of the name of Fairfax]4033-a family of the name of fairfax . [I]82-mr. weston shall have no difficulty , [I]82-mr. weston suppose , in finding [the house]425-the house ; though [Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , [I]82-mr. weston believe , is not the proper name — [I]82-mr. weston should rather say [Barnes]198-barnes , or [Bates]101-miss bates . Do [you]1706-he know [any family of that name]4035-any family of that name ? ”[82-mr. weston] “ To be sure [we]4036-we do , ”[3213-his father] cried [[his]1713-his father]3213-his father ; “ [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates — [we]4036-we passed [[her]106-mrs. bates house]3401-her house — [I]82-mr. weston saw [Miss Bates]101-miss bates at the window . True , true , [you]1706-he are acquainted with [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ; [I]82-mr. weston remember [you]1706-he knew [her]142-miss fairfax at [Weymouth]26-weymouth , and [a fine girl]4038-a fine girl [she]142-miss fairfax is . Call upon [her]142-miss fairfax , by all means . ”[82-mr. weston] “ There is no necessity for [my]3228-the young man calling this morning , ”[3228-the young man] said [the young man]3228-the young man ; “ another day would do as well ; but there was that degree of acquaintance at [Weymouth]26-weymouth which — ”[3228-the young man] “ Oh ! go to - day , go to - day . Do not defer it . What is right to be done can not be done too soon . And , besides , [I]3169-the son must give [you]1706-he a hint , [Frank]98-frank churchill ; any want of attention to [her]142-miss fairfax here should be carefully avoided . [You]1706-he saw [her]142-miss fairfax with [the Campbells]180-the campbells , when [she]142-miss fairfax was [the equal of every body [she]142-miss fairfax mixed with]4039-the equal of every body she mixed with , but here [she]142-miss fairfax is with [a poor old grandmother , who has barely enough to live on]4040-a poor old grandmother , who has barely enough to live on . If [you]1706-he do not call early it will be a slight . ”[3169-the son] [The son]3169-the son looked convinced . “ [I]79-emma have heard [her]142-miss fairfax speak of the acquaintance , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma ; “ [she]142-miss fairfax is [a very elegant young woman]4041-a very elegant young woman . ”[79-emma] [He]3169-the son agreed to it , but with so quiet a “ Yes , ”[79-emma] as inclined [her]79-emma almost to doubt [his]3169-the son real concurrence ; and yet there must be a very distinct sort of elegance for the fashionable world , if [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax could be thought only ordinarily gifted with it . “ If [you]3169-the son were never particularly struck by [her]142-miss fairfax manners before , ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma , “ [I]79-emma think [you]3169-the son will to - day . [You]3169-the son will see [her]142-miss fairfax to advantage ; see [her]142-miss fairfax and hear [her]142-miss fairfax — no , [I]79-emma am afraid [you]3169-the son will not hear [her]142-miss fairfax at all , for [she]142-miss fairfax has [an aunt who never holds [her]142-miss fairfax tongue]4042-an aunt who never holds her tongue . ”[79-emma] “ [You]3169-the son are acquainted with [Miss Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , [sir]3139-sir , are [you]3169-the son ? ”[81-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , always the last to make [his]81-mr. woodhouse way in conversation ; “ then give [me]81-mr. woodhouse leave to assure [you]3169-the son that [you]3169-the son will find [her]142-miss fairfax [a very agreeable young lady]4044-a very agreeable young lady . [She]142-miss fairfax is staying [here]3113-here on a visit to [[her]142-miss fairfax grandmama]951-her grandmama and [aunt]1419-aunt , [very worthy people]4048-very worthy people ; [I]81-mr. woodhouse have known [them]4048-very worthy people all [my]81-mr. woodhouse life . [They]4048-very worthy people will be extremely glad to see [you]3169-the son , [I]81-mr. woodhouse am sure ; and [one of [[my]81-mr. woodhouse servants]4050-my servants]4049-one of my servants shall go with [you]3169-the son to shew [you]3169-the son the way . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ [[My]79-emma dear [sir]3139-sir]741-my dear sir , upon no account in [the world]392-the world ; [[my]79-emma father]3146-my father can direct [me]79-emma . ”[79-emma] “ But [[your]3169-the son father]1389-your father is not going so far ; [he]1389-your father is only going to [the Crown]4056-the crown , quite on the other side of [the street]3836-the street , and there are [a great many houses]4058-a great many houses ; [you]3169-the son might be very much at a loss , and it is a very dirty walk , unless [you]3169-the son keep on the footpath ; but [[my]98-frank churchill coachman]4059-my coachman can tell [you]3169-the son where [you]3169-the son had best cross [the street]3836-the street . ”[98-frank churchill] [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill still declined it , looking as serious as [he]98-frank churchill could , and [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father gave [his]3213-his father hearty support by calling out , “ [[My]3213-his father good friend]4061-my good friend , this is quite unnecessary ; [Frank]98-frank churchill knows a puddle of water when [he]98-frank churchill sees it , and as to [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates ’s , [he]98-frank churchill may get there from the Crown in a hop , step , and jump . ”[3213-his father] [They]1718-they were permitted to go alone ; and with a cordial nod from [one]475-one , and a graceful bow from the other , [the two gentlemen]1720-the two gentlemen took leave . [Emma]79-emma remained very well pleased with this beginning of the acquaintance , and could now engage to think of [them]1720-the two gentlemen all at [Randalls]97-randalls any hour of the day , with full confidence in [their]1720-the two gentlemen comfort . CHAPTER VI The next morning brought [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill again . [He]98-frank churchill came with [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , to whom and to [Highbury]3-highbury [he]98-frank churchill seemed to take very cordially . [He]98-frank churchill had been sitting with [her]84-mrs. weston , it appeared , most companionably at [home]3258-home , till [her]84-mrs. weston usual hour of exercise ; and on being desired to chuse [their]1718-they walk , immediately fixed on [Highbury.—“He]199-highbury.—“he did not doubt there being very pleasant walks in every direction , but if left to [him]98-frank churchill , [he]98-frank churchill should always chuse the same . [Highbury]3-highbury , [that airy , cheerful , happy - looking Highbury]3-highbury , would be [his]98-frank churchill constant attraction . ”—Highbury[84-mrs. weston] , with [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , stood for [Hartfield]90-hartfield ; and [she]84-mrs. weston trusted to its bearing the same construction with [him]98-frank churchill . [They]1718-they walked thither directly . [Emma]79-emma had hardly expected [them]1718-they : for [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , who had called in for half a minute , in order to hear that [[his]82-mr. weston son]3218-his son was very handsome , knew nothing of [their]1718-they plans ; and it was an agreeable surprize to [her]79-emma , therefore , to perceive [them]1718-they walking up to [the house]425-the house together , arm in arm . [She]79-emma was wanting to see [him]98-frank churchill again , and especially to see [him]98-frank churchill in company with [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , upon [his]98-frank churchill behaviour to whom [her]84-mrs. weston opinion of [him]98-frank churchill was to depend . If [he]98-frank churchill were deficient there , nothing should make amends for it . But on seeing [them]1718-they together , [she]79-emma became perfectly satisfied . It was not merely in fine words or hyperbolical compliment that [he]98-frank churchill paid [his]98-frank churchill duty ; nothing could be more proper or pleasing than [his]98-frank churchill whole manner to [her]79-emma — nothing could more agreeably denote [his]98-frank churchill wish of considering [her]79-emma as [a friend]405-a friend and securing [her]79-emma affection . And there was time enough for [Emma]79-emma to form a reasonable judgment , as [their]1718-they visit included all the rest of the morning . [They]1718-they were all three walking about together for an hour or two — first round [the shrubberies of [Hartfield]90-hartfield]1725-the shrubberies of hartfield , and afterwards in [Highbury]3-highbury . [He]98-frank churchill was delighted with every thing ; admired [Hartfield]90-hartfield sufficiently for [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s ear ; and when [their]1718-they going farther was resolved on , confessed [his]98-frank churchill wish to be made acquainted with [the whole village]1726-the whole village , and found matter of commendation and interest much oftener than [Emma]79-emma could have supposed . Some of the objects of [his]98-frank churchill curiosity spoke very amiable feelings . [He]98-frank churchill begged to be shewn [the house which [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father]1727-the house which his father had lived in so long , and which had been [the home of [[his]98-frank churchill father ’s father]1730-his father ’s father]1729-the home of his father ’s father ; and on recollecting that [an old woman who had nursed [him]98-frank churchill]1731-an old woman who had nursed him was still living , walked in quest of [[her]1731-an old woman who had nursed him cottage]1732-her cottage from one end of [the street]3836-the street to the other ; and though in some points of pursuit or observation there was no positive merit , [they]1718-they shewed , altogether , a good - will towards [Highbury]3-highbury in general , which must be very like a merit to those [he]98-frank churchill was with . [Emma]79-emma watched and decided , that with such feelings as were now shewn , it could not be fairly supposed that [he]98-frank churchill had been ever voluntarily absenting [himself]98-frank churchill ; that [he]98-frank churchill had not been acting a part , or making a parade of insincere professions ; and that [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley certainly had not done [him]98-frank churchill justice . [Their]1718-they first pause was at [the Crown Inn]1734-the crown inn , [an inconsiderable house]1735-an inconsiderable house , though [the principal one of the sort]1736-the principal one of the sort , where a couple of pair of post - horses were kept , more for the convenience of [the neighbourhood]1737-the neighbourhood than from any run on [the road]3487-the road ; and [[his]98-frank churchill companions]3777-his companions had not expected to be detained by any interest excited there ; but in passing it [they]1718-they gave the history of [the large room]1740-the large room visibly added ; [it]1740-the large room had been built many years ago for [a ball - room]1741-a ball - room , and while [the neighbourhood]1737-the neighbourhood had been in a particularly populous , dancing state , had been occasionally used as such;—but such brilliant days had long passed away , and now the highest purpose for which it was ever wanted was to accommodate a whist club established among [the gentlemen]1743-the gentlemen and [half - gentlemen of [the place]439-the place]1744-half - gentlemen of the place . [He]98-frank churchill was immediately interested . Its character as [a ball - room]1741-a ball - room caught [him]98-frank churchill ; and instead of passing on , [he]98-frank churchill stopt for several minutes at the two superior sashed windows which were open , to look in and contemplate [its]1740-the large room capabilities , and lament that its original purpose should have ceased . [He]98-frank churchill saw no fault in [the room]3386-the room , [he]98-frank churchill would acknowledge none which [they]1718-they suggested . No , it was long enough , broad enough , handsome enough . [It]3386-the room would hold the very number for comfort . [They]1718-they ought to have balls [there]437-there at least every fortnight through the winter . Why had not [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield revived the former good old days of the room?—She who could do any thing in [Highbury]3-highbury ! The want of [proper families]1749-proper families in [the place]439-the place , and the conviction that none beyond [the place]439-the place and [[its]439-the place immediate environs]1752-its immediate environs could be tempted to attend , were mentioned ; but [he]98-frank churchill was not satisfied . [He]98-frank churchill could not be persuaded that [so many good - looking houses as [he]98-frank churchill saw around [him]98-frank churchill]1753-so many good - looking houses as he saw around him , could not furnish numbers enough for such a meeting ; and even when particulars were given and [families]1754-families described , [he]98-frank churchill was still unwilling to admit that the inconvenience of such a mixture would be any thing , or that there would be the smallest difficulty in every body ’s returning into [their]1718-they proper place the next morning . [He]98-frank churchill argued like [a young man very much bent on dancing]1755-a young man very much bent on dancing ; and [Emma]79-emma was rather surprized to see the constitution of [the Weston]82-mr. weston prevail so decidedly against the habits of [the Churchills]96-the churchills . [He]98-frank churchill seemed to have all the life and spirit , cheerful feelings , and social inclinations of [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father , and nothing of the pride or reserve of [Enscombe]7-enscombe . Of pride , indeed , there was , perhaps , scarcely enough ; [his]98-frank churchill indifference to a confusion of rank , bordered too much on inelegance of mind . [He]98-frank churchill could be [no judge]1757-no judge , however , of the evil [he]98-frank churchill was holding cheap . It was but an effusion of lively spirits . At last [he]98-frank churchill was persuaded to move on from the front of [the Crown]46-the crown ; and being now almost facing [the house where [the Bateses]149-the bateses lodged]1758-the house where the bateses lodged , [Emma]79-emma recollected [his]98-frank churchill intended visit the day before , and asked [him]98-frank churchill if [he]98-frank churchill had paid it . “ Yes , oh ! yes”—he[79-emma] replied ; “ [I]79-emma was just going to mention it . [A very successful visit:—I]4062-a very successful visit:—i saw [all the three ladies]4063-all the three ladies ; and felt very much obliged to [you]79-emma for [your]79-emma preparatory hint . If [the talking aunt]4064-the talking aunt had taken [me]79-emma quite by surprize , it must have been the death of [me]79-emma . As it was , [I]79-emma was only betrayed into paying a most unreasonable visit . Ten minutes would have been all that was necessary , perhaps all that was proper ; and [I]79-emma had told [[my]79-emma father]3146-my father [I]79-emma should certainly be at [home]3258-home before [him]3146-my father — but there was no getting away , no pause ; and , to [my]79-emma utter astonishment , [I]79-emma found , when [he]3146-my father ( finding [me]79-emma nowhere else ) joined [me]79-emma [there]437-there at last , that [I]79-emma had been actually sitting with [them]4068-them very nearly three - quarters of an hour . [The good lady]4069-the good lady had not given [me]79-emma the possibility of escape before . ”[79-emma] “ And how did [you]79-emma think [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax looking ? ”[79-emma] “ Ill , very ill — that is , if [a young lady]467-a young lady can ever be allowed to look ill . But the expression is hardly admissible , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , is it ? [Ladies]1252-ladies can never look ill . And , seriously , [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax is naturally so pale , as almost always to give the appearance of ill health.—A most deplorable want of complexion . ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma would not agree to this , and began a warm defence of [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s complexion . “ It was certainly never brilliant , but [she]142-miss fairfax would not allow it to have a sickly hue in general ; and there was a softness and delicacy in [her]142-miss fairfax skin which gave peculiar elegance to the character of [her]142-miss fairfax face . ”[1759-you] [He]1759-you listened with all due deference ; acknowledged that [he]1759-you had heard [many people]1218-many people say the same — but yet [he]1759-you must confess , that to [him]1759-you nothing could make amends for the want of the fine glow of health . Where features were indifferent , a fine complexion gave beauty to [them]1761-them all ; and where [they]1761-them were good , the effect was — fortunately [he]1759-you need not attempt to describe what the effect was . “ Well , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , “ there is no disputing about taste.—At least [you]1759-you admire [her]142-miss fairfax except [her]142-miss fairfax complexion . ”[79-emma] [He]1759-you shook [his]1759-you head and laughed.—“I can not separate [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and [her]142-miss fairfax complexion . ”[1759-you] “ Did [you]1759-you see [her]142-miss fairfax often at [Weymouth]26-weymouth ? Were [you]1759-you often in the same society ? ”[1759-you] At this moment [they]1762-they were approaching [[Ford]200-ford ’s ’s]1763-ford ’s , and [he]1759-you hastily exclaimed , “ Ha ! this must be the very shop that [every body]3270-every body attends every day of [their]3270-every body lives , as [[my]1759-you father]3146-my father informs [me]1759-you . [He]3146-my father comes to [Highbury]3-highbury [himself]3146-my father , [he]3146-my father says , six days out of the seven , and has always business at [Ford ’s]200-ford ’s . If it be not inconvenient to [you]1759-you , pray let [us]1762-they go in , that [I]1759-you may prove [myself]1759-you to belong to [the place]439-the place , to be [a true citizen of [Highbury]3-highbury]4075-a true citizen of highbury . [I]1759-you must buy something at [Ford ’s]200-ford ’s . [It]4076-it will be taking out [my]1759-you freedom.—I dare say [they]4077-they sell gloves . ”[1759-you] “ Oh ! yes , gloves and every thing . [I]1764-i do admire [your]1759-you patriotism . [You]1759-you will be adored in [Highbury]3-highbury . [You]1759-you were very popular before [you]1759-you came , because [you]1759-you were [[Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s son]4078-mr. weston ’s son — but lay out half a guinea at [Ford ’s]200-ford ’s , and [your]1759-you popularity will stand upon [your]1759-you own virtues . ”[1764-i] [They]1764-i went in ; and while [the sleek , well - tied parcels of “ Men ’s Beavers ”[1759-you] and “ York Tan ”]4079-the sleek , well - tied parcels of “ men ’s beavers ” and “ york tan ”[1759-you] were bringing down and displaying on the counter , [he]1765-i said—“But [I]1759-you beg [your]1759-you pardon , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [you]1759-you were speaking to [me]1759-you , [you]1759-you were saying something at the very moment of this burst of [my]1759-you amor patriae . Do not let [me]1759-you lose it . [I]1759-you assure [you]1759-you the utmost stretch of public fame would not make [me]1759-you amends for the loss of any happiness in private life . ”[1759-you] “ [I]1759-you merely asked , whether [you]1759-you had known much of [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and [[her]142-miss fairfax party]4080-her party at [Weymouth]26-weymouth . ”[1759-you] “ And now that [I]1765-i understand [your]1759-you question , [I]1765-i must pronounce it to be a very unfair one . It is always [the lady]774-the lady ’s right to decide on the degree of acquaintance . [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax must already have given [her]142-miss fairfax account.—I shall not commit [myself]1765-i by claiming more than [she]142-miss fairfax may chuse to allow . ”[1765-i] “ Upon [my]1759-you word ! [you]1759-you answer as discreetly as [she]142-miss fairfax could do [herself]142-miss fairfax . But [her]142-miss fairfax account of every thing leaves so much to be guessed , [she]142-miss fairfax is so very reserved , so very unwilling to give the least information about any body , that [I]1759-you really think [you]1759-you may say what [you]1759-you like of [your]1759-you acquaintance with [her]142-miss fairfax . ”[1759-you] “ May [I]1759-you , indeed?—Then [I]1759-you will speak the truth , and nothing suits [me]1759-you so well . [I]1759-you met [her]142-miss fairfax frequently at [Weymouth]26-weymouth . [I]1759-you had known [the Campbells]4082-the campbells a little in [town]3165-town ; and at [Weymouth]26-weymouth [we]4084-we were very much in the same set . [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell is [a very agreeable man]4085-a very agreeable man , and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell [a friendly , warm - hearted woman]4086-a friendly , warm - hearted woman . [I]1759-you like [them]4087-them all . ”[1759-you] “ [You]1759-you know [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s situation in life , [I]1765-i conclude ; what [she]142-miss fairfax is destined to be ? ”[1765-i] “ Yes—(rather hesitatingly)—I believe [I]1759-you do . ”[1759-you] “ [You]1759-you get upon [delicate subjects]4088-delicate subjects , [Emma]79-emma , ”[84-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston smiling ; “ remember that [I]84-mrs. weston am here.—Mr .
