[I]84-mrs. weston will move a little farther off . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ [I]79-emma certainly do forget to think of [her]142-miss fairfax , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , “ as having ever been any thing but [[my]79-emma friend]877-my friend and [[my]79-emma dearest friend]4090-my dearest friend . ”[79-emma] [He]1766-i looked as if [he]1766-i fully understood and honoured such a sentiment . When the gloves were bought , and [they]1767-we had quitted [the shop]3995-the shop again , “ Did [you]1759-you ever hear [the young lady [we]1767-we were speaking of]4091-the young lady we were speaking of , play ? ”[98-frank churchill] said [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . “ Ever hear [her]142-miss fairfax ! ”[79-emma] repeated [Emma]79-emma . “ [You]1766-i forget how much [she]142-miss fairfax belongs to [Highbury]3-highbury . [I]98-frank churchill have heard [her]142-miss fairfax every year of [our]1767-we lives since [we]1767-we both began . [She]142-miss fairfax plays charmingly . ”[98-frank churchill] “ [You]1759-you think so , do you?—I wanted the opinion of [some one who could really judge]4092-some one who could really judge . [She]142-miss fairfax appeared to [me]1766-i to play well , that is , with considerable taste , but [I]1766-i know nothing of the matter myself.—I am excessively fond of music , but without the smallest skill or right of judging of any body ’s performance.—I have been used to hear [her]142-miss fairfax ’s admired ; and [I]1766-i remember one proof of [her]142-miss fairfax being thought to play [well:—a man]4093-well:—a man , [a very musical man]4094-a very musical man , and in love with [another woman]4095-another woman — engaged to [her]142-miss fairfax — on the point of marriage — would yet never ask [that other woman]4096-that other woman to sit down to the instrument , if [the lady in question]4097-the lady in question could sit down instead — never seemed to like to hear one if [he]4093-well:—a man could hear the other . That , [I]1766-i thought , in [a man of known musical talent]4098-a man of known musical talent , was some proof . ”[1766-i] “ Proof indeed ! ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , highly amused.—“Mr . [Dixon]182-mr. dixon is very musical , is [he]182-mr. dixon ? [We]4099-we shall know more about [them]4100-them all , in half an hour , from [you]79-emma , than [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax would have vouchsafed in half a year . ”[79-emma] “ Yes , [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon and [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell were [the persons]4101-the persons ; and [I]1766-i thought it a very strong proof . ”[1766-i] “ Certainly — very strong it was ; to own the truth , a great deal stronger than , if [I]1766-i had been [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell , would have been at all agreeable to [me]1766-i . [I]1766-i could not excuse [a man]548-a man ’s having more music than love — more ear than eye — a more acute sensibility to fine sounds than to [my]1766-i feelings . How did [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell appear to like it ? ”[1766-i] “ It was [[her]183-miss campbell very particular friend]4103-her very particular friend , [you]79-emma know . ”[1766-i] “ Poor comfort ! ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , laughing . “ [One]475-one would rather have [a stranger]4105-a stranger preferred than [one ’s very particular friend]4106-one ’s very particular friend — with [a stranger]4105-a stranger it might not recur again — but the misery of having [a very particular friend]4108-a very particular friend always at hand , to do every thing better than one does oneself!—Poor [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon ! Well , [I]79-emma am glad [she]183-miss campbell is gone to settle in [Ireland]34-ireland . ”[79-emma] “ [You]79-emma are right . It was not very flattering to [Miss Campbell]183-miss campbell ; but [she]183-miss campbell really did not seem to feel it . ”[1766-i] “ So much the better — or so much [the worse:—I]4109-the worse:—i do not know which . But be it sweetness or be it stupidity in [her]183-miss campbell — quickness of friendship , or dulness of feeling — there was one person , [I]1766-i think , who must have felt it : [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax [herself]142-miss fairfax . [She]142-miss fairfax must have felt the improper and dangerous distinction . ”[1766-i] “ As to that — [I]1766-i do not — ”[1766-i] “ Oh ! do not imagine that [I]1766-i expect an account of [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s sensations from [you]79-emma , or from [any body else]1324-any body else . [They]4111-they are known to [no human being]4112-no human being , [I]1766-i guess , but [herself]142-miss fairfax . But if [she]142-miss fairfax continued to play whenever [she]142-miss fairfax was asked by [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , [one]4113-one may guess what [one chuses]4114-one chuses . ”[1766-i] “ There appeared such a perfectly good understanding among [them]4111-they all — ”[1769-i] [he]1769-i began rather quickly , but checking [himself]1769-i , added , “ however , it is impossible for [me]1769-i to say on what terms they really were — how it might all be behind the scenes . [I]1769-i can only say that there was smoothness outwardly . But [you]79-emma , who have known [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax from [a child]603-a child , must be a better judge of [her]142-miss fairfax character , and of how [she]142-miss fairfax is likely to conduct [herself]142-miss fairfax in critical situations , than [I]1769-i can be . ”[1769-i] “ [I]1766-i have known [her]142-miss fairfax from [a child]603-a child , undoubtedly ; [we]4117-we have been [children]3869-children and [women]1136-women together ; and it is natural to suppose that [we]4117-we should be intimate,—that [we]4117-we should have taken to [each other]420-each other whenever [she]142-miss fairfax visited [[her]142-miss fairfax friends]817-her friends . But [we]4117-we never did . [I]1766-i hardly know how it has happened ; a little , perhaps , from that wickedness on [my]1766-i side which was prone to take disgust towards [a girl so idolized and so cried up]4122-a girl so idolized and so cried up as [she]142-miss fairfax always was , by [[her]142-miss fairfax aunt]1061-her aunt and [grandmother]4124-grandmother , and all [their]817-her friends set . And then , [her]142-miss fairfax reserve — [I]1766-i never could attach [myself]1766-i to any one so completely reserved . ”[1766-i] “ It is a most repulsive quality , indeed , ”[1770-he] said [he]1770-he . “ Oftentimes very convenient , no doubt , but never pleasing . There is safety in reserve , but no attraction . [One]475-one can not love [a reserved person]4126-a reserved person . ”[1770-he] “ Not till the reserve ceases towards [oneself]475-one ; and then the attraction may be the greater . But [I]1770-he must be more in want of [a friend]405-a friend , or [an agreeable companion]4128-an agreeable companion , than [I]1770-he have yet been , to take the trouble of conquering any body ’s reserve to procure one . Intimacy between [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and [me]1770-he is quite out of the question . [I]1770-he have no reason to think ill of [her]142-miss fairfax — not the least — except that such extreme and perpetual cautiousness of word and manner , such a dread of giving a distinct idea about any body , is apt to suggest suspicions of there being something to conceal . ”[1770-he] [He]1770-he perfectly agreed with [her]1770-he : and after walking together so long , and thinking so much alike , [Emma]79-emma felt [herself]79-emma so well acquainted with [him]1770-he , that [she]79-emma could hardly believe it to be only [their]1771-their second meeting . [He]1770-he was not exactly what [she]79-emma had expected ; less of [the man of [the world]392-the world]1772-the man of the world in some of [his]1770-he notions , less of [the spoiled child of fortune]1774-the spoiled child of fortune , therefore better than [she]79-emma had expected . [His]1770-he ideas seemed more moderate — [his]1770-he feelings warmer . [She]79-emma was particularly struck by [his]1770-he manner of considering [[Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s house]1775-mr. elton ’s house , which , as well as [the church]921-the church , [he]1770-he would go and look at , and would not join [them]1777-them in finding much fault with . No , [he]1770-he could not believe it [a bad house]1778-a bad house ; [not such a house as [a man]548-a man]1779-not such a house as a man was to be pitied for having . If [it]1775-mr. elton ’s house were to be shared with [the woman [he]1770-he loved]1781-the woman he loved , [he]1770-he could not think [any man]1031-any man to be pitied for having [that house]1783-that house . There must be ample room in [it]1783-that house for every real comfort . [The man]758-the man must be a blockhead who wanted more . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston laughed , and said [he]1770-he did not know what [he]1770-he was talking about . Used only to [a large house]1785-a large house [himself]1770-he , and without ever thinking how many advantages and accommodations were attached to [its]1785-a large house size , [he]1770-he could be no judge of the privations inevitably belonging to [a small one]1786-a small one . But [Emma]79-emma , in [her]79-emma own mind , determined that [he]1770-he did know what [he]1770-he was talking about , and that [he]1770-he shewed a very amiable inclination to settle early in life , and to marry , from worthy motives . [He]1770-he might not be aware of the inroads on domestic peace to be occasioned by [[no housekeeper]1787-no housekeeper ’s room]1788-no housekeeper ’s room , or [a bad butler]1789-a bad butler ’s pantry , but no doubt [he]1770-he did perfectly feel that [Enscombe]7-enscombe could not make [him]1770-he happy , and that whenever [he]1770-he were attached , [he]1770-he would willingly give up much of wealth to be allowed an early establishment . CHAPTER VII [Emma]79-emma ’s very good opinion of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill was a little shaken the following day , by hearing that [he]98-frank churchill was gone off to [London]1-london , merely to have [his]98-frank churchill hair cut . A sudden freak seemed to have seized [him]98-frank churchill at breakfast , and [he]98-frank churchill had sent for a chaise and set off , intending to return to dinner , but with no more important view that appeared than having [his]98-frank churchill hair cut . There was certainly no harm in [his]98-frank churchill travelling sixteen miles twice over on such an errand ; but there was an air of foppery and nonsense in it which [she]79-emma could not approve . It did not accord with the rationality of plan , the moderation in expense , or even the unselfish warmth of heart , which [she]79-emma had believed [herself]79-emma to discern in [him]98-frank churchill yesterday . Vanity , extravagance , love of change , restlessness of temper , which must be doing something , good or bad ; heedlessness as to the pleasure of [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , indifferent as to how [his]98-frank churchill conduct might appear in general ; [he]98-frank churchill became liable to all these charges . [[His]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father only called [him]98-frank churchill [a coxcomb]1792-a coxcomb , and thought it a very good story ; but that [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston did not like it , was clear enough , by [her]84-mrs. weston passing it over as quickly as possible , and making no other comment than that “ [all young people]4129-all young people would have [their]4129-all young people little whims . ”[84-mrs. weston] With the exception of this little blot , [Emma]79-emma found that [his]98-frank churchill visit hitherto had given [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend only good ideas of [him]98-frank churchill . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was very ready to say how attentive and pleasant a companion [he]98-frank churchill made [himself]98-frank churchill — how much [she]84-mrs. weston saw to like in [his]98-frank churchill disposition altogether . [He]98-frank churchill appeared to have a very open temper — certainly a very cheerful and lively one ; [she]84-mrs. weston could observe nothing wrong in [his]98-frank churchill notions , a great deal decidedly right ; [he]98-frank churchill spoke of [[his]98-frank churchill uncle]3212-his uncle with warm regard , was fond of talking of [him]3212-his uncle — said [he]98-frank churchill would be [the best man in [the world]392-the world]1795-the best man in the world if [he]98-frank churchill were left to [himself]98-frank churchill ; and though there was no being attached to [the aunt]3215-the aunt , [he]98-frank churchill acknowledged [her]3215-the aunt kindness with gratitude , and seemed to mean always to speak of [her]3215-the aunt with respect . This was all very promising ; and , but for such an unfortunate fancy for having [his]98-frank churchill hair cut , there was nothing to denote [him]98-frank churchill unworthy of the distinguished honour which [her]3215-the aunt imagination had given [him]98-frank churchill ; the honour , if not of being really in love with [her]3215-the aunt , of being at least very near it , and saved only by [her]3215-the aunt own indifference—(for still [her]3215-the aunt resolution held of never marrying)—the honour , in short , of being marked out for [her]3215-the aunt by all [their]1798-their joint acquaintance . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , on [his]82-mr. weston side , added a virtue to the account which must have some weight . [He]82-mr. weston gave [her]3215-the aunt to understand that [Frank]98-frank churchill admired [her]3215-the aunt extremely — thought [her]3215-the aunt very beautiful and very charming ; and with so much to be said for [him]98-frank churchill altogether , [she]3215-the aunt found [she]3215-the aunt must not judge [him]98-frank churchill harshly . As [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston observed , “ [all young people]4129-all young people would have [their]4129-all young people little whims . ”[84-mrs. weston] There was [one person among [his]98-frank churchill new acquaintance]1799-one person among his new acquaintance in [Surry]24-surry , not so leniently disposed . In general [he]1799-one person among his new acquaintance was judged , throughout [the parishes of [Donwell]202-donwell and [Highbury]3-highbury]1494-the parishes of donwell and highbury , with great candour ; liberal allowances were made for the little excesses of such [a handsome young man]1801-a handsome young man — [one who smiled so often and bowed so well]1802-one who smiled so often and bowed so well ; but there was one spirit among [them]1494-the parishes of donwell and highbury not to be softened , from its power of censure , by bows or smiles — [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . The circumstance was told [him]88-mr. knightley at [Hartfield]90-hartfield ; for the moment , [he]88-mr. knightley was silent ; but [Emma]79-emma heard [him]88-mr. knightley almost immediately afterwards say to [himself]88-mr. knightley , over a newspaper [he]88-mr. knightley held in [his]88-mr. knightley hand , “ [Hum]201-hum ! just the trifling , silly fellow [I]88-mr. knightley took [him]88-mr. knightley for . ”[88-mr. knightley] [She]79-emma had half a mind to resent ; but an instant ’s observation convinced [her]79-emma that it was really said only to relieve [his]88-mr. knightley own feelings , and not meant to provoke ; and therefore [she]79-emma let it pass . Although in one instance [the bearers of not good tidings]1803-the bearers of not good tidings , [Mr.]1804-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s visit this morning was in another respect particularly opportune . Something occurred while [they]1494-the parishes of donwell and highbury were at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , to make [Emma]79-emma want [their]1494-the parishes of donwell and highbury advice ; and , which was still more lucky , [she]79-emma wanted exactly the advice [they]1494-the parishes of donwell and highbury gave . This was the occurrence:—The [Coles]175-the coles had been settled some years in [Highbury]3-highbury , and were [very good sort of people — friendly , liberal , and unpretending]1805-very good sort of people — friendly , liberal , and unpretending ; but , on the other hand , [they]175-the coles were of low origin , in trade , and only moderately genteel . On [their]175-the coles first coming into [the country]3306-the country , [they]175-the coles had lived in proportion to [their]175-the coles income , quietly , keeping little company , and that little unexpensively ; but the last year or two had brought [them]175-the coles a considerable increase of means — [the house in [town]3165-town]1807-the house in town had yielded greater profits , and fortune in general had smiled on [them]175-the coles . With [their]175-the coles wealth , [their]175-the coles views increased ; [their]175-the coles want of [a larger house]1809-a larger house , [their]175-the coles inclination for more company . [They]175-the coles added to [[their]175-the coles house]1810-their house , to [[their]175-the coles number of [servants]1644-servants]1811-their number of servants , to [their]175-the coles expenses of every sort ; and by this time were , in fortune and style of living , second only to [the family at [Hartfield]90-hartfield]1813-the family at hartfield . [Their]175-the coles love of society , and [[their]175-the coles new dining - room]1814-their new dining - room , prepared every body for [their]175-the coles keeping dinner - company ; and a few parties , chiefly among [the single men]1815-the single men , had already taken place . [The regular and best families]1816-the regular and best families [Emma]79-emma could hardly suppose [they]175-the coles would presume to invite — neither [Donwell]202-donwell , nor [Hartfield]90-hartfield , nor [Randalls]97-randalls . Nothing should tempt [her]79-emma to go , if [they]175-the coles did ; and [she]79-emma regretted that [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s known habits would be giving [her]79-emma refusal less meaning than [she]79-emma could wish . [The Coles]175-the coles were very respectable in [their]175-the coles way , but [they]175-the coles ought to be taught that it was not for [them]175-the coles to arrange the terms on which [the superior families]1818-the superior families would visit [them]175-the coles . This lesson , [she]79-emma very much feared , [they]175-the coles would receive only from [herself]79-emma ; [she]79-emma had little hope of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , none of [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston . But [she]79-emma had made up [her]79-emma mind how to meet this presumption so many weeks before it appeared , that when the insult came at last , it found [her]79-emma very differently affected . [Donwell]202-donwell and [Randalls]97-randalls had received [their]175-the coles invitation , and none had come for [[her]79-emma father]415-her father and [herself]79-emma ; and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s accounting for it with “ [I]84-mrs. weston suppose [they]175-the coles will not take the liberty with [you]79-emma ; [they]175-the coles know [you]79-emma do not dine out , ”[84-mrs. weston] was not quite sufficient . [She]79-emma felt that [she]79-emma should like to have had the power of refusal ; and afterwards , as the idea of [the party to be assembled]1820-the party to be assembled [there]437-there , consisting precisely of [those whose society was dearest to [her]79-emma]1822-those whose society was dearest to her , occurred again and again , [she]79-emma did not know that [she]79-emma might not have been tempted to accept . [Harriet]107-harriet was to be [there]437-there in the evening , and [the Bateses]149-the bateses . [They]1824-they had been speaking of it as [they]1824-they walked about [Highbury]3-highbury the day before , and [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill had most earnestly lamented [her]107-harriet absence . Might not the evening end in a dance ? had been a question of [his]98-frank churchill . The bare possibility of it acted as a farther irritation on [her]107-harriet spirits ; and [her]107-harriet being left in solitary grandeur , even supposing the omission to be intended as a compliment , was but poor comfort . It was the arrival of this very invitation while [the Westons]104-the westons were at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , which made [their]1824-they presence so acceptable ; for though [her]107-harriet first remark , on reading it , was that “ of course it must be declined , ”[107-harriet] [she]107-harriet so very soon proceeded to ask [them]1824-they what [they]1824-they advised [her]107-harriet to do , that [their]1824-they advice for [her]107-harriet going was most prompt and successful . [She]107-harriet owned that , considering every thing , [she]107-harriet was not absolutely without inclination for the party . [The Coles]175-the coles expressed [themselves]175-the coles so properly — there was so much real attention in the manner of it — so much consideration for [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father . “ [They]175-the coles would have solicited the honour earlier , but had been waiting the arrival of a folding - screen from [London]1-london , which [they]175-the coles hoped might keep [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse from any draught of air , and therefore induce [him]81-mr. woodhouse the more readily to give [them]175-the coles the honour of [[his]81-mr. woodhouse company]4131-his company . ”[107-harriet] Upon the whole , [she]107-harriet was very persuadable ; and it being briefly settled among [themselves]175-the coles how it might be done without neglecting [his]415-her father comfort — how certainly [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard , if not [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates , might be depended on for bearing [him]415-her father company — [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was to be talked into an acquiescence of [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter ’s going out to dinner on a day now near at hand , and spending the whole evening away from [him]415-her father . As for [his]415-her father going , [Emma]79-emma did not wish [him]415-her father to think it possible , the hours would be too late , and the party too numerous . [He]415-her father was soon pretty well resigned . “ [I]84-mrs. weston am not fond of dinner - visiting , ”[84-mrs. weston] said [he—“I]203-he—“i never was . No more is [Emma]79-emma . Late hours do not agree with [us]175-the coles . [I]84-mrs. weston am sorry [Mr.]4132-mr. and [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole should have done it . [I]84-mrs. weston think it would be much better if [they]4133-they would come in one afternoon next summer , and take [their]4133-they tea with [us]175-the coles — take [us]175-the coles in [their]4133-they afternoon walk ; which [they]4133-they might do , as [our]175-the coles hours are so reasonable , and yet get [home]3258-home without being out in the damp of the evening . The dews of a summer evening are what [I]84-mrs. weston would not expose [any body]530-any body to . However , as [they]4133-they are so very desirous to have [dear Emma]79-emma dine with [them]4133-they , and as [you]84-mrs. weston will both be [there]437-there , and [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley too , to take care of [her]79-emma , [I]84-mrs. weston can not wish to prevent it , provided the weather be what it ought , neither damp , nor cold , nor windy . ”[84-mrs. weston] Then turning to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , with a look of gentle reproach—“Ah ! [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor , if [you]80-miss taylor had not married , [you]80-miss taylor would have staid at [home]3258-home with [me]84-mrs. weston . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ Well , [sir]3139-sir , ”[82-mr. weston] cried [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , “ as [I]82-mr. weston took [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor away , it is incumbent on [me]82-mr. weston to supply [[her]80-miss taylor place]4139-her place , if [I]82-mr. weston can ; and [I]82-mr. weston will step to [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard in a moment , if [you]3139-sir wish it . ”[82-mr. weston] But the idea of any thing to be done in a moment , was increasing , not lessening , [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s agitation . [The ladies]3323-the ladies knew better how to allay it . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston must be quiet , and every thing deliberately arranged . With this treatment , [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was soon composed enough for talking as usual . “ [He]81-mr. woodhouse should be happy to see [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard . [He]81-mr. woodhouse had a great regard for [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ; and [Emma]79-emma should write a line , and invite [her]105-mrs. goddard . [James]86-james could take the note . But first of all , there must be an answer written to [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ [You]3139-sir will make [my]81-mr. woodhouse excuses , [[my]81-mr. woodhouse dear]3120-my dear , as civilly as possible . [You]3139-sir will say that [I]81-mr. woodhouse am quite [an invalid]4141-an invalid , and go no where , and therefore must decline [their]3323-the ladies obliging invitation ; beginning with [my]81-mr. woodhouse compliments , of course . But [you]3139-sir will do every thing right . [I]81-mr. woodhouse need not tell [you]3139-sir what is to be done . [We]4142-we must remember to let [James]86-james know that [the carriage]3125-the carriage will be wanted on Tuesday . [I]81-mr. woodhouse shall have no fears for [you]3139-sir with [him]81-mr. woodhouse . [We]4142-we have never been [there]437-there above once since the new approach was made ; but still [I]81-mr. woodhouse have no doubt that [James]86-james will take [you]3139-sir very safely . And when [you]3139-sir get [there]437-there , [you]3139-sir must tell [him]81-mr. woodhouse at what time [you]3139-sir would have [him]81-mr. woodhouse come for [you]3139-sir again ; and [you]3139-sir had better name an early hour . [You]3139-sir will not like staying late . [You]3139-sir will get very tired when tea is over . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ But [you]81-mr. woodhouse would not wish [me]81-mr. woodhouse to come away before [I]81-mr. woodhouse am tired , [papa]3114-papa ? ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ Oh ! no , [[my]81-mr. woodhouse love]1093-my love ; but [you]3139-sir will soon be tired . There will be [a great many people]4148-a great many people talking at once . [You]3139-sir will not like the noise . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ But , [[my]82-mr. weston dear sir]741-my dear sir , ”[82-mr. weston] cried [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , “ if [Emma]79-emma comes away early , it will be breaking up the party . ”[82-mr. weston] “ And no great harm if it does , ”[81-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse . “ The sooner every party breaks up , the better . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ But [you]741-my dear sir do not consider how it may appear to [the Coles]175-the coles . [Emma]79-emma ’s going away directly after tea might be giving offence . [They]175-the coles are [good - natured people]4150-good - natured people , and think little of [their]175-the coles own claims ; but still [they]175-the coles must feel that [any body]530-any body ’s hurrying away is no great compliment ; and [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor ’s doing it would be more thought of than [any other person]4152-any other person ’s in [the room]3386-the room . [You]741-my dear sir would not wish to disappoint and mortify [the Coles]175-the coles , [I]81-mr. woodhouse am sure , [sir]3139-sir ; [friendly , good sort of people as ever lived]4155-friendly , good sort of people as ever lived , and who have been [[your]741-my dear sir neighbours]4156-your neighbours these ten years . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ No , upon no account in [the world]392-the world , [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ; [I]81-mr. woodhouse am much obliged to [you]82-mr. weston for reminding [me]81-mr. woodhouse . [I]81-mr. woodhouse should be extremely sorry to be giving [them]175-the coles any pain . [I]81-mr. woodhouse know what [worthy people]4158-worthy people [they]175-the coles are . [Perry]100-mrs. perry tells [me]81-mr. woodhouse that [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole never touches malt liquor . [You]741-my dear sir would not think it to look at [him]135-mr. cole , but [he]135-mr. cole is bilious — [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole is very bilious . No , [I]81-mr. woodhouse would not be the means of giving [them]175-the coles any pain . [[My]81-mr. woodhouse dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , [we]4160-we must consider this . [I]81-mr. woodhouse am sure , rather than run the risk of hurting [Mr.]4161-mr. and [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole , [you]741-my dear sir would stay a little longer than [you]741-my dear sir might wish . [You]741-my dear sir will not regard being tired . [You]741-my dear sir will be perfectly safe , [you]741-my dear sir know , among [[your]741-my dear sir friends]926-your friends . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] “ Oh yes , [papa]3114-papa . [I]81-mr. woodhouse have no fears at all for [myself]81-mr. woodhouse ; and [I]81-mr. woodhouse should have no scruples of staying as late as [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , but on [your]3114-papa account . [I]81-mr. woodhouse am only afraid of [your]3114-papa sitting up for [me]81-mr. woodhouse . [I]81-mr. woodhouse am not afraid of [your]3114-papa not being exceedingly comfortable with [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard . [She]105-mrs. goddard loves piquet , [you]3114-papa know ; but when [she]105-mrs. goddard is gone [home]3258-home , [I]81-mr. woodhouse am afraid [you]3114-papa will be sitting up by [yourself]3114-papa , instead of going to bed at [your]3114-papa usual time — and the idea of that would entirely destroy [my]81-mr. woodhouse comfort . [You]3114-papa must promise [me]81-mr. woodhouse not to sit up . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] [He]1828-he did , on the condition of some promises on [her]1829-her side : such as that , if [she]1829-her came [home]3258-home cold , [she]1829-her would be sure to warm [herself]1829-her thoroughly ; if hungry , that [she]1829-her would take something to eat ; that [[her]1829-her own maid]1831-her own maid should sit up for [her]1829-her ; and that [Serle]109-serle and [the butler]1832-the butler should see that every thing were safe in [the house]425-the house , as usual . CHAPTER VIII [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill came back again ; and if [he]98-frank churchill kept [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father ’s dinner waiting , it was not known at [Hartfield]90-hartfield ; for [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was too anxious for [his]98-frank churchill being a favourite with [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , to betray any imperfection which could be concealed . [He]98-frank churchill came back , had had [his]98-frank churchill hair cut , and laughed at [himself]98-frank churchill with a very good grace , but without seeming really at all ashamed of what [he]98-frank churchill had done . [He]98-frank churchill had no reason to wish [his]98-frank churchill hair longer , to conceal any confusion of face ; no reason to wish the money unspent , to improve [his]98-frank churchill spirits . [He]98-frank churchill was quite as undaunted and as lively as ever ; and , after seeing [him]98-frank churchill , [Emma]79-emma thus moralised to [herself]79-emma : — “ [I]79-emma do not know whether it ought to be so , but certainly silly things do cease to be silly if they are done by [sensible people]4165-sensible people in an impudent way . Wickedness is always wickedness , but folly is not always folly.—It depends upon the character of [those who handle it]4166-those who handle it . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , [he]88-mr. knightley is not [a trifling , silly young man]4167-a trifling , silly young man . If [he]88-mr. knightley were , [he]88-mr. knightley would have done this differently . [He]88-mr. knightley would either have gloried in the achievement , or been ashamed of it . There would have been either the ostentation of [a coxcomb]1792-a coxcomb , or the evasions of a mind too weak to defend its own vanities.—No , [I]79-emma am perfectly sure that [he]88-mr. knightley is not trifling or silly . ”[79-emma] With [Tuesday]204-tuesday came the agreeable prospect of seeing [him]98-frank churchill again , and for a longer time than hitherto ; of judging of [his]98-frank churchill general manners , and by inference , of the meaning of [his]98-frank churchill manners towards [herself]79-emma ; of guessing how soon it might be necessary for [her]79-emma to throw coldness into [her]79-emma air ; and of fancying what the observations of all those might be , who were now seeing [them]1835-them together for the first time . [She]79-emma meant to be very happy , in spite of the scene being laid at [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole ’s ; and without being able to forget that among the failings of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , even in the days of [his]91-mr. elton favour , none had disturbed [her]79-emma more than [his]91-mr. elton propensity to dine with [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole . [[Her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s comfort was amply secured , [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates as well as [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard being able to come ; and [her]79-emma last pleasing duty , before [she]79-emma left [the house]425-the house , was to pay [her]79-emma respects to [them]1835-them as [they]1835-them sat together after dinner ; and while [[her]79-emma father]415-her father was fondly noticing the beauty of [her]79-emma dress , to make [the two ladies]1839-the two ladies all the amends in [her]79-emma power , by helping [them]1839-the two ladies to large slices of cake and full glasses of wine , for whatever unwilling self - denial [his]415-her father care of [their]1839-the two ladies constitution might have obliged [them]1839-the two ladies to practise during the meal.—She had provided a plentiful dinner for [them]1839-the two ladies ; [she]79-emma wished [she]79-emma could know that [they]1839-the two ladies had been allowed to eat it . [She]79-emma followed [another carriage]1840-another carriage to [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole ’s door ; and was pleased to see that it was [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s ; for [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley keeping no horses , having little spare money and a great deal of health , activity , and independence , was too apt , in [Emma]79-emma ’s opinion , to get about as [he]88-mr. knightley could , and not use [[his]88-mr. knightley carriage]3651-his carriage so often as became [the owner of [Donwell Abbey]202-donwell]1842-the owner of donwell abbey . [She]79-emma had an opportunity now of speaking [her]79-emma approbation while warm from [her]79-emma heart , for [he]88-mr. knightley stopped to hand [her]79-emma out . “ This is coming as [you]88-mr. knightley should do , ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma ; “ like [a gentleman.—I]4169-a gentleman.—i am quite glad to see [you]88-mr. knightley . ”[79-emma] [He]88-mr. knightley thanked [her]79-emma , observing , “ How lucky that [we]4170-we should arrive at the same moment ! for , if [we]4170-we had met first in [the drawing - room]1313-the drawing - room , [I]88-mr. knightley doubt whether [you]79-emma would have discerned [me]88-mr. knightley to be more of [a gentleman]527-a gentleman than usual.—You might not have distinguished how [I]88-mr. knightley came , by [my]88-mr. knightley look or manner . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Yes [I]88-mr. knightley should , [I]88-mr. knightley am sure [I]88-mr. knightley should . There is always a look of consciousness or bustle when [people]704-people come in a way which [they]704-people know to be beneath [them]704-people . [You]79-emma think [you]79-emma carry it off very well , [I]88-mr. knightley dare say , but with [you]79-emma it is a sort of bravado , an air of affected unconcern ; [I]88-mr. knightley always observe it whenever [I]88-mr. knightley meet [you]79-emma under those circumstances . Now [you]79-emma have nothing to try for . [You]79-emma are not afraid of being supposed ashamed . [You]79-emma are not striving to look taller than [any body else]1324-any body else . Now [I]88-mr. knightley shall really be very happy to walk into [the same room]4175-the same room with [you]79-emma . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [Nonsensical girl]4176-nonsensical girl ! ”[1843-his] was [his]1843-his reply , but not at all in anger . [Emma]79-emma had as much reason to be satisfied with the rest of the party as with [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [She]79-emma was received with a cordial respect which could not but please , and given all the consequence [she]79-emma could wish for . When [the Westons]104-the westons arrived , the kindest looks of love , the strongest of admiration were for [her]79-emma , from [both husband]1844-both husband and [wife]1845-wife ; [the son]3169-the son approached [her]79-emma with a cheerful eagerness which marked [her]79-emma as [his]3169-the son peculiar object , and at dinner [she]79-emma found [him]3169-the son seated by [her]79-emma — and , as [she]79-emma firmly believed , not without some dexterity on [his]3169-the son side . [The party]3632-the party was rather large , as it included [one other family]1848-one other family , [a proper unobjectionable country family , whom [the Coles]175-the coles had the advantage of naming among [[their]175-the coles acquaintance]1850-their acquaintance]1849-a proper unobjectionable country family , whom the coles had the advantage of naming among their acquaintance , and [the male part of [[Mr. Cox]205-mr. cox ’s family]1852-mr. cox ’s family]1851-the male part of mr. cox ’s family , [the lawyer of [Highbury]3-highbury]1853-the lawyer of highbury . [The less worthy females]1854-the less worthy females were to come in the evening , with [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , and [Miss Smith]107-harriet ; but already , at dinner , [they]1854-the less worthy females were too numerous for any subject of conversation to be general ; and , while politics and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton were talked over , [Emma]79-emma could fairly surrender all [her]79-emma attention to the pleasantness of [[her]79-emma neighbour]1855-her neighbour . The first remote sound to which [she]79-emma felt [herself]79-emma obliged to attend , was the name of [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole seemed to be relating something of [her]79-emma that was expected to be very interesting . [She]176-mrs. cole listened , and found it well worth listening to . [That very dear part of [Emma]79-emma]1856-that very dear part of emma , [her]79-emma fancy , received an amusing supply . [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole was telling that [she]176-mrs. cole had been calling on [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , and as soon as [she]176-mrs. cole entered [the room]3386-the room had been struck by the sight of a pianoforte — a very elegant looking instrument — not a grand , but a large - sized square pianoforte ; and the substance of the story , the end of all the dialogue which ensued of surprize , and inquiry , and congratulations on [her]176-mrs. cole side , and explanations on [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ’s , was , that this pianoforte had arrived from [Broadwood]49-broadwood ’s the day before , to the great astonishment of [both aunt]1858-both aunt and [niece]1859-niece — entirely unexpected ; that at first , by [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ’s account , [Jane]101-miss bates [herself]101-miss bates was quite at a loss , quite bewildered to think who could possibly have ordered it — but now , [they]1860-their were both perfectly satisfied that it could be from only one quarter;—of course it must be from [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell . “ [One]475-one can suppose nothing else , ”[176-mrs. cole] added [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole , “ and [I]176-mrs. cole was only surprized that there could ever have been a doubt . But [Jane]101-miss bates , it seems , had a letter from [them]1860-their very lately , and not a word was said about it . [She]101-miss bates knows [their]1860-their ways best ; but [I]176-mrs. cole should not consider [their]1860-their silence as any reason for [their]1860-their not meaning to make the present . [They]1860-their might chuse to surprize [her]101-miss bates . ”[176-mrs. cole] [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole had many to agree with [her]176-mrs. cole ; [every body who spoke on the subject]1861-every body who spoke on the subject was equally convinced that it must come from [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell , and equally rejoiced that such a present had been made ; and there were enough ready to speak to allow [Emma]79-emma to think [her]79-emma own way , and still listen to [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole . “ [I]80-miss taylor declare , [I]80-miss taylor do not know when [I]80-miss taylor have heard any thing that has given [me]80-miss taylor more satisfaction!—It always has quite hurt [me]80-miss taylor that [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , who plays so delightfully , should not have an instrument . It seemed quite a shame , especially considering how many houses there are where fine instruments are absolutely thrown away . This is like giving [ourselves]4178-our a slap , to be sure ! and it was but yesterday [I]80-miss taylor was telling [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole , [I]80-miss taylor really was ashamed to look at [our]4178-our new grand pianoforte in [the drawing - room]1313-the drawing - room , while [I]80-miss taylor do not know one note from another , and [our]4178-our [little girls , who are but just beginning]4180-little girls , who are but just beginning , perhaps may never make any thing of it ; and there is [poor [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , who is [mistress of music]4182-mistress of music , has not any thing of the nature of an instrument , not even the pitifullest old spinet in [the world]392-the world]4181-poor jane fairfax , who is mistress of music , has not any thing of the nature of an instrument , not even the pitifullest old spinet in the world , to amuse [herself]142-miss fairfax with.—I was saying this to [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole but yesterday , and [he]135-mr. cole quite agreed with [me]80-miss taylor ; only [he]135-mr. cole is so particularly fond of music that [he]135-mr. cole could not help indulging [himself]135-mr. cole in the purchase , hoping that [some of [[our]4178-our good neighbours]4185-our good neighbours]4184-some of our good neighbours might be so obliging occasionally to put it to a better use than [we]4178-our can ; and that really is the reason why the instrument was bought — or else [I]80-miss taylor am sure [we]4178-our ought to be ashamed of [it.—We]4178-our are in great hopes that [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor may be prevailed with to try it this evening . ”[80-miss taylor] [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor made the proper acquiescence ; and finding that nothing more was to be entrapped from any communication of [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole ’s , turned to [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . “ Why do [you]98-frank churchill smile ? ”[176-mrs. cole] said [she]176-mrs. cole . “ Nay , why do [you]98-frank churchill ? ”[176-mrs. cole] “ [Me!—I]80-miss taylor suppose [I]80-miss taylor smile for pleasure at [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell ’s being so rich and so liberal.—It is a handsome present . ”[80-miss taylor] “ Very . ”[80-miss taylor] “ [I]176-mrs. cole rather wonder that it was never made before . ”[176-mrs. cole] “ Perhaps [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax has never been staying [here]3113-here so long before . ”[80-miss taylor] “ Or that [he]153-colonel campbell did not give [her]142-miss fairfax the use of [their]4187-their own instrument — which must now be shut up in [London]1-london , untouched by [any body]530-any body . ”[80-miss taylor] “ That is a grand pianoforte , and [he]153-colonel campbell might think it too large for [[Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates ’s house]4189-mrs. bates ’s house . ”[176-mrs. cole] “ [You]98-frank churchill may say what [you]98-frank churchill chuse — but [your]98-frank churchill countenance testifies that [your]98-frank churchill thoughts on this subject are very much like [mine]98-frank churchill . ”[80-miss taylor] “ [I]80-miss taylor do not know . If [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell is not [the person]4190-the person , who can be ? ”[80-miss taylor] “ What do [you]80-miss taylor say to [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon ? ”[176-mrs. cole] “ [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon ! very true indeed . [I]80-miss taylor had not thought of [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon . [She]181-mrs. dixon must know as well as [[her]181-mrs. dixon father]415-her father , how acceptable an instrument would be ; and perhaps the mode of it , the mystery , the surprize , is more like [a young woman]1346-a young woman ’s scheme than [an elderly man]4193-an elderly man ’s . It is [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon , [I]80-miss taylor dare say . [I]80-miss taylor told [you]98-frank churchill that [your]98-frank churchill suspicions would guide [mine]80-miss taylor . ”[80-miss taylor] “ If so , [you]98-frank churchill must extend [your]98-frank churchill suspicions and comprehend [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon in them . ”[80-miss taylor] “ [Mr. Dixon.—Very]206-mr. dixon.—very well . Yes , [I]176-mrs. cole immediately perceive that it must be the joint present of [Mr.]4194-mr. and [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon . [We]4195-we were speaking the other day , [you]98-frank churchill know , of [his]182-mr. dixon being so warm an admirer of [her]181-mrs. dixon performance . ”[176-mrs. cole] “ Yes , and what [you]98-frank churchill told [me]80-miss taylor on that head , confirmed an idea which [I]80-miss taylor had entertained before.—I do not mean to reflect upon the good intentions of either [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon or [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , but [I]80-miss taylor can not help suspecting either that , after making [his]182-mr. dixon proposals to [[her]181-mrs. dixon friend]417-her friend , [he]182-mr. dixon had the misfortune to fall in love with [her]181-mrs. dixon , or that [he]182-mr. dixon became conscious of a little attachment on [her]181-mrs. dixon side . [One]475-one might guess twenty things without guessing exactly the right ; but [I]80-miss taylor am sure there must be a particular cause for [her]181-mrs. dixon chusing to come to [Highbury]3-highbury instead of going with [the Campbells]4082-the campbells to [Ireland]34-ireland . Here , [she]181-mrs. dixon must be leading a life of privation and penance ; there it would have been all enjoyment . As to the pretence of trying [her]181-mrs. dixon native air , [I]80-miss taylor look upon that as a mere excuse.—In the summer it might have passed ; but what can any body ’s native air do for [them]4199-them in the months of January , February , and March ? Good fires and carriages would be much more to the purpose in most cases of delicate health , and [I]80-miss taylor dare say in [her]181-mrs. dixon ’s . [I]80-miss taylor do not require [you]4200-you to adopt all [my]80-miss taylor suspicions , though [you]4200-you make so noble a profession of doing it , but [I]80-miss taylor honestly tell [you]4200-you what they are . ”[80-miss taylor] “ And , upon [my]80-miss taylor word , [they]4199-them have an air of great probability . [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon ’s preference of [her]181-mrs. dixon music to [[her]181-mrs. dixon friend]417-her friend ’s , [I]80-miss taylor can answer for being very decided . ”[80-miss taylor] “ And then , [he]182-mr. dixon saved [her]181-mrs. dixon life . Did [you]4200-you ever hear of [that?—A water party]4202-that?—a water party ; and by some accident [she]181-mrs. dixon was falling overboard . [He]182-mr. dixon caught [her]181-mrs. dixon . ”[176-mrs. cole] “ [He]182-mr. dixon did . [I]80-miss taylor was [there]437-there — [one of the party]664-one of the party . ”[80-miss taylor] “ Were [you]4200-you really?—Well!—But [you]4200-you observed nothing of course , for it seems to be a new idea to you.—If [I]80-miss taylor had been [there]437-there , [I]80-miss taylor think [I]80-miss taylor should have made some discoveries . ”[80-miss taylor] “ [I]176-mrs. cole dare say [you]4200-you would ; but [I]176-mrs. cole , simple [I]176-mrs. cole , saw nothing but the fact , that [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax was nearly dashed from [the vessel]4206-the vessel and that [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon caught her.—It was the work of a moment . And though the consequent shock and alarm was very great and much more durable — indeed [I]176-mrs. cole believe it was half an hour before any of [us]1862-we were comfortable again — yet that was too general a sensation for any thing of peculiar anxiety to be observable . [I]176-mrs. cole do not mean to say , however , that [you]4200-you might not have made discoveries . ”[176-mrs. cole] The conversation was here interrupted . [They]1862-we were called on to share in the awkwardness of a rather long interval between the courses , and obliged to be as formal and as orderly as [the others]3512-the others ; but when the table was again safely covered , when every corner dish was placed exactly right , and occupation and ease were generally restored , [Emma]79-emma said , “ The arrival of this pianoforte is decisive with [me]79-emma . [I]79-emma wanted to know a little more , and this tells [me]79-emma quite enough . Depend upon it , [we]1862-we shall soon hear that it is a present from [Mr.]4207-mr. and [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon . ”[79-emma] “ And if [the Dixons]184-the dixons should absolutely deny all knowledge of it [we]1862-we must conclude it to come from [the Campbells]180-the campbells . ”[1864-i] “ No , [I]1864-i am sure it is not from [the Campbells]180-the campbells . [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax knows it is not from [the Campbells]180-the campbells , or [they]180-the campbells would have been guessed at first . [She]142-miss fairfax would not have been puzzled , had [she]142-miss fairfax dared fix on [them]180-the campbells . [I]1864-i may not have convinced [you]4208-you perhaps , but [I]1864-i am perfectly convinced [myself]1864-i that [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon is [a principal in the business]4209-a principal in the business . ”[1864-i] “ Indeed [you]4208-you injure [me]79-emma if [you]4208-you suppose [me]79-emma unconvinced . [Your]4208-you reasonings carry [my]79-emma judgment along with them entirely . At first , while [I]79-emma supposed [you]4208-you satisfied that [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell was [the giver]4210-the giver , [I]79-emma saw it only as paternal kindness , and thought it the most natural thing in [the world]392-the world . But when [you]4208-you mentioned [Mrs. Dixon]181-mrs. dixon , [I]79-emma felt how much more probable that it should be the tribute of warm female friendship . And now [I]79-emma can see it in no other light than as an offering of love . ”[79-emma] There was no occasion to press the matter farther . The conviction seemed real ; [he]1864-i looked as if [he]1864-i felt it . [She]1865-she said no more , [other subjects]1866-other subjects took [their]1866-other subjects turn ; and the rest of the dinner passed away ; the dessert succeeded , [the children]3286-the children came in , and were talked to and admired amid the usual rate of conversation ; a few clever things said , a few downright silly , but by much the larger proportion neither the one nor the other — nothing worse than everyday remarks , dull repetitions , old news , and heavy jokes . [The ladies]3323-the ladies had not been long in [the drawing - room]1313-the drawing - room , before [the other ladies]1870-the other ladies , in [their]1870-the other ladies different divisions , arrived . [Emma]79-emma watched the entree of [[her]79-emma own particular little friend]1871-her own particular little friend ; and if [she]79-emma could not exult in [her]79-emma dignity and grace , [she]79-emma could not only love the blooming sweetness and the artless manner , but could most heartily rejoice in that light , cheerful , unsentimental disposition which allowed [her]79-emma so many alleviations of pleasure , in the midst of the pangs of disappointed affection . There [she]79-emma sat — and who would have guessed how many tears [she]79-emma had been lately shedding ? To be in company , nicely dressed [herself]79-emma and seeing [others nicely dressed]1872-others nicely dressed , to sit and smile and look pretty , and say nothing , was enough for the happiness of the present hour . [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax did look and move superior ; but [Emma]79-emma suspected [she]79-emma might have been glad to change feelings with [Harriet]107-harriet , very glad to have purchased the mortification of having loved — yes , of having loved even [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton in vain — by the surrender of all the dangerous pleasure of knowing [herself]79-emma beloved by [the husband of [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend]1873-the husband of her friend . In so large a party it was not necessary that [Emma]79-emma should approach [her]107-harriet . [She]79-emma did not wish to speak of the pianoforte , [she]79-emma felt too much in the secret [herself]79-emma , to think the appearance of curiosity or interest fair , and therefore purposely kept at a distance ; but by [the others]3512-the others , the subject was almost immediately introduced , and [she]79-emma saw the blush of consciousness with which congratulations were received , the blush of guilt which accompanied the name of “ [[my]84-mrs. weston excellent friend]4212-my excellent friend [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell . ”[84-mrs. weston] [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , kind - hearted and musical , was particularly interested by the circumstance , and [Emma]79-emma could not help being amused at [her]79-emma perseverance in dwelling on the subject ; and having so much to ask and to say as to tone , touch , and pedal , totally unsuspicious of that wish of saying as little about it as possible , which [she]79-emma plainly read in [the fair heroine]1876-the fair heroine ’s countenance . [They]1877-they were soon joined by [some of [the gentlemen]1743-the gentlemen]1878-some of the gentlemen ; and the very first of [the early]1880-the early was [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . In [he]98-frank churchill walked , [the first and the handsomest]1881-the first and the handsomest ; and after paying [his]98-frank churchill compliments en passant to [Miss Bates]101-miss bates and [[her]101-miss bates niece]3833-her niece , made [his]98-frank churchill way directly to the opposite side of the circle , where sat [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor ; and till [he]98-frank churchill could find a seat by [her]80-miss taylor , would not sit at all . [Emma]79-emma divined what [every body present]1883-every body present must be thinking . [She]80-miss taylor was [his]98-frank churchill object , and [every body]3270-every body must perceive it . [She]79-emma introduced [him]98-frank churchill to [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend , [Miss Smith]107-harriet , and , at convenient moments afterwards , heard what [each]1886-each thought of [the other]3423-the other . “ [He]98-frank churchill had never seen so lovely a face , and was delighted with [her]80-miss taylor naïveté . ”[79-emma] And [she]79-emma , “ Only to be sure it was paying [him]98-frank churchill too great a compliment , but [she]80-miss taylor did think there were some looks a little like [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma restrained [her]79-emma indignation , and only turned from [her]79-emma in silence . Smiles of intelligence passed between [her]79-emma and [the gentleman]3371-the gentleman on first glancing towards [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ; but it was most prudent to avoid speech . [He]98-frank churchill told [her]79-emma that [he]98-frank churchill had been impatient to leave [the dining - room]1889-the dining - room — hated sitting long — was always the first to move when [he]98-frank churchill could — that [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , [Mr. Cox]205-mr. cox , and [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole , were left very busy over parish business — that as long as [he]98-frank churchill had staid , however , it had been pleasant enough , as [he]98-frank churchill had found [them]1891-them in general a set of [gentlemanlike , sensible men]1892-gentlemanlike , sensible men ; and spoke so handsomely of [Highbury]3-highbury altogether — thought it so abundant in [agreeable families]1893-agreeable families — that [Emma]79-emma began to feel [she]79-emma had been used to despise [the place]439-the place rather too much . [She]79-emma questioned [him]98-frank churchill as to the society in [Yorkshire]50-yorkshire — the extent of [the neighbourhood about [Enscombe]7-enscombe]1895-the neighbourhood about enscombe , and the sort ; and could make out from [his]98-frank churchill answers that , as far as [Enscombe]7-enscombe was concerned , there was very little going on , that [their]1891-them visitings were among [a range of great families]1896-a range of great families , none very near ; and that even when days were fixed , and invitations accepted , it was an even chance that [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill were not in health and spirits for going ; that [they]1891-them made a point of visiting [no fresh person]1897-no fresh person ; and that , though [he]98-frank churchill had [his]98-frank churchill separate engagements , it was not without difficulty , without considerable address at times , that [he]98-frank churchill could get away , or introduce [an acquaintance]1898-an acquaintance for a night . [She]79-emma saw that [Enscombe]7-enscombe could not satisfy , and that [Highbury]3-highbury , taken at its best , might reasonably please [a young man who had more retirement at [home]3258-home than [he]98-frank churchill liked]1899-a young man who had more retirement at home than he liked . [His]98-frank churchill importance at [Enscombe]7-enscombe was very evident . [He]98-frank churchill did not boast , but it naturally betrayed [itself]1901-itself , that [he]98-frank churchill had persuaded [[his]98-frank churchill aunt]1331-his aunt where [[his]98-frank churchill uncle]3212-his uncle could do nothing , and on [her]1331-his aunt laughing and noticing it , [he]98-frank churchill owned that [he]98-frank churchill believed ( excepting one or two points ) [he]98-frank churchill could with time persuade [her]1331-his aunt to any thing . One of those points on which [his]98-frank churchill influence failed , [he]98-frank churchill then mentioned . [He]98-frank churchill had wanted very much to go abroad — had been very eager indeed to be allowed to travel — but [she]1331-his aunt would not hear of it . This had happened the year before . Now , [he]98-frank churchill said , [he]98-frank churchill was beginning to have no longer the same wish . The unpersuadable point , which [he]98-frank churchill did not mention , [Emma]79-emma guessed to be good behaviour to [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father . “ [I]98-frank churchill have made a most wretched discovery , ”[98-frank churchill] said [he]98-frank churchill , after a short pause . — “ [I]98-frank churchill have been [here]3113-here a week to - morrow — half [my]98-frank churchill time . [I]98-frank churchill never knew days fly so fast . A week to - morrow!—And [I]98-frank churchill have hardly begun to enjoy [myself]98-frank churchill . But just got acquainted with [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , and [others!—I]98-frank churchill hate the recollection . ”[98-frank churchill] “ Perhaps [you]79-emma may now begin to regret that [you]79-emma spent one whole day , out of so few , in having [your]79-emma hair cut . ”[98-frank churchill] “ No , ”[98-frank churchill] said [he]98-frank churchill , smiling , “ that is no subject of regret at all . [I]98-frank churchill have no pleasure in seeing [[my]98-frank churchill friends]629-my friends , unless [I]98-frank churchill can believe [myself]98-frank churchill fit to be seen . ”[98-frank churchill] [The rest of [the gentlemen]1743-the gentlemen]1905-the rest of the gentlemen being now in [the room]3386-the room , [Emma]79-emma found [herself]79-emma obliged to turn from [him]98-frank churchill for a few minutes , and listen to [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole . When [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole had moved away , and [her]79-emma attention could be restored as before , [she]79-emma saw [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill looking intently across [the room]3386-the room at [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , who was sitting exactly opposite . “ What is the matter ? ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma . [He]98-frank churchill started . “ Thank [you]79-emma for rousing [me]98-frank churchill , ”[98-frank churchill] [he]98-frank churchill replied . “ [I]98-frank churchill believe [I]98-frank churchill have been very rude ; but really [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax has done [her]142-miss fairfax hair in so odd a way — so very odd a way — that [I]98-frank churchill can not keep [my]98-frank churchill eyes from [her]142-miss fairfax . [I]98-frank churchill never saw any thing so outrée!—Those curls!—This must be a fancy of [her]142-miss fairfax own . Shall [I?—Yes]98-frank churchill , [I]98-frank churchill will — [I]98-frank churchill declare [I]98-frank churchill will — and [you]882-the young lady shall see how [she]142-miss fairfax takes it;—whether [she]142-miss fairfax colours . ”[98-frank churchill] [He]98-frank churchill was gone immediately ; and [Emma]79-emma soon saw [him]98-frank churchill standing before [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , and talking to [her]142-miss fairfax ; but as to its effect on [the young lady]882-the young lady , as [he]98-frank churchill had improvidently placed [himself]98-frank churchill exactly between [them]1910-they , exactly in front of [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , [she]79-emma could absolutely distinguish nothing . Before [he]98-frank churchill could return to [his]98-frank churchill chair , it was taken by [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . “ This is the luxury of a large party , ”[84-mrs. weston] said [she:—“one]207-she:—“one can get near every body , and say every thing . [[My]84-mrs. weston dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , [I]84-mrs. weston am longing to talk to [you]79-emma . [I]84-mrs. weston have been making discoveries and forming plans , just like [yourself]79-emma , and [I]84-mrs. weston must tell [them]1910-they while the idea is fresh . Do [you]79-emma know how [Miss Bates]101-miss bates and [[her]101-miss bates niece]3833-her niece came [here]3113-here ? ”[84-mrs. weston] “ [How?—They]208-how?—they were invited , were not [they]1910-they ? ”[84-mrs. weston] “ Oh ! yes — but how [they]1910-they were conveyed hither?—the manner of [their]1910-they coming ? ”[84-mrs. weston] “ [They]1910-they walked , [I]84-mrs. weston conclude . How else could [they]1910-they come ? ”[84-mrs. weston] “ Very true.—Well , a little while ago it occurred to [me]84-mrs. weston how very sad it would be to have [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax walking [home]3258-home again , late at night , and cold as the nights are now . And as [I]84-mrs. weston looked at [her]142-miss fairfax , though [I]84-mrs. weston never saw [her]142-miss fairfax appear to more advantage , it struck [me]84-mrs. weston that [she]142-miss fairfax was heated , and would therefore be particularly liable to take cold . [Poor girl]1411-poor girl ! [I]84-mrs. weston could not bear the idea of it ; so , as soon as [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston came into [the room]3386-the room , and [I]84-mrs. weston could get at [him]82-mr. weston , [I]84-mrs. weston spoke to [him]82-mr. weston about [the carriage]3125-the carriage . [You]4223-you may guess how readily [he]82-mr. weston came into [my]84-mrs. weston wishes ; and having [his]82-mr. weston approbation , [I]84-mrs. weston made [my]84-mrs. weston way directly to [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , to assure [her]101-miss bates that [the carriage]3125-the carriage would be at [her]101-miss bates service before it took [us]4225-us [home]3258-home ; for [I]84-mrs. weston thought it would be making [her]101-miss bates comfortable at once . Good soul ! [she]101-miss bates was as grateful as possible , [you]4223-you may be sure . ‘ [Nobody]3124-nobody was ever so fortunate as herself!’—but with many , many thanks—‘there was no occasion to trouble [us]4225-us , for [[Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s carriage]4228-mr. knightley ’s carriage had brought , and was to take [them]4225-us [home]3258-home again . ’ [I]84-mrs. weston was quite surprized;—very glad , [I]84-mrs. weston am sure ; but really quite surprized . Such a very kind attention — and so thoughtful an attention!—the sort of thing that [so few men]4230-so few men would think of . And , in short , from knowing [his]88-mr. knightley usual ways , [I]84-mrs. weston am very much inclined to think that it was for [their]4225-us accommodation [the carriage]3125-the carriage was used at all . [I]84-mrs. weston do suspect [he]88-mr. knightley would not have had a pair of horses for [himself]88-mr. knightley , and that it was only as an excuse for assisting [them]4225-us . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ Very likely , ”[84-mrs. weston] said [Emma—“nothing]209-emma—“nothing more likely . [I]84-mrs. weston know [no man]570-no man more likely than [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley to do the sort of thing — to do any thing really good - natured , useful , considerate , or benevolent . [He]88-mr. knightley is not [a gallant man]4233-a gallant man , but [he]88-mr. knightley is [a very humane one]4234-a very humane one ; and this , considering [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s ill - health , would appear a case of humanity to [him;—and]88-mr. knightley for an act of unostentatious kindness , there is nobody whom [I]84-mrs. weston would fix on more than on [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [I]84-mrs. weston know [he]88-mr. knightley had horses to - day — for [we]4235-we arrived together ; and [I]84-mrs. weston laughed at [him]88-mr. knightley about it , but [he]88-mr. knightley said not a word that could betray . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ Well , ”[84-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , smiling , “ [you]84-mrs. weston give [him]88-mr. knightley credit for more simple , disinterested benevolence in this instance than [I]84-mrs. weston do ; for while [Miss Bates]101-miss bates was speaking , a suspicion darted into [my]84-mrs. weston head , and [I]84-mrs. weston have never been able to get it out again . The more [I]84-mrs. weston think of it , the more probable it appears . In short , [I]84-mrs. weston have made a match between [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . [Knightley!—Mr]4236-knightley!—mr . And , upon [my]79-emma word , [I]79-emma do not think [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley would be much disturbed by [Miss Bates]101-miss bates . Little things do not irritate [him]88-mr. knightley . [She]142-miss fairfax might talk on ; and if [he]88-mr. knightley wanted to say any thing [himself]88-mr. knightley , [he]88-mr. knightley would only talk louder , and drown [her]142-miss fairfax voice . But the question is not , whether it would be a bad connexion for [him]88-mr. knightley , but whether [he]88-mr. knightley wishes it ; and [I]79-emma think [he]88-mr. knightley does . [I]79-emma have heard [him]88-mr. knightley speak , and so must [you]79-emma , so very highly of [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ! [I]79-emma can not help suspecting [him]88-mr. knightley .
