[They]4447-poor isabella ’s little ones can do nothing satisfactorily without [you]79-emma . ”[98-frank churchill] [Emma]79-emma was most happy to be called to such a council ; and [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , engaging to think it all over while [she]79-emma was gone , [the two young people]1984-the two young people set off together without delay for the Crown . There were [Mr.]2012-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ; delighted to see [her]79-emma and receive [her]79-emma approbation , very busy and very happy in [their]1984-the two young people different way ; [she]79-emma , in some little distress ; and [he]415-her father , finding every thing perfect . “ [Emma]79-emma , ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma , “ this paper is worse than [I]79-emma expected . Look ! in places [you]79-emma see it is dreadfully dirty ; and the wainscot is more yellow and forlorn than any thing [I]79-emma could have imagined . ”[79-emma] “ [[My]431-her husband dear]3120-my dear , [you]3120-my dear are too particular , ”[431-her husband] said [[her]79-emma husband]431-her husband . “ What does all that signify ? [You]3120-my dear will see nothing of it by candlelight . It will be as clean as [Randalls]97-randalls by candlelight . [We]4453-we never see any thing of it on [our]4453-we club - nights . ”[431-her husband] [The ladies here]2014-the ladies here probably exchanged looks which meant , “ [Men]828-men never know when things are dirty or not ; ”[1743-the gentlemen] and [the gentlemen]1743-the gentlemen perhaps thought each to [himself]1743-the gentlemen , “ [Women]1136-women will have [their]1136-women little nonsenses and needless cares . ”[1743-the gentlemen] One perplexity , however , arose , which [the gentlemen]1743-the gentlemen did not disdain . It regarded [a supper - room]2017-a supper - room . At the time of [the ballroom]2018-the ballroom ’s being built , suppers had not been in question ; and [a small card - room adjoining]2019-a small card - room adjoining , was [the only addition]2020-the only addition . What was to be done ? [This card - room]2021-this card - room would be wanted as [a card - room]2022-a card - room now ; or , if cards were conveniently voted unnecessary by [their]2023-their four selves , still was it not too small for any comfortable supper ? [Another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose]2024-another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose ; but [it]2024-another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose was at [the other end of [the house]425-the house]2025-the other end of the house , and a long awkward passage must be gone through to get at [it]2024-another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose . This made a difficulty . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was afraid of draughts for [the young people]2027-the young people in [that passage]2028-that passage ; and neither [Emma]79-emma nor [the gentlemen]1743-the gentlemen could tolerate the prospect of being miserably crowded at supper . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston proposed having no regular supper ; merely sandwiches , & c. , set out in [the little room]2030-the little room ; but that was scouted as a wretched suggestion . A private dance , without sitting down to supper , was pronounced an infamous fraud upon the rights of [men]828-men and [women]1136-women ; and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston must not speak of it again . [She]84-mrs. weston then took another line of expediency , and looking into [the doubtful room]2033-the doubtful room , observed , “ [I]84-mrs. weston do not think it is so very small . [We]4456-our shall not be many , [you]82-mr. weston know . ”[84-mrs. weston] And [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston at the same time , walking briskly with long steps through [the passage]3927-the passage , was calling out , “ [You]82-mr. weston talk a great deal of the length of [this passage]4457-this passage , [[my]82-mr. weston dear]3120-my dear . It is a mere nothing after all ; and not the least draught from the stairs . ”[82-mr. weston] “ [I]84-mrs. weston wish , ”[84-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , “ [one]475-one could know which arrangement [[our]4456-our guests]4460-our guests in general would like best . To do what would be most generally pleasing must be [our]4456-our object — if one could but tell what that would be . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ Yes , very true , ”[98-frank churchill] cried [Frank]98-frank churchill , “ very true . [You]82-mr. weston want [[your]82-mr. weston neighbours]4156-your neighbours ’ opinions . [I]98-frank churchill do not wonder at [you]82-mr. weston . If one could ascertain what [the chief of [them]4156-your neighbours]4462-the chief of them — [the Coles]175-the coles , for instance . [They]175-the coles are not far off . Shall [I]98-frank churchill call upon [them]175-the coles ? Or [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ? [She]101-miss bates is still nearer.—And [I]98-frank churchill do not know whether [Miss Bates]101-miss bates is not as likely to understand the inclinations of [the rest of [the people]4464-the people]4463-the rest of the people as [any body]530-any body . [I]98-frank churchill think [we]4466-we do want [a larger council]4467-a larger council . Suppose [I]98-frank churchill go and invite [Miss Bates]101-miss bates to join [us]4466-we ? ”[98-frank churchill] “ Well — if [you]98-frank churchill please , ”[84-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston rather hesitating , “ if [you]98-frank churchill think [she]101-miss bates will be of any use . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ [You]98-frank churchill will get nothing to the purpose from [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma . “ [She]101-miss bates will be all delight and gratitude , but [she]101-miss bates will tell [you]98-frank churchill nothing . [She]101-miss bates will not even listen to [your]98-frank churchill questions . [I]79-emma see no advantage in consulting [Miss Bates]101-miss bates . ”[79-emma] “ But [she]101-miss bates is so amusing , so extremely amusing ! [I]84-mrs. weston am very fond of hearing [Miss Bates]101-miss bates talk . And [I]84-mrs. weston need not bring [the whole family]3875-the whole family , [you]98-frank churchill know . ”[84-mrs. weston] Here [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston joined [them]2035-them , and on hearing what was proposed , gave [it]2036-it [his]82-mr. weston decided approbation . “ Aye , do , [Frank.—Go]234-frank.—go and fetch [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , and let [us]2035-them end the matter at once . [She]101-miss bates will enjoy the scheme , [I]82-mr. weston am sure ; and [I]82-mr. weston do not know [a properer person]4469-a properer person for [shewing]4470-shewing [us]2035-them how to do away difficulties . Fetch [Miss Bates]101-miss bates . [We]2035-them are growing a little too nice . [She]101-miss bates is a standing lesson of how to be happy . But fetch [them]2035-them both . Invite [them]2035-them both . ”[82-mr. weston] “ Both [sir]3139-sir ! Can [the old lady]4472-the old lady ? ”[82-mr. weston] ... “ [The old lady]4472-the old lady ! No , [the young lady]882-the young lady , to be sure . [I]82-mr. weston shall think [you]3139-sir [a great blockhead]4475-a great blockhead , [Frank]98-frank churchill , if [you]3139-sir bring [the aunt]3215-the aunt without [the niece]4477-the niece . ”[82-mr. weston] “ Oh ! [I]82-mr. weston beg [your]3139-sir pardon , [sir]3139-sir . [I]82-mr. weston did not immediately recollect . Undoubtedly if [you]3139-sir wish it , [I]82-mr. weston will endeavour to persuade [them]4479-them both . ”[82-mr. weston] And away [he]2037-he ran . Long before [he]2037-he reappeared , attending [the short , neat , brisk - moving aunt]2038-the short , neat , brisk - moving aunt , and [her]2038-the short , neat , brisk - moving aunt elegant niece,—Mrs . [Weston]82-mr. weston , like [a sweet - tempered woman]2039-a sweet - tempered woman and [a good wife]592-a good wife , had examined [the passage]3927-the passage again , and found the evils of it much less than [she]2038-the short , neat , brisk - moving aunt had supposed before — indeed very trifling ; and here ended the difficulties of decision . All the rest , in speculation at least , was perfectly smooth . All the minor arrangements of table and chair , lights and music , tea and supper , made themselves ; or were left as mere trifles to be settled at any time between [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston and [Mrs. Stokes.—Every body]235-mrs. stokes.—every body invited , was certainly to come ; [Frank]98-frank churchill had already written to [Enscombe]7-enscombe to propose staying a few days beyond [his]98-frank churchill fortnight , which could not possibly be refused . And a delightful dance it was to be . Most cordially , when [Miss Bates]101-miss bates arrived , did [she]101-miss bates agree that it must . As [a counsellor]2042-a counsellor [she]101-miss bates was not wanted ; but as [an approver]2043-an approver , ( a much safer character , ) [she]101-miss bates was truly welcome . [Her]101-miss bates approbation , at once general and minute , warm and incessant , could not but please ; and for another half - hour [they]2044-they were all walking to and fro , between [the different rooms]2045-the different rooms , some suggesting , [some attending]2046-some attending , and all in happy enjoyment of the future . The party did not break up without [Emma]79-emma ’s being positively secured for the two first dances by [the hero of the evening]2047-the hero of the evening , nor without [her]79-emma overhearing [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston whisper to [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife , “ [He]82-mr. weston has asked [her]79-emma , [[my]82-mr. weston dear]3120-my dear . That ’s right . [I]82-mr. weston knew [he]82-mr. weston would ! ”[82-mr. weston] CHAPTER XII One thing only was wanting to make the prospect of the ball completely satisfactory to [Emma]79-emma — its being fixed for a day within the granted term of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s stay in [Surry]24-surry ; for , in spite of [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s confidence , [she]79-emma could not think it so very impossible that [the Churchills]96-the churchills might not allow [[their]2049-their nephew]2050-their nephew to remain a day beyond [his]2050-their nephew fortnight . But this was not judged feasible . The preparations must take [their]2049-their time , nothing could be properly ready till the third week were entered on , and for a few days [they]2049-their must be planning , proceeding and hoping in uncertainty — at the risk — in [her]79-emma opinion , the great risk , of its being all in vain . [Enscombe]7-enscombe however was gracious , gracious in fact , if not in word . [His]7-enscombe wish of staying longer evidently did not please ; but it was not opposed . All was safe and prosperous ; and as the removal of one solicitude generally makes way for another , [Emma]79-emma , being now certain of [[her]79-emma ball]2051-her ball , began to adopt as the next vexation [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s provoking indifference about it . Either because [he]7-enscombe did not dance [himself]7-enscombe , or because the plan had been formed without [his]7-enscombe being consulted , [he]7-enscombe seemed resolved that it should not interest [him]7-enscombe , determined against its exciting any present curiosity , or affording [him]7-enscombe any future amusement . To [her]79-emma voluntary communications [Emma]79-emma could get no more approving reply , than , “ Very well . If [the Westons]104-the westons think it worth while to be at all this trouble for a few hours of noisy entertainment , [I]79-emma have nothing to say against it , but that [they]2049-their shall not chuse pleasures for me.—Oh ! yes , [I]79-emma must be [there]437-there ; [I]79-emma could not refuse ; and [I]79-emma will keep as much awake as [I]79-emma can ; but [I]79-emma would rather be at [home]3258-home , looking over [William Larkins]223-william larkins ’s week ’s account ; much rather , [I]79-emma confess.—Pleasure in seeing dancing!—not [I]79-emma , indeed — [I]79-emma never look at it — [I]79-emma do not know who does.—Fine dancing , [I]79-emma believe , like virtue , must be its own reward . [Those who are standing by]4483-those who are standing by are usually thinking of something very different . ”[79-emma] This [Emma]79-emma felt was aimed at [her]79-emma ; and it made [her]79-emma quite angry . It was not in compliment to [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax however that [he]2052-he was so indifferent , or so indignant ; [he]2052-he was not guided by [her]79-emma feelings in reprobating the ball , for [she]79-emma enjoyed the thought of it to an extraordinary degree . It made [her]79-emma animated — open hearted — [she]79-emma voluntarily said ; — “ Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , [I]79-emma hope nothing may happen to prevent the ball . What a disappointment it would be ! [I]79-emma do look forward to it , [I]79-emma own , with very great pleasure . ”[79-emma] It was not to oblige [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax therefore that [he]2052-he would have preferred [the society of [William Larkins]223-william larkins]2053-the society of william larkins . [No!—she]236-no!—she was more and more convinced that [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was quite mistaken in that surmise . There was a great deal of friendly and of compassionate attachment on [his]2052-he side — but no love . Alas ! there was soon no leisure for quarrelling with [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . Two days of joyful security were immediately followed by the over - throw of every thing . A letter arrived from [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill to urge [[his]98-frank churchill nephew]2054-his nephew ’s instant return . [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill was unwell — far too unwell to do without [him]2054-his nephew ; [she]94-mrs. churchill had been in a very suffering state ( so said [[her]94-mrs. churchill husband]431-her husband ) when writing to [[her]94-mrs. churchill nephew]1441-her nephew two days before , though from [her]94-mrs. churchill usual unwillingness to give pain , and constant habit of never thinking of [herself]94-mrs. churchill , [she]94-mrs. churchill had not mentioned it ; but now [she]94-mrs. churchill was too ill to trifle , and must entreat [him]2054-his nephew to set off for [Enscombe]7-enscombe without delay . The substance of this letter was forwarded to [Emma]79-emma , in a note from [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , instantly . As to [his]2054-his nephew going , it was inevitable . [He]2054-his nephew must be gone within a few hours , though without feeling any real alarm for [[his]2054-his nephew aunt]1331-his aunt , to lessen [his]2054-his nephew repugnance . [He]2054-his nephew knew [her]1331-his aunt illnesses ; they never occurred but for [her]1331-his aunt own convenience . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston added , “ that [he]2054-his nephew could only allow [himself]2054-his nephew time to hurry to [Highbury]3-highbury , after breakfast , and take leave of [the few friends there whom [he]2054-his nephew could suppose to feel any interest in [him]2054-his nephew]4484-the few friends there whom he could suppose to feel any interest in him ; and that [he]2054-his nephew might be expected at [Hartfield]90-hartfield very soon . ”[84-mrs. weston] This wretched note was the finale of [Emma]79-emma ’s breakfast . When once it had been read , there was no doing any thing , but lament and exclaim . The loss of the ball — the loss of [the young man]3228-the young man — and all that [the young man]3228-the young man might be feeling!—It was too wretched!—Such a delightful evening as it would have been!—Every body so happy ! and [she]79-emma and [[her]79-emma partner]2060-her partner the happiest!—“I said it would be so , ”[415-her father] was the only consolation . [[Her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s feelings were quite distinct . [He]2054-his nephew thought principally of [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill ’s illness , and wanted to know how [she]79-emma was treated ; and as for the ball , it was shocking to have dear [Emma]79-emma disappointed ; but [they]2062-they would all be safer at [home]3258-home . [Emma]79-emma was ready for [[her]79-emma visitor]2064-her visitor some time before [he]2064-her visitor appeared ; but if this reflected at all upon [his]2064-her visitor impatience , [his]2064-her visitor sorrowful look and total want of spirits when [he]2064-her visitor did come might redeem [him]2064-her visitor . [He]2064-her visitor felt the going away almost too much to speak of it . [His]2064-her visitor dejection was most evident . [He]2064-her visitor sat really lost in thought for the first few minutes ; and when rousing [himself]2064-her visitor , it was only to say , “ Of all horrid things , leave - taking is the worst . ”[2064-her visitor] “ But [you]2064-her visitor will come again , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma . “ This will not be [your]2064-her visitor only visit to [Randalls]97-randalls . ”[79-emma] “ Ah!—(shaking [his]2064-her visitor head)—the uncertainty of when [I]2064-her visitor may be able to return!—I shall try for it with a zeal!—It will be the object of all [my]2064-her visitor thoughts and cares!—and if [[my]2064-her visitor uncle]4485-my uncle and [aunt]1419-aunt go to [town]3165-town this spring — but [I]2064-her visitor am afraid — [they]4488-they did not stir last spring — [I]2064-her visitor am afraid it is a custom gone for ever . ”[2064-her visitor] “ [Our]4489-we poor ball must be quite given up . ”[2064-her visitor] “ Ah ! that ball!—why did [we]4489-we wait for any thing?—why not seize the pleasure at once?—How often is happiness destroyed by preparation , foolish preparation!—You told [us]4489-we it would be so.—Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , why are [you]2065-you always so right ? ”[79-emma] “ Indeed , [I]2064-her visitor am very sorry to be right in this instance . [I]2064-her visitor would much rather have been merry than wise . ”[2064-her visitor] “ If [I]79-emma can come again , [we]4489-we are still to have [our]4489-we ball . [[My]79-emma father]3146-my father depends on it . Do not forget [your]2065-you engagement . ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma looked graciously . “ Such a fortnight as it has been ! ”[2065-you] [he]2065-you continued ; “ every day more precious and more delightful than the day before!—every day making [me]2065-you less fit to bear any other place . Happy those , who can remain at [Highbury]3-highbury ! ”[2065-you] “ As [you]2065-you do [us]4489-we such ample justice now , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , laughing , “ [I]2065-you will venture to ask , whether [you]2065-you did not come a little doubtfully at first ? Do not [we]4489-we rather surpass [your]2065-you expectations ? [I]2065-you am sure [we]4489-we do . [I]2065-you am sure [you]2065-you did not much expect to like [us]4489-we . [You]2065-you would not have been so long in coming , if [you]2065-you had had a pleasant idea of [Highbury]3-highbury . ”[2065-you] [He]2065-you laughed rather consciously ; and though denying the sentiment , [Emma]79-emma was convinced that it had been so . “ And [you]2065-you must be off this very morning ? ”[79-emma] “ Yes ; [[my]2065-you father]3146-my father is to join [me]2065-you here : [we]4489-we shall walk back together , and [I]2065-you must be off immediately . [I]2065-you am almost afraid that every moment will bring [him]3146-my father . ”[2065-you] “ Not five minutes to spare even for [[your]2065-you friends]926-your friends [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ? How unlucky ! [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ’s powerful , argumentative mind might have strengthened [yours]2065-you . ”[2065-you] “ Yes — [I]79-emma have called [there]437-there ; passing the door , [I]79-emma thought it better . It was a right thing to do . [I]79-emma went in for three minutes , and was detained by [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ’s being absent . [She]101-miss bates was out ; and [I]79-emma felt it impossible not to wait till [she]101-miss bates came in . [She]101-miss bates is [a woman that one]4494-a woman that one may , that [one]475-one must laugh at ; but [that one]4496-that one would not wish to slight . It was better to pay [my]79-emma visit , then ”[79-emma] — [He]2066-he hesitated , got up , walked to a window . “ In short , ”[2066-he] said [he]2066-he , “ perhaps , [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor — [I]2066-he think [you]2067-she can hardly be quite without suspicion ”[2066-he] — [He]2066-he looked at [her]2067-she , as if wanting to read [her]2067-she thoughts . [She]2067-she hardly knew what to say . It seemed like the forerunner of something absolutely serious , which [she]2067-she did not wish . Forcing [herself]2067-she to speak , therefore , in the hope of putting it by , [she]2067-she calmly said , “ [You]2066-he are quite in the right ; it was most natural to pay [your]2066-he visit , then ”[2067-she] — [He]2066-he was silent . [She]2067-she believed [he]2066-he was looking at [her]2067-she ; probably reflecting on what [she]2067-she had said , and trying to understand the manner . [She]2067-she heard [him]2066-he sigh . It was natural for [him]2066-he to feel that [he]2066-he had cause to sigh . [He]2066-he could not believe [her]2067-she to be encouraging [him]2066-he . A few awkward moments passed , and [he]2066-he sat down again ; and in a more determined manner said , “ It was something to feel that all the rest of [my]2066-he time might be given to [Hartfield]90-hartfield . [My]2066-he regard for [Hartfield]90-hartfield is most warm ”[2066-he] — [He]2066-he stopt again , rose again , and seemed quite embarrassed.—He was more in love with [her]2067-she than [Emma]79-emma had supposed ; and who can say how it might have ended , if [[his]2066-he father]3213-his father had not made [his]3213-his father appearance ? [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse soon followed ; and the necessity of exertion made [him]2066-he composed . A very few minutes more , however , completed the present trial . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , always alert when business was to be done , and as incapable of procrastinating any evil that was inevitable , as of foreseeing any that was doubtful , said , “ It was time to go ; ”[3228-the young man] and [the young man]3228-the young man , though [he]3228-the young man might and did sigh , could not but agree , to take leave . “ [I]2066-he shall hear about [you]4497-you all , ”[2066-he] said [he]2066-he ; “ that is [my]2066-he chief consolation . [I]2066-he shall hear of every thing that is going on among [you]4497-you . [I]2066-he have engaged [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston to correspond with [me]2066-he . [She]84-mrs. weston has been so kind as to promise it . Oh ! the blessing of [a female correspondent]4498-a female correspondent , when [one]475-one is really interested in [the absent!—she]4500-the absent!—she will tell [me]2066-he every thing . In [her]84-mrs. weston letters [I]2066-he shall be at dear [Highbury]3-highbury again . ”[2066-he] A very friendly shake of the hand , a very earnest “ Good - bye , ”[2066-he] closed the speech , and the door had soon shut out [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . [Short]237-short had been the notice — short [their]2070-their meeting ; [he]98-frank churchill was gone ; and [Emma]79-emma felt so sorry to part , and foresaw so great a loss to [[their]2070-their little society]2071-their little society from [his]98-frank churchill absence as to begin to be afraid of being too sorry , and feeling it too much . It was a sad change . [They]2070-their had been meeting almost every day since [his]98-frank churchill arrival . Certainly [his]98-frank churchill being at [Randalls]97-randalls had given great spirit to the last two weeks — indescribable spirit ; the idea , the expectation of seeing [him]98-frank churchill which every morning had brought , the assurance of [his]98-frank churchill attentions , [his]98-frank churchill liveliness , [his]98-frank churchill manners ! It had been a very happy fortnight , and forlorn must be the sinking from it into the common course of [Hartfield]90-hartfield days . To complete every other recommendation , [he]98-frank churchill had almost told [her]79-emma that [he]98-frank churchill loved [her]79-emma . What strength , or what constancy of affection [he]98-frank churchill might be subject to , was another point ; but at present [she]79-emma could not doubt [his]98-frank churchill having a decidedly warm admiration , a conscious preference of [herself]79-emma ; and this persuasion , joined to all the rest , made [her]79-emma think that [she]79-emma must be a little in love with [him]98-frank churchill , in spite of every previous determination against it . “ [I]79-emma certainly must , ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma . “ This sensation of listlessness , weariness , stupidity , this disinclination to sit down and employ [myself]79-emma , this feeling of every thing ’s being dull and insipid about [the house]425-the house ! — [I]79-emma must be in love ; [I]79-emma should be the oddest creature in [the world]392-the world if [I]79-emma were not — for a few weeks at least . Well ! evil to some is always good to [others]473-others . [I]79-emma shall have [many fellow - mourners]4504-many fellow - mourners for the ball , if not for [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ; but [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley will be happy . [He]88-mr. knightley may spend the evening with [[his]88-mr. knightley dear]3590-his dear [William Larkins]223-william larkins now if [he]88-mr. knightley likes . ”[79-emma] [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , however , [shewed]2072-shewed no triumphant happiness . [He]88-mr. knightley could not say that [he]88-mr. knightley was sorry on [his]88-mr. knightley own account ; [his]88-mr. knightley very cheerful look would have contradicted [him]88-mr. knightley if [he]88-mr. knightley had ; but [he]88-mr. knightley said , and very steadily , that [he]88-mr. knightley was sorry for the disappointment of [the others]3512-the others , and with considerable kindness added , “ [You]2074-she , [Emma]79-emma , who have so few opportunities of dancing , [you]2074-she are really out of luck ; [you]2074-she are very much out of luck ! ”[88-mr. knightley] It was some days before [she]2074-she saw [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , to judge of [her]2074-she honest regret in this woeful change ; but when [they]2075-they did meet , [her]2074-she composure was odious . [She]2074-she had been particularly unwell , however , suffering from headache to a degree , which made [[her]2074-she aunt]1061-her aunt declare , that had the ball taken place , [she]2074-she did not think [Jane]142-miss fairfax could have attended it ; and it was charity to impute some of [her]2074-she unbecoming indifference to the languor of ill - health . [CHAPTER XIII Emma]79-emma continued to entertain no doubt of [her]2074-she being in love . [Her]2074-she ideas only varied as to the how much . At first , [she]2074-she thought it was a good deal ; and afterwards , but little . [She]2074-she had great pleasure in hearing [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill talked of ; and , for [his]98-frank churchill sake , greater pleasure than ever in seeing [Mr.]2077-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ; [she]2074-she was very often thinking of [him]98-frank churchill , and quite impatient for a letter , that [she]2074-she might know how [he]98-frank churchill was , how were [his]98-frank churchill spirits , how was [[his]98-frank churchill aunt]1331-his aunt , and what was the chance of [his]98-frank churchill coming to [Randalls]97-randalls again this spring . But , on the other hand , [she]2074-she could not admit [herself]2074-she to be unhappy , nor , after the first morning , to be less disposed for employment than usual ; [she]2074-she was still busy and cheerful ; and , pleasing as [he]98-frank churchill was , [she]2074-she could yet imagine [him]98-frank churchill to have faults ; and farther , though thinking of [him]98-frank churchill so much , and , as [she]2074-she sat drawing or working , forming a thousand amusing schemes for the progress and close of [their]2079-their attachment , fancying interesting dialogues , and inventing elegant letters ; the conclusion of every imaginary declaration on [his]98-frank churchill side was that [she]2074-she refused [him]98-frank churchill . [Their]2079-their affection was always to subside into friendship . Every thing tender and charming was to mark [their]2079-their parting ; but still [they]2079-their were to part . When [she]2074-she became sensible of this , it struck [her]2074-she that [she]2074-she could not be very much in love ; for in spite of [her]2074-she previous and fixed determination never to quit [[her]2074-she father]415-her father , never to marry , a strong attachment certainly must produce more of a struggle than [she]2074-she could foresee in [her]2074-she own feelings . “ [I]2074-she do not find [myself]2074-she making any use of the word sacrifice , ”[2074-she] said she.—“In not one of all [my]2074-she clever replies , [my]2074-she delicate negatives , is there any allusion to making a sacrifice . [I]2074-she do suspect that [he]98-frank churchill is not really necessary to [my]2074-she happiness . So much the better . [I]2074-she certainly will not persuade [myself]2074-she to feel more than [I]2074-she do . [I]2074-she am quite enough in love . [I]2074-she should be sorry to be more . ”[2074-she] Upon the whole , [she]2074-she was equally contented with [her]2074-she view of [his]2081-his feelings . “ [He]2081-his is undoubtedly very much in love — every thing denotes it — very much in love indeed!—and when [he]2081-his comes again , if [his]2081-his affection continue , [I]2074-she must be on [my]2074-she guard not to encourage it.—It would be most inexcusable to do otherwise , as [my]2074-she own mind is quite made up . Not that [I]2074-she imagine [he]2081-his can think [I]2074-she have been encouraging [him]2081-his hitherto . No , if [he]2081-his had believed [me]2074-she at all to share [his]2081-his feelings , [he]2081-his would not have been so wretched . Could [he]2081-his have thought [himself]2081-his encouraged , [his]2081-his looks and language at parting would have been different.—Still , however , [I]2074-she must be on [my]2074-she guard . This is in the supposition of [his]2081-his attachment continuing what it now is ; but [I]2074-she do not know that [I]2074-she expect it will ; [I]2074-she do not look upon [him]2081-his to be quite [the sort of man]4506-the sort of man — [I]2074-she do not altogether build upon [his]2081-his steadiness or constancy.—His feelings are warm , but [I]2074-she can imagine them rather changeable.—Every consideration of the subject , in short , makes [me]2074-she thankful that [my]2074-she happiness is not more deeply involved.—I shall do very well again after a little while — and then , it will be a good thing over ; for [they]4507-they say every body is in love once in [their]4507-they lives , and [I]2074-she shall have been let off easily . ”[2074-she] When [his]2082-his letter to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston arrived , [Emma]79-emma had the perusal of it ; and [she]79-emma read it with a degree of pleasure and admiration which made [her]79-emma at first shake [her]79-emma head over [her]79-emma own sensations , and think [she]79-emma had undervalued [their]2083-their strength . It was a long , well - written letter , giving the particulars of [his]2082-his journey and of [his]2082-his feelings , expressing all the affection , gratitude , and respect which was natural and honourable , and describing every thing exterior and local that could be supposed attractive , with spirit and precision . No suspicious flourishes now of apology or concern ; it was the language of real feeling towards [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ; and the transition from [Highbury]3-highbury to [Enscombe]7-enscombe , the contrast between the places in some of the first blessings of social life was just enough touched on to shew how keenly it was felt , and how much more might have been said but for the restraints of propriety.—The charm of [her]84-mrs. weston own name was not wanting . [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield appeared more than once , and never without a something of pleasing connexion , either a compliment to [her]90-hartfield taste , or a remembrance of what [she]90-hartfield had said ; and in the very last time of its meeting [her]79-emma eye , unadorned as it was by any such broad wreath of gallantry , [she]79-emma yet could discern the effect of [her]90-hartfield influence and acknowledge the greatest compliment perhaps of all conveyed . Compressed into the very lowest vacant corner were these words—“I had not a spare moment on Tuesday , as [you]4508-you know , for [[Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield ’s beautiful little friend]4509-miss woodhouse ’s beautiful little friend . Pray make [my]79-emma excuses and adieus to [her]4509-miss woodhouse ’s beautiful little friend . ”[79-emma] This , [Emma]79-emma could not doubt , was all for [herself]79-emma . [Harriet]107-harriet was remembered only from being [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend . [His]2085-his information and prospects as to [Enscombe]7-enscombe were neither worse nor better than had been anticipated ; [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill was recovering , and [he]2085-his dared not yet , even in [his]2085-his own imagination , fix a time for coming to [Randalls]97-randalls again . Gratifying , however , and stimulative as was the letter in the material part , its sentiments , [she]79-emma yet found , when it was folded up and returned to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , that it had not added any lasting warmth , that [she]84-mrs. weston could still do without [the writer]3411-the writer , and that [he]2085-his must learn to do without [her]84-mrs. weston . [Her]79-emma intentions were unchanged . [Her]79-emma resolution of refusal only grew more interesting by the addition of a scheme for [his]2085-his subsequent consolation and happiness . [His]2085-his recollection of [Harriet]107-harriet , and the words which clothed it , [the “ beautiful little friend]4510-the “ beautiful little friend , ”[4510-the “ beautiful little friend] suggested to [her]79-emma the idea of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s succeeding [her]107-harriet in [his]2085-his affections . Was it impossible?—No.—Harriet undoubtedly was greatly [his]2085-his inferior in understanding ; but [he]2085-his had been very much struck with the loveliness of [her]107-harriet face and the warm simplicity of [her]107-harriet manner ; and all the probabilities of circumstance and connexion were in [her]107-harriet favour.—For [Harriet]107-harriet , it would be advantageous and delightful indeed . “ [I]107-harriet must not dwell upon it , ”[107-harriet] said she.—“I must not think of it . [I]107-harriet know the danger of indulging such speculations . But stranger things have happened ; and when [we]4511-we cease to care for [each other]420-each other as [we]4511-we do now , it will be the means of confirming [us]4511-we in that sort of true disinterested friendship which [I]107-harriet can already look forward to with pleasure . ”[107-harriet] It was well to have a comfort in store on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s behalf , though it might be wise to let the fancy touch it seldom ; for evil in [that quarter]2087-that quarter was at hand . As [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s arrival had succeeded [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s engagement in the conversation of [Highbury]3-highbury , as the latest interest had entirely borne down the first , so now upon [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s disappearance , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s concerns were assuming the most irresistible form.—His wedding - day was named . [He]98-frank churchill would soon be among [them]2088-them again ; [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton and [[his]91-mr. elton bride]1626-his bride . There was hardly time to talk over the first letter from [Enscombe]7-enscombe before “ [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton and [[his]91-mr. elton bride]1626-his bride ”[91-mr. elton] was in every body ’s mouth , and [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill was forgotten . [Emma]79-emma grew sick at the sound . [She]79-emma had had three weeks of happy exemption from [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ; and [Harriet]107-harriet ’s mind , [she]79-emma had been willing to hope , had been lately gaining strength . With [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s ball in view at least , there had been a great deal of insensibility to other things ; but it was now too evident that [she]79-emma had not attained such a state of composure as could stand against the actual approach — [new carriage]2090-new carriage , bell - ringing , and all . [Poor Harriet]107-harriet was in a flutter of spirits which required all the reasonings and soothings and attentions of every kind that [Emma]79-emma could give . [Emma]79-emma felt that [she]79-emma could not do too much for [her]107-harriet , that [Harriet]107-harriet had a right to all [her]107-harriet ingenuity and all [her]107-harriet patience ; but it was heavy work to be for ever convincing without producing any effect , for ever agreed to , without being able to make [their]2091-them opinions the same . [Harriet]107-harriet listened submissively , and said “ it was very true — it was just as [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield described — it was not worth while to think about [them]2091-them — and [she]79-emma would not think about [them]2091-them any longer ”[107-harriet] but no change of subject could avail , and the next half - hour saw [her]107-harriet as anxious and restless about [the Eltons]134-the eltons as before . At last [Emma]79-emma attacked [her]107-harriet on another ground . “ [Your]107-harriet allowing [yourself]107-harriet to be so occupied and so unhappy about [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s marrying , [Harriet]107-harriet , is the strongest reproach [you]107-harriet can make [me]79-emma . [You]107-harriet could not give [me]79-emma a greater reproof for the mistake [I]79-emma fell into . It was all [my]79-emma doing , [I]79-emma know . [I]79-emma have not forgotten it , [I]79-emma assure you.—Deceived [myself]79-emma , [I]79-emma did very miserably deceive [you]107-harriet — and it will be a painful reflection to [me]79-emma for ever . Do not imagine [me]79-emma in danger of forgetting it . ”[79-emma] [Harriet]107-harriet felt this too much to utter more than a few words of eager exclamation . [Emma]79-emma continued , “ [I]79-emma have not said , exert [yourself]107-harriet [Harriet]107-harriet for [my]79-emma sake ; think less , talk less of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton for [my]79-emma sake ; because for [your]107-harriet own sake rather , [I]79-emma would wish it to be done , for the sake of what is more important than [my]79-emma comfort , a habit of self - command in [you]107-harriet , a consideration of what is [your]107-harriet duty , an attention to propriety , an endeavour to avoid the suspicions of [others]473-others , to save [your]107-harriet health and credit , and restore [your]107-harriet tranquillity . These are the motives which [I]79-emma have been pressing on [you]107-harriet . They are very important — and sorry [I]79-emma am that [you]107-harriet can not feel [them]4515-them sufficiently to act upon [them]4515-them . [My]79-emma being saved from pain is a very secondary consideration . [I]79-emma want [you]107-harriet to save [yourself]107-harriet from greater pain . Perhaps [I]79-emma may sometimes have felt that [Harriet]107-harriet would not forget what was due — or rather what would be kind by [me]79-emma . ”[79-emma] This appeal to [her]2092-her affections did more than all the rest . The idea of wanting gratitude and consideration for [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , whom [she]2092-her really loved extremely , made [her]2092-her wretched for a while , and when the violence of grief was comforted away , still remained powerful enough to prompt to what was right and support [her]2092-her in it very tolerably . “ [You]107-harriet , who have been [the best friend [I]79-emma ever had in [my]79-emma life]4516-the best friend i ever had in my life — Want gratitude to you!—Nobody is equal to you!—I care for [nobody]3124-nobody as [I]79-emma do for you!—Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , how ungrateful [I]79-emma have been ! ”[79-emma] Such expressions , assisted as they were by every thing that look and manner could do , made [Emma]79-emma feel that [she]79-emma had never loved [Harriet]107-harriet so well , nor valued [her]107-harriet affection so highly before . “ There is no charm equal to tenderness of heart , ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma afterwards to [herself]79-emma . “ There is nothing to be compared to it . Warmth and tenderness of heart , with an affectionate , open manner , will beat all the clearness of head in [the world]392-the world , for attraction , [I]79-emma am sure it will . It is tenderness of heart which makes [[my]79-emma dear father]4519-my dear father so generally beloved — which gives [Isabella]83-isabella all [her]83-isabella popularity.—I have it not — but [I]79-emma know how to prize and respect it.—Harriet is [my]79-emma superior in all the charm and all the felicity it gives . [Dear Harriet!—I]239-dear harriet!—i would not change [you]239-dear harriet!—i for [the clearest - headed , longest - sighted , best - judging female]4520-the clearest - headed , longest - sighted , best - judging female breathing . Oh ! the coldness of [a Jane Fairfax!—Harriet]240-a jane fairfax!—harriet is worth a hundred such — And for [a wife]3164-a wife — [[a sensible man]684-a sensible man ’s wife]4523-a sensible man ’s wife — it is invaluable . [I]79-emma mention no names ; but happy [the man who changes [Emma]79-emma for [Harriet]107-harriet]4524-the man who changes emma for harriet ! ”[79-emma] CHAPTER XIV [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton was first seen at [church]3288-church : but though devotion might be interrupted , curiosity could not be satisfied by [a bride]2094-a bride in a pew , and it must be left for the visits in form which were then to be paid , to settle whether [she]2094-a bride were very pretty indeed , or only rather pretty , or not pretty at all . [Emma]79-emma had feelings , less of curiosity than of pride or propriety , to make [her]79-emma resolve on not being the last to pay [her]79-emma respects ; and [she]79-emma made a point of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s going with [her]79-emma , that the worst of the business might be gone through as soon as possible . [She]79-emma could not enter [the house]425-the house again , could not be in [the same room to which [she]79-emma had with such vain artifice retreated three months ago , to lace up [her]79-emma boot]2096-the same room to which she had with such vain artifice retreated three months ago , to lace up her boot , without recollecting . A thousand vexatious thoughts would recur . Compliments , charades , and horrible blunders ; and it was not to be supposed that [poor Harriet]107-harriet should not be recollecting too ; but [she]107-harriet behaved very well , and was only rather pale and silent . The visit was of course short ; and there was so much embarrassment and occupation of mind to shorten it , that [Emma]79-emma would not allow [herself]79-emma entirely to form an opinion of [the lady]774-the lady , and on no account to give one , beyond the nothing - meaning terms of being “ elegantly dressed , and very pleasing . ”[79-emma] [She]79-emma did not really like [her]774-the lady . [She]79-emma would not be in a hurry to find fault , but [she]79-emma suspected that there was no elegance;—ease , but not elegance . — [She]79-emma was almost sure that for [a young woman]1346-a young woman , [a stranger]4105-a stranger , [a bride]2094-a bride , there was too much ease . [Her]774-the lady person was rather good ; [her]774-the lady face not unpretty ; but neither feature , nor air , nor voice , nor manner , were elegant . [Emma]79-emma thought at least it would turn out so . As for [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [his]91-mr. elton manners did not appear — but no , [she]79-emma would not permit a hasty or a witty word from [herself]79-emma about [his]91-mr. elton manners . It was an awkward ceremony at any time to be receiving wedding visits , and [a man]548-a man had need be all grace to acquit [himself]548-a man well through it . [The woman]2102-the woman was better off ; [she]2102-the woman might have the assistance of fine clothes , and the privilege of bashfulness , but [the man]758-the man had only [his]758-the man own good sense to depend on ; and when [she]79-emma considered how peculiarly unlucky poor [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was in being in [the same room]4175-the same room at once with [the woman [he]91-mr. elton had just married]2105-the woman he had just married , [the woman [he]91-mr. elton had wanted to marry]2106-the woman he had wanted to marry , and [the woman whom [he]91-mr. elton had been expected to marry]2107-the woman whom he had been expected to marry , [she]79-emma must allow [him]91-mr. elton to have the right to look as little wise , and to be as much affectedly , and as little really easy as could be . “ Well , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , ”[107-harriet] said [Harriet]107-harriet , when [they]2108-they had quitted [the house]425-the house , and after waiting in vain for [[her]107-harriet friend]417-her friend to begin ; “ Well , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , ( with a gentle sigh , ) what do [you]90-hartfield think of her?—Is not [she]2105-the woman he had just married very charming ? ”[107-harriet] There was a little hesitation in [Emma]79-emma ’s answer . “ Oh ! yes — very — [a very pleasing young woman]4525-a very pleasing young woman . ”[107-harriet] “ [I]107-harriet think [her]2105-the woman he had just married beautiful , quite beautiful . ”[107-harriet] “ Very nicely dressed , indeed ; a remarkably elegant gown . ”[107-harriet] “ [I]107-harriet am not at all surprized that [he]91-mr. elton should have fallen in love . ”[107-harriet] “ Oh ! no — there is nothing to surprize one at all.—A pretty fortune ; and [she]2105-the woman he had just married came in [his]91-mr. elton way . ”[107-harriet] “ [I]107-harriet dare say , ”[107-harriet] returned [Harriet]107-harriet , sighing again , “ [I]107-harriet dare say [she]2105-the woman he had just married was very much attached to [him]91-mr. elton . ”[107-harriet] “ Perhaps [she]2105-the woman he had just married might ; but it is not [every man]834-every man ’s fate to marry [the woman who loves [him]834-every man best]4527-the woman who loves him best . [Miss Hawkins]187-miss hawkins perhaps wanted [a home]4528-a home , and thought this the best offer [she]187-miss hawkins was likely to have . ”[107-harriet] “ Yes , ”[107-harriet] said [Harriet]107-harriet earnestly , “ and well [she]2105-the woman he had just married might , [nobody]3124-nobody could ever have a better . Well , [I]107-harriet wish [them]4530-them happy with all [my]107-harriet heart . And now , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [I]107-harriet do not think [I]107-harriet shall mind seeing [them]4530-them again . [He]91-mr. elton is just as superior as ever;—but being married , [you]90-hartfield know , it is quite a different thing . No , indeed , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [you]90-hartfield need not be afraid ; [I]107-harriet can sit and admire [him]91-mr. elton now without any great misery . To know that [he]91-mr. elton has not thrown [himself]91-mr. elton away , is such a comfort!—She does seem [a charming young woman]4531-a charming young woman , just what [he]91-mr. elton deserves . [Happy creature]4532-happy creature ! [He]91-mr. elton called [her]4532-happy creature ‘ [Augusta]192-augusta . ’ How delightful ! ”[107-harriet] When the visit was returned , [Emma]79-emma made up [her]79-emma mind . [She]79-emma could then see more and judge better . From [Harriet]107-harriet ’s happening not to be at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , and [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father ’s being present to engage [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , [she]107-harriet had a quarter of an hour of [the lady]774-the lady ’s conversation to [herself]107-harriet , and could composedly attend to [her]774-the lady ; and the quarter of an hour quite convinced [her]107-harriet that [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton was [a vain woman]2113-a vain woman , extremely well satisfied with [herself]195-mrs. elton , and thinking much of [her]195-mrs. elton own importance ; that [she]195-mrs. elton meant to shine and be very superior , but with manners which had been formed in a bad school , pert and familiar ; that all [her]195-mrs. elton notions were drawn from one set of [people]704-people , and one style of living ; that if not foolish [she]195-mrs. elton was ignorant , and that [[her]195-mrs. elton society]2115-her society would certainly do [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton no good . [Harriet]107-harriet would have been a better match . If not wise or refined [herself]107-harriet , [she]107-harriet would have connected [him]91-mr. elton with [those who were]2116-those who were ; but [Miss Hawkins]187-miss hawkins , it might be fairly supposed from [her]187-miss hawkins easy conceit , had been the best of [her]187-miss hawkins own set . [The rich brother - in - law near [Bristol]43-bristol]2117-the rich brother - in - law near bristol was [the pride of [the alliance]2119-the alliance]2118-the pride of the alliance , and [his]2117-the rich brother - in - law near bristol place and [[his]2117-the rich brother - in - law near bristol carriages]2120-his carriages were the pride of [him]2117-the rich brother - in - law near bristol . The very first subject after being seated was [Maple Grove]53-maple grove , “ [[My]195-mrs. elton brother]648-my brother [Mr. Suckling]241-mr. suckling ’s seat;”—a[195-mrs. elton] comparison of [Hartfield]90-hartfield to [Maple Grove]53-maple grove . [The grounds of [Hartfield]90-hartfield]2121-the grounds of hartfield were small , but neat and pretty ; and [the house]425-the house was modern and well - built . [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton seemed most favourably impressed by the size of [the room]3386-the room , the entrance , and all that [she]195-mrs. elton could see or imagine . “ Very like [Maple Grove]53-maple grove indeed!—She was quite struck by [the likeness!—That room]4534-the likeness!—that room was the very shape and size of [the morning - room at [Maple Grove]53-maple grove]4535-the morning - room at maple grove ; [[[her]195-mrs. elton sister]396-her sister ’s favourite room]4537-her sister ’s favourite room . ”—Mr[195-mrs. elton] . [Elton]195-mrs. elton was appealed to.—“Was not it astonishingly like?—She could really almost fancy [herself]195-mrs. elton at [Maple Grove]53-maple grove . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ And the staircase — [You]195-mrs. elton know , as [I]79-emma came in , [I]79-emma observed how very like the staircase was ; placed exactly in the same part of [the house]425-the house . [I]79-emma really could not help exclaiming ! [I]79-emma assure [you]195-mrs. elton , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , it is very delightful to [me]79-emma , to be reminded of [a place [I]79-emma am so extremely partial to as [Maple Grove]53-maple grove]4539-a place i am so extremely partial to as maple grove . [I]79-emma have spent so many happy months there ! ( with a little sigh of sentiment ) . [A charming place]4540-a charming place , undoubtedly . [Every body who sees it]4541-every body who sees it is struck by its beauty ; but to [me]79-emma , [it]4540-a charming place has been quite [a home]4528-a home . Whenever [you]195-mrs. elton are transplanted , like [me]79-emma , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [you]195-mrs. elton will understand how very delightful it is to meet with any thing at all like what [one]475-one has left behind . [I]79-emma always say this is quite one of the evils of matrimony . ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma made as slight a reply as [she]79-emma could ; but it was fully sufficient for [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , who only wanted to be talking [herself]195-mrs. elton . “ So extremely like [Maple Grove]53-maple grove ! And it is not merely [the house]425-the house — [the grounds]4545-the grounds , [I]195-mrs. elton assure [you]195-mrs. elton , as far as [I]195-mrs. elton could observe , are strikingly like . The laurels at [Maple Grove]53-maple grove are in the same profusion as here , and stand very much in the same way — just across [the lawn]4546-the lawn ; and [I]195-mrs. elton had a glimpse of a fine large tree , with a bench round it , which put [me]195-mrs. elton so exactly in mind ! [[My]195-mrs. elton brother]648-my brother and [sister]977-sister will be enchanted with [this place]4549-this place . [People who have [extensive grounds]4551-extensive grounds [themselves]2124-people who had extensive grounds themselves]4550-people who have extensive grounds themselves are always pleased with any thing in the same style . ”[195-mrs. elton] [Emma]79-emma doubted the truth of this sentiment . [She]79-emma had a great idea that [people who had [extensive grounds]4551-extensive grounds [themselves]2124-people who had extensive grounds themselves]2124-people who had extensive grounds themselves cared very little for the extensive grounds of any body else ; but it was not worth while to attack an error so double - dyed , and therefore only said in reply , “ When [you]195-mrs. elton have seen more of [this country]531-this country , [I]79-emma am afraid [you]195-mrs. elton will think [you]195-mrs. elton have overrated [Hartfield]90-hartfield . [Surry]24-surry is full of beauties . ”[79-emma] “ Oh ! yes , [I]195-mrs. elton am quite aware of that . It is [the garden of [England]38-england]4553-the garden of england , [you]195-mrs. elton know . [Surry]24-surry is [the garden of [England]38-england]4553-the garden of england . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ Yes ; but [we]4555-we must not rest [our]4555-we claims on that distinction . [Many counties]4556-many counties , [I]195-mrs. elton believe , are called [the garden of [England]38-england]4553-the garden of england , as well as [Surry]24-surry . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ No , [I]195-mrs. elton fancy not , ”[195-mrs. elton] replied [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , with a most satisfied smile . “ [I]195-mrs. elton never heard [any county]4558-any county but [Surry]24-surry called so . ”[195-mrs. elton] [Emma]79-emma was silenced . “ [[My]195-mrs. elton brother]648-my brother and [sister]977-sister have promised [us]4555-we a visit in the spring , or summer at farthest , ”[195-mrs. elton] continued [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ; “ and that will be [our]4555-we time for exploring . While [they]4561-their are with [us]4555-we , [we]4555-we shall explore a great deal , [I]195-mrs. elton dare say . [They]4561-their will have [[their]4561-their barouche - landau]4562-their barouche - landau , of course , which holds four perfectly ; and therefore , without saying any thing of [our]4555-we carriage , [we]4555-we should be able to explore the different beauties extremely well . [They]4561-their would hardly come in [their]4561-their chaise , [I]195-mrs. elton think , at that season of the year . Indeed , when the time draws on , [I]195-mrs. elton shall decidedly recommend [their]4561-their bringing [the barouche - landau]4563-the barouche - landau ; it will be so very much preferable . When [people]704-people come into [a beautiful country of this sort]4565-a beautiful country of this sort , [you]4566-you know , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [one]475-one naturally wishes [them]704-people to see as much as possible ; and [Mr. Suckling]241-mr. suckling is extremely fond of exploring . [We]4555-we explored to [King’s - Weston]55-king’s - weston twice last summer , in that way , most delightfully , just after [their]4561-their first having [the barouche - landau]4563-the barouche - landau . [You]90-hartfield have many parties of that kind here , [I]195-mrs. elton suppose , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , every summer ? ”[195-mrs. elton] “ No ; not immediately here . [We]4555-we are rather out of distance of the very striking beauties which attract the sort of parties [you]4566-you speak of ; and [we]4555-we are [a very quiet set of people]4569-a very quiet set of people , [I]195-mrs. elton believe ; more disposed to stay at [home]3258-home than engage in schemes of pleasure . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ Ah ! there is nothing like staying at [home]3258-home for real comfort . [Nobody]3124-nobody can be more devoted to [home]3258-home than [I]195-mrs. elton am . [I]195-mrs. elton was quite a proverb for it at [Maple Grove]53-maple grove . Many a time has [Selina]242-selina said , when [she]242-selina has been going to [Bristol]43-bristol , ‘ [I]195-mrs. elton really can not get [this girl]3843-this girl to move from [the house]425-the house . [I]195-mrs. elton absolutely must go in by [myself]195-mrs. elton , though [I]195-mrs. elton hate being stuck up in [the barouche - landau]4563-the barouche - landau without [a companion]569-a companion ; but [Augusta]192-augusta , [I]195-mrs. elton believe , with [her]192-augusta own good - will , would never stir beyond [the park paling]4578-the park paling . ’ Many a time has [she]192-augusta said so ; and yet [I]195-mrs. elton am no advocate for entire seclusion . [I]195-mrs. elton think , on the contrary , when [people]704-people shut [themselves]704-people up entirely from [society]4580-society , it is a very bad thing ; and that it is much more advisable to mix in [the world]392-the world in a proper degree , without living in it either too much or too little . [I]195-mrs. elton perfectly understand [your]195-mrs. elton situation , however , [Miss Woodhouse—(looking]4582-miss woodhouse—(looking towards [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ) , [[Your]195-mrs. elton father]1389-your father ’s state of health must be a great drawback . [I]195-mrs. elton assure [you]195-mrs. elton [I]195-mrs. elton have no doubt of its doing [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse good . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ [[My]195-mrs. elton father]3146-my father tried it more than once , formerly ; but without receiving any benefit ; and [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry , whose name , [I]195-mrs. elton dare say , is not unknown to [you]195-mrs. elton , does not conceive it would be at all more likely to be useful now . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ Ah ! that ’s a great pity ; for [I]195-mrs. elton assure [you]195-mrs. elton , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , where the waters do agree , it is quite wonderful the relief [they]4586-they give . In [my]195-mrs. elton Bath life , [I]195-mrs. elton have seen such instances of it ! And it is so cheerful a place , that it could not fail of being of use to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s spirits , which , [I]195-mrs. elton understand , are sometimes much depressed . And as to its recommendations to [you]195-mrs. elton , [I]195-mrs. elton fancy [I]195-mrs. elton need not take much pains to dwell on them . The advantages of [Bath]32-bath to [the young]4587-the young are pretty generally understood . [I]195-mrs. elton am doatingly fond of music — passionately fond;—and [[my]195-mrs. elton friends]629-my friends say [I]195-mrs. elton am not entirely devoid of taste ; but as to any thing else , upon [my]195-mrs. elton honour [my]195-mrs. elton performance is mediocre to the last degree . [You]195-mrs. elton , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [I]195-mrs. elton well know , play delightfully . [I]195-mrs. elton assure [you]195-mrs. elton it has been the greatest satisfaction , comfort , and delight to [me]195-mrs. elton , to hear what a musical society [I]195-mrs. elton am got into . [I]195-mrs. elton absolutely can not do without music . It is a necessary of life to [me]195-mrs. elton ; and having always been used to a very musical society , both at [Maple Grove]53-maple grove and in [Bath]32-bath , it would have been a most serious sacrifice . [I]195-mrs. elton honestly said as much to [Mr. E.]245-mr. e. when [he]245-mr. e. was speaking of [[my]195-mrs. elton future [home]3258-home]4599-my future home , and expressing [his]245-mr. e. fears lest the retirement of it should be disagreeable ; and the inferiority of [the house]425-the house too — knowing what [I]195-mrs. elton had been accustomed to — of course [he]245-mr. e. was not wholly without apprehension . When [he]245-mr. e. was speaking of it in that way , [I]195-mrs. elton honestly said that [the world]392-the world [I]195-mrs. elton could give up — parties , balls , plays — for [I]195-mrs. elton had no fear of retirement . Blessed with so many resources within [myself]195-mrs. elton , [the world]392-the world was not necessary to [me]195-mrs. elton . [I]195-mrs. elton could do very well without it . To [those who had no resources it]4604-those who had no resources it was a different thing ; but [my]195-mrs. elton resources made [me]195-mrs. elton quite independent . And as to [smaller - sized rooms than [I]195-mrs. elton had been used to]4605-smaller - sized rooms than i had been used to , [I]195-mrs. elton really could not give it a thought . [Her]79-emma mind returned to [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s offences , and long , very long , did [they]2134-they occupy [her]79-emma . [CHAPTER XV Emma]254-emma was not required , by any subsequent discovery , to retract [her]79-emma ill opinion of [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton . [Her]79-emma observation had been pretty correct . Such as [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton appeared to [her]79-emma on this second interview , such [she]195-mrs. elton appeared whenever [they]2135-they met again,—self - important , presuming , familiar , ignorant , and ill - bred . [She]195-mrs. elton had a little beauty and a little accomplishment , but so little judgment that [she]195-mrs. elton thought [herself]195-mrs. elton coming with superior knowledge of [the world]392-the world , to enliven and improve [a country neighbourhood]2137-a country neighbourhood ; and conceived [Miss Hawkins]187-miss hawkins to have held such a place in [society]4580-society as [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s consequence only could surpass . There was no reason to suppose [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton thought at all differently from [[his]91-mr. elton wife]3168-his wife . [He]91-mr. elton seemed not merely happy with [her]3168-his wife , but proud . [He]91-mr. elton had the air of congratulating [himself]91-mr. elton on having brought [such a woman]2140-such a woman to [Highbury]3-highbury , as not even [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor could equal ; and the greater part of [[her]3168-his wife new acquaintance]2141-her new acquaintance , disposed to commend , or not in the habit of judging , following the lead of [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ’s good - will , or taking it for granted that [the bride]2142-the bride must be as clever and as agreeable as [she]2142-the bride professed [herself]2142-the bride , were very well satisfied ; so that [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s praise passed from one mouth to another as it ought to do , unimpeded by [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , who readily continued [her]80-miss taylor first contribution and talked with a good grace of [her]80-miss taylor being “ very pleasant and very elegantly dressed . ”[80-miss taylor] In one respect [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton grew even worse than [she]195-mrs. elton had appeared at first . [Her]195-mrs. elton feelings altered towards [Emma.—Offended]255-emma.—offended , probably , by the little encouragement which [her]195-mrs. elton proposals of intimacy met with , [she]195-mrs. elton drew back in [her]195-mrs. elton turn and gradually became much more cold and distant ; and though the effect was agreeable , the ill - will which produced it was necessarily increasing [Emma]254-emma ’s dislike . [Her]195-mrs. elton manners , too — and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s , were unpleasant towards [Harriet]107-harriet . [They]2143-they were sneering and negligent . [Emma]254-emma hoped it must rapidly work [Harriet]107-harriet ’s cure ; but the sensations which could prompt such behaviour sunk [them]2143-they both very much.—It was not to be doubted that poor [Harriet]107-harriet ’s attachment had been an offering to conjugal unreserve , and [her]107-harriet own share in the story , under a colouring the least favourable to [her]107-harriet and the most soothing to [him]91-mr. elton , had in all likelihood been given also . [She]107-harriet was , of course , the object of [their]2143-they joint dislike.—When [they]2143-they had nothing else to say , it must be always easy to begin abusing [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor ; and the enmity which [they]2143-they dared not shew in open disrespect to [her]107-harriet , found a broader vent in contemptuous treatment of [Harriet]107-harriet . [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton took a great fancy to [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ; and from the first . Not merely when a state of warfare with [one young lady]2144-one young lady might be supposed to recommend [the other]3423-the other , but from the very first ; and [she]142-miss fairfax was not satisfied with expressing a natural and reasonable admiration — but without solicitation , or plea , or privilege , [she]142-miss fairfax must be wanting to assist and befriend her.—Before [Emma]254-emma had forfeited [her]254-emma confidence , and about the third time of [their]2143-they meeting , [she]254-emma heard all [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s knight - errantry on the subject . — “ [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax is absolutely charming , [Miss Woodhouse.—I]4678-miss woodhouse.—i quite rave about [Jane Fairfax.—A]256-jane fairfax.—a sweet , interesting creature . [I]195-mrs. elton do not scruple to say that [she]142-miss fairfax plays extremely well . [I]195-mrs. elton know enough of music to speak decidedly on that point . Oh ! [We]4680-we must bring [her]142-miss fairfax forward . [You]80-miss taylor and [I]195-mrs. elton need not be afraid . If [we]4690-we set the example , [many]3239-many will follow it as far as [they]3239-many can ; though all have not [our]4690-we situations . [We]4690-we have carriages to fetch and convey [her]142-miss fairfax [home]3258-home , and [we]4690-we live in a style which could not make the addition of [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , at any time , the least inconvenient.—I should be extremely displeased if [Wright]258-wright were to send [us]4690-we up such a dinner , as could make [me]195-mrs. elton regret having asked more than [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax to partake of it . [I]195-mrs. elton have no idea of that sort of thing . It is not likely that [I]195-mrs. elton should , considering what [I]195-mrs. elton have been used to . [My]195-mrs. elton greatest danger , perhaps , in housekeeping , may be quite the other way , in doing too much , and being too careless of expense . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , [your]84-mrs. weston argument weighs most with [me]79-emma . [I]79-emma can much more readily enter into the temptation of getting away from [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , than [I]79-emma can believe in the triumph of [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s mind over [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton . [I]79-emma have no faith in [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s acknowledging [herself]195-mrs. elton the inferior in thought , word , or deed ; or in [her]195-mrs. elton being under any restraint beyond [her]195-mrs. elton own scanty rule of good - breeding . [I]79-emma can not imagine that [she]195-mrs. elton will not be continually insulting [[her]195-mrs. elton visitor]2064-her visitor with praise , encouragement , and offers of service ; that [she]195-mrs. elton will not be continually detailing [her]195-mrs. elton magnificent intentions , from the procuring [her]195-mrs. elton a permanent situation to the including [her]195-mrs. elton in those delightful exploring parties which are to take place in [the barouche - landau]4563-the barouche - landau . ”[79-emma] “ [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax has feeling , ”[263-mr. knightley—“i] said [Mr. Knightley—“I]263-mr. knightley—“i do not accuse [her]142-miss fairfax of want of feeling . [Her]142-miss fairfax sensibilities , [I]79-emma suspect , are strong — and [her]142-miss fairfax temper excellent in its power of forbearance , patience , self - control ; but it wants openness . [She]142-miss fairfax is reserved , more reserved , [I]79-emma think , than [she]142-miss fairfax used to be — And [I]79-emma love an open temper . No — till [Cole]135-mr. cole alluded to [my]79-emma supposed attachment , it had never entered [my]79-emma head . [I]79-emma saw [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and conversed with [her]142-miss fairfax , with admiration and pleasure always — but with no thought beyond . ”[79-emma] “ Well , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma triumphantly when [he]2163-he left [them]2164-them , “ what do [you]84-mrs. weston say now to [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s marrying [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ? ”[79-emma] “ Why , really , [dear Emma]79-emma , [I]79-emma say that [he]91-mr. elton is so very much occupied by the idea of not being in love with [her]142-miss fairfax , that [I]79-emma should not wonder if it were to end in [his]91-mr. elton being so at last . Do not beat [me]79-emma . ”[79-emma] CHAPTER XVI [Every body in and about [Highbury]3-highbury who had ever visited [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ,]2165-every body in and about highbury who had ever visited mr. elton , was disposed to pay [him]91-mr. elton attention on [his]91-mr. elton marriage . Dinner - parties and evening - parties were made for [him]91-mr. elton and [[his]91-mr. elton lady]2166-his lady ; and invitations flowed in so fast that [she]2166-his lady had soon the pleasure of apprehending [they]2164-them were never to have a disengaged day . “ [I]2166-his lady see how it is , ”[2166-his lady] said [she]2166-his lady . “ [I]2166-his lady see what a life [I]2166-his lady am to lead among [you]91-mr. elton . Upon [my]2166-his lady word [we]4730-we shall be absolutely dissipated . [We]4730-we really seem quite the fashion . If this is living in [the country]3306-the country , it is nothing very formidable . From Monday next to Saturday , [I]2166-his lady assure [you]91-mr. elton [we]4730-we have not [a disengaged day!—A woman with fewer resources than [I]2166-his lady have]4732-a disengaged day!—a woman with fewer resources than i have , need not have been at a loss . ”[2166-his lady] No invitation came amiss to [her]2166-his lady . [Her]2166-his lady Bath habits made evening - parties perfectly natural to [her]2166-his lady , and [Maple Grove]53-maple grove had given [her]2166-his lady a taste for dinners . [She]2166-his lady was a little shocked at the want of [two drawing rooms]2167-two drawing rooms , at the poor attempt at rout - cakes , and there being no ice in the [Highbury]3-highbury card - parties . [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates , [Mrs. Perry]100-mrs. perry , [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard and [others]473-others , were a good deal behind - hand in knowledge of [the world]392-the world , but [she]2166-his lady would soon shew [them]2170-their how every thing ought to be arranged . In the course of the spring [she]2166-his lady must return [their]2170-their civilities by one very superior party — in which [her]2166-his lady card - tables should be set out with [their]2170-their separate candles and unbroken packs in the true style — and more waiters engaged for the evening than [[their]2170-their own establishment]2171-their own establishment could furnish , to carry round the refreshments at exactly the proper hour , and in the proper order . [Emma]79-emma , in the meanwhile , could not be satisfied without a dinner at [Hartfield]90-hartfield for [the Eltons]134-the eltons . [They]2170-their must not do less than [others]473-others , or [she]79-emma should be exposed to odious suspicions , and imagined capable of pitiful resentment . A dinner there must be . After [Emma]79-emma had talked about it for ten minutes , [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse felt no unwillingness , and only made the usual stipulation of not sitting at the bottom of the table [himself]81-mr. woodhouse , with the usual regular difficulty of deciding who should do it for [him]81-mr. woodhouse . [The persons to be invited]2173-the persons to be invited , required little thought . Besides [the Eltons]134-the eltons , it must be [the Westons]104-the westons and [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ; so far it was all of course — and it was hardly less inevitable that [poor little Harriet]107-harriet must be asked to make the eighth:—but this invitation was not given with equal satisfaction , and on many accounts [Emma]79-emma was particularly pleased by [Harriet]107-harriet ’s begging to be allowed to decline it . “ [She]107-harriet would rather not be in [his]81-mr. woodhouse company more than [she]107-harriet could help . [She]107-harriet was not yet quite able to see [him]81-mr. woodhouse and [[his]81-mr. woodhouse charming happy wife]4733-his charming happy wife together , without feeling uncomfortable . [She]79-emma was delighted with the fortitude of [[her]79-emma little friend]3440-her little friend — for fortitude [she]79-emma knew it was in [her]79-emma to give up being in company and stay at [home]3258-home ; and [she]79-emma could now invite [the very person whom [she]79-emma really wanted to make the eighth , [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax]2176-the very person whom she really wanted to make the eighth , jane fairfax . — Since [her]79-emma last conversation with [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston and [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , [she]79-emma was more conscience - stricken about [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax than [she]79-emma had often been.—Mr .
