[He]88-mr. knightley had said that [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax received attentions from [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton which [nobody else]1495-nobody else paid [her]142-miss fairfax . “ This is very true , ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma , “ at least as far as relates to [me]79-emma , which was all that was meant — and it is very shameful.—Of the same age — and always knowing [her]142-miss fairfax — [I]79-emma ought to have been more [her]142-miss fairfax friend.—She will never like [me]79-emma now . [I]79-emma have neglected [her]142-miss fairfax too long . But [I]79-emma will shew [her]142-miss fairfax greater attention than [I]79-emma have done . ”[79-emma] Every invitation was successful . [They]2178-them were all disengaged and all happy.—The preparatory interest of this dinner , however , was not yet over . A circumstance rather unlucky occurred . [The two eldest little Knightleys]141-the mr. knightleys were engaged to pay [[their]2178-them grandpapa]2179-their grandpapa and [aunt]1419-aunt a visit of some weeks in the spring , and [[their]2178-them papa]2181-their papa now proposed bringing [them]2178-them , and staying one whole day at [Hartfield]90-hartfield — which one day would be the very day of this party.—His professional engagements did not allow of [his]2181-their papa being put off , but both [father]1574-father and [daughter]3344-daughter were disturbed by its happening so . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse considered [eight persons at dinner together]2184-eight persons at dinner together as the utmost that [his]81-mr. woodhouse nerves could bear — and here would be a ninth — and [Emma]79-emma apprehended that it would be a ninth very much out of humour at not being able to come even to [Hartfield]90-hartfield for forty - eight hours without falling in with a dinner - party . [She]79-emma comforted [[her]79-emma father]415-her father better than [she]79-emma could comfort [herself]79-emma , by representing that though [he]415-her father certainly would make [them]2178-them nine , yet [he]415-her father always said so little , that the increase of noise would be very immaterial . [She]79-emma thought it in reality a sad exchange for [herself]79-emma , to have [him]415-her father with [his]415-her father grave looks and reluctant conversation opposed to [her]79-emma instead of [[his]415-her father brother]3468-his brother . The event was more favourable to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse than to [Emma]79-emma . [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley came ; but [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was unexpectedly summoned to [town]3165-town and must be absent on the very day . [He]82-mr. weston might be able to join [them]2178-them in the evening , but certainly not to dinner . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was quite at ease ; and the seeing [him]415-her father so , with the arrival of [the little boys]2188-the little boys and the philosophic composure of [[her]79-emma brother]3179-her brother on hearing [his]3179-her brother fate , removed the chief of even [Emma]79-emma ’s vexation . The day came , [the party]3632-the party were punctually assembled , and [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley seemed early to devote [himself]88-mr. knightley to the business of being agreeable . Instead of drawing [[his]88-mr. knightley brother]3468-his brother off to a window while [they]2178-them waited for dinner , [he]88-mr. knightley was talking to [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , as elegant as lace and pearls could make [her]195-mrs. elton , [he]88-mr. knightley looked at in silence — wanting only to observe enough for [Isabella]83-isabella ’s information — but [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax was [an old acquaintance]4330-an old acquaintance and [a quiet girl]2193-a quiet girl , and [he]88-mr. knightley could talk to [her]142-miss fairfax . [He]88-mr. knightley had met [her]142-miss fairfax before breakfast as [he]88-mr. knightley was returning from a walk with [[his]88-mr. knightley little boys]2194-his little boys , when it had been just beginning to rain . It was natural to have some civil hopes on the subject , and [he]88-mr. knightley said , “ [I]88-mr. knightley hope [you]142-miss fairfax did not venture far , [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , this morning , or [I]88-mr. knightley am sure [you]142-miss fairfax must have been wet.—We scarcely got [home]3258-home in time . [I]88-mr. knightley hope [you]142-miss fairfax turned directly . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [I]142-miss fairfax went only to [the post - office]4736-the post - office , ”[142-miss fairfax] said [she]142-miss fairfax , “ and reached [home]3258-home before the rain was much . It is [my]142-miss fairfax daily errand . [I]142-miss fairfax always fetch the letters when [I]142-miss fairfax am [here]3113-here . It saves trouble , and is a something to get [me]142-miss fairfax out . A walk before breakfast does [me]142-miss fairfax good . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ Not a walk in the rain , [I]88-mr. knightley should imagine . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ No , but it did not absolutely rain when [I]142-miss fairfax set out . ”[142-miss fairfax] [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley smiled , and replied , “ That is to say , [you]142-miss fairfax chose to have [your]142-miss fairfax walk , for [you]142-miss fairfax were not six yards from [your]142-miss fairfax own door when [I]88-mr. knightley had the pleasure of meeting [you]142-miss fairfax ; and [Henry]118-henry and [John]88-mr. knightley had seen more drops than [they]4739-they could count long before . [The post - office]4736-the post - office has a great charm at one period of [our]4741-our lives . When [you]142-miss fairfax have lived to [my]88-mr. knightley age , [you]142-miss fairfax will begin to think letters are never worth going through the rain for . ”[88-mr. knightley] There was a little blush , and then this answer , “ [I]88-mr. knightley must not hope to be ever situated as [you]142-miss fairfax are , in the midst of every dearest connexion , and therefore [I]88-mr. knightley can not expect that simply growing older should make [me]88-mr. knightley indifferent about letters . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Indifferent ! Oh ! no — [I]88-mr. knightley never conceived [you]142-miss fairfax could become indifferent . Letters are no matter of indifference ; they are generally a very positive curse . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [You]2195-you are speaking of letters of business ; mine are letters of friendship . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [I]2195-you have often thought them the worst of the two , ”[2195-you] replied [he]2195-you coolly . “ Business , [you]2195-you know , may bring money , but friendship hardly ever does . ”[2195-you] “ Ah ! [you]2195-you are not serious now . [I]88-mr. knightley know [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley too well — [I]88-mr. knightley am very sure [he]88-mr. knightley understands the value of friendship as well as [any body]530-any body . [I]88-mr. knightley can easily believe that letters are very little to [you]142-miss fairfax , much less than to [me]88-mr. knightley , but it is not [your]142-miss fairfax being ten years older than [myself]88-mr. knightley which makes the difference , it is not age , but situation . [You]142-miss fairfax have every body dearest to [you]142-miss fairfax always at hand , [I]88-mr. knightley , probably , never shall again ; and therefore till [I]88-mr. knightley have outlived all [my]88-mr. knightley affections , a post - office , [I]88-mr. knightley think , must always have power to draw [me]88-mr. knightley out , in worse weather than to - day . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ When [I]88-mr. knightley talked of [your]142-miss fairfax being altered by time , by the progress of years , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley , “ [I]88-mr. knightley meant to imply the change of situation which time usually brings . If [one]475-one thinks of all that it has to do , and all that it does so well , it is really astonishing ! ”[142-miss fairfax] “ It is certainly very well regulated . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ So seldom that any negligence or blunder appears ! So seldom that a letter , among the thousands that are constantly passing about [the kingdom]1435-the kingdom , is even carried wrong — and not one in a million , [I]142-miss fairfax suppose , actually lost ! And when one considers the variety of hands , and of bad hands too , that are to be deciphered , it increases the wonder . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ [The clerks]4781-the clerks grow expert from habit.—They must begin with some quickness of sight and hand , and exercise improves [them]4781-the clerks . If [you]3120-my dear want any farther explanation , ”[88-mr. knightley] continued [he]88-mr. knightley , smiling , “ [they]4781-the clerks are paid for it . That is the key to a great deal of capacity . [The public]4782-the public pays and must be served well . ”[88-mr. knightley] The varieties of handwriting were farther talked of , and the usual observations made . “ [I]88-mr. knightley have heard it asserted , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley , “ that the same sort of handwriting often prevails in [a family]1439-a family ; and where [the same master]4784-the same master teaches , it is natural enough . But for that reason , [I]88-mr. knightley should imagine the likeness must be chiefly confined to [the females]4785-the females , for [boys]1041-boys have very little teaching after an early age , and scramble into any hand [they]1041-boys can get . [Isabella]83-isabella and [Emma]79-emma , [I]88-mr. knightley think , do write very much alike . [I]84-mrs. weston certainly get better and better.—Now for it . ”[84-mrs. weston] [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was disengaged and [Emma]79-emma began again—“Mr . [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill writes one of the best gentleman ’s hands [I]79-emma ever saw . ”[79-emma] “ [I]88-mr. knightley do not admire it , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . “ It is too small — wants strength . It is like [a woman]3207-a woman ’s writing . ”[88-mr. knightley] This was not submitted to by [either lady]2205-either lady . [They]2206-they vindicated [him]88-mr. knightley against the base aspersion . “ No , it by no means wanted strength — it was not a large hand , but very clear and certainly strong . Had not [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston any letter about [her]84-mrs. weston to produce ? ”[2206-they] No , [she]79-emma had heard from [him]88-mr. knightley very lately , but having answered the letter , had put it away . “ If [we]4793-we were in [the other room]1314-the other room , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , “ if [I]79-emma had [my]79-emma writing - desk , [I]79-emma am sure [I]79-emma could produce a specimen . [I]79-emma have a note of his.—Do not [you]84-mrs. weston remember , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , employing [him]88-mr. knightley to write for [you]84-mrs. weston one day ? ”[79-emma] “ [He]88-mr. knightley chose to say [he]88-mr. knightley was employed ”[2206-they] — “ Well , well , [I]2206-they have that note ; and can shew it after dinner to convince [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . ”[2206-they] “ Oh ! when [a gallant young man]4795-a gallant young man , like [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley dryly , “ writes to [a fair lady]4796-a fair lady like [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , [he]4795-a gallant young man will , of course , put forth [his]4795-a gallant young man best . ”[88-mr. knightley] Dinner was on table.—Mrs . [Elton]195-mrs. elton , before [she]195-mrs. elton could be spoken to , was ready ; and before [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse had reached [her]195-mrs. elton with [his]81-mr. woodhouse request to be allowed to hand [her]195-mrs. elton into [the dining - parlour]2207-the dining - parlour , was saying — “ Must [I]81-mr. woodhouse go first ? [I]81-mr. woodhouse really am ashamed of always leading the way . ”[81-mr. woodhouse] [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s solicitude about fetching [her]142-miss fairfax own letters had not escaped [Emma]79-emma . [She]79-emma had heard and seen it all ; and felt some curiosity to know whether the wet walk of this morning had produced any . [She]79-emma suspected that it had ; that it would not have been so resolutely encountered but in full expectation of hearing from [some one very dear]2208-some one very dear , and that it had not been in vain . [She]79-emma thought there was an air of greater happiness than usual — a glow both of complexion and spirits . [She]79-emma could have made an inquiry or two , as to the expedition and the expense of the Irish mails;—it was at [her]79-emma tongue ’s end — but [she]79-emma abstained . [She]79-emma was quite determined not to utter a word that should hurt [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s feelings ; and [they]2209-i followed [the other ladies]1870-the other ladies out of [the room]3386-the room , arm in arm , with an appearance of good - will highly becoming to the beauty and grace of each . CHAPTER XVII When [the ladies]3323-the ladies returned to [the drawing - room]1313-the drawing - room after dinner , [Emma]79-emma found it hardly possible to prevent [their]2209-i making two distinct parties;—with so much perseverance in judging and behaving ill did [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton engross [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and slight [herself]195-mrs. elton . [She]195-mrs. elton and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston were obliged to be almost always either talking together or silent together . [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton left [them]2209-i no choice . If [Jane]142-miss fairfax repressed [her]195-mrs. elton for a little time , [she]195-mrs. elton soon began again ; and though much that passed between [them]2209-i was in a half - whisper , especially on [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s side , there was no avoiding a knowledge of [[their]2209-i principal subjects]2214-their principal subjects : [The post - office]4736-the post - office — catching cold — fetching letters — and friendship , were long under discussion ; and to [them]2209-i succeeded one , which must be at least equally unpleasant to [Jane]142-miss fairfax — inquiries whether [she]142-miss fairfax had yet heard of any situation likely to suit [her]142-miss fairfax , and professions of [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s meditated activity . “ Here is [April]265-april come ! ”[142-miss fairfax] said [she]142-miss fairfax , “ [I]142-miss fairfax get quite anxious about [you]142-miss fairfax . [June]266-june will soon be here . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ But [I]2209-i have never fixed on June or any other month — merely looked forward to the summer in general . ”[2209-i] “ But have [you]142-miss fairfax really heard of nothing ? ”[142-miss fairfax] “ [I]142-miss fairfax have not even made any inquiry ; [I]142-miss fairfax do not wish to make any yet . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ Oh ! [[my]2209-i dear]3120-my dear , [we]4798-we can not begin too early ; [you]142-miss fairfax are not aware of the difficulty of procuring exactly the desirable thing . ”[2209-i] “ [I]142-miss fairfax not aware ! ”[142-miss fairfax] said [Jane]142-miss fairfax , shaking [her]142-miss fairfax head ; “ [dear Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , who can have thought of it as [I]142-miss fairfax have done ? ”[142-miss fairfax] “ But [you]142-miss fairfax have not seen so much of [the world]392-the world as [I]2209-i have . [You]142-miss fairfax do not know how many candidates there always are for the first situations . [I]2209-i saw a vast deal of that in [the neighbourhood round [Maple Grove]53-maple grove]4800-the neighbourhood round maple grove . [A cousin of [Mr. Suckling]241-mr. suckling]4801-a cousin of mr. suckling , [Mrs. Bragge]267-mrs. bragge , had such an infinity of applications ; every body was anxious to be in [[her]267-mrs. bragge family]578-her family , for [she]267-mrs. bragge moves in the first circle . Wax - candles in [the schoolroom]4803-the schoolroom ! [You]142-miss fairfax may imagine how desirable ! Of [all houses in [the kingdom]1435-the kingdom [Mrs. Bragge]267-mrs. bragge ’s]4804-all houses in the kingdom mrs. bragge ’s is [the one [I]2209-i would most wish to see [you]142-miss fairfax in]4806-the one i would most wish to see you in . ”[2209-i] “ [Colonel]153-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell are to be in [town]3165-town again by midsummer , ”[142-miss fairfax] said [Jane]142-miss fairfax . “ [I]142-miss fairfax must spend some time with [them]4808-them ; [I]142-miss fairfax am sure [they]4808-them will want it;—afterwards [I]142-miss fairfax may probably be glad to dispose of [myself]142-miss fairfax . But [I]142-miss fairfax would not wish [you]142-miss fairfax to take the trouble of making any inquiries at present . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ Trouble ! aye , [I]2209-i know [your]142-miss fairfax scruples . [You]142-miss fairfax are afraid of giving [me]2209-i trouble ; but [I]2209-i assure [you]142-miss fairfax , [[my]2209-i dear]3120-my dear [Jane]142-miss fairfax , [the Campbells]180-the campbells can hardly be more interested about [you]142-miss fairfax than [I]2209-i am . [I]2209-i shall write to [Mrs. Partridge]243-mrs. partridge in a day or two , and shall give [her]243-mrs. partridge a strict charge to be on the look - out for any thing eligible . ”[2209-i] “ Thank [you]142-miss fairfax , but [I]2209-i would rather [you]142-miss fairfax did not mention the subject to [her]243-mrs. partridge ; till the time draws nearer , [I]2209-i do not wish to be giving any body trouble . ”[2209-i] “ But , [[my]142-miss fairfax dear child]4810-my dear child , the time is drawing near ; here is April , and [June]266-june , or say even July , is very near , with such business to accomplish before [us]4811-us . [Your]142-miss fairfax inexperience really amuses [me]142-miss fairfax ! A situation such as [you]142-miss fairfax deserve , and [[your]142-miss fairfax friends]926-your friends would require for [you]142-miss fairfax , is no everyday occurrence , is not obtained at a moment ’s notice ; indeed , indeed , [we]4811-us must begin inquiring directly . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ Excuse [me]2209-i , [ma’am]4289-ma’am , but this is by no means [my]2209-i intention ; [I]2209-i make no inquiry [myself]2209-i , and should be sorry to have any made by [[my]2209-i friends]629-my friends . When [I]2209-i am quite determined as to the time , [I]2209-i am not at all afraid of being long unemployed . There are places in [town]3165-town , [offices]4816-offices , where inquiry would soon produce something — Offices for the sale — not quite of [human flesh — but of human intellect]4817-human flesh — but of human intellect . ”[2209-i] “ Oh ! [my]2209-i dear , [human flesh]4818-human flesh ! [You]142-miss fairfax quite shock [me]2209-i ; if [you]142-miss fairfax mean a fling at the slave - trade , [I]2209-i assure [you]142-miss fairfax [Mr. Suckling]241-mr. suckling was always rather [a friend to the abolition]4819-a friend to the abolition . ”[2209-i] “ [I]142-miss fairfax did not mean , [I]142-miss fairfax was not thinking of the slave - trade , ”[142-miss fairfax] replied [Jane]142-miss fairfax ; “ governess - trade , [I]142-miss fairfax assure [you]142-miss fairfax , was all that [I]142-miss fairfax had in view ; widely different certainly as to the guilt of [those who carry it on]4820-those who carry it on ; but as to the greater misery of [the victims]4821-the victims , [I]142-miss fairfax do not know where it lies . But [I]142-miss fairfax only mean to say that there are advertising [offices]4816-offices , and that by applying to [them]4816-offices [I]142-miss fairfax should have no doubt of very soon meeting with something that would do . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ Something that would do ! ”[195-mrs. elton] repeated [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton . “ Aye , that may suit [your]142-miss fairfax humble ideas of yourself;—I know what [a modest creature]4823-a modest creature [you]142-miss fairfax are ; but it will not satisfy [[your]142-miss fairfax friends]926-your friends to have [you]142-miss fairfax taking up with any thing that may offer , any inferior , commonplace situation , in [a family]1439-a family not moving in a certain circle , or able to command the elegancies of life . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ [You]142-miss fairfax are very obliging ; but as to all that , [I]2209-i am very indifferent ; it would be no object to [me]2209-i to be with [the rich]4826-the rich ; [my]2209-i mortifications , [I]2209-i think , would only be the greater ; [I]2209-i should suffer more from comparison . [[A gentleman]527-a gentleman ’s family]4828-a gentleman ’s family is all that [I]2209-i should condition for . ”[2209-i] “ [I]195-mrs. elton know [you]142-miss fairfax , [I]195-mrs. elton know [you]142-miss fairfax ; [you]142-miss fairfax would take up with any thing ; but [I]195-mrs. elton shall be a little more nice , and [I]195-mrs. elton am sure [the good Campbells]4829-the good campbells will be quite on [my]195-mrs. elton side ; with [your]142-miss fairfax superior talents , [you]142-miss fairfax have a right to move in the first circle . [Your]142-miss fairfax musical knowledge alone would entitle [you]142-miss fairfax to name [your]142-miss fairfax own terms , have as many rooms as [you]142-miss fairfax like , and mix in [the family]423-the family as much as [you]142-miss fairfax chose;—that is — [I]195-mrs. elton do not know — if [you]142-miss fairfax knew the harp , [you]142-miss fairfax might do all that , [I]195-mrs. elton am very sure ; but [you]142-miss fairfax sing as well as play;—yes , [I]195-mrs. elton really believe [you]142-miss fairfax might , even without the harp , stipulate for what [you]142-miss fairfax chose;—and [you]142-miss fairfax must and shall be delightfully , honourably and comfortably settled before [the Campbells]180-the campbells or [I]195-mrs. elton have any rest . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ [You]142-miss fairfax may well class the delight , the honour , and the comfort of such a situation together , ”[142-miss fairfax] said [Jane]142-miss fairfax , “ [they]4831-they are pretty sure to be equal ; however , [I]142-miss fairfax am very serious in not wishing any thing to be attempted at present for [me]142-miss fairfax . [I]142-miss fairfax am exceedingly obliged to [you]142-miss fairfax , [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , [I]142-miss fairfax am obliged to any body who feels for [me]142-miss fairfax , but [I]142-miss fairfax am quite serious in wishing nothing to be done till the summer . For two or three months longer [I]142-miss fairfax shall remain where [I]142-miss fairfax am , and as [I]142-miss fairfax am . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ And [I]195-mrs. elton am quite serious too , [I]195-mrs. elton assure [you]142-miss fairfax , ”[195-mrs. elton] replied [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton gaily , “ in resolving to be always on the watch , and employing [[my]195-mrs. elton friends]629-my friends to watch also , that nothing really unexceptionable may pass [us]4833-us . ”[195-mrs. elton] In this style [she]195-mrs. elton ran on ; never thoroughly stopped by any thing till [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse came into [the room]3386-the room ; [her]195-mrs. elton vanity had then a change of object , and [Emma]79-emma heard [her]195-mrs. elton saying in the same half - whisper to [Jane]142-miss fairfax , “ Here comes [this dear old beau of [mine]142-miss fairfax]4834-this dear old beau of mine , [I]195-mrs. elton protest!—Only think of [his]4834-this dear old beau of mine gallantry in coming away before [the other men!—what a dear creature]4835-the other men!—what a dear creature [he]4834-this dear old beau of mine is;—I assure [you]142-miss fairfax [I]195-mrs. elton like [him]4834-this dear old beau of mine excessively . [I]195-mrs. elton admire all that quaint , old - fashioned politeness ; it is much more to [my]195-mrs. elton taste than modern ease ; modern ease often disgusts [me]195-mrs. elton . But this good old [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , [I]195-mrs. elton wish [you]142-miss fairfax had heard [his]4834-this dear old beau of mine gallant speeches to [me]195-mrs. elton at dinner . Oh ! [I]195-mrs. elton assure [you]142-miss fairfax [I]195-mrs. elton began to think [my]195-mrs. elton caro sposo would be absolutely jealous . How do [you]142-miss fairfax like [it?—Selina]81-mr. woodhouse ’s choice — handsome , [I]195-mrs. elton think , but [I]195-mrs. elton do not know whether it is not over - trimmed ; [I]195-mrs. elton have the greatest dislike to the idea of being over - trimmed — quite a horror of finery . [I]195-mrs. elton must put on a few ornaments now , because it is expected of [me]195-mrs. elton . [A bride]2094-a bride , [you]142-miss fairfax know , must appear like [a bride]2094-a bride , but [my]195-mrs. elton natural taste is all for simplicity ; a simple style of dress is so infinitely preferable to finery . But [I]195-mrs. elton am quite in the minority , [I]195-mrs. elton believe ; [few people]4838-few people seem to value simplicity of dress,—show and finery are every thing . [I]195-mrs. elton have some notion of putting such a trimming as this to [my]195-mrs. elton white and silver poplin . Do [you]142-miss fairfax think it will look well ? ”[195-mrs. elton] [The whole party]3782-the whole party were but just reassembled in [the drawing - room]1313-the drawing - room when [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston made [his]82-mr. weston appearance among [them]3782-the whole party . [He]82-mr. weston had returned to a late dinner , and walked to [Hartfield]90-hartfield as soon as it was over . [He]82-mr. weston had been too much expected by [the best judges]2219-the best judges , for surprize — but there was great joy . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was almost as glad to see [him]82-mr. weston now , as [he]81-mr. woodhouse would have been sorry to see [him]82-mr. weston before . [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley only was in mute astonishment.—That [a man who might have spent [his]2220-a man who might have spent his evening quietly at home after a day of business in london evening quietly at [home]3258-home after a day of business in [London]1-london]2220-a man who might have spent his evening quietly at home after a day of business in london , should set off again , and walk half a mile to [[another man]1273-another man ’s house]1274-another man ’s house , for the sake of being in [mixed company]2224-mixed company till bed - time , of finishing [his]2220-a man who might have spent his evening quietly at home after a day of business in london day in the efforts of civility and the noise of numbers , was a circumstance to strike [him]88-mr. knightley deeply . [A man who had been in motion since eight o’clock in the morning , and might now have been still , who had been long talking , and might have been silent , who had been in more than one crowd]2225-a man who had been in motion since eight o’clock in the morning , and might now have been still , who had been long talking , and might have been silent , who had been in more than one crowd , and might have been [alone!—Such a man]2226-alone!—such a man , to quit the tranquillity and independence of [[his]82-mr. weston own fireside]2227-his own fireside , and on the evening of a cold sleety April day rush out again into the world!—Could [he]82-mr. weston by a touch of [his]82-mr. weston finger have instantly taken back [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife , there would have been a motive ; but [his]82-mr. weston coming would probably prolong rather than break up the party . [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley looked at [him]88-mr. knightley with amazement , then shrugged [his]88-mr. knightley shoulders , and said , “ [I]88-mr. knightley could not have believed it even of [him]82-mr. weston . ”[88-mr. knightley] [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston meanwhile , perfectly unsuspicious of the indignation [he]82-mr. weston was exciting , happy and cheerful as usual , and with all the right of being [principal talker]2229-principal talker , which a day spent anywhere from [home]3258-home confers , was making [himself]82-mr. weston agreeable among the rest ; and having satisfied the inquiries of [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife as to [his]82-mr. weston dinner , convincing [her]3168-his wife that none of all [her]3168-his wife careful directions to [the servants]2232-the servants had been forgotten , and spread abroad what public news [he]82-mr. weston had heard , was proceeding to a family communication , which , though principally addressed to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , [he]82-mr. weston had not the smallest doubt of being highly interesting to [every body in [the room]3386-the room]2233-every body in the room . [He]82-mr. weston gave [her]3168-his wife a letter , it was from [Frank]98-frank churchill , and to [herself]3168-his wife ; [he]82-mr. weston had met with it in [his]82-mr. weston way , and had taken the liberty of opening it . “ Read it , read it , ”[82-mr. weston] said [he]82-mr. weston , “ it will give [you]3168-his wife pleasure ; only a few lines — will not take [you]3168-his wife long ; read it to [Emma]79-emma . ”[82-mr. weston] [The two ladies]1839-the two ladies looked over it together ; and [he]82-mr. weston sat smiling and talking to [them]1839-the two ladies the whole time , in a voice a little subdued , but very audible to [every body]3270-every body . “ Well , [he]82-mr. weston is coming , [you]1839-the two ladies see ; good news , [I]82-mr. weston think . Well , what do [you]1839-the two ladies say to it?—I always told [you]1839-the two ladies [he]82-mr. weston would be here again soon , did not I?—Anne , [[my]82-mr. weston dear]3120-my dear , did not [I]82-mr. weston always tell [you]1839-the two ladies so , and [you]1839-the two ladies would not believe me?—In [town]3165-town next week , [you]1839-the two ladies see — at the latest , [I]82-mr. weston dare say ; for [she]79-emma is as impatient as [the black gentleman]4841-the black gentleman when any thing is to be done ; most likely [they]1839-the two ladies will be there to - morrow or Saturday . As to [her]79-emma illness , all nothing of course . But it is an excellent thing to have [Frank]98-frank churchill among [us]4842-us again , so near as [town]3165-town . [They]1839-the two ladies will stay a good while when [they]1839-the two ladies do come , and [he]82-mr. weston will be half [his]82-mr. weston time with [us]4842-us . This is precisely what [I]82-mr. weston wanted . Well , pretty good news , is not it ? Have [you]84-mrs. weston finished it ? Has [Emma]79-emma read it all ? Put it up , put it up ; [we]4842-us will have a good talk about it some other time , but it will not do now . [I]82-mr. weston shall only just mention the circumstance to [the others]3512-the others in a common way . ”[82-mr. weston] [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was most comfortably pleased on the occasion . [Her]84-mrs. weston looks and words had nothing to restrain [them]2237-them . [She]84-mrs. weston was happy , [she]84-mrs. weston knew [she]84-mrs. weston was happy , and knew [she]84-mrs. weston ought to be happy . [Her]84-mrs. weston congratulations were warm and open ; but [Emma]79-emma could not speak so fluently . [She]79-emma was a little occupied in weighing [her]79-emma own feelings , and trying to understand the degree of [her]79-emma agitation , which [she]79-emma rather thought was considerable . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , however , too eager to be very observant , too communicative to want [others]473-others to talk , was very well satisfied with what [she]84-mrs. weston did say , and soon moved away to make the rest of [[his]82-mr. weston friends]3166-his friends happy by a partial communication of what [the whole room]2240-the whole room must have overheard already . It was well that [he]82-mr. weston took [every body]3270-every body ’s joy for granted , or [he]82-mr. weston might not have thought either [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse or [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley particularly delighted . [They]2242-they were the first entitled , after [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston and [Emma]79-emma , to be made happy;—from [them]2242-they [he]82-mr. weston would have proceeded to [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , but [she]142-miss fairfax was so deep in conversation with [John Knightley]88-mr. knightley , that it would have been too positive an interruption ; and finding [himself]82-mr. weston close to [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , and [her]195-mrs. elton attention disengaged , [he]82-mr. weston necessarily began on the subject with [her]195-mrs. elton . CHAPTER XVIII “ [I]82-mr. weston hope [I]82-mr. weston shall soon have the pleasure of introducing [[my]82-mr. weston son]1306-my son to [you]195-mrs. elton , ”[82-mr. weston] said [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston . [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , very willing to suppose a particular compliment intended [her]195-mrs. elton by such a hope , smiled most graciously . “ [You]195-mrs. elton have heard of a certain [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , [I]82-mr. weston presume , ”[82-mr. weston] [he]82-mr. weston continued—“and know [him]98-frank churchill to be [[my]82-mr. weston son]1306-my son , though [he]98-frank churchill does not bear [my]82-mr. weston name . ”[82-mr. weston] “ Oh ! yes , and [I]82-mr. weston shall be very happy in [his]98-frank churchill acquaintance . [I]82-mr. weston am sure [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton will lose no time in calling on [him]98-frank churchill ; and [we]4847-we shall both have great pleasure in seeing [him]98-frank churchill at [the Vicarage]3485-the vicarage . ”[82-mr. weston] “ [You]195-mrs. elton are very obliging.—Frank will be extremely happy , [I]82-mr. weston am sure . — [He]98-frank churchill is to be in [town]3165-town next week , if not sooner . [We]4847-we have notice of it in a letter to - day . [I]82-mr. weston met the letters in [my]82-mr. weston way this morning , and seeing [[my]82-mr. weston son]1306-my son ’s hand , presumed to open it — though it was not directed to [me]82-mr. weston — it was to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . [She]84-mrs. weston is [[his]98-frank churchill principal correspondent]4851-his principal correspondent , [I]82-mr. weston assure [you]195-mrs. elton . [I]82-mr. weston hardly ever get a letter . ”[82-mr. weston] “ And so [you]195-mrs. elton absolutely opened what was directed to [her]84-mrs. weston ! Oh ! [Mr. Weston—(laughing]268-mr. weston—(laughing affectedly ) [I]82-mr. weston must protest against that.—A most dangerous precedent indeed!—I beg [you]195-mrs. elton will not let [[your]195-mrs. elton neighbours]4156-your neighbours follow [your]195-mrs. elton example.—Upon [my]82-mr. weston word , if this is what [I]82-mr. weston am to expect , [we]4853-us [married women]4614-married women must begin to exert ourselves!—Oh ! [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , [I]82-mr. weston could not have believed it of [you]195-mrs. elton ! ”[82-mr. weston] “ Aye , [[we]4853-us [men]828-men]4855-we men are [sad fellows]4857-sad fellows . [You]195-mrs. elton must take care of [yourself]195-mrs. elton , [Mrs. Elton.—This]269-mrs. elton.—this letter tells [us]4853-us — it is a short letter — written in a hurry , merely to give [us]4853-us notice — it tells [us]4853-us that [they]828-men are all coming up to [town]3165-town directly , on [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill ’s account — [she]94-mrs. churchill has not been well the whole winter , and thinks [Enscombe]7-enscombe too cold for [her]94-mrs. churchill — so [they]828-men are all to move southward without loss of time . ”[82-mr. weston] “ Indeed!—from [Yorkshire]50-yorkshire , [I]82-mr. weston think . [Enscombe]7-enscombe is in [Yorkshire]50-yorkshire ? ”[82-mr. weston] “ Yes , [they]828-men are about one hundred and ninety miles from [London]1-london , a considerable journey . ”[82-mr. weston] “ Yes , upon [my]82-mr. weston word , very considerable . [The remaining five]2249-the remaining five were left to [their]2249-the remaining five own powers , and [Emma]79-emma doubted [their]2249-the remaining five getting on very well ; for [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley seemed little disposed for conversation ; [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton was wanting notice , which [nobody]3124-nobody had inclination to pay , and [she]195-mrs. elton was [herself]195-mrs. elton in a worry of spirits which would have made [her]195-mrs. elton prefer being silent . [[Your]79-emma neighbourhood]4943-your neighbourhood is increasing , and [you]79-emma mix more with it . A little while ago , every letter to [Isabella]83-isabella brought an account of fresh gaieties ; dinners at [Mr. Cole]135-mr. cole ’s , or balls at the Crown . And as to [[my]79-emma dear little boys]4949-my dear little boys , [I]79-emma must say , that if [Aunt Emma]79-emma has not time for [them]4949-my dear little boys , [I]79-emma do not think [they]4949-my dear little boys would fare much better with [Uncle Knightley , who is absent from [home]3258-home about five hours where [she]79-emma is absent one — and who , when [he]88-mr. knightley is at [home]3258-home , is either reading to [himself]88-mr. knightley or settling [his]88-mr. knightley accounts]279-uncle knightley , who is absent from home about five hours where she is absent one — and who , when he is at home , is either reading to himself or settling his accounts . ”[79-emma] [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley seemed to be trying not to smile ; and succeeded without difficulty , upon [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s beginning to talk to [him]88-mr. knightley . VOLUME III CHAPTER I A very little quiet reflection was enough to satisfy [Emma]79-emma as to the nature of [her]79-emma agitation on hearing this news of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . [She]79-emma was soon convinced that it was not for [herself]79-emma [she]79-emma was feeling at all apprehensive or embarrassed ; it was for [him]98-frank churchill . [Her]79-emma own attachment had really subsided into a mere nothing ; it was not worth thinking of;—but if [he]98-frank churchill , who had undoubtedly been always so much the most in love of [the two]1913-the two , were to be returning with the same warmth of sentiment which [he]98-frank churchill had taken away , it would be very distressing . If a separation of two months should not have cooled [him]98-frank churchill , there were dangers and evils before her:—caution for [him]98-frank churchill and for [herself]79-emma would be necessary . [She]79-emma did not mean to have [her]79-emma own affections entangled again , and it would be incumbent on [her]79-emma to avoid any encouragement of [his]98-frank churchill . [She]79-emma wished [she]79-emma might be able to keep [him]98-frank churchill from an absolute declaration . That would be so very painful a conclusion of [their]1913-the two present acquaintance ! and yet , [she]79-emma could not help rather anticipating something decisive . [She]79-emma felt as if the spring would not pass without bringing a crisis , an event , a something to alter [her]79-emma present composed and tranquil state . It was not very long , though rather longer than [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston had foreseen , before [she]79-emma had the power of forming some opinion of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s feelings . [The Enscombe family]2255-the enscombe family were not in [town]3165-town quite so soon as had been imagined , but [he]98-frank churchill was at [Highbury]3-highbury very soon afterwards . [He]98-frank churchill rode down for a couple of hours ; [he]98-frank churchill could not yet do more ; but as [he]98-frank churchill came from [Randalls]97-randalls immediately to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [she]79-emma could then exercise all [her]79-emma quick observation , and speedily determine how [he]98-frank churchill was influenced , and how [she]79-emma must act . [They]1913-the two met with the utmost friendliness . There could be no doubt of [his]98-frank churchill great pleasure in seeing [her]79-emma . But [she]79-emma had an almost instant doubt of [his]98-frank churchill caring for [her]79-emma as [he]98-frank churchill had done , of [his]98-frank churchill feeling the same tenderness in the same degree . [She]79-emma watched [him]98-frank churchill well . It was a clear thing [he]98-frank churchill was less in love than [he]98-frank churchill had been . [Absence]280-absence , with the conviction probably of [her]79-emma indifference , had produced this very natural and very desirable effect . [He]98-frank churchill was in high spirits ; as ready to talk and laugh as ever , and seemed delighted to speak of [his]98-frank churchill former visit , and recur to old stories : and [he]98-frank churchill was not without agitation . It was not in [his]98-frank churchill calmness that [she]79-emma read [his]98-frank churchill comparative indifference . [He]98-frank churchill was not calm ; [his]98-frank churchill spirits were evidently fluttered ; there was restlessness about [him]98-frank churchill . Lively as [he]98-frank churchill was , it seemed a liveliness that did not satisfy [himself]98-frank churchill ; but what decided [her]79-emma belief on the subject , was [his]98-frank churchill staying only a quarter of an hour , and hurrying away to make other calls in [Highbury]3-highbury . “ [He]98-frank churchill had seen [a group of old acquaintance]4952-a group of old acquaintance in [the street]3836-the street as [he]98-frank churchill passed — [he]98-frank churchill had not stopped , [he]98-frank churchill would not stop for more than a word — but [he]98-frank churchill had the vanity to think [they]4952-a group of old acquaintance would be disappointed if [he]98-frank churchill did not call , and much as [he]98-frank churchill wished to stay longer at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [he]98-frank churchill must hurry off . ”[79-emma] [She]79-emma had no doubt as to [his]98-frank churchill being less in love — but neither [his]98-frank churchill agitated spirits , nor [his]98-frank churchill hurrying away , seemed like a perfect cure ; and [she]79-emma was rather inclined to think it implied a dread of [her]79-emma returning power , and a discreet resolution of not trusting [himself]98-frank churchill with [her]79-emma long . This was the only visit from [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill in the course of ten days . [He]98-frank churchill was often hoping , intending to come — but was always prevented . [[His]98-frank churchill aunt]1331-his aunt could not bear to have [him]98-frank churchill leave [her]1331-his aunt . Such was [his]98-frank churchill own account at [Randall]281-randall ’s . If [he]98-frank churchill were quite sincere , if [he]98-frank churchill really tried to come , it was to be inferred that [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill ’s removal to [London]1-london had been of no service to the wilful or nervous part of [her]94-mrs. churchill disorder . That [she]94-mrs. churchill was really ill was very certain ; [he]98-frank churchill had declared [himself]98-frank churchill convinced of it , at [Randalls]97-randalls . Though much might be fancy , [he]98-frank churchill could not doubt , when [he]98-frank churchill looked back , that [she]94-mrs. churchill was in a weaker state of health than [she]94-mrs. churchill had been half a year ago . [He]98-frank churchill did not believe it to proceed from any thing that care and medicine might not remove , or at least that [she]94-mrs. churchill might not have many years of existence before [her]94-mrs. churchill ; but [he]98-frank churchill could not be prevailed on , by all [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father ’s doubts , to say that [her]94-mrs. churchill complaints were merely imaginary , or that [she]94-mrs. churchill was as strong as ever . It soon appeared that [London]1-london was not the place for [her]94-mrs. churchill . [She]94-mrs. churchill could not endure [its]1-london noise . [Her]94-mrs. churchill nerves were under continual irritation and suffering ; and by the ten days ’ end , [[her]94-mrs. churchill nephew]1441-her nephew ’s letter to [Randalls]97-randalls communicated a change of plan . [They]2260-they were going to remove immediately to [Richmond]62-richmond . [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill had been recommended to the medical skill of [an eminent person there]2261-an eminent person there , and had otherwise a fancy for [the place]439-the place . [A ready - furnished house in [a favourite spot]2264-a favourite spot]2263-a ready - furnished house in a favourite spot was engaged , and much benefit expected from the change . [Emma]79-emma heard that [Frank]98-frank churchill wrote in the highest spirits of this arrangement , and seemed most fully to appreciate the blessing of having two months before [him]98-frank churchill of such near neighbourhood to [many dear friends]2265-many dear friends — for [the house]425-the house was taken for [May]273-may and [June]266-june . [She]79-emma was told that now [he]98-frank churchill wrote with the greatest confidence of being often with [them]2265-many dear friends , almost as often as [he]98-frank churchill could even wish . [Emma]79-emma saw how [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston understood these joyous prospects . [He]98-frank churchill was considering [her]94-mrs. churchill as the source of all the happiness [they]2265-many dear friends offered . [She]79-emma hoped it was not so . Two months must bring it to the proof . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s own happiness was indisputable . [He]98-frank churchill was quite delighted . It was the very circumstance [he]98-frank churchill could have wished for . Now , it would be really having [Frank]98-frank churchill in [[their]2265-many dear friends neighbourhood]2267-their neighbourhood . What were nine miles to [a young man?—An hour]2268-a young man?—an hour ’s ride . [He]98-frank churchill would be always coming over . The difference in that respect of [Richmond]62-richmond and [London]1-london was enough to make the whole difference of seeing [him]98-frank churchill always and seeing [him]98-frank churchill never . Sixteen miles — nay , eighteen — it must be full eighteen to [[Manchester]63-manchester - street]2269-manchester - street — was a serious obstacle . Were [he]98-frank churchill ever able to get away , the day would be spent in coming and returning . There was no comfort in having [him]98-frank churchill in [London]1-london ; [he]98-frank churchill might as well be at [Enscombe]7-enscombe ; but [Richmond]62-richmond was the very distance for easy intercourse . Better than nearer ! One good thing was immediately brought to a certainty by this removal,—the ball at [the Crown]46-the crown . It had not been forgotten before , but it had been soon acknowledged vain to attempt to fix a day . Now , however , it was absolutely to be ; every preparation was resumed , and very soon after [the Churchills]96-the churchills had removed to [Richmond]62-richmond , a few lines from [Frank]98-frank churchill , to say that [[his]98-frank churchill aunt]1331-his aunt felt already much better for the change , and that [he]98-frank churchill had no doubt of being able to join [them]2271-them for twenty - four hours at any given time , induced [them]2271-them to name as early a day as possible . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s ball was to be a real thing . [A very few to - morrows]2272-a very few to - morrows stood between [the young people of [Highbury]3-highbury and happiness]2273-the young people of highbury and happiness . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse was resigned . The time of year lightened the evil to [him]81-mr. woodhouse . [May]273-may was better for every thing than February . [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates was engaged to spend the evening at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [James]86-james had due notice , and [he]98-frank churchill sanguinely hoped that neither [dear little Henry]118-henry nor [dear little John]88-mr. knightley would have any thing the matter with [them]2271-them , while [dear Emma]79-emma were gone . CHAPTER II No misfortune occurred , again to prevent the ball . The day approached , the day arrived ; and after a morning of some anxious watching , [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , in all the certainty of [his]98-frank churchill own self , reached [Randalls]97-randalls before dinner , and every thing was safe . No second meeting had there yet been between [him]98-frank churchill and [Emma]79-emma . [The room at [the Crown]46-the crown]4422-the room at the crown was to witness it;—but it would be better than a common meeting in a crowd . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston had been so very earnest in [his]82-mr. weston entreaties for [her]79-emma arriving [there]437-there as soon as possible after [themselves]2276-they , for the purpose of taking [her]79-emma opinion as to the propriety and comfort of [the rooms]4443-the rooms before [any other persons]2278-any other persons came , that [she]79-emma could not refuse [him]82-mr. weston , and must therefore spend some quiet interval in [the young man]3228-the young man ’s company . [She]79-emma was to convey [Harriet]107-harriet , and [they]2276-they drove to [the Crown]46-the crown in good time , the Randalls party just sufficiently before [them]2276-they . [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill seemed to have been on the watch ; and though [he]98-frank churchill did not say much , [his]98-frank churchill eyes declared that [he]98-frank churchill meant to have a delightful evening . [They]2276-they all walked about together , to see that every thing was as it should be ; and within a few minutes were joined by the contents of [another carriage]1840-another carriage , which [Emma]79-emma could not hear the sound of at first , without great surprize . “ So unreasonably early ! ”[79-emma] [she]79-emma was going to exclaim ; but [she]79-emma presently found that it was [a family of old friends]2281-a family of old friends , who were coming , like [herself]79-emma , by particular desire , to help [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s judgment ; and [they]2281-a family of old friends were so very closely followed by another carriage of [cousins , who had been entreated to come early with the same distinguishing earnestness , on the same errand]2282-cousins , who had been entreated to come early with the same distinguishing earnestness , on the same errand , that it seemed as if half [the company]2283-the company might soon be collected together for the purpose of preparatory inspection . [Emma]79-emma perceived that [her]79-emma taste was not the only taste on which [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston depended , and felt , that to be the favourite and intimate of [a man who had so many intimates and confidantes]2284-a man who had so many intimates and confidantes , was not the very first distinction in the scale of vanity . [She]79-emma liked [his]98-frank churchill open manners , but a little less of open - heartedness would have made [him]98-frank churchill a higher character.—General benevolence , but not general friendship , made [a man]548-a man what [he]548-a man ought to be.—She could fancy [such a man]593-such a man . [The whole party]3782-the whole party walked about , and looked , and praised again ; and then , having nothing else to do , formed a sort of half - circle round the fire , to observe in [their]3782-the whole party various modes , till other subjects were started , that , though May , a fire in the evening was still very pleasant . [Emma]79-emma found that it was not [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s fault that the number of [privy councillors]2288-privy councillors was not yet larger . Every thing so good ! ”[284-mrs. weston.—“very] [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill returned to [[his]98-frank churchill station]2310-his station by [Emma]79-emma ; and as soon as [Miss Bates]101-miss bates was quiet , [she]79-emma found [herself]79-emma necessarily overhearing the discourse of [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton and [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , who were standing a little way behind her.—He was thoughtful . [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton then said , “ [Nobody]3124-nobody can think less of dress in general than [I]195-mrs. elton do — but upon such an occasion as this , when every body ’s eyes are so much upon [me]195-mrs. elton , and in compliment to [the Westons]104-the westons — who [I]195-mrs. elton have no doubt are giving this ball chiefly to do [me]195-mrs. elton honour — [I]195-mrs. elton would not wish to be inferior to [others]473-others . And [I]195-mrs. elton see very few pearls in [the room]3386-the room except mine.—So [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill is [a capital dancer]4992-a capital dancer , [I]195-mrs. elton understand.—We shall see if [our]4993-our styles [suit.—A fine young man]4994-suit.—a fine young man certainly is [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . [I]195-mrs. elton like [him]98-frank churchill very well . ”[195-mrs. elton] At this moment [Frank]98-frank churchill began talking so vigorously , that [Emma]79-emma could not but imagine [he]98-frank churchill had overheard [his]98-frank churchill own praises , and did not want to hear more;—and the voices of [the ladies]3323-the ladies were drowned for a while , till another suspension brought [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s tones again distinctly forward.—Mr . [He]98-frank churchill walked off to find [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father , but was quickly back again with both [Mr.]2316-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . [He]98-frank churchill had met with [them]2317-them in a little perplexity , which must be laid before [Emma]79-emma . [Weston]82-mr. weston and [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton led the way , [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill and [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor followed . [Emma]79-emma must submit to stand second to [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , though [she]79-emma had always considered the ball as peculiarly for [her]79-emma . It was almost enough to make [her]79-emma think of marrying . [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton had undoubtedly the advantage , at this time , in vanity completely gratified ; for though [she]195-mrs. elton had intended to begin with [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , [she]195-mrs. elton could not lose by the change . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston might be [[his]82-mr. weston son]3218-his son ’s superior.—In spite of this little rub , however , [Emma]79-emma was smiling with enjoyment , delighted to see the respectable length of the set as it was forming , and to feel that [she]79-emma had so many hours of unusual festivity before her.—She was more disturbed by [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s not dancing than by any thing else.—There [he]88-mr. knightley was , among [the standers - by]2322-the standers - by , where [he]88-mr. knightley ought not to be ; [he]88-mr. knightley ought to be dancing,—not classing [himself]88-mr. knightley with [the husbands]2323-the husbands , and [fathers]2324-fathers , and [whist - players , who were pretending to feel an interest in the dance]2325-whist - players , who were pretending to feel an interest in the dance till [their]2325-whist - players , who were pretending to feel an interest in the dance rubbers were made up,—so young as [he]88-mr. knightley looked!—He could not have appeared to greater advantage perhaps anywhere , than where [he]88-mr. knightley had placed [himself]88-mr. knightley . [[His]88-mr. knightley tall , firm , upright figure , among the bulky forms and stooping shoulders of [the elderly men]2327-the elderly men]2326-his tall , firm , upright figure , among the bulky forms and stooping shoulders of the elderly men , was such as [Emma]79-emma felt must draw [every body]3270-every body ’s eyes ; and , excepting [[her]79-emma own partner]2329-her own partner , there was not one among the whole row of [young men who could be compared with him.—He]2330-young men who could be compared with him.—he moved a few steps nearer , and those few steps were enough to prove in how gentlemanlike a manner , with what natural grace , [he]88-mr. knightley must have danced , would [he]88-mr. knightley but take the trouble.—Whenever [she]79-emma caught [his]88-mr. knightley eye , [she]79-emma forced [him]88-mr. knightley to smile ; but in general [he]88-mr. knightley was looking grave . [She]79-emma wished [he]88-mr. knightley could love [a ballroom]2331-a ballroom better , and could like [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill better.—He seemed often observing [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma must not flatter [herself]79-emma that [he]88-mr. knightley thought of [her]79-emma dancing , but if [he]88-mr. knightley were criticising [her]79-emma behaviour , [she]79-emma did not feel afraid . There was nothing like flirtation between [her]79-emma and [[her]79-emma partner]2060-her partner . [They]2333-they seemed more like cheerful , [easy friends]2334-easy friends , than [lovers]2335-lovers . That [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill thought less of [her]79-emma than [he]98-frank churchill had done , was indubitable . The ball proceeded pleasantly . The anxious cares , the incessant attentions of [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , were not thrown away . [Every body]3270-every body seemed happy ; and the praise of being a delightful ball , which is seldom bestowed till after a ball has ceased to be , was repeatedly given in the very beginning of the existence of this . Of very important , very recordable events , it was not more productive than such meetings usually are . There was one , however , which [Emma]79-emma thought something of.—The two last dances before supper were begun , and [Harriet]107-harriet had no [partner;—the only young lady sitting down;—and so equal had been hitherto the number of [dancers]2338-dancers]2337-partner;—the only young lady sitting down;—and so equal had been hitherto the number of dancers , that how there could be [any one disengaged]2339-any one disengaged was the wonder!—But [Emma]79-emma ’s wonder lessened soon afterwards , on seeing [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton sauntering about . [He]91-mr. elton would not ask [Harriet]107-harriet to dance if it were possible to be avoided : [she]79-emma was sure [he]91-mr. elton would not — and [she]79-emma was expecting [him]91-mr. elton every moment to escape into [the card - room]2340-the card - room . Escape , however , was not [his]91-mr. elton plan . [He]91-mr. elton came to the part of [the room]3386-the room where [the sitters - by]2342-the sitters - by were collected , spoke to [some]2343-some , and walked about in front of [them]2343-some , as if to shew [his]91-mr. elton liberty , and [his]91-mr. elton resolution of maintaining it . [He]91-mr. elton did not omit being sometimes directly before [Miss Smith]107-harriet , or speaking to [those who were close to her.—Emma]2344-those who were close to her.—emma saw it . [She]107-harriet was not yet dancing ; [she]107-harriet was working [her]107-harriet way up from the bottom , and had therefore leisure to look around , and by only turning [her]107-harriet head a little [she]107-harriet saw it all . When [she]107-harriet was half - way up the set , [the whole group]2345-the whole group were exactly behind [her]107-harriet , and [she]107-harriet would no longer allow [her]107-harriet eyes to watch ; but [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was so near , that [she]107-harriet heard every syllable of a dialogue which just then took place between [him]91-mr. elton and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ; and [she]107-harriet perceived that [[his]91-mr. elton wife]3168-his wife , who was standing immediately above [her]107-harriet , was not only listening also , but even encouraging [him]91-mr. elton by significant glances.—The kind - hearted , [gentle Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston had left [her]84-mrs. weston seat to join [him]91-mr. elton and say , “ Do not [you]91-mr. elton dance , [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ? ”[84-mrs. weston] to which [his]91-mr. elton prompt reply was , “ Most readily , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , if [you]84-mrs. weston will dance with [me]84-mrs. weston . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ [Me!—oh]4997-me!—oh ! no — [I]84-mrs. weston would get [you]84-mrs. weston a better partner than [myself]84-mrs. weston . [the amiable , obliging , gentle Mr. Elton.—She]296-the amiable , obliging , gentle mr. elton.—she looked round for a moment ; [he]91-mr. elton had joined [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley at a little distance , and was arranging [himself]91-mr. elton for settled conversation , while smiles of high glee passed between [him]91-mr. elton and [[his]91-mr. elton wife]3168-his wife . [She]79-emma was all pleasure and gratitude , both for [Harriet]107-harriet and [herself]79-emma , and longed to be thanking [him]91-mr. elton ; and though too distant for speech , [her]79-emma countenance said much , as soon as [she]79-emma could catch [his]91-mr. elton eye again . [His]91-mr. elton dancing proved to be just what [she]79-emma had believed it , extremely good ; and [Harriet]107-harriet would have seemed almost too lucky , if it had not been for the cruel state of things before , and for the very complete enjoyment and very high sense of the distinction which [her]79-emma happy features announced . It was not thrown away on [her]79-emma , [she]79-emma bounded higher than ever , flew farther down the middle , and was in a continual course of smiles . [I]101-miss bates never saw any thing equal to the comfort and style — Candles everywhere.—I was telling [you]101-miss bates of [[your]101-miss bates grandmama]5020-your grandmama , [Jane,—There]299-jane,—there was a little disappointment.—The baked apples and biscuits , excellent in [their]5021-their way , [you]101-miss bates know ; but there was a delicate fricassee of sweetbread and some asparagus brought in at first , and good [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , not thinking the asparagus quite boiled enough , sent it all out again . Now there is nothing [grandmama]1518-grandmama loves better than sweetbread and asparagus — so [she]1518-grandmama was rather disappointed , but [we]5016-we agreed [we]5016-we would not speak of it to any body , for fear of its getting round to dear [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , who would be so very much concerned!—Well , this is brilliant ! [I]101-miss bates am all amazement ! could not have supposed any thing!—Such elegance and profusion!—I have seen nothing like it since — Well , where shall [we]5016-we sit ? where shall [we]5016-we sit ? [He]88-mr. knightley was warm in [his]88-mr. knightley reprobation of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s conduct ; it had been unpardonable rudeness ; and [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s looks also received the due share of censure . “ [They]5025-they aimed at wounding more than [Harriet]107-harriet , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [he]88-mr. knightley . “ [Emma]79-emma , why is it that [they]5025-they are [[your]79-emma enemies]5026-your enemies ? ”[88-mr. knightley] [He]88-mr. knightley looked with smiling penetration ; and , on receiving no answer , added , “ [She]195-mrs. elton ought not to be angry with [you]79-emma , [I]88-mr. knightley suspect , whatever [he]88-mr. knightley may be.—To that surmise , [you]79-emma say nothing , of course ; but confess , [Emma]79-emma , that [you]79-emma did want [him]88-mr. knightley to marry [Harriet]107-harriet . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [I]79-emma did , ”[79-emma] replied [Emma]79-emma , “ and [they]5025-they can not forgive [me]88-mr. knightley . ”[88-mr. knightley] [He]88-mr. knightley shook [his]88-mr. knightley head ; but there was a smile of indulgence with it , and [he]88-mr. knightley only said , “ [I]88-mr. knightley shall not scold [you]79-emma .
