[I]0-i shall talk about it to [him]153-colonel campbell ; [he]153-colonel campbell will settle for [me]0-i ; [he]153-colonel campbell will help [me]0-i out of all [my]0-i difficulties . ’—And to this day , [I]0-i do believe , [she]101-miss bates knows not whether it was [his]153-colonel campbell present or [[his]153-colonel campbell daughter]3129-his daughter ’s . ” Now [Emma]79-emma was obliged to think of the pianoforte ; and the remembrance of all [her]79-emma former fanciful and unfair conjectures was so little pleasing , that [she]79-emma soon allowed [herself]79-emma to believe [her]79-emma visit had been long enough ; and , with a repetition of every thing that [she]79-emma could venture to say of the good wishes which [she]79-emma really felt , took leave . [CHAPTER IX Emma]79-emma ’s pensive meditations , as [she]79-emma walked [home]3258-home , were not interrupted ; but on entering [the parlour]3353-the parlour , [she]79-emma found [those who must rouse [her]79-emma]5270-those who must rouse her . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [Harriet]107-harriet had arrived during [her]79-emma absence , and were sitting with [her]79-emma father.—Mr . [Knightley]88-mr. knightley immediately got up , and in a manner decidedly graver than usual , said , “[101-miss bates] [I]0-i would not go away without seeing [you]2696-you , but [I]0-i have no time to spare , and therefore must now be gone directly . [I]0-i am going to [London]1-london , to spend a few days with [John]88-mr. knightley and [Isabella]83-isabella . Have [you]2696-you any thing to send or say , besides the ‘ love , ’ which [nobody]3124-nobody carries ? ” “[2696-you] Nothing at all . But is not this a sudden scheme ? ” “[0-i] Yes — rather — [I]0-i have been thinking of it some little time . ” [Emma]79-emma was sure [he]88-mr. knightley had not forgiven [her]79-emma ; [he]88-mr. knightley looked unlike [himself]88-mr. knightley . Time , however , [she]79-emma thought , would tell [him]88-mr. knightley that [they]5271-they ought to be [friends]3230-friends again . While [he]88-mr. knightley stood , as if meaning to go , but not going — [[her]79-emma father]415-her father began [his]0-i inquiries . “[0-i] Well , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , and did [you]2696-you get [there]437-there safely?—And how did [you]2696-you find [[my]0-i worthy old friend]2700-my worthy old friend and [[her]2700-my worthy old friend daughter?—I]2701-her daughter?—i dare say [they]2702-they must have been very much obliged to [you]2696-you for coming . [Dear Emma]79-emma has been to call on [Mrs.]2703-mrs. and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , as [I]0-i told [you]2696-you before . [She]79-emma is always so attentive to [them]2702-they ! ” [Emma]79-emma ’s colour was heightened by this unjust praise ; and with a smile , and shake of the head , which spoke much , [she]79-emma looked at [Mr. Knightley.—It]326-mr. knightley.—it seemed as if there were an instantaneous impression in [her]79-emma favour , as if [his]88-mr. knightley eyes received the truth from [hers]79-emma , and all that had passed of good in [her]79-emma feelings were at once caught and honoured . — [He]88-mr. knightley looked at [her]79-emma with a glow of regard . [She]79-emma was warmly gratified — and in another moment still more so , by a little movement of more than common friendliness on [his]88-mr. knightley part.—He took [her]79-emma hand;—whether [she]79-emma had not [herself]79-emma made the first motion , [she]79-emma could not say — [she]79-emma might , perhaps , have rather offered it — but [he]88-mr. knightley took [her]79-emma hand , pressed it , and certainly was on the point of carrying it to [his]88-mr. knightley lips — when , from some fancy or other , [he]88-mr. knightley suddenly let it go.—Why [he]88-mr. knightley should feel such a scruple , why [he]88-mr. knightley should change [his]88-mr. knightley mind when it was all but done , [she]79-emma could not perceive.—He would have judged better , [she]79-emma thought , if [he]88-mr. knightley had not stopped.—The intention , however , was indubitable ; and whether it was that [his]88-mr. knightley manners had in general so little gallantry , or however else it happened , but [she]79-emma thought nothing became [him]88-mr. knightley more.—It was with [him]88-mr. knightley , of so simple , yet so dignified a nature.—She could not but recall the attempt with great satisfaction . It spoke such perfect amity.—He left [them]5274-them immediately afterwards — gone in a moment . [He]88-mr. knightley always moved with the alertness of a mind which could neither be undecided nor dilatory , but now [he]88-mr. knightley seemed more sudden than usual in [his]88-mr. knightley disappearance . [Emma]79-emma could not regret [her]79-emma having gone to [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , but [she]79-emma wished [she]79-emma had left [her]79-emma ten minutes earlier;—it would have been a great pleasure to talk over [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s situation with [Mr. Knightley.—Neither]327-mr. knightley.—neither would [she]79-emma regret that [he]88-mr. knightley should be going to [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square , for [she]79-emma knew how much [his]88-mr. knightley visit would be enjoyed — but it might have happened at a better time — and to have had longer notice of it , would have been pleasanter.—They parted [thorough friends]5275-thorough friends , however ; [she]79-emma could not be deceived as to the meaning of [his]88-mr. knightley countenance , and [his]88-mr. knightley unfinished gallantry;—it was all done to assure [her]79-emma that [she]79-emma had fully recovered [his]88-mr. knightley good opinion.—He had been sitting with [them]5276-them half an hour , [she]79-emma found . It was a pity that [she]79-emma had not come back earlier ! In the hope of diverting [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s thoughts from the disagreeableness of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s going to [London]1-london ; and going so suddenly ; and going on horseback , which [she]79-emma knew would be all very bad ; [Emma]79-emma communicated [her]79-emma news of [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , and [her]79-emma dependence on the effect was justified ; it supplied a very useful check,—interested , without disturbing [him]88-mr. knightley . [He]88-mr. knightley had long made up [his]88-mr. knightley mind to [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s going out as [governess]401-governess , and could talk of it cheerfully , but [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s going to [London]1-london had been an unexpected blow . “[79-emma] [I]0-i am very glad , indeed , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , to hear [she]3120-my dear is to be so comfortably settled . [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton is very good - natured and agreeable , and [I]0-i dare say [her]3120-my dear acquaintance are just what they ought to be . [I]0-i hope it is a dry situation , and that [her]3120-my dear health will be taken good care of . It ought to be a first object , as [I]0-i am sure poor [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ’s always was with [me]0-i . [You]3120-my dear know , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , [she]3120-my dear is going to be to [this new lady]2706-this new lady what [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor was to [us]2707-us . And [I]0-i hope [she]3120-my dear will be better off in one respect , and not be induced to go away after it has been [her]3120-my dear home so long . ” The following day brought news from [Richmond]62-richmond to throw every thing else into the background . An express arrived at [Randalls]97-randalls to announce the death of [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill ! Though [[her]94-mrs. churchill nephew]1441-her nephew had had no particular reason to hasten back on [her]94-mrs. churchill account , [she]94-mrs. churchill had not lived above six - and - thirty hours after [his]1441-her nephew return . A sudden seizure of a different nature from any thing foreboded by [her]94-mrs. churchill general state , had carried [her]94-mrs. churchill off after a short struggle . [The great Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill was no more . It was felt as such things must be felt . Every body had a degree of gravity and sorrow ; tenderness towards [the departed]5280-the departed , solicitude for [the surviving friends]5281-the surviving friends ; and , in a reasonable time , curiosity to know where [she]94-mrs. churchill would be buried . [Goldsmith]329-goldsmith tells [us]5282-us , that when [lovely woman]3464-lovely woman stoops to folly , [she]3464-lovely woman has nothing to do but to die ; and when [she]3464-lovely woman stoops to be disagreeable , it is equally to be recommended as a clearer of ill - fame . [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill , after being disliked at least twenty - five years , was now spoken of with compassionate allowances . In one point [she]94-mrs. churchill was fully justified . [She]94-mrs. churchill had never been admitted before to be seriously ill . The event acquitted [her]94-mrs. churchill of all the fancifulness , and all the selfishness of imaginary complaints . “[94-mrs. churchill] [Poor Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill ! no doubt [she]94-mrs. churchill had been suffering a great deal : more than any body had ever supposed — and continual pain would try the temper . It was a sad event — a great shock — with all [her]94-mrs. churchill faults , what would [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill do without [her]94-mrs. churchill ? [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s loss would be dreadful indeed . [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill would never get over it . ”—Even [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston shook [his]82-mr. weston head , and looked solemn , and said , “[98-frank churchill] Ah ! [poor woman , who would have thought it]2708-poor woman , who would have thought it ! ” and resolved , that [his]98-frank churchill mourning should be as handsome as possible ; and [[his]98-frank churchill wife]3168-his wife sat sighing and moralising over [her]3168-his wife broad hems with a commiseration and good sense , true and steady . How it would affect [Frank]98-frank churchill was among the earliest thoughts of both . It was also a very early speculation with [Emma]79-emma . The character of [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill , the grief of [[her]94-mrs. churchill husband]431-her husband — [her]79-emma mind glanced over [them]5286-their both with awe and compassion — and then rested with lightened feelings on how [Frank]98-frank churchill might be affected by the event , how benefited , how freed . [She]79-emma saw in a moment all the possible good . Now , an attachment to [Harriet Smith]107-harriet would have nothing to encounter . [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill , independent of [[his]98-frank churchill wife]3168-his wife , was feared by [nobody]3124-nobody ; [an easy , guidable man]5289-an easy , guidable man , to be persuaded into any thing by [[his]98-frank churchill nephew]2054-his nephew . All that remained to be wished was , that [the nephew]1355-the nephew should form the attachment , as , with all [her]79-emma goodwill in the cause , [Emma]79-emma could feel no certainty of its being already formed . [Harriet]107-harriet behaved extremely well on the occasion , with great self - command . What ever [she]107-harriet might feel of brighter hope , [she]107-harriet betrayed nothing . [Emma]79-emma was gratified , to observe such a proof in [her]107-harriet of strengthened character , and refrained from any allusion that might endanger its maintenance . [They]5286-their spoke , therefore , of [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill ’s death with mutual forbearance . Short letters from [Frank]98-frank churchill were received at [Randalls]97-randalls , communicating all that was immediately important of [their]5286-their state and plans . [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill was better than could be expected ; and [their]5286-their first removal , on the departure of the funeral for [Yorkshire]50-yorkshire , was to be to [the house of [a very old friend in [Windsor]72-windsor , to whom [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill had been promising a visit the last ten years]5293-a very old friend in windsor , to whom mr. churchill had been promising a visit the last ten years]5292-the house of a very old friend in windsor , to whom mr. churchill had been promising a visit the last ten years . At present , there was nothing to be done for [Harriet]107-harriet ; good wishes for the future were all that could yet be possible on [Emma]79-emma ’s side . It was a more pressing concern to [shew]5294-shew attention to [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , whose prospects were closing , while [Harriet]107-harriet ’s opened , and whose engagements now allowed of no delay in any one at [Highbury]3-highbury , who wished to shew [her]79-emma kindness — and with [Emma]79-emma it was grown into a first wish . [She]79-emma had scarcely a stronger regret than for [her]79-emma past coldness ; and [the person , whom [she]79-emma had been so many months neglecting]5295-the person , whom she had been so many months neglecting , was now the very one on whom [she]79-emma would have lavished every distinction of regard or sympathy . [She]79-emma wanted to be of use to [her]79-emma ; wanted to shew a value for [her]79-emma society , and testify respect and consideration . [She]79-emma resolved to prevail on [her]79-emma to spend a day at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . A note was written to urge it . The invitation was refused , and by a verbal message . “[98-frank churchill] [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax was not well enough to write ; ” and when [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry called at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , the same morning , it appeared that [she]142-miss fairfax was so much indisposed as to have been visited , though against [her]142-miss fairfax own consent , by [himself]102-mr. perry , and that [she]142-miss fairfax was suffering under severe headaches , and a nervous fever to a degree , which made [him]102-mr. perry doubt the possibility of [her]142-miss fairfax going to [Mrs. Smallridge]322-mrs. smallridge ’s at the time proposed . [Her]142-miss fairfax health seemed for the moment completely deranged — appetite quite gone — and though there were no absolutely alarming symptoms , nothing touching the pulmonary complaint , which was the standing apprehension of [the family]423-the family , [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry was uneasy about [her]142-miss fairfax . [He]102-mr. perry thought [she]142-miss fairfax had undertaken more than [she]142-miss fairfax was equal to , and that [she]142-miss fairfax felt it so [herself]142-miss fairfax , though [she]142-miss fairfax would not own it . [Her]142-miss fairfax spirits seemed overcome . [[Her]142-miss fairfax present home]5297-her present home , [he]102-mr. perry could not but observe , was unfavourable to a nervous disorder:—confined always to one room;—he could have wished it otherwise — and [[her]142-miss fairfax good aunt]5298-her good aunt , though [[his]102-mr. perry very old friend]5299-his very old friend , [he]102-mr. perry must acknowledge to be not the best companion for [an invalid of that description]5300-an invalid of that description . [Her]142-miss fairfax care and attention could not be questioned ; they were , in fact , only too great . [He]102-mr. perry very much feared that [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax derived more evil than good from [them]5301-them . [Emma]79-emma listened with the warmest concern ; grieved for [her]142-miss fairfax more and more , and looked around eager to discover some way of being useful . To take [her]142-miss fairfax — be it only an hour or two — from [[her]142-miss fairfax aunt]1061-her aunt , to give [her]142-miss fairfax change of air and scene , and quiet rational conversation , even for an hour or two , might do [her]142-miss fairfax good ; and the following morning [she]79-emma wrote again to say , in the most feeling language [she]79-emma could command , that [she]79-emma would call for [her]142-miss fairfax in [the carriage]3125-the carriage at any hour that [Jane]142-miss fairfax would name — mentioning that [she]79-emma had [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry ’s decided opinion , in favour of such exercise for [[his]102-mr. perry patient]5304-his patient . The answer was only in this short note : “[142-miss fairfax] [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s compliments and thanks , but is quite unequal to any exercise . ” [Emma]79-emma felt that [her]79-emma own note had deserved something better ; but it was impossible to quarrel with words , whose tremulous inequality shewed indisposition so plainly , and [she]79-emma thought only of how [she]79-emma might best counteract this unwillingness to be seen or assisted . In spite of the answer , therefore , [she]79-emma ordered [the carriage]3125-the carriage , and drove to [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates ’s , in the hope that [Jane]142-miss fairfax would be induced to join [her]79-emma — but it would not do;—Miss [Bates]106-mrs. bates came to the carriage door , all gratitude , and agreeing with [her]79-emma most earnestly in thinking an airing might be of the greatest service — and every thing that message could do was tried — but all in vain . [Miss Bates]101-miss bates was obliged to return without success ; [Jane]101-miss bates was quite unpersuadable ; the mere proposal of going out seemed to make [her]79-emma worse.—Emma wished [she]79-emma could have seen [her]101-miss bates , and tried [her]79-emma own powers ; but , almost before [she]79-emma could hint the wish , [Miss Bates]101-miss bates made it appear that [she]79-emma had promised [[her]79-emma niece]3833-her niece on no account to let [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor in . “[142-miss fairfax] Indeed , the truth was , that poor dear [Jane]101-miss bates could not bear to see any body — any body at all — [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , indeed , could not be denied — and [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole had made such a point — and [Mrs. Perry]100-mrs. perry had said so much — but , except [them]2709-them , [Jane]101-miss bates would really see [nobody]3124-nobody . ” [Emma]79-emma did not want to be classed with [the Mrs. Eltons]331-the eltons , [the Mrs. Perrys]103-the little perrys , and [the Mrs. Coles]175-the coles , who would force [themselves]2709-them anywhere ; neither could [she]79-emma feel any right of preference [herself]79-emma — [she]79-emma submitted , therefore , and only questioned [Miss Bates]101-miss bates farther as to [[her]79-emma niece]3833-her niece ’s appetite and diet , which [she]79-emma longed to be able to assist . On that subject poor [Miss Bates]101-miss bates was very unhappy , and very communicative ; [Jane]101-miss bates would hardly eat any thing:—Mr . [Perry]100-mrs. perry recommended nourishing food ; but every thing [they]2709-them could command ( and never had any body such [good neighbours]3273-good neighbours ) was distasteful . [Emma]79-emma , on reaching [home]3258-home , called [the housekeeper]3524-the housekeeper directly , to an examination of [[her]3524-the housekeeper stores]5311-her stores ; and some arrowroot of very superior quality was speedily despatched to [Miss Bates]101-miss bates with a most friendly note . In half an hour the arrowroot was returned , with a thousand thanks from [Miss Bates]101-miss bates , but “[101-miss bates] [dear Jane]101-miss bates would not be satisfied without its being sent back ; it was a thing [she]101-miss bates could not take — and , moreover , [she]101-miss bates insisted on [her]101-miss bates saying , that [she]101-miss bates was not at all in want of any thing . ” When [Emma]79-emma afterwards heard that [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax had been seen wandering about [the meadows]5312-the meadows , at some distance from [Highbury]3-highbury , on the afternoon of the very day on which [she]142-miss fairfax had , under the plea of being unequal to any exercise , so peremptorily refused to go out with [her]142-miss fairfax in [the carriage]3125-the carriage , [she]79-emma could have no doubt — putting every thing together — that [Jane]142-miss fairfax was resolved to receive no kindness from [her]142-miss fairfax . [She]79-emma was sorry , very sorry . [Her]79-emma heart was grieved for a state which seemed but the more pitiable from this sort of irritation of spirits , inconsistency of action , and inequality of powers ; and it mortified [her]79-emma that [she]79-emma was given so little credit for proper feeling , or esteemed so little worthy as [a friend]405-a friend : but [she]79-emma had the consolation of knowing that [her]79-emma intentions were good , and of being able to say to [herself]79-emma , that could [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley have been privy to all [her]79-emma attempts of assisting [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , could [he]88-mr. knightley even have seen into [her]79-emma heart , [he]88-mr. knightley would not , on this occasion , have found any thing to reprove . CHAPTER X One morning , about ten days after [Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill ’s decease , [Emma]79-emma was called [downstairs]1683-downstairs to [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , who “[101-miss bates] could not stay five minutes , and wanted particularly to speak with [her]2711-her . [”—He]82-mr. weston met [her]2711-her at the parlour - door , and hardly asking [her]2711-her how [she]2711-her did , in the natural key of [his]82-mr. weston voice , sunk it immediately , to say , unheard by [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , “[101-miss bates] Can [you]2712-you come to [Randalls]97-randalls at any time this morning?—Do , if it be possible . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston wants to see [you]2712-you . [She]84-mrs. weston must see [you]2712-you . ” “[84-mrs. weston] Is [she]84-mrs. weston unwell ? ” “[84-mrs. weston] No , no , not at all — only a little agitated . [She]84-mrs. weston would have ordered [the carriage]3125-the carriage , and come to [you]2712-you , but [she]84-mrs. weston must see [you]2712-you alone , and that [you]2712-you know—(nodding towards [her]84-mrs. weston father)—Humph!—Can [you]2712-you come ? ” “[2712-you] Certainly . This moment , if [you]2712-you please . It is impossible to refuse what [you]2712-you ask in such a way . But what can be the matter?—Is [she]84-mrs. weston really not ill ? ” “[84-mrs. weston] Depend upon [me]0-i — but ask no more questions . [You]2712-you will know it all in time . The most unaccountable business ! But hush , hush ! ” To guess what all this meant , was impossible even for [Emma]79-emma . Something really important seemed announced by [his]0-i looks ; but , as [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend was well , [she]79-emma endeavoured not to be uneasy , and settling it with [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , that [she]79-emma would take [her]79-emma walk now , [she]79-emma and [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston were soon out of [the house]425-the house together and on [their]5320-their way at a quick pace for [Randalls]97-randalls . “[2712-you] Now,”—said [Emma]79-emma , when [they]5320-their were fairly beyond the sweep gates,—“now[82-mr. weston] [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , do let [me]0-i know what has happened . ” “[82-mr. weston] No , no,”—he gravely replied.—“Don’t[0-i] ask [me]0-i . [I]0-i promised [[my]0-i wife]2607-my wife to leave it all to [her]2607-my wife . [She]2607-my wife will break it to [you]0-i better than [I]0-i can . Do not be impatient , [Emma]79-emma ; it will all come out too soon . ” “[79-emma] Break it to [me]0-i , ” cried [Emma]79-emma , standing still with [terror.—“Good[79-emma] God!—Mr . Weston]82-mr. weston , tell [me]0-i at once.—Something has happened in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square . [I]0-i know it has . Tell [me]0-i , [I]0-i charge [you]82-mr. weston tell [me]0-i this moment what it is . ” “[82-mr. weston] No , indeed [you]82-mr. weston are mistaken . ” — “[82-mr. weston] [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston do not trifle with me.—Consider how many of [[my]0-i dearest friends]2715-my dearest friends are now in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square . Which of [them]2716-them is it?—I charge [you]0-i by all that is sacred , not to attempt concealment . ” “[0-i] Upon [my]0-i word , [Emma]79-emma . ” — “[0-i] [Your]0-i word!—why not [your]0-i honour!—why not say upon [your]0-i honour , that it has nothing to do with any of [them]2716-them ? [Good Heavens!—What]332-good heavens!—what can be to be broke to [me]0-i , that does not relate to [one of [that family]2718-that family]2717-one of that family ? ” “[0-i] Upon [my]0-i honour , ” said [he]0-i very seriously , “[0-i] it does not . It is not in the smallest degree connected with [any human being of the name of Knightley]2719-any human being of the name of knightley . ” [Emma]79-emma ’s courage returned , and [she]79-emma walked on . “[0-i] [I]0-i was wrong , ” [he]0-i continued , “[0-i] in talking of its being broke to [you]79-emma . [I]0-i should not have used the expression . In fact , it does not concern [you]79-emma — it concerns only [myself,—that]2720-myself,—that is , [we]2721-we hope.—Humph!—In short , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , there is no occasion to be so uneasy about it . [I]0-i do n’t say that it is not a disagreeable business — but things might be much worse.—If [we]2721-we walk fast , [we]2721-we shall soon be at [Randalls]97-randalls . ” [Emma]79-emma found that [she]79-emma must wait ; and now it required little effort . [She]79-emma asked no more questions therefore , merely employed [her]79-emma own fancy , and that soon pointed out to [her]79-emma the probability of its being some money concern — something just come to light , of a disagreeable nature in the circumstances of the family,—something which the late event at [Richmond]62-richmond had brought forward . [Her]79-emma fancy was very active . [Half a dozen natural children]5321-half a dozen natural children , perhaps — and poor [Frank]98-frank churchill cut off!—This , though very undesirable , would be no matter of agony to [her]79-emma . It inspired little more than an animating curiosity . “[2723-that gentleman on horseback] Who is [that gentleman on horseback]2723-that gentleman on horseback ? ” said [she]79-emma , as [they]5322-they proceeded — speaking more to assist [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston in keeping [his]82-mr. weston secret , than with any other view . “[2723-that gentleman on horseback] [I]0-i do not know.—One of [the Otways.—Not Frank;—it]333-the otways.—not frank;—it is not [Frank]98-frank churchill , [I]0-i assure [you]2724-you . [You]2724-you will not see [him]98-frank churchill . [He]98-frank churchill is half way to [Windsor]72-windsor by this time . ” “[98-frank churchill] Has [[your]0-i son]1340-your son been with [you]0-i , then ? ” “[98-frank churchill] Oh ! yes — did not [you]0-i know?—Well , well , never mind . ” For a moment [he]0-i was silent ; and then added , in a tone much more guarded and demure , “[98-frank churchill] Yes , [Frank]98-frank churchill came over this morning , just to ask [us]2726-they how [we]2726-they did . ” [They]2726-they hurried on , and were speedily at [Randalls.—“Well]334-randalls.—“well[98-frank churchill] , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear , ” said [he]0-i , as [they]2726-they entered the room—“I[1340-your son] have brought [her]1340-your son , and now [I]0-i hope [you]3120-my dear will soon be better . [I]0-i shall leave [you]3120-my dear together . There is no use in delay . [I]0-i shall not be far off , if [you]3120-my dear want [me]0-i . ”—And [Emma]79-emma distinctly heard [him]0-i add , in a lower tone , before [he]0-i quitted the room,—“I[0-i] have been as good as [my]0-i word . [She]1340-your son has not the least idea . ” [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was looking so ill , and had an air of so much perturbation , that [Emma]79-emma ’s uneasiness increased ; and the moment [they]2729-they were alone , [she]84-mrs. weston eagerly said , “[1340-your son] What is it [[my]0-i dear friend]2728-my dear friend ? Something of a very unpleasant nature , [I]0-i find , has occurred;—do let [me]0-i know directly what it is . [I]0-i have been walking all this way in complete suspense . [We]2729-they both abhor suspense . Do not let [mine]0-i continue longer . It will do [you]3120-my dear good to speak of [your]3120-my dear distress , whatever it may be . ” “[3120-my dear] Have [you]3120-my dear indeed no idea ? ” said [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston in a trembling voice . “[3120-my dear] Can not [you]3120-my dear , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma — cannot [you]3120-my dear form a guess as to what [you]3120-my dear are to hear ? ” “[3120-my dear] So far as that it relates to [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , [I]0-i do guess . ” “[98-frank churchill] [You]0-i are right . It does relate to [him]98-frank churchill , and [I]0-i will tell [you]3120-my dear directly ; ” ( resuming [her]84-mrs. weston work , and seeming resolved against looking up . ) “[0-i] [He]98-frank churchill has been [here]3113-here this very morning , on a most extraordinary errand . It is impossible to express [our]2732-our surprize . [He]98-frank churchill came to speak to [[his]98-frank churchill father]3213-his father on a subject,—to announce an attachment — ” [She]84-mrs. weston stopped to breathe . [Emma]79-emma thought first of [herself]79-emma , and then of [Harriet]107-harriet . “[98-frank churchill] More than an attachment , indeed , ” resumed [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ; “[3120-my dear] an engagement — a positive engagement.—What will [you]3120-my dear say , [Emma]79-emma — what will [any body]530-any body say , when it is known that [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill and [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax are engaged;—nay , that [they]2735-they have been long engaged ! ” [Emma]79-emma even jumped with [surprize;—and]5323-surprize;—and , horror - struck , exclaimed , “[2735-they] [Jane Fairfax!—Good God]178-god ! [You]79-emma are not serious ? [You]79-emma do not mean it ? ” “[79-emma] [You]3120-my dear may well be amazed , ” returned [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , still averting [her]84-mrs. weston eyes , and talking on with eagerness , that [Emma]79-emma might have time to recover — “[3120-my dear] [You]3120-my dear may well be amazed . But it is even so . There has been a solemn engagement between [them]2735-they ever since October — formed at [Weymouth]26-weymouth , and kept a secret from every body . Not a creature knowing it but [themselves]2735-they — neither [the Campbells]180-the campbells , nor [[her]142-miss fairfax family]578-her family , nor his.—It is so wonderful , that though perfectly convinced of the fact , it is yet almost incredible to [myself]0-i . [I]0-i can hardly believe [it.—I]0-i thought [I]0-i knew [him]2737-him . ” [Emma]79-emma scarcely heard what was said.—Her mind was divided between two ideas — [her]79-emma own former conversations with [him]2737-him about [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ; and [poor Harriet;—and]335-poor harriet;—and for some time [she]79-emma could only exclaim , and require confirmation , repeated confirmation . “[2737-him] Well , ” said [she]79-emma at last , trying to recover [herself]79-emma ; “[2737-him] this is a circumstance which [I]0-i must think of at least half a day , before [I]0-i can at all comprehend it . What!—engaged to [her]142-miss fairfax all the winter — before [either of [them]2739-them]2738-either of them came to [Highbury]3-highbury ? ” “[2737-him] Engaged since October,—secretly engaged.—It has hurt [me]0-i , [Emma]79-emma , very much . It has hurt [[his]2737-him father]3213-his father equally . Some part of [his]2737-him conduct [we]2741-we can not excuse . ” [Emma]79-emma pondered a moment , and then replied , “[2737-him] [I]0-i will not pretend not to understand [you]79-emma ; and to give [you]79-emma all the relief in [my]0-i power , be assured that no such effect has followed [his]2737-him attentions to [me]0-i , as [you]79-emma are apprehensive of . ” [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston looked up , afraid to believe ; but [Emma]79-emma ’s countenance was as steady as [her]79-emma words . “[79-emma] That [you]79-emma may have less difficulty in believing this boast , of [my]0-i present perfect indifference , ” [she]79-emma continued , “[0-i] [I]0-i will farther tell [you]79-emma , that there was a period in the early part of [our]2741-we acquaintance , when [I]0-i did like [him]2737-him , when [I]0-i was very much disposed to be attached to [him]2737-him — nay , was attached — and how it came to cease , is perhaps the wonder . Fortunately , however , it did cease . [I]0-i have really for some time past , for at least these three months , cared nothing about [him]2737-him . [You]79-emma may believe [me]0-i , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . This is the simple truth . ” [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston kissed [her]84-mrs. weston with tears of joy ; and when [she]84-mrs. weston could find utterance , assured [her]84-mrs. weston , that this protestation had done [her]84-mrs. weston more good than any thing else in [the world]392-the world could do . “[84-mrs. weston] [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston will be almost as much relieved as [myself]0-i , ” said [she]84-mrs. weston . “[82-mr. weston] On this point [we]2741-we have been wretched . It was [our]2741-we darling wish that [you]79-emma might be attached to [each other]420-each other — and [we]2741-we were persuaded that it was so . — Imagine what [we]2741-we have been feeling on [your]79-emma account . ” “[2741-we] [I]0-i have escaped ; and that [I]0-i should escape , may be a matter of grateful wonder to [you]79-emma and [myself]0-i . But this does not acquit [him]82-mr. weston , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ; and [I]0-i must say , that [I]0-i think [him]82-mr. weston greatly to blame . What right had [he]82-mr. weston to come among [us]2741-we with affection and faith engaged , and with manners so very disengaged ? What right had [he]82-mr. weston to endeavour to please , as [he]82-mr. weston certainly did — to distinguish [any one young woman with persevering attention]2743-any one young woman with persevering attention , as [he]82-mr. weston certainly did — while [he]82-mr. weston really belonged to [another?—How]2744-another?—how could [he]82-mr. weston tell what mischief [he]82-mr. weston might be doing?—How could [he]82-mr. weston tell that [he]82-mr. weston might not be making [me]0-i in love with [him?—very]2745-him?—very wrong , very wrong indeed . ” “[82-mr. weston] From something that [he]82-mr. weston said , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , [I]0-i rather imagine — ” “[82-mr. weston] And how could [she]2747-she bear such behaviour ! Composure with [a witness]2748-a witness ! to look on , while repeated attentions were offering to [another woman]4095-another woman , before [her]2747-she face , and not resent it.—That is a degree of placidity , which [I]0-i can neither comprehend nor respect . ” “[82-mr. weston] There were misunderstandings between [them]2750-them , [Emma]79-emma ; [he]82-mr. weston said so expressly . [He]82-mr. weston had not time to enter into much explanation . [He]82-mr. weston was here only a quarter of an hour , and in a state of agitation which did not allow the full use even of the time [he]82-mr. weston could stay — but that there had been misunderstandings [he]82-mr. weston decidedly said . The present crisis , indeed , seemed to be brought on by [them]2751-them ; and those misunderstandings might very possibly arise from the impropriety of [his]82-mr. weston conduct . ” “[82-mr. weston] Impropriety ! Oh ! [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston — it is too calm a censure . Much , much beyond impropriety!—It has sunk [him]82-mr. weston , [I]0-i can not say how it has sunk [him]82-mr. weston in [my]0-i opinion . So unlike what [a man should be!—None of that upright integrity]2752-a man should be!—none of that upright integrity , that strict adherence to truth and principle , that disdain of trick and littleness , which [a man]548-a man should display in every transaction of [his]548-a man life . ” “[82-mr. weston] Nay , [dear Emma]2754-dear emma , now [I]0-i must take [his]82-mr. weston part ; for though [he]82-mr. weston has been wrong in this instance , [I]0-i have known [him]82-mr. weston long enough to answer for [his]82-mr. weston having many , very many , good qualities ; and — ” “[2755-good god] [Good God]2755-good god ! ” cried [Emma]79-emma , not attending to her.—“Mrs[2755-good god] . [Smallridge]322-mrs. smallridge , too ! [Jane]142-miss fairfax actually on the point of going as [governess]401-governess ! What could [he]82-mr. weston mean by such horrible indelicacy ? To suffer [her]142-miss fairfax to engage [herself]142-miss fairfax — to suffer [her]142-miss fairfax even to think of such a measure ! ” “[82-mr. weston] [He]82-mr. weston knew nothing about it , [Emma]79-emma . On this article [I]0-i can fully acquit [him]82-mr. weston . It was a private resolution of hers , not communicated to [him]82-mr. weston — or at least not communicated in a way to carry conviction.—Till yesterday , [I]0-i know [he]82-mr. weston said [he]82-mr. weston was in the dark as to [her]142-miss fairfax plans . [They]2757-they burst on [him]82-mr. weston , [I]0-i do not know how , but by some letter or message — and it was the discovery of what [she]142-miss fairfax was doing , of this very project of [hers]142-miss fairfax , which determined [him]82-mr. weston to come forward at once , own it all to [[his]82-mr. weston uncle]3212-his uncle , throw [himself]82-mr. weston on [his]82-mr. weston kindness , and , in short , put an end to the miserable state of concealment that had been carrying on so long . ” [Emma]79-emma began to listen better . “[82-mr. weston] [I]0-i am to hear from [him]82-mr. weston soon , ” continued [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . “[82-mr. weston] [He]82-mr. weston told [me]0-i at parting , that [he]82-mr. weston should soon write ; and [he]82-mr. weston spoke in a manner which seemed to promise [me]0-i many particulars that could not be given now . Let [us]2759-us wait , therefore , for this letter . It may bring many extenuations . It may make many things intelligible and excusable which now are not to be understood . Do n’t let [us]2759-us be severe , do n’t let [us]2759-us be in a hurry to condemn [him]82-mr. weston . Let [us]2759-us have patience . [I]0-i must love [him]82-mr. weston ; and now that [I]0-i am satisfied on one point , the one material point , [I]0-i am sincerely anxious for its all turning out well , and ready to hope that it may . [They]2760-they must both have suffered a great deal under such a system of secresy and concealment . ” “[82-mr. weston] [His]82-mr. weston sufferings , ” replied [Emma]79-emma dryly , “[82-mr. weston] do not appear to have done [him]82-mr. weston much harm . Well , and how did [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill take it ? ” “[98-frank churchill] Most favourably for [[his]98-frank churchill nephew]2054-his nephew — gave [his]82-mr. weston consent with scarcely a difficulty . Conceive what the events of a week have done in [that family]2718-that family ! While [poor Mrs. Churchill]94-mrs. churchill lived , [I]0-i suppose there could not have been a hope , a chance , a possibility;—but scarcely are [her]94-mrs. churchill remains at rest in [the family vault]2763-the family vault , than [[her]94-mrs. churchill husband]431-her husband is persuaded to act exactly opposite to what [she]94-mrs. churchill would have required . What a blessing it is , when undue influence does not survive [the grave!—He]2765-the grave!—he gave [his]82-mr. weston consent with very little persuasion . ” “[82-mr. weston] Ah ! ” thought [Emma]79-emma , “[82-mr. weston] [he]82-mr. weston would have done as much for [Harriet]107-harriet . ” “[82-mr. weston] This was settled last night , and [Frank]98-frank churchill was off with the light this morning . [He]98-frank churchill stopped at [Highbury]3-highbury , at [the [Bates]101-miss bates ’s]2766-the bates ’s , [I]0-i fancy , some time — and then came on hither ; but was in such a hurry to get back to [[his]98-frank churchill uncle]3212-his uncle , to whom [he]98-frank churchill is just now more necessary than ever , that , as [I]0-i tell [you]2768-you , [he]98-frank churchill could stay with [us]2769-us but a quarter of an hour.—He was very much agitated — very much , indeed — to a degree that made [him]98-frank churchill appear quite a different creature from any thing [I]0-i had ever seen [him]98-frank churchill before.—In addition to all the rest , there had been the shock of finding [her]107-harriet so very unwell , which [he]98-frank churchill had had no previous suspicion of — and there was every appearance of [his]98-frank churchill having been feeling a great deal . ” “[98-frank churchill] And do [you]2770-you really believe the affair to have been carrying on with such perfect [secresy?—The Campbells]180-the campbells , [the Dixons]184-the dixons , did [none of [them]2772-them]2771-none of them know of the engagement ? ” [Emma]79-emma could not speak the name of [Dixon]181-mrs. dixon without a little blush . “[2771-none of them] None ; [not one]2773-not one . [He]98-frank churchill positively said that it had been known to no being in [the world]392-the world but [[their]2775-their two selves]2452-their two selves . ” “[98-frank churchill] Well , ” said [Emma]79-emma , “[98-frank churchill] [I]0-i suppose [we]2777-us shall gradually grow reconciled to the idea , and [I]0-i wish [them]2772-them very happy . But [I]0-i shall always think it a very abominable sort of proceeding . What has it been but a system of hypocrisy and deceit,—espionage , and treachery?—To come among [us]2777-us with professions of openness and simplicity ; and such a league in secret to judge [us]2777-us all!—Here have [we]2777-us been , the whole winter and spring , completely duped , fancying [ourselves]2777-us all on an equal footing of truth and honour , with [two people in the midst of [us]2777-us [who may have been carrying round , comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both]2779-who may have been carrying round , comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both to hear.—They]2778-two people in the midst of us who may have been carrying round , comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both to hear.—they must take the consequence , if [they]2772-them have heard [each other]420-each other spoken of in a way not perfectly agreeable ! ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am quite easy on that head , ” replied [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . “[0-i] [I]0-i am very sure that [I]0-i never said any thing of either to [the other]3423-the other , which [both]2160-both might not have heard . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i are in luck.—Your only blunder was confined to [my]0-i ear , when [you]0-i imagined [a certain friend of [ours]2777-us in love with [the lady]774-the lady]2783-a certain friend of ours in love with the lady . ” “[0-i] True . But as [I]0-i have always had a thoroughly good opinion of [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , [I]0-i never could , under any blunder , have spoken ill of [her]142-miss fairfax ; and as to speaking ill of [him]2783-a certain friend of ours in love with the lady , there [I]0-i must have been safe . ” At this moment [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston appeared at a little distance from the window , evidently on the watch . [[His]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife gave [him]82-mr. weston a look which invited [him]82-mr. weston in ; and , while [he]82-mr. weston was coming round , added , “[0-i] Now , dearest [Emma]79-emma , let [me]0-i intreat [you]79-emma to say and look every thing that may set [his]2783-a certain friend of ours in love with the lady heart at ease , and incline [him]2783-a certain friend of ours in love with the lady to be satisfied with the match . Let [us]2777-us make the best of it — and , indeed , almost every thing may be fairly said in [her]774-the lady favour . It is not a connexion to gratify ; but if [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill does not feel that , why should [we]2777-us ? and it may be a very fortunate circumstance for [him]98-frank churchill , for [Frank]98-frank churchill , [I]0-i mean , that [he]98-frank churchill should have attached [himself]98-frank churchill to [a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment]2785-a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment as [I]0-i have always given [her]774-the lady credit for — and still am disposed to give [her]774-the lady credit for , in spite of this one great deviation from the strict rule of right . And how much may be said in [her]774-the lady situation for even that error ! ” “[336-jane fairfax’s.—of] Much , indeed ! ” cried [Emma]79-emma feelingly . “[336-jane fairfax’s.—of] If [a woman]3207-a woman can ever be excused for thinking only of [herself]3207-a woman , it is in a situation like [Jane Fairfax’s.—Of]336-jane fairfax’s.—of such , one may almost say , that ‘ [the world]392-the world is not [their]2788-their ’s , nor [the world]392-the world ’s law . ’ ” [She]79-emma met [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston on [his]82-mr. weston entrance , with a smiling countenance , exclaiming , “[2790-you] A very pretty trick [you]2790-you have been playing [me]0-i , upon [my]0-i word ! This was a device , [I]0-i suppose , to sport with [my]0-i curiosity , and exercise [my]0-i talent of guessing . But [you]2790-you really frightened [me]0-i . [I]0-i thought [you]2790-you had lost half [your]2790-you property , at least . And here , instead of its being a matter of condolence , it turns out to be one of congratulation.—I congratulate [you]2790-you , [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , with all [my]0-i heart , on the prospect of having [one of the most lovely and accomplished young women in [England]38-england for [[your]2790-you daughter]2792-your daughter]2791-one of the most lovely and accomplished young women in england for your daughter . ” A glance or two between [him]82-mr. weston and [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife , convinced [him]82-mr. weston that all was as right as this speech proclaimed ; and its happy effect on [his]82-mr. weston spirits was immediate . [His]82-mr. weston air and voice recovered [their]5327-their usual briskness : [he]82-mr. weston shook [her]3168-his wife heartily and gratefully by the hand , and entered on the subject in a manner to prove , that [he]82-mr. weston now only wanted time and persuasion to think the engagement no very bad thing . [[His]82-mr. weston companions]3777-his companions suggested only what could palliate imprudence , or smooth objections ; and by the time [they]3777-his companions had talked it all over together , and [he]82-mr. weston had talked it all over again with [Emma]79-emma , in [their]3777-his companions walk back to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [he]82-mr. weston was become perfectly reconciled , and not far from thinking it the very best thing that [Frank]98-frank churchill could possibly have done . CHAPTER XI “[107-harriet] [Harriet]107-harriet , [poor Harriet!”—Those]337-poor harriet!”—those were the words ; in them lay the tormenting ideas which [Emma]79-emma could not get rid of , and which constituted the real misery of the business to [her]79-emma . [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill had behaved very ill by [herself]98-frank churchill — very ill in many ways,—but it was not so much [his]82-mr. weston behaviour as [her]3168-his wife own , which made [her]3168-his wife so angry with [him]82-mr. weston . It was the scrape which [he]82-mr. weston had drawn [her]3168-his wife into on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s account , that gave the deepest hue to [his]82-mr. weston offence.—Poor [Harriet]107-harriet ! to be a second time the dupe of [her]3168-his wife misconceptions and flattery . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley had spoken prophetically , when [he]88-mr. knightley once said , “[337-poor harriet!”—those] [Emma]79-emma , [you]79-emma have been [no friend to [Harriet Smith]107-harriet]819-no friend to harriet smith . ”—She was afraid [she]3168-his wife had done [her]3168-his wife nothing but disservice.—It was true that [she]3168-his wife had not to charge [herself]3168-his wife , in this instance as in the former , with being [the sole and original author of the mischief]5329-the sole and original author of the mischief ; with having suggested such feelings as might otherwise never have entered [Harriet]107-harriet ’s imagination ; for [Harriet]107-harriet had acknowledged [her]107-harriet admiration and preference of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill before [she]107-harriet had ever given [her]107-harriet a hint on the subject ; but [she]107-harriet felt completely guilty of having encouraged what [she]107-harriet might have repressed . [She]107-harriet might have prevented the indulgence and increase of such sentiments . [Her]107-harriet influence would have been enough . And now [she]107-harriet was very conscious that [she]107-harriet ought to have prevented them.—She felt that [she]107-harriet had been risking [[her]107-harriet friend]417-her friend ’s happiness on most insufficient grounds . Common sense would have directed [her]107-harriet to tell [Harriet]107-harriet , that [she]107-harriet must not allow [herself]107-harriet to think of [him]417-her friend , and that there were five hundred chances to one against [his]417-her friend ever caring for her.—“But[79-emma] , with common sense , ” [she]107-harriet added , “[79-emma] [I]0-i am afraid [I]0-i have had little to do . ” [She]107-harriet was extremely angry with [herself]107-harriet . If [she]107-harriet could not have been angry with [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill too , it would have been dreadful.—As for [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , [she]107-harriet might at least relieve [her]107-harriet feelings from any present solicitude on [her]107-harriet account . [Harriet]107-harriet would be anxiety enough ; [she]107-harriet need no longer be unhappy about [Jane]142-miss fairfax , whose troubles and whose ill - health having , of course , the same origin , must be equally under cure.—Her days of insignificance and evil were over.—She would soon be well , and happy , and prosperous.—Emma could now imagine why [her]107-harriet own attentions had been slighted . This discovery laid many smaller matters open . No doubt it had been from [jealousy.—In Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s eyes [she]142-miss fairfax had been [a rival]5331-a rival ; and well might any thing [she]142-miss fairfax could offer of assistance or regard be repulsed . An airing in [the Hartfield carriage]5332-the hartfield carriage would have been the rack , and arrowroot from [the Hartfield storeroom]5333-the hartfield storeroom must have been poison . [She]107-harriet understood it all ; and as far as [her]107-harriet mind could disengage itself from the injustice and selfishness of angry feelings , [she]107-harriet acknowledged that [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax would have neither elevation nor happiness beyond [her]142-miss fairfax desert . But [poor Harriet]107-harriet was such an engrossing charge ! There was little sympathy to be spared for any body else . [Emma]79-emma was sadly fearful that this second disappointment would be more severe than the first . Considering the very superior claims of the object , it ought ; and judging by its apparently stronger effect on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s mind , producing reserve and self - command , it would.—She must communicate the painful truth , however , and as soon as possible . An injunction of secresy had been among [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s parting words . “[79-emma] For the present , the whole affair was to be completely a secret . [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill had made a point of it , as a token of respect to [the wife [he]98-frank churchill had so very recently lost]2794-the wife he had so very recently lost ; and [every body]3270-every body admitted it to be no more than due decorum . ”—Emma had promised ; but still [Harriet]107-harriet must be excepted . It was [her]107-harriet superior duty . In spite of [her]107-harriet vexation , [she]107-harriet could not help feeling it almost ridiculous , that [she]107-harriet should have the very same distressing and delicate office to perform by [Harriet]107-harriet , which [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston had just gone through by [herself]84-mrs. weston . The intelligence , which had been so anxiously announced to [her]107-harriet , [she]107-harriet was now to be anxiously announcing to [another]5334-another . [Her]107-harriet heart beat quick on hearing [Harriet]107-harriet ’s footstep and voice ; so , [she]107-harriet supposed , had poor [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston felt when [she]84-mrs. weston was approaching [Randalls]97-randalls . Could the event of the disclosure bear an equal resemblance!—But of that , unfortunately , there could be no chance . “[80-miss taylor] Well , [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor ! ” cried [Harriet]107-harriet , coming eagerly into the room—“is[80-miss taylor] not this the oddest news that ever was ? ” “[2796-you] What news do [you]2796-you mean ? ” replied [Emma]79-emma , unable to guess , by look or voice , whether [Harriet]107-harriet could indeed have received any hint . “[2796-you] About [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . Did [you]2796-you ever hear any thing so strange ? Oh!—you need not be afraid of owning it to [me]0-i , for [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston has told [me]0-i [himself]82-mr. weston . [I]0-i met [him]82-mr. weston just now . [He]82-mr. weston told [me]0-i it was to be a great secret ; and , therefore , [I]0-i should not think of mentioning it to any body but [you]2796-you , but [he]82-mr. weston said [you]2796-you knew it . ” “[82-mr. weston] What did [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston tell you?”—said [Emma]79-emma , still perplexed . “[82-mr. weston] Oh ! [he]82-mr. weston told [me]0-i all about it ; that [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill are to be married , and that [they]2797-they have been privately engaged to [one another]3150-one another this long while . How very odd ! ” It was , indeed , so odd ; [Harriet]107-harriet ’s behaviour was so extremely odd , that [Emma]79-emma did not know how to understand it . [Her]107-harriet character appeared absolutely changed . [She]107-harriet seemed to propose [shewing]5335-shewing no agitation , or disappointment , or peculiar concern in the discovery . [Emma]79-emma looked at [her]107-harriet , quite unable to speak . “[82-mr. weston] Had [you]2796-you any idea , ” cried [Harriet]107-harriet , “[142-miss fairfax] of [his]98-frank churchill being in love with her?—You , perhaps , might.—You ( blushing as [she]142-miss fairfax spoke ) who can see into every body ’s heart ; but [nobody else]1495-nobody else — ” “[142-miss fairfax] Upon [my]0-i word , ” said [Emma]79-emma , “[142-miss fairfax] [I]0-i begin to doubt [my]0-i having any such talent . Can [you]2796-you seriously ask [me]0-i , [Harriet]107-harriet , whether [I]0-i imagined [him]98-frank churchill attached to [another woman]4095-another woman at the very time that [I]0-i was — tacitly , if not openly — encouraging [you]2796-you to give way to [your]2796-you own feelings?—I never had the slightest suspicion , till within the last hour , of [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s having the least regard for [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . [You]2796-you may be very sure that if [I]0-i had , [I]0-i should have cautioned [you]2796-you accordingly . ” “[0-i] [Me]0-i ! ” cried [Harriet]107-harriet , colouring , and astonished . “[0-i] Why should [you]0-i caution me?—You do not think [I]0-i care about [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am delighted to hear [you]2796-you speak so stoutly on the subject , ” replied [Emma]79-emma , smiling ; “[2796-you] but [you]2796-you do not mean to deny that there was a time — and not very distant either — when [you]2796-you gave [me]0-i reason to understand that [you]2796-you did care about [him]98-frank churchill ? ” “[2796-you] [Him!—never]338-him!—never , never . [Dear Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , how could [you]0-i so mistake [me]0-i ? ” turning away distressed . “[107-harriet] [Harriet]107-harriet ! ” cried [Emma]79-emma , after a moment ’s pause—“What[107-harriet] do [you]107-harriet mean?—Good Heaven ! what do [you]107-harriet mean?—Mistake you!—Am [I]0-i to suppose then ? — ” [She]79-emma could not speak another word.—Her voice was lost ; and [she]79-emma sat down , waiting in great terror till [Harriet]107-harriet should answer . [Harriet]107-harriet , who was standing at some distance , and with face turned from [her]107-harriet , did not immediately say any thing ; and when [she]107-harriet did speak , it was in a voice nearly as agitated as [Emma]79-emma ’s . “[107-harriet] [I]0-i should not have thought it possible , ” [she]107-harriet began , “[107-harriet] that [you]0-i could have misunderstood [me]0-i ! [I]0-i know [we]2801-we agreed never to name [him]2802-him — but considering how infinitely superior [he]2802-him is to every body else , [I]0-i should not have thought it possible that [I]0-i could be supposed to mean [any other person]4152-any other person . [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , indeed ! [I]0-i do not know who would ever look at [him]2802-him in the company of the other . [I]0-i hope [I]0-i have a better taste than to think of [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , who is like nobody by [his]2802-him side . And that [you]0-i should have been so mistaken , is [amazing!—I]0-i am sure , but for believing that [you]0-i entirely approved and meant to encourage [me]0-i in [my]0-i attachment , [I]0-i should have considered it at first too great a presumption almost , to dare to think of [him]2802-him . At first , if [you]0-i had not told [me]0-i that more wonderful things had happened ; that there had been matches of greater disparity ( those were [your]0-i very words);—I should not have dared to give way to — [I]0-i should not have thought it possible — But if [you]0-i , who had been always acquainted with [him]2802-him — ” “[0-i] [Harriet]107-harriet ! ” cried [Emma]79-emma , collecting [herself]79-emma resolutely—“Let[107-harriet] [us]2804-us understand [each other]420-each other now , without the possibility of farther mistake . Are [you]107-harriet speaking of — [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ? ” “[107-harriet] To be sure [I]0-i am . [I]0-i never could have an idea of any body else — and so [I]0-i thought [you]0-i knew . When [we]2804-us talked about [him]2802-him , it was as clear as possible . ” “[2806-a different person] Not quite , ” returned [Emma]79-emma , with forced calmness , “[2806-a different person] for all that [you]0-i then said , appeared to [me]0-i to relate to [a different person]2806-a different person . [I]0-i could almost assert that [you]0-i had named [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . [I]0-i am sure the service [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill had rendered [you]0-i , in protecting [you]0-i from the gipsies , was spoken of . ” “[0-i] Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , how [you]107-harriet do forget ! ” “[80-miss taylor] [[My]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Harriet]107-harriet , [I]0-i perfectly remember the substance of what [I]0-i said on the occasion . [I]0-i told [you]107-harriet that [I]0-i did not wonder at [your]107-harriet attachment ; that considering the service [he]98-frank churchill had rendered [you]107-harriet , it was extremely natural:—and [you]107-harriet agreed to it , expressing [yourself]107-harriet very warmly as to [your]107-harriet sense of that service , and mentioning even what [your]107-harriet sensations had been in seeing [him]98-frank churchill come forward to [your]107-harriet rescue.—The impression of it is strong on [my]0-i memory . ” “[1023-dear] Oh , [dear]1023-dear , ” cried [Harriet]107-harriet , “[1023-dear] now [I]0-i recollect what [you]1023-dear mean ; but [I]0-i was thinking of something very different at the time . It was not the gipsies — it was not [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill that [I]0-i meant . No ! ( with some elevation ) [I]0-i was thinking of a much more precious circumstance — of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s coming and asking [me]0-i to dance , when [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton would not stand up with [me]0-i ; and when there was [no other partner]2809-no other partner in [the room]3386-the room . That was the kind action ; that was the noble benevolence and generosity ; that was the service which made [me]0-i begin to feel how superior [he]88-mr. knightley was to [every other being upon earth]2811-every other being upon earth . ” “[178-god] Good [God]178-god ! ” cried [Emma]79-emma , “[178-god] this has been a most unfortunate — most deplorable mistake!—What is to be done ? ” “[1023-dear] [You]1023-dear would not have encouraged [me]0-i , then , if [you]1023-dear had understood [me]0-i ? At least , however , [I]0-i can not be worse off than [I]0-i should have been , if [the other]3423-the other had been [the person]4190-the person ; and now — it is possible — ” [She]79-emma paused a few moments . [Emma]79-emma could not speak . “[0-i] [I]0-i do not wonder , [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , ” [she]79-emma resumed , “[80-miss taylor] that [you]80-miss taylor should feel a great difference between the two , as to [me]0-i or as to any body . [You]80-miss taylor must think one five hundred million times more above [me]0-i than the other . But [I]0-i hope , [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , that supposing — that if — strange as it may appear—. But [you]80-miss taylor know they were [your]80-miss taylor own words , that more wonderful things had happened , matches of greater disparity had taken place than between [Mr. Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill and [me]0-i ; and , therefore , it seems as if such a thing even as this , may have occurred before — and if [I]0-i should be so fortunate , beyond expression , as to — if [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley should really — if [he]88-mr. knightley does not mind the disparity , [I]0-i hope , [dear Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , [you]80-miss taylor will not set [yourself]80-miss taylor against it , and try to put difficulties in the way . But [you]80-miss taylor are too good for that , [I]0-i am sure . ” [Harriet]107-harriet was standing at one of the windows . [Emma]79-emma turned round to look at [her]107-harriet in consternation , and hastily said , “[80-miss taylor] Have [you]80-miss taylor any idea of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s returning [your]80-miss taylor affection ? ” “[80-miss taylor] Yes , ” replied [Harriet]107-harriet modestly , but not [fearfully—“I]0-i[0-i] must say that [I]0-i have . ” [Emma]79-emma ’s eyes were instantly withdrawn ; and [she]79-emma sat silently meditating , in a fixed attitude , for a few minutes . A few minutes were sufficient for making [her]79-emma acquainted with [her]79-emma own heart . A mind like [hers]79-emma , once opening to suspicion , made rapid progress . [She]79-emma touched — [she]79-emma admitted — [she]79-emma acknowledged the whole truth . Why was it so much worse that [Harriet]107-harriet should be in love with [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , than with [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ? Why was the evil so dreadfully increased by [Harriet]107-harriet ’s having some hope of a return ? It darted through [her]79-emma , with the speed of an arrow , that [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley must marry [no one]813-no one but [herself]79-emma ! [Her]79-emma own conduct , as well as [her]79-emma own heart , was before [her]79-emma in the same few minutes . [She]79-emma saw it all with a clearness which had never blessed [her]79-emma before . How improperly had [she]79-emma been acting by [Harriet]107-harriet ! How inconsiderate , how indelicate , how irrational , how unfeeling had been [her]79-emma conduct ! What blindness , what madness , had led [her]79-emma on ! It struck [her]79-emma with dreadful force , and [she]79-emma was ready to give it every bad name in [the world]392-the world . Some portion of respect for [herself]79-emma , however , in spite of all these demerits — some concern for [her]79-emma own appearance , and a strong sense of justice by [Harriet—(there]339-harriet—(there would be no need of compassion to [the girl who believed [herself]79-emma loved by [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley]5338-the girl who believed herself loved by mr. knightley — but justice required that [she]79-emma should not be made unhappy by any coldness now , ) gave [Emma]79-emma the resolution to sit and endure farther with calmness , with even apparent kindness.—For [her]79-emma own advantage indeed , it was fit that the utmost extent of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s hopes should be enquired into ; and [Harriet]107-harriet had done nothing to forfeit the regard and interest which had been so voluntarily formed and maintained — or to deserve to be slighted by [the person]4190-the person , whose counsels had never led [her]79-emma right.—Rousing from reflection , therefore , and subduing [her]79-emma emotion , [she]79-emma turned to [Harriet]107-harriet again , and , in a more inviting accent , renewed the conversation ; for as to the subject which had first introduced it , the wonderful story of [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , that was quite sunk and [lost.—Neither of [them]5340-lost.—neither of them]5340-lost.—neither of them thought but of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [themselves]5340-lost.—neither of them . [Harriet]107-harriet , who had been standing in no unhappy reverie , was yet very glad to be called from it , by the now encouraging manner of [such a judge]5341-such a judge , and [such a friend as [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor]5342-such a friend as miss woodhouse , and only wanted invitation , to give the history of [her]107-harriet hopes with great , though trembling delight.—Emma ’s tremblings as [she]79-emma asked , and as [she]79-emma listened , were better concealed than [Harriet]107-harriet ’s , but they were not less . [Her]107-harriet voice was not unsteady ; but [her]107-harriet mind was in all the perturbation that such a development of self , such a burst of threatening evil , such a confusion of sudden and perplexing emotions , must create.—She listened with much inward suffering , but with great outward patience , to [Harriet]107-harriet ’s detail.—Methodical , or well arranged , or very well delivered , it could not be expected to be ; but it contained , when separated from all the feebleness and tautology of the narration , a substance to sink [her]107-harriet spirit — especially with the corroborating circumstances , which [her]107-harriet own memory brought in favour of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s most improved opinion of [Harriet]107-harriet . [Harriet]107-harriet had been conscious of a difference in [his]88-mr. knightley behaviour ever since those two decisive dances.—Emma knew that [he]88-mr. knightley had , on that occasion , found [her]107-harriet much superior to [his]88-mr. knightley expectation . From that evening , or at least from the time of [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor ’s encouraging [her]107-harriet to think of [him]88-mr. knightley , [Harriet]107-harriet had begun to be sensible of [his]88-mr. knightley talking to [her]107-harriet much more than [he]88-mr. knightley had been used to do , and of [his]88-mr. knightley having indeed quite a different manner towards [her]107-harriet ; a manner of kindness and sweetness!—Latterly [she]107-harriet had been more and more aware of it . When [they]5343-they had been all walking together , [he]88-mr. knightley had so often come and walked by [her]107-harriet , and talked so very delightfully!—He seemed to want to be acquainted with [her]107-harriet . [Emma]79-emma knew it to have been very much the case . [She]79-emma had often observed the change , to almost the same extent.—Harriet repeated expressions of approbation and praise from [him]88-mr. knightley — and [Emma]79-emma felt [them]5344-them to be in the closest agreement with what [she]79-emma had known of [his]88-mr. knightley opinion of [Harriet]107-harriet . [He]88-mr. knightley praised [her]107-harriet for being without art or affectation , for having simple , honest , generous , feelings.—She knew that [he]88-mr. knightley saw such recommendations in [Harriet]107-harriet ; [he]88-mr. knightley had dwelt on them to [her]107-harriet more than once.—Much that lived in [Harriet]107-harriet ’s memory , many little particulars of the notice [she]107-harriet had received from [him]88-mr. knightley , a look , a speech , a removal from one chair to another , a compliment implied , a preference inferred , had been unnoticed , because unsuspected , by [Emma]79-emma . Circumstances that might swell to half an hour ’s relation , and contained multiplied proofs to [her]107-harriet who had seen [them]5344-them , had passed undiscerned by [her]107-harriet who now heard [them]5344-them ; but the two latest occurrences to be mentioned , the two of strongest promise to [Harriet]107-harriet , were not without some degree of witness from [Emma]79-emma herself.—The first , was [his]88-mr. knightley walking with [her]107-harriet apart from the others , in the lime - walk at [Donwell]202-donwell , where [they]5345-they had been walking some time before [Emma]79-emma came , and [he]88-mr. knightley had taken pains ( as [she]107-harriet was convinced ) to draw [her]107-harriet from the rest to [himself]88-mr. knightley — and at first , [he]88-mr. knightley had talked to [her]107-harriet in a more particular way than [he]88-mr. knightley had ever done before , in a very particular way indeed!—(Harriet could not recall it without a blush . ) [He]88-mr. knightley seemed to be almost asking [her]107-harriet , whether [her]107-harriet affections were engaged.—But as soon as [she]107-harriet ( [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor ) appeared likely to join [them]5345-they , [he]88-mr. knightley changed the subject , and began talking about farming:—The second , was [his]88-mr. knightley having sat talking with [her]107-harriet nearly half an hour before [Emma]79-emma came back from [her]79-emma visit , the very last morning of [his]88-mr. knightley being at [Hartfield]90-hartfield — though , when [he]88-mr. knightley first came in , [he]88-mr. knightley had said that [he]88-mr. knightley could not stay five minutes — and [his]88-mr. knightley having told [her]107-harriet , during [their]5345-they conversation , that though [he]88-mr. knightley must go to [London]1-london , it was very much against [his]88-mr. knightley inclination that [he]88-mr. knightley left [home]3258-home at all , which was much more ( as [Emma]79-emma felt ) than [he]88-mr. knightley had acknowledged to [her]107-harriet . The superior degree of confidence towards [Harriet]107-harriet , which this one article marked , gave [her]107-harriet severe pain . On the subject of the first of the two circumstances , [she]107-harriet did , after a little reflection , venture the following question . “[2814-he] Might [he]2814-he not?—Is not it possible , that when enquiring , as [you]2815-you thought , into the state of [your]2815-you affections , [he]2814-he might be alluding to [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin — [he]2814-he might have [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin ’s interest in view ? But [Harriet]107-harriet rejected the suspicion with spirit . “ [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin ! No indeed!—There was not a hint of [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin . [I]107-harriet hope [I]107-harriet know better now , than to care for [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin , or to be suspected of it . ”[107-harriet] When [Harriet]107-harriet had closed [her]107-harriet evidence , [she]107-harriet appealed to [[her]107-harriet dear]2816-her dear [Miss Woodhouse]80-miss taylor , to say whether [she]107-harriet had not good ground for hope . “ [I]107-harriet never should have presumed to think of it at first , ”[107-harriet] said [she]107-harriet , “ but for [you]80-miss taylor . [You]80-miss taylor told [me]107-harriet to observe [him]112-mr. martin carefully , and let [his]112-mr. martin behaviour be the rule of [mine]107-harriet — and so [I]107-harriet have . But now [I]107-harriet seem to feel that [I]107-harriet may deserve [him]112-mr. martin ; and that if [he]112-mr. martin does chuse [me]107-harriet , it will not be any thing so very wonderful . ”[107-harriet] The bitter feelings occasioned by this speech , the many bitter feelings , made the utmost exertion necessary on [Emma]79-emma ’s side , to enable [her]79-emma to say on reply , “ [Harriet]107-harriet , [I]79-emma will only venture to declare , that [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley is [the last man in [the world]392-the world]5347-the last man in the world , who would intentionally give [any woman]820-any woman the idea of [his]88-mr. knightley feeling for [her]820-any woman more than [he]88-mr. knightley really does . ”[79-emma] [Harriet]107-harriet seemed ready to worship [[her]107-harriet friend]417-her friend for a sentence so satisfactory ; and [Emma]79-emma was only saved from raptures and fondness , which at that moment would have been dreadful penance , by the sound of [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s footsteps . [He]417-her friend was coming through [the hall]1685-the hall . [Harriet]107-harriet was too much agitated to encounter [him]417-her friend . “ [She]107-harriet could not compose [herself]107-harriet — [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse would be alarmed — [she]107-harriet had better go;”—with[417-her friend] most ready encouragement from [[her]107-harriet friend]417-her friend , therefore , [she]107-harriet passed off through another door — and the moment [she]107-harriet was gone , this was the spontaneous burst of [Emma]79-emma ’s feelings : “ Oh God ! that [I]79-emma had never seen [her]79-emma ! ”[79-emma] The rest of the day , the following night , were hardly enough for [her]107-harriet thoughts.—She was bewildered amidst the confusion of all that had rushed on [her]107-harriet within the last few hours . Every moment had brought a fresh surprize ; and every surprize must be matter of humiliation to her.—How to understand it all ! How to understand the deceptions [she]107-harriet had been thus practising on [herself]107-harriet , and living under!—The blunders , the blindness of [her]107-harriet own head and heart!—she sat still , [she]107-harriet walked about , [she]107-harriet tried [[her]107-harriet own room]955-her own room , [she]107-harriet tried the shrubbery — in every place , every posture , [she]107-harriet perceived that [she]107-harriet had acted most weakly ; that [she]107-harriet had been imposed on by [others]473-others in a most mortifying degree ; that [she]107-harriet had been imposing on [herself]107-harriet in a degree yet more mortifying ; that [she]107-harriet was wretched , and should probably find this day but the beginning of wretchedness . To understand , thoroughly understand [her]107-harriet own heart , was the first endeavour . To that point went every leisure moment which [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father ’s claims on [her]107-harriet allowed , and every moment of involuntary absence of mind . How long had [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley been so dear to [her]107-harriet , as every feeling declared [him]88-mr. knightley now to be ? When had [his]88-mr. knightley influence , such influence begun ? — When had [he]88-mr. knightley succeeded to that place in [her]107-harriet affection , which [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill had once , for a short period , occupied?—She looked back ; [she]107-harriet compared [the two]1913-the two — compared [them]1913-the two , as [they]1913-the two had always stood in [her]107-harriet estimation , from the time of the latter ’s becoming known to [her]107-harriet — and as [they]1913-the two must at any time have been compared by [her]107-harriet , had it — oh ! had it , by [any blessed felicity]2825-any blessed felicity , occurred to [her]107-harriet , to institute the comparison.—She saw that there never had been a time when [she]107-harriet did not consider [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley as infinitely the superior , or when [his]88-mr. knightley regard for [her]107-harriet had not been infinitely the most dear . [She]107-harriet saw , that in persuading [herself]107-harriet , in fancying , in acting to the contrary , [she]107-harriet had been entirely under a delusion , totally ignorant of [her]107-harriet own heart — and , in short , that [she]107-harriet had never really cared for [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill at all ! This was the conclusion of the first series of reflection . This was the knowledge of [herself]107-harriet , on the first question of inquiry , which [she]107-harriet reached ; and without being long in reaching it.—She was most sorrowfully indignant ; ashamed of every sensation but the one revealed to [her]107-harriet — [her]107-harriet affection for [Mr. Knightley.—Every]340-mr. knightley.—every other part of [her]107-harriet mind was disgusting . With insufferable vanity had [she]107-harriet believed [herself]107-harriet in the secret of every body ’s feelings ; with unpardonable arrogance proposed to arrange every body ’s destiny . [She]107-harriet was proved to have been universally mistaken ; and [she]107-harriet had not quite done nothing — for [she]107-harriet had done mischief . [She]107-harriet had brought evil on [Harriet]107-harriet , on [herself]107-harriet , and [she]107-harriet too much feared , on [Mr. Knightley.—Were]2826-mr. knightley.—were this most unequal of all connexions to take place , on [her]107-harriet must rest all the reproach of having given it a beginning ; for [his]2826-mr. knightley.—were attachment , [she]107-harriet must believe to be produced only by a consciousness of [Harriet’s;—and]341-harriet’s;—and even were this not the case , [he]2826-mr. knightley.—were would never have known [Harriet]107-harriet at all but for [her]107-harriet folly . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [Harriet Smith!—It]342-harriet smith!—it was a union to distance every wonder of the kind.—The attachment of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill and [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax became commonplace , threadbare , stale in the comparison , exciting no surprize , presenting no disparity , affording nothing to be said or thought.—Mr . [Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [Harriet Smith!—Such]343-harriet an elevation on [her]107-harriet side ! Such a debasement on [his]2826-mr. knightley.—were ! It was horrible to [Emma]79-emma to think how it must sink [him]2826-mr. knightley.—were in the general opinion , to foresee the smiles , the sneers , the merriment it would prompt at [his]2826-mr. knightley.—were expense ; the mortification and disdain of [[his]2826-mr. knightley.—were brother]3468-his brother , the thousand inconveniences to himself.—Could it be?—No ; it was impossible . And yet it was far , very far , from impossible.—Was it a new circumstance for [a man of first - rate abilities to be captivated by very inferior powers]2828-a man of first - rate abilities to be captivated by very inferior powers ? Was it new for one , perhaps too busy to seek , to be the prize of [a girl who would seek him?—Was it new for any thing in [this world]1658-this world]2829-a girl who would seek him?—was it new for any thing in this world to be unequal , inconsistent , incongruous — or for chance and circumstance ( as second causes ) to direct the human fate ? Oh ! had [she]107-harriet never brought [Harriet]343-harriet forward !
