Had [she]107-harriet left [her]343-harriet where [she]343-harriet ought , and where [he]88-mr. knightley had told [her]343-harriet [she]343-harriet ought!—Had [she]343-harriet not , with a folly which [no tongue]2831-no tongue could express , prevented [her]343-harriet marrying [the unexceptionable young man who would have made [her]343-harriet happy and respectable in the line of life to which [she]343-harriet ought to belong]2832-the unexceptionable young man who would have made her happy and respectable in the line of life to which she ought to belong — all would have been safe ; none of this dreadful sequel would have been . How [Harriet]343-harriet could ever have had the presumption to raise [her]343-harriet thoughts to [Mr. Knightley!—How]344-mr. knightley!—how [she]343-harriet could dare to fancy [herself]343-harriet the chosen of [such a man]593-such a man till actually assured of it!—But [Harriet]343-harriet was less humble , had fewer scruples than formerly.—Her inferiority , whether of mind or situation , seemed little felt.—She had seemed more sensible of [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton ’s being to stoop in marrying [her]343-harriet , than [she]343-harriet now seemed of [Mr. Knightley’s.—Alas]345-mr. knightley’s.—alas ! was not that [her]343-harriet own doing too ? Who had been at pains to give [Harriet]343-harriet notions of self - consequence but herself?—Who but [herself]343-harriet had taught [her]343-harriet , that [she]343-harriet was to elevate [herself]343-harriet if possible , and that [her]343-harriet claims were great to a high worldly establishment?—If [Harriet]343-harriet , from being humble , were grown vain , it was [her]343-harriet doing too . CHAPTER XII Till now that [she]343-harriet was threatened with its loss , [Emma]79-emma had never known how much of [her]343-harriet happiness depended on being first with [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , first in interest and affection.—Satisfied that it was so , and feeling it [her]343-harriet due , [she]343-harriet had enjoyed it without reflection ; and only in the dread of being supplanted , found how inexpressibly important it had been.—Long , very long , [she]343-harriet felt [she]343-harriet had been first ; for , having no female connexions of [his]88-mr. knightley own , there had been only [Isabella]83-isabella whose claims could be compared with [hers]343-harriet , and [she]343-harriet had always known exactly how far [he]88-mr. knightley loved and esteemed [Isabella]83-isabella . [She]343-harriet had [herself]343-harriet been first with [him]88-mr. knightley for many years past . [She]343-harriet had not deserved it ; [she]343-harriet had often been negligent or perverse , slighting [his]88-mr. knightley advice , or even wilfully opposing [him]88-mr. knightley , insensible of half [his]88-mr. knightley merits , and quarrelling with [him]88-mr. knightley because [he]88-mr. knightley would not acknowledge [her]343-harriet false and insolent estimate of [her]343-harriet own — but still , from family attachment and habit , and thorough excellence of mind , [he]88-mr. knightley had loved [her]343-harriet , and watched over [her]343-harriet from [a girl]600-a girl , with an endeavour to improve [her]343-harriet , and an anxiety for [her]343-harriet doing right , which [no other creature had at all shared]2835-no other creature had at all shared . In spite of all [her]343-harriet faults , [she]343-harriet knew [she]343-harriet was dear to [him]88-mr. knightley ; might [she]343-harriet not say , very dear?—When the suggestions of hope , however , which must follow here , presented [themselves]2836-themselves , [she]343-harriet could not presume to indulge them . [Harriet Smith]107-harriet might think [herself]107-harriet not unworthy of being peculiarly , exclusively , passionately loved by [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . [She]107-harriet could not . [She]107-harriet could not flatter [herself]107-harriet with any idea of blindness in [his]88-mr. knightley attachment to [her]107-harriet . [She]107-harriet had received a very recent proof of its impartiality.—How shocked had [he]88-mr. knightley been by [her]107-harriet behaviour to [Miss Bates]101-miss bates ! How directly , how strongly had [he]88-mr. knightley expressed [himself]88-mr. knightley to [her]107-harriet on the subject!—Not too strongly for the offence — but far , far too strongly to issue from any feeling softer than upright justice and clear - sighted goodwill.—She had no hope , nothing to deserve the name of hope , that [he]88-mr. knightley could have that sort of affection for [herself]107-harriet which was now in question ; but there was a hope ( at times a slight one , at times much stronger , ) that [Harriet]107-harriet might have deceived [herself]107-harriet , and be overrating [his]88-mr. knightley regard for her.—Wish it [she]107-harriet must , for [his]88-mr. knightley sake — be the consequence nothing to [herself]107-harriet , but [his]88-mr. knightley remaining single all [his]88-mr. knightley life . Could [she]107-harriet be secure of that , indeed , of [his]88-mr. knightley never marrying at all , [she]107-harriet believed [she]107-harriet should be perfectly satisfied.—Let [him]88-mr. knightley but continue the same [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley to [her]107-harriet and [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father , the same [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley to [all the world]4726-all the world ; let [Donwell]202-donwell and [Hartfield]90-hartfield lose none of [their]2839-them precious intercourse of friendship and confidence , and [her]107-harriet peace would be fully secured.—Marriage , in fact , would not do for [her]107-harriet . It would be incompatible with what [she]107-harriet owed to [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father , and with what [she]107-harriet felt for [him]88-mr. knightley . Nothing should separate [her]107-harriet from [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father . [She]107-harriet would not marry , even if [she]107-harriet were asked by [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . It must be [her]107-harriet ardent wish that [Harriet]107-harriet might be disappointed ; and [she]107-harriet hoped , that when able to see [them]2839-them together again , [she]107-harriet might at least be able to ascertain what the chances for it were.—She should see [them]2839-them henceforward with the closest observance ; and wretchedly as [she]107-harriet had hitherto misunderstood even those [she]107-harriet was watching , [she]107-harriet did not know how to admit that [she]107-harriet could be blinded here.—He was expected back every day . The power of observation would be soon given — frightfully soon it appeared when [her]107-harriet thoughts were in one course . In the meanwhile , [she]107-harriet resolved against seeing [Harriet.—It]319-frank and harriet.—it would do neither of [them]2839-them good , it would do the subject no good , to be talking of it farther.—She was resolved not to be convinced , as long as [she]107-harriet could doubt , and yet had no authority for opposing [Harriet]107-harriet ’s confidence . To talk would be only to irritate.—She wrote to [her]107-harriet , therefore , kindly , but decisively , to beg that [she]107-harriet would not , at present , come to [Hartfield]90-hartfield ; acknowledging it to be [her]107-harriet conviction , that all farther confidential discussion of one topic had better be avoided ; and hoping , that if a few days were allowed to pass before [they]2839-them met again , except in the company of [others]473-others — [she]107-harriet objected only to a tête - à - tête — [they]2839-them might be able to act as if [they]2839-them had forgotten the conversation of yesterday.—Harriet submitted , and approved , and was grateful . This point was just arranged , when [a visitor]775-a visitor arrived to tear [Emma]79-emma ’s thoughts a little from the one subject which had engrossed [them]2839-them , sleeping or waking , the last twenty - four hours — [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , who had been calling on [[her]84-mrs. weston daughter - in - law]2844-her daughter - in - law elect , and took [Hartfield]90-hartfield in [her]84-mrs. weston way [home]3258-home , almost as much in duty to [Emma]79-emma as in pleasure to [herself]79-emma , to relate all the particulars of so interesting an interview . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston had accompanied [her]107-harriet to [[Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates ’s]2846-mrs. bates ’s , and gone through [his]82-mr. weston share of this essential attention most handsomely ; but [she]107-harriet having then induced [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax to join [her]107-harriet in an airing , was now returned with much more to say , and much more to say with satisfaction , than a quarter of an hour spent in [[Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates ’s parlour]2847-mrs. bates ’s parlour , with all the encumbrance of awkward feelings , could have afforded . A little curiosity [Emma]79-emma had ; and [she]79-emma made the most of it while [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend related . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston had set off to pay the visit in a good deal of agitation [herself]84-mrs. weston ; and in the first place had wished not to go at all at present , to be allowed merely to write to [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax instead , and to defer this ceremonious call till a little time had passed , and [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill could be reconciled to the engagement ’s becoming known ; as , considering every thing , [she]107-harriet thought such a visit could not be paid without leading to reports:—but [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston had thought differently ; [he]82-mr. weston was extremely anxious to shew [his]82-mr. weston approbation to [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and [[her]142-miss fairfax family]578-her family , and did not conceive that any suspicion could be excited by it ; or if it were , that it would be of any consequence ; for “ such things , ”[82-mr. weston] [he]82-mr. weston observed , “ always got about . ”[82-mr. weston] [Emma]79-emma smiled , and felt that [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston had very good reason for saying so . [They]2850-they had gone , in short — and very great had been the evident distress and confusion of [the lady]774-the lady . [She]774-the lady had hardly been able to speak a word , and every look and action had shewn how deeply [she]774-the lady was suffering from consciousness . The quiet , heart - felt satisfaction of [the old lady]4472-the old lady , and the rapturous delight of [[her]4472-the old lady daughter]3264-her daughter — who proved even too joyous to talk as usual , had been a gratifying , yet almost an affecting , scene . [They]2850-they were both so truly respectable in [their]2850-they happiness , so disinterested in every sensation ; thought so much of [Jane]142-miss fairfax ; so much of every body , and so little of [themselves]2850-they , that every kindly feeling was at work for [them]2850-they . [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s recent illness had offered a fair plea for [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston to invite [her]774-the lady to an airing ; [she]774-the lady had drawn back and declined at first , but , on being pressed had yielded ; and , in the course of [their]2850-they drive , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston had , by gentle encouragement , overcome so much of [her]774-the lady embarrassment , as to bring [her]774-the lady to converse on the important subject . Apologies for [her]774-the lady seemingly ungracious silence in [their]2850-they first reception , and the warmest expressions of the gratitude [she]774-the lady was always feeling towards [herself]774-the lady and [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , must necessarily open the cause ; but when these effusions were put by , [they]2850-they had talked a good deal of the present and of the future state of the engagement . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was convinced that such conversation must be the greatest relief to [[her]84-mrs. weston companion]3365-her companion , pent up within [her]84-mrs. weston own mind as every thing had so long been , and was very much pleased with all that [she]84-mrs. weston had said on the subject . “ On the misery of what [she]774-the lady had suffered , during the concealment of so many months , ”[84-mrs. weston] continued [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , “ [she]774-the lady was energetic . This was one of [her]774-the lady expressions . ‘ [I]84-mrs. weston will not say , that since [I]84-mrs. weston entered into the engagement [I]84-mrs. weston have not had some happy moments ; but [I]84-mrs. weston can say , that [I]84-mrs. weston have never known the blessing of one tranquil hour:’—and the quivering lip , [Emma]79-emma , which uttered it , was an attestation that [I]84-mrs. weston felt at [my]84-mrs. weston heart . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ [Poor girl]1411-poor girl ! ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma . “ [She]774-the lady thinks [herself]774-the lady wrong , then , for having consented to a private engagement ? ”[79-emma] “ Wrong ! [No one]813-no one , [I]84-mrs. weston believe , can blame [her]774-the lady more than [she]774-the lady is disposed to blame [herself]774-the lady . ‘ The consequence , ’ said [she]774-the lady , ‘ has been a state of perpetual suffering to [me]84-mrs. weston ; and so it ought . But after all the punishment that misconduct can bring , it is still not less misconduct . Pain is no expiation . [I]84-mrs. weston never can be blameless . [I]84-mrs. weston have been acting contrary to all [my]84-mrs. weston sense of right ; and the fortunate turn that every thing has taken , and the kindness [I]84-mrs. weston am now receiving , is what [my]84-mrs. weston conscience tells [me]84-mrs. weston ought not to be . ’ ‘ Do not imagine , [madam]1401-madam , ’ [she]774-the lady continued , ‘ that [I]84-mrs. weston was taught wrong . Do not let any reflection fall on the principles or the care of [the friends who brought [me]84-mrs. weston up]5353-the friends who brought me up . The error has been all [my]84-mrs. weston own ; and [I]84-mrs. weston do assure [you]1401-madam that , with all the excuse that present circumstances may appear to give , [I]84-mrs. weston shall yet dread making the story known to [Colonel Campbell]153-colonel campbell . ’ ”[84-mrs. weston] “ [Poor girl]1411-poor girl ! ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma again . “ [She]1411-poor girl loves [him]153-colonel campbell then excessively , [I]79-emma suppose . [Her]1411-poor girl affection must have overpowered [her]1411-poor girl judgment . ”[79-emma] “ Yes , [I]84-mrs. weston have no doubt of [her]1411-poor girl being extremely attached to [him]153-colonel campbell . ”[84-mrs. weston] “ [I]79-emma am afraid , ”[79-emma] returned [Emma]79-emma , sighing , “ that [I]79-emma must often have contributed to make [her]1411-poor girl unhappy . ”[79-emma] “ On [your]1401-madam side , [[my]79-emma love]1093-my love , it was very innocently done . But [she]1411-poor girl probably had something of that in [her]1411-poor girl thoughts , when alluding to the misunderstandings which [he]153-colonel campbell had given [us]5356-us hints of before . One natural consequence of the evil [she]1411-poor girl had involved [herself]1411-poor girl in , ”[79-emma] [she]79-emma said , “ was that of making [her]1411-poor girl unreasonable . [She]1411-poor girl was sensible that [you]1093-my love had never received any proper acknowledgment from [herself]1411-poor girl . ”[79-emma] “ If [I]79-emma did not know [her]1411-poor girl to be happy now , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , seriously , “ which , in spite of every little drawback from [her]1411-poor girl scrupulous conscience , [she]1411-poor girl must be , [I]79-emma could not bear these thanks;—for , oh ! [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , if there were an account drawn up of the evil and the good [I]79-emma have done [Miss Fairfax!—Well]346-miss fairfax!—well ( checking [herself]1411-poor girl , and trying to be more lively ) , this is all to be forgotten . [You]1093-my love are very kind to bring [me]79-emma these interesting particulars . [They]5357-they shew [her]1411-poor girl to the greatest advantage . [I]79-emma am sure [she]1411-poor girl is very good — [I]79-emma hope [she]1411-poor girl will be very happy . It is fit that the fortune should be on [his]98-frank churchill side , for [I]79-emma think the merit will be all on [hers]1411-poor girl . ”[79-emma] Such a conclusion could not pass unanswered by [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . [She]84-mrs. weston thought well of [Frank]98-frank churchill in almost every respect ; and , what was more , [she]84-mrs. weston loved [him]98-frank churchill very much , and [her]84-mrs. weston defence was , therefore , earnest . [She]84-mrs. weston talked with a great deal of reason , and at least equal affection — but [she]84-mrs. weston had too much to urge for [Emma]79-emma ’s attention ; it was soon gone to [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square or to [Donwell]202-donwell ; [she]84-mrs. weston forgot to attempt to listen ; and when [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ended with , “ [We]2855-we have not yet had the letter [we]2855-we are so anxious for , [you]79-emma know , but [I]84-mrs. weston hope it will soon come , ”[84-mrs. weston] [she]84-mrs. weston was obliged to pause before [she]84-mrs. weston answered , and at last obliged to answer at random , before [she]84-mrs. weston could at all recollect what letter it was which [they]2855-we were so anxious for . “ Are [you]79-emma well , [[my]84-mrs. weston [Emma]79-emma]1327-my emma ? ”[84-mrs. weston] was [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s parting question . “ Oh ! perfectly . [I]84-mrs. weston am always well , [you]79-emma know . Be sure to give [me]84-mrs. weston intelligence of the letter as soon as possible . ”[84-mrs. weston] [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s communications furnished [Emma]79-emma with more food for unpleasant reflection , by increasing [her]79-emma esteem and compassion , and [her]79-emma sense of past injustice towards [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax . [She]79-emma bitterly regretted not having sought a closer acquaintance with [her]142-miss fairfax , and blushed for the envious feelings which had certainly been , in some measure , the cause . Had [she]79-emma followed [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s known wishes , in paying that attention to [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , which was every way [her]79-emma due ; had [she]79-emma tried to know [her]142-miss fairfax better ; had [she]79-emma done [her]79-emma part towards intimacy ; had [she]79-emma endeavoured to find [a friend there]2856-a friend there instead of in [Harriet Smith]107-harriet ; [she]79-emma must , in all probability , have been spared from every pain which pressed on [her]79-emma now.—Birth , abilities , and education , had been equally marking one as an associate for [her]79-emma , to be received with gratitude ; and the other — what was she?—Supposing even that [they]2857-they had never become [intimate friends]2858-intimate friends ; that [she]79-emma had never been admitted into [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s confidence on this important matter — which was most probable — still , in knowing [her]79-emma as [she]79-emma ought , and as [she]79-emma might , [she]79-emma must have been preserved from the abominable suspicions of an improper attachment to [Mr. Dixon]182-mr. dixon , which [she]79-emma had not only so foolishly fashioned and harboured [herself]79-emma , but had so unpardonably imparted ; an idea which [she]79-emma greatly feared had been made a subject of material distress to the delicacy of [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s feelings , by the levity or carelessness of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s . Of all the sources of evil surrounding the former , since [her]79-emma coming to [Highbury]3-highbury , [she]79-emma was persuaded that [she]79-emma must [herself]79-emma have been the worst . [She]79-emma must have been [a perpetual enemy]2859-a perpetual enemy . [They]2860-them never could have been all three together , without [her]79-emma having stabbed [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s peace in a thousand instances ; and on [Box Hill]64-box hill , perhaps , it had been the agony of a mind that would bear no more . The evening of this day was very long , and melancholy , at [Hartfield]90-hartfield . The weather added what it could of gloom . A cold stormy rain set in , and nothing of July appeared but in the trees and shrubs , which the wind was despoiling , and the length of the day , which only made such cruel sights the longer visible . The weather affected [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , and [he]81-mr. woodhouse could only be kept tolerably comfortable by almost ceaseless attention on [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter ’s side , and by exertions which had never cost [her]3129-his daughter half so much before . It reminded [her]79-emma of [their]2860-them first forlorn tête - à - tête , on the evening of [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s wedding - day ; but [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley had walked in then , soon after tea , and dissipated every melancholy fancy . Alas ! such delightful proofs of [Hartfield]90-hartfield ’s attraction , as those sort of visits conveyed , might shortly be over . The picture which [she]79-emma had then drawn of the privations of the approaching winter , had proved erroneous ; [no friends]2862-no friends had deserted [them]2860-them , no pleasures had been lost.—But [her]79-emma present forebodings [she]79-emma feared would experience no similar contradiction . The prospect before [her]79-emma now , was threatening to a degree that could not be entirely dispelled — that might not be even partially brightened . If all took place that might take place among the circle of [[her]79-emma friends]817-her friends , [Hartfield]90-hartfield must be comparatively deserted ; and [she]79-emma left to cheer [[her]79-emma father]415-her father with the spirits only of ruined happiness . [The child]3193-the child to be born at [Randalls]97-randalls must be a tie there even dearer than [herself]79-emma ; and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s heart and time would be occupied by it . [They]2860-them should lose [her]79-emma ; and , probably , in great measure , [[her]79-emma husband]431-her husband also.—Frank [Churchill]98-frank churchill would return among [them]2860-them no more ; and [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , it was reasonable to suppose , would soon cease to belong to [Highbury]3-highbury . [They]2867-they would be married , and settled either at or near [Enscombe]7-enscombe . All that were good would be withdrawn ; and if to these losses , the loss of [Donwell]202-donwell were to be added , what would remain of cheerful or of rational society within [their]2867-they reach ? [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley to be no longer coming [there]437-there for [his]88-mr. knightley evening comfort!—No longer walking in at all hours , as if ever willing to change [[his]88-mr. knightley own [home]3258-home]2869-his own home for their’s!—How was it to be endured ? And if [he]88-mr. knightley were to be lost to [them]2860-them for [Harriet]107-harriet ’s sake ; if [he]88-mr. knightley were to be thought of hereafter , as finding in [[Harriet]107-harriet ’s society]2871-harriet ’s society all that [he]88-mr. knightley wanted ; if [Harriet]107-harriet were to be the chosen , the first , [the dearest]2872-the dearest , [the friend]881-the friend , [the wife to whom [he]88-mr. knightley looked for all the best blessings of existence]2874-the wife to whom he looked for all the best blessings of existence ; what could be increasing [Emma]79-emma ’s wretchedness but the reflection never far distant from [her]107-harriet mind , that it had been all [her]107-harriet own work ? When it came to such a pitch as this , [she]107-harriet was not able to refrain from a start , or a heavy sigh , or even from walking about [the room]3386-the room for a few seconds — and the only source whence any thing like consolation or composure could be drawn , was in the resolution of [her]107-harriet own better conduct , and the hope that , however inferior in spirit and gaiety might be the following and every future winter of [her]107-harriet life to the past , it would yet find [her]107-harriet more rational , more acquainted with [herself]107-harriet , and leave [her]107-harriet less to regret when it were gone . CHAPTER XIII The weather continued much the same all the following morning ; and the same loneliness , and the same melancholy , seemed to reign at [Hartfield]90-hartfield — but in the afternoon it cleared ; the wind changed into a softer quarter ; the clouds were carried off ; the sun appeared ; it was summer again . With all the eagerness which such a transition gives , [Emma]79-emma resolved to be out of doors as soon as possible . Never had the exquisite sight , smell , sensation of nature , tranquil , warm , and brilliant after a storm , been more attractive to [her]107-harriet . [She]107-harriet longed for the serenity [they]2876-they might gradually introduce ; and on [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry ’s coming in soon after dinner , with a disengaged hour to give [[her]107-harriet father]415-her father , [she]107-harriet lost no time in hurrying into [the shrubbery.—There]2878-the shrubbery.—there , with spirits freshened , and thoughts a little relieved , [she]107-harriet had taken a few turns , when [she]107-harriet saw [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley passing through [the garden]5129-the garden door , and coming towards her.—It was the first intimation of [his]88-mr. knightley being returned from [London]1-london . [She]107-harriet had been thinking of [him]88-mr. knightley the moment before , as unquestionably sixteen miles distant.—There was time only for the quickest arrangement of mind . [She]107-harriet must be collected and calm . In half a minute [they]2876-they were together . The “ How d’ye do ’s ”[107-harriet] were quiet and constrained on each side . [She]107-harriet asked after [[their]2876-they mutual friends]2880-their mutual friends ; [they]2880-their mutual friends were all well.—When had [he]88-mr. knightley left them?—Only that morning . [He]88-mr. knightley must have had a wet ride.—Yes.—He meant to walk with [her]107-harriet , [she]107-harriet found . “ [He]88-mr. knightley had just looked into [the dining - room]1889-the dining - room , and as [he]88-mr. knightley was not wanted [there]437-there , preferred being out of doors . ”—She[88-mr. knightley] thought [he]88-mr. knightley neither looked nor spoke cheerfully ; and the first possible cause for it , suggested by [her]107-harriet fears , was , that [he]88-mr. knightley had perhaps been communicating [his]88-mr. knightley plans to [[his]88-mr. knightley brother]3468-his brother , and was pained by the manner in which [they]2876-they had been received . [They]2876-they walked together . [He]88-mr. knightley was silent . [She]107-harriet thought [he]88-mr. knightley was often looking at [her]107-harriet , and trying for a fuller view of [her]107-harriet face than it suited [her]107-harriet to give . And this belief produced another dread . Perhaps [he]88-mr. knightley wanted to speak to [her]107-harriet , of [his]88-mr. knightley attachment to [Harriet]107-harriet ; [he]88-mr. knightley might be watching for encouragement to begin.—She did not , could not , feel equal to lead the way to any such subject . [He]88-mr. knightley must do it all [himself]88-mr. knightley . Yet [she]107-harriet could not bear this silence . With [him]88-mr. knightley it was most unnatural . [She]107-harriet considered — resolved — and , trying to smile , began — “ [You]88-mr. knightley have some news to hear , now [you]88-mr. knightley are come back , that will rather surprize [you]88-mr. knightley . ”[107-harriet] “ Have [I]88-mr. knightley ? ”[88-mr. knightley] said [he]88-mr. knightley quietly , and looking at [her]107-harriet ; “ of what nature ? ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Oh ! the best nature in [the world]392-the world — a wedding . ”[88-mr. knightley] After waiting a moment , as if to be sure [she]107-harriet intended to say no more , [he]88-mr. knightley replied , “ If [you]107-harriet mean [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax and [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , [I]88-mr. knightley have heard that already . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ How is it possible ? ”[79-emma] cried [Emma]79-emma , turning [her]79-emma glowing cheeks towards [him]88-mr. knightley ; for , while [she]79-emma spoke , it occurred to [her]79-emma that [he]88-mr. knightley might have called at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s in [his]88-mr. knightley way . “ [I]88-mr. knightley had a few lines on parish business from [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston this morning , and at the end of [them]5362-them [he]82-mr. weston gave [me]88-mr. knightley a brief account of what had happened . ”[88-mr. knightley] [Emma]79-emma was quite relieved , and could presently say , with a little more composure , “ [You]88-mr. knightley probably have been less surprized than any of [us]5363-us , for [you]88-mr. knightley have had [[your]88-mr. knightley suspicions.—I]5364-your suspicions.—i have not forgotten that [you]88-mr. knightley once tried to give [me]79-emma a caution.—I wish [I]79-emma had attended to it — but—(with a sinking voice and a heavy sigh ) [I]79-emma seem to have been doomed to blindness . ”[79-emma] For a moment or two nothing was said , and [she]79-emma was unsuspicious of having excited any particular interest , till [she]79-emma found [her]79-emma arm drawn within [his]88-mr. knightley , and pressed against [his]88-mr. knightley heart , and heard [him]88-mr. knightley thus saying , in a tone of great sensibility , speaking low , “ Time , [[my]88-mr. knightley dearest]696-my dearest [Emma]79-emma , time will heal the wound.—Your own excellent sense — [your]79-emma exertions for [[your]79-emma father]1389-your father ’s sake — [I]88-mr. knightley know [you]79-emma will not allow yourself—. ”[88-mr. knightley] [Her]79-emma arm was pressed again , as [he]88-mr. knightley added , in a more broken and subdued accent , “ The feelings of the warmest friendship — Indignation — Abominable scoundrel!”—And[88-mr. knightley] in a louder , steadier tone , [he]88-mr. knightley concluded with , “ [He]88-mr. knightley will soon be gone . [They]5367-they will soon be in [Yorkshire]50-yorkshire . [I]88-mr. knightley am sorry for [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma deserves a better fate . ”[88-mr. knightley] [Emma]79-emma understood [him]88-mr. knightley ; and as soon as [she]79-emma could recover from the flutter of pleasure , excited by such tender consideration , replied , “ [You]88-mr. knightley are very kind — but [you]88-mr. knightley are mistaken — and [I]88-mr. knightley must set [you]88-mr. knightley right . — [I]88-mr. knightley am not in want of that sort of compassion . [My]88-mr. knightley blindness to what was going on , led [me]88-mr. knightley to act by [them]5367-they in a way that [I]88-mr. knightley must always be ashamed of , and [I]88-mr. knightley was very foolishly tempted to say and do many things which may well lay [me]88-mr. knightley open to unpleasant conjectures , but [I]88-mr. knightley have no other reason to regret that [I]88-mr. knightley was not in the secret earlier . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [Emma]79-emma ! ”[88-mr. knightley] cried [he]88-mr. knightley , looking eagerly at [her]79-emma , “ are [you]79-emma , indeed?”—but[88-mr. knightley] checking himself—“No , no , [I]88-mr. knightley understand [you]79-emma — forgive [me]88-mr. knightley — [I]88-mr. knightley am pleased that [you]79-emma can say even so much.—He is no object of regret , indeed ! and it will not be very long , [I]88-mr. knightley hope , before that becomes the acknowledgment of more than [your]79-emma reason.—Fortunate that [your]79-emma affections were not farther entangled!—I could never , [I]88-mr. knightley confess , from [your]79-emma manners , assure [myself]88-mr. knightley as to the degree of what [you]79-emma felt — [I]88-mr. knightley could only be certain that there was a preference — and a preference which [I]88-mr. knightley never believed [him]88-mr. knightley to deserve.—He is a disgrace to the name of [man.—And]5368-man.—and is [he]88-mr. knightley to be rewarded with [that sweet young woman?—Jane]5369-that sweet young woman?—jane , [Jane]142-miss fairfax , [you]79-emma will be [a miserable creature]5370-a miserable creature . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma , trying to be lively , but really [confused—“I]79-emma am in a very extraordinary situation . [I]79-emma can not let [you]2882-his continue in [your]2882-his error ; and yet , perhaps , since [my]79-emma manners gave such an impression , [I]79-emma have as much reason to be ashamed of confessing that [I]79-emma never have been at all attached to [the person [we]5372-we are speaking of]5371-the person we are speaking of , as it might be natural for [a woman]3207-a woman to feel in confessing exactly the reverse.—But [I]79-emma never have . ”[79-emma] [He]2882-his listened in perfect silence . [She]79-emma wished [him]2882-his to speak , but [he]2882-his would not . [She]79-emma supposed [she]79-emma must say more before [she]79-emma were entitled to [his]2882-his clemency ; but it was a hard case to be obliged still to lower [herself]79-emma in [his]2882-his opinion . [She]79-emma went on , however . “ [I]79-emma have very little to say for [my]79-emma own conduct.—I was tempted by [his]2882-his attentions , and allowed [myself]79-emma to appear pleased.—An old story , probably — a common case — and no more than has happened to hundreds of [my]79-emma sex before ; and yet it may not be the more excusable in one who sets up as [I]79-emma do for Understanding . Many circumstances assisted the temptation . [He]2882-his was [the son of [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston]5374-the son of mr. weston — [he]2882-his was continually [here]3113-here — [I]79-emma always found [him]2882-his very pleasant — and , in short , for ( with a sigh ) let [me]79-emma swell out the causes ever so ingeniously , [they]5376-they all centre in this at last — [my]79-emma vanity was flattered , and [I]79-emma allowed [his]2882-his attentions . Latterly , however — for some time , indeed — [I]79-emma have had no idea of [their]5376-they meaning any thing.—I thought [them]5376-they a habit , a trick , nothing that called for seriousness on [my]79-emma side . [He]2882-his has imposed on [me]79-emma , but [he]2882-his has not injured [me]79-emma . [I]79-emma have never been attached to [him]2882-his . And now [I]79-emma can tolerably comprehend [his]2882-his behaviour . [He]2882-his never wished to attach [me]79-emma . It was merely a blind to conceal [his]2882-his real situation with another.—It was [his]2882-his object to blind all about [him]2882-his ; and [no one]813-no one , [I]79-emma am sure , could be more effectually blinded than [myself]79-emma — except that [I]79-emma was not blinded — that it was [my]79-emma good fortune — that , in short , [I]79-emma was somehow or other safe from [him]2882-his . ”[79-emma] [She]2883-she had hoped for an answer here — for a few words to say that [her]2883-she conduct was at least intelligible ; but [he]2884-i was silent ; and , as far as [she]2883-she could judge , deep in thought . At last , and tolerably in [his]2884-i usual tone , [he]2884-i said , “ [I]2884-i have never had a high opinion of [Frank Churchill.—I]347-frank churchill.—i can suppose , however , that [I]2884-i may have underrated [him]2882-his . [My]2884-i acquaintance with [him]2882-his has been but trifling.—And even if [I]2884-i have not underrated [him]2882-his hitherto , [he]2882-his may yet turn out well.—With [such a woman [he]2882-his has [a chance.—I]5379-a chance.—i]5378-such a woman he has a chance.—i have no motive for wishing [him]2882-his ill — and for [her]5378-such a woman he has a chance.—i sake , whose happiness will be involved in [his]2882-his good character and conduct , [I]2884-i shall certainly wish [him]2882-his well . ”[2884-i] “ [I]79-emma have no doubt of [their]5380-their being happy together , ”[79-emma] said [Emma]79-emma ; “ [I]2884-i believe [them]5380-their to be very mutually and very sincerely attached . ”[2884-i] “ [He]2882-his is [a most fortunate man]5381-a most fortunate man ! ”[88-mr. knightley] returned [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , with energy . “ So early in life — at three - and - twenty — a period when , if [a man]548-a man chuses [a wife]3164-a wife , [he]548-a man generally chuses ill . At three - and - twenty to have drawn such a prize ! What years of felicity [that man]5384-that man , in all human calculation , has before him!—Assured of the love of [such a woman]2140-such a woman — the disinterested love , for [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s character vouches for [her]142-miss fairfax disinterestedness ; every thing in [his]2882-his favour,—equality of situation — [I]88-mr. knightley mean , as far as regards society , and all the habits and manners that are important ; equality in every point but one — and that one , since the purity of [her]142-miss fairfax heart is not to be doubted , such as must increase [his]2882-his felicity , for it will be [his]2882-his to bestow the only advantages [she]142-miss fairfax wants.—A [man]3454-man would always wish to give [a woman]3207-a woman a better home than [the one [he]3454-man takes [her]3207-a woman from]5388-the one he takes her from ; and [[he]3454-man who can do it , where there is no doubt of [her]142-miss fairfax regard]5389-he who can do it , where there is no doubt of her regard , must , [I]88-mr. knightley think , be the happiest of [mortals.—Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill is , indeed , [the favourite of fortune]5390-the favourite of fortune . Every thing turns out for [[his]2882-his good.—He]5391-his good.—he meets with [a young woman]1346-a young woman at [a watering - place]5393-a watering - place , gains [her]1346-a young woman affection , can not even weary [her]1346-a young woman by negligent treatment — and had [he]2882-his and all [[his]2882-his family]736-his family sought round [the world]392-the world for [a perfect wife for [him]2882-his]5396-a perfect wife for him , [they]736-his family could not have found [her]142-miss fairfax superior.—His aunt is in the way.—His aunt dies.—He has only to speak.—His [friends]3230-friends are eager to promote [his]2882-his happiness.—He had used every body ill — and [they]3230-friends are all delighted to forgive him.—He is [a fortunate man]5398-a fortunate man indeed ! ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [You]79-emma speak as if [you]79-emma envied [him]2882-his . ”[79-emma] “ And [I]79-emma do envy [him]2882-his , [Emma]79-emma . In one respect [he]2882-his is the object of [my]79-emma envy . ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma could say no more . [They]2885-they seemed to be within half a sentence of [Harriet]107-harriet , and [her]79-emma immediate feeling was to avert the subject , if possible . [She]79-emma made [her]79-emma plan ; [she]79-emma would speak of something totally different — [the children in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square]2886-the children in brunswick square ; and [she]79-emma only waited for breath to begin , when [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley startled [her]79-emma , by saying , “ [You]79-emma will not ask [me]88-mr. knightley what is the point of envy.—You are determined , [I]88-mr. knightley see , to have no curiosity.—You are wise — but [I]88-mr. knightley can not be wise . [Emma]79-emma , [I]88-mr. knightley must tell [you]79-emma what [you]79-emma will not ask , though [I]88-mr. knightley may wish it unsaid the next moment . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Oh ! then , do n’t speak it , do n’t speak it , ”[79-emma] [she]79-emma eagerly cried . “ Take a little time , consider , do not commit [yourself]79-emma . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Thank [you]79-emma , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [he]88-mr. knightley , in an accent of deep mortification , and not another syllable followed . [Emma]79-emma could not bear to give [him]88-mr. knightley pain . [He]88-mr. knightley was wishing to confide in [her]79-emma — perhaps to consult her;—cost [her]79-emma what it would , [she]79-emma would listen . [She]79-emma might assist [his]88-mr. knightley resolution , or reconcile [him]88-mr. knightley to it ; [she]79-emma might give just praise to [Harriet]107-harriet , or , by representing to [him]88-mr. knightley [his]88-mr. knightley own independence , relieve [him]88-mr. knightley from that state of indecision , which must be more intolerable than any alternative to such a mind as his.—They had reached [the house]425-the house . “ [You]79-emma are going in , [I]88-mr. knightley suppose ? ”[88-mr. knightley] said [he]88-mr. knightley . “ No,”—replied[88-mr. knightley] [Emma]79-emma — quite confirmed by the depressed manner in which [he]88-mr. knightley still spoke—“I should like to take another turn . [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry is not gone . ”[88-mr. knightley] And , after proceeding a few steps , [she]79-emma added—“I stopped [you]79-emma ungraciously , just now , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , and , [I]88-mr. knightley am afraid , gave [you]79-emma pain.—But if [you]79-emma have any wish to speak openly to [me]88-mr. knightley as [a friend]405-a friend , or to ask [my]88-mr. knightley opinion of any thing that [you]79-emma may have in contemplation — as [a friend]405-a friend , indeed , [you]79-emma may command me.—I will hear whatever [you]79-emma like . [I]88-mr. knightley will tell [you]79-emma exactly what [I]88-mr. knightley think . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ As a friend!”—repeated[348-mr. knightley.—“emma] [Mr. Knightley.—“Emma]348-mr. knightley.—“emma , that [I]2888-i fear is a word — No , [I]2888-i have no wish — Stay , yes , why should [I]2888-i hesitate?—I have gone too far already for concealment.—Emma , [I]2888-i accept [your]2888-i offer — Extraordinary as it may seem , [I]2888-i accept it , and refer [myself]2888-i to [you]2888-i as a friend.—Tell [me]2888-i , then , have [I]2888-i no chance of ever succeeding ? ”[2888-i] [He]2888-i stopped in [his]2888-i earnestness to look the question , and the expression of [his]2888-i eyes overpowered [her]2889-her . “ [[My]2888-i dearest]696-my dearest [Emma]79-emma , ”[2888-i] said [he]2888-i , “ for dearest [you]79-emma will always be , whatever the event of this hour ’s conversation , [[my]2888-i dearest , most beloved [Emma]79-emma]5402-my dearest , most beloved emma — tell [me]2888-i at once . Say ‘ No , ’ if it is to be said . ”—She[2888-i] could really say [nothing.—“You]79-emma are silent , ”[2888-i] [he]2888-i cried , with great animation ; “ absolutely silent ! at present [I]2888-i ask no more . ”[2888-i] [Emma]79-emma was almost ready to sink under the agitation of this moment . The dread of being awakened from the happiest dream , was perhaps the most prominent feeling . “ [I]2888-i can not make speeches , [Emma]79-emma : ”[2888-i] [he]2888-i soon resumed ; and in a tone of such sincere , decided , intelligible tenderness as was tolerably convincing.—“If [I]2888-i loved [you]79-emma less , [I]2888-i might be able to talk about it more . But [you]79-emma know what [I]2888-i am.—You hear nothing but truth from me.—I have blamed [you]79-emma , and lectured [you]79-emma , and [you]79-emma have borne it as [no other woman in [England]38-england]5403-no other woman in england would have borne it.—Bear with the truths [I]2888-i would tell [you]79-emma now , [dearest Emma]79-emma , as well as [you]79-emma have borne with [them]5404-them . The manner , perhaps , may have as little to recommend [them]5404-them . God knows , [I]2888-i have been [a very indifferent]5405-a very indifferent lover.—But [you]79-emma understand me.—Yes , [you]79-emma see , [you]79-emma understand [my]2888-i feelings — and will return them if [you]79-emma can . At present , [I]2888-i ask only to hear , once to hear [your]79-emma voice . ”[2888-i] While [he]2890-he spoke , [Emma]79-emma ’s mind was most busy , and , with all the wonderful velocity of thought , had been able — and yet without losing a word — to catch and comprehend the exact truth of the whole ; to see that [Harriet]107-harriet ’s hopes had been entirely groundless , a mistake , a delusion , as complete a delusion as any of [her]79-emma own — that [Harriet]107-harriet was nothing ; that [she]107-harriet was every thing [herself]107-harriet ; that what [she]107-harriet had been saying relative to [Harriet]107-harriet had been all taken as the language of [her]107-harriet own feelings ; and that [her]107-harriet agitation , [her]107-harriet doubts , [her]107-harriet reluctance , [her]107-harriet discouragement , had been all received as discouragement from herself.—And not only was there time for these convictions , with all [their]2891-their glow of attendant happiness ; there was time also to rejoice that [Harriet]107-harriet ’s secret had not escaped [her]79-emma , and to resolve that it need not , and should not.—It was all the service [she]79-emma could now render [[her]79-emma poor friend]2892-her poor friend ; for as to any of that heroism of sentiment which might have prompted [her]79-emma to entreat [him]2892-her poor friend to transfer [his]2892-her poor friend affection from [herself]79-emma to [Harriet]107-harriet , as infinitely the most worthy of [the two]1913-the two — or even the more simple sublimity of resolving to refuse [him]2892-her poor friend at once and for ever , without vouchsafing any motive , because [he]2892-her poor friend could not marry [them]1913-the two both , [Emma]79-emma had it not . [She]79-emma felt for [Harriet]107-harriet , with pain and with contrition ; but no flight of generosity run mad , opposing all that could be probable or reasonable , entered [her]79-emma brain . [She]79-emma had led [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend astray , and it would be a reproach to [her]79-emma for ever ; but [her]79-emma judgment was as strong as [her]79-emma feelings , and as strong as it had ever been before , in reprobating any such alliance for [him]2892-her poor friend , as most unequal and degrading . [Her]79-emma way was clear , though not quite smooth.—She spoke then , on being so entreated.—What did [she]79-emma say?—Just what [she]79-emma ought , of course . [A lady]626-a lady always does.—She said enough to [shew]2896-shew there need not be despair — and to invite [him]2892-her poor friend to say more [himself]2892-her poor friend . [He]2892-her poor friend had despaired at one period ; [he]2892-her poor friend had received such an injunction to caution and silence , as for the time crushed every hope;—she had begun by refusing to hear him.—The change had perhaps been somewhat sudden;—her proposal of taking another turn , [her]79-emma renewing the conversation which [she]79-emma had just put an end to , might be a little extraordinary!—She felt its inconsistency ; but [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley was so obliging as to put up with it , and seek no farther explanation . Seldom , very seldom , does complete truth belong to any human disclosure ; seldom can it happen that something is not a little disguised , or a little mistaken ; but where , as in this case , though the conduct is mistaken , the feelings are not , it may not be very material.—Mr . [Knightley]88-mr. knightley could not impute to [Emma]79-emma a more relenting heart than [she]79-emma possessed , or a heart more disposed to accept of [his]88-mr. knightley . [He]88-mr. knightley had , in fact , been wholly unsuspicious of [his]88-mr. knightley own influence . [He]88-mr. knightley had followed [her]79-emma into the shrubbery with no idea of trying it . [He]88-mr. knightley had come , in [his]88-mr. knightley anxiety to see how [she]79-emma bore [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s engagement , with no selfish view , no view at all , but of endeavouring , if [she]79-emma allowed [him]88-mr. knightley an opening , to soothe or to counsel her.—The rest had been the work of the moment , the immediate effect of what [he]88-mr. knightley heard , on [his]88-mr. knightley feelings . The delightful assurance of [her]79-emma total indifference towards [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , of [her]79-emma having a heart completely disengaged from [him]88-mr. knightley , had given birth to the hope , that , in time , [he]88-mr. knightley might gain [her]79-emma affection himself;—but it had been no present hope — [he]88-mr. knightley had only , in the momentary conquest of eagerness over judgment , aspired to be told that [she]79-emma did not forbid [his]88-mr. knightley attempt to attach her.—The superior hopes which gradually opened were so much the more enchanting.—The affection , which [he]88-mr. knightley had been asking to be allowed to create , if [he]88-mr. knightley could , was already his!—Within half an hour , [he]88-mr. knightley had passed from a thoroughly distressed state of mind , to something so like perfect happiness , that it could bear no other name . [Her]79-emma change was equal.—This one half - hour had given to each the same precious certainty of being beloved , had cleared from each the same degree of ignorance , jealousy , or distrust.—On [his]88-mr. knightley side , there had been a long - standing jealousy , old as the arrival , or even the expectation , of [Frank Churchill.—He]349-frank churchill.—he had been in love with [Emma]79-emma , and jealous of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , from about the same period , one sentiment having probably enlightened [him]88-mr. knightley as to the other . It was [his]88-mr. knightley jealousy of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill that had taken [him]88-mr. knightley from [the country.—The Box Hill party]2897-the country.—the box hill party had decided [him]88-mr. knightley on going away . [He]88-mr. knightley would save [himself]88-mr. knightley from witnessing again such permitted , encouraged [attentions.—He]350-attentions.—he had gone to learn to be indifferent.—But [he]88-mr. knightley had gone to [a wrong place]2898-a wrong place . There was too much domestic happiness in [[[his]88-mr. knightley brother]3468-his brother ’s house]2900-his brother ’s house ; [woman]3428-woman wore too amiable a form in it ; [Isabella]83-isabella was too much like [Emma]79-emma — differing only in those striking inferiorities , which always brought [the other]3423-the other in brilliancy before [him]88-mr. knightley , for much to have been done , even had [his]88-mr. knightley time been longer.—He had stayed on , however , vigorously , day after day — till this very morning ’s post had conveyed the history of [Jane Fairfax.—Then]351-jane fairfax.—then , with the gladness which must be felt , nay , which [he]88-mr. knightley did not scruple to feel , having never believed [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill to be at all deserving [Emma]79-emma , was there so much fond solicitude , so much keen anxiety for [her]79-emma , that [he]88-mr. knightley could stay no longer . [He]88-mr. knightley had ridden [home]3258-home through the rain ; and had walked up directly after dinner , to see how [this sweetest and best of all creatures]2904-this sweetest and best of all creatures , faultless in spite of all [her]79-emma faults , bore the discovery . [He]88-mr. knightley had found [her]79-emma agitated and [low.—Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill was [a villain]2905-a villain . — [He]88-mr. knightley heard [her]79-emma declare that [she]79-emma had never loved [him]98-frank churchill . [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s character was not desperate.—She was [his]98-frank churchill own [Emma]79-emma , by hand and word , when [they]2906-they returned into [the house]425-the house ; and if [he]98-frank churchill could have thought of [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill then , [he]98-frank churchill might have deemed [him]98-frank churchill [a very good sort of fellow]2908-a very good sort of fellow . CHAPTER XIV What totally different feelings did [Emma]79-emma take back into [the house]425-the house from what [she]79-emma had brought out!—she had then been only daring to hope for a little respite of suffering;—she was now in an exquisite flutter of happiness , and such happiness moreover as [she]79-emma believed must still be greater when the flutter should have passed away . [They]2906-they sat down to tea — the same party round the same table — how often it had been collected!—and how often had [her]79-emma eyes fallen on the same shrubs in [the lawn]4546-the lawn , and observed the same beautiful effect of the western sun!—But never in such a state of spirits , never in any thing like it ; and it was with difficulty that [she]79-emma could summon enough of [her]79-emma usual self to be [the attentive lady of [the house]425-the house]2911-the attentive lady of the house , or even [the attentive daughter]2913-the attentive daughter . [Poor Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse little suspected what was plotting against [him]81-mr. woodhouse in the breast of [that man whom [he]81-mr. woodhouse was so cordially welcoming]2914-that man whom he was so cordially welcoming , and so anxiously hoping might not have taken cold from [his]81-mr. woodhouse ride.—Could [he]81-mr. woodhouse have seen the heart , [he]81-mr. woodhouse would have cared very little for the lungs ; but without the most distant imagination of the impending evil , without the slightest perception of any thing extraordinary in the looks or ways of either , [he]81-mr. woodhouse repeated to [them]2906-they very comfortably all the articles of news [he]81-mr. woodhouse had received from [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry , and talked on with much self - contentment , totally unsuspicious of what [they]2906-they could have told [him]81-mr. woodhouse in return . As long as [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley remained with [them]2906-they , [Emma]79-emma ’s fever continued ; but when [he]88-mr. knightley was gone , [she]79-emma began to be a little tranquillised and subdued — and in the course of the sleepless night , which was the tax for such an evening , [she]79-emma found one or two such very serious points to consider , as made [her]79-emma feel , that even [her]79-emma happiness must have some alloy . [[Her]79-emma father]415-her father — and [Harriet]107-harriet . [She]79-emma could not be alone without feeling the full weight of [their]2906-they separate claims ; and how to guard the comfort of both to the utmost , was the question . With respect to [[her]79-emma father]415-her father , it was a question soon answered . [She]79-emma hardly knew yet what [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley would ask ; but a very short parley with [her]79-emma own heart produced the most solemn resolution of never quitting [her]79-emma father.—She even wept over the idea of it , as a sin of thought . While [he]88-mr. knightley lived , it must be only an engagement ; but [she]79-emma flattered [herself]79-emma , that if divested of the danger of drawing [her]79-emma away , it might become an increase of comfort to him.—How to do [her]79-emma best by [Harriet]107-harriet , was of more difficult decision;—how to spare [her]107-harriet from any unnecessary pain ; how to make [her]107-harriet any possible atonement ; how to appear least [her]107-harriet enemy?—On these subjects , [her]107-harriet perplexity and distress were very great — and [her]79-emma mind had to pass again and again through every bitter reproach and sorrowful regret that had ever surrounded it.—She could only resolve at last , that [she]79-emma would still avoid a meeting with [her]107-harriet , and communicate all that need be told by letter ; that it would be inexpressibly desirable to have [her]107-harriet removed just now for a time from [Highbury]3-highbury , and — indulging in one scheme more — nearly resolve , that it might be practicable to get an invitation for [her]107-harriet to [Brunswick Square.—Isabella]73-brunswick square.—isabella had been pleased with [Harriet]107-harriet ; and a few weeks spent in [London]1-london must give [her]107-harriet some amusement.—She did not think it in [Harriet]107-harriet ’s nature to escape being benefited by novelty and variety , by [the streets]2917-the streets , [the shops]2918-the shops , and the children.—At any rate , it would be a proof of attention and kindness in [herself]107-harriet , from whom every thing was due ; a separation for the present ; an averting of the evil day , when [they]2919-they must all be together again . [She]107-harriet rose early , and wrote [her]107-harriet letter to [Harriet]107-harriet ; an employment which left [her]107-harriet so very serious , so nearly sad , that [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , in walking up to [Hartfield]90-hartfield to breakfast , did not arrive at all too soon ; and half an hour stolen afterwards to go over the same ground again with [him]88-mr. knightley , literally and figuratively , was quite necessary to reinstate [her]107-harriet in a proper share of the happiness of the evening before . [He]88-mr. knightley had not left [her]107-harriet long , by no means long enough for [her]107-harriet to have the slightest inclination for thinking of any body else , when a letter was brought [her]107-harriet from [Randalls]97-randalls — a very thick letter;—she guessed what it must contain , and deprecated the necessity of reading it.—She was now in perfect charity with [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ; [she]107-harriet wanted no explanations , [she]107-harriet wanted only to have [her]107-harriet thoughts to [herself]107-harriet — and as for understanding any thing [he]88-mr. knightley wrote , [she]107-harriet was sure [she]107-harriet was incapable of it.—It must be waded through , however . [She]107-harriet opened the packet ; it was too surely so;—a note from [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston to [herself]107-harriet , ushered in the letter from [Frank]98-frank churchill to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . “ [I]2920-i have the greatest pleasure , [[my]2920-i dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , in forwarding to [you]79-emma the enclosed . [I]2920-i know what thorough justice [you]79-emma will do it , and have scarcely a doubt of its happy effect.—I think [we]5407-we shall never materially disagree about [the writer]3411-the writer again ; but [I]2920-i will not delay [you]79-emma by a long preface.—We are quite well.—This letter has been the cure of all the little nervousness [I]2920-i have been feeling lately.—I did not quite like [your]79-emma looks on Tuesday , but it was an ungenial morning ; and though [you]79-emma will never own being affected by weather , [I]2920-i think [every body]3270-every body feels a north - east wind.—I felt for [[your]79-emma dear father]5410-your dear father very much in the storm of Tuesday afternoon and yesterday morning , but had the comfort of hearing last night , by [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry , that it had not made [him]102-mr. perry ill . “[2920-i] [Yours]2920-i ever , “ A. W. ”[84-mrs. weston] [ To [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . ] [Windsor]72-windsor — July . [[MY]0-i DEAR MADAM]1118-my dear madam , “ If [I]1118-my dear madam made [myself]1118-my dear madam intelligible yesterday , this letter will be expected ; but expected or not , [I]1118-my dear madam know it will be read with candour and indulgence.—You are all goodness , and [I]1118-my dear madam believe there will be need of even all [your]79-emma goodness to allow for some parts of [my]1118-my dear madam past conduct.—But [I]1118-my dear madam have been forgiven by one who had still more to resent . [My]1118-my dear madam courage rises while [I]1118-my dear madam write . It is very difficult for [the prosperous]5411-the prosperous to be humble . [I]1118-my dear madam have already met with such success in two applications for pardon , that [I]1118-my dear madam may be in danger of thinking [myself]1118-my dear madam too sure of [yours]79-emma , and of those among [[your]79-emma friends who have had any ground of offence.—You]5412-your friends who have had any ground of offence.—you must all endeavour to comprehend the exact nature of [my]1118-my dear madam situation when [I]1118-my dear madam first arrived at [Randalls]97-randalls ; [you]79-emma must consider [me]1118-my dear madam as having a secret which was to be kept at all hazards . This was the fact . [My]1118-my dear madam right to place [myself]1118-my dear madam in a situation requiring such concealment , is another question . [I]1118-my dear madam shall not discuss it here . For [my]1118-my dear madam temptation to think it a right , [I]1118-my dear madam refer every caviller to [a brick house]5413-a brick house , sashed windows below , and casements above , in [Highbury]3-highbury . [I]1118-my dear madam dared not address [her]79-emma openly ; [my]1118-my dear madam difficulties in the then state of [Enscombe]7-enscombe must be too well known to require definition ; and [I]1118-my dear madam was fortunate enough to prevail , before [we]5414-we parted at [Weymouth]26-weymouth , and to induce [the most upright female mind in the creation]5415-the most upright female mind in the creation to stoop in charity to a secret engagement.—Had [she]79-emma refused , [I]1118-my dear madam should have gone mad.—But [you]79-emma will be ready to say , what was [your]79-emma hope in doing this?—What did [you]79-emma look forward to?—To any thing , every thing — to time , chance , circumstance , slow effects , sudden bursts , perseverance and weariness , health and sickness . Every possibility of good was before [me]1118-my dear madam , and the first of blessings secured , in obtaining [her]79-emma promises of faith and correspondence . If [you]79-emma need farther explanation , [I]1118-my dear madam have the honour , [[my]1118-my dear madam dear madam]1118-my dear madam , of being [[[your]79-emma husband]5417-your husband ’s son]5418-your husband ’s son , and the advantage of inheriting a disposition to hope for good , which no inheritance of [houses]5419-houses or lands can ever equal the value of.—See [me]1118-my dear madam , then , under these circumstances , arriving on [my]1118-my dear madam first visit to [Randalls;—and]74-randalls;—and [here]3113-here [I]1118-my dear madam am conscious of wrong , for that visit might have been sooner paid . [You]79-emma will look back and see that [I]1118-my dear madam did not come till [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax was in [Highbury]3-highbury ; and as [you]79-emma were [the person slighted]5421-the person slighted , [you]79-emma will forgive [me]1118-my dear madam instantly ; but [I]1118-my dear madam must work on [[my]1118-my dear madam father]3146-my father ’s compassion , by reminding [him]3146-my father , that so long as [I]1118-my dear madam absented [myself]1118-my dear madam from [[his]3146-my father house]398-his house , so long [I]1118-my dear madam lost the blessing of knowing [you]79-emma . [My]1118-my dear madam behaviour , during the very happy fortnight which [I]1118-my dear madam spent with [you]79-emma , did not , [I]1118-my dear madam hope , lay [me]1118-my dear madam open to reprehension , excepting on one point . And now [I]1118-my dear madam come to [the principal]5424-the principal , the only important part of [my]1118-my dear madam conduct while belonging to [you]79-emma , which excites [my]1118-my dear madam own anxiety , or requires very solicitous explanation . With the greatest respect , and the warmest friendship , do [I]1118-my dear madam mention [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield ; [[my]1118-my dear madam father]3146-my father perhaps will think [I]1118-my dear madam ought to add , with the deepest humiliation.—A few words which dropped from [him]3146-my father yesterday spoke [his]3146-my father opinion , and some censure [I]1118-my dear madam acknowledge [myself]1118-my dear madam liable to.—My behaviour to [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield indicated , [I]1118-my dear madam believe , more than it ought.—In order to assist a concealment so essential to [me]1118-my dear madam , [I]1118-my dear madam was led on to make more than an allowable use of the sort of intimacy into which [we]5426-we were immediately thrown.—I can not deny that [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield was [my]1118-my dear madam ostensible object — but [I]1118-my dear madam am sure [you]79-emma will believe the declaration , that had [I]1118-my dear madam not been convinced of [her]90-hartfield indifference , [I]1118-my dear madam would not have been induced by any selfish views to go on.—Amiable and delightful as [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield is , [she]90-hartfield never gave [me]1118-my dear madam the idea of [a young woman]1346-a young woman likely to be attached ; and that [she]90-hartfield was perfectly free from any tendency to being attached to [me]1118-my dear madam , was as much [my]1118-my dear madam conviction as [my]1118-my dear madam wish.—She received [my]1118-my dear madam attentions with an easy , friendly , goodhumoured playfulness , which exactly suited [me]1118-my dear madam . [We]5426-we seemed to understand [each other]420-each other . From [our]5426-we relative situation , those attentions were [her]90-hartfield due , and were felt to be [so.—Whether Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield began really to understand [me]1118-my dear madam before the expiration of that fortnight , [I]1118-my dear madam can not say;—when [I]1118-my dear madam called to take leave of [her]90-hartfield , [I]1118-my dear madam remember that [I]1118-my dear madam was within a moment of confessing the truth , and [I]1118-my dear madam then fancied [she]90-hartfield was not without suspicion ; but [I]1118-my dear madam have no doubt of [her]90-hartfield having since detected [me]1118-my dear madam , at least in some degree.—She may not have surmised the whole , but [her]90-hartfield quickness must have penetrated a part . [I]1118-my dear madam can not doubt it . [You]5429-you will find , whenever the subject becomes freed from its present restraints , that it did not take [her]90-hartfield wholly by surprize . [She]90-hartfield frequently gave [me]1118-my dear madam hints of it . [I]1118-my dear madam remember [her]90-hartfield telling [me]1118-my dear madam at the ball , that [I]1118-my dear madam owed [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton gratitude for [her]90-hartfield attentions to [Miss Fairfax.—I]352-miss fairfax.—i hope this history of [my]1118-my dear madam conduct towards [her]90-hartfield will be admitted by [you]5429-you and [[my]1118-my dear madam father]3146-my father as great extenuation of what [you]5429-you saw amiss . While [you]5429-you considered [me]1118-my dear madam as having sinned against [Emma Woodhouse]79-emma , [I]1118-my dear madam could deserve nothing from either . Acquit [me]1118-my dear madam here , and procure for [me]1118-my dear madam , when it is allowable , the acquittal and good wishes of that said [[Emma Woodhouse]79-emma , whom [I]1118-my dear madam regard with so much brotherly affection , as to long to have [her]90-hartfield as deeply and as happily in love as myself.—Whatever strange things [I]1118-my dear madam said or did during that fortnight , [you]5429-you have now a key to]79-emma . [My]1118-my dear madam heart was in [Highbury]3-highbury , and [my]1118-my dear madam business was to get [my]1118-my dear madam body thither as often as might be , and with the least suspicion . If [you]5429-you remember any queernesses , set them all to the right account.—Of the pianoforte so much talked of , [I]1118-my dear madam feel it only necessary to say , that its being ordered was absolutely unknown to [Miss F]353-miss f — , who would never have allowed [me]1118-my dear madam to send it , had any choice been given her.—The delicacy of [her]90-hartfield mind throughout the whole engagement , [[my]1118-my dear madam dear madam]1118-my dear madam , is much beyond [my]1118-my dear madam power of doing justice to . [You]5429-you will soon , [I]1118-my dear madam earnestly hope , know [her]90-hartfield thoroughly yourself.—No description can describe [her]90-hartfield . [She]90-hartfield must tell [you]5429-you [herself]90-hartfield what [she]90-hartfield is — yet not by word , for never was there a human creature who would so designedly suppress [her]90-hartfield own merit.—Since [I]1118-my dear madam began this letter , which will be longer than [I]1118-my dear madam foresaw , [I]1118-my dear madam have heard from her.—She gives a good account of [her]90-hartfield own health ; but as [she]90-hartfield never complains , [I]1118-my dear madam dare not depend . [I]1118-my dear madam want to have [your]5429-you opinion of [her]90-hartfield looks . [I]1118-my dear madam know [you]5429-you will soon call on [her]90-hartfield ; [she]90-hartfield is living in dread of the visit . Perhaps it is paid already . Let [me]1118-my dear madam hear from [you]5429-you without delay ; [I]1118-my dear madam am impatient for a thousand particulars . Remember how few minutes [I]1118-my dear madam was at [Randalls]97-randalls , and in how bewildered , how mad a state : and [I]1118-my dear madam am not much better yet ; still insane either from happiness or misery . When [I]1118-my dear madam think of the kindness and favour [I]1118-my dear madam have met with , of [her]90-hartfield excellence and patience , and [[my]1118-my dear madam uncle]4485-my uncle ’s generosity , [I]1118-my dear madam am mad with joy : but when [I]1118-my dear madam recollect all the uneasiness [I]1118-my dear madam occasioned [her]90-hartfield , and how little [I]1118-my dear madam deserve to be forgiven , [I]1118-my dear madam am mad with anger . If [I]1118-my dear madam could but see [her]90-hartfield again!—But [I]1118-my dear madam must not propose it yet . [[My]1118-my dear madam uncle]4485-my uncle has been too good for [me]1118-my dear madam to encroach.—I must still add to this long letter . [You]5434-you have not heard all that [you]5434-you ought to hear . [I]1118-my dear madam could not give any connected detail yesterday ; but the suddenness , and , in one light , the unseasonableness with which the affair burst out , needs explanation ; for though the event of the 26th ult . , as [you]5434-you will conclude , immediately opened to [me]1118-my dear madam the happiest prospects , [I]1118-my dear madam should not have presumed on such early measures , but from the very particular circumstances , which left [me]1118-my dear madam not an hour to lose . [I]1118-my dear madam should [myself]1118-my dear madam have shrunk from any thing so hasty , and [she]90-hartfield would have felt every scruple of [mine]1118-my dear madam with multiplied strength and refinement.—But [I]1118-my dear madam had no choice . The hasty engagement [she]90-hartfield had entered into with [that woman]4698-that woman — Here , [[my]1118-my dear madam dear madam]1118-my dear madam , [I]1118-my dear madam was obliged to leave off abruptly , to recollect and compose myself.—I have been walking over [the country]3306-the country , and am now , [I]1118-my dear madam hope , rational enough to make the rest of [my]1118-my dear madam letter what it ought to be.—It is , in fact , a most mortifying retrospect for [me]1118-my dear madam . [I]1118-my dear madam behaved shamefully . And here [I]1118-my dear madam can admit , that [my]1118-my dear madam manners to [Miss W.]354-miss w. , in being unpleasant to [Miss F.]355-miss f. , were highly blameable . [She]90-hartfield disapproved them , which ought to have been enough.—My plea of concealing the truth [she]90-hartfield did not think sufficient.—She was displeased ; [I]1118-my dear madam thought unreasonably so : [I]1118-my dear madam thought [her]90-hartfield , on a thousand occasions , unnecessarily scrupulous and cautious : [I]1118-my dear madam thought [her]90-hartfield even cold . But [she]90-hartfield was always right . If [I]1118-my dear madam had followed [her]90-hartfield judgment , and subdued [my]1118-my dear madam spirits to the level of what [she]90-hartfield deemed proper , [I]1118-my dear madam should have escaped the greatest unhappiness [I]1118-my dear madam have ever known.—We quarrelled . — Do [you]5438-you remember the morning spent at [Donwell?—There]75-donwell?—there every little dissatisfaction that had occurred before came to a crisis . [I]1118-my dear madam was late ; [I]1118-my dear madam met [her]90-hartfield walking [home]3258-home by [herself]90-hartfield , and wanted to walk with [her]90-hartfield , but [she]90-hartfield would not suffer it . [She]90-hartfield absolutely refused to allow [me]1118-my dear madam , which [I]1118-my dear madam then thought most unreasonable . Now , however , [I]1118-my dear madam see nothing in it but a very natural and consistent degree of discretion . While [I]1118-my dear madam , to blind [the world]392-the world to [our]5441-our engagement , was behaving one hour with objectionable particularity to [another woman]4095-another woman , was [she]90-hartfield to be consenting the next to a proposal which might have made every previous caution useless?—Had [we]5441-our been met walking together between [Donwell]202-donwell and [Highbury]3-highbury , the truth must have been suspected.—I was mad enough , however , to resent.—I doubted [her]90-hartfield affection . [I]1118-my dear madam doubted it more the next day on [Box Hill]64-box hill ; when , provoked by such conduct on [my]1118-my dear madam side , such shameful , insolent neglect of [her]90-hartfield , and such apparent devotion to [Miss W.]354-miss w. , as it would have been impossible for [any woman of sense to endure]5443-any woman of sense to endure , [she]90-hartfield spoke [her]90-hartfield resentment in a form of words perfectly intelligible to me.—In short , [[my]1118-my dear madam dear madam]1118-my dear madam , it was a quarrel blameless on [her]90-hartfield side , abominable on [mine]1118-my dear madam ; and [I]1118-my dear madam returned the same evening to [Richmond]62-richmond , though [I]1118-my dear madam might have staid with [you]1118-my dear madam till the next morning , merely because [I]1118-my dear madam would be as angry with [her]90-hartfield as possible . Even then , [I]1118-my dear madam was not such [a fool]1027-a fool as not to mean to be reconciled in time ; but [I]1118-my dear madam was [the injured person]5446-the injured person , injured by [her]90-hartfield coldness , and [I]1118-my dear madam went away determined that [she]90-hartfield should make the first advances.—I shall always congratulate [myself]1118-my dear madam that [you]1118-my dear madam were not of [the Box Hill party]5447-the box hill party . Had [you]1118-my dear madam witnessed [my]1118-my dear madam behaviour [there]437-there , [I]1118-my dear madam can hardly suppose [you]1118-my dear madam would ever have thought well of [me]1118-my dear madam again . Its effect upon [her]90-hartfield appears in the immediate resolution it produced : as soon as [she]90-hartfield found [I]1118-my dear madam was really gone from [Randalls]97-randalls , [she]90-hartfield closed with the offer of that officious [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ; the whole system of whose treatment of [her]90-hartfield , by the bye , has ever filled [me]1118-my dear madam with indignation and hatred . [I]1118-my dear madam must not quarrel with a spirit of forbearance which has been so richly extended towards [myself]1118-my dear madam ; but , otherwise , [I]1118-my dear madam should loudly protest against the share of it which [that woman]4698-that woman has known.—‘Jane , ’ indeed!—You will observe that [I]1118-my dear madam have not yet indulged [myself]1118-my dear madam in calling [her]90-hartfield by that name , even to [you]1118-my dear madam . Think , then , what [I]1118-my dear madam must have endured in hearing it bandied between [the Eltons]331-the eltons with all the vulgarity of needless repetition , and all the insolence of imaginary superiority . Have patience with [me]1118-my dear madam , [I]1118-my dear madam shall soon have [done.—She]5450-done.—she closed with this offer , resolving to break with [me]1118-my dear madam entirely , and wrote the next day to tell [me]1118-my dear madam that [we]5451-we never were to meet again.—She felt the engagement to be a source of repentance and misery to each : [she]90-hartfield dissolved it.—This letter reached [me]1118-my dear madam on the very morning of [[my]1118-my dear madam poor aunt]5452-my poor aunt ’s death . [I]1118-my dear madam answered it within an hour ; but from the confusion of [my]1118-my dear madam mind , and the multiplicity of business falling on [me]1118-my dear madam at once , [my]1118-my dear madam answer , instead of being sent with all the many other letters of that day , was locked up in [my]1118-my dear madam writing - desk ; and [I]1118-my dear madam , trusting that [I]1118-my dear madam had written enough , though but a few lines , to satisfy [her]90-hartfield , remained without any uneasiness.—I was rather disappointed that [I]1118-my dear madam did not hear from [her]90-hartfield again speedily ; but [I]1118-my dear madam made excuses for [her]90-hartfield , and was too busy , and — may [I]1118-my dear madam add?—too cheerful in [my]1118-my dear madam views to be captious.—We removed to [Windsor]72-windsor ; and two days afterwards [I]1118-my dear madam received a parcel from [her]90-hartfield , [my]1118-my dear madam own letters all returned!—and a few lines at the same time by the post , stating [her]90-hartfield extreme surprize at not having had the smallest reply to [her]90-hartfield last ; and adding , that as silence on such a point could not be misconstrued , and as it must be equally desirable to both to have every subordinate arrangement concluded as soon as possible , [she]90-hartfield now sent [me]1118-my dear madam , by a safe conveyance , all [my]1118-my dear madam letters , and requested , that if [I]1118-my dear madam could not directly command [hers]90-hartfield , so as to send them to [Highbury]3-highbury within a week , [I]1118-my dear madam would forward them after that period to [her]90-hartfield at — : in short , the full direction to [Mr. Smallridge]356-mr. smallridge ’s , near [Bristol]43-bristol , stared [me]1118-my dear madam in the face . [I]1118-my dear madam knew the name , [the place]439-the place , [I]1118-my dear madam knew all about it , and instantly saw what [she]90-hartfield had been doing . It was perfectly accordant with that resolution of character which [I]1118-my dear madam knew [her]90-hartfield to possess ; and the secrecy [she]90-hartfield had maintained , as to any such design in [her]90-hartfield former letter , was equally descriptive of its anxious delicacy . For [the world]392-the world would not [she]90-hartfield have seemed to threaten [me.—Imagine]90-hartfield the shock ; imagine how , till [I]1118-my dear madam had actually detected [my]1118-my dear madam own blunder , [I]1118-my dear madam raved at the blunders of the post.—What was to be done?—One thing only.—I must speak to [[my]1118-my dear madam uncle]4485-my uncle .
