Without [his]4485-my uncle sanction [I]1118-my dear madam could not hope to be listened to again.—I spoke ; circumstances were in [my]1118-my dear madam favour ; the late event had softened away [his]4485-my uncle pride , and [he]4485-my uncle was , earlier than [I]1118-my dear madam could have anticipated , wholly reconciled and complying ; and could say at last , [poor man]5456-poor man ! with a deep sigh , that [he]4485-my uncle wished [I]1118-my dear madam might find as much happiness in the marriage state as [he]4485-my uncle had done.—I felt that it would be of a different sort.—Are [you]5457-you disposed to pity [me]1118-my dear madam for what [I]1118-my dear madam must have suffered in opening the cause to [him]4485-my uncle , for [my]1118-my dear madam suspense while all was at stake?—No ; do not pity [me]1118-my dear madam till [I]1118-my dear madam reached [Highbury]3-highbury , and saw how ill [I]1118-my dear madam had made [her]3-highbury . Do not pity [me]1118-my dear madam till [I]1118-my dear madam saw [her]3-highbury wan , sick looks.—I reached [Highbury]3-highbury at the time of day when , from [my]1118-my dear madam knowledge of [their]5458-their late breakfast hour , [I]1118-my dear madam was certain of a good chance of finding [her]3-highbury alone.—I was not disappointed ; and at last [I]1118-my dear madam was not disappointed either in the object of [my]1118-my dear madam journey . A great deal of very reasonable , very just displeasure [I]1118-my dear madam had to persuade away . But it is done ; [we]5459-we are reconciled , dearer , much dearer , than ever , and no moment ’s uneasiness can ever occur between [us]5459-we again . Now , [[my]1118-my dear madam dear madam]1118-my dear madam , [I]1118-my dear madam will release [you]1118-my dear madam ; but [I]1118-my dear madam could not conclude before . A thousand and a thousand thanks for all the kindness [you]1118-my dear madam have ever shewn [me]1118-my dear madam , and ten thousand for the attentions [your]1118-my dear madam heart will dictate towards her.—If [you]1118-my dear madam think [me]1118-my dear madam in a way to be happier than [I]1118-my dear madam deserve , [I]1118-my dear madam am quite of [your]1118-my dear madam opinion.—Miss W. calls [me]1118-my dear madam [the child of good fortune]5461-the child of good fortune . [I]1118-my dear madam hope [she]1118-my dear madam is right.—In one respect , [my]1118-my dear madam good fortune is undoubted , that of being able to subscribe [myself]1118-my dear madam , [Your]1118-my dear madam obliged and affectionate Son , [F. C. WESTON CHURCHILL]145-f. c. weston churchill . CHAPTER XV This letter must make its way to [Emma]79-emma ’s feelings . [She]79-emma was obliged , in spite of [her]79-emma previous determination to the contrary , to do it all the justice that [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston foretold . As soon as [she]79-emma came to [her]79-emma own name , it was irresistible ; every line relating to [herself]79-emma was interesting , and almost every line agreeable ; and when this charm ceased , the subject could still maintain itself , by the natural return of [her]79-emma former regard for [the writer]3411-the writer , and the very strong attraction which any picture of love must have for [her]79-emma at that moment . [She]79-emma never stopt till [she]79-emma had gone through the whole ; and though it was impossible not to feel that [he]3411-the writer had been wrong , yet [he]3411-the writer had been less wrong than [she]79-emma had supposed — and [he]3411-the writer had suffered , and was very sorry — and [he]3411-the writer was so grateful to [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , and so much in love with [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , and [she]79-emma was so happy [herself]79-emma , that there was no being severe ; and could [he]3411-the writer have entered [the room]3386-the room , [she]79-emma must have shaken hands with [him]3411-the writer as heartily as ever . [She]79-emma thought so well of the letter , that when [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley came again , [she]79-emma desired [him]88-mr. knightley to read it . [She]79-emma was sure of [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s wishing it to be communicated ; especially to one , who , like [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , had seen so much to blame in [his]0-i conduct . “[1118-my dear madam] [I]0-i shall be very glad to look it over , ” said [he]0-i ; “[0-i] but it seems long . [I]0-i will take it [home]3258-home with [me]0-i at night . ” But that would not do . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston was to call in the evening , and [she]79-emma must return it by [him]0-i . “[0-i] [I]0-i would rather be talking to [you]2923-you , ” [he]0-i replied ; “[0-i] but as it seems a matter of justice , it shall be done . ” [He]0-i began — stopping , however , almost directly to say , “[0-i] Had [I]0-i been offered the sight of one of [this gentleman]2924-this gentleman ’s letters to [[his]2924-this gentleman mother - in - law]1704-his mother - in - law a few months ago , [Emma]79-emma , it would not have been taken with such indifference . ” [He]0-i proceeded a little farther , reading to [himself]0-i ; and then , with a smile , observed , “[357-humph] [Humph]357-humph ! a fine complimentary opening : But it is [his]2924-this gentleman way . [One man]2926-one man ’s style must not be the rule of another ’s . [We]2927-we will not be severe . ” “[2927-we] It will be natural for [me]0-i , ” [he]0-i added shortly afterwards , “[0-i] to speak [my]0-i opinion aloud as [I]0-i read . By doing it , [I]0-i shall feel that [I]0-i am near [you]2923-you . It will not be so great a loss of time : but if [you]2923-you dislike it — ” “[2923-you] Not at all . [I]0-i should wish it . ” [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley returned to [his]0-i reading with greater alacrity . “[2924-this gentleman] [He]2924-this gentleman trifles here , ” said [he]0-i , “[2924-this gentleman] as to the temptation . [He]2924-this gentleman knows [he]2924-this gentleman is wrong , and has nothing rational to urge.—Bad.—He ought not to have formed [the engagement.—‘His father]2928-the engagement.—‘his father ’s disposition:’—he is unjust , however , to [[his]2924-this gentleman father]3213-his father . [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston ’s sanguine temper was a blessing on all [his]82-mr. weston upright and honourable exertions ; but [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston earned every present comfort before [he]82-mr. weston endeavoured to gain it.—Very true ; [he]82-mr. weston did not come till [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax was [here]3113-here . ” “[142-miss fairfax] And [I]0-i have not forgotten , ” said [Emma]79-emma , “[142-miss fairfax] how sure [you]2923-you were that [he]82-mr. weston might have come sooner if [he]82-mr. weston would . [You]2923-you pass it over very handsomely — but [you]2923-you were perfectly right . ” “[2923-you] [I]0-i was not quite impartial in [my]0-i judgment , [Emma:—but]358-emma:—but yet , [I]0-i think — had [you]2923-you not been in the case — [I]0-i should still have distrusted [him]82-mr. weston . ” When [he]82-mr. weston came to [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , [he]82-mr. weston was obliged to read the whole of it aloud — all that related to [her]90-hartfield , with a smile ; a look ; a shake of the head ; a word or two of assent , or disapprobation ; or merely of love , as the subject required ; concluding , however , seriously , and , after steady reflection , thus — “[0-i] Very bad — though it might have been worse.—Playing a most dangerous game . Too much indebted to the event for [his]82-mr. weston acquittal.—No judge of [his]82-mr. weston own manners by you.—Always deceived in fact by [his]82-mr. weston own wishes , and regardless of little besides [his]82-mr. weston own convenience.—Fancying [you]2923-you to have fathomed [his]82-mr. weston secret . Natural enough!—his own mind full of intrigue , that [he]82-mr. weston should suspect it in others.—Mystery ; Finesse — how [they]2931-they pervert the understanding ! [[My]0-i Emma]1327-my emma , does not every thing serve to prove more and more the beauty of truth and sincerity in all [our]2933-our dealings with each other ? ” [Emma]79-emma agreed to it , and with a blush of sensibility on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s account , which [she]79-emma could not give any sincere explanation of . “[82-mr. weston] [You]82-mr. weston had better go on , ” said [she]3207-a woman . [He]82-mr. weston did so , but very soon stopt again to say , “[82-mr. weston] the pianoforte ! Ah ! That was the act of [a very , very young man]2934-a very , very young man , [one too young to consider whether the inconvenience of it might not very much exceed the pleasure]2935-one too young to consider whether the inconvenience of it might not very much exceed the pleasure . A boyish scheme , indeed!—I can not comprehend [a man]548-a man ’s wishing to give [a woman]3207-a woman any proof of affection which [he]548-a man knows [she]3207-a woman would rather dispense with ; and [he]548-a man did know that [she]3207-a woman would have prevented the instrument ’s coming if [she]3207-a woman could . ” After this , [he]82-mr. weston made some progress without any pause . [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill ’s confession of having behaved shamefully was the first thing to call for more than a word in passing . “[3207-a woman] [I]0-i perfectly agree with [you]82-mr. weston , sir,”—was then [his]98-frank churchill remark . “[0-i] [You]82-mr. weston did behave very shamefully . [You]82-mr. weston never wrote a truer line . ” And having gone through what immediately followed of the basis of [their]5464-their disagreement , and [his]98-frank churchill persisting to act in direct opposition to [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s sense of right , [he]98-frank churchill made a fuller pause to say , “[82-mr. weston] This is very bad.—He had induced [her]3207-a woman to place [herself]3207-a woman , for [his]548-a man sake , in a situation of extreme difficulty and uneasiness , and it should have been [his]548-a man first object to prevent [her]3207-a woman from suffering unnecessarily.—She must have had much more to contend with , in carrying on the correspondence , than [he]548-a man could . [He]548-a man should have respected even unreasonable scruples , had there been such ; but [hers]2938-hers were all reasonable . [We]2939-we must look to [her]3207-a woman one fault , and remember that [she]3207-a woman had done a wrong thing in consenting to the engagement , to bear that [she]3207-a woman should have been in such a state of punishment . ” [Emma]79-emma knew that [he]98-frank churchill was now getting to the Box Hill party , and grew uncomfortable . [Her]79-emma own behaviour had been so very improper ! [She]79-emma was deeply ashamed , and a little afraid of [his]98-frank churchill next look . It was all read , however , steadily , attentively , and without the smallest remark ; and , excepting one momentary glance at [her]79-emma , instantly withdrawn , in the fear of giving pain — no remembrance of [Box Hill]64-box hill seemed to exist . “[3207-a woman] There is no saying much for the delicacy of [[our]2939-we good friends]2940-our good friends , [the Eltons]331-the eltons , ” was [his]98-frank churchill next observation.—“His[3207-a woman] feelings are natural.—What ! actually resolve to break with [him]548-a man entirely!—She felt the engagement to be a source of repentance and misery to each — [she]3207-a woman dissolved it.—What a view this gives of [her]3207-a woman sense of [his]548-a man behaviour!—Well , [he]548-a man must be a most extraordinary — ” “[548-a man] Nay , nay , read on.—You will find how very much [he]548-a man suffers . ” “[548-a man] [I]0-i hope [he]548-a man does , ” replied [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley coolly , and resuming the letter . “[0-i] ‘ [Smallridge!’—What]359-smallridge!’—what does this mean ? What is all this ? ” “[3207-a woman] [She]3207-a woman had engaged to go as [[governess]401-governess to [[Mrs. Smallridge]322-mrs. smallridge ’s children]2943-mrs. smallridge ’s children]2942-governess to mrs. smallridge ’s children — [a dear friend of [Mrs. Elton’s]244-mrs. elton’s]2944-a dear friend of mrs. elton’s — [a neighbour of [Maple Grove]53-maple grove]2945-a neighbour of maple grove ; and , by the bye , [I]0-i wonder how [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton bears the disappointment ? ” “[195-mrs. elton] Say nothing , [[my]0-i dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , while [you]79-emma oblige [me]0-i to read — not even of [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton . Only one page more . [I]0-i shall soon have done . What a letter [the man]758-the man writes ! ” “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [you]79-emma would read it with a kinder spirit towards [him]758-the man . ” “[79-emma] Well , there is feeling here.—He does seem to have suffered in finding [her]195-mrs. elton ill.—Certainly , [I]0-i can have no doubt of [his]758-the man being fond of [her]195-mrs. elton . ‘ Dearer , much dearer than ever . ’ [I]0-i hope [he]758-the man may long continue to feel all the value of such a reconciliation.—He is a very liberal thanker , with [his]758-the man thousands and tens of thousands.—‘Happier than [I]0-i deserve . ’ Come , [he]758-the man knows [himself]758-the man there . ‘ [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield calls [me]0-i [the child of good fortune]5461-the child of good fortune . ’—Those were [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield ’s words , were they ? — And a fine ending — and there is the letter . [The child of good fortune]5461-the child of good fortune ! That was [your]79-emma name for [him]758-the man , was it ? ” “[79-emma] [You]79-emma do not appear so well satisfied with [his]758-the man letter as [I]0-i am ; but still [you]79-emma must , at least [I]0-i hope [you]79-emma must , think the better of [him]758-the man for it . [I]0-i hope it does [him]758-the man some service with [you]79-emma . ” “[0-i] Yes , certainly it does . [He]758-the man has had great faults , faults of inconsideration and thoughtlessness ; and [I]0-i am very much of [his]758-the man opinion in thinking [him]758-the man likely to be happier than [he]758-the man deserves : but still as [he]758-the man is , beyond a doubt , really attached to [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , and will soon , it may be hoped , have the advantage of being constantly with [her]142-miss fairfax , [I]0-i am very ready to believe [his]758-the man character will improve , and acquire from [hers]142-miss fairfax the steadiness and delicacy of principle that it wants . And now , let [me]0-i talk to [you]79-emma of something else . [I]0-i have [another person]2950-another person ’s interest at present so much at heart , that [I]0-i can not think any longer about [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill . Ever since [I]0-i left [you]79-emma this morning , [Emma]79-emma , [my]0-i mind has been hard at work on one subject . ” The subject followed ; it was in plain , unaffected , gentlemanlike English , such as [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley used even to [the woman [he]88-mr. knightley was in love with]5465-the woman he was in love with , how to be able to ask [her]5465-the woman he was in love with to marry [him]88-mr. knightley , without attacking the happiness of [[her]142-miss fairfax father]415-her father . [Emma]79-emma ’s answer was ready at the first word . “[0-i] While [[her]142-miss fairfax dear father]2951-her dear father lived , any change of condition must be impossible for [her]142-miss fairfax . [She]142-miss fairfax could never quit [him]2951-her dear father . ” Part only of this answer , however , was admitted . The impossibility of [her]142-miss fairfax quitting [[her]142-miss fairfax father]415-her father , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley felt as strongly as [herself]142-miss fairfax ; but the inadmissibility of any other change , [he]88-mr. knightley could not agree to . [He]88-mr. knightley had been thinking it over most deeply , most intently ; [he]88-mr. knightley had at first hoped to induce [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse to remove with [her]142-miss fairfax to [Donwell]202-donwell ; [he]88-mr. knightley had wanted to believe it feasible , but [his]88-mr. knightley knowledge of [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse would not suffer [him]88-mr. knightley to deceive [himself]88-mr. knightley long ; and now [he]88-mr. knightley confessed [his]88-mr. knightley persuasion , that such a transplantation would be a risk of [[her]142-miss fairfax father]415-her father ’s comfort , perhaps even of [his]88-mr. knightley life , which must not be hazarded . [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse taken from [Hartfield!—No]76-hartfield!—no , [he]88-mr. knightley felt that it ought not to be attempted . But the plan which had arisen on the sacrifice of this , [he]88-mr. knightley trusted [[his]88-mr. knightley dearest]5469-his dearest [Emma]79-emma would not find in any respect objectionable ; it was , that [he]88-mr. knightley should be received at [Hartfield]90-hartfield ; that so long as [[her]142-miss fairfax father]415-her father ’s happiness — in other words , [his]88-mr. knightley life — required [Hartfield]90-hartfield to continue [[her]142-miss fairfax home]3333-her home , it should be [his]88-mr. knightley likewise . Of [their]5472-their all removing to [Donwell]202-donwell , [Emma]79-emma had already had [her]79-emma own passing thoughts . Like [him]88-mr. knightley , [she]79-emma had tried the scheme and rejected it ; but such an alternative as this had not occurred to [her]79-emma . [She]79-emma was sensible of all the affection it evinced . [She]79-emma felt that , in quitting [Donwell]202-donwell , [he]88-mr. knightley must be sacrificing a great deal of independence of hours and habits ; that in living constantly with [[her]142-miss fairfax father]415-her father , and in [no house of [his]88-mr. knightley own]5474-no house of his own , there would be much , very much , to be borne with . [She]79-emma promised to think of it , and advised [him]88-mr. knightley to think of it more ; but [he]88-mr. knightley was fully convinced , that no reflection could alter [his]88-mr. knightley wishes or [his]88-mr. knightley opinion on the subject . [He]88-mr. knightley had given it , [he]88-mr. knightley could assure [her]79-emma , very long and calm consideration ; [he]88-mr. knightley had been walking away from [William Larkins]223-william larkins the whole morning , to have [his]88-mr. knightley thoughts to [himself]88-mr. knightley . “[142-miss fairfax] Ah ! there is one difficulty unprovided for , ” cried [Emma]79-emma . “[142-miss fairfax] [I]0-i am sure [William Larkins]223-william larkins will not like it . [You]2952-you must get [his]223-william larkins consent before [you]2952-you ask [mine]0-i . ” [She]79-emma promised , however , to think of it ; and pretty nearly promised , moreover , to think of it , with the intention of finding it a very good scheme . It is remarkable , that [Emma]79-emma , in the many , very many , points of view in which [she]79-emma was now beginning to consider [Donwell Abbey]202-donwell , was never struck with any sense of injury to [[her]79-emma nephew]1441-her nephew [Henry]118-henry , whose rights as [heir - expectant]5476-heir - expectant had formerly been so tenaciously regarded . Think [she]79-emma must of the possible difference to [the poor little boy]5477-the poor little boy ; and yet [she]79-emma only gave [herself]79-emma a saucy conscious smile about it , and found amusement in detecting the real cause of that violent dislike of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s marrying [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , or any body else , which at the time [she]79-emma had wholly imputed to the amiable solicitude of [the sister]5478-the sister and [the aunt]3215-the aunt . This proposal of [his]88-mr. knightley , this plan of marrying and continuing at [Hartfield]90-hartfield — the more [she]79-emma contemplated it , the more pleasing it became . [His]88-mr. knightley evils seemed to lessen , [her]79-emma own advantages to increase , [their]5480-their mutual good to outweigh every drawback . Such a companion for [herself]79-emma in the periods of anxiety and cheerlessness before her!—Such [a partner]1928-a partner in all those duties and cares to which time must be giving increase of melancholy ! [She]79-emma would have been too happy but for [poor Harriet]107-harriet ; but every blessing of [her]79-emma own seemed to involve and advance the sufferings of [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend , who must now be even excluded from [Hartfield]90-hartfield . The delightful family party which [Emma]79-emma was securing for [herself]79-emma , [poor Harriet]107-harriet must , in mere charitable caution , be kept at a distance from . [She]107-harriet would be [a loser]5483-a loser in every way . [Emma]79-emma could not deplore [her]79-emma future absence as any deduction from [her]79-emma own enjoyment . In such a party , [Harriet]107-harriet would be rather a dead weight than otherwise ; but for [the poor girl]5484-the poor girl [herself]5484-the poor girl , it seemed a peculiarly cruel necessity that was to be placing [her]5484-the poor girl in such a state of unmerited punishment . In time , of course , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley would be forgotten , that is , supplanted ; but this could not be expected to happen very early . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley [himself]88-mr. knightley would be doing nothing to assist the cure;—not like [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , always so kind , so feeling , so truly considerate for every body , would never deserve to be less worshipped than now ; and it really was too much to hope even of [Harriet]107-harriet , that [she]107-harriet could be in love with [more than three men]5485-more than three men in one year . CHAPTER XVI It was a very great relief to [Emma]79-emma to find [Harriet]107-harriet as desirous as [herself]107-harriet to avoid a meeting . [Their]5486-their intercourse was painful enough by letter . How much worse , had [they]5486-their been obliged to meet ! [Harriet]107-harriet expressed [herself]107-harriet very much as might be supposed , without reproaches , or apparent sense of ill - usage ; and yet [Emma]79-emma fancied there was a something of resentment , a something bordering on it in [her]79-emma style , which increased the desirableness of [their]5486-their being separate.—It might be only [her]79-emma own consciousness ; but it seemed as if [an angel]612-an angel only could have been quite without resentment under such a stroke . [She]79-emma had no difficulty in procuring [Isabella]83-isabella ’s invitation ; and [she]79-emma was fortunate in having a sufficient reason for asking it , without resorting to invention.—There was a tooth amiss . [Harriet]107-harriet really wished , and had wished some time , to consult [a dentist]5488-a dentist . [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley was delighted to be of use ; any thing of ill health was a recommendation to [her]117-mrs. john knightley — and though not so fond of [a dentist]5488-a dentist as of [a Mr. Wingfield]147-mr. wingfield , [she]117-mrs. john knightley was quite eager to have [Harriet]107-harriet under [her]117-mrs. john knightley care.—When it was thus settled on [[her]79-emma sister]396-her sister ’s side , [Emma]79-emma proposed it to [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend , and found [her]79-emma very persuadable.—Harriet was to go ; [she]79-emma was invited for at least a fortnight ; [she]79-emma was to be conveyed in [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s carriage.—It was all arranged , it was all completed , and [Harriet]107-harriet was safe in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square . Now [Emma]79-emma could , indeed , enjoy [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s visits ; now [she]79-emma could talk , and [she]79-emma could listen with true happiness , unchecked by that sense of injustice , of guilt , of something most painful , which had haunted [her]79-emma when remembering how disappointed a heart was near [her]79-emma , how much might at that moment , and at a little distance , be enduring by the feelings which [she]79-emma had led astray [herself]79-emma . The difference of [Harriet]107-harriet at [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ’s , or in [London]1-london , made perhaps an unreasonable difference in [Emma]79-emma ’s sensations ; but [she]79-emma could not think of [her]107-harriet in [London]1-london without objects of curiosity and employment , which must be averting the past , and carrying [her]107-harriet out of [herself]107-harriet . [She]79-emma would not allow any other anxiety to succeed directly to the place in [her]79-emma mind which [Harriet]107-harriet had occupied . There was a communication before [her]79-emma , one which [she]79-emma only could be competent to make — the confession of [her]79-emma engagement to [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ; but [she]79-emma would have nothing to do with it at present.—She had resolved to defer the disclosure till [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston were safe and well . No additional agitation should be thrown at this period among those [she]79-emma loved — and the evil should not act on [herself]79-emma by anticipation before the appointed time.—A fortnight , at least , of leisure and peace of mind , to crown every warmer , but more agitating , delight , should be [hers]79-emma . [She]79-emma soon resolved , equally as a duty and a pleasure , to employ half an hour of this holiday of spirits in calling on [Miss Fairfax.—She]5493-miss fairfax.—she ought to go — and [she]79-emma was longing to see [her]5493-miss fairfax.—she ; the resemblance of [their]5494-their present situations increasing every other motive of goodwill . It would be a secret satisfaction ; but the consciousness of a similarity of prospect would certainly add to the interest with which [she]79-emma should attend to any thing [Jane]142-miss fairfax might communicate . [She]79-emma went — [she]79-emma had driven once unsuccessfully to the door , but had not been into [the house]425-the house since the morning after [Box Hill]64-box hill , when poor [Jane]142-miss fairfax had been in such distress as had filled [her]79-emma with compassion , though all the worst of [her]79-emma sufferings had been unsuspected.—The fear of being still unwelcome , determined [her]79-emma , though assured of [their]5494-their being at [home]3258-home , to wait in [the passage]3927-the passage , and send up [her]79-emma name.—She heard [Patty]185-patty announcing it ; but no such bustle succeeded as poor [Miss Bates]101-miss bates had before made so happily intelligible.—No ; [she]79-emma heard nothing but the instant reply of , “[2952-you] Beg [her]2953-her to walk up;”—and a moment afterwards [she]79-emma was met on the stairs by [Jane]101-miss bates [herself]101-miss bates , coming eagerly forward , as if no other reception of [her]101-miss bates were felt sufficient.—Emma had never seen [her]101-miss bates look so well , so lovely , so engaging . There was consciousness , animation , and warmth ; there was every thing which [her]101-miss bates countenance or manner could ever have wanted . — [She]79-emma came forward with an offered hand ; and said , in a low , but very feeling tone , “[2952-you] This is most kind , [indeed!—Miss Woodhouse]79-emma , it is impossible for [me]0-i to express — [I]0-i hope [you]79-emma will believe — Excuse [me]0-i for being so entirely without words . ” [Emma]79-emma was gratified , and would soon have [shewn]5498-shewn no want of words , if the sound of [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s voice from [the sitting - room]5499-the sitting - room had not checked [her]79-emma , and made it expedient to compress all [her]79-emma friendly and all [her]79-emma congratulatory sensations into a very , very earnest shake of the hand . [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates and [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton were together . [Miss Bates]101-miss bates was out , which accounted for the previous tranquillity . [Emma]79-emma could have wished [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton elsewhere ; but [she]79-emma was in a humour to have patience with every body ; and as [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton met [her]79-emma with unusual graciousness , [she]79-emma hoped [the rencontre]5500-the rencontre would do [them]5501-them no harm . [She]79-emma soon believed [herself]79-emma to penetrate [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton ’s thoughts , and understand why [she]79-emma was , like [herself]79-emma , in happy spirits ; it was being in [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s confidence , and fancying [herself]79-emma acquainted with what was still a secret to [other people]445-other people . [Emma]79-emma saw symptoms of it immediately in the expression of [her]79-emma face ; and while paying [her]79-emma own compliments to [Mrs. Bates]106-mrs. bates , and appearing to attend to [the good old lady]3835-the good old lady ’s replies , [she]79-emma saw [her]106-mrs. bates with a sort of anxious parade of mystery fold up a letter which [she]106-mrs. bates had apparently been reading aloud to [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , and return it into the purple and gold reticule by [her]106-mrs. bates side , saying , with significant nods , “[2954-our] [We]2954-our can finish this some other time , [you]2955-you know . [You]101-miss bates knew [I]2166-his lady should not stir till [[my]2166-his lady lord]4768-my lord and [master]4769-master appeared.—Here have [I]2166-his lady been sitting this hour , giving [these young ladies]5548-these young ladies a sample of true conjugal obedience — for who can say , [you]101-miss bates know , how soon it may be wanted ? ”[2166-his lady] [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was so hot and tired , that all this wit seemed thrown away . [His]91-mr. elton civilities to [the other ladies]1870-the other ladies must be paid ; but [his]91-mr. elton subsequent object was to lament over [himself]91-mr. elton for the heat [he]91-mr. elton was suffering , and the walk [he]91-mr. elton had had for nothing . “ When [I]91-mr. elton got to [Donwell]202-donwell , ”[91-mr. elton] said [he]91-mr. elton , “ [Knightley]88-mr. knightley could not be found . Very odd ! very unaccountable ! after the note [I]91-mr. elton sent [him]88-mr. knightley this morning , and the message [he]88-mr. knightley returned , that [he]88-mr. knightley should certainly be at [home]3258-home till one . ”[91-mr. elton] “ [Donwell]202-donwell ! ”[91-mr. elton] cried [[his]91-mr. elton wife.—“My]5550-his wife.—“my dear [Mr. E.]245-mr. e. , [you]245-mr. e. have not been to [Donwell!—You]368-donwell!—you mean [the Crown]4056-the crown ; [you]245-mr. e. come from the meeting at [the Crown]46-the crown . ”[91-mr. elton] “ No , no , that ’s to - morrow ; and [I]79-emma particularly wanted to see [Knightley]88-mr. knightley to - day on that very account.—Such a dreadful broiling morning!—I went over [the fields]5552-the fields too—(speaking in a tone of great ill - usage , ) which made it so much the worse . And then not to find [him]88-mr. knightley at [home]3258-home ! [I]79-emma assure [you]245-mr. e. [I]79-emma am not at all pleased . And no apology left , no message for [me]79-emma . [The housekeeper]3524-the housekeeper declared [she]3524-the housekeeper knew nothing of [my]79-emma being expected.—Very extraordinary!—And [nobody]3124-nobody knew at all which way [he]88-mr. knightley was gone . Perhaps to [Hartfield]90-hartfield , perhaps to [the Abbey Mill]5556-the abbey mill , perhaps into [[his]88-mr. knightley woods.—Miss Woodhouse]5557-his woods.—miss woodhouse , this is not like [[our]5558-our friend]5559-our friend Knightley!—Can [you]79-emma explain it ? ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma amused [herself]79-emma by protesting that it was very extraordinary , indeed , and that [she]79-emma had not a syllable to say for [him]2966-he . “ [I]195-mrs. elton can not imagine , ”[195-mrs. elton] said [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , ( feeling the indignity as [a wife]3164-a wife ought to do , ) “ [I]195-mrs. elton can not imagine how [he]2966-he could do such a thing by [you]79-emma , of [all people in [the world]392-the world]5560-all people in the world ! [The very last person whom one]5562-the very last person whom one should expect to be forgotten!—My dear [Mr. E.]245-mr. e. , [he]2966-he must have left a message for [you]79-emma , [I]195-mrs. elton am sure [he]2966-he must.—Not even [Knightley]88-mr. knightley could be so very eccentric;—and [[his]2966-he servants]5563-his servants forgot it . Depend upon it , that was the case : and very likely to happen with [the Donwell servants]5564-the donwell servants , who are all , [I]195-mrs. elton have often observed , extremely awkward and remiss.—I am sure [I]195-mrs. elton would not have such a creature as [[his]2966-he Harry]5565-his harry stand at [our]5566-our sideboard for any consideration . And as for [Mrs. Hodges]224-mrs. hodges , [Wright]258-wright holds [her]224-mrs. hodges very cheap indeed.—She promised [Wright]258-wright a receipt , and never sent it . ”[195-mrs. elton] “ [I]91-mr. elton met [William Larkins]223-william larkins , ”[91-mr. elton] continued [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , “ as [I]91-mr. elton got near [the house]425-the house , and [he]223-william larkins told [me]91-mr. elton [I]91-mr. elton should not find [[his]223-william larkins master]4331-his master at [home]3258-home , but [I]91-mr. elton did not believe him.—William seemed rather out of humour . [He]223-william larkins did not know what was come to [[his]223-william larkins master]4331-his master lately , [he]223-william larkins said , but [he]223-william larkins could hardly ever get the speech of [him]223-william larkins . [I]91-mr. elton have nothing to do with [William]223-william larkins ’s wants , but it really is of very great importance that [I]91-mr. elton should see [Knightley]88-mr. knightley to - day ; and it becomes a matter , therefore , of very serious inconvenience that [I]91-mr. elton should have had this hot walk to no purpose . ”[91-mr. elton] [Emma]79-emma felt that [she]79-emma could not do better than go [home]3258-home directly . In all probability [she]79-emma was at this very time waited for [there]437-there ; and [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley might be preserved from sinking deeper in aggression towards [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , if not towards [William Larkins]223-william larkins . [She]79-emma was pleased , on taking leave , to find [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax determined to attend [her]79-emma out of [the room]3386-the room , to go with [her]79-emma even [downstairs]1683-downstairs ; it gave [her]79-emma an opportunity which [she]79-emma immediately made use of , to say , “ It is as well , perhaps , that [I]79-emma have not had the possibility . Had [you]79-emma not been surrounded by [other friends]5571-other friends , [I]79-emma might have been tempted to introduce a subject , to ask questions , to speak more openly than might have been strictly correct.—I feel that [I]79-emma should certainly have been impertinent . ”[79-emma] “ Oh ! ”[142-miss fairfax] cried [Jane]142-miss fairfax , with a blush and an hesitation which [Emma]79-emma thought infinitely more becoming to [her]142-miss fairfax than all the elegance of all [her]142-miss fairfax usual composure—“there would have been no danger . The danger would have been of [my]79-emma wearying [you]79-emma . [You]79-emma could not have gratified [me]79-emma more than by expressing an interest—. Indeed , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , ( speaking more collectedly , ) with the consciousness which [I]79-emma have of misconduct , very great misconduct , it is particularly consoling to [me]79-emma to know that [those of [[my]79-emma friends]629-my friends , whose good opinion is most worth preserving]5572-those of my friends , whose good opinion is most worth preserving , are not disgusted to such a degree as to — [I]79-emma have not time for half that [I]79-emma could wish to say . [I]79-emma long to make apologies , excuses , to urge something for [myself]79-emma . [I]79-emma feel it so very due . But , unfortunately — in short , if [your]79-emma compassion does not stand [[my]79-emma friend]877-my friend — ”[79-emma] “ Oh ! [you]79-emma are too scrupulous , indeed [you]79-emma are , ”[79-emma] cried [Emma]79-emma warmly , and taking [her]2972-her hand . “ [You]79-emma owe [me]79-emma no apologies ; and [every body to whom [you]79-emma might be supposed to owe [them]5575-every body to whom you might be supposed to owe them]5575-every body to whom you might be supposed to owe them , is so perfectly satisfied , so delighted even — ”[79-emma] “ [You]79-emma are very kind , but [I]79-emma know what [my]79-emma manners were to you.—So cold and artificial!—I had always a part to act.—It was a life of deceit!—I know that [I]79-emma must have disgusted [you]79-emma . ”[79-emma] “ Pray say no more . [I]79-emma feel that all the apologies should be on [my]79-emma side . Let [us]5576-we forgive [each other]420-each other at once . [We]5576-we must do whatever is to be done quickest , and [I]79-emma think [our]5576-we feelings will lose no time there . [I]79-emma hope [you]79-emma have pleasant accounts from [Windsor]72-windsor ? ”[79-emma] “ Very . ”[79-emma] “ And the next news , [I]79-emma suppose , will be , that [we]5576-we are to lose [you]79-emma — just as [I]79-emma begin to know [you]79-emma . ”[79-emma] “ Oh ! as to all that , of course nothing can be thought of yet . [I]79-emma am here till claimed by [Colonel]153-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]154-mrs. campbell . ”[79-emma] “ Nothing can be actually settled yet , perhaps , ”[79-emma] replied [Emma]79-emma , smiling—“but , excuse [me]79-emma , it must be thought of . ”[79-emma] The smile was returned as [Jane]142-miss fairfax answered , “ [You]79-emma are very right ; it has been thought of . And [I]142-miss fairfax will own to [you]79-emma , ( [I]142-miss fairfax am sure it will be safe ) , that so far as [our]5576-we living with [Mr. Churchill]98-frank churchill at [Enscombe]7-enscombe , it is settled . There must be three months , at least , of deep mourning ; but when they are over , [I]142-miss fairfax imagine there will be nothing more to wait for . ”[142-miss fairfax] “ Thank [you]79-emma , thank you.—This is just what [I]79-emma wanted to be assured of.—Oh ! if [you]79-emma knew how much [I]79-emma love every thing that is decided and open!—Good - bye , good - bye . ”[79-emma] CHAPTER XVII [[Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s friends]2973-mrs. weston ’s friends were all made happy by [her]84-mrs. weston safety ; and if the satisfaction of [her]84-mrs. weston well - doing could be increased to [Emma]79-emma , it was by knowing [her]84-mrs. weston to be [the mother of [a little girl]2975-a little girl]2974-the mother of a little girl . [She]79-emma had been decided in wishing for a [Miss Weston]370-miss weston . [She]79-emma would not acknowledge that it was with any view of making a match for [her]84-mrs. weston , hereafter , with [either of [[Isabella]83-isabella ’s sons]2977-isabella ’s sons]2976-either of isabella ’s sons ; but [she]79-emma was convinced that [a daughter]5244-a daughter would suit both [father]1574-father and [mother]1537-mother best . It would be a great comfort to [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston , as [he]82-mr. weston grew older — and even [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston might be growing older ten years hence — to have [his]82-mr. weston fireside enlivened by the sports and the nonsense , the freaks and the fancies of [a child]603-a child never banished from [home]3258-home ; and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston — [no one]813-no one could doubt that [a daughter]5244-a daughter would be most to [her]84-mrs. weston ; and it would be quite a pity that [any one who so well knew how to teach]2985-any one who so well knew how to teach , should not have [their]2985-any one who so well knew how to teach powers in exercise again . “ [She]84-mrs. weston has had the advantage , [you]5578-you know , of practising on [me]79-emma , ”[79-emma] [she]79-emma continued—“like [La Baronne]371-la baronne d’Almane on [La Comtesse d’Ostalis]5579-la comtesse d’ostalis , in [Madame de Genlis]372-madame de genlis ’ Adelaide and [Theodore]373-theodore , and [we]5580-we shall now see [her]84-mrs. weston own little [Adelaide]374-adelaide educated on a more perfect plan . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ That is , ”[88-mr. knightley] replied [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , “ [she]84-mrs. weston will indulge [her]84-mrs. weston even more than [she]84-mrs. weston did [you]79-emma , and believe that [she]84-mrs. weston does not indulge [her]84-mrs. weston at all . It will be the only difference . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [Poor child]5581-poor child ! ”[79-emma] cried [Emma]79-emma ; “ at that rate , what will become of [her]84-mrs. weston ? ”[79-emma] “ Nothing very bad.—The fate of [thousands]5582-thousands . [She]84-mrs. weston will be disagreeable in infancy , and correct [herself]84-mrs. weston as [she]84-mrs. weston grows older . [I]79-emma am losing all [my]79-emma bitterness against [spoilt children]5583-spoilt children , [[my]79-emma dearest]696-my dearest [Emma]79-emma . [I]79-emma , who am owing all [my]79-emma happiness to [you]79-emma , would not it be horrible ingratitude in [me]79-emma to be severe on [them]5583-spoilt children ? ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma laughed , and replied : “ But [I]79-emma had the assistance of all [your]79-emma endeavours to counteract the indulgence of [other people]445-other people . [I]79-emma doubt whether [my]79-emma own sense would have corrected [me]79-emma without it . ”[79-emma] “ Do you?—I have no doubt . [Nature]375-nature gave [you]79-emma understanding:—Miss [Taylor]80-miss taylor gave [you]79-emma principles . [You]79-emma must have done well . [My]79-emma interference was quite as likely to do harm as good . It was very natural for [you]79-emma to say , what right has [he]5586-he to lecture me?—and [I]79-emma am afraid very natural for [you]79-emma to feel that it was done in a disagreeable manner . [I]79-emma do not believe [I]79-emma did [you]79-emma any good . The good was all to [myself]79-emma , by making [you]79-emma an object of the tenderest affection to [me]79-emma . [I]79-emma could not think about [you]79-emma so much without doating on [you]79-emma , faults and all ; and by dint of fancying so many errors , have been in love with [you]79-emma ever since [you]79-emma were thirteen at least . ”[79-emma] “ [I]79-emma am sure [you]79-emma were of use to [me]79-emma , ”[79-emma] cried [Emma]79-emma . “ [I]79-emma was very often influenced rightly by [you]79-emma — oftener than [I]79-emma would own at the time . [I]79-emma am very sure [you]79-emma did [me]79-emma good . And if [poor little Anna Weston]376-poor little anna weston is to be spoiled , it will be the greatest humanity in [you]79-emma to do as much for [her]376-poor little anna weston as [you]79-emma have done for [me]79-emma , except falling in love with [her]376-poor little anna weston when [she]376-poor little anna weston is thirteen . ”[79-emma] “ How often , when [you]79-emma were [a girl]600-a girl , have [you]79-emma said to [me]79-emma , with one of [your]79-emma saucy looks—‘Mr . [Knightley]88-mr. knightley , [I]79-emma am going to do so - and - so ; [papa]3114-papa says [I]79-emma may , or [I]79-emma have [Miss Taylor]80-miss taylor ’s leave’—something which , [you]79-emma knew , [I]79-emma did not approve . In such cases [my]79-emma interference was giving [you]79-emma two bad feelings instead of one . ”[79-emma] “ What [an amiable creature]5589-an amiable creature [I]79-emma was!—No wonder [you]79-emma should hold [my]79-emma speeches in such affectionate remembrance . ”[79-emma] “ ‘ [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . ’—You always called [me]79-emma , ‘ [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ; ’ and , from habit , it has not so very formal a sound.—And yet it is formal . [I]79-emma want [you]79-emma to call [me]79-emma something else , but [I]79-emma do not know what . ”[79-emma] “ [I]79-emma remember once calling [you]79-emma ‘ [George]119-george , ’ in one of [my]79-emma amiable fits , about ten years ago . [I]79-emma did it because [I]79-emma thought it would offend [you]79-emma ; but , as [you]79-emma made no objection , [I]79-emma never did it again . ”[79-emma] “ And can not [you]79-emma call [me]79-emma ‘ [George]119-george ’ now ? ”[79-emma] “ [Impossible!—I]377-impossible!—i never can call [you]79-emma any thing but ‘ [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . ’ [I]2986-i will not promise even to equal the elegant terseness of [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , by calling [you]79-emma [Mr. K.—But]378-mr. k.—but [I]2986-i will promise , ”[2986-i] [she]2986-i added presently , laughing and blushing—“I will promise to call [you]79-emma once by [your]79-emma Christian name . [I]2986-i do not say when , but perhaps [you]79-emma may guess where;—in [the building in which N. takes M. for better , for worse]5590-the building in which n. takes m. for better , for worse . ”[2986-i] [Emma]79-emma grieved that [she]79-emma could not be more openly just to one important service which [his]2987-his better sense would have rendered [her]79-emma , to the advice which would have saved [her]79-emma from the worst of all [her]79-emma womanly follies — [her]79-emma wilful intimacy with [Harriet Smith]107-harriet ; but it was too tender a subject.—She could not enter on it.—Harriet was very seldom mentioned between [them]2988-them . This , on [his]2987-his side , might merely proceed from [her]79-emma not being thought of ; but [Emma]79-emma was rather inclined to attribute it to delicacy , and a suspicion , from some appearances , that [their]2988-them friendship were declining . [She]79-emma was aware [herself]79-emma , that , parting under any other circumstances , [they]2988-them certainly should have corresponded more , and that [her]79-emma intelligence would not have rested , as it now almost wholly did , on [Isabella]83-isabella ’s letters . [He]2987-his might observe that it was so . The pain of being obliged to practise concealment towards [him]2987-his , was very little inferior to the pain of having made [Harriet]107-harriet unhappy . [Isabella]83-isabella sent quite as good an account of [[her]83-isabella visitor]2064-her visitor as could be expected ; on [her]83-isabella first arrival [she]83-isabella had thought [her]83-isabella out of spirits , which appeared perfectly natural , as there was [a dentist to be consulted]2990-a dentist to be consulted ; but , since that business had been over , [she]83-isabella did not appear to find [Harriet]107-harriet different from what [she]83-isabella had known [[her]83-isabella before.—Isabella]2991-her before.—isabella , to be sure , was [no very quick observer]2992-no very quick observer ; yet if [Harriet]107-harriet had not been equal to playing with [the children]3286-the children , it would not have escaped [her]107-harriet . [Emma]79-emma ’s comforts and hopes were most agreeably carried on , by [Harriet]107-harriet ’s being to stay longer ; [her]107-harriet fortnight was likely to be a month at least . [Mr.]2994-mr. and [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley were to come down in August , and [she]79-emma was invited to remain till [they]2995-they could bring [her]79-emma back . “ [John]117-mrs. john knightley does not even mention [[your]79-emma friend]630-your friend , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . “ Here is [his]88-mr. knightley answer , if [you]79-emma like to see it . ”[88-mr. knightley] It was the answer to the communication of [his]88-mr. knightley intended marriage . [Emma]79-emma accepted it with a very eager hand , with an impatience all alive to know what [he]88-mr. knightley would say about it , and not at all checked by hearing that [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend was unmentioned . “ [John]88-mr. knightley enters like [a brother]5592-a brother into [my]88-mr. knightley happiness , ”[88-mr. knightley] continued [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , “ but [he]88-mr. knightley is no complimenter ; and though [I]88-mr. knightley well know [him]88-mr. knightley to have , likewise , a most brotherly affection for [you]79-emma , [he]88-mr. knightley is so far from making flourishes , that [any other young woman]5593-any other young woman might think [him]88-mr. knightley rather cool in [her]5593-any other young woman praise . But [I]88-mr. knightley am not afraid of [your]79-emma seeing what [he]88-mr. knightley writes . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [He]88-mr. knightley writes like [a sensible man]684-a sensible man , ”[79-emma] replied [Emma]79-emma , when [she]79-emma had read the letter . “ [I]79-emma honour [his]88-mr. knightley sincerity . Had [he]88-mr. knightley said any thing to bear a different construction , [I]79-emma should not have believed [him]88-mr. knightley . ”[79-emma] “ [[My]88-mr. knightley Emma]1327-my emma , [he]88-mr. knightley means no such thing . [He]88-mr. knightley only means — ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [He]88-mr. knightley and [I]2997-i should differ very little in [our]5596-our estimation of [the two]1913-the two , ”[2997-i] interrupted [she]2997-i , with a sort of serious smile—“much less , perhaps , than [he]88-mr. knightley is aware of , if [we]5596-our could enter without ceremony or reserve on the subject . ”[2997-i] “ [Emma]79-emma , [[my]88-mr. knightley dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma — ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Oh ! ”[2997-i] [she]2997-i cried with more thorough gaiety , “ if [you]79-emma fancy [[your]79-emma brother]1106-your brother does not do [me]2997-i justice , only wait till [[my]2997-i dear father]4519-my dear father is in the secret , and hear [his]88-mr. knightley opinion . Depend upon it , [he]88-mr. knightley will be much farther from doing [you]79-emma justice . [He]88-mr. knightley will think all the happiness , all the advantage , on [your]79-emma side of the question ; all the merit on [mine]2997-i . [I]2997-i wish [I]2997-i may not sink into ‘ poor [Emma]79-emma ’ with [him]1106-your brother at once.—His tender compassion towards oppressed worth can go no farther . ”[2997-i] “ Ah ! ”[2997-i] [he]2997-i cried , “ [I]2997-i wish [[your]79-emma father]1389-your father might be half as easily convinced as [John]88-mr. knightley will be , of [our]5602-our having every right that equal worth can give , to be happy together . [I]2997-i am amused by one part of [John]88-mr. knightley ’s letter — did [you]79-emma notice it?—where [he]88-mr. knightley says , that [my]2997-i information did not take [him]88-mr. knightley wholly by surprize , that [he]88-mr. knightley was rather in expectation of hearing something of the kind . ”[2997-i] “ If [I]2997-i understand [[your]79-emma brother]1106-your brother , [he]1106-your brother only means so far as [your]79-emma having some thoughts of marrying . [He]1106-your brother had no idea of [me]2997-i . [He]1106-your brother seems perfectly unprepared for that . ”[2997-i] “ Yes , yes — but [I]2997-i am amused that [he]1106-your brother should have seen so far into [my]2997-i feelings . What has [he]1106-your brother been judging by?—I am not conscious of any difference in [my]2997-i spirits or conversation that could prepare [him]1106-your brother at this time for [my]2997-i marrying any more than at another.—But it was so , [I]2997-i suppose . [I]2997-i dare say there was a difference when [I]2997-i was staying with [them]5604-them the other day . [I]2997-i believe [I]2997-i did not play with [the children]3286-the children quite so much as usual . [I]2997-i remember one evening [the poor boys]5606-the poor boys saying , ‘ [Uncle]5607-uncle seems always tired now . ’ ”[2997-i] The time was coming when the news must spread farther , and [other persons]2998-other persons ’ reception of it tried . As soon as [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was sufficiently recovered to admit [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s visits , [Emma]79-emma having it in view that [her]79-emma gentle reasonings should be employed in the cause , resolved first to announce it at [home]3258-home , and then at [Randalls.—But]379-randalls.—but how to break it to [[her]79-emma father]415-her father at last!—She had bound [herself]79-emma to do it , in such an hour of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s absence , or when it came to the point [her]79-emma heart would have failed [her]79-emma , and [she]79-emma must have put it off ; but [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley was to come at such a time , and follow up the beginning [she]79-emma was to make.—She was forced to speak , and to speak cheerfully too . [She]79-emma must not make it a more decided subject of misery to [him]88-mr. knightley , by a melancholy tone [herself]79-emma . [She]79-emma must not appear to think it a misfortune.—With all the spirits [she]79-emma could command , [she]79-emma prepared [him]88-mr. knightley first for something strange , and then , in a few words , said , that if [his]88-mr. knightley consent and approbation could be obtained — which , [she]79-emma trusted , would be attended with no difficulty , since it was a plan to promote the happiness of all — [she]79-emma and [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley meant to marry ; by which means [Hartfield]90-hartfield would receive the constant addition of [[that person]3001-that person ’s company whom [she]79-emma knew [he]88-mr. knightley loved]3002-that person ’s company whom she knew he loved , next to [[his]88-mr. knightley daughters]3623-his daughters and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , best in [the world]392-the world . [Poor man!—it]380-poor man!—it was at first a considerable shock to [him]88-mr. knightley , and [he]88-mr. knightley tried earnestly to dissuade [her]79-emma from it . [She]79-emma was reminded , more than once , of having always said [she]79-emma would never marry , and assured that it would be a great deal better for [her]79-emma to remain single ; and told of [poor Isabella]83-isabella , and [poor Miss Taylor.—But]3005-poor miss taylor.—but it would not do . [Emma]79-emma hung about [him]88-mr. knightley affectionately , and smiled , and said it must be so ; and that [he]88-mr. knightley must not class [her]79-emma with [Isabella]83-isabella and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , whose marriages taking [them]3006-they from [Hartfield]90-hartfield , had , indeed , made a melancholy change : but [she]79-emma was not going from [Hartfield]90-hartfield ; [she]79-emma should be always [there]437-there ; [she]79-emma was introducing no change in [their]3006-they numbers or [their]3006-they comforts but for the better ; and [she]79-emma was very sure that [he]88-mr. knightley would be a great deal the happier for having [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley always at hand , when [he]88-mr. knightley were once got used to the idea.—Did [he]88-mr. knightley not love [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley very much?—He would not deny that [he]88-mr. knightley did , [she]79-emma was sure.—Whom did [he]88-mr. knightley ever want to consult on business but [Mr. Knightley?—Who]381-mr. knightley?—who was so useful to [him]88-mr. knightley , who so ready to write [his]88-mr. knightley letters , who so glad to assist [him?—Who]88-mr. knightley so cheerful , so attentive , so attached to him?—Would not [he]88-mr. knightley like to have [him]88-mr. knightley always on the spot?—Yes . That was all very true . [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley could not be there too often ; [he]88-mr. knightley should be glad to see [him]88-mr. knightley every day;—but [they]3006-they did see [him]88-mr. knightley every day as it was.—Why could not [they]3006-they go on as [they]3006-they had done ? [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse could not be soon reconciled ; but the worst was overcome , the idea was given ; time and continual repetition must do the rest.—To [Emma]79-emma ’s entreaties and assurances succeeded [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s , whose fond praise of [her]79-emma gave the subject even a kind of welcome ; and [he]88-mr. knightley was soon used to be talked to by each , on every fair occasion.—They had all the assistance which [Isabella]83-isabella could give , by letters of the strongest approbation ; and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was ready , on the first meeting , to consider the subject in the most serviceable light — first , as a settled , and , secondly , as a good one — well aware of the nearly equal importance of the two recommendations to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s mind.—It was agreed upon , as what was to be ; and every body by whom [he]88-mr. knightley was used to be guided assuring [him]88-mr. knightley that it would be for [his]88-mr. knightley happiness ; and having some feelings [himself]88-mr. knightley which almost admitted it , [he]88-mr. knightley began to think that some time or other — in another year or two , perhaps — it might not be so very bad if the marriage did take place . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston was acting no part , feigning no feelings in all that [she]84-mrs. weston said to [him]88-mr. knightley in favour of the event.—She had been extremely surprized , never more so , than when [Emma]79-emma first opened the affair to [her]84-mrs. weston ; but [she]84-mrs. weston saw in it only increase of happiness to all , and had no scruple in urging [him]88-mr. knightley to the utmost.—She had such a regard for [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , as to think [he]88-mr. knightley deserved even [her]84-mrs. weston dearest [Emma]79-emma ; and it was in every respect so proper , suitable , and unexceptionable a connexion , and in one respect , one point of the highest importance , so peculiarly eligible , so singularly fortunate , that now it seemed as if [Emma]79-emma could not safely have attached [herself]79-emma to [any other creature]3008-any other creature , and that [she]79-emma had [herself]79-emma been the stupidest of [beings in not having thought of it]3009-beings in not having thought of it , and wished it long ago.—How [very few of [those men in a rank of life]3011-those men in a rank of life]3010-very few of those men in a rank of life to address [Emma]79-emma would have renounced [[their]3010-very few of those men in a rank of life own home for [Hartfield]90-hartfield]3012-their own home for hartfield ! And who but [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley could know and bear with [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , so as to make such an arrangement desirable!—The difficulty of disposing of [poor Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse had been always felt in [[her]84-mrs. weston husband]431-her husband ’s plans and [her]84-mrs. weston own , for a marriage between [Frank]98-frank churchill and [Emma]79-emma . How to settle the claims of [Enscombe]7-enscombe and [Hartfield]90-hartfield had been a continual impediment — less acknowledged by [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston than by [herself]84-mrs. weston — but even [he]431-her husband had never been able to finish the subject better than by saying—“Those matters will take care of [themselves]5608-themselves ; [the young people]2027-the young people will find a way . ”[431-her husband] But here there was nothing to be shifted off in a wild speculation on the future . It was all right , all open , all equal . No sacrifice on any side worth the name . It was a union of the highest promise of felicity in itself , and without one real , rational difficulty to oppose or delay it . [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston , with [[her]84-mrs. weston baby]3014-her baby on [her]84-mrs. weston knee , indulging in such reflections as these , was one of [the happiest women in [the world]392-the world]3015-the happiest women in the world . If any thing could increase [her]84-mrs. weston delight , it was perceiving that [the baby]3588-the baby would soon have outgrown its first set of caps . The news was universally a surprize wherever it spread ; and [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston had [his]82-mr. weston five minutes share of it ; but five minutes were enough to familiarise the idea to [his]82-mr. weston quickness of mind.—He saw the advantages of the match , and rejoiced in them with all the constancy of [[his]82-mr. weston wife]3168-his wife ; but the wonder of it was very soon nothing ; and by the end of an hour [he]82-mr. weston was not far from believing that [he]82-mr. weston had always foreseen it . “ It is to be a secret , [I]82-mr. weston conclude , ”[82-mr. weston] said [he]82-mr. weston . “ These matters are always a secret , till it is found out that [every body]3270-every body knows them . Only let [me]82-mr. weston be told when [I]82-mr. weston may speak out.—I wonder whether [Jane]142-miss fairfax has any suspicion . ”[82-mr. weston] [He]82-mr. weston went to [Highbury]3-highbury the next morning , and satisfied [himself]82-mr. weston on that point . [He]82-mr. weston told [her]3168-his wife the news . Was not [she]3168-his wife like [a daughter]5244-a daughter , [[his]82-mr. weston eldest]3020-his eldest daughter?—he must tell [her]3168-his wife ; and [Miss Bates]101-miss bates being present , it passed , of course , to [Mrs. Cole]176-mrs. cole , [Mrs. Perry]100-mrs. perry , and [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , immediately afterwards . It was no more than [the principals]3021-the principals were prepared for ; [they]3021-the principals had calculated from the time of its being known at [Randalls]97-randalls , how soon it would be over [Highbury]3-highbury ; and were thinking of [themselves]3021-the principals , as the evening wonder in [many a family circle]3022-many a family circle , with great sagacity . In general , it was a very well approved match . [Some]2343-some might think [him]82-mr. weston , and [others]473-others might think [her]3168-his wife , the most in luck . [One set]3025-one set might recommend [their]3021-the principals all removing to [Donwell]202-donwell , and leaving [Hartfield]90-hartfield for [the John Knightleys]382-the john knightleys ; and another might predict disagreements among [[their]3021-the principals servants]5128-their servants ; but yet , upon the whole , there was no serious objection raised , except in one habitation , [the Vicarage.—There]77-the vicarage.—there , the surprize was not softened by any satisfaction . [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton cared little about it , compared with [[his]91-mr. elton wife]3168-his wife ; [he]91-mr. elton only hoped “ [the young lady]882-the young lady ’s pride would now be contented ; ”[91-mr. elton] and supposed “ [she]882-the young lady had always meant to catch [Knightley]88-mr. knightley if [she]882-the young lady could ; ”[91-mr. elton] and , on the point of living at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , could daringly exclaim , “ Rather [he]88-mr. knightley than [I!”—But[91-mr. elton] Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton was very much discomposed indeed.—“Poor [Knightley]88-mr. knightley ! poor fellow!—sad business for [him]91-mr. elton . ”—She[91-mr. elton] was extremely concerned ; for , though very eccentric , [he]91-mr. elton had a thousand good qualities.—How could [he]91-mr. elton be so taken in?—Did not think [him]91-mr. elton at all in love — not in the least.—Poor [Knightley!—There]383-knightley!—there would be an end of all pleasant intercourse with him.—How happy [he]91-mr. elton had been to come and dine with [them]3028-them whenever [they]3028-them asked [him]91-mr. elton ! But that would be all over now.—Poor fellow!—No more exploring parties to [Donwell]202-donwell made for [her]3168-his wife . Oh ! no ; there would be a [Mrs. Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley to throw cold water on every thing.—Extremely disagreeable ! But [she]3168-his wife was not at all sorry that [she]3168-his wife had abused [the housekeeper]3524-the housekeeper the other day.—Shocking plan , living together . It would never do . [She]3168-his wife knew [a family near [Maple Grove]53-maple grove]3030-a family near maple grove who had [tried it , and been obliged to separate before the end of the first quarter]3031-tried it , and been obliged to separate before the end of the first quarter . CHAPTER XVIII Time passed on . A few more to - morrows , and [the party from [London]1-london]3032-the party from london would be arriving . It was an alarming change ; and [Emma]79-emma was thinking of it one morning , as what must bring a great deal to agitate and grieve [her]79-emma , when [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley came in , and distressing thoughts were put by . After the first chat of pleasure [he]88-mr. knightley was silent ; and then , in a graver tone , began with , “ [I]88-mr. knightley have something to tell [you]79-emma , [Emma]79-emma ; some news . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Good or bad ? ”[79-emma] said [she]79-emma , quickly , looking up in [his]88-mr. knightley face . “ [I]79-emma do not know which it ought to be called . ”[79-emma] “ Oh ! good [I]88-mr. knightley am sure.—I see it in [your]88-mr. knightley countenance . [You]88-mr. knightley are trying not to smile . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ [I]88-mr. knightley am afraid , ”[88-mr. knightley] said [he]88-mr. knightley , composing [his]88-mr. knightley features , “ [I]88-mr. knightley am very much afraid , [[my]88-mr. knightley dear]3120-my dear [Emma]79-emma , that [you]79-emma will not smile when [you]79-emma hear it . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ Indeed ! but why so?—I can hardly imagine that any thing which pleases or amuses [you]79-emma , should not please and amuse [me]88-mr. knightley too . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ There is one subject , ”[88-mr. knightley] [he]88-mr. knightley replied , “ [I]88-mr. knightley hope but one , on which [we]5613-we do not think alike . ”[88-mr. knightley] [He]88-mr. knightley paused a moment , again smiling , with [his]88-mr. knightley eyes fixed on [her]3033-her face . “ Does nothing occur to you?—Do not [you]79-emma [recollect?—Harriet Smith]107-harriet . ”[88-mr. knightley] [Her]3033-her cheeks flushed at the name , and [she]3033-her felt afraid of something , though [she]3033-her knew not what . “ Have [you]79-emma heard from [her]3033-her [yourself]79-emma this morning ? ”[88-mr. knightley] cried [he]88-mr. knightley . “ [You]79-emma have , [I]88-mr. knightley believe , and know the whole . ”[88-mr. knightley] “ No , [I]79-emma have not ; [I]79-emma know nothing ; pray tell [me]79-emma . ”[79-emma] “ [You]79-emma are prepared for the worst , [I]79-emma see — and very bad it is . [Harriet Smith]107-harriet marries [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin . ”[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma gave a start , which did not seem like being prepared — and [her]79-emma eyes , in eager gaze , said , “ No , this is impossible ! ”[79-emma] but [her]79-emma lips were closed . “ It is so , indeed , ”[88-mr. knightley] continued [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ; “ [I]88-mr. knightley have it from [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin [himself]112-mr. martin . [He]112-mr. martin left [me]88-mr. knightley not half an hour ago . ”[88-mr. knightley] [She]79-emma was still looking at [him]88-mr. knightley with the most speaking amazement . “ [You]88-mr. knightley like it , [[my]79-emma Emma]1327-my emma , as little as [I]79-emma feared.—I wish [our]5615-our opinions were the same . But in time they will . Time , [you]88-mr. knightley may be sure , will make one or the other of [us]5615-our think differently ; and , in the meanwhile , [we]5615-our need not talk much on the subject . ”[79-emma] “ [You]88-mr. knightley mistake [me]79-emma , [you]88-mr. knightley quite mistake [me]79-emma , ”[79-emma] [she]79-emma replied , exerting [herself]79-emma . “ It is not that such a circumstance would now make [me]79-emma unhappy , but [I]79-emma can not believe it . It seems [an impossibility!—You]5616-an impossibility!—you can not mean to say , that [Harriet Smith]107-harriet has accepted [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin . [You]88-mr. knightley can not mean that [he]112-mr. martin has even proposed to [her]107-harriet again — yet . How , where , when?—Let [me]0-i know it all . [I]0-i never was more surprized — but it does not make [me]0-i unhappy , [I]0-i assure you.—How — how has it been possible ? ” “[0-i] It is a very simple story . [He]3034-he went to [town]3165-town on business three days ago , and [I]0-i got [him]3034-he to take charge of some papers which [I]0-i was wanting to send to [John.—He]384-john.—he delivered these papers to [John]88-mr. knightley , at [[his]88-mr. knightley chambers]3036-his chambers , and was asked by [him]88-mr. knightley to join [their]3037-their party the same evening to [[Astley]78-astley ’s ’s]3038-astley ’s . [They]3037-their were going to take [the two eldest boys]3039-the two eldest boys to [Astley ’s]78-astley ’s .
