[[My]0-i friend]877-my friend [Robert]112-mr. martin could not resist . [They]3037-their called for [him]112-mr. martin in [their]3037-their way ; were all extremely amused ; and [[my]0-i brother]648-my brother asked [him]112-mr. martin to dine with [them]3037-their the next day — which [he]112-mr. martin did — and in the course of that visit ( as [I]0-i understand ) [he]112-mr. martin found an opportunity of speaking to [Harriet]107-harriet ; and certainly did not speak in vain.—She made [him]112-mr. martin , by [her]107-harriet acceptance , as happy even as [he]112-mr. martin is deserving . [He]112-mr. martin came down by [yesterday ’s coach]3044-yesterday ’s coach , and was with [me]0-i this morning immediately after breakfast , to report [his]112-mr. martin proceedings , first on [my]0-i affairs , and then on [his]112-mr. martin own . This is all that [I]0-i can relate of the how , where , and when . [[Your]3045-you friend]630-your friend [Harriet]107-harriet will make a much longer history when [you]3045-you see her.—She will give [you]3045-you all the minute particulars , which [only woman]3047-only woman ’s language can make interesting.—In [our]3048-our communications [we]3048-our deal only in the great.—However , [I]0-i must say , that [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin ’s heart seemed for [him]112-mr. martin , and to [me]0-i , very overflowing ; and that [he]112-mr. martin did mention , without its being much to the purpose , that on quitting [[their]3049-their box at [Astley ’s]78-astley ’s]3050-their box at astley ’s , [[my]0-i brother]648-my brother took charge of [Mrs. John Knightley]117-mrs. john knightley and [little John]117-mrs. john knightley , and [he]648-my brother followed with [Miss Smith]107-harriet and [Henry]118-henry ; and that at one time [they]3049-their were in such a crowd , as to make [Miss Smith]107-harriet rather uneasy . ” [He]0-i stopped.—Emma dared not attempt any immediate reply . To speak , [she]79-emma was sure would be to betray a most unreasonable degree of happiness . [She]79-emma must wait a moment , or [he]0-i would think [her]79-emma mad . [Her]79-emma silence disturbed [him]0-i ; and after observing [her]79-emma a little while , [he]0-i added , “[79-emma] [Emma]79-emma , [[my]0-i love]1093-my love , [you]79-emma said that this circumstance would not now make [you]79-emma unhappy ; but [I]0-i am afraid it gives [you]79-emma more pain than [you]79-emma expected . [His]0-i situation is an evil — but [you]79-emma must consider it as what satisfies [[your]79-emma friend]630-your friend ; and [I]0-i will answer for [your]79-emma thinking better and better of [him]0-i as [you]79-emma know [him]0-i more . [His]0-i good sense and good principles would delight you.—As far as [the man]758-the man is concerned , [you]79-emma could not wish [[your]79-emma friend]630-your friend in better hands . [His]0-i rank in [society]4580-society [I]0-i would alter if [I]0-i could , which is saying a great deal [I]0-i assure [you]79-emma , [Emma.—You]386-emma.—you laugh at [me]0-i about [William Larkins]223-william larkins ; but [I]0-i could quite as ill spare [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin . ” [He]0-i wanted [her]107-harriet to look up and smile ; and having now brought [herself]107-harriet not to smile too broadly — [she]107-harriet did — cheerfully answering , “[79-emma] [You]79-emma need not be at any pains to reconcile [me]0-i to the match . [I]0-i think [Harriet]107-harriet is doing extremely well . [Her]107-harriet connexions may be worse than [his]0-i . In respectability of character , there can be no doubt that they are . [I]0-i have been silent from surprize merely , excessive surprize . [You]79-emma can not imagine how suddenly it has come on [me]0-i ! how peculiarly unprepared [I]0-i was!—for [I]0-i had reason to believe [her]107-harriet very lately more determined against [him]0-i , much more , than [she]107-harriet was before . ” “[0-i] [You]79-emma ought to know [[your]79-emma friend]630-your friend best , ” replied [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ; “[79-emma] but [I]0-i should say [she]630-your friend was [a good - tempered , soft - hearted girl]3058-a good - tempered , soft - hearted girl , not likely to be very , very determined against [any young man who told [her]630-your friend [he]3059-any young man who told her he loved her loved [her]630-your friend]3059-any young man who told her he loved her . ” [Emma]79-emma could not help laughing as [she]79-emma answered , “[0-i] Upon [my]0-i word , [I]0-i believe [you]0-i know [her]107-harriet quite as well as [I]0-i do.—But , [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , are [you]0-i perfectly sure that [she]107-harriet has absolutely and downright accepted [him]3059-any young man who told her he loved her . [I]0-i could suppose [she]107-harriet might in time — but can [she]107-harriet already?—Did not [you]0-i misunderstand [him?—You]3060-him?—you were both talking of other things ; of business , shows of cattle , or new drills — and might not [you]0-i , in the confusion of so many subjects , mistake him?—It was not [Harriet]107-harriet ’s hand that [he]3059-any young man who told her he loved her was certain of — it was the dimensions of [some famous ox]3061-some famous ox . ” The contrast between the countenance and air of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin was , at this moment , so strong to [Emma]79-emma ’s feelings , and so strong was the recollection of all that had so recently passed on [Harriet]107-harriet ’s side , so fresh the sound of those words , spoken with such emphasis , “[3061-some famous ox] No , [I]0-i hope [I]0-i know better than to think of [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin , ” that [she]79-emma was really expecting the intelligence to prove , in some measure , premature . It could not be otherwise . “[112-mr. martin] Do [you]0-i dare say this ? ” cried [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley . “[0-i] Do [you]0-i dare to suppose [me]0-i so great [a blockhead]3062-a blockhead , as not to know what [a man]548-a man is talking of?—What do [you]0-i deserve ? ” “[0-i] Oh ! [I]0-i always deserve the best treatment , because [I]0-i never put up with any other ; and , therefore , [you]0-i must give [me]0-i a plain , direct answer . Are [you]0-i quite sure that [you]0-i understand the terms on which [Mr. Martin]112-mr. martin and [Harriet]107-harriet now are ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am quite sure , ” [he]0-i replied , speaking very distinctly , “[0-i] that [he]112-mr. martin told [me]0-i [she]107-harriet had accepted [him]112-mr. martin ; and that there was no obscurity , nothing doubtful , in the words [he]112-mr. martin used ; and [I]0-i think [I]0-i can give [you]0-i a proof that it must be so . [He]112-mr. martin asked [my]0-i opinion as to what [he]112-mr. martin was now to do . [He]112-mr. martin knew of [no one]813-no one but [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard to whom [he]112-mr. martin could apply for information of [[her]107-harriet relations]3065-her relations or [friends]3230-friends . Could [I]0-i mention any thing more fit to be done , than to go to [Mrs. Goddard]105-mrs. goddard ? [I]0-i assured [him]112-mr. martin that [I]0-i could not . Then , [he]112-mr. martin said , [he]112-mr. martin would endeavour to see [her]107-harriet in the course of this day . ” “[112-mr. martin] [I]0-i am perfectly satisfied , ” replied [Emma]79-emma , with the brightest smiles , “[0-i] and most sincerely wish [them]3067-them happy . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i are materially changed since [we]3068-we talked on this subject before . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i hope so — for at that time [I]0-i was [a fool]1027-a fool . ” “[1027-a fool] And [I]0-i am changed also ; for [I]0-i am now very willing to grant [you]0-i all [Harriet]107-harriet ’s good qualities . [I]0-i have taken some pains for [your]0-i sake , and for [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin ’s sake , ( whom [I]0-i have always had reason to believe as much in love with [her]107-harriet as ever , ) to get acquainted with [her]107-harriet . [I]0-i have often talked to [her]107-harriet a good deal . [You]0-i must have seen that [I]0-i did . Sometimes , indeed , [I]0-i have thought [you]0-i were half suspecting [me]0-i of pleading poor [Martin]112-mr. martin ’s cause , which was never the case ; but , from all [my]0-i observations , [I]0-i am convinced of [her]107-harriet being [an artless , amiable girl , with very good notions , very seriously good principles]3070-an artless , amiable girl , with very good notions , very seriously good principles , and placing [her]107-harriet happiness in the affections and utility of domestic life.—Much of this , [I]0-i have no doubt , [she]107-harriet may thank [you]0-i for . ” “[107-harriet] [Me]0-i ! ” cried [Emma]79-emma , shaking [her]79-emma head.—“Ah[107-harriet] ! poor [Harriet]107-harriet ! ” [She]79-emma checked [herself]79-emma , however , and submitted quietly to a little more praise than [she]79-emma deserved . [Their]5617-their conversation was soon afterwards closed by the entrance of [[her]79-emma father]415-her father . [She]79-emma was not sorry . [She]79-emma wanted to be alone . [Her]79-emma mind was in a state of flutter and wonder , which made it impossible for [her]79-emma to be collected . [She]79-emma was in dancing , singing , exclaiming spirits ; and till [she]79-emma had moved about , and talked to [herself]79-emma , and laughed and reflected , [she]79-emma could be fit for nothing rational . [[Her]79-emma father]415-her father ’s business was to announce [James]86-james ’s being gone out to put the horses to , preparatory to [their]5617-their now daily drive to [Randalls]97-randalls ; and [she]79-emma had , therefore , an immediate excuse for disappearing . The joy , the gratitude , the exquisite delight of [her]79-emma sensations may be imagined . The sole grievance and alloy thus removed in the prospect of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s welfare , [she]79-emma was really in danger of becoming too happy for security.—What had [she]79-emma to wish for ? Nothing , but to grow more worthy of [him]415-her father , whose intentions and judgment had been ever so superior to [her]79-emma own . Nothing , but that the lessons of [her]79-emma past folly might teach [her]79-emma humility and circumspection in future . Serious [she]79-emma was , very serious in [her]79-emma thankfulness , and in [her]79-emma resolutions ; and yet there was no preventing a laugh , sometimes in the very midst of [them]5620-they . [She]79-emma must laugh at such a close ! Such an end of the doleful disappointment of five weeks back ! Such a heart — such a [Harriet]107-harriet ! Now there would be pleasure in [her]79-emma returning — Every thing would be a pleasure . It would be a great pleasure to know [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin . High in the rank of [her]79-emma most serious and heartfelt felicities , was the reflection that all necessity of concealment from [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley would soon be over . The disguise , equivocation , mystery , so hateful to [her]79-emma to practise , might soon be over . [She]79-emma could now look forward to giving [him]415-her father that full and perfect confidence which [her]79-emma disposition was most ready to welcome as a duty . In the gayest and happiest spirits [she]79-emma set forward with [[her]79-emma father]415-her father ; not always listening , but always agreeing to what [he]415-her father said ; and , whether in speech or silence , conniving at the comfortable persuasion of [his]415-her father being obliged to go to [Randalls]97-randalls every day , or [poor Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston would be disappointed . [They]5620-they arrived.—Mrs . [Weston]84-mrs. weston was alone in [the drawing - room:—but]5622-the drawing - room:—but hardly had [they]5620-they been told of [the baby]3588-the baby , and [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse received the thanks for coming , which [he]81-mr. woodhouse asked for , when a glimpse was caught through the blind , of [two figures passing near the window]5624-two figures passing near the window . “[107-harriet] It is [Frank]98-frank churchill and [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax , ” said [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston . “[142-miss fairfax] [I]0-i was just going to tell [you]3071-you of [our]3072-our agreeable surprize in seeing [him]98-frank churchill arrive this morning . [He]98-frank churchill stays till to - morrow , and [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax has been persuaded to spend the day with [us.—They]3073-us.—they are coming in , [I]0-i hope . ” In half a minute [they]5620-they were in [the room]3386-the room . [Emma]79-emma was extremely glad to see [him]98-frank churchill — but there was a degree of confusion — a number of embarrassing recollections on each side . [They]5620-they met readily and smiling , but with a consciousness which at first allowed little to be said ; and having all sat down again , there was for some time such a blank in the circle , that [Emma]79-emma began to doubt whether the wish now indulged , which [she]79-emma had long felt , of seeing [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill once more , and of seeing [him]98-frank churchill with [Jane]142-miss fairfax , would yield its proportion of pleasure . When [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston joined the party , however , and when [the baby]3588-the baby was fetched , there was no longer a want of subject or animation — or of courage and opportunity for [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill to draw near [her]3074-you and say , “[0-i] [I]0-i have to thank [you]3074-you , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield , for a very kind forgiving message in one of [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston ’s letters . [I]0-i hope time has not made [you]3074-you less willing to pardon . [I]0-i hope [you]3074-you do not retract what [you]3074-you then said . ” “[3074-you] No , indeed , ” cried [Emma]79-emma , most happy to begin , “[3074-you] not in the least . [I]0-i am particularly glad to see and shake hands with [you]3074-you — and to give [you]3074-you joy in person . ” [He]3074-you thanked [her]79-emma with all [his]3074-you heart , and continued some time to speak with serious feeling of [his]3074-you gratitude and happiness . “[0-i] Is not [she]84-mrs. weston looking well ? ” said [he]3074-you , turning [his]3074-you eyes towards [Jane]142-miss fairfax . “[84-mrs. weston] Better than [she]84-mrs. weston ever used to do?—You see how [[my]0-i father]3146-my father and [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston doat upon [her]84-mrs. weston . ” But [his]3074-you spirits were soon rising again , and with laughing eyes , after mentioning the expected return of [the Campbells]180-the campbells , [he]3074-you named the name of [Dixon.—Emma]387-dixon.—emma blushed , and forbade its being pronounced in [her]142-miss fairfax hearing . “[84-mrs. weston] [I]0-i can never think of it , ” [she]142-miss fairfax cried , “[84-mrs. weston] without extreme shame . ” “[84-mrs. weston] The shame , ” [he]3074-you answered , “[0-i] is all [mine]0-i , or ought to be . But is it possible that [you]0-i had no suspicion?—I mean of late . Early , [I]0-i know , [you]0-i had none . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i never had the smallest , [I]0-i assure [you]0-i . ” “[0-i] That appears quite wonderful . [I]0-i was once very near — and [I]0-i wish [I]0-i had — it would have been better . But though [I]0-i was always doing wrong things , they were very bad wrong things , and such as did [me]0-i no service.—It would have been a much better transgression had [I]0-i broken the bond of secrecy and told [you]0-i every thing . ” “[0-i] It is not now worth a regret , ” said [Emma]79-emma . “[0-i] [I]0-i have some hope , ” resumed [he]0-i , “[0-i] of [[my]0-i uncle]4485-my uncle ’s being persuaded to pay a visit at [Randalls]97-randalls ; [he]4485-my uncle wants to be introduced to [her]3077-her . When [the Campbells]180-the campbells are returned , [we]3078-we shall meet [them]180-the campbells in [London]1-london , and continue [there]437-there , [I]0-i trust , till [we]3078-we may carry [her]3077-her northward.—But now , [I]0-i am at such a distance from [her]3077-her — is not it hard , [Miss Woodhouse?—Till]3080-miss woodhouse?—till this morning , [we]3078-we have not once met since the day of reconciliation . Do not [you]0-i pity [me]0-i ? ” [Emma]79-emma spoke [her]79-emma pity so very kindly , that with a sudden accession of gay thought , [he]0-i cried , “[0-i] Ah ! by the bye , ” then sinking [his]0-i voice , and looking demure for the moment—“I[0-i] hope [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley is well ? ” [He]0-i paused.—She coloured and laughed.—“I[0-i] know [you]0-i saw [my]0-i letter , and think [you]0-i may remember [my]0-i wish in [your]0-i favour . Let [me]0-i return [your]0-i congratulations.—I assure [you]0-i that [I]0-i have heard the news with the warmest interest and satisfaction.—He is [a man whom [I]0-i can not presume to praise]3081-a man whom i can not presume to praise . ” [Emma]79-emma was delighted , and only wanted [him]0-i to go on in the same style ; but [his]0-i mind was the next moment in [his]0-i own concerns and with [his]0-i own [Jane]142-miss fairfax , and [his]0-i next words were , “[3081-a man whom i can not presume to praise] Did [you]0-i ever see such a skin?—such smoothness ! such delicacy!—and yet without being actually fair.—One can not call [her]3082-her fair . It is a most uncommon complexion , with [her]3082-her dark eye - lashes and hair — a most distinguishing complexion ! So peculiarly the lady in it.—Just colour enough for beauty . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have always admired [her]3082-her complexion , ” replied [Emma]79-emma , archly ; “[0-i] but do not [I]0-i remember the time when [you]0-i found fault with [her]3082-her for being so pale?—When [we]3083-us first began to talk of her.—Have [you]0-i quite forgotten ? ” “[0-i] Oh ! no — what [an impudent dog]3084-an impudent dog [I]0-i was!—How could [I]0-i dare — ” But [he]0-i laughed so heartily at the recollection , that [Emma]79-emma could not help saying , “[0-i] [I]0-i do suspect that in the midst of [your]0-i perplexities at that time , [you]0-i had very great amusement in tricking [us]3083-us all.—I am sure [you]0-i had.—I am sure it was a consolation to [you]0-i . ” “[0-i] Oh ! no , no , no — how can [you]0-i suspect [me]0-i of such a thing ? [I]0-i was [the most miserable wretch]3085-the most miserable wretch ! ” “[3085-the most miserable wretch] Not quite so miserable as to be insensible to mirth . [I]0-i am sure it was a source of high entertainment to [you]0-i , to feel that [you]0-i were taking [us]3083-us all in.—Perhaps [I]0-i am [the readier]3086-the readier to suspect , because , to tell [you]0-i the truth , [I]0-i think it might have been some amusement to [myself]0-i in the same situation . [I]0-i think there is a little likeness between [us]3083-us . ” [He]0-i bowed . “[0-i] If not in [our]3083-us dispositions , ” [she]3088-a complete angel presently added , with a look of true sensibility , “[0-i] there is a likeness in [our]3083-us destiny ; the destiny which bids fair to connect [us]3083-us with two characters so much superior to [our]3083-us own . ” “[3087-no superior] True , true , ” [he]0-i answered , warmly . “[3087-no superior] No , not true on [your]0-i side . [You]0-i can have [no superior]3087-no superior , but most true on mine.—She is [a complete angel]3088-a complete angel . Look at [her]3088-a complete angel . Is not [she]3088-a complete angel [an angel]612-an angel in every gesture ? Observe the turn of [her]3088-a complete angel throat . Observe [her]3088-a complete angel eyes , as [she]3088-a complete angel is looking up at [[my]0-i father.—You]3090-my father.—you will be glad to hear ( inclining [his]3090-my father.—you head , and whispering seriously ) that [[my]0-i uncle]4485-my uncle means to give [her]3088-a complete angel all [[my]0-i aunt]4280-my aunt ’s jewels . They are to be new set . [I]0-i am resolved to have some in an ornament for the head . Will not it be beautiful in [her]3088-a complete angel dark hair ? ” “[3088-a complete angel] Very beautiful , indeed , ” replied [Emma]79-emma ; and [she]79-emma spoke so kindly , that [he]0-i gratefully burst out , “[3088-a complete angel] How delighted [I]0-i am to see [you]3088-a complete angel again ! and to see [you]3088-a complete angel in such excellent looks!—I would not have missed this meeting for [the world]392-the world . [I]0-i should certainly have called at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , had [you]3088-a complete angel failed to come . ” [The others]3512-the others had been talking of [the child]3193-the child , [Mrs. Weston]84-mrs. weston giving an account of a little alarm [she]84-mrs. weston had been under , the evening before , from [the infant]5629-the infant ’s appearing not quite well . [She]84-mrs. weston believed [she]84-mrs. weston had been foolish , but it had alarmed [her]84-mrs. weston , and [she]84-mrs. weston had been within half a minute of sending for [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry . Perhaps [she]84-mrs. weston ought to be ashamed , but [Mr. Weston]82-mr. weston had been almost as uneasy as herself.—In ten minutes , however , [the child]3193-the child had been perfectly well again . This was [her]84-mrs. weston history ; and particularly interesting it was to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse , who commended [her]84-mrs. weston very much for thinking of sending for [Perry]102-mr. perry , and only regretted that [she]84-mrs. weston had not done it . “[0-i] [She]3094-she should always send for [Perry]102-mr. perry , if [the child]3193-the child appeared in the slightest degree disordered , were it only for a moment . [She]3094-she could not be too soon alarmed , nor send for [Perry]102-mr. perry too often . It was a pity , perhaps , that [he]102-mr. perry had not come last night ; for , though [the child]3193-the child seemed well now , very well considering , it would probably have been better if [Perry]102-mr. perry had seen [it]3097-it . ” [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill caught the name . “[102-mr. perry] [Perry]102-mr. perry ! ” said [he]98-frank churchill to [Emma]79-emma , and trying , as [he]98-frank churchill spoke , to catch [Miss Fairfax]142-miss fairfax ’s eye . “[102-mr. perry] [[My]0-i friend]877-my friend [Mr. Perry]102-mr. perry ! What are [they]3099-they saying about [Mr.]3100-mr. Perry?—Has [he]102-mr. perry been [here]3113-here this morning?—And how does [he]102-mr. perry travel now?—Has [he]102-mr. perry set up [[his]102-mr. perry carriage]3651-his carriage ? ” [Emma]79-emma soon recollected , and understood [him]98-frank churchill ; and while [she]79-emma joined in the laugh , it was evident from [Jane]142-miss fairfax ’s countenance that [she]142-miss fairfax too was really hearing [him]98-frank churchill , though trying to seem deaf . “[102-mr. perry] Such an extraordinary dream of [mine]0-i ! ” [he]98-frank churchill cried . “[0-i] [I]0-i can never think of it without laughing.—She hears [us]3103-us , [she]3104-her hears [us]3103-us , [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield . [I]0-i see it in [her]3104-her cheek , [her]3104-her smile , [her]3104-her vain attempt to frown . Look at [her]3104-her . Do not [you]90-hartfield see that , at this instant , the very passage of [her]3104-her own letter , which sent [me]0-i the report , is passing under [her]3104-her eye — that the whole blunder is spread before [her]3104-her — that [she]3104-her can attend to nothing else , though pretending to listen to [the others]3512-the others ? ” [Jane]142-miss fairfax was forced to smile completely , for a moment ; and the smile partly remained as [she]142-miss fairfax turned towards [him]0-i , and said in a conscious , low , yet steady voice , “[0-i] How [you]0-i can bear such recollections , is astonishing to me!—They will sometimes obtrude — but how [you]0-i can court [them]3106-them ! ” [He]0-i had a great deal to say in return , and very entertainingly ; but [Emma]79-emma ’s feelings were chiefly with [Jane]142-miss fairfax , in the argument ; and on leaving [Randalls]97-randalls , and falling naturally into a comparison of [the two men]5631-the two men , [she]79-emma felt , that pleased as [she]79-emma had been to see [Frank Churchill]98-frank churchill , and really regarding [him]0-i as [she]79-emma did with friendship , [she]79-emma had never been more sensible of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley ’s high superiority of character . The happiness of this most happy day , received its completion , in the animated contemplation of [his]0-i worth which this comparison produced . CHAPTER XIX If [Emma]79-emma had still , at intervals , an anxious feeling for [Harriet]107-harriet , a momentary doubt of its being possible for [her]79-emma to be really cured of [her]79-emma attachment to [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , and really able to accept [another man]1273-another man from unbiased inclination , it was not long that [she]79-emma had to suffer from the recurrence of any such uncertainty . A very few days brought the party from [London]1-london , and [she]79-emma had no sooner an opportunity of being one hour alone with [Harriet]107-harriet , than [she]79-emma became perfectly satisfied — unaccountable as it was!—that [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin had thoroughly supplanted [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley , and was now forming all [her]79-emma views of happiness . [Harriet]107-harriet was a little distressed — did look a little foolish at first : but having once owned that [she]107-harriet had been presumptuous and silly , and self - deceived , before , [her]107-harriet pain and confusion seemed to die away with the words , and leave [her]107-harriet without a care for the past , and with the fullest exultation in the present and future ; for , as to [[her]79-emma friend]417-her friend ’s approbation , [Emma]79-emma had instantly removed every fear of that nature , by meeting [her]417-her friend with the most unqualified congratulations.—Harriet was most happy to give every particular of the evening at [Astley ’s]78-astley ’s , and the dinner the next day ; [she]79-emma could dwell on it all with the utmost delight . But what did such particulars explain?—The fact was , as [Emma]79-emma could now acknowledge , that [Harriet]107-harriet had always liked [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin ; and that [his]112-mr. martin continuing to love [her]107-harriet had been irresistible.—Beyond this , it must ever be unintelligible to [Emma]79-emma . The event , however , was most joyful ; and every day was giving [her]79-emma fresh reason for thinking so.—Harriet ’s parentage became known . [She]79-emma proved to be [the daughter of [a tradesman]5635-a tradesman]5634-the daughter of a tradesman , rich enough to afford [her]79-emma the comfortable maintenance which had ever been [hers]79-emma , and decent enough to have always wished for concealment.—Such was the blood of gentility which [Emma]79-emma had formerly been so ready to vouch for!—It was likely to be as untainted , perhaps , as the blood of [many a gentleman]5636-many a gentleman : but what a connexion had [she]79-emma been preparing for [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley — or for [the Churchills]96-the churchills — or even for [Mr. Elton!—The]388-mr. elton!—the [stain of illegitimacy , unbleached by nobility]5637-stain of illegitimacy , unbleached by nobility or wealth , would have been a stain indeed . No objection was raised on [the father]1634-the father ’s side ; [the young man]3228-the young man was treated liberally ; it was all as it should be : and as [Emma]79-emma became acquainted with [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin , who was now introduced at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , [she]79-emma fully acknowledged in [him]112-mr. martin all the appearance of sense and worth which could bid fairest for [[her]79-emma little friend]3440-her little friend . [She]79-emma had no doubt of [Harriet]107-harriet ’s happiness with [any good - tempered man]5641-any good - tempered man ; but with [him]112-mr. martin , and in [the home]5642-the home [he]112-mr. martin offered , there would be the hope of more , of security , stability , and improvement . [She]107-harriet would be placed in the midst of [those who loved [her]107-harriet , and who had better sense than [herself]107-harriet]5643-those who loved her , and who had better sense than herself ; retired enough for safety , and occupied enough for cheerfulness . [She]107-harriet would be never led into temptation , nor left for it to find [her]107-harriet out . [She]107-harriet would be respectable and happy ; and [Emma]79-emma admitted [her]107-harriet to be [the luckiest creature in [the world]392-the world]5644-the luckiest creature in the world , to have created so steady and persevering an affection in [such a man;—or]5646-such a man;—or , if not quite the luckiest , to yield only to [herself]107-harriet . [Harriet]107-harriet , necessarily drawn away by [her]107-harriet engagements with [the Martins]110-the martins , was less and less at [Hartfield]90-hartfield ; which was not to be regretted.—The intimacy between [her]107-harriet and [Emma]79-emma must sink ; [their]5647-they friendship must change into a calmer sort of goodwill ; and , fortunately , what ought to be , and must be , seemed already beginning , and in the most gradual , natural manner . Before the end of September , [Emma]79-emma attended [Harriet]107-harriet to [church]3288-church , and saw [her]79-emma hand bestowed on [Robert Martin]112-mr. martin with so complete a satisfaction , as no remembrances , even connected with [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton as [he]91-mr. elton stood before [them]5647-they , could impair.—Perhaps , indeed , at that time [she]79-emma scarcely saw [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton , but as [the clergyman whose blessing at the altar]5649-the clergyman whose blessing at the altar might next fall on herself.—Robert [Martin]112-mr. martin and [Harriet Smith]107-harriet , [the latest couple engaged of [the three]5651-the three]5650-the latest couple engaged of the three , were [the first to be married]5652-the first to be married . [Jane Fairfax]142-miss fairfax had already quitted [Highbury]3-highbury , and was restored to the comforts of [[her]142-miss fairfax beloved home]5653-her beloved home with [the Campbells.—The Mr. Churchills]96-the churchills were also in [town]3165-town ; and [they]5647-they were only waiting for November . The intermediate month was the one fixed on , as far as [they]5647-they dared , by [Emma]79-emma and [Mr. Knightley.—They]389-mr. knightley.—they had determined that [their]5647-they marriage ought to be concluded while [John]88-mr. knightley and [Isabella]83-isabella were still at [Hartfield]90-hartfield , to allow [them]5647-they the fortnight ’s absence in a tour to [the seaside]5655-the seaside , which was the plan.—John and [Isabella]83-isabella , and [every other friend]5656-every other friend , were agreed in approving it . But [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse — how was [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse to be induced to consent?—he , who had never yet alluded to [their]5647-they marriage but as a distant event . When first sounded on the subject , [he]81-mr. woodhouse was so miserable , that [they]5647-they were almost hopeless.—A second allusion , indeed , gave less pain.—He began to think it was to be , and that [he]81-mr. woodhouse could not prevent it — a very promising step of the mind on its way to resignation . Still , however , [he]81-mr. woodhouse was not happy . Nay , [he]81-mr. woodhouse appeared so much otherwise , that [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter ’s courage failed . [She]3129-his daughter could not bear to see [him]81-mr. woodhouse suffering , to know [him]81-mr. woodhouse fancying [himself]81-mr. woodhouse neglected ; and though [her]3129-his daughter understanding almost acquiesced in the assurance of both [the Mr. Knightleys]141-the mr. knightleys , that when once the event were over , [his]81-mr. woodhouse distress would be soon over too , [she]3129-his daughter hesitated — [she]3129-his daughter could not proceed . In this state of suspense [they]5647-they were befriended , not by any sudden illumination of [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s mind , or any wonderful change of [his]81-mr. woodhouse nervous system , but by the operation of the same system in another way.—Mrs . [[Weston]82-mr. weston ’s [poultry - house]5659-poultry - house]5658-weston ’s poultry - house was robbed one night of all [her]3129-his daughter turkeys — evidently by the ingenuity of [man]3454-man . [Other poultry - yards in [the neighbourhood]1737-the neighbourhood]5661-other poultry - yards in the neighbourhood also suffered.—Pilfering was housebreaking to [Mr. Woodhouse]81-mr. woodhouse ’s fears.—He was very uneasy ; and but for the sense of [[his]81-mr. woodhouse son - in - law]3703-his son - in - law ’s protection , would have been under wretched alarm every night of [his]81-mr. woodhouse life . The strength , resolution , and presence of mind of [the Mr. Knightleys]141-the mr. knightleys , commanded [his]81-mr. woodhouse fullest dependence . While either of [them]5647-they protected [him]81-mr. woodhouse and [his]81-mr. woodhouse , [Hartfield]90-hartfield was safe.—But [Mr. John Knightley]88-mr. knightley must be in [London]1-london again by the end of the first week in November . The result of this distress was , that , with a much more voluntary , cheerful consent than [[his]81-mr. woodhouse daughter]3129-his daughter had ever presumed to hope for at the moment , [she]3129-his daughter was able to fix [her]3129-his daughter wedding - day — and [Mr. Elton]91-mr. elton was called on , within a month from the marriage of [Mr.]5665-mr. and [Mrs. Robert Martin]111-mrs. martin , to join the hands of [Mr. Knightley]88-mr. knightley and [Miss Woodhouse]90-hartfield . The wedding was very much like other weddings , where [the parties]1625-the parties have no taste for finery or parade ; and [Mrs. Elton]195-mrs. elton , from the particulars detailed by [[her]195-mrs. elton husband]431-her husband , thought it all extremely shabby , and very inferior to [her]195-mrs. elton own.—“Very[3107-a most pitiful business!—selina] little white satin , very few lace veils ; [a most pitiful business!—Selina]3107-a most pitiful business!—selina would stare when [she]3107-a most pitiful business!—selina heard of it . ”—But , in spite of these deficiencies , the wishes , the hopes , the confidence , the predictions of [the small band of [true friends who witnessed the ceremony]3109-true friends who witnessed the ceremony]3108-the small band of true friends who witnessed the ceremony , were fully answered in the perfect happiness of the union .
